This is the sort of poetry anthology that could persuade intelligent general readers that they really do like poetry, after all.

Kathi Wolfe's "The Green Light" is one of those little books of poetry that contains multitudes of wit, poignancy and insight. In just 26 pages, Wolfe tells the story of a mid-20th-century American family: father Stan, mother Rita, daughter Kate, son Josh. Even Sparky the Dog gets a poem. The poem "Cheesesteak at Pat's" tells vividly of the bigotry faced by couples of that time who married outside their faiths:Love and marriage go together like a horse and carriagebut not for a Jew and gentile, everyone said,your children would be mongrels. What would Godwant with them?Other poems deal with Rita's diabetes, at a time when medical treatments for the disease were much less effective than they are now. In "The Twist," Rita is on the dance floor, imagining she "grinds her diabetes/to a pulp/just like she did last summer,/and bumps death/right/off/the Billboard charts." As for Kate, who is born blind, she expresses her rebellion in "Blind Ambition:" "I don't want to be/any Goody-Two-Shoes Helen./I want to baptize/my new sneakers/in the mud."Richly detailed and deeply humane, Wolfe's poems bring the family and the era to vibrant life. "The Green Light" is as thrilling in its storytelling as any fiction. I can't see why any intelligent general reader--even one who claims not to like poetry--wouldn't think this is a fine book.

Philipp Meyer's "The Son" is one of those books that comes out of nowhere to bowl you over with its brilliance. Taking as its epigraph a quote from Gibbon's "Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire," Meyer tells the breathtakingly sweeping story of the rise, decline and fall of the McCulloughs, a Texas ranching and oil family. That capsule description undoubtedly will make you think of "Dallas," but comparing "Dallas" with "The Son" is like comparing "Married...With Children" with "King Lear."Meyer's story, sprawling over 160 years of American history, is told through the lives of three main characters in 72 brief, alternating chapters. The main characters are Eli McCullough, patriarch of the family, who spent his youth as a captive of the Comanches; Peter McCullough, Eli's intellectual son, who rebels against his father's kill-or-be-killed view of the world; and Jeanne Anne McCullough, who finds herself trapped as a modern-day woman in upholding the traditions of a violent, sexist frontier society. A fourth character--whose identity must be withheld here--steps forward toward the end to tell his story and bring the novel to its tragic conclusion.The advance publicity compares Meyer with Larry McMurtry and Cormac McCarthy. Both comparisons are apt: he has both McCarthy's violent imagery and grim fatalism, and McMurtry's narrative sweep and richly imagined characters. Meyer's style is every bit as distinguished as McCarthy's or McMurtry's, and his attention to period detail is meticulous and persuasive. One of the book's best chapters is Eli's brief description of the different uses the Comanche made of a killed buffalo. As Eli tells it, they used every part except one. The one part they did not use, and the reason why they did not use it, adds a poignant, ironic sting to the end of the chapter."The Son" is a book filled with poignancy and irony, as well as excitement and gore. It makes the point that all the greatest books have made: our characters, our places, and our times equal our destiny. This is a novel that shows every sign of becoming a classic.

"How Green Was My Valley" is famous as the film that beat "Citizen Kane" for the 1941 Best Picture Oscar. That has dampened the film's reputation, undeservedly. "How Green Was My Valley" is one of Ford's greatest achievements--equal to "The Grapes of Wrath" or "The Quiet Man"--and, as the "Making Of" documentary of this DVD tell us, it was Ford's personal favorite of all his films."Citizen Kane" is the more daring and innovative film, but "How Green Was My Valley" has the greater emotional impact. It's a great example of old-fashioned Hollywood filmmaking at its very best. Ford, working with screenwriter Philip Dunne from Richard Llewellyn's book, created a film that combines rollicking humor and tearjerking tragedy with remarkable seamlessness. The actors--from the veterans Donald Crisp, Barry Fitzgerald and Sara Allgood to 13-year-old Roddy McDowall, making his film debut--could not be better. The black-and-white photography by Arthur Miller is breathtakingly beautiful, most notably in two scenes: the scene in the meadow in which Walter Pidgeon encourages McDowall to walk again after a terrible illness, and the hellish subterranean scene of the flooded, caved-in mine at the end.The "Making Of" documentary contains a lot of fascinating information about the fraught but fruitful relationship between Ford and Darryl F. Zanuck, two hard-headed control freaks who understood each other very well. It also contains an illuminating quote from Peter Bogdanovich, who was friends with both Welles and Ford. "Citizen Kane," he said, is a movie from the head, whereas "How Green Was My Valley" is a movie from the heart. In the end, the only conceivable objection to awarding a Best Picture Oscar to "How Green Was My Valley" is that the prize did not go to "Citizen Kane." Which movie should have won? That's a matter of opinion.

Caroline Bottaro's "Queen to Play" is a charming, inspiring film about confounding the world's expectations and getting a second chance in life. Helene (Sandrine Bonnaire) is a cleaning woman on the island of Corsica, living a quiet, contented life with her boat-painter husband and teenage daughter. Then, one day, she sees an elegant couple playing chess at the hotel where she works, and something deep inside her clicks. Although she has never played chess before, she suddenly becomes obsessed with the game, playing an electronic chessboard far into the night. She even asks Professor Kroger (Kevin Kline), the curmudgeonly academic whose house she cleans for extra money, to pay her with chess lessons instead."Queen to Play" reminded me of the original Japanese version of "Shall We Dance?," about a Japanese salary man whose life is transformed by ballroom dancing. In both movies, just one glance is enough to change a life completely, and for the better. In the making-of featurette on this DVD, Bottaro describes Helene's story as one of class conflict; that is certainly plain when the president of the chess club whose tournament Helene tries to enter suggests that she clean his house instead. But it could just as easily be seen as a woman's struggle in a male-dominated world. When Helene starts spending more time with Professor Kroger and her demeanor changes at work, everyone--including Helene's husband--comes to the usual, and dreary, conclusion."Queen to Play" is a touching story about the flowering of an intellect and the empowerment of a working-class woman who leaps over society's expectations to fulfill her dreams. Kevin Kline is persuasively ursine as the professor, and the rest of the cast is fine, but it is Bonnaire who dominates the movie with a moving performance as a woman discovering resources within herself that she didn't even know she had.Graced with jaw-droppingly gorgeous photography of the Corsican coastline, "Queen to Play" is a must-see.

The exquisitely phrased poems of Bernadette Geyer's "The Scabbard of Her Throat" capture the subtle mystery of human existence. Throughout the book--most clearly in the "Thumbelina's Mother" poems and the final poem, "Advice to My Daughter Regarding Houses in the Woods"--Geyer evokes the disturbing, wood-scented depths of Andersen and the Brothers Grimm, intimating that those macabre forests encroach more on our daily lives than we suppose. Geyer's poems contain a vibrant synecdoche, with small things touching a larger thing as Frost said. "Oyster Shells," a shocking meditation on the murder of Hypatia, begins with a remarkable stanza: "The oyster knows how to keep/a secret, parting its lips/only when boiled alive." Throughout the book there are lines that take our breath away with a few well-chosen words. "Asthma Attack" begins, "The bird in my throat/will not be still." "Without Warning" contains the stanza, "They don't mention how quickly/a storm can gather and cross the bay/in the rushed flight of wings and sails." Geyer is a close observer of the natural world, all the better to present her observations on love, motherhood, and seizing the day. She is a meticulous, abundantly talented poet, and those who read "The Scabbard of Her Throat" will cherish her work.

Lonely Planet's 40th-anniversary edition of its guide to England, as it promises, covers the Scepter'd Isle from Land's End to Lindisfarne. While of necessity--even at nearly 850 pages--it can't provide exhaustive detail on everything it covers, it does give us entertaining and informative snapshots of a wide range of English landmarks and attractions. Of course the most space (about 100 pages) is devoted to London, but there are substantial sections on every region in England, with special attention devoted to major cities and popular tourist areas.Readers look to Lonely Planet to provide the quirky details other guides don't bother with. In its guide to England--the land that invented quirkiness--it certainly doesn't disappoint. The Dinosaurland Fossil Museum in Lyme Regis? The annual Cheese Rolling at Cooper's Hill in the Cotswolds? Ezekial Bone's Robin Hood Tours in Nottingham? They're all there, and much, much more. The lovely thing about the Lonely Planet guides is that they whet your appetite to visit even the places most tourists would never think of going. For example, the guide's authors make a special plea for Bristol as "one of Britain's quirkiest and coolest cities...reinvent(ing) itself over the past decade as a hub of culture and creativity." Even with a town like Hull--which the guide admits is "a curmudgeonly British seaport"--the authors provide an overriding reason to visit: the Larkin Trail, a self-guided tour past significant landmarks in the life of Hull's most famous son, the poet Philip Larkin. (Not surprisingly, considering Larkin's life, the landmarks include a goodly number of pubs.Lonely Planet's England guide is an excellent trip planner. Even more, however, it is a wish book, revealing all the charming places we tourists would visit if we only had the time. It helps us travel in our imaginations, as much as in reality.

Derek Cianfrance's "The Place Beyond the Pines" is a hard film to review. I can't help but feel that too many reviewers, both on Amazon and elsewhere, have told too much of the story. This is what I knew going to see the movie: that it starred Ryan Gosling and Bradley Cooper as antagonistic characters on opposite sides of the law, and that the story took place over a number of years (15, to be exact). I'm glad I didn't know anything more than that, because the surprises Cianfrance had in store for me took my breath away.You already know the story in detail if you've read any other reviews, but here is what I feel safe in telling you:1. Gosling, as a daredevil motorcyclist turned bank robber, dominates the first half of "The Place Beyond the Pines."2. Cooper, as a cop turned district attorney, is the main character of the second half, though there are also important plot twists involving Emory Cohen, as Cooper's son, and Dane DeHaan, as Gosling's.3. All four aforementioned actors are wonderful, as are Eva Mendes, as the love of Gosling's life; Ben Mendelsohn, as Gosling's partner in crime; Ray Liotta, as Cooper's corrupt superior in the police department; Rose Byrne, as Cooper's wife; and Harris Yulin, as Cooper's politically savvy father.4. Despite the sprawling structure of "The Place Beyond the Pines," Cianfrance's direction keeps us on the edge of our seats for most of its 140-minute running time. He is helped immeasurably by cinematographer Sean Bobbitt and editors Jim Helton and Ron Patane. The opening sequence, showing a heavily tattooed Gosling swaggering his way through a carnival crowd, is a wow, as is a chase scene in the middle of the movie between Gosling and Cooper.5. "The Place Beyond the Pines" reminds me of some of the great old TV miniseries, such as "Rich Man, Poor Man" and "Captains and the Kings." The thrust of its story, however, is as old as the Bible, with the fathers eating sour grapes and the sons' teeth being set on edge. "The Place Beyond the Pines" is messy in its structure, and not every loose end gets tied. But it is powerful and moving, and I think its reputation will grow with the years.

Woody Allen's "You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger" simmers entertainingly for a while, thanks largely to a gifted cast, but it never comes amywhere near a boil. This is because the characters are neither interesting nor likable. Gemma Jones, as a flighty, severely depressed woman who finds solace in the occult, comes closest to gaining our sympathy; her scenes with a fortune teller played by Pauline Collins are the best in the movie. As a big fan of "The Duchess of Duke Street," I'm delighted to see Jones in such a prominent part.However, everyone else is boring--even the great Anthony Hopkins, because his character is the same dull beige as all the other characters. "Vicky Cristina Barcelona" had a similar problem, only "You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger" doesn't have Penelope Cruz or the scenery of Barcelona to compensate us. There is a beguiling plot twist involving Josh Brolin, as a failed novelist, and his friend's unpublished manuscript, and it's mordantly amusing how Allen keeps that plot angle dangling over Brolin's head, like the sword of Damocles. However, that story line and Gemma Jones' performance aren't enough to make the movie satisfying in the end. I don't mind that the various storylines are inconclusive, but I DO mind that I didn't really care how or if they concluded. "You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger" is just another of a string of movies Allen has been making recently, about coddled, privileged people who are vaguely yet permanently dissatisfied with their lives.

Anyone who has read Christopher Conlon's previous work--such as his novels, "Midnight on Mourn Street" and "A Matrix of Angels," and his books of poetry including "Mary Falls" and "Gilbert and Garbo in Love"--knows he is a masterful storyteller with a finely honed sense of the macabre. "Herding Ravens: Bon-Bons and Cold Cuts" is a delightfully creepy collection of Conlon's short-short stories, some no longer than a single page. "A bon-bon," Conlon tells us in the flash fiction that serves as an introduction, "is a very short tale of fantasy with no rules or logic, or with dream logic, or the logic of the grave." The twenty-six stories in "Herding Ravens" live up to that description.Conlon's hero Edgar Allan Poe is invoked in "The Raven 2" and is actually a character in the final story, aptly named "The End." But the stories mark Conlon as a scholar of horror and thriller fiction. Throughout the book, you will hear echoes of H.P. Lovecraft, Shirley Jackson, Cornell Woolrich, Patricia Highsmith, all blended together in a witty, ironic manner that is Conlon's own. My favorite story in the collection is the saddest and most elegiac--"Wild Radish," a story of a very old man, the last representative of his civilization. Other winners include "I, Ringo," an alternative history of the Fab Four; "A Cup of Coffee," which in a just world would have been filmed by Alfred Hitchcock; "Say Cheese," which will give you pause the next time someone takes your picture; and "How to Live if Not Why," a bracing variation on "The Devil's Dictionary." ("Since living with air conditioning is basically living in a refrigerator, use air conditioning liberally. This is good practice for when you'll be in the morgue.") But there isn't a dud in the bunch, and it's likely your favorites will be entirely different from mine. In any case, "Herding Ravens" is a wonderful choice for readers who love a good scare before bedtime.

The most brilliant scene in Kenneth Branagh's "As You Like It" is Kevin Kline, as Jaques, delivering a golden-throated version of the "Seven Ages of Man" soliloquy as Branagh's camera swirls around him. The entire cast is excellent: Bryce Dallas Howard is a radiant Rosalind, and Brian Blessed is majestic--no other word will do--in his dual role as the deposed and usurper Dukes. The photography, by Roger Lanser, is exquisite, capturing enchanting scenes of bucolic beauty. Yet for all its excellent parts, Branagh's "As You Like It" feels slightly off. He gives us no good reason why he sets the play in a late-19th-century European enclave in Japan; except for staging the wrestling match between Orlando and Charles as a sumo bout, the mix of English and Japanese costumes and customs is unpersuasive. Of course, Japan is beautiful--but so is England, where the film was actually shot, and where of course the play was originally set."As You Like It" contains nothing as jarring as Keanu Reeves' off-key performance in Branagh's version of "Much Ado About Nothing." But neither does it have the magical cohesiveness of the earlier film, and without that "As You Like It" is just a collection of eccentric scenes, albeit interspered with some of the most soaring poetry in the English language. For its pictorial beauty and the excellence of its cast, however, I give Branagh's "As You Like It" four stars out of five.

Vivienne Sosnowski's "When the Rivers Ran Red" is a decently written, decently presented history of the Napa and Sonoma Wine Country during Prohibition. Her tales of the venality and stupidity of government agents, and the sheer injustice that grape growers faced, will make your blood boil. We can only be happy that Prohibition, an unjust law pushed down America's throats by fanatics, is a distant if unpleasant memory.

This Premium Stainless Steel Zester with Safety Gaurd for Cheese, Lemons, Limes, Chocolate and Spicesby Kozy Kitchen Works is the first MicroPlane I have had. So I am learning so many ways to use it, Here are some1) Zesting citrus â This Microplane makes zesting effortless.2) Shaving Parmesan or other hard cheeses â It makes it easy to grate right onto your plate of spaghetti. I have even used it for less-hard cheeses, like cheddar.3) Grating ginger â Pro-tip: You don't really need to peel ginger; just scrub it well. Then store it in the freezer to make grating even easier. It will stay fresh and grate nicely without getting all juicy.4) Mincing garlic â I love how fast and easy it is to grate a clove of garlic straight into the frying pan.5) Shaving chocolate â A fancy garnish for cake or ice cream.6) Grating whole nutmeg, cinnamon â A quick way to grind your own spices for a fresher taste.7) Mincing onion â Sometimes you don't want chunks of onion, and while using a microplane can get a little juicy here, it's great for meatballs, tacos or dip where you want the onion to blend right in.8) Grating dried mushrooms â Ever thought to use dried mushroom powder as a seasoning? Me neither, but this article from the Washington Post teaches you how. http://voices.washingtonpost.com/all-we-can-eat/i-spice/i-spice-mushroom-powder.html Sounds great on steak, right?9) Mincing hot peppers â For the same reason you may not want chunks of chopped onion in a dish.10) Grating nuts â Another nice garnish for desserts or even oatmeal. While many books on the topic of depression tend to focus on one particular aspect of the complex issue, Mark has done an excellent job of offering up a balanced book that manages to relate to readers with personal anecdotes and encouragement while at the same time offering up intensely practical advice and logical explanations based on a scriptural worldview.Throughout the book, you will find numerous references to personal experiences, scripture, historical examples, parables, current events, and studies that help to back up the advice and explanations. Those conclusions are organized into easy-to-read bulleted lists and action points. I REALLY like the "Take-Home Tidbits" at the end of each chapter with the key statements! They help to provide extra clarity with complicated topics.For such a heavy topic, the book is easy to read and flows well. I can't emphasize enough how the authors own experiences sprinkled throughout the book give it such a personable feel.This book is highly recommended!I purchased the kindle version and found it to be well formatted and easy to flip back and forth to various chapters.

2:00 MinsI purchased this bottle locally here in Kathmandu and have used it extensively over the last month. While there are features to like with this unit, I couldn't rely on it and it is sitting on a shelf somewhere.This is only the second powerpack that I have owned. The other unit is slightly bulkier and was purchased ~3years ago. I was looking forward to seeing how things have advanced since that point and letting my wife keep this in her purse.When I received the unit it was empty and needed charged. The charging didn't take too long, but when I plugged in my phone for charging, it charged extremely slowly. I switched to the cable that I always use, but it didn't help. After some time, I came back and found that the battery pack had switched off on it's own after charging only 1% of my phone battery(Oneplus One). I didn't have time to keep an eye on it, so I put it away to deal with later.My son was in the hospital this past week and I grabbed this power bank to keep our phones alive during the ordeal. I was expecting slow charging and having to keep an eye on it, but what else did I have to do? It performed even worse than before. I was attempting to charge my OPO and my wife's GS3, but neither got even a single % of charge from the unit.I am glad that this was not the only power bank I brought to the hospital. I switched back to my trusty old NewTrent iCarrier backup battery and had both phones charged in no time.I don't know what the problem was. When plugged in, the phone would indicate that it was charging. The battery pack was freshly charged and the little flashlight LED worked well. Unfortunately, it didn't work for the primary purpose: charging other devicesThis item was sent to me free of charge in return for an honest review.

I have used the more expensive Plantronics Backbeat Go headphones for some time and was interested to see how these less expensive headphones compare. The most obvious difference is the size. The Mpow heaphones are massive and look like they wouldn't even stay in my ears, however after wearing them, I found that, despite their size, retention is not an issue. These will definitely not fit under a motorcycle helmet and will even be uncomfortable under a knit cap that covers the ears.That being said, the battery life on these headphones is significantly better than my smaller plantronics headphones. I don't know if the extra space is dedicated to the battery, but these lasted more than twice as long as the smaller plantronics.The usb charging port cover has a good seal, but is a little difficult to dislodge without longer nails.In the end, these get used every day while around the house, but I would hesitate to wear them out in public, while jogging, riding, etc.These headphones were sent to me free of charge for an honest review.
