You won't waste time reading useless fluff, but he does cover the important stuff. He shows you how to prepare, set up and run the campaign itself, then capitalize on the attention you receive, and more. This book is highly recommended!

From the moment I heard about this book, it intrigued me. I have lived in Nepal for the past four years, traveling primarily by motorcycle. Add that to the fact that I have close family living in China for the past 7 years and I had to read this book.The story is very well told. It is obvious that the Pyle brothers thought about the story-telling aspect of the trip in advance. Obviously, they were preparing for the video documentary(which I haven't seen yet), but they also did a good job of documenting the details of the trip day by day. After a large undertaking like this, it is easy to forget the ups and downs encountered through the experience itself, but having documented the trip well, they were able to share the fears, disappointments, in an emotionally honest way that has the reader wondering about the outcome of the trip even though we already know(from the product description) that they were successful.I appreciated how the authors didn't belittle the cultural differences that were highlighted throughout their trip. Some travel/adventure writers take this opportunity to make the foreign culture look stupid, but the Pyle brothers attempted to explain the rationale behind many of the utterly confusing decisions and actions of the police, proprietors, and other people that they met along the way.I found the book to be the perfect length for this type of story. This is not a long book and it doesn't drag things out, but it isn't so short that you feel cheated either. I am a pretty fast reader and was able to finish the story in two sittings of several hours each.My biggest complaint is actually a rather small one. I was annoyed by the small grammar mistakes throughout. Simple things like "forward and backward" instead of "back and forth". No, they don't confuse readers, but they distract from an otherwise fantastic story. A professional copy-editor could polish this into a 5-star book in no time!If you are are a fan of the travel adventure non-fiction genre and want to hear some interesting and insightful stories about areas of China that few have visited, you will love this book!Full disclosure: I was given a (digital) copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

This book is a great motivator and practical how-to guide for new entrepreneurs that struggle with actually getting started. He focuses on common mistakes in "proving" your business concept or idea. He gives lots of great stories to illustrate his points and show you exactly what is meant.When you finish this book, you have no excuses not to get started!

Beautiful!Nothing like the bright, warm glow of these incandescent bulbs.I am a LED person for everything possible, but for the bathroom fixture we had similar bulbs but they were some off brand. The off brand was frosted and had the logo and name written on it, which was an ugly effect for the fixture which has no cover over the bulbs.I replaced them with these beautiful GE lights and I couldn't be happier.They are bright, but warm and not too bright which I had some reservations about.  They look VERY nice and high end.They are a little bit more expensive, but they are beautiful and we use our bathroom every day so it's worth every penny.

I loved this novel!"Bad Sex" is narrated in first person in quick vignette style which reminded me of Italo Calvo.  Each chapter was almost just a thought, a memory, a quick situation.  We ride along with her, cringing along the way as she makes bad decisions and goes off the rails.There is very little actual sex in the book.  And when it happens, it is so matter of fact, like "we had sex three times."What there is here, is a fantastic story which makes you feel her and can't help to bring to mind the many bad decisions we all make.Beautifully written, lovely novel.

Good quality!  I've gone through a few of these types of lights.  They vary quite a bit in price and quality.  These Bright Eyes are the brightest and best quality of these small lights.  They are the most durable, with fairly thick "rubber band" to hold them in. The lights are much brighter than others- I'm not sure why.Worth the money!

If you can buy only one "old school" hip-hop record on vinyl, this could be the one.Or, if you are like me and consider NWA/Dr.Dre efforts to be "must-owns" you could say"If you can buy only one East Coast "old school" hip-hop record on vinyl, this is the one.What is amazing is although it's true that traditional musical instruments like piano, guitar, and even harmonica gain the most benefit from vinyl, actually hip-hop like this record are also MUCH better on vinyl.  You will hear things you never heard before on your CD or MP3s.Nas "Illmatic" is quite simply the best of the best.

These have been well-reviewed, so let me just add the following:1.  Yes, they can hold double albums easily2.  No, they are not the super-thick "Japanese style" sleeves3.  Yes, they are great quality, perfect basic protection for vinyl4.  Yes, it's quite easy to use all 100 and need to buy another pack if you like music at all- where do these records keep coming from?

Magnificent!Good quality silicone ice cube tray.  This one is more durable than the first one I had from another manufacturer.Once you start using these nice big blocks of ice in your drinks, there is no going back.  For me, it's a perfect cube for a (home pour) of Bourbon in a lowball glass.  The cubes do melt a little tiny bit, but for the most part your drink remains delicious, unmolested by unwanted dilution.

I tried SO hard to wade through this book.  I just COULD NOT do it.  I lasted only 100 pages, I admit with embarrassment.I know this book is on everyone's "greatest books ever" list and I really wanted to like it.  I attempted it, and hated the first 30 pages.I soldiered on.Another 50 pages, I was told, and it gets good.For me, it never got better.  I didn't like the characters.  There was no real plot. The humor was lost on me.Winner of the Pulitzer Prize!The good news is I bought the Kindle version so there were no trees killed in this frustrating process.

There are some good insights here, but there is a lot to wade through to get to them.The pacing and writing style of this book really made it hard for me to slog through it.  You would think the subject matter alone would make for compelling reading.  And at times, it does, especially in the vignettes of erotic encounters that have been sent to the writer.  He approaches the subject in a dry, analytical manner.  This makes sense; he was a professional therapist.  But reading about sexual dysfunction is not entertaining.I got some real gems out of this book that have actually helped my sex life.  But for the most part, this is an overlong, ultimately unsatisfying book that reads almost as dry as a textbook.

Wow this is a great razor.I've become cynical about razors- it seems like each new generation is just another excuse to raise prices, add blades, include batteries- anything in the quest for more and more profit.  These cretins know that we have whiskers that grow EVERY SINGLE DAY.  Many of us have rebelled, choosing to grow beards.I'm no lumberjack, however, and my flirtation with beardedness only lasted a year.So back I am, to razors.  And this one is amazing!  The ball mechanism does indeed make for a better shave because you know what, my head isn't flat like a board!  This thing glides around the curves and gives a tight shave without pain or irritation.I can't believe I'm writing this, but this one is actually worth the money.

Little pieces of magic.  Calvino's stories are short, sometimes sweet, sometimes bitter, sometimes mystical. Brilliant!Calvino's mastery of the short short story format is unparalleled.  He just lures you in with every little tale that he spins.  I think he almost purposely starts the stories out uninteresting at times.  I found myself reading the first page or two of a story thinking "this is boring- I don't even want to read another word."  But literally seconds later I  find myself enthralled with the characters, the story, the ideas.Every single story touches you in a different way.  Some are just funny and silly.  Others are deeply sad.  But they are all lovely.

Life changing little information robot.First, just the basics- what do I use Echo for?1. "Alexa, what's the weather forecast?"2. "Alexa, tell me the news."3. (Lying in bed in the morning) "Alexa, what time is it?"4. "Alexa, what is my schedule like today/tomorrow/this week?"5. (I have Phillips Hue LED lights) "Alexa turn off all the lights."6. "Alexa, turn on the kitchen lights."7. "Alexa, set a 5 minute timer."8.  "Alexa, tell me when it is 8:00."9. "Alexa who starred in XYZ movie?"  (Or any other general fact-finding)10. "Alexa, tell me a joke."Her voice recognition is not perfect, but it gets better every day.Amazon continues to add features and capabilities, such as control of music playlists, Spotify/Pandora, wifi-enabled LED lights, Google calendar, etc.Everyone talks about how robots will be a big thing in the future.  Well, the future is here.  Alexa is an information and home automation robot.  I don't need an expensive robot to do manual things like vacuum my floor.  What makes the most sense is an "information robot" like her, who can harness the power of the internet to give me information.Before you tell me how Siri on the iPhone can do the same thing, let me tell you, it's A LOT more convenient to simply talk to a robot that is always on than to go get your iPhone, unlock it, find the Hue lights app, and turn lights off or on. Same with Siri searches. It's just easier and intuitive to use voice commands to simply tell Alexa to do something.I have no doubt that some form of this information robot will be found in EVERY home over the next few years.  It just makes so much sense- voice control of your home.  Control temperature, play music, set timers, turn on and off lights, all with voice commands.My only complaint is this robot doesn't play all that well with Apple which is Apple's fault.  It's hard to play songs from iTunes or have it tell you your iCloud calendar.  No problem; I've just switched my calendaring to Google instead.The bigger question- why in the world is Amazon innovating so much more than Apple?I want to buy another echo for my office.  When I travel and stay in hotel rooms, it's weird not having Alexa there.

Good idea!This is a good idea- incorporate modern LED technology into a grilling spatula.  Shine light on your dark grill.  Who hasn't wished they had more light on their grill, especially as the sun goes down on those late summer nights?Well, it works.  But the actual object is so clunky and ugly that it looks and feels about as elegant as if a kid had taken a flashlight and rubber-banded it to the handle of a cheap spatula.This object is an example of the things that discourage me about modern life.  The designers don't even take the time or effort to make something that looks and feels nice.  I guess it costs more money to do that.  But it seems like if they would just spend a little effort and cost in the design of the product, then mass produce it in China like always, but this way it's at least a nice thing you are making millions of.Too bad- the extra cost, spread out over so many more units sold, would be more than worth the time.

Gentle indeed.  This is very strange feeling soap.  It has a weird slimy, slippery texture that reminds you of other things. It basically slides right off your hands before you can wash them.  Maybe it's the coconut oil in the soap.  It has fancy packaging to give the impression that it is on par with L'Occitane or other premium soaps.  I don't find it to be nearly the quality of those other soaps.

Dated, but still informative book about Silicon Valley.  The author admits that it will be dated, due to the rapid change that has always been the nature of the Valley.  The book would have held up better if it had been more of a history book with some key locations such as companies, museums, and universities, and less restaurants.  But to be fair, the restaurants are often included due to proximity near a major tech company or when it is frequented by tech luminaries.Overall this is solid book that will be of  interest mainly to real geeks and those interested in silicon valley history. My favorite parts of the book by far are the ones that tell the history of the various tech companies and personalities.The formatting is terrible on the Kindle version of this book due to the sidebars.  It makes it disjointed and hard to follow at times. I constantly felt like I was re-reading what I had read.

Very solid, decent looking rack at a reasonable price.My only criticism, keeping it from being 5 stars, is that the assembly instructions are poorly written.  They consist of a single page of tiny print with a couple of diagrams.  Having said that, it still only took about 30 minutes to assemble, but it was not a fun process.  But luckily, you only have to do this once.My box initially was missing 2 parts, but the people at Nashbar promptly mailed me the missing parts.  Great customer service.So how does the rack work?  It works really well.  I have two bikes on my rack, a fixie and a carbon fiber roadbike.  The rack is easily adjustable so you can get your bikes positioned perfectly, regardless of frame type.The rack is a little bigger than I was expecting, but it is also a lot more stable than I was expecting.  You do NOT need to anchor this to the wall or the floor.  It can easily hold two bikes and still feels fairly stable.  I wouldn't do work on my bikes on this rack, but it is definitely stable for holding the bikes.It looks great with the bikes stacked above each other, raised off the floor.  I have the rack in my loft and really like the way it conveniently displays my bikes.Great product, great customer service.

More durable than the original iPhone part, and better looking (If you like colors).I like this cable a lot better than the original iPhone part.  Even though it's the same price, it is made out of a more durable plastic.  I've seen a lot of the original cables break and get frayed around the tip part that goes into the iPhone.  This one is much stronger and will take a lot more abuse/use.  It is not delicate.I like the purple color because the white ones get dirty gray color with time anyway.

This book is well researched, and the author had great access to Elon Musk. The style is fast paced, yet detailed enough to give some great insight into the man and his companies.  I thoroughly enjoyed it and believe it is a âmust-readâ for anyone investing in Tesla stock or its competitors.I do have a couple of criticisms: first, the part about the Justine Musk divorce was a nearly word for word copy of her blog describing her side of the story.  I was shocked by how similar it was. Also, the last chapter "unified field theory of Elon Musk" seemed to be unnecessary padding, wasting time on other people's opinions on Musk.  It didnât fit into the biography.  Perhaps it was an attempt to ensure that the book doesn't come across as hagiography.Some interesting points about Elon Musk:1. He eats fast2. He has had a challenging life: the loss of an infant, a brutal upbringing in South Africa, pushed out of companies he co-founded, nearly going broke in 2008, divorces3. Late bloomer; he was more ambitious in college than he was in high school4. Extremely hard worker; for the first three months of his first start-up he and his brother literally lived in the office.  He slept on a beanbag next to his desk. Justine said: "Elon would come home at 11 and work some more.  People didn't always get the sacrifice he made in order to be where he was."  His co-investor Gracias said: "He has the ability to work harder and endure more stress than anyone I've ever met.  What he went through in 2008 would have broken anyone else.  He didn't just survive.  He kept working and stayed focused. Most people under that sort of pressure fray, their decisions go bad.  Elon gets hyperrational.  He's still able to make very clear, long-term decisions. The harder it gets, the better he gets. Anyone who saw what he went through firsthand came away with more respect for the guy.  I've just never seen anything like his ability to take pain." Watson at SpaceX said: "I don't want to be the person who ever has to compete with Elon.  You might as well leave the business and find something else fun to do. He will outmaneuver you, outthink you, and out-execute you."5. Very intelligent and self-taught in many fields; he read books about rockets and propulsion to start Space X.  Maniacal attention to detail.6. He doesn't spend time on niceties or "building relationships" other than family or close work colleagues because he is too busy and smart to want to waste time.7. Not afraid to face withering criticism: he faced tremendous resistance on the idea of electric cars and had to invest mostly his own money in the company.8. He nearly went broke in 2008: "he looked like death itself," said Riley.  He would have nightmares and yell out, his weight fluctuated wildly, he had bags under his eyes, and they had to start borrowing money from his friend.  He no longer flew his jet back and forth between LA and Silicon Valley- he took Southwest.Some good quotes:"Where Mark Zuckerberg wants to help you share baby photos, Musk wants to save the human race from self-imposed or accidental annihilation." â the authorMusk: "That's my lesson from taking a vacation: vacations will kill you." after he nearly died from malaria from a trip to Africa."The longer you wait to fire someone the longer it has been since you should have fired them.""I will spend my last dollar on these companies.  If we have to move into Justine's parents' basement, we'll do it."  -Elon MuskThings I took away:â¢ I expected to read the book to be mostly interested in Elon Musk and Tesla and instead the SpaceX portion was the more interesting part.  The amazing effort and persistence in the face of constant set-backs was mind-blowing. He sunk millions of his own money into the company- basically, all of his net worth went into TSLA and SpaceX and he lost all of it by 2008 when the cars weren't selling and the rockets weren't working.  Yet today, both companies are worth billions because he said he would live in his parent-in-laws' basement if that is what it took to succeed.â¢ I didn't realize how close both TSLA and SpaceX were from going broke.  He had to put in his last $12 million cash.â¢ Interesting fact: if you buy a Tesla car, they will give you the option of picking it up in Silicon Valley and touring the factory where it was made.

I LOVE IT!This recipe binder is beautiful, fun and almost perfect.I'm using it to hold not only recipes, but pages of handouts from the various culinary classes I have attended.The binder is customizable, big, nice, and holds cut out recipes perfectly in plastic pages.Yes, even in the age of the internet and googling how to cook things, there is a place for a real life binder to keep cooking ideas and recipes.Great quality; this would even make a nice gift for that budding chef in your life.

Just no.These minis aren't good at all.  They are smaller than the original Starburst, and all you end up with is a sticky mess of them stuck together in a bag.  This feels like some marketing expert with an MBA idea to extend the product line to sell more sugar.They don't have the same great taste in these little mushy squares.  The big, individually wrapped Starburst are much better.I threw away the bag half way through.

Just OK.This is a great idea, but not so great in actual execution.It is easy to set up, but if you are like me, your outlets and router locations are pretty cluttered and full already.  This unit requires additional ethernet cables (not included) and don't seem to work with power strips.  When you plug them in, the block the other outlet so basically take 2 outlets each to work.  I found their size and physical configuration to be unwieldy enough that I couldn't really use them.If you have no other choice and your wifi just won't cover a room in your (big) house, this is a good solution.  For me in a relatively modest space, it didn't really add any value.

Fantastic glasses; good value.Although I have broken countless wine glasses in my lifetime, I still enjoy wine more in half-way decent glasses.  What's worse than enjoying a decent wine and seeing the seam visible on your wine glass?  Someone who reviewed these glasses before me wrote "wine tastes better in Riedel glasses." You know what?  He was right!These white wine glasses are nicely balanced, reasonably priced, and well made.  They are a little on the small side, but then again, it's white wine.Now to see how long they last before I break them...

This watch is almost the perfect watch. If you define a watch as a beautiful, simple object whose form and function are in perfect harmony, this may be the ideal watch.Simple minimalism, yet not stark.  Light weight, but not flimsy. Quartz movement keeps time perfectly.A perfect balance between casual and "dressy," this watch is equally at home on a wrist with a business suit or workout clothes.  It is so versatile that you can wear it with anything and it blends in.  It is also a nice counterbalance to the digital era we live in.The value is extraordinary.  When I wear nice work clothes, I get a lot of compliments on this watch.  People think it is a very expensive watch.  The great thing is it is very inexpensive, so it is also a "low concern" watch, unlike my Rolex which I always feel is delicate and too valuable to wear daily.  This is exactly the watch I would recommend for someone who needs to look decent on job interviews but does not have the funds for an expensive Swiss watch.

Uh oh... addictive!These are some delicious little sugarbombs of delight.  Smooth, creamy, and delightful!Nothing will replace the hand-made caramels of the old county state fair, loaded with salt and butter, but these little beauties come pretty close.Only downside: pretty hard to eat only one of them!

High quality, non-slip gloves.If you are like me, you clean, wash dishes, and do a lot of routine bike and home maintenance.  It's pretty rough on your hands, exposing them to detergents, washing liquids, grease and grime all the time.  I have tried nitrile gloves before and they were always too flimsy and too slippery.These gloves solve both of those problems.  They are very durable and with the textured surface, they actually give you a good grip on things, even when wet.  I have not broken one of these yet, except for taking one pair off after a long cleaning sessions.These can be used to wash dishes with confidence that you will not drop a dish.  They give enough tactile feel for working on bikes and cars.A couple of side benefits: they are somewhat heat resistant, so I find that I can wash dishes with almost steaming water without burning my hands. The orange color is also cool!The only drawback to these gloves is they are so useful that I end up using a pair every day- uses for them will occur to you that you never imagined.

Solid little book, full of adventurous eating, history, and even recipes.Robert Sietsema, in this fast-paced little book shares his encyclopedic knowledge of the New York City eating scene.  What's great about this book is he focuses on eating in all the boroughs, and at the affordable restaurants.  Do we really need another Zagat-style book on the high-end restaurants that you can either not afford to dine in or can't get a reservation at?In each chapter, he picks a different specific food, such as Pizza, Fried Chicken, Pho, or even Pastrami, and tells the history of the food in New York, and discusses the best places to get the food.  The guide is both up to date, and timeless because he shares the history of each specific dish in NYC.Even the most experienced NYC eater will learn new things here.  Even tourists to NYC can use this to learn where to REALLY eat when you arrive in NYC.

Utter and complete A-holes!Not only does the "Premier" software not include basic things such as rental property, but then when you try to finish your taxes, they double charge you for the state download.Deceptive pricing, because this will cost you at least double the price stated by the time you download the rest of the program and you pay twice for the state.And to make things worse, when you call in you get a robot which will talk you in circles for 20 minutes before sending you to a real representative.I was told by the representative that they knew they had a lot of issues with pricing this year and will go back to the way they did things in 2013.I don't know if I can believe them.

Fantastic!I never thought I could get this excited about a simple light bulb.This amazing LED bulb is so well constructed and the light quality is so soft and nice that it is just as good as an incandescent bulb.  Wait- it's even better!  Why?1. LEDs will last 10-20 years.  These lightbulbs will go with me when I move to my next place.2. LEDs use 1/10th the power of old light bulbs.  Good for the environment, and saves wasted dollars going to the utility.3.  This one is so solid and well-built that you don't need to replace them every year.4.  Price is good now- the prices have come down so much that in relation to the energy savings and the longer life, they are actually about 1/10th the cost of a regular bulb.I put these bulbs in my entry way, which has recessed fixtures by the entryway.  It's always hard to replace these bulbs, since I have high ceilings and I have to get a ladder out to change them.  Well, I just changed them for the last time for maybe a decade!The advances in LED bulbs lately is mind-blowing.  These are no longer a weird shape, but look and feel just like a regular bulb- except they are higher quality, since they are built to last for 20 years.

Brilliant, unfiltered, rollercoaster ride with Bourdain.Bourdain follows up Kitchen Confidential with a nice collection of unvarnished observations and opinions about a wide range of topics.His discourse on the importance of EVERYONE learning basic cooking skills may be worth the price of the book itself. "Basic knife skills should be a must. Nothing too serious.  Just enough facility with a knife to be on par with any Sicilian grandmother."  Words of wisdom concerning the merits of attending cooking school and career advice to aspiring chefs is priceless for those so inclined.  Like Michael Douglas, surprised that his Gordon Gekko character inspired a generation of young people to go work on Wall Street, Bourdain marvels that people still want to become a chef despite his blunt talk in Kitchen Confidential.He opines on the sorry state of Food Inc., and the danger of eating hamburgers in this country: "Call me crazy, but I believe that when you're making hamburger for human consumption, you should at no time deem it necessary or desirable to treat its ingredients in ammonia.  Or any cleaning product, for that matter."One of the best parts is his soul-searching after the break-up of his first marriage, and how he struggled as an aspiring writer and slightly burnt-out chef.Bourdain may be more introspective, but make no mistake, he still retains his rapier wit.  He pens an entire chapter to vilify (mediocre yet famous) food critic Alan Richman.  He pulls no punches, entitling the chapter "Alan Richman is a douchebag."Still "uncut" he writes lines like this one, when describing an episode of a cooking contest TV show: "The plate looked like the last shot of a backache video - filmed at Chilis."  This is why I love Bourdain.For me, the absolute climax of the book is the chapter in which he describes the dominican man, Justo, the fish prep chef for Le Bernardin.  Again, if the book had only this chapter, it would be worth the price.  Bourdain again shows his humanity when he takes Justo to eat at Le Bernardin for lunch- the first time the man had ever eaten the food he has spent years prepping for cooking.Must-read!

One of the only "protein bars" that is edible!I am a little picky about these things.  I just can't choke down 99% of the nutrition bars on the market today.  To my palate, they are a combination of waxy fake chocolate filled with sawdust.But these are really different!  They actually taste really good.  I would almost eat them without the health benefits.They are perfect for giving you enough energy when you have to "stretch" your meals.  They give me enough energy to make it from lunch through a workout, to a late dinner.They also digest really well and you don't get that bloated feeling after you eat them.Really good stuff.

High quality product, like most things Neutrogena.Reasonably strong scrub, which I found to be a bit "gritty" for my tastes.  This product seems to be better for someone with fairly oily skin.Fairly powerful exfoliation, with a mild fragrance.Priced appropriately for the quality.I prefer a competitive brand, which is more expensive.

Beautiful, functional.Why didn't they think of this years ago?  For those of us visual people, enraptured by color, these measuring cups are a joy.  They make it easy to reach for the exact right cup right away.  Color and size, matched up!Good quality, beautiful functional objects.  Why doesn't every company make things with care, like this?

Waste of money.This is simply L-Argine with caffeine.How much caffeine?  In the recommended dose, it is 300 mg of caffeine.So when they boast on the label that taking these pills before your workout will enable you to do "insane" rips, maybe they mean manic, caffeine boosted activity.That's no problem- if that's what you're looking for.  Just buy these instead of Red Bull.But muscle supplements?  I'm not so sure.

Excellent, artisanal, well-crafted chocolates.So here's the idea:  Scharffenberger, a wino producer, meets Sternberg, who has apprenticed in chocolate-making in Europe.  Scharffenberger teams up with him to produce artisanal chocolates in the U.S.So this little bucket is full of 55 chocolate squares of 4 different types, with the idea that you pair them with wines and do a "tasting" like a wine and chocolate flight.I only paired with a couple of wines, but I of course tried all of the chocolates.  They are excellent!  These are among the best chocolates I've ever tasted, and I eat more chocolate than half the lovers in France!The four different types are all spectacular; Extra Rich Milk, Semisweet, Bittersweet, and Extra Dark.I liked them all equally for different reasons.  They are in nice small tasting size squares which are perfect for blasting your senses with flavor yet not filling you up.

What a cute little ebook cover!  This Hello Kitty cover is a high quality, "kawaii" little cover for Kindles. Designed for Paperwhites, it actually also works for my Voyager (although the on/off switch is on the back so I have to take it out for it to turn on).This is not just a cheap plastic case but instead has a nicely textured, high quality fabric and materials. Her bow is sewn on fabric.This is really nice!

Beautiful, lyrical, touching.I could not put this novel down once I started it.  It is so beautiful and pristine and simple.  Haruf's minimalist style is a joy to read; he removes all distractions and cuts right to the heart of the matter.  The story is of small-town Colorado, but the truths are universal.  Emotional, yet not saccharine.  Detailed, yet sparse.  Parallels between the hardscrabble life on the Colorado plains among the cattle and small-town human creatures.  Lovely.  Piercing.One of the best American novels of the last 50 years.

Brilliant, soothing New Age album.  This music is perfect for concentration at work, when studying or doing difficult analysis.  Grab a cup of green tea and put this on and your mood will change.None of the saccharine, elevator-music tinged new age here; this is really great music.

Important, moving, fascinating.Since "The Bell Jar" has a monumental, if controversial reputation I set out to read it.  Fortunately I am a persistent person, because I was able to wade through the first 60 pages of minutiae including a few pages discussing how she got sick on crab meat at a dinner in New York City.  Perhaps there was some deep metaphor or she was instead just writing the banality of her life to set the tempo for her eventual disintegration into madness.When she finally descends into "The Bell Jar" of lunacy is when the writing soars.  Amazingly well done, with sparse writing and brilliant passages of truth, this book thrilled me.I have never read a book in which my opinion of it changed so greatly as I read it.  What a skill this writer had, before she herself succumbed to madness.A must read.

This a fascinating book. It is exactly what the title says: Brooklyn then and now.  As you open the book and lay it flat, on the left side is Brooklyn then, and on the right side is almost the exactly same angle, but what it looks like now.  Full of interesting captions that carry a lot of historical detail, this book makes for enjoyable study.  Neighborhood by neighborhood, they author compares the past with the present.The book is about 12 years old and what makes it doubly interesting is how much parts of Brooklyn, such as Williamsburg have changed even since publication of the book!  It is also interesting how much MORE leafy and tree-lined Brooklyn is today than it was 50-100 years ago.  The early photos of the bridges are probably the most spell-binding.  Of course, it is also amazing to see the very same buildings still in existence from 100 years ago, but in even better condition today.What a great book!

Irvine Welsh doing what he does best: making despicable actions by unsavory characters fascinating and likable.This fast-paced novel is written from a variety of viewpoints.  It centers on Lucy Brennan, shallow, manic personal fitness trainer in Miami Beach, and her fitness client muse, artist Lena Sorenson.  He threads their stories through the third main character: South Beach.  He skewers the shallow Miami culture, the art world, and even U.S. culture as a whole in this entertaining novel.As fun as it is to read, I felt like it needed a bit of editing.  Some motifs that ran throughout the book didn't quite have enough gravity and felt gimmicky.  Welsh does not seem to care about "economy of character" because the central opening event of the story doesn't even factor into the book later, which was a bit disorienting.This is no "Trainspotting" but it is an entertaining read, perhaps on your way to Art Basel in Miami.

What a beautiful volume this is!  Great artistry here, held together by a flimsy but fun story.  Magic and technology do battle as impossibly beautiful young people fight the evil powers that be.  Lead character Grace is the stunningly sexy and beautiful magical creature with dragonfly wings.  Her male counterpart is on his epic journey, straight out of the fantasy quest formula, but told in a very fun way.For me the story at times was a bit formulaic and slow, but the illustrations made up for it.Extras included in this TP are story development notes, some scripting, and best of all, several pages of alternate covers.  These covers are all pin-up style art by a variety of artists, showcasing the lovely Grace and occasionally a minor character or two.A delicious, light confection, as light as cotton candy.

Decent quality product but the packaging is low-quality.  The ziplock back doesn't stay shut well and the package ends up getting all sticky from the sugary powder.  For an expensive product like this I expect a better quality package.Otherwise, the product itself tastes good and sort of "works" in keeping you hydrated.  It wasn't noticeably better than Gatorade or other sport drinks in my opinion.

Haunting, deeply moving book.This lovely, meandering epic coming of age story concerns Astrid and her mother Ingrid, who has been imprisoned for murder.  Astrid goes through a handful of foster homes and all of the dysfunction that it entails.At times this book is moving, at other times shocking, it ultimately attempts to answer the question: why and how do mothers and daughters relate to each other?  The depth of the writing is amazing for a "first" novel (Janet Fitch had actually been writing for at least a decade before this book was published).The only part I found a bit distracting was Astrid, the narrator's habit of needing to make even mundane details sound poetic.  I suppose it was done for effect, to show the way she thinks, but it was at times tiresome.  Of course, at other times, it was lyrical and beautiful and the prose soared.The subject matter can be shocking, as it includes explicit sexual descriptions, drug use and violence.  it is never gratuitous, however, as it is intended to be an accurate portrayal of foster home life.There are many, many messages here, as Fitch is ambitious and covers a lot of themes- loneliness, sex, mothers and daughters,class issues, the racial divide and how women are treated in modern culture.  Los Angeles as a setting is the third most important character in the book.Astrid's mother writes to her:"The best you'll ever do is to understand yourself, know what it is that you want, and not let the cattle stand in your way."And Astrid thinks: "I hated my mother but I craved her."Complex.

Look out, Apple! Amazon is coming for you...This device is amazing.  Well packaged, easy to set up, extremely fast, huge range of content.Amazon is crushing Apple lately with innovation.  This little Fire TV stick is an example.It's very well-priced and easy to setup and gives you access to Prime movies, music, TV and outside services like Netflix and Pandora.Pros:- Small, easy to attach hardware- good build quality- menus are easy to navigate- beautiful screens- synced with your Amazon account already- Netflix looks better on this than on Apple TV- less buggy than Apple TV- can access Amazon cloud photos if you want- great for musicCons:- no Spotify app (at time of writing)- plays through TV speakers only- voice activated control requires separate hardwareOur Apple TV box went to the island of misfit obsolete gadgets after we set up this amazing Fire TV Stick.

Well-researched, this book is destined to become the definitive summary of Amazon's first 20 years.This fascinating book gives some insights into what Amazon is like today and what it was like as it grew like crazy from startup to behemoth.  The author writes in an accessible, fast-paced style.  This is no hagiography; author Brad Stone has portrayed Jeff Bezos as a maniacal, almost mad genius. At times he paints this picture of Bezos as a cult-like figure.We learn a lot of previously unknown biographical information about Jeff Bezos.  But to me, it all seemed fairly superficial and it didn't do enough to paint a picture of the man Jeff Bezos.  Fairly boilerplate stuff about how Bezos went to gifted public schools and was very smart.When it comes to Amazon itself, the most fascinating part by far was the many challenges the company faced.  The growing pains were never-ending.  I got the impression from reading this book that the whole thing was holding on by a thread and threatening to careen off the tracks multiple times during the first few years.Unfortunately, other than a cursory description of the fulfilment centers and some attempts to illustrate the unique corporate culture, it feels like writer Brad Stone didn't ACTUALLY get that much access to Amazon itself.  Perhaps due to its extreme secrecy, as a reader, I never truly felt like I was "inside" the company.  The story is still compelling.My only complaint is Stone's obvious bias against Amazon.  He paints them as ruthless in cutting prices from the mega sized suppliers and companies like book publishers, the music industry and hard goods producers.  How is it so bad that Amazon is doing this, all for the consumer?  He even paints Amazon as evil for scouring the web to find if other sites price goods more cheaply, so they can match their price.  The most ludicrous example of Stone's outrage is when Amazon battles against Wusthoff's anti-consumer price fixing strategy.  Stone himself admits their knives for $159 retail price are nearly the same as $20 knives at department stores.  Wusthoff is the number one knife seller in the US and trying to maintain extremely high margins.  How is Amazon bad for trying to cut those prices for consumers?If you admire Amazon, especially from a customer point of view, this book will not change your mind.If you invest in stocks, this book is a must-read, because it will pound home the great lengths Bezos is going to in order to change retailing forever.  Anyone who runs retail stores of any size must read this book.

Best reading device of all time. (So far.)- Amazing screen, although the resolution difference from the previous Paperwhite is too subtle for me to notice.- Light, small, grippy in your hands- Haptics are also too subtle and I ended up moving pages the "old way" by touching the screen itself- Long battery life as advertisedNegative:- I don't like where they place the power button.  It's in a weird location on the back instead of on the side like most tablet-like gadgets. They may have copied the way Apple puts the power button on the back of the iMac.  This is great for esthetics but lousy for daily use as I find myself fumbling around looking for the power buttonAmazon, in the Kindle franchise, has made the absolutely best reader in the world.  It has taken several iterations, but they have relentlessly improved both the hardware and the software.Ignore the newspaper reviews that say "Why would anyone pay this much for a single-use device."  If you are an avid reader, this is the BEST way to read- free of distractions, on a screen that is gentle on the  eyes.

Brilliant, epic coming of age story.In this ambitious, massive novel, Dickens brings plots, subplots, and unforgettable characters together to address themes of wealth's corrosive influence, the pain of love, and the meaning of friendship.Although written in a dated, flowery, difficult style (by design), the actual ideas that Dickens explores are timeless.  Not an easy read, but a worthwhile read.The tone is dark, gothic, and foreboding.  Dickens at times is lyrical in his descriptions of London of old.  Central character Kip is complex; at times we love him, pity him, and dislike him.  But we are never bored.My favorite theme he illustrates is the idea of falling in love with the wrong person- especially how men can fall in love with women that do not love them at all.  In fact, they often fall for the worst possible woman for them.If you never were "forced" to read this in a literature class, try it out, you may love it.  If you did wade through it as a young person, give it another try as an adult- it is certain to move you in a very different way.

Solid construction.  These are not the flimsy hangers with the seams that snap in half right away.  They are nice looking, strong enough for even men's heavier clothing, and line up nicely in the closet.There were 12 in the pack.

Just fantastic.  Worth every penny.  Once you cook with All-Clad copper core cookware, everything else seems flimsy in comparison.I use this saucepan for small sauces and to do small water boils for things such as poaching eggs and small servings of pasta.  It is perfect for these projects.The construction is superb.  Truly a thing of beauty, the pan is solid, perfectly machined, and the inside is smooth and gleams with stainless steel perfection.  It is not non-stick, but fairly stick resistant if used correctly.  Even if you really stick something to it, like I did with a poached egg that went awry, it is easy to clean with (manufacturer's recommended) Bar Keepers' Friend.If you appreciate well-made, beautiful, useful things, you will enjoy this pan.

This is a nice guide for cooking for the home chef that does not want to waste a single thing.  It is a cookbook, and more.  Eugenia Bone takes us through the kitchen, from A to Z, apples to zucchinis, with recipes and tips for using the rinds, bones, shells, and peels of the ingredients.The book is beautifully illustrated with color photographs.  Chock full of practical tips on cleaning, shelling, and gutting ingredients such as lobster, asparagus, mushrooms and more, it is a worthwhile read even if you don't use any of the recipes.My only caveat about this book is you would need a lot of time, space in your kitchen, and access to good local ingredients to do what she suggests here.  City dwellers in small apartments will find many of her ideas difficult to use.

Gets the job done.  Fluval is the best system for messy little turtles that defecate constantly during their "eating season."You can never have too much of this media!We have gotten years of life out of our Fluval canister system- it is quiet, and super clean.  This media is top-quality.I suggest rinsing it in the sink first, to get rid of the initial charcoal dust.  After that, it will get your tank crystal clear.

The brilliant Laurie Anderson soars in this amazing album!She is a pioneer and blazed the trail for all the creative, artistic women artists after her.Quirky, beautiful, poignant and emotional, this set of her music is more accessible than past efforts.  It stays more with conventional music structures.  But that doesn't mean it isn't ground-breaking.Loyalists may prefer her other albums, but this one is the best starting point for fans new to her fold.Just lovely, especially the title track.

(NOTICE:  I have updated this review, since the company that makes this software reached out to me in the comments field below to offer assistance with this product.  For me, it is still only a 3-star product, but for many people their excellent customer support may be not only a pleasant surprise but will help them enjoy the product more than I did.)I have always loved Mavis Beacon typing and she has helped me to achieve decent speeds of around 70 wpm with accuracy.  I thought this program would help me to touch that up a bit, and knock some cobwebs off of my typing skills.This program itself isn't terrible. But the software seems like something from the mid-90s.  From the CD-Rom and product key you have to use to install it, to the buggy installation software, to the old Mac-like software icons, it truly feels like going back in time.Unfortunately, on my Windows PC, this program was crashy and hard to keep running.I think ultimately this should be a web-based application that could live in the cloud and stay up to date with current software quality.For now, I can't recommend this software highly.

In "Simplify," prolific blogger Joshua Becker lays out his definition of modern minimalism and how to achieve it in today's consumer-driven society.What is minimalism?  Becker writes:"Minimalism is the intentional promotion of things we most value and the removal of anything that distracts us from it."Clutter is anything you don't need or love.  One of the joys of becoming minimalist is that we are constantly pushed to define what we truly value in life. Instead of 25 mediocre shirts in your closet, have 10 that you truly love and get rid of the restRealize that possessions do not equal joy.Learn to enjoy things without owning them- like parks, museums, etc.Simplify can mean not only removing physical belongings, but deciding what is most important in your life and removing the things that distract you from it. Remove the urgent for the sake of the important.This is a wonderful book not only for aspiring minimalists, but for everyone to broaden their perspective and perhaps get off the advertising/mass consumption/debt treadmill.

McGee is the Infinite Jest of food and cooking.  Exhaustive, at times exhausting, amazing, joyous, and LONG, it is a must-read for aspiring home chefs and professionals alike.  I can't imagine anyone serious about understanding food and cooking not having read this book.  This is a man who truly loves food and the science of it.  It actually reads quite quickly at times and fascinates the reader with many facts, quotes from literature, science lessons and historical excerpts, all about food!  The wine and liquor chapter is also quite compelling.  Where he may lose you is in the hard-core chemistry explanations, which I suspect are thrilling for chemists, but less so for the rest of us.  Also, at one point I asked myself if I really needed to know such excruciating detail for every single fruit every discovered.  But all in all, this is an amazing book which has changed the way I look at food forever.Below are some of my favorite quotes from the book to give you a "flavor" for his writing:"I think it's a sad reflection on our civilization that while we can and do measure the temperature in the atmosphere of Venus, we do not know what goes on inside our soufflÃ©s.""A sip of milk itself or a scoop of ice cream can be a Proustian draft of youth's innocence and energy and possibility, while a morsel of fine cheese is a rich meditation on maturity, the fulfillment of possibility, the way of all flesh.""Butter and cheese, once prized, delicate concentrates of milk's goodness, have become inexpensive, mass-produced, uninspiring commodities piling up in government warehouses.""Cheese is one of the great achievements of humankind.""An egg is the sun's light refracted into life.""But because we raise meat animals in order to eat them, it seems only just that we try to make their brief lives as satisfying as possible. By fortunate coincidence, the methods of slaughter that result in good-quality meat are also the most humane.""The sensation of warm, firm, flavorful flesh melting away between tongue and palate is unparalleled.""Oysters are the sea's most tender morsels, the marine equivalent of penned veal or the fattened chicken, which just sit and eat.""Plant pigments are one of life's glories! The various greens of forest and field, the purples and yellows and reds of fruits and flower- these color speak to us of vitality, renewal, and the sheer pleasure of sensation.""Sugar is pure sensation, crystallized pleasure.""Like all good foods, wine beer and spirits nourish and satisfy the body.""Sparkling wines delight by emitting bubbles that catch the light and prick the tongue."

At times brilliant, but many times the poems left me flat.This collection of poems starts and ends strong. The first few poems are the best.  They are inventive, creative, engaging and mind-bending.  Then the middle mass of poems felt plain, almost monotonous.The final couple of poems were fantastic.What makes these poems so good is Lockwood's ability to make connections between disparate facts, emotions, ideas and cultural touchstones.  Despite the title, there is very little that is overtly sexual in these poems.  Thought provoking, fresh approach, and when she is at her best, she soars.

Worth the money.I was skeptical that an expensive pan would make this much difference, as I have been "cooking" on cheaper pans for the last few years.  This pan is worth every penny, and changes the way I think about stove-top cooking.  Other than my cast iron, this is my new favorite kitchen pan. I could survive in the kitchen with this and the cast iron alone.First, the pan itself is a thing of beauty.  Wonderfully well-built, smart design, elegant, shiny and solid.  Some people may think it's a bit heavy, but to me, I love it's weight.  It's like a heavy chef knife- wielded properly, the weight allows the pan to do the work for you.Food cooks so evenly on this pan it's amazing.  The copper core allows the pan to get hot extremely quickly, and to cook food through evenly in much less time than cheap pans.  (You can do shrimp on this pan in about 45 seconds).Easy to clean, and I found non issue with even omelettes sticking- obviously you have to use oil or butter.  But I figure I have eaten enough teflon in my lifetime.Less not more.  Buy this pan and throw away those 3 or 4 crappy pans that are cluttering up your kitchen.Only negative is the price, but it's worth it.

Every moment in business happens only once.  With that sentence, Peter Thiel begins Zero to One with the best opening of any business book in memory.  At times he shines with brilliant thoughts, at other times he sounds like a madman, and other times he just sounds silly.  But through all the passion here, there is some truly original thinking.  If you are thinking of doing a start-up, this should be high on your list of required reading.  As an investor, it helped me hone my thinking as well.  And besides that, who doesn't love a book in which the writer compares hipsters to the Unabomber?The way to understand Thiel's unique thought process is to know his favorite question: "What important truth do very few people agree with you on?"  His answer: most people think the future of the world will be defined by globalization, but he thinks the truth is that technology matters more.This quote is one of my favorites: "The most contrarian thing of all is not to oppose the crowd but to think for yourself."He deftly explains how monopolists, especially in technology, take pains to pretend that they have a lot of competition, while companies with no real differentiation attempt to do the opposite.  He has strong views; "monopoly is the condition of every successful business," he says.He doesn't love the current educational regime in the United States: "For the privilege of being turned into conformists, students pay hundreds of thousands of dollars in skyrocketing tuition that continues to outpace inflation."  And another shot: "All Rhodes Scholars had a great future in their past."Thiel relates some business truisms for aspiring entrepreneurs, such as the importance of a sales effort, the power of compounding, the way to determine if you have a niche.  He lays out a seven-point list of success factors for new ventures.He loses his way a little bit 2/3 of the way in this short book when he relates his opinions on hipsters, Britney Spears, Michael Jackson and Lady Gaga (with pictures!) He even opines that Star Wars is capitalist while Star Trek is communist.  I guess he got a bit tired of writing at some point. I do like his principle of never investing in a tech company that has a CEO that wears a suit, though.With a tidy wrap-up chapter on potential future outcomes for the entire world, this entertaining and informative little volume is done.  Did I mention there are pictures?

The Backstory.This could have been the title for this book, but that is nowhere nearly as sexy as "The Saint."In this book by the charming Tiffany Reisz, we get Soren and Nora's entire backstory.  The tale unwinds as we find Nora in the present day, in the arms of another lover.I found the detailed explanation of how she met Soren during her high school years to be interesting, if at times a bit slow-moving.The sexy parts of this book are great as usual.  I thought the book was almost all romance and almost no BDSM.  But that's fine, because that is what Reisz's readers are probably looking for anyway.The Saint is an enjoyable read- not enough perversity for me - but sexy nonetheless and longtime fans of Nora (or actually Soren) will not be disappointed.

These are comfortable, well-made, stylish, well-fitting undershirts.  And the best thing: they are very reasonably priced.  Mens' underwear and undershirts can be quite expensive.  I've found these to be amazing quality and feel and a good value.  Size runs true and they are quite durable.  They last for over a year without looking yellowed or frayed.  And when you wear them, they feel good.Great quality- good value.

These are the best cycling shorts for the price.  They are a little more than the cheaper line of Izumi, but they are MUCH better.  They are comfortable, and durable.  My pair lasted about 3 years of very heavy use- 2 rides per week.  They finally gave way after a 120 mile ride through NYC.The chamois offers great padding but is of a material that wicks away a lot of moisture.  The only time you get that awful soggy diaper effect is in peak riding in August many, many miles into a long ride.For spin class these are perfect.Some people say they run small, but for me they were perfect.  I'm 5'9", about 165 lbs and the medium fit perfectly.Also, as I write this, the Amazon price is MUCH lower that the local retailers prices.

Lenox is a name that connotes heirloom quality. And, with so many other companies producing substandard products recently, we were concerned that these would no longer be worth the investment. Once we held this ornament, we knew that Lenox has not changed one iota. The quality here is outstanding ... and, the attention to detail is staggering. These are ornaments that you will treasure and pass on to your own children.And, I know your worry. The shipping process? These arrived bubble-wrapped and packed with plastic pillows surrounding it. it will, clearly, be safe from any sort of holiday jostling. (Moreover, it warrants notice that Lenox also VERY careful packs these ornaments in little boxes ... to the point where they nearly float in the middle of the box (so well encased in packing material are they).Start your collection here! Add one to your tree every year. Or, grab one a year and store it away until your son or daughter has his/her own tree. These are even more beautiful, delicate, and charming in-person.
