The headline just about sums it up!, The Syma S107 line of choppers are great!. They are fun to fly and are priced great. I have an S107C and had to get these s107gs for my nephew for Christmas, Of course I had to try them out, They fly great!, I recommend getting the 240mah upgraded battery for even more fun, check out my review for it for more info.When getting your chopper be sure to put it on the charger and charger it until the red light goes off, after that you're ready to fly, A full charge will get you a good 5 minutes flying time then let it cool about 10 minutes before putting it back on the charger and charge fully before going again. I enjoy the S107 line of choppers and I'm sure you will too!

0:58 MinsGreat Little chopper, the camera in mine was very fragile, every time I would crash the chopper the camera would pop off the connector in the housing, so I opened the camera housing up and folded a little tiny peice of electrical tape up and put it on the chip then when closing the camera housing back up it helps hold the camera fitting into the circuit board, Be sure to let battery cool down for about 10-15 minutes before charging, when you plug the charger into the USB port their will be a red light on showing that it is ready to charge, Plug the chopper in and the red light will shut off meaning it is charging, when it is fully charged the red light will come back on. do not fly the chopper but about 5 minutes, do not run the battery completly empty before charging again and you should not have any problems, I can fly the chopper a lot easier by adjusting the trim before taking off, put it on either a wood floor or some flat surface and start the rotors up but do not take off, then use the trim control on the top right side of the remote to adjust the trim until the chopper stays straight, then you can put more effort into the throttle to start flying, it will fly very straight then. I will update this review as I fly more.

This by far has to be the best purchase and upgrade I have my for my Syma S107C, The chopper is much more responsive now and the fly time is much longer, I just flew this thing with the camera on for a full 8 minutes and there was enough juice left in the battery I'm sure for at least 1 or two more minutes, I can now pinpoint my landings and fly this thing very precisely because of the extra power gained through this upgrade, The installation went fairly easy, I de-soldered the old battery from the wires and soldered the new battery to it but you could always probably just splice the wires in, It was hard getting the canopy to fit back over the new larger battery, but after finessing it went on, this battery did come with a little charge on it but I stuck it on the charger anyway to be safe and it took about thirty minutes to charge. the battery was shipped quickly and at a price like this you would be stupid not to but this upgrade.

0:58 MinsGreat Little chopper, the camera in mine was very fragile, every time I would crash the chopper the camera would pop off the connector in the housing, so I opened the camera housing up and folded a little tiny peice of electrical tape up and put it on the chip then when closing the camera housing back up it helps hold the camera fitting into the circuit board, Be sure to let battery cool down for about 10-15 minutes before charging, when you plug the charger into the USB port their will be a red light on showing that it is ready to charge, Plug the chopper in and the red light will shut off meaning it is charging, when it is fully charged the red light will come back on. do not fly the chopper but about 5 minutes, do not run the battery completly empty before charging again and you should not have any problems, I can fly the chopper a lot easier by adjusting the trim before taking off, put it on either a wood floor or some flat surface and start the rotors up but do not take off, then use the trim control on the top right side of the remote to adjust the trim until the chopper stays straight, then you can put more effort into the throttle to start flying, it will fly very straight then. I will update this review as I fly more.

I've been using this on my rooftop antenna for a couple months now and have had no trouble what so ever, No interference either, I did tape everthing up real good though, But in my opinion this was a great purchase.

This sound card works flawlessly with my Windows 8 system, I plugged it into my USB hub and windows installed it in about 3 seconds, The sound seems more crisp and more loud than my internal sound card in my laptop. The reason I purchased this sound card was to connect my amateur radios to the input/output so I could decode data and it is working great for that, the system sounds, etc can be routed to my internal sound card and I use the external for my amateur radio needs, I am very happy with this purchase and very happy with the people shipping it, I received my order 2 days after purchasing and that was with regular post and Iive on the east coas, I would most definatly recommend this product and the seller.

Excellent antenna, great gain when I need it, extra portable when I need it to be also, antenna is a lot lighter than others too so it makes the radio that much easier to carry, Hitting repeaters 35-40 miles away in hilly terrain.
Very well built cable, could use some extra moisture protection at the connectors, nothing a little electrical tape and a lighter won't take care of though.

First things first, The fan is very loud. That being said, The PSU works great, I'm using it with a 2 meter radio and I get no feedback from the PSU into the receive or transmit of the radio, The fan is loud but not loud enough to interrupt me.

This is a great little Radio, I feel it is a good improvement over the Baofeng UV-5R series.The batteries on these units take a long time to charge, I've seen them take up to 8 hours to charge at times.The Battery charger could use some work too, the charger is *supposed* to have red, and green LED to give you the charging status, but this one only has green "charged" and a very greenish colored yellow, making it hard to distinguish whether the battery is charging.Other than that I love the performance of this radio, it's easy to program, etc. With the help of a few websites because the manuals are still lacking.

The drive CD that came with this cable was blank, The data on those discs is useless anyway, These particular cables carry a phony prolific chip so if you have a newer version of windows you have major driver issues, there is a fix for it though and there are many sights on the web that could help you get it fixed quickly.I do believe now that Baofeng has a newer USB cable out that addresses these issues.Other that that, this product has worked flawlessly.

This is a great little unit, I'm not going to say "for the price" either because truthfully I can say in some aspects this Baofeng exceeds the performance of some of the big 3.This radio does have its little quirks that tick you off a little in the beginning but you quickly grow fond of this radio if you just have a little patience, there are many great sources on the internet to get all the information you need to get these thing going quickly.I have on of their newer models also, The UV-B5 which addresses some of the issues in this radio, these radios are evolving and being improved at a quick rate. So you might want to invest in one while they are still cheap!

These are excellent screen protectors, in my opinion. There are 5 in a pack, It took my second try to actually get an install free of bubbles, But here it is 6 months later and I still have that second one on. These are very durable and they have good clarity also,It's about time to change to a new one, this one after 6 months is starting to show its age with scratches, etc.. But I still have 3 left so even if I do mess up on the next installation I know I will at least get six more months out of this cheap little 5 pack
Its Memory, It works :)I've had this item for a good while now, I use it almost daily, never have any trouble.Great dealBuy it already, This is what you came for right?

This antenna has potential if they step up their quality control a little better, The Antenna is a little flimsy and bends easily. The tip of the antenna fell off the second day I had it, I lightly glued it back so this in no way affected the performance of this antenna.The antenna performed just as good or better than a couple other high gain antennas I have, I get good signal reports from repeaters 35+ miles away, depending on condition, this antenna is great to work satellites with because of the flexabilty of the antenna so it is a great performer.UPDATE, After having the antenna for a few months I have added another star, I'm very happy with this antenna it has really showed its true performance when I really need it and has out-performed other higher dollar antennas I have..

This little speaker Mic is great, It is light-weight, yet durable. It fits snug on my Baofeng UV-5R+ and my Baofeng UV-B5, The audio from the speaker is crisp and clear, And the Microphone picks up your voice great, Like any mic hold the mic about three inches from your mouth and speak across it, not directly into it, I have had great audio and modulation reports with mic. I highly recommend!

This is a great little antenna, It is a great improvement over the rubber duck that comes with the Baofeng UV-5R+, It gets about the same performance as the antenna that comes with the Baofeng UV-B5, I hit repeaters up to 20 miles away in a hilly and city terrain.and contrary to what many say on here, this antenna fits both the UV-5R+ and the UV-B5 like a glove.

this is a great antenna, I feel I have gotten a great deal on this item, I use this with my Kenwood TM-281a mobile 2 meter radio and hit repeaters up to 100 line of site miles away, In hilly terrain, The magnet is great I've had no problems with it trying to slip off the car at speeds of up to 80 mph, the swr at around 145.XXX is 1.1, I would however take some electrical tape and wrap around where the coax goes into the magnetic base to keep moisture out, I wrapped it tight and put heat to the tape to shrink it. Other than that this is an excellent antenna, I would give 5 stars if that issue was fixed.

Wow, wow, wow.  I have no words for this novel.  It starts off a bit slowly but then completely sucks you in.  Since I read it on Kindle I really don't know how long it is but it felt like a big book - particularly as I was pushing to follow the story line.  I think I must have sobbed through the last quarter of the book.  Those characters will live with me for a long long time.  The writing is beautiful and very descriptive but I must admit I sometimes wish there was less description and more of the powerful story line.  But we got there and it was worth it.  I keep going back to it.  DO NOT MISS THIS BOOK!  I don't want to say anything about the plot as that is how I like to start a book....
Lovely, soft washcloths that are sturdy but not too plush to be useful.  I highly recommend them.
I like to have stacks of white wash cloths that are sturdy but not too plush and these were perfect.  Wash and dry beautifully.
Amazing little tool.  In art if you don't want to be bogged down by the rules of perspective, this little tool handles all the angles.  Saves me a lot of grief.

Delightful and engrossing reading.  About aging and death and sex and caring for one's parents and aging husband.  A love story that is poignant and sometimes very funny.  The narrator considers reaching out for anonymous sex as an antidote to aging and dying but - well I won't give any more away.  A real mediation on life, death, family and the meaning of things.  This is my first Erica Jong book and I loved it.  Beautiful and touching writing.

Pearl Buck never disappoints!  This is a fascinating and lovely book.  Very hard to put down.  It gives an insight into the matriarch of a wealthy Chinese family in the early 1900s (I think) and how she rules her family with wisdom.  It is a large household since all the wives of her sons and all their children plus all the servants live in the same household under her rule.  When she turns 40 she decides that her sexual life is finished (no explicit sex - everything is simply hinted at) and she decides to bring in a concubine for her husband.  But even she with all her wisdom cannot contain the forces of life, and big changes come into the family.  Fascinating.  Don't miss it!

Love these bras.  I do not like elastic to touch my skin anywhere as I am mildly allergic and these are fully covered everywhere by very soft lingerie type fabric.  These are the only bras I will wear and I keep buying more.  I machine wash and dry and they hold up beautifully over the years.  I highly recommend them.

I live in San Diego which is comparatively bug free but in the summer the flies do come out.  I usually buy another brand of fly trap but since this one got so many good recommendations on Amazon I decided to try it.  It came quickly and was easy to set up and seems to be attracting lots of flies.  It hangs by a loop which is fine if you have a nail or something but since I wanted to hang the two I bought on tree branches on the patio I had to find something to hang them with.  And I had to be careful because I sure didn't want all that smelly stuff to spill!  I recommend they include a tie on or wire to hang it.  As for the smell, it obviously doesn't smell good but it is not offensive and quickly dissipates outside.  I think I will be a regular user

WARNING to watercolorists.  This is NOT your typical artist tape that is easily removed without damage to paper or the board.  This tape is permanent and will not come off your paper.  You have to cut your paper out.  Which is fine if that is what you intended but it surprised me.  I must say it does stick beautifully and stretches the paper but then you have to cut off all parts of the paper that are taped.  And it is a mess to get off your board.
Gorgeous book for watercolorist.  She is free and easy but gets some breathtaking results

This is a classic on color. I found an old copy at the library and knew I just had to have my own copy.  Thanks Amazon for finding it.  You will learn so much about colors and their properties.  And it is a fine reference book that I often go back to.
Very nice for the price.  I use it to stack watercolor paintings.
Delightful introduction to watercolor by the always wonderful Hazel Sloan.  I buy everything of hers that I can find.  Thanks Amazon!
This is a gorgeous DVD that will free up your painting.  I love everything by this artist
Nice price for a pack of white mats that just fit my watercolor paper.
It's wonderful to be able to get these fine watercolors through PRIME with no shipping charges and quick deliver - even just one tube at a time.  This is a lovely lovely color.

Love these shoes - as a matter of fact as soon as I tried them on I ordered a second pair.  They are as light as air yet give good support and look wonderful.  They come in an interesting range of colors.  I highly recommend them.

This course is a very practical and comprehensive introduction to Microsoft Access 2013.  It is designed for three different types of users: #1 - The user who has worked with previous versions and Access and now wants to take advantage of the new features of 2013.  I think the options to use touch screen and also the ability to build web apps are the best features but it also goes over all the interface changes in Office 2013#2 â Someone who has used other databases/programming languages â like SQL, FoxPro, Visual Basic, Excel, etc. â and now wants to work with Access 2013#3 â The user who is new to database design (these last types of users will have to work very hard to understand everything but be patient as he carefully explains everything and you will learn a great deal).As you can imagine writing a course that will be helpful to such a diverse group is not easy but I think this course does it quite well.  If you are an experienced user you might find the beginning classes slow but be patient as you will never regret learning the correct way to do things in Office/Access 2013 and the many options to do them different ways.  It would take ages of trial and error to figure all of this out.  If you are not completely familiar with Office 2013 it is easy to get lost about where you are but he goes over the âribbonâ and all the options in great detail.  Even if you are experienced, you wonât be sorry you sat through all of this.I wondered how he would approach database design without losing the beginners but he jumps right in.  His database is small, somewhat simple but quite a few tables with crosstabs and cross reference tables and insights into data types, etc.  Beginners will have to take this part slowly but he makes it quite possible to learn it if you follow closely and do all the assigned lessons.  (Experienced users will probably prefer to practice on their own databases and not the assigned ones but it is important to practice or test as you go along since you will never remember as much as you think you will!)  He covers database design, keys, relationships, normalization, indexes etc. and shows you how to use the data in datasheet form.  For a beginner getting all the properties correct will take some attention but he does it all with great detail and with practice.  He shows you how to add list boxes and/or validations to fields, etc. and how to navigate, sort and search the records.Then he goes to SQL and gives a nice introduction.  I am new to Access but experienced in SQL so I was looking forward to using Access SQL.  It is different from standard Microsoft SQL but it has wonderful wizards that build any query for you and then you can look at what it built and see how this SQL works so that you can build your own queries as needed.  Access offers wizards to build queries of all types â UPDATE, DELETE, searches for blank fields, searches for duplicate records, etc.  Once you use the wizard you can see the SQL statement itself and build on that for the future.  (I thought the Access SQL Statement to update one table from another - a straightforward statement in the conventional SQL I am familiar with - was mind boggling,  but it makes sense and now I know how it wants it done.)  Those wizards can be quite helpful.He then spends quite a few lessons on forms.  There are so many different ways to approach them.  Access has a lot of wizards that build forms in different ways from the simple to the complex.  Once you see what it does you can easily go on from there to build much more complex ones.  The possibilities are almost infinite and he tries to touch on many types of objects from combo boxes, to text boxes to command buttons.  Again, for beginners, do the assignments and for the experienced, work on your own app trying to use what he taught because you will forget it otherwise.He also spends time on reports and Access is wonderfully helpful here allowing both beginners and experienced programmers many options.When it comes to the most complicated issues like macros and VBA (Visual Basic for Applications â Accessâs programming language) he can only give a brief overview.  Once you get to this point if you want to go more deeply into VBA, you need to get books on that (Amazon has a number of new ones that seem comprehensive).He also lightly touches on data conversion â from Excel tables or text files or ODBC  or SQL (of particular interest to me as I had old data to pull in) and on setting up your app for users and how to handle things like security.All in all I found this to be a very comprehensive and useful course.  Iâll never regret sitting through the parts I thought I already knew because I got some insights.  It will be useful to users of all types if they are careful to pay attention and practice what is new to them.  I highly recommend this course.Footnote:  The nice thing about Access is that it comes with Microsoft Office and has a comparatively small footprint which makes it easier than keeping the big programming engines like SQL, Oracle, .NET, C++, C## on your system if you donât need the complexity of the more powerful languages and databases.

I want to praise these little tablets as they have worked wonders for me.  I have a dry cough that badly interrupts my sleep.  My doctors say it is related to sinus/polyps issues and the treatments have either not worked or only worked for a few weeks (polyps grow back whether treated with surgery or steroids).  So for the last 10-15 years I have had to sleep with lozenges in my mouth all night.  Of course, there is a danger of aspiration but it was the only way to get sleep.  Recently I stumbled across these OraMoist tabs â they are wonderful.  The little tablet sticks to the roof of your mouth and keeps your mouth moist for many hours as it dissolves.  One or two gets me through the whole night.  I just love them.I tried other brands but like OraMoist best as they last much longer.  Also some of the others do not stick on the roof of your mouth but on a tooth (yuck!) or the side of the mouth.  I much prefer OraMoist and highly recommend them.
I love Daniel Smith watercolors and and happy for the convenience to be able to buy one tube at a time from Amazon Prime

I received a free item to review.I'm an 11 1/2 extra-wide. I tried a pair of the gel pads in the exercise sneakers I wear on a treadmill 5-6 days a week. I've gotten blisters and callouses around my heels over the years from ill-fitting/worn sneakers and have used a number of homebrew remedies to add extra padding and comfort - some more successful than others.These gel pads add perhaps a quarter inch of support at the back end and thin out to about 1/16" at the front, which isn't much. But on an inclined treadmill even that much is noticeable and does relieve some of the tension on my ankles.If only they were about 3/8" wider on both sides they would really fit snug and secure. The adhesive sticks well initially but, I suspect over time with a lot of sweat and movement, the pads are going to gravitate to one side and begin to feel awkward. I know my tolerance if I have to start adjusting them before each run and I'll just end up yanking them.But that hasn't yet happened in the couple of weeks I've used them so for now I'm satisfied.

I received a free item to review.Great for taking the dog out in the dark winter months. Unlike the flat-faced LED headlamps, this one has an adjustable beam focus that nicely  narrows and diffuses - making it doubly useful for reading during blackouts (my inevitable pastime), or in cars where an overhead light would distract the driver (or won't reach the back seat). I have a forced air blower in the attic and strapping this lamp on will make changing filters up there a lot easier than crawling around (and propping up) with a hand-held flashlight.There's plenty of headroom in the straps and a wide range of adjustment to fit any head size. The switch button protrudes nicely, making it easy to grab and press without looking. It's the standard two-levels of brightness plus a strobe and the bright setting is more than adequate for my use (still waiting for that big retro-party to whip out the strobe!).

I received a free item to review.This is not a fancy, heavy-weight leather belt by any means. But I like the 'non-shiny' matte black, the double-row stitching, and the 1 1/2" width.It's got some weight to it; it's not one of those old-fashioned 'cardboard belts' I doubt anyone wears anymore. It's reasonably solid, the kind of belt I'd wear with casual pants including other-than-blue jeans and khakis. The buckle has a nice gunmetal shine to it, with the roller, and the latch is comfortably loose making it easy to set.The inside doesn't even pretend to be fake leather, it's tightly woven poly-whatever, but it's just as matte-black and actually quite comfortable and easy to slide over a variety of pants materials.Bottom line: A good utilitarian belt to have in your collection for casual use.

I received a free item to review.The 'infinity' part is the large loop form of the scarf - kind of zen. It's hard to measure precisely with stretchy material but it's perhaps 2-3 feet in diameter. You toss it once over your head, then twist and loop again, fitting it snugly around your neck. You can also pull it up into a convenient hood. The beauty of the loop design is the scarf can't unravel and fall off or worse - no 'Isadora Duncan' moments (look it up).The material is definitely heavier than ultra-light synthetic scarfs that can feel like cotton candy in the breeze. But it's not as thick as the heavy wool you get on say classic Irish sweaters. It also has a open weave, sort of a tight macramÃ© texture that's more apparent as you stretch. It's not yet deep winter around here but I suspect it'll provide adequate protection outdoors. And if you keep your house 'less than toasty' or heat only one  zone, it's a handy thing to throw on to keep warm in colder rooms.Bottom Line: Attractive color and texture. Useful and comfortable to wear.

I received a free item to review.I'm a lefty and, without thinking about it much, I tend to sling backpacks and shoulder bags over my right shoulder and hold them on that side to keep my left arm free. Unfortunately the lower side strap on this bag attaches on the wrong side for me. Obviously I can still secure the pack with the large center strap but it lacks the extra support the pack is designed to deliver. It's a shame they didn't make the lower strap attachable on either side - doesn't seem like an expensive proposition or technical difficulty.Other than that, it's a good bag to store 'wet' (as in workout or beach) towels and clothing. Not an excessive number of compartments and zippers to deal with, for those who prefer simple and functional. The zipper pull is comfortable but the pack material sits very close to the track and got caught a couple of times I pulled. The yoga mat straps can be tightened enough not to worry my mat will slide out.The top handle is nicely designed and comfortable - some backpack manufacturers ignore or miss that many customers spend more time hand-carrying their products than back-carrying and they give too little thought to the balance and comfort of the top handles.Bottom Line: Attractive and durable enough, although I wouldn't use it for heavy-duty loads or items with sharp/jagged edges that might puncture the lining.

I bought these batteries for one of those faux-military, variable-focus flashlights I got for free. Military-grade it isn't, but it's a well-made little flashlight with a beam focus feature that really does something.It came with a charger but no batteries. It takes one of these 18650's and the two-pack I received look exactly like the green ones in the image and are - at least stamped - Made in Japan.Out of the box they appear fully charged and work just fine.I see the contrary-reviews and would just say: If this seller goes out of his way to put 'Made In Japan' in the item description he's vouching only for himself, not for other third-party sellers. I receive a free item to review.Note these bulbs will not fit in regular-sized incandescent lamps or outside lantern fixtures and many holiday houselights.They're made for smaller chandelier outlets and similar-sized fixtures.Beyond that, not much to say except the bulb is as bright as a filament 40W incandescent bulb.

I received a free item to review.I suppose it's a double-edged sword: you want cycling accessories to be lightweight, but you want them to be rugged as well to withstand active use, drops, and normal 'banging around'. However both the plastic lenses and frame of these glasses are so lightweight I consider the case and lens pouch pretty much a necessity.For my head size the glasses are barely wearable and not especially comfortable. The all-plastic frame hinges aren't very smooth-operating and have no spring to them. Beyond the maximum opening the frame easily begins to bend - particularly at the center bridge point where it's most likely to snap. The nose bridge is too narrow which keeps the glasses from sitting snug - mine would require constant straightening were I moving my head around a lot in outdoor activities.The lenses themselves scuff easily when dropped on pavement (I tried and confirmed it) and I don't understand the point of the openings along the top edge corners: Is that some kind of vent/air circulation thing? I think they're ugly viewed up close and, at particular angles to light sources, definitely allow light to enter and be reflected on the inner frame.Bottom line: These glasses are purely functional if you need a pair in a pinch, but I wouldn't be satisfied with the workmanship at this price. Not a good value.

This is essentially a syllabus designed for Schoenberg's American composition classes. It contains original examples 'in the style of' early 19th century piano pieces. The pedagogy begins simply: expressing the pitches of a single harmony, and builds logically, gradually, to multiple harmonies, motif forms, sentences, periods, contrasting middle sections. The goals are to train the ear to compose in small forms such as minuet and scherzo.'Models' is a relatively short book (though dense with examples) and the explanations are on the terse side - or rather they presume Schoenberg is there in the classroom to expound in more detail. If you're unfamiliar with his methodology, I strongly recommend working with 'Fundamentals of Musical Composition' at the same time. That text explains these ideas in more depth, particularly 'developing variation', the core driving force in Schoenberg's concept of tonal composition. Instead of original examples as in 'Models', 'Fundamentals' draws heavily upon Beethoven (mostly piano sonatas and string quartets) as well as other late 18th and 19th century composers.Combined with studying Schoenberg's Harmony and (if you can find it) his Preliminary Exercises in Counterpoint, you've got a pretty solid grounding in tonal composition leading into the early 20th century - ironically coming from a musician many people would least expect, but who was adamant that his own music, no matter how radical it appeared to some, was in fact grounded in and the logical successor to a musical tradition he very much respected.

The 'classic' modern foot stool has taken a beating in recent decades as general awareness of musicians' injuries and overall 'body wellness' has become an issue in pedagogy - not just for the guitar, but for all instruments.I'm not knocking the perspective and the awareness - I've benefited greatly from it. I suffered lower back pain and excess tension as a result of a too-high foot stool for years - in the mistaken belief 'one size fits all' and if <insert famous player's name here> uses it this way, who am I to argue.Well, I'm now a firm believer that one size or approach does not fit all when it comes to positioning the instrument. You really should take into account the length of your legs versus your torso, thighs versus the entire leg, your arm lengths, how the instrument contacts your 'lap', the angle of the soundboard to the floor as well as the neck angle to both the floor and your body's 'front plane' - not to mention the height and positioning of the chair you're using and the position of the foot stool on the floor versus an imaginary center line from your body as well as the inside angle of your knee joint.Lot's of things to consider and experiment with to arrive at a comfortable and appropriate position for the foot stool - and I won't deny that for some people the answer may be not to use one. For myself I set the stool to its lowest possible height and, taking everything else into account, I play more comfortably today than ever before - and I've played for over 40 years.A little 'tricking out' of my own is to contact cement a matching piece of short pile carpet over the top of the stool. The softer feel is especially welcome playing at home in socks.If you're not sure the foot stool is for you, it's certainly cheaper than the Shearer Strap to try out. The strap is an interesting alternative for classical - I also play steel string and electric and have nothing against using one (although drilling an eyehook on the neck of my nylon string as one Shearer recommended option does make me cringe a bit). I'd first experiment with 'temporary' applications using Velcro tape or even go the traditional steel string end strap pin with a 'tie-on' neck end before I put holes in the neck - especially if you have a valuable instrument you might sell down the line.(BTW, for those inclined, hiding small pin holes can be accomplished with a combination of filler, stain, lacquer and/or poly/super glue.)

I received a free item to review.If you have a desktop (musical) keyboard and need a more substantial music stand than the lightweights that often come built-in, the angle/height options this portable desk provides work really well. I took off the fans and mouse platform and widened the shelf by attaching a strip of 1/4" thick birch plywood. I also use it, in a more intended way, for an old laptop I use strictly to display printed music.If you draw or paint, the desk can be fashioned into a convenient easel you can prop a drawing pad or small canvas against.The large push buttons that free the joints are easy to operate and the legs feel absolutely secure when locked - there's no slop in them at all.Personally, the metal desktop is a little 'rough' to use in bed, but if you like to 'slouch on a couch' this works well (also makes a handy meal tray!).I built a homebrew version years ago that didn't work nearly as well. I tossed it once I got my hands on this.

I think the most valuable part of the book is the measure-by-measure bowing instructions for each of the dozen or so Beginner Songs in chapter 6, many of which are of Suzuki book 1 caliber. When studied in combination with the video demonstrations on DVD you get a real sense of how to distribute bow length across musical phrases and the effect of bow speed on volume.These devices become more refined as you grow in ability and are essential parts of a violinist's toolkit of expression as you study more involved pieces. But I found this book to be an excellent application of the concepts, giving immediate and satisfying results.If you're self-teaching and reach the point of bringing both hands together functionally, bow distribution is one of the most challenging aspects of violin playing - particularly when you're starting out and also trying to focus on tone production, reading, and keeping time.It's something that's too often taken for granted or outright ignored in early level learning material - and that's a shame because providing clarity on the mechanics of using the bow length makes it easier - not more difficult - to integrate more 'ear and feel' concerns such as tone and time. Worrying about 'running out of bow' and slowing down to conserve length is self-defeating musically and can sabotage a playing experience that requires relaxed focus.I'm less enthusiastic about some of the other material in the book: Seidel teaches dropping the elbow when approaching the frog from the midpoint square - something I personally disagree with and feel contributes to bow bounce and uneven tone. The best book on pure violin playing mechanics (no music) I've come across for self-learners is Mark Rush's 'Playing the Violin'. It's essentially Galamian's approach with many more and much better pictures. A little pricey but well-worth it.But this book's chapter on bow distribution applied clearly to beginning pieces alone makes it worth getting.

Regardless, she loves the way it feels â and Iâm sure when sheâs shedding it will manage to pick off a lot of hair.Itâs well-made, doesnât vibrate excessively in the hand, and is easy to wash (take out the batteries beforehand, as the compartment isnât well-sealed.Bottom Line: Fun, flexible âmassage toyâ for short-haired dogs that can withstand a drop here and there (watch out on concrete and hard tile, though).

I received a free item to review.I play classical guitar and Iâm fussy about the nails on my plucking hand. Contour, edge, and smoothness have a huge influence on tone. Many guitarists, being a superstitious lot with a fondness for ritual, use some combination of files followed by a buffing surface (A teacher once recommended sprinkling dental pumice as a buffing agent â a little messy for dark clothes).  I actually use a 1 ½ inch smooth pebble to buff â I discovered it by chance and it works for me.My immediate reaction to this portable trimmer/filer was, âNo way am I sticking my nails into some electric cheese grater to be torn offâ. But I was pleasantly surprised by how finely-calibrated the action is. Itâs not a fast, aggressive cut like sticking your nails on a bench sander. Itâs easy to work the tool left to right, following the contour you want.I have pretty large hands and âsausage fingersâ yet had no trouble covering the full contour of even my thumbnail.  Nail corners are especially problematic and can catch strings if not shaped properly.  I was able to take my time and work those corners the way I like.As far as I can tell, the only difference between âtrimâ and âfileâ modes are the trim has a somewhat more aggressive cut, but itâs easy to control.I expected a coarse edge left in either mode and was surprised at how smooth the results were. Granted, not quite smooth enough to do without buffing, but most people might not bother.On the down side, the vibration felt in the finger tip is somewhat âchalk on a blackboardâ tingly and, depending on your tolerance, may or may not be a problem. The high-pitch whirr of the trimmer will no doubt scare the heck out of anyone watching and is loud enough to be disturbing if youâre in public in close quarters.  And finally, depending on your current technique, you just may find it faster and more focused to pull out a file.In case anyoneâs wondering, the opening is too narrow to use with pet claws â at least with my dogâs.Bottom Line: the filer/trimmer works better than I suspected and thereâs really no risk of rapidly grinding your nails off!

I received a free item to review.I put the bulb in my garage door opener, where it's diffused by the white translucent cover. It's slightly less bright than the ordinary 60W bulb on the other side, so I'd rate it as a 40W equivalent. The bulb itself is clear and I find the light too harsh for an exposed lamp fixture, but it's fine diffused. I don't detect an unusual amount of heat coming off it either.I go through a lot of bulbs in the opener because it's programmed to keep them on for 5 minutes every time the door moves. I put a fresh 60W in at the same time so I'm curious to see which one lasts longer.

I received a free item to review.The cover is microfiber plush with some 'grain' to it, meaning your hand will feel smoother in one direction while raising the short fabric 'hairs' in the other. The texture is fairly attractive and there's about an inch of squeeze/give to it. The gray is, well, neutral but should work with most car interiors and many indoor chairs.It appears they went for less-weight versus stability, The circular frame of the seat and the rotating base are made of heavy-enough plastic not to worry about cracking, but the price for the lighter-weight is the rotation is not as smooth as I'd like and there's an annoying plastic-on-plastic sound that doesn't add up to a secure feeling.I play violin seated and I modified an old piano bench into a practice chair. I need fairly firm support but there's a lot of incidental reaching and motion while turning music pages, reaching for accessories, digital recorder, putting the instrument down, etc. I thought such a cushion would add some flexibility and comfort without risking straining my lower back muscles.I have to say the swivel seat does improve the situation, but it's not as secure or as comfortable as I'd like and I worry it'll get even less so over time.Bottom Line: I'll use the cushion it for now but keep searching for something better.

I received a free item to review.Best I can tell with my radius gauges the contact surface is a 12". The rubber surface has enough give to make that fine for all but very arched electric necks (i.e. 50's Fender). I can use it on my Martin OM-1, which has a 16" radius, because I generally play with a light touch for both flat and finger picking. I also used the capo successfully on my classical - I capo at the third fret and tune the G to F# for lute music - the shorter scale length gives a more appropriate response and feel.If you play hard with a flatter radius neck this capo may buzz on you - you're better off using one designed for a classical neck.Compared to the Planet Waves design, the frame of the Furios capo is definitely lighter and the back handle feels thinner though no less stiff. This is a plus for me as I like a capo to feel and look as unobtrusive as possible - I remember using those 'wrought iron fence' Kaysers that were anything but unobtrusive and easy to apply, although they held quite well at the time.The main shortcoming of the Furios capo is the spring has no tension adjustment. I don't think there's any real danger of compressing neck wood. But the spring action itself is stiffer and less smooth than the Planet Waves. If you're someone with a dedicated instrument and keep the capo on all the time, this probably doesn't matter. But if you change a lot the stiffer tension can be annoying or worse - if you've ever gotten a hand cramp onstage you know what I'm talking about.The neck-side rubber has a half-ribbed design which I don't think has much value for guitar necks but better holds narrower banjo and mandolin necks (I play both but have never capo'd a mandolin).Bottom Line: In a pinch the Furios is a adequate, lightweight capo. If you're always misplacing them like me, you can't have too many. But I prefer a Schubb for my steel string and my classical gauge Planet Waves model - both are easier on the hands and work fine.

I received a free item to review.Job One of course is, is the square 'square' and, comparing it with both my carpenter's and speed squares, it looks good - for everyday woodworking - you're not going to use this for precision machining.I do a lot of hand drilling and sawing of small work pieces and I like to use a level or speed square as an eyeball guide to stay perpendicular to the work surface. Keeping the guide steady can be a challenge but the 1 1/8" width of this square sits well. The 'rubberized' surface is just barely - I wish it were a bit heavier and 'non-skid'. But I guess the thinner, harder surface will stay a bit more true over time and, if you saw with it, you're less likely to take bits and chunks out.The pencil holder/sharpener feature doesn't add much value for me and I don't like that it obstructs lying the long surface flat. I think it could have been better incorporated into the sides. I cut off the holder loop to make the edge flush. I use a marking knife when I can but when I use pencils I either use a carpenter's pencil sharpened with a knife or an electric pencil sharpener. I don't like the cut of the embedded sharpener.Having a metric/imperial tape is very handy if you constantly work in both, as I do. I especially like that the tape tip sits well below flush and doesn't interfere with the corner surfaces at all. The push lock button has just the right amount of 'stick' and resistance - no worry it'll move without you.Bottom Line: If you're like me that pencil-erasable white writing surface will quickly fill up with 'non-erasable' pen measurements, phone numbers, etc. But I appreciate the thought!A decently-made, useful square to keep around.

I received a free item to review.The bowls have a firm but 'rubbery' texture; they're easy to expand and collapse by holding the rims with both hands and pressing with your thumbs. The 'ribs' in the sides don't have deep crevices that might catch food and make them hard to clean. We use dry food and there's no problem; wet food obviously takes more cleanup effort, especially directly under the rim.Capacity is about a small (human) cereal bowl, about a 5 inch outside diameter at the top, a little too small for our large lab unless we really pile it on.The colors look much nicer in person than in the images, especially the green and pink.Bottom Line: They're handy for both dogs and humans, but I wouldn't trust them in a microwave.

I received a free item to review.I never thought about having that secondary large handle loop at the pet end of a leash before - what a great idea. I'm old school and still prefer heavy leather leashes, but I use synthetics for wet weather, in the car, etc.We have a yellow lab who's thankfully not aggressive, but she's jumpy and excitable - especially when close up with new people and other large dogs.  Even with a 4-5 ft leash she can be two-handfuls until she calms down. The leverage I get from the loop on this leash really makes a difference; I feel much more in control and less likely to abraid my hand from grasping wildly at a taut and tangled leash.The synthetic material is quite heavy all-around and especially at the tied ends. This isn't one of those cheap thin leashes you have to worry about a dog shredding or gnawing through. Another advantage of the synthetic is it's easy to clean and there's no smell (for those not crazy about the scent of wet, worn leather - which I happen to love).The collar hook is what I'd call medium-heavy - much better than some lightweight hollow metal hooks I've encountered, but not quite the heavy solid nickel-steel hooks I remember from years ago. These are what you'll find on good quality leashes these days; the spring is plenty tight and unlikely to give way, no matter how active the dog.Bottom Line: The red is really bold, attractive, and doesn't look like it's going to fade anytime soon. Really good quality and that second handle is something I'm afraid I'll get use to and decide it's worth retiring my classic leather leashes.

I like the 'straight-in-the-ear' design for ease of insertion and quick removal at work (as in 'Sorry, what was that again?'). But the backs do protrude more than other designs and there's uncomfortable pressure while wearing large ear muffs - which I do while mowing and blowing snow.The cord gauge is a little heavier than other buds I have and longer (about 4ft) - both of which I like. I find flat ribbon cords tangle less easily than regular round cables but in this case the heavier gauge helps.Sound is so subjective the only way I know to evaluate earphones is to A/B them with other pairs using comparable sound sources:I found the Panasonic drops 360 has by far the strongest bass and overall warmth and signal strength than either my Bose SoundTrue Ultra or Brainwavz phones.There's a fair amount of depth in the response of the drops360 as well. The Bose, on the other hand, has a flatter, more evenly-balanced response, with more clarity and definition. For music with a wide frequency span and quite a few instrument/vocal sources, clarity is often more desirable than sheer bottom end.But in the several reference recordings I used (orchestral, small group jazz, acoustic solo instruments, chorus) I was very impressed by these Panasonic phones. I'm a musician and for more 'analytical' listening I might prefer the clarity of the Bose. But for sheer pleasure listening the drops360 is an unexpected surprise.(I have to say, the Brainwavz, which I'd previously considered quite good really showed its limitations against the other pairs, in terms of overall sound quality.)

I received a free item to review.I know it's controversial but from my own experience I conclude that staring directly into LED lights for more than brief unintended moments is not good for my eyes - and I wouldn't count on a small child to understand that and avoid doing so. I'm not going to quantify duration, measure the lamp output, or trust the specs. I simply would not recommend using them where a baby or small child is likely to become fascinated and be drawn to them.That aside, plug the card into a full-size powered USB port and the light is directed to the USB 'up' side. The juice from my phone charger drives them quite nicely.There's no on-board battery but you can dig up one of those portable USB power supplies you've got lying around and you've got a truly portable little lamp. The 'keychain hole' let's you to rig up a hanging hook - although I think a small spring clip would be more helpful and offer more options.

The centerpieces of this collection are Turtledoveâs 100 page Hugo-winning novella âDown In The Bottomlandsâ along with the 50 page âHoxbombâ  â just an upfront for anyone who prefers their short stories exclusively short.Turtledoveâs a historian by training and he explains in a thoughtful essay on writing alt history how it helps lend credibility. Heâs a stickler for accuracy â or accurate plausibility â and doesnât abide sloppy mismatches of events and details.While heâs best-known for alt-history, Turtledoveâs no one-trick pony: His stories reveal broad interests and writing chops suitable for any context: a super sharp eye and ear for detail, human nature, and dialog, a great sense of humor, and an intellect that never condescends to readers, doesnât feel too clever by half, or consumed by cynicism.Heâll occasionally step outside the story frame and wink at you, but itâs always in good fun and never enough to distract from Job One â effective storytelling.If thereâs one criticism I have itâs that Turtledoveâs characters are so well done and his scene painting so vivid it sometimes comes at the expense of pacing and drama. I found âDown In The Bottomlandsâ for example extremely slow going at first before an unexpected murder âlivened things upâ and announced there was more than a far-future travelogue intended here.The introductions to each piece in âWe Installâ run from a several sentences to a few paragraphs and the one-time aspiring writer in me (arenât we all?) found them fascinating. Itâs illuminating and instructional to see how a seasoned writer can mine story inspiration in an offhand comment, magazine article, or some combination of current events.For example, the title piece in âWe Installâ is a brief story inspired by an actual solicitation to install a home solar energy system and Turtledoveâs daughterâs amusement at the pun.For pros like Turtledove itâs not necessary to retire to some exotic locale, exclusive arts colony, or ritual inner sanctum to get work done. I have the feeling he can crank out a story sitting in a dentist office â and the setting will work its way in somehow.

I received a free item to review.Unlike other faux-leathers this wallet has an attractive, soft texture that feels good when handled as well as while worn. It's wider than the men's wallet I usually carry and the open card sleeves are easier to deal with than the tight pockets on my other wallet. The card readers at work vary in sensitivity - some I can swipe the open wallet against while others require me to expose part of my ID badge.To be honest I don't carry enough cards to do this particular design justice, but it makes for a nice back-up wallet.

I received a free item to review.My concern with non-wood/bamboo cutting boards is creating tiny fibers or flakes of the plastic/composite material that can find their way into food. I gave these a good chopping and bashing with sharp knives and a heavy cleaver and detected no such residue to worry about.You can't flex these boards. They're quite solid with a good amount of mass to them. No worry about dropping or banging them.I like the shallow lips; they're enough to keep light juices and water from running off but won't stop heavy run-off.The slightly rounded sides are a nice style touch and the wide opening grip makes it easy to hang from my ceiling rack hooks.I'll use the two smaller size boards in the kitchen; the largest one I have another use for in my shop as a base for sharpening stones.

I'd have to go back to Scofield's 'Enja Period' to find as consistently rich, song-form blowing as on 'Past Present'. It's great hearing him dig in so much in what, I think, is his most comfortable, 'home-base' setting: the trio + sax.  The recorded guitar tone is gorgeous - upfront and warm, with plenty of 'amp' and plenty of percussive undertone (pick feel) that I haven't enjoyed so much since the 'Works For Me' record. Scofield likes to feel some string resistance and tends to pick closer to the bridge, which gives his legato phrasing clarity and definition. There's nothing flabby or 'glissy/ghosty' about his playing - the notes speak, picked or slurred.Scofield remains a underrated jazz composer with as pure a melodic sense as you'll come across in any genre. He's that uncommon guitarist whose tunes rarely descend into guitar-cliches. Double-stops may evoke harmonic stabs and bent notes vocal and horn expression, but it never feels like it's about the guitar, always about the music and the interaction of the musicians. A deceptively complex sense of form and harmony make his tunes great fun (and educational) to study and play.With so much writing under his belt it's natural to hear echoes of tunes-past on 'Past Present'. But if like me you're as much a fan of his writing as his playing, you won't mind at all.Sad to read about his son's passing in the notes (I'm pretty sure I stood next to the young man at a gig in upstate NY several years back attended by Scofield's parents as well). It's a very poignant gesture to use his son's words to name the project and tunes.Scofield can be such a musical chameleon - and he rarely disappoints - but I hope he sticks around for awhile in this particular incarnation. I go back to his days with Galper and the trio with Swallow and Nussbaum. And I think, without a doubt, 'Past Present' is as good as anything he's done.

I received a free item to review.Nasty-smelling stuff - be sure to work outside and wear the nitrile gloves.But couldn't be easier to apply, 'like using a damp washcloth', let it sit for an hour, and you're done.I tried it on a 'canvas-style' violin case worn dull and slightly grey, compared to the rich black of new ones. I could see the rejuvenation occur as I wiped and it didn't take much effort at all. I also spruced-up a small 25+ year-old guitar amp with coarse black 'Tolex' covering. It took a bit more elbow grease but the thing looks '1986' all over again.Avoid the fumes and there's a flammable agent in there so when you're done, to be safe, soak the cloth in water and let it sit in the air overnight before tossing it in the garbage.Bottom Line: Much easier, better results than typical household spray cleaners. Use those for easy, repetitive cleaning. Save Wipe New for the tough jobs.

I received a free item to review.This 'bento-box'-sized case will look and feel familiar to owners of Brainwavz and other earphone makers. It's a larger variation of those storage cases with a single, similar rubberized zipper, webbed pouch, and 'dry fabric feel' that has limited water-resistance.The top and bottom have similar rigidity - but being larger and flatter, the rounded arch strength of the smaller cases is sacrificed here. This camera case can be crushed and deformed in a way the smaller earphone cases wouldn't likely be.The fully removable foam inserts are a good idea and allow the case to be used to store plenty of things if you don't have a GoPro camera. I've been looking for a case for my Zoom digital recorder and this will do nicely. It would also make a fine microphone case by cutting custom separators from the foam.

I received a free item to review.No kids in the house, but plenty of stringed instruments: violin, viola, mandolins, guitars, bouzouki, you name it.I don't just play them; I repair and restore them and I've no shortage of 'little cotton cloths' I keep handy and stick in their cases to keep delicate finishes clean.Bowed instruments, in particular, accumulate rosin dust - I know some players like that 'snowblind effect' but I'd rather see a nice varnish so I keep two cloths for violins - one to wipe excess rosin from the strings and the top and a second to clean the already-dusted surfaces.These bamboo cloths serve either purpose dry: Exceptionally soft, I have no concerns about reactivity with old finishes. They're lightweight with the faintest of pleasant aroma. It's also easy to 'wash the washcloths' and air dry them on the deck this time of year.Bottom Line: Can't have too many, and they beat paint rags and cutting up old t-shirts by a mile!

I received a free item to review.Three of them, actually (they make great gifts for people without refrigerator built-ins, or who entertain a lot).The difference between the three models of Ivation portable mini-icemaker comes down to the number of ice cube sizes each can produce (1, 2, or 3), the relative size of the compartment lid, the control panel and its orientation (top or front-facing), and the overall size/style of the unit.The compressor, capacity, and operation of the three models are essentially the same. I went into more detail in my review of the 3-sizes-of-cubes model so Iâm just going to recap here:This particular model produces only one size of ice cube. My fridge built-in only makes one-size and I've never thought it a problem. The size corresponds to the 'large' size of the two-size model and the 'medium' size of the three-size model.The ice cubes are shaped like hollowed-out rounded cones, not the semi-circular solids many refrigerator built-ins produce nor the classic cube shape you get with freezer trays.It takes just over a 6-cup Brita pitcher-full of water to fill the icemaker to the max indicator. The compartment lid stays open by itself so pouring is comfortable.It takes about two hours to make cubes using just about all of the water. All three units will simply detect and go into standby when the basket is full so thereâs no worry about overflow. I emptied the basket twice, the first time at about the one hour mark.All three icemaker models are very easy to operate and donât produce excessive noise. The three-cube model has a somewhat more complex control panel with a standby/pause function and auto on/off timer. It also provides a bit more feedback in the form of troubleshooting icons.This one-sized cube models is probably the simplest to operate and I think the appearance of the control panels is more attractive than the one on the three size model.All three models use the same drain plug mechanism and are easy to position over a sink.Bottom Line: All three icemaker models are well-made and attractive â although all are too large to keep permanently on our countertop. The hollow cone-shaped cubes are an acquired taste but if you entertain a lot and need to crank out more ice than the fridge can handle (or you donât have a built-in), itâs a handy and easy-to-use addition.

I received a free item to review.A lot of so-called athletic/exercise headphones claim to be sweat-resistant  but  the reality is their thin cords, lightweight and exposed cushions and controls  start to break down  -or get smelly-funky â fast, especially in warmer weather.The connecting band on these wireless phones is short and relatively stiff â with the kind of hard plastic coating I can easily wipe-down after a workout and clean with paper towel and a small dab of detergent.The Bluetooth pairing and functioning is fine with my Samsung Android phone. The sound quality is not as good as phones I use for âserious listeningâ but itâs more than adequate for exercising where thereâs a lot of background noise from my treadmill - and Iâll take durability over less than top-shelf sound for this purpose.Thereâs a simple, easy to grab volume adjustment along the outside of one phone rim â thatâs all I need.  Forget about phone calls â the world can wait for the hour Iâm exercising.

I received a free item to review.The drive was recognized on Windows 7 32 and 64-bit machines without requiring a driver installation.I like that the spring ejects the disc (as well as the empty caddy) a good inch and a half outwards, unlike my laptop's built-in drive that often barely ejects a half inch. Speaking of eject, I wish the button protruded a bit more from the door front. I find it's easier to press while leaning over the top of the drive from the back and using my index finger, rather than my thumb from the front.The cord is short, perhaps 18 inches. But it's fairly heavy-duty and fine for laptop use, though not ideal for desktops.The instructions warn not to use front panel desktop USB ports due to insufficient power - but I ignored this. I already plug an external Memorex burner into the front port of my 8+ year old Dell Dimension E521. I linked the RUBAN drive and the Memorex with a passive 4-port USB hub and had no problem reading or burning with the RUBAN drive.I also used the drive on a 3 year-old corporate-issued Lenovo laptop straight into a USB port with similar results.I was able to play and burn CDs as well as single and double-sided DVD-ROMs (8.4 GB capacity). I go back to 2x burners in the 90's that had very little underrun tolerance (and with blank HP CD-ROMs originally going for $25 a pop, write errors were an expensive proposition).Although newer software packages like Nero include underrun protection options I still prefer to leave the machine alone while burning and recommend others do as well.Bottom line: 24x burning is adequate for my needs. The RUBAN drive reads/writes fine, and feels well-made and easy-to-use. Cosmetically, I like the flat matte finish, the strong spring response, and the sturdiness of the cord.

As a straightforward (monophonic) tuner the Polytune works well-enough, although the clip hinge has less mobility (i.e. no swivel) than some smaller clip-on tuners which makes headstock positioning more critical.Iâm a lefty and, whatever gyro-detection itâs using, the tuner really does flip the displayed pitch letters - a nice touch to an already bright, easy-to-read display â at least in basic âStrobeâ mode.But a combination of unfortunate design choices and poor instructions left me with a mixed impression.The larger power button along the narrow side of the tuner is easy to press with minimal force while Iâm wearing the guitar in playing position. But the two buttons on the longer edge, one to toggle the display between âStrobeâ and âNeedleâ modes, and the other to select chromatic pitches are both too small and recessed too far into the case to be comfortable and easy to press. I have to jam my fingernail to press them and for one particular function â setting the reference pitch - you have to hold both down simultaneously, which is a neat trick to pull off.I wish there were more rubber on the spring clip arm surface and directly in front of the spring. Itâs not difficult to scrape that exposed metal along the edge of a headstock where any finish provides less protection. Iâd recommend thin electrical tape to cover those areas without impacting smooth operation.I agree with a point made in the instructions about not keeping the tuner attached âpermanentlyâ, especially in direct sunlight (Iâd add very warm/hot environments). Rubber and lacquer donât play well under heat â I learned the hard way by damaging a vintage Gibson finish by leaving a guitar on a stand with rubber contacts in a hot room several summers back.As far as the display of âpolyphonicâ 6-string tuning of chords, it only seems to appear and remain briefly before the tuner reverts to âmonophonicâ mode and registers what must be the fundamental chord pitch. You strum a chord and see six pairs of alignment bars that stay until the chord resolves itself to its most âpresentâ pitch, which in root position tends to be the root of the chord.Rather than full chords, I tune to a variety of double stops and triads: mostly octaves, 5ths, 4ths and 3rds. Every guitar intonates differently depending on a host of factors and, to be honest, at this point I rely on my ears more than a tuner once I have a reference pitch.But I was curious to see how the Polytune handled intervals:Sure enough, the full chord behavior of reverting the display to the fundamental seems to apply to smaller two and three note dyads and triads - except the polyphonic display doesnât appear at all. When I play ascending fifths simultaneously the bottom tone always displays in the tuner. If I play the higher fifth immediately after sounding the pair, so long as the bottom tone is still sounding the tuner continues to register it. As soon as I stop sounding the lower pitch, the upper pitch registers.This applies to fourths (inverted fifths) as well. When playing G-C ascending as a double stop the C registers in the tuner and will continue so long as itâs sounding.If I tune to a full five or six string chord (usually the last step in the process, just to confirm) Iâm listening for particular pitches that are off, which may or may not be the root. The tuner isn't helping me by confirming the root is in tune if other pitches are out.Iâm willing to accept I may be missing something here, but the instructions are so minimal â and I consider myself fairly savvy about equipment, having played for many years â that I just fail to see the value beyond a basic âmonophonicâ tuner that works well with a display that I'd say is  steps above those tiny monochrome LED chicklet-sized clip-on tuners.Bottom Line: Iâm not sure if thereâs adequate value here, but the display and response for single-string tuning is certainly adequate.As for me, if I have to use a tuner, I grab my old-school Korg AT1-AC from the 80âs, with the long cord and clip-on sensor thatâs perfect for guitar, mandolin, and fiddle â it still works fine and the back-lit needle is even easier for me to read and I know its response very well.

I received a free item to review.If this cutter is truly better than the 'inferior imitations' for sale on Amazon, I'd hate to see how those perform - because this one is flat-out useless.I tried positioning the cutter close to the cork end, as well as further down the neck, holding it while turning either the cutter or the bottle itself. But neither action put more than a surface scratch on the foil. While the plastic cutter frame is not what I'd call delicate or brittle I'm not completely at ease 'wish-boning' the sides out to place around even a normal sized bottle neck. My concern is were the cutter frame to snap it could deliver a nasty gash to my hand and fingers.I examined the cutters - they're not especially sharp and seem to be set too far back into the frame for adequate surface contact.All I know is in the time it took to try this thing out I could have used my 'scratch with the cork remover tip'  technique and removed the foil from at least 3-4 wine bottles.A disappointment to say the least.

I haven't mailed a non-commercial postcard of my own in at least ten (twenty?) years and I'm not going to pretend that's my experience with these blanks. But I am a compulsive note-taker, list-maker, jotter-downer, occasional-drawer/doodler, music notator, and bookmark-improviser who always keeps plenty of stationary on hand.And this mid-weight postcard stock is a welcome addition: The sheet perforations are extremely fine and easy to tear off and the non-glare eggshell white stock is finish and texture consistent on both sides. I printed five pages worth (four cards per sheet) of color Thank You note templates on my HP LaserJet in a single run with no jamming or mis-feeds. The colors look crisp and vivid, with no smudges or bleeding.Bottom Line: These laser postcard blanks clearly work well for their intended use. But for me they'll be sitting in my 'grab-something' stack for whatever comes my way worth taking note of.

The discussions of testing/performance-monitoring tools including HTTP Archive, WebPageTest, and Boomerang are not enough to make anyone an expert (or even proficient) but enough to expose you to their basic capabilities and steer you in the direction of deeper knowledge.The large number of footnote links is a real strength of the book: well-chosen, appearing at appropriate points in the text, and easy to read.The code for the book is easy to grab from github and thereâs an assumed level of expertise as far as basic HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, as well as maintaining web pages and accessing the developer tools inside various browsers.But itâs not necessary to be a JavaScript or HTML guru to get important lessons from this book. In fact, the most important ideas are not coding idioms and tricks, itâs understanding how website performance is influenced by content, how to sell this to your local group and the broader organization, how to manage and manipulate content to improve performance, and what tools and techniques are available to help you in this effort.I found it eye-opening to shift my perceptions a bit and view websites in terms of Measurable Performance Modules (MPMs) and average number of requests (queries) versus average size of âpayload returnedâ.The early chapter on perceived performance is very well done, taking into account the psychological aspects of user-responses in the ever-faster, ever-more-impatience world everyoneâs site is operating in â like it or not.Rather than hard core developers, Iâm tempted to say the ideal audience here is senior tech leads and group managers who need to understand the technical ins-and-outs mostly in order to explain and sell them to higher, non-technical folks.If thereâs a negative, the overall production value of the book and the graphics in particular are often too small to enjoy without a magnifier in hand(!). But the writing is very clean and informative, with a minimum of jargon, and that more than compensates for the âlo-fiâ production vibe.Finally, thereâs an irony and a lesson in relative perception here for anyone old enough to recall how slow early websites were. I can well remember watching images take forever to load compared to desktop and local client/server applications and thinking to myself, âThis web stuff is a sham. No one will ever accept this step backwards in performanceâ.  Yeah, no one.

With the glut of earphones, headphones, buds, etc. on the market it's tempting to imagine them all made from the same base components at some Chinese factory and simply customized per casing and brand.But listening experience suggests otherwise and, for anyone seriously interested in audio, I would recommend direct A-B comparisons using the same set of music â ideally each piece featuring various instruments, textures, ambience, and frequency span.Itâs really enlightening and just plain fun to uncover real and often dramatic differences in relative signal strength, frequency response as well as the overall 'voicing' of the devices that can drastically alter the clarity and warmth of what you hear.I compared the Bose earphones to two sets of Brainwavz earphones and a no-name import brand that impressed me with its bass response.The Bose phones have neither the richest bass response nor the shimmering top end, but what they have hands-down over the other phones is amazing clarity and superior gain - even compared to some full over the ear headphone phones I own.Clarity in this case means the instrumental separation and detail is at the forefront and not obscured by excessive bass (donât get me wrong, I love bass, but not overall muddiness). The other phones sounded either more-distance, with excessive high-end, or unbalanced compared to the Bose.Just for kicks I tried the Bose phones in a non-musical context (an online class) and they performed great â although I wish the cable were a couple of feet longer for plugging into a desktop computer rather than a portable phone or player.While sound is job one a very close second is comfort and the Bose phones really shine here for me. For some reason a lot of âdeep earâ phones are flat out uncomfortable for me to wear - with or without the surrounding hook. If you wear these things in public whether at work or while commuting you going to have to take them out occasionally and doing that comfortably makes a real difference.As someone famously described talking about music, talking about sound is like dancing about architecture so I can only repeat my earlier suggestion: gather together a bunch of phones, choose some music you enjoy listening to and know well, and go round-robin. Youâll learn things I promise - and you just may decide to hang onto multiple pairs of phones for different kinds of listening.

I receive a free item to review.I don't use the lamp on a desk, I use it on my shop bench for close-up woodworking with a magnifier. The gooseneck really holds a bend and allows a tight radius at the top to keep the light well below eyelevel - important for me with LED light otherwise I feel a slight sensitivity when it's in my direct or perpiheral eyesight line. Psychosomatic or not, it bugs me and is the opposite of relaxing.Plenty of outlets in the shop and I like the AC adaptor so I don't have to worry about batteries or charging.The sliding brightness switch is a great feature while I'm working - easy to swipe with minimal disruption (and requiring minimal leverage while holding work, tools, and glue) - and I really use the different settings to beat close-up glare. LED lamps can get warm but this one doesn't give off an excessive amount of heat.Bottom Line: Attractive lamp that gives strong, steady light, easy to operate and store, does the job. I'm happy with it.

For me, the most worthwhile are the selections from Virtuoso 2 and perhaps a single line solo from a personal favorite, (the underrated, I think)  'Intercontinental'.But if you're interested mostly in chord-solo transcriptions (and let's face it, as solid as Joe's line work was, it's chord melody that set him apart and is the main reason he's remembered today) - there's entirely too much from the early Pacific Jazz era including things available elsewhere. You'll likely be far better off zeroing in on what you want from the Mel Bay-published transcriptions and/or Wolf Marshall's ("Explore the style of") series.Bottom line for me: Unless you absolutely must have everything, there's just not enough of interest here to justify the purchase.

The cable I received was defective right out of the package.  I plugged my Galaxy Note 10.1 into my computer and tried to copy files over, but the transfers kept stalling and never finished.  I switched back to another (OEM) cable I had, and the files copied over in seconds.

This app is basically a digital version of the US Army Field Manual 3-05.70 (formerly FM 21-76), probably the most popular Army Field Manual of all time.  While it is primarily geared towards a soldier lost in the field, with chapters such as "Survival Movement in Hostile Areas" and "Camouflage", the majority of the manual is useful for civilians as well.  The manual includes information on first aid, obtaining shelter, water and food, lighting a fire, expedient weapons and tools, dangerous plants and animals, direction finding, signaling, and surviving in the desert, tropics, arctic or at sea.I noticed there are some glaring errors in the app.  In particular, several of the images for the edible plants in Appendix B are obviously wrong.  The photo for asparagus shows a tree!  The photo for the baobab shows onions, the photo for beech shows some kind of grass-like plant, and the entry for banana has an incorrect photo as well.This app appears to have been lifted from a website, though since there are several websites containing the same erroneous photos, likely all copied from one another, it's hard to say which.While Amazon's website mentions nothing at all about permissions, this app does call on the Modify/Delete SD Card Contents and Read Phone State and Identity permissions.  It can't really do much with that information, fortunately, since it lacks permissions to access the Internet.FM 3-05.70 and its predecessor FM 21-76 are readily available on the Internet for free.  If you don't want to pay the 99 cents for this app, you can easily find it in webpage or PDF form using Google.

Sudoku Samurai is a very pretty version of the famous number puzzle.  You can select different Japanese watercolor backgrounds and you can even choose to use Kanji instead of Western numerals.Unfortunately, the actual game play leaves a lot to be desired.  To enter a number, you have to tap on the cell, then tap on the number.  This means filling in notes becomes a tedious process of tapping cell, number, cell, number, cell, number, cell, number, cell, number, over and over again.  There is no option to tap on the number first, then all the cells you want to fill in, a much faster method and the one I prefer.The game also does not automatically clear your notes when you fill in a cell.  You have to remove your notes manually, using the same tedious cell, number, cell, number.The interface can be a bit confusing unless you read the instructions.  Tap the brush to switch between pencil and pen; the only visual indication of which mode you are in is the amount of ink on the brush. The doll in the upper right gives you hints, the lantern in the upper left is the back button.  Tapping the beads on the left undoes your last entry, while the sword clears the entire board.The transitions between screens is extremely slow, with a paper screen closing and opening.  The game crashed several times on my Motorola Xoom tablet during one of these transitions.This app was built using Corona, which means it's chock full of data miners, including OpenFeint, Papaya Social, Flurry, AdKnowledge, InMobi and Inneractive.  It calls on the Full Internet Access, Read Phone State and Identity, and Access Network State permissions.Overall, it's a beautiful app, marred by a clunky interface and a bounty of data harvesters.

Mysteryville is a fairly basic hidden-object game.  I made as far as level 4 before dying of boredom; there was only one spot-the-difference puzzle, all the rest were just finding stuff.I was unable to zoom in or move around in any of the puzzles.  Every touch on the screen counted as a mistake, regardless of what I was trying to do.Why does every house in a hidden object game look like it should be on the TV show Hoarders?  And why is it nobody in these games will ever help you unless you clean up their mess?  Just imagine if you ever had to go to the hospital. "Oh dear, you're bleeding all over the place.  Help me pick up a few things first then I'll put a bandage on that."Some of the characters are highly stereotyped, almost to the point of racism, particularly the Chinese guy in chapter 3.  "Then you dlink, blave girl."  Really?The real hidden objects in this game, however, are the hidden data mining modules.
