I purchased this at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion...and I am glad I did. Whenever I had been working out, I have been putting my phone upside down in an old armband I had used in the Army to hold my ID card overseas. The Flexion is amazing. It fits my iPhone perfectly, the touchscreen works through the plastic, there is no way it is falling out, and it has a hole for headphones (if you don't have bluetooth). I have yet to run with it, but I also like to have music while doing yardwork and this has made it a breeze.It has not slipped or fallen down my arm once, no matter what kind of bending, lifting, or twisting I do. The material is neoprene and is soft, stretchy, and super comfortable. It is machine washable which is a plus and has a lifetime warranty. I will be purchasing another one for my wife and can't recommend it enough.

After 30 days of continuous rain, Texas has been dealing with Texas sized mosquitoes. We wanted to try this out for our newborn as we didn't want to spray him down with harsh chemicals.The bracelet is well made and the scent inserts are extremely strong. We ended up attaching it to the stroller and were shocked that none of us got a single bite when we went on a long walk. Mosquitoes LOVE ME and can smell dinner through deet - I am so glad we found a natural product that works.I received this product at a discount for my honest and unbiased review. I do a lot of work outside and get bitten by mosquitoes constantly. This is a game changer.

I spent 8 years in the Army and this is the same type of material that we used as the good 'ol PT belt. This harness is excellent for providing visibility in low light situations and is extremely comfortable. I have actually replaced my old PT belt with this for my early morning runs as it is far more visible and still extremely comfortable. I also like how it provides a lot of visibility without the weight or discomfort of a full on vest.While it stretches easily, it feels sturdy and secure and I am confident it will last for a long time. If you are looking for something that is extremely reflective and is lightweight and comfortable at the same time, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.

I am an avid wine, whiskey, and beer drinker and absolutely love these things. You can keep your drink cold without ruining it by watering it down. I have used these in scotch/bourbon, white wine, and a beer that I left out just long enough to get warm and I am impressed at how quickly they cooled the drinks down and how long they stayed cold. I didn't notice any flavor changes either, which is important.As for the product itself...make sure you wash everything when you get it. That should go without saying, but do it. The soapstone had some dust that got on the stainless cubes as well. No big deal, just wash. I like the fact that it has a tray that can easily fit in any freezer and keeps everything together and away from touching something that might get into your drink.If you are a drinker who likes to keep their booze cold without watering it down, I highly recommend this combo set. 4 of each is enough to keep a couple in your drink and a couple in the freezer - and you can switch them out.

First and foremost, I received this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review - so here it is.This portable charger is pretty cool. I left my charger at home and my phone got down to about 3% at work today. I plugged it in and it started charging right away and started charging quickly. It is worth noting that I had not yet plugged it in, I just opened the package and plugged it in - so they ship it with a charge.I wasn't sure how I would feel about a bracelet for a portable charger, but it is easy to still use the phone while charging. The way it was designed allows for a natural grip on the phone without the charger getting in the way or falling off of your lap, table, etc.The bracelet comes with a charging cable with USB to Micro USB. You can charge the bracelet via a wall wort or your computer's USB port. It also comes with a Micro USB to Micro USB cable with an attached lightning adapter. The product description incorrectly lists it as a mini USB when it is in fact, a micro. So this will work with iPhones and other Samsung, LG, etc. phones with a micro USB.You can tell that this is water resistant, it has a smooth black silicone-like cover over the internal battery segments. The only thing keeping this from being totally waterproof is the flap that covers the micro USB input. When closed, I have faith that normal use and light splashing won't damage this - just don't go swimming with it and be careful while washing your hands.The bracelet charges your phone pretty quickly and charges up when connected to a USB port fairly quickly too. FYI, your phone charged much more quickly when you turn off WiFi and Bluetooth. I turn them off before connecting to the charger and just let it sit and do its thing for a while. It takes a couple presses/a long press of the top button to start charging your phone, but you can feel the phone vibrate or make noise when it starts getting power from the bracelet.Overall, this is a fantastic idea and is executed well. I like the ergonomics of being able to use my phone while charging it. If I am at my desk, I can just leave the bracelet flat out on the table while charging and put it on if I need to be mobile. If you are looking for a mobile charger for your phone, I recommend considering this - it is well made, convenient, and well thought out.

This thing is a life saver. We were out of ground coffee and only had beans...but no grinder, and I was able to get this in exchange for my honest and unbiased review. This little guy came through and easily ground through the beans that we threw at it. The nice thing about a manual grinder like this is that you are able to control how coarse/fine the grind is.One thing to note, I do not think these are dishwasher safe. I washed it by hand as soon as I received it, but make sure that you wash it by hand - it is easy enough to do as it is so compact and you don't want to risk ruining it! It is quiet and easy to grind small amounts for maximum coffee freshness.

Like many other reviewers, I tested this with a piece of paper as I didn't want to risk the phone in case it didn't work. I am happy to report that it did in fact work - it is totally waterproof.It is large enough to fit my iPhone5s and had plenty of room if I wanted to throw some other things like keys in there. The touch screen was easy to use through the plastic. One thing to consider is that water does get in-between the plastic tabs so you have to make sure you are careful when you open it up and remove your phone.I think that this is great solution for keeping your phone dry if you are going to be around water. While it did protect the paper in my pool experiment, I have a hard time trusting one piece of equipment to keep something as valuable as my phone safe.

I was thrilled to be able to order these at a discount for my honest and unbiased review. That being said, I put these to the test over the course of a few days. I used them with metal and glass in the oven, pots and pans on the stove, and on the BBQ. They have performed flawlessly and I am extremely impressed with the dexterity and heat protection these offer. I didn't feel any heat through them from anything the entire time. They are also a breeze to clean - I just threw them on the top rack of the dishwasher. Highly recommended.

I bought this yoga towel for the wife and she is absolutely THRILLED with it. She had to throw away her last yoga mat because it absorbed sweat and smelled terrible. When I was offered a chance to review this product at a discounted price for an honest and unbiased review, I jumped at it. She took both the towel and the mat to a hot yoga class and came home raving about how great they both are. The towel is comfortable, didnât slip, and kept her mat dry. She loves the feel and the fact that the color matches her mat. The seller is also extremely communicative and made sure that everything was good with the order via email. They also provided a friendly and helpful reminder on the best way to wash the towel to make sure it lasts.

I bought this yoga mat for the wife and she is absolutely THRILLED with it. Her last yoga mat had a terrible smell and was thin and uncomfortable. She loves everything about it, from the color and thickness to the lack of smell and carrying strap. I will admit that I know very little about yoga mats (or these products in general), but she has let me know that I did an awesome job â so thanks for that!I also got her the yoga towel as it is recommended for hot yoga, which she also loves. First off, I received this item at a discounted rate in exchange for an honest review and I donât know how I functioned without it. I am a heavy Waze user and stream music via Bluetooth and used to throw the phone in the cup holder and call it good. After some messing around with the positioning, I found that it works best for me in one of the vents. The included clip fits securely and the phone has not fallen or moved at all, even with rough road and quick turns.The clip is adjustable and holds the phone securely in the mount, I am impressed with the quality design â it works well. If you are looking for a versatile mount, I highly recommend this one. There is enough flexibility for you to test out the setup that works best for you, your phone, and your vehicle. I had planned on using the suction mount, but found that the vent clip worked best. I was so impressed with this mount, I ordered one for my wife and I am sure she will love it as much as I do.

I purchased this to use in a beer keg refrigerator and it doesn't work. I have a humidity gauge in there and it remains the same whether this unit is in there or not. There is absolutely no change in the humidity. I have never seen the beads turn pink and there is moisture on the sides as well as on the bottom inside the fridge.Even though the beads are purple, I plugged it in to see if that would fix anything. After charging and putting back in the fridge, still nothing.I am disappointed that this doesn't work, I will have to figure out another solution to keep moisture from building up. Buyer beware.

The only pocket knives I use are Kershaw Leeks. This knife has a smooth assist and came extremely sharp. It can stand up to my daily abuse, and is much easier to clean than the partially serrated Leek.This is truly an amazing knife and I would recommend it to anyone who needs a quality knife that wont break the bank. Buy this, you wont be disappointed

I use this in my kegorater and it lets me know the temperature and humidity. It is accurate, easy to use, and has a magnetic back, making it super convenient to stick on the inside of the refrigerator. Temperature and humidity work well, even with prolonged exposure to cold temperature. If you need something for brewing or storage, this is perfect. It also would be convenient to use in other areas of the house.Highly recommended

This is a super simple brush. I like the holder as it opens up when you pull the brush up and closes when you place it back down. There is a little drip tray in there too, so any leftover water will evaporate. That is a nice feature.As for the brush itself, the bristles are nice and stiff and it does a great job cleaning. I highly recommend these...and again, I have one in every single bathroom in my house.

The wife loves this iron, it works extremely well and has a lot of cool features. We were especially excited about the cord being retractable and staying out of the way.Sadly after about a month or 2 of use, the cord has trouble retracting back into the iron. We now have to hold down the button and kind of push the cable in. Even after we force the cord back in, the best we can do still leaves 3-4 inches of cord exposed. Aside from the shoddy cord retraction design, this is a nice iron.

I was a little worried about how this would handle my water pressure and after installing (and removing the restrictors) I am happy to say that it works well. It looks great, performs well, and has excellent water pressure.The nice thing is that they even provide instructions on how to remove the water flow regulators with the unit. I have not seen any that do so as clearly and with pictures! It looks and feels like a good quality product and it has held up for me so far. I have had shower heads with cheap plastic tubing that twists too easily for the removable head. This one does not have that problem. Highly Recommended

I got this for my 2011 Convertible and it fits perfectly. It is extremely well made and isnt too bulky when folded or rolled up. I simply fold it up and throw it in the back seat and it is good to go.It fits perfectly along the inside of the windshield and the visors hold it in place. It kept the car cool in the hot Texas summer, so it had a trial by fire and came out on top. Absolutely love it.

The pictures really dont do this watch justice, it is beautiful. I bought one for my wife and she absolutely loves it. It really is a classic look and the details (like the shiny hour markers) really make this watch awesome for the price.The only thing is that this watch comes BIG. I think they had to remove 7 or 8 links to get it down to my wife's wrist size. I tried it on, and it was too big for me...and I am not a small guy. A quick trip to the jewelry store to get it sized and all is well. I can't recommend this enough, it is stunning.

I bought a pair of these for my wife and she absolutely loves them. She calls them her "comfy pants" and wears them like pijamas. They are true to size, dont show through, and stay up. She also tells me that they are super comfortable and wants a couple more pairs.Repeat business is the best kind of review, and they got ours.

I ordered these for the wife and she absolutely loves them. They stay up, dont show through, and work perfectly for her. They are true to size and the colors are more vivid than in the pictures. Looks like I will be buying some of the other colors...

I bought this to spray our back patio and I am impressed with the power. I used it on stained concrete and it worked so well, it blasted the stain off. The 2 nozzles easily handle anything I have thrown at it (concrete, siding, my cars) and it performs like a champ.The only reason I gave it 4 stars is that it is a pain to set up and break down. The holders in the back dont grip the wands very well, so they are always falling off. Everything is tedious to set up and break down. Other than that minor issue, the pressure washer performs quite well. I am happy I ordered it and I have (and do) recommend it to my buddies looking for one for themselves.

I purchased this to use for IDPA for my 1911 single stack .45 mags. It works well and holds the magazines snugly. The reason for only 4 stars is that it was unnecessarily difficult to adjust the width of the belt side on this thing. It really was more difficult than it needed to be.I had to modify one of these to take mags from a S&W M&P shield 9mm since it seems their mags are 1.5 stack. It was simple enough to switch out the screws for longer ones and it works just as well.

I bought a couple of these for yard maintenance and shooting. The noise reduction works well and they are comfortable to wear for long periods of time. The only issue I have with them is that they are still bulky when they are "folded up" after use. They dont fold in on the headband like all the other hearing protection I have used in the past.Not a deal breaker and they are still nice ear protection, just thought yall should know.

I ordered this for the wife and she absolutely loves it. I was a bit worried about some of the negative reviews, but so far we havent had any problems and it has been used almost daily. Packaging was sufficient and it didnt arrive damaged. The board feels sturdy and has stood up to our moderate daily use without any issues.When we are not using it, we fold it up and hang it on the wall. It feels like a quality product and the iron rest is a nice touch. No problems holding onto our iron and the rubber area hasnt melted or scorched. I would recommend this to anyone as I know how hard it is to find an ironing board that isnt a piece of junk. This one is it!

I ordered this for my wife for IDPA for her S&W Shield 9mm. The weapon fits snugly in and doesnt move unless you pull it out. The fit and finish look very nice and it feels like a quality product. I was a bit hesitant to order this sight unseen, but it was one of the few OWB holsters made specifically for the Shield and it fits perfectly.

I was starting to see dust and a layer of film on the inside of my windshield. I checked the filter and it was extremely dirty. I ordered one of these and replacement took about 10 minutes.It was super easy to replace and the dust/film havent come back since I changed it.

I was skeptical at how this would perform as opposed to an electronic one. I absolutely love this. It works every single time and the power of the magnets is surprising. It is now my go to for finding studs. Way better than knocking...

I was in the market for a mount for the 55" and was shocked to see how much other brands were charging. I purchased the cheetah mount without even realizing that it came with the HDMI cable. I was able to assemble it fairly quickly (15 minutes) and after drilling a few holes in the wall, I was good to go.It comes with A LOT of screws/bolts/washers for every imaginable type of setup. Once the TV was mounted (securely) I drilled some larger holes for the cords. My old HDMI cable would have been too short to use, but thankfully this came with one that is nice and long.Look at the price/features of other brands and you would be surprised. This is a quality product at a reasonable price and I can tell you from my own experience that this is the way to go. Im satisfied and recommend it to all.

My wife and I were moving and our old vacuum had been losing suction for quite some time. We moved into a house and the previous owners had dogs. The house smelled like dog. The wife was using a carpet cleaner and it kept pulling up hair clumps and getting stuck. We vacuumed with the old vacuum and cleaned the carpet with an upright cleaner with solution 3 times. I decided on this model since we have 2 cats and anxiously waited for its arrival. The wife wasn't happy with the price, but hey you get what you pay for. As soon as it arrived, we had it assembled within 10 minutes and started to vacuum the old carpet.This is where I fell in love with this vacuum:The amount of dust, dirt, sand, hair, and other stuff that came out of the carpet of ONE ROOM was unbelievable. Even after several cleanings and a few passes with the old vacuum, the amount that was left behind was disgustingly unbelievable. We used it on the rest of the carpets with the same result. The once overpowering dog smell had been removed. The wife was an immediate convert. We have been using this a couple of times a week and we are still amazed at how much it pulls out of the carpets.The attachments and tools that come with this version are invaluable. The cats like to chill on the microfiber couches, but a little attention with the attachments easily takes care of that. It is easy to empty the plastic bin and we do it every time just to see how much we are actually picking up when we use it.I have never been this excited about a vacuum...and I didnt know one could be excited about a vacuum.The only negatives that I can see with it are minor and have been discussed in other reviews:Tips over easilyRequires a bit of force to get that click when standing it uprightRequires full unwrapping of the cord to use the hose featureAll of these are minor. I am completely satisfied and I absolutely love this vacuum. I recommend it to anyone that will hear it, even if they are not pet owners. The price is up there, but the quality of the product is second to none. If you are in the market for a new vacuum, this one is it.

I wanted to get a quality flag for the front of the house and after much research, I landed on this one. The quality is there and it looks like it will hold up to the elements nicely. The flag has not wrapped a single time, so as far as I can tell the spinning pole works well.If I ever need another one, I will most likely go for this exact product again. It looks great, is sturdy, and the price is right.

I bought this to replace an older model in our new home. I was able to install it quickly and easily.After getting it all set up and on the network (which was a breeze), I noticed that the AC would turn off after about 5 minutes of use. I did some more research and found that even though my old unit didnt need the common (blue) wire, this one did. After connecting the common wire, I have had ZERO problems with the nest and I am going to purchase another for the upstairs.The fit/finish of the unit is excellent. It looks awesome on the wall and it performs extremely well. I know for a fact that this is saving us on our energy bill because I would forget to change the temperature on the old upstairs thermostat and it would still be running where the Nest's auto-away feature would keep the down stairs off while I am at work. The mobile ap is straightforward, but I would like to see a little more functionality out of it. It is easy to change the temperature from anywhere and it isnt enough for me to dock a star.Awesome product, I will be buying another one, and I highly recommend it to all who are looking. Just make sure your system is compatible and you will be good to go.

I purchased this primarily because our AC had a blocked drain and was leaking. This caused a giant puddle of standing water, which is a no go. I unpacked and assembled and within minutes, I was amazed at how well this vac performs. I was able to suck up all of the water after emptying it only once, showing me that it has a decent capacity for its size. I again was amazed at how well it handled that much water.It is easy to disassemble and clean/dry out and I have since been able to use it to pick up dry dirt, dust, etc. After properly cleaning and drying the filter, this little guy is and has been back in action and performing extremely well. I cant recommend this enough, it works and it works well.

I use a leather zipper binder that holds a notepad for everyday business use. When I ran out of paper, I came to Amazon to find a replacement and I am extremely happy with my purchase.The price is right, it fits in the notebook, and it is a quality product.Pros:Price (Buy more and save more)Quality - It is nice paper to write onPerforation - Unlike some other reviewers' experiences, I find that the pages are easy to pull out and I have had no tears so far.Cons:As some have mentioned, the cardboard on the back is a bit flimsy. Its not really a factor for me since the paper is being used in a rigid folder.Conclusion:I will order more of this brand when I run out. It is hard to find notepads that fit exactly what you want/need and this is it for me. Recommended

I ordered this because I needed a binder that would zip shut.Pros:Well thought out pocket design, it has zippers and velcro that makes things easier to store.The carrying handle on the spine makes it a lot easier to transportThe color is bright, which makes it easier to remember and harder to loseCons:None so far, but I am keeping an eye on the main compartment zipper. It feels a bit cheap and flimsy to me, but it has not had any issues so far.

I needed a belt for daily wear because the last one's buckle separated from the leather. I have been wearing this daily for a month and a half and it is holding up very well.At any rate, here are my thoughts.Pros:Well constructed and it feels like it will lastBelt buckle is darker than pictured (it looks great)Stitching is black on the black side (also looks great)It is easy to reverse if you need to, simply pull the buckle away from the belt and twist itCons:The sizing info was a bit off. I am a 34 waist and I ordered a L. I have to wear it on the very last hole on the belt. I should have listened to the reviews and ordered a Medium. Word to the wise, the belt sizes run a bit big so factor that in!Conclusion:I really like this belt. I wear it everyday and it has held up extremely well. I am tired of buying new belts that break after 6 months of casual use or 3 months of continuous daily use. This is a quality belt that feels like it will last. Highly recommended.

After growing my hair out a bit, I had determined that I needed a comb. I used to have an old black tail comb that disappeared a few years ago.Now to find a replacement...the amazon search returned few results that were similar to the one I used to have at a decent price. Then I stumbled across these little gems. They feel solid and fit in my toothbrush holder, too easy.Pros:CheapThere are 2 of themThey work wellThey are not rough on the scalpCons:None so farConclusion:Its a comb. Actually it is 2. They are cheap and work well, I recommend them without reservation.

I was a little concerned when I saw how many people complained about the burning. I tried it and the first few times, it did burn. Was it bad? Not really.This is mouthwash that is designed to kill germs and maintain oral health. I have noticed that I have gotten used to it and now it is more of a tingling than a burning, but it has been a couple of weeks. I like this product and in my experience, the mild discomfort is brief and well worth the benefits of a mouthwash that works well and whitens.To those concerned about the burn: try it out and you will see that it really isn't that bad. This product deserves better than to be blasted by people who are unwilling to endure mild discomfort for the overall greater health of their teeth and gums.

The other reviewers have pretty much got this one right, it is the best hair gel I have used to date. I have relatively short hair and it holds it in place. Having black hair has always been tough because it is easy to see when other gels flake white.The only drawback to this is that when you put it on, it takes a while to harden. I have found that an easy fix is to use a hair dryer and comb to get it exactly how you want it and dry it more quickly. Once in place, it stays.I would recommend it for a strong hold without the nasty crust. It also smells pretty good too.You wont be disappointed

1:49 MinsThis is the unboxing of Dockers Mens Extra Capacity Slimfold Leather Wallet.Credit cards, IDs, and other types of standard wallet things fit in there quite well. The sections hold the cards in place without being too tight. I like this wallet much more than my previous and it is much slimmer.Pros:Build qualityLooksFeelPriceCons:non-removable middle ID sectionConclusion:Overall I dont think that the ID part being non removable is a bad thing. This wallet is soft and is constructed well. I have no doubts it will stand up to the punishment I will give it...sadly not from overflowing with cash...Highly recommended

I received the cable and was pleasantly surprised at the quality. It arrived packaged well and was exactly as described. One of the other reviewers stated that the cable was blue and I received a black one, so I dont know what that is all about. It was solid, heavy, and well constructed. I used it to patch into my receiver from a phono preamp and couldnt be more pleased with the sound quality. It was long enough and does its job. It is a simple RCA cable that works well and is inexpensive. The ends of the cord are split apart, but the middle portion of the cable are joined into one.Pros:PriceDesignFunctionLooksCons:None so farConclusion:This is perfect for someone who needs a simple RCA cable. It is worth mentioning that it has an extra little wire on it that kind of looks like a grounding wire for both ends. I don't need it for my application of it but others might and it is worth mentioning. If I needed another cable, I wouldnt hesitate to buy another of this brand and I am sure it would last quite some time.

While the Springfrield XD(m) series weapons come with a holster, the holster is incompatible with any add-on rail-mounted device.  The supplied holster also relies on friction for retention, which I've never quite been comfortable with.I own a tactical (thigh-mount) holster, as well, though it also isn't compatible with rail-mounted devices.  I far prefer that, and have used it largely exclusively until recently.My XD(m) has trijicon night sights installed, but I wanted the option of a laser-sight and/or tactical light.  I tried a guide-rod laser (a wonderful concept, but poorly executed, and thus largely useless, but the only option compatible with a standard holster, best suitable, really, for aligning the iron sights).  I have a boresight laser (which, unfortunately, does not work well with the XD(m)'s ejector mechanism, giving a false boresight location and thus being largely useless for this weapon).  So, I realized I needed a rail-mounted device.  Unfortunately, but inevitablly, this also means new holsters.So, I bought this as a replacement for the waistband holster provided by Springfield, and I absolutely LOVE it for that purpose.  While very slightly higher-profile than the stock holster, it is adjustable (to one of several different draw angles, using tools), is more comfortable at my waist, and most importantly of all, it has a mechanical latch which means that drawing is far easier than a "friction-retained" holster.  The latch is ideally located...  put your trigger finger on this latch, depress, draw, and your finger is properly located either for the "safe hold" position, in front of the trigger along the barrel slide direction (and on top of the activation button for the laser/light), or, very easily, right onto the trigger (if you're in a "sudden action" situation).I'm very, very happy with this holster for that reason.  But even better, this has a feature which will deactivate your Veridian sight when holstering your weapon, saving power, but (if holstered while active) will immediately return your firearm accessory to the same operating mode upon drawing the weapon.  It's really very convenient, unless you'd prefer to draw without anything on (in which case, just holster the weapon with the laser/light deactivated, and it will return to that same mode, of course).For this weapon/light combo, you don't have many options (I've also found a nylon fabric thigh-holster compatible with it, thankfully).  But the good thing is that this holster, along with this light, is a nearly perfect solution.

I've had a pair of Databank watches for quite some time...  a 150 and a 300 version.  I made the fatal error of taking my 150 to a "watch repair shop" to get the battery changed, at some point, and then next time did it myself (as I usually do).  And I discovered that the repair shop had failed to replace the o-ring seal...  which I knew would eventually result in the watch failing.Well, recently, it did.  The 150's module is totally non-functional.  And my 300 is almost too valuable to wear anymore.  I wanted something new.  This watch is the last version which is (mostly) compatible with those earlier watched.  It comes in several variants, so I bought a silver one and a black one.  This review relates to both versions.This is a pretty decent watch, comparable to the older (and better) versions in most ways.  It has a lot less available data memory (which seems odd, doesn't it?) and no longer has the "Indiglo" electroluminescent backlight) which is wonderful, instead merely using white surface-mount LEDs to reflect light inside the case.  And, of course, it loses the "countdown timer" function (which I almost never used, anyway).But the calculator functionality is equivalent to, and in one way better, the earlier models.  This has a built-in "currency conversion" mode (really just a single memory which you can multiply your entries by) which does come in handy if you travel a lot.The "dual time" mode is less capable than the earlier version.  In that case, you'd set it based upon whatever time zone  you might be in, and you could step through timezones (say, from London to Cairo) without having to reset the time itself.  In this case, you simply have to reset the watch time for a second entry... not quite as nice.It does have a "daylight savings time" option which helps a bit, since you don't have to reset the watch twice a year (you only turn DST on or off).The reduced "databank" feature set means that you no longer have the calendar display at the top of the screen (which was nice... you'd see a darkened box on days when an event was set, or a blank if nothing was set).  However, this is replaced by a LARGE text box which tells you the day of the week, so it's probably a improvement in the eyes of most people.The keypad is actually an improvement over the prior versions in terms of ease of pressing of the buttons.  There's a triangular "pyramid" atop each button, in clear plastic, with the printed label underneath.  Unfortunately, they removed the "three letters" (in addition to the number) from each button.  This is supposed to make it easier to see the numbers, I guess, but it makes text entry a lot more challenging (if you don't have the num-pad text entry scheme committed to memory).Basically, Casio has severely hamstrung the "databank" portion of this device, to the point where it's largely not worth it to use except as a conventional watch or a calculator.But that's OK, for most of us, as not many people probably made full use of the older version's feature set.  It's still the best option out there.Soon, practically-sized "smart watches" may become an actual reality.  The i-Watch is not really what I mean... it's just a first step down the path.  It's pretty much useless without an iPhone, and a watch should be a stand-alone device, or at least be capable of being a stand-alone device.  The Samsung "smart watch" is a great concept, except that it's HUGE.  But until real, practical smart-watches arrive (in a few years) this remains your best option, in my opinion.This particular watch is the "black" version.  The band itself is a pretty standard plastic band, and is quite comfortable to me.

This is supposed to make it easier to see the numbers, I guess, but it makes text entry a lot more challenging (if you don't have the num-pad text entry scheme committed to memory).Basically, Casio has severely hamstrung the "databank" portion of this device, to the point where it's largely not worth it to use except as a conventional watch or a calculator.But that's OK, for most of us, as not many people probably made full use of the older version's feature set. The Samsung "smart watch" is a great concept, except that it's HUGE.  But until real, practical smart-watches arrive (in a few years) this remains your best option, in my opinion.This particular watch is the "silver tone" version.  The band itself is metal, but the case is silver-painted plastic (which is disappointing... I'm sure that eventually the case will become scratched and will look ugly after that point).  The band is pretty easy to use... a standard steel-link watch band...  but you may need to either figure out how to remove links or, more probably, get someone to do it for you.  Unless you're HUGE...  you can't wear it as-shipped.  (I had to remove 4x links to make it fit perfectly.)

I had very high hopes for this...  conceptually, it's a wonderful idea.Unfortunately, the execution is terrible.  Not just "poor" but TERRIBLE.  I have removed this from my XDm, permanently.Why?Well, the existing guide rod is a consistent cylinder.  This is not... they make one size, it seems, and add "adapter rings" to the ends to fit different weapon guide rod sizes.  So, except at the far ends of the slide travel, the "guide rod" is LOOSE.  This results in some loss of accuracy and an increased probability of jamming.But worse, the part tends to rotate when in-place, rendering the (rather ingenious!) activation mechanism unworkable.  The first time I encountered this, I tried to field-strip the weapon, only to discover that (due to this same rotation issue) it became very, very difficult to disassemble the weapon.  I had to "wiggle" the rod from the front, to rotate it, until I was eventually able to rotate it back to the "as designed" position, at which point I could again disassemble the weapon.Now, had Lasermax actually put this into a dimensionally-accurate replica of the original Springfield guide rod, instead of "shimming" the two ends with add-on fittings, this would be the PERFECT laser sight for any XDm and I would recommend it unconditionally.But an add-on which (a) fails regularly, (b) increase the potential for weapon failure, and (c) makes field-stripping nearly impossible ("immediate action" becomes a half-hour exercise in frustration!)...  is not something I would ever recommend anyone spend their money on.Lasermax, PLEASE develop a version of this using a dimensionally-accurate replica of the actual Springfield guide rod.  THAT would get a "five star" rating from me, without hesitation.

While this is not QUITE as good as a device made just for my own chair, specifically, it's as close as I could have hoped to see.  I have a "home theater PC" which I usually operate with a media center remote type device, but sometimes I want more control, or even to play a game or the like.  I have a nice wireless mouse and wireless keyboard.  Using this, I can use my mouse on the arm of my chair, and my keyboard on my lap, right there sitting in a recliner!I went looking for something like this, not really expecting to find it, and I'm very pleased I DID find one.  Thanks!

This is a NECESSARY addition to the 1:1000 "Reliant" kit sold by Polar Lights/Round 2.  In fact, it's really strange that the item was not included with the model (guess they're feeling the economic pinch like the rest of us are?)I was tempted to mark it down due to the above, but that's not really what "reviews" are for.  A review is there to discuss the product itself.  So while it may be reasonable to mark down the model (for not including the decals) it's not reasonable to mark down the decals themselves.These decals consist of supplementary decals to help you build the kit provided by Round 2.  Note that this is not a FULL decal set... those which are present in the main kit sheet are not necessarily duplicated here.  It contains two different things, really.1)  A whole set of different names and registry numbers.  The names and numbers provided are of ships seen on-screen...  other than the Reliant, which is on the original kit decal sheet.  Most of the ship names seen here are from episodes of "Star Trek - The Next Generation" or "Star Trek - Deep Space Nine."  One is from the film "The Voyage Home."So, you get some extra names...  but that's not really the "big deal" with this set, nor is it what I meant when I said "this should have been included."No, the other thing this contains is a complete set of very nice, pretty subtle "aztec panel" decals.  With only a very few exceptions, these decals cover every single exposed surface on the model (though they are very subtle and just "shade" the color of paint underneath, rather than covering it up, so you still need to paint!)For those unfamiliar, the term "aztec" is not a technical term.  Rather, it derives from how, on the first Movie Enterprise, the ship was painted with a beautiful, regular pattern, which (when looked at closely) resembled ancient Aztec heiroglyphics.  (Look closely at the upper hull of the Enterprise and you can see the little "men" on each major panel!)You don't want to put these over white paint, but rather over some nice, neutral grey color (say "light ghost grey").  They'll require decal setting solution and/or decal solvent in order to properly seat on the various curved surfaces, and once fully dry will require a clear over-coat paint to protect them (be careful with what you choose... some overcoatings yellow over time!)If you use them properly, the model will (at arms length) very, very closely resemble the ship as seen on-screen.  It's really wonderful to see.But in prior R2 kits, these have been "in the box," and I wish R2 hadn't changed course on this particular model.

Note that this is not really a review of the cable itself, but of the mis-labeling it has in this ad.The cable is NOT compatible with all... possibly not ANY... of the items it's listed as.  I have a two different Foscam cameras, both of which are listed in the "compatible with" listing above, and it is simply the wrong size to fit EITHER of them.  The diameter of the connector cylinder is larger, and longer as well, on this than on the connector used on at least these two different cameras.And thus, though the cable itself is likely entirely fine, it is NOT what is being advertised here, and is useless to me due to this incorrect advertising here.

I'm the sort of consumer who buys "really good" equipment and then keeps it 'til it fails (or is rendered obsolete by conditions outside my ability to control).  So, when my last pair of nice, mid-range headphones died recently, I wanted to get something really nice.  These headphones were my choice to replace the old ones, based upon significant research on my part.First off...  yes, the stories  you've heard are true... these headphones really do have an extended "break-in" period (several days of steady use) before they sound as good as they ought to sound.  I knew this going in, but was still uneasy when I first tried them out and heard almost "hollow and tinny" sound.  Now that I've owned and used them for several weeks, the sound is truly wonderful, however... rich, full, and encompassing, with the best tonal accuracy I've heard on any set I've ever used.  I realize that there are better sets out there... but those sell for thousands of dollars, and honestly, I doubt I'd be able to tell the difference.These are definitely "open" which means that (given appropriate listening volume) you can hear things around you, and those around you can hear (at very reduced apparent volume) whatever you're listening to.  I don't mind that, but bear it in mind if you want to use them to listen in bed, for example, without disturbing the person next to you.  That's not going to happen.As for comfort...  I suppose those with very hard heads would find them uncomfortable at first.  My head isn't quite that large so I feel perfectly comfortable with them on for extended use.I've tried them on my Pioneer receiver in both "pure direct" playback mode and in "headphones" based modes... I strongly prefer the "pure direct" mode.  Any processed playback loses some fidelity... something I'd never noticed on my prior headphones but can definitely notice using these.I'm very satisfied.  They look nice, feel nice, and sound wonderful.  My only "wish" is that I would have preferred a longer cable... and I guess I need to get a high-end extension (which, despite what I've read, I doubt will harm my sound quality).  I want to use them while sitting in my recliner about ten feet back from my home entertainment center.

I previously owned a rather cheap, but reliable, battery-operated sorter, (cylindrical in form) which was a gift from my mom, years ago.  When it failed, recently, I purchased what seemed to be the same unit...  but which was a piece of junk, and failed within two months.  So I decided to get a better one.  I chose this one.So far, I'm quite satisfied.  It's larger than the old one, and requires a power connection rather than batteries...  but it does nice things that the prior device I owned would not do (like count, stop at the end of filling a tube, etc).There is one drawback to this design.  Dumping a large pile of coins into the hopper tends to jam up at the neck of the hopper, which is inconvenient.  The hopper can be raised, which frees any such jam, however.  A small screw (which can be opened, conveniently enough, with any standard US coin!) can be removed which then allows the hopper to be swung upwards and forwards.  The sorting wheel is then directly exposed.  I have removed that screw and don't plan on putting it back, except for if the unit is moved at some point.I can't tell how long this will last, yet... and if it fails prematurely, I'll update this review.  But I like the device so far, quite a bit.

I purchased this very recently, knowing (a) that it was a discontinued model, and (b) that there are some issues with it.  However, I really wanted to have a real full-function joystick I could use with my newly-upgraded-to-top-of-the-line Home Theater PC.  Previously, the HTPC was sufficient for media playback, but not really for anything like games.  Now, it's my most powerful computer in my home.  And this means that games sitting on the couch is a reasonable possibility.I already own a Logitech Cordless Rumblepad, but pads are useless for flight sims and the like, in my experience.  I really wanted a joystick for the living room, and for it to be wireless.  This discontinued model remains the pinnacle of wireless-joysticks, it seems.So... THE GOOD, first.  It's very, very comfortable to use, and has a smooth mechanism.  I understand that some people have failed the sensors and buttons in their units, but I suspect that this may be related to contamination (spilling a coke on it?) or the like.  I could be wrong, and if so, I'll certainly update this review accordingly, of course.  But for now, I'm not concerned with that.  And for now, the sensors and buttons are very smooth and responsive.I've read several comments about the three "feet" not being rubber, but mine has a rubberized coating on those, which grips my end-table's top surface quite effectively.The buttons on this are atypical for most joysticks...  but they're not bad in any way.  I do prefer my F-16 flight stick based controls, however.  The most problematic part of this is the location of the throttle.  Having it be in the upper left "foot" region would have been far better, in my opinion.  But since few of the sims I'm using this with are really useful for "single axis throttles" anyway...  the main exception being MS Flight Sim X, where "rapid throttle changes" are not the norm...  this hasn't been a problem for me.  If I want to do serious flight simming, I'll do so in my office using my full HOTAS rig.  ("Hands on throttle and stick")In general, I REALLY like this stick.  But there's a major drawback, and it's one several other people have already pointed out.  It's remarkable to me that Logitech never fixed this, because it renders the stick almost unusable as a result.This is the rapid transition into "Power Saver" mode, which seems to occur in less than two minutes.  And note that this is based ONLY on "button presses," not on axis activity... meaning that if you're not hitting buttons, but are still steering, the stick will "shut down" while you're in flight.  THIS IS A TERRIBLE THING, unless you're playing games where shooting perpetually is always part of the gameplay.I believe I can create a work-around for this, however, using the Logitech Gaming Software.  I simply need to choose one button I'm not going to use, and set that up as a defacto "power button."  I'll assign that button to go into "auto-repeat" mode once pressed, perpetually, until the button is pressed again.  I'll make sure that whatever keypress or button press this is generating is not one which is assigned to any function in the game I'm playing.  I HOPE that doing this will prevent the "auto-shut-down" "feature."Of course, this might not be something that can be affected by the software, and actually requires REAL button presses at least once a minute to stay "alive."  If so, I can still work around this by assigning, say, the "thumb button" to do nothing, and then just keep it depressed at all times.  Annoying, but doable.I knew that this would probably be an issue going in, so I'm not really upset about it, but it's a serious design defect, and one which Logitech COULD have easily avoided.A version of this which was rechargable via USB, and which had a "time out" of something more like ten minutes... and, less importantly,  with the throttle moved to a better location... would be nearly the perfect wireless joystick.  It's a shame Logitech killed the product rather than simply fixing the one major, glaring defect... a SOFTWARE defect no less, not a hardware one.  A second generation version of this, with the "bugs fixed" would have been nice.

I've owned this very device (from the same mold) previously, from another manufacturer.  I had two of them in my home theater PC, and when I decided to add a third drive, I needed another one (with the intent of keeping the unit both cool and quiet... and of extending system life).Note that this requires that you leave the slot underneath your disk unoccupied.  This will work nicely in almost any situation I've seen, though note, the mounting tabs can potentially interfere with the "shelf" tabs the drive sits on in some mounting configurations.  This is even the case in my own HTPC, and I had to mount them to the drives while already installed in the disk cages.  Still, the small tabs DO fit in between the various "shelf tabs" on these cages, so I can use them (unlike most other HD coolers I've seen).They run quietly and definitely reduce the measured drive temperatures, which should significantly improve overall disk lifespan.  They don't produce enough stray magnetism to impact the drive's storage, either.Note that  you require a 4-wire "Molex-type" drive connector... the old HD/CD type...  for power, not a "SATA" type connector.  The connector is a pass-through type, so you can plug this into the cable and then plug something else into this plug (even another fan)Overall, recommended.

My girlfriend has cats...  and I've adopted them as well.  Frequently, they come to stay with me... and that's what this is for.  It's a "monster scratchy-post" that they can literally CLIMB, not just "scratch" or "even "stretch out on."  The little one, younger but smaller, uses it like a gym rope... climb it, get on top, "ring the bell" (she really does pat a paw on top) and climb back down.  The older one has gotten on top of it... it's pretty large in diameter, and while they can't lay down up there, he was able to turn around on his four paws and face the table, which he then jumped over to.It's the best scratching post I've seen from the standpoint of "cats love it" so far.It's actually pretty light, and can be disassembled and reassembled easily.  And the sisal rope is going to be (relatively) easy to replace once that eventually becomes necessary.Cons?  Well, so far none, except for the obvious... it's BIG, and if you're pressed for space, it may not fit into your lifestyle.Between this and the "shoelace prize" that they both love to play with (which I'll string over the top sometimes) these are two happy cats.  I definitely recommend this if you have active cats who're looking for some more activity.

Jason Brandt's writing style is easy to read, and very entertaining, though by no  means "high art prose."  This series is an attempt to create a "monsters of myth if they were scientifically, plausibly real" scenario, which is almost entirely different from the prior book series he wrote which I've read, the "West of Hell" series (which is entirely allegorical and spiritual in nature).His writing is full of "tells" which are less subtle than might be found from a more talented author...  the many, many references early on to "apparent pranksters" who were tossing what seemed to be "smoke bombs" at major events was always, blatantly, obvious to me as what it was (the source of the infection).  It just smacked me in the face a bit too strongly.  And we were never told WHY these were being done, or who was behind it...  which, with the series now completed, bothers me significantly.His characters, in this book series, are a bit less subtle than I might like, as well...  in some cases played for laughs, in others, to differentiate them more effectively, it seems.  This could have been a bit less "overstated."But overall, I enjoyed the books.  I really liked the idea of how some people associated these things with the werewolf mythos, while others with the vampire mythos, and still others with the zombie mythos.  The reality is that these things... which were once human... have been mutated by a disease, so that they've taken on characteristics of all of these (and more, most likely, though these three were quite obvious to me).The thing is... if you want all your threads tied up all nice and neat at the end of a story (as most people do) you'll find this frustrating, as the situation simply "IS"...  there's never a real explanation given for it, though it seems clear that the author had one in his own imagination. SOMEBODY spread the virus (?) which caused this.  Somebody had a reason for doing so.  I really want to know WHO, and WHY, and whether they didn't know what they were introducing, or whether they knew exactly what they were doing.  That's the part of this story which remains untold.  And without that, it will bug those of us who want to know the whole story.If, on the other hand, you simply like interesting characters in bad situations making the best of things...  survival horror, in other words... you'll like this quite a bit.

After buying a set of Trijicon sights for my XDm sidearm, and paying too much to get my local gun shop to install them (and not to align them properly anyway!) I decided to get one of these.  It's an investment I already am glad I made.It's really quite simple... and it does work far better for the rear sight than for the front but does work fine for both with a little care...  and it does the job.  Better yet, it's a FIELD-USEABLE device...  you don't need to wait until you get home to adjust your sights.  It's a heavy chunk of metal, but not too heavy...  and along with a crescent wrench (part of any good portable tool kit) will allow you to "tune in" your sights wherever you happen to be.  Or to install a new set of sight, for that matter.Definitely worth the price paid.

If you own a Ruger LCP, YOU NEED at least one of these...  period.The weapon is a fine weapon, but it has no safety whatsoever...  the only safety you have is ensuring that it's unloaded, and relying on your own discipline.  Of course, it can't fire unless a round is loaded, but as a six-round-magazine weapon, that extra "one in the pipe" can mean the difference between life and death in a crisis situation.So...  you need this.  Every weapon should ship with one.  With it in place, you simply cannot pull the trigger (and thus the weapon cannot discharge inadvertently).  And yet, relatively easy pressure on the core of it with your trigger finger pushes the device out, making the weapon ready to fire.  It works, and it works well.  (And it doesn't interfere with your holster, by the way...  but it DOES ensure that nobody will pull the weapon from their holster with their finger ready to pull the trigger.)

I purchased these for my girlfriend, who is still becoming comfortable with her "personal protection" and needs to be able to practice loading, unloading, clearing, etc, without the risk of making a mistake which could be dangerous.That's what these are for, and they're perfectly suited to the task.  Their weight is similar to a real round, permitting her to practice handling the weapon with it feeling "correct"...  but without any potential for misfiring.I have a full batch for my own sidearm as well...  which I use to practice speed-loading my magazine, as well as clearing the weapon.  I've loaded and ejected them many, many times and the anodized finish remains intact..  I'm not sure how some people have managed to chip this hard, anodized surface, but I suspect that they've been beating them up pretty badly in order to do that."Snap caps" aren't intended for use in the field... they're for the workshop, or the backyard, really.  But these are, in my view, superior to the plastic caps I've seen others use (even if they do not have a spring, relying instead on a piece of soft material, to protect your firing pin).

The problem with this device is that it is not shaped like an actual round (as it needs to be).  In many models of sidearms, the extractor mechanism will push this off of center (for example, the Springfield XD and XDm series).I confirmed that my laser was, in fact, straight (relative to the body of the device), before using it.  I discovered that the point emitted by this was far, far to the right of the factory-default aim point.  A test firing proved that this was incorrect, and that the factory sight location was pretty close to spot-on.Ideally, this device should have a "rim" around the rear edge, just as a bullet does.  This would allow the round to be held properly, as a bullet's casing is, in pretty much any weapon around.  Without that, the extractor tend to put pressure on something which (if it were a real bullet) would be up against a hard surface, but in this case, is "in air" and allows the boresight "round" to be pushed off-center (due to the necessary clearance in the barrel, some ability to "tip" will always be present).There may be a means to "finesse" this to point ahead... several people have mentioned this in their own comment here.  I have not yet found that for my own weapon, however.Better yet, the vendor ought to provide a replacement rear cap which actually reflects the physical form of a real casing.  This would NOT be difficult to do, and should be part of the design.  It's hard for me to imagine why they did otherwise, frankly...  except perhaps to save a few pennies on the cost of metal?It's a GREAT concept, and for some weapons it works beautifully...  but for those with an extraction system which applies side pressure to the round when loaded, it's not very useful.My goal is to replace the end cap with a properly shaped one... or to put a sleeve over that end cap (perhaps made from an actual casing?).  That should make this fully functional.  But Sightmark ought to be the one to do that FOR us, shouldn't they?

As a former military officer, I'm very accustomed to "web-gear" and nylon-rip-stop gear.  When I got a new sidearm, a Springfield XDm 40S&W (4.5" barrel), it came with a hard-plastic "paddle" holster with the FBI-preferrred "pull to the front at an angle to draw" configuration, which I personally dislike.  I really wanted a low-hanging holster that I could strap to my thigh, like my old military-issue holster (used for my 9mm 1911 sidearm).Well, this is pretty close.  I like it, overall, but there are a few things worth pointing out.1)  There's a LOT of excess material on all the nylon straps.  This is a good idea, frankly, to provide the wides possible range of adjustment.  I've sized it to the point where I'm pretty happy now, and now I'm going to have to cut off the excess material and then "seal" the cut ends.  Ideally, you'd do this with a hot knife or hot scissors... but if you can't manage that, cut it to length and then run a flame over the cut end until the material at that end melts very, very slightly.  Otherwise, the web material WILL fray and unravel over time, which you don't want.2)  The neoprene pads on the leg straps works well with most materials... denim, etc... but won't work as well to "grip" your leg if you're wearing slick material (such as most rain gear).  While you can clamp the straps down really hard to compensate for that, they'll still "work down" the taper of your thigh.  Really, you need to pair this with a rough, "grippable" fabric, for best behavior.3)  Maybe my sidearm is just slightly too long for this... but the thumb strap is almost impossible to attach without removing my weapon belt.  I'd have preferred that the "snap" be on the exposed side, not underneath the weapon.  I get WHY they did this... to make it less likely to inadvertently unsnap this strap...  but if you can't reattach it when using the holster, and it instead just goes unsnapped...  well, that makes it less than useful, doesn't it?  I may need to modify my holster to fix this problem.4)  The "overstrap" (the large strap of nylon which goes over the rear of your sidearm, on top of the thumb strap) is a nice feature, but I think it could be improved quite a bit.5)  The ammo pouch on the front will accept a standard 16-round Springfield magazine, though it's a bit on the snug side.6)  This is NOT intended to be worn on your pants belt.  You need a load-bearing belt (I got one from Condor which has two magazine pouches provided, for a total of four on my person when I wear my belt) to support the weight, trust me on this.  Do NOT just attach it to your pants belt.Ultimately, I'm pretty happy with this, but the thumb strap issue is a real annoyance for me, and I'm going to have to modify my holster if I'm going to use this at all.I had been considering a SERPA type holster, but this is far less expensive and far more comfortable.  If the thumb stay worked as it ought to for this sidearm, I'd be totally satisfied.Oh, and key to those who think in military/tactical terms, as I do...  "nothing rattles, nothing shines."  Nice.

The phone case shipped is not the phone case shown in the image.  I had one of those when I first got my Razr, years ago.  I got another one a couple of years back.  It was always a perfect fit for the phone, and has cut-outs in the right places (matching the buttons and USB port).The case I received is not the same style, nor is it the same size.  It does appear to be similar construction materials, but that's about where the similarity ends.The case provided is designed for a phone of similar overall dimensions (height x width), but slightly larger.  And it is "tapered" so that it is very wide at the bottom and (when the flap is closed) tight at the top.  It's BIZARRE.  It's like having a pyramid shape to hold a cube.If the vendor had shipped the actual, correct phone case, I'd be a happy guy.  But apparently they think that this is like horseshoes...  getting "close" is somehow "good enough.It's not.If you can find a case which is ACTUALLY what you see in the image for this item, get it.  But don't trust this vendor to send the proper phone case.I may post a side-by-side, with images, of this versus the old (worn out) actual Razr case later on, just to illustrate the problem.  It should be... illuminating... for anyone considering buying a case from this vendor.

I was a young man when the LucasArts game "TIE Fighter" came out, decades ago.  I absolutely fell in love with the game, and am a huge fan (by the way, two of the three release versions are now available through "Good Old Games," but unfortunately not the best version of the three, at this point).In TIE Fighter, you were basically a pilot in the Imperial Navy.  These games expanded, quite extensively, the original Star Wars lore... and provided a semi-believable universe in the fantasy-based framework set out by Lucas's films.  The creators, led by the great Larry Holland, made what is still, to this day, treated as one of the best PC gaming experiences of all time.  The first series of games, X-Wing (and its two expansions) were great, allowing you to fly for the Rebellion in the period leading up to the Battle of Yavin (see the original Star Wars film).  TIE Fighter was better, and allowed you to fight for the Empire during a time of internal machinations, in some cases even flying alongside Darth Vader himself.  X-Wing Vs. TIE was their first foray into "online competitive gaming" but lacked a story (initially... an expansion pack gave it one) and "X-Wing Alliance" wrapped up the series, giving you the ability to fly heavy freighters (like the Millenium Falcon) as well as many different fighters, and leading you through the Battle of Endor (the final defeat of the Emperor at the second Death Star).Anyway... in TIE Fighter, there is an imperial "arms race" which leads to an internal rebellion of sorts, with an imperial military officer attempting to stage a coup.  During this game, you receive the "TIE Avenger" (aka "TIE Advanced") which is LOOSELY based upon Darth Vader's fighter from the first film, but is significantly different as well.  (Vader's ship was the "TIE Advanced Prototype," not the production ship).  The TIE Defender was a "secret weapon" which came out late in that game, and was the most powerful (and expensive and rare) fighter in the entire galaxy at that point.The thing is, that "TIE Defender" looked very, very little like the ship provided in this pack.  The best way to think of the TIE Defender is to think of Darth Vader's TIE Fighter with three wings rather than two.  It should have an extended rear hull, behind the main hull, and large flat wings at three positions going out to solar arrays which are very similar to those on Vader's ship, essentially rectangular, except for notches front and rear.A few years back, someone "kit-bashed" a model of the Defender, using parts from the TIE Interceptor model kit, and started promoting that as the "TIE Defender."  That, not the ship as seen in the game, is what this miniature is based upon.For anyone wanting to see a fairly nice (if still not 100% accurate) comparison of the two versions... here's an image someone else made up.h t t p : / / m e d i a . m o d d b . c o m / i m a g e s / m o d s / 1 / 1 1 / 1 0 6 1 1 / T I E _ D e f e n d e r _ c o m p a r i s o n . p n gIn my own case, I've made a fairly complete model of the Defender as seen in TIE Fighter using a professional CAD software package, matching images from the game itself.Now, don't get me wrong... I really appreciate the efforts the guys making this new tabletop game are making, but I really wish that they'd go with the ORIGINAL, ACCURATE version of the TIE Defender, rather than the cheap, fast kit-bash made for a photo for the "collectible card game" from a pair of TIE Interceptor models several years ago.Now, as far as gameplay itself, the representation of the Defender in this game is reasonably good... albeit a small bit underpowered compared to the version in TIE Fighter.  But it's pretty close.So... if you don't care about consistency, or have no real interest in the (wonderful) original PC game, you wont' care at all... but if you do care about that, you'll find this ship miniature annoying.

Well, the game itself is just great...  a few years out of date by now, but for flight sims, that's OK.  It's a lot of fun, and allows you to fly some terrific pseudo-historical missions set in the WWII era.  Visually, it's very nice, though I wish it had full head-tracker support (which is pretty much crucial for prop-era non-radar-equipped aircraft without AWACS/etc.There's a problem with this game, though...  and if you run modern hardware, you'll very likely encounter it.  The problem is a so-called "copy protection" scheme which is bundled with the game called "Safedisk."  Safedisk encrypts the actual game executable (in an "ICD" file) and when you run the apparent game-executable, it merely decrypts the REAL executable and runs it.In concept, not that bad of an idea.  In execution, a HORRIBLE one.  Because, for example, if you have a CD burner or the equivalent, and the Safedisk tools identify that, it will simply refuse to decrypt the file, and you will "crash to desktop."  It's not a problem with the program itself, it's a problem with the supposed "copy protection" technique.If you want to run in a compatibility mode... well, that would work just fine with the ACTUAL executable, but not in this case.  You'll be putting the "decrypter" into compatibility mode, not the actual game executable.  And the decrypter will fail if you put it into a compatibility mode, most of the time.  Plus, of course, you're prevented from making settings which apply to the game executable which might allow it to run properly (through setting compatibility settings).SO...  If you're willing to gamble with getting this running, I recommend it.  But if you're not technically savy, and don't have a LOT of patience... and if you expect what you buy to just work out of the box...  don't bother.  The odds are not in your favor.

This is one of the large number of really well-made simulations made under the Jane's Combat Simulations label some years ago.  While it is not the #1 best in the series, it's excellent in its own right.This is one of the first games I ever played which used "Voxels" (volumetric pixels...  ie, pixels which exist in three dimensions, rather than just two) to model terrain.  It does stand out a bit at low altitude, but it gives some truly remarkable visuals above a could of hundred feet of altitude.There are some technical snags in the game, for more modern operating systems, however.  The most notable one is the fact that this game uses a font type which is no longer present in Windows... and thus much of the written text in the game is thus unreadable ( including menu picks and the like).  I've tried to find a way around that, but to date, with no luck.  No one has done a patch to fix this font-engine issue, and it's doubtful that anyone ever will.  So, most of us will not be able to get the game to work properly, even if the game itself runs perfectly (since you can't see the menus).As an aside, there's also a historical disk in the set, which is worth the price of purchase alone.

It really is ludicrous to have to pay for "extra licenses" to permit the use of additional cameras... but I get why this is something Foscam is doing.  They want to sell into the "high end security" market... which typically costs a lot more than a typical home server.  If they didn't do this, nobody would buy the high-end security stations, and everybody would just go with the traditional NAS device (which is a marvelous device).It's mildly annoying, to be sure.  But most of us will only have a handful of cameras (if we're just securing our home) and the cost of a license is pretty low compared to, say, the cost of a good-quality IP camera.  So, if you're serious about setting up surveillance for your home or office, the cost of the licenses, while annoying, is actually fairly trivial.It doesn't excuse Synology's doing this... I consider it a massively boneheaded maneuver (obviously driven by internal competition between their NAS group and their Security group).  But as bone-headed maneuvers go, it's not as bad as many others I've seen.  I can live with this one, in other words...  while in every other way I'm very happy with my Diskstation.

Another gorgeous, high-quality Star Trek ship replica from Hallmark...  this is nearly perfect.  The lighting effects are spectacular.I only wish that it would REMAIN LIT (as the older ones do) so that it could be used as a lighted Christmas tree ornament.  At the moment, Hallmark is using the "press to light up" model, using small batteries... and this means that the ornament is, for all PRACTICAL purposes, an unlit one when hanging on the tree.

Well,  I've previously owned two other (MPC-type) models of the Falcon.  The first I built "stock," and the second I modified, radically, to make it more accurate.  Neither was remotely as nice as this.This is nearly the "holy grail" for fans of the Falcon as seen in the original Star Wars films.  (A larger version... "studio scale" matching the original filming miniature from TESB...  would be greatly desired by some folks, I know, but I could never have one of those... no place to put it!)It's very, very accurate.  Some people have found issues with the model, but they seem almost undetectable to me.  You can improve this even further with some aftermarket items (photoetched brass for some details, for example, or replacing plastic "tubing" with formed brass) and the kit isn't set up, out of the box, for lighting (but there are some truly impressive lighted builds out there already)  I plan to do that to my own version.But in general... this is about as close to perfect as you're ever going to find.  And for the cost... it OUGHT to be.FYI, folks...  "Fine Molds," who make this model, have lost the license to produce Star Wars kits (which has now been awarded to Bandai, who are also quite good but tend to make "easier to build" kits, often with toy-like features included).  Fine Molds does very high-quality kits... I've never really seen better.  But Bandai has a relationship with Disney, which recently purchased Lucasfilm, so the relationship with Fine Molds is over now.So...  if you want this, get it while you can.  The odds of being able to get it in the future are going down all the time.

This is a very, very nice replica of the frigate-type starship ("Miranda" class or "Avenger" class) seen in the second classic Star Trek film.  It's exceptionally accurate, with one major (but understandable) deviation... the saucer is quite a bit thicker than the "real" thing would be.As with all recent Hallmark ornaments, though, this has a flaw.  The flaw is that they only stay lit for a matter of seconds, after pressing a button.  The older ones, which were powered by the (incandescent) tree light strings, would stay illluminated indefinitely.So, while it's a wonderful replica of the Reliant, the lights (which look great) do not stay on, and thus is is essentially an "unlighted" ornament.

Okay, folks... first things first...  this is a "Mini Mega Kit"  These are the tiny little "cheepie" box items found near the checkout counter at Barnes and Noble, at Hallmark stores, and the like.  Note the price, and you should realize what you're getting isn't going to be a big, full-function, metal prop replica (my Master Replicas phaser cost several hundred dollars, after all!)So, what is it?  It's a "nick-nack."  It's something to sit on a shelf, to play with a little bit... or......  Well, in this case, it's now on the belt of a plush teddy-bear.  It's the PERFECT size for the typical plush toy... especially if that toy has a red shirt on!Now... functionally, the thing has a nice bright red LED at the tip, but that's all it has...  it's disappointing that the thing makes no sound, so I've marked it down a star for that.Geometrically, it's very, very accurate to the on-screen prop (including colors).  Note that there were several different paint and detail schemes used on phasers throughout the series, but this represents the best-recognized version, with the blue-gray body, bronze power-pack/grip, and black plug-in phaser-1 module.  I can't pick out any errors in the design...  it looks right (except for the size, of course).Because of how I'm using it, I gave it a higher score than I might otherwise have done.  If I were buying this for someone as a stand-alone toy, I'd be disappointed.  (But as part of a toy's outfit... it's perfect!)

This is probably the single best of all the ornaments Hallmark has produced in this line... it's GORGEOUS.  Yeah, the electronic effects have been disappointing since Hallmark stopped letting you power the device (indefinitely) off the christmas-tree-lighting and instead only lets you push a button to make something happen... and this one is no exception (though I love the "torpedo firing" effect in the front tube)  But the modeling itself is extraordinary, and the paint and finish is perfect.

First off, let me preface this by saying I'm not building this "stock out of the box" but instead intend to make significant "upgrades" to the model... all of which are easily supported by this kit as shipped.This is a model of the "Hunter Killer Tank" as seen in the flashback sequences in "Terminator 2."  There are some sequences in the first terminator movie showing this same era, but this is not seen clearly in those (although it's presumed to be there).  In the later Terminator films (and TV series) there are alternative versions of this... similar but not identical... as well as dramatically different designs in some cases.  But this is the one you see crushing skulls under the treads in the best of the movie series.It's actually a very well-designed machine.  If you've ever built a model kit of a tank, construction of this will be pretty familiar, except of course that most tanks are tan or grey or green, while this is supposed to be something like stainless steel.  (It's actually a fictitious metal, but it's a steel alloy, supposedly, as described in the "Sarah Connor Chronicles" TV series).  So, you'll need to work on doing high-quality metal finishes to make this look good.It has clear colored parts for the "siren lights" on the head, as well as for the "eye" searchlights.  The rest is all a nice, neutral grey plastic, except for the treads, which are rubber and which wrap around rotating rollers on the foot tread mechanisms.There's plenty of hardware in here to allow the thing to actually drive...  and I'm thinking about doing that (with an RC controller).  In addition to the fully-articulated treadwork, you also have pivoting joints for the head (atop the torso) and the torso (atop the base) and for the two plasma turrets which are in place of "arms" for this particular robot.  There are also two "gripping arms" at the front of the torso, but they cannot be made into functional devices without basically rebuilding them from scratch, and I'm not inclined to do that.There's a nice "garage kit" lighting kit already available for this (and for the air-borne variant which Pegasus also offers a model of) which, in this case, includes the "siren lights" in their proper flashing configuration.  With some small servomotors for the canon turrets and torso joints, and a decent gearbox and cable-drives for the motive section, I ought to be able to make this into a working scale-model (less the ability to shoot plasma, of course... or to operate without external control!)The build quality is excellent, and takes into account the desire of people like me to do the sort of thing I'm planning to do.The main "drawback" (if you can call it that) is that this is a pretty big model...  bear that in mind.

I bought a trio of these (which I then "marked" with colored shrink-tube on both ends... orange, green, or (none - aka "black") to replace the factory-provided cable for my Logitech Z-5500 5.1 computer speaker system.They're very high-quality, standard 3.5mm (1/8") jack stereo cables.  The gold plating is more than adequate to prevent long-term degradation by oxidation of the contact surfaces.  And the heads are VERY small in diameter, which is critical when putting these into a computer sound card (the factory-provided ones were almost 150% the side of these, and pushed against each other, with the potential to cause sound card jack damage!)I can recommend these enthusiastically, especially if you're making multiple connections close to each other, as in a computer audio output.

These are exactly what I was looking for, as it turns out.  I needed them as replacements for some plastic parts which my movers lost during my last move (I told them to put the parts into zip-lock baggies, but they did the "trust us" routine and ended up costing me days setting up the bookshelves in my bedroom as a result of my having trusted them!)There's nothing "special" about these, but they're ideal for this sort of usage, so if you need replacement pins, I can certainly recommend these.

This is the original factory part.
