There are some aftermarket versions available, which are less expensive, and MAY be just as good, or perhaps even better, but I wanted the "factory original" replacement for my failed part.The factory original installation uses "heat staking" to affix this to the door panel.  This means that, basically, they press a hot iron (think of a soldering iron with a special head) onto plastic posts and melt them down into "mushroom caps" over the door panel interior holes which the posts pass through.The replacement part is the exact same part, so you have the option of heat-staking in place... but instead, the part ships with sheet-metal press-nuts which slip down over the posts, with "teeth" which prevent the press-nuts from pulling back out.  I appreciate the replacement's giving us that option, and I used the press-nuts in installation.The reason that the device needed to be replaced is that the inside portion of the handle lever (which is entirely plastic) fractures after extended use, rendering the door incapable of operation from inside the vehicle (you can roll the window down and use the outside handle just fine, of course).  The problem is a fundamental design defect, with a "knit line" from the injection molding process right at the maximum stress point of this (far too weak, anyway) plastic "lever arm."  Mine took over a decade to fracture, but many others broke a lot earlier in the vehicle's life.  It's VERY BAD MECHANICAL DESIGN, and whoever designed this part ought to be looking for a new job (it's a fundamental part of this job, which happens to be what I do for a living, too.)  Probably, this was designed by a young kid straight out of school, and never really checked by any more experienced engineer.  It LOOKS good, and it will last for a while, but it's a flawed design.So...  if you own one of the vehicles which uses this (my own is a 2003 Dodge Intrepid), and yours has failed, this is the right part for a replacement, but realize, you may still see another failure at the same point some time into the future.I'm giving this a 4-star rating because (a) it was easy to replace, (b) is EXACTLY the original factory part (with no appearance differences whatsoever) and (c) it does have the installation process improvement.  I'm knocking off the one, not based upon the part itself, but upon the vehicle design defect.  To get a 5-star rating from me, someone would have to offer an improved lever, without the design defect that the original factory design has, plus all of the above.

I recently purchased a second one of these, to replace another brand-name repeater/bridge device.  (Note - this is NOT a repeater, merely a bridge...  meaning it doesn't act as a wireless retransmitter, but DOES wirelessly connect up to four wired devices to the wireless network.)I bought a second one because my first was so utterly flawless in its performance, while the "other name brand" device needed to be power-cycled on, sometimes, a DAILY basis in order to remain connected.  That it's also a pretty sharp-looking device isn't really a "selection criteria" for me, but it certainly doesn't hurt.  It's small and unobtrusive, and retains a near-perfect link with my Asus N900 wireless router (and should do at least as well with my new AC2400 one which I have yet to actually hook up)Basically, you hook up a computer to it (through the internet cable... any of the four ports will do) and ensure that you're only connecting through the wired network, not over wireless.  This will allow you direct access to the device.  You then go through a very basic setup process, which results in the device being connected to your preferred wireless network.  You can use the "parent network's" security settings, or establish your own for this device, as is the case with pretty much all bridges.I have one of these in my living room, and now another one in my master bedroom.  Each is hooked up to my home entertainment equipment (BD player, Roku, TV, and for the living room, a "Home Theater PC").  And it provides a very, very effective, consistent, and reliable connection in both situations...  not QUITE as good as if it were a hardwired network connection, but more than adequate for streaming HD video or doing normal internet stuff.  The only place I've noticed an issue at all is with file transfers, which are (NATURALLY) far faster over a gigabit wired connection than over this, which provides about 50% of the throughput...  in theory, around 600 megabits for second, but in reality, more like 500.  Still a lot faster than any "to the outside world" internet connection you're likely to have (which is going to be at around 10MB, 20MB, 30MB, or 50MB, for most cable internet providers).  So, if you're connecting to the outside work, it's every bit as good as being hooked up to your main router directly, and you'll only ever notice any lower throughput if you're passing files around on a home network.This is a "discontinued model."  TRENDNet now has an AC-type version of this, and I've seen mixed reviews of that new device, so I stuck with the one I KNOW works well.  So, unless you have a wireless AC-type router (like the Asus AC-2400), there's absolutely no reason not to go with this, and if you DO have one, this will still be very very effective, if perhaps not QUITE as fast or with QUITE as much range.

This model is based upon a tool which has been around for many, many years, and was originally a "glue" kit.  MPC produced Star Wars kits during the original run of the original films, and this was one of the later kits produced.Overall, it's not a TERRIBLE kit.  In fact, the upper and lower hull sections (which make up the bulk of the kit) are really pretty accurate.  The "inserts" are fine, if a bit simplified from the original filming model, as well.The big issue with this kit is the "side panels" which go between the top and bottom halves.  These are nearly 2x as tall as they ought to be in order for this to be an accurate model of the Falcon.  (I purchased some "garage-kit" resin replacement sidewalls, years ago, along with some other parts, and was able to turn one of these into a really pretty accurate model of the Falcon as seen in "The Empire Strikes Back.")  The sidewalls are also very, very poorly detailed, and not at all representative of the details found on the "real" Millenium Falcon.Now, realize, there were multiple models of the Falcon which were made during the run of the original films, not to mention two "full scale" (not really, but close enough for filming work) Falcons (the one seen in the hangar during ESB is about 2/3 scale, while the first film had a roughly 4/5 scale "half-only" version).  And between the first film and the second film, major revisions were made to the Falcon's design as well, most obviously with the addition of two large additional "underside boxes" with additional landing gear emplacements.  (The original version, which this kit is based upon, has three landing gear placements, two rear and one forward, while the revised version adds two additional "pods" forward, to either side.)  Each of these models, or "full sized" props were detailed in subtly different ways, as the models or props were built, in large part using "found objects" (model kit parts, or hardware salvaged from junkyards, etc).The "Definitive" version of the Falcon is the roughly 3.5 foot diameter primary filming miniature used in "The Empire Strikes Back."  It is that version with the (very expensive and very complex) "Fine Molds" Falcon models are based upon, while this one is based on the first-film model.Later on, when MPC was absorbed by Revell, the tooling for this kit was modified several times.  They removed the original lighting kit, then later on they added an "interior set" for the forward cargo-bay/lounge, and later still they converted the "glue kit" into a "snap-tite" kit.Also, the tooling was original used right here in the United States, and later was shipped off to Mexico, and then later still to China, where the product is produced today.  The attention to work paid by the workers has suffered, accordingly... so it's not shocking to me to hear that kits are being shipped with only part of the total kit in the box.  Suffice it to say the original (American-produced) version never had this issue.This is an "adequate" model... assuming that you receive the full kit... but is really more appropriate as a TOY than it is as an accurate model of the Falcon as seen on-screen.  And while the "snap-tite" approach may make for an easier build, the kit was never intended to be "snap-tite" and they had to shoehorn these features into a design which was intended to be glued together.  SO, I STRONGLY recommend that you go ahead and glue the kit together, if you want the kit to not just fall apart during normal handling.  (You may need to cut away some of the "snap features" to accomplish this, but in the long run, you'll be a lot happier with the result of this little bit of extra effort.)I had one of these sitting atop my turntable/8-track-player in my bedroom as a kid.  I later built another one up with the resin and photo-etch "replacement parts" which allowed me to turn the fairly accurate upper and lower hull sections into a very nice Falcon model.  But today, wanting a truly impressive and screen-accurate model (though IN NO WAY WHATSOEVER a "toy") I've built the 1:72 scale "Fine Molds" Falcon...  which puts this kit to shame by comparison.  But which is far more delicate (with many very fine details which can be damaged by excessive handling) and costs ten times more, at a minimum.If you want a "simple" Falcon, or want to "play" with it...  this is your kit.  But trust me... ignore the "snap-tite" element and go ahead and glue it together.

When Star Wars proved to be a blockbuster, game-changing entertainment event, the studios scrambled to come up with other productions which could cash in on that.  One project which got a green-light as a result of Star Wars' success was something producer Glenn Larson had been trying to get made for a while, "Mythology as science fiction" series which became "Battlestar Galactica."The original premise for BSG was very, very serious, though the characters were very, very human and relate-able.  It was never intended to be a "kid-friendly show."  But the studio and the network chose to push it into that direction, and production cost issues also came into play (it was tremendously expensive as a television series at the time... remember, this was in the days before CGI).  Both of these factors "undercut" the ability to make the show which the production team originally set out to make.So, we got endlessly recycle special effects sequences...  we got "cute kids" and a wide range of "kid-friendly" bits (including a ROBOTIC DOG "character").  There was plenty which was mock-worthy in the original series, and that's what is most remembered about it by many today.But... if you scrape away that, you find a premise which was truly outstanding, and very, very serious.More recently, a "re-imagining" was done, which did "scrape away" the bad parts of the original series, but also "scraped away" the truly GOOD parts of the original as well, and replaced those with parts which were every bit as bad as the bad parts of the original, albeit in very different ways.  While it started off strong, it lost people, flailed around, became incomprehensible, and ended up with an ending that most of its biggest fans were very unhappy with.In Larson's original idea, the Cylons were not "robots built by humans which rebelled," but rather an alien race which embraced its technology to such an extent that they, step by step, replaced their own bodies with machinery, and lost their "humanity" (so to speak) in the process.  And the colonies were the true "mythological basis" for our own legends.  "Apollo" wasn't a "pilot's call sign," but rather, was the actual figure our ancient ancestors knew as a "god" (with that being his actual NAME).  They're HUMANS...  in their souls, much like us... but their culture is as different from our modern culture as our culture is from the ancient Egyptians.So...  now, Larson is taking part in yet another "reboot," returning to the original's vision.  And part of that is retaining the original parts, which worked so well.  Including THIS SHIP (although, I'm sure, with enhanced fine details).  The folks who made the last "reboot" were under orders to not use the original ship design, even though they tried to honor it as much as they could.Years ago, MPC put out a model of the Galactica.  It was...  unimpressive.  Both inaccurate, and lacking in detail  The entire kit had only, as I recall, 17 parts, including two for the stand.  With a lot of effort and a lot of "aftermarket resin detail parts" you could turn it into something decent to look at, but the overall shapes were fairly inaccurate, and there was no way to fix that.So...  now, you have a model which is essentially the same size as that older kit, but is many, many orders of magnitude superior.  It's a GORGEOUS kit, very screen-accurate (though there are some compromises made in the production of the kit, mostly due to moldmaking limitations... and most of which can be fixed using aftermarket parts which are already available).The level of detail is many many times greater than the old "toy like" MPC kit.  The shapes are accurate to what was seen on-screen.  And the fit and the assembly process is nearly perfect...  there's really no need for any "filler putty" if you're careful as you assemble the kit.At this size (and there's quite a bit of debate as to the actual size of the original-series ship...  based upon inconsistent special effects work...  you can find some outstanding discussions of this online if you search for "how big is the galactica?"), this is about the best you could ask for.I LOVE this model.  It's a bit too small for full lighting, but you can light key elements (landing bays, main engines, etc) easily enough.  You'd need fiber-optic strands as small as a human hair, and a drill of similar size, to get the "windows" right, though, so there's no point in even trying at this scale, in my view.Paul at Paragrafix has produced a great after-market photo-etched brass detail kit for this, which includes illumination-friend interior setpieces for the landing bays (as well as a few other minor details which were unable to be properly molded in the kit).http://www.amazon.com/Paragrafix-Original-Series-Galactica-Photoetch/dp/B00IWVDXAS/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1404783106&sr=8-1&keywords=paragrafix+galacticaWhile the original Galactica had its low points, the design work was top-notch in all areas.  If you appreciate this design, you'll LOVE this model.I HIGHLY recommend this model, and yes, the Paragrafix photoetch sheet as well.

What do I mean by the above, my title for this review?  Well...  I've been a HUGE Star Trek fan for many, many years, and I now the USS Enterprise backwards and forwards, inside and out.  I've created my own (extraordinarily detailed and accurate) digital model of the ship, complete with a full interior (so every set seen on the show, plus many, many other features, are present).  I don't say this to brag, but rather to point out that I've paid a lot more attention to this ship than most folks have, and I know her very, very well.Revell's model is an excellent model...  of a ship LIKE the Enterprise.  But it's not the Enterprise.  There are many, many "errors" in the kit, and it's hard to believe that they're accidental, given just how much information is available regarding this topic.Now, for real-world naval vessels, these ships are often built at different shipyards, and there are sometimes fairly significant differences between two real-world naval vessels which are nevertheless both of the same "class" of ship.  "Class," you see, doesn't mean that two ships are identical...  only that they are "operationally interchangeable" (meaning that both can do the same job, essentially all of the time) and also interchangeable regarding support facilities (meaning that they both can be serviced by the same servicing systems).This model is, therefore, really a very nice example of a "sister ship" of the Enterprise, built at a different shipyard... functionally interchangeable with the Enterprise, able to be serviced and maintained at the same facilities using the same equipment... but not an identical ship.The overall proportions of the model are actually pretty good... quite accurate.  the problems are with the "fine details," which includes some more significant elements as well.This is a list of just the most obvious, blatant "errors" on this model (if it's supposed to be the Enterprise).1)  The top-side saucer.  There's a fairly sharp dividing line between the flat outer region and the curved inner region.  On the Enterprise, this is a very smooth, consistent curve.  (You can see this in pictures associated with this Amazon page.)2)  The bottom-side saucer.  The outer rim "flat area" is much wider than it ought to be, and has another "sharp transition."  The Enterprise has a very slight "flat area" with a smooth, gentle curve.  The curved "inset" area on the underside has its tallest point much further out on the Enterprise than this model does, and the inner, downwards-pointing region is wider (and less "steep") throughout, with a more gentle compound curve as well.3)  The bridge (on top of the saucer) of the Enterprise is not QUITE a "shallow" of a dome as you see on this kit, and the clear bit atop that should be larger in diameter as well (this is, depending on your perspective, either a "sensor dome" or the clear ceiling of the bridge... or, perhaps, both).4)  The area surrounding the dome on the underside of the saucer should be another fairly fancy "compound curve which actually has slight recessing.  On this model, it's a tiered, semi-conical shape, completely different from the feature on the Enterprise.  Also, the Enterprise has three "bumps" evenly spaced around this ring, which are absent on this model.5)  There are two triangular shapes on the underside of the saucer.  Each of these should have a raised "rib" on the inboard side.  This is absent on this kit.6)  The "slope" on the outer edge of the saucer is less on the Enterprise that the slope on the outside of this kit's saucer.7)  On the engines, there are two upwards-facing "fins"... these are supposed to be "intercoolers" (a real-world term for an intermediate cooling stage in a heat-exchanger system).  This means that they are, and should be, essentially "finned pipes."  On the Enterprise, that's what they are.  But on this kit, they're very thin, very flat... and are essentially JUST "fins."8)  The "boxy shapes" on the engine nacelles are more prominent on this kit than they are on the "real" Enterprise (as portrayed on screen by the 11' filming miniature)9)  The front end of the secondary hull ("cigar shaped" section) is completely wrong.  The kit has a region of several nearly perfectly symmetrical cylinders, but on the "real" Enterprise, these are much broader, and the outermost one has a significant taper to it.  Basically, it blends right into the shape of the secondary hull.  On this model, these are far narrower, with a much greater (and steeper) "step down" in front of the dorsal ("neck") leading into the dish emplacement.10)  The dish "antenna" (which is supposed to be something like a radar dish, but is powerful enough to also push objects out of the path of the ship... it's referred to as a sensor/deflector dish) on this kit is quite a bit different from that seen on the on-screen Enterprise.And finally... and most likely to be noticed by the casual builder...11)  This model is covered by large, prominent "grid lines" which, in scale are several feet wide.  The "real" Enterprise never had anything remotely like this.  The 11" miniature had some very, very fine PENCIL LINES drawn on it... impossible to see on the TV sets the makers of the show believed would be the only place the show would ever be seen, and used mainly to help them replace decals when they became damaged or if the production team wanted to, for example, portray another ship (or the other, unfinished, side of the 11" model).I could go on, but that's the list of the most egregious "errors" in this kit.The thing is... I get the impression that these aren't really "errors" per-se, but rather "artistic flourishes" made by the team which developed this kit.  They wanted to make a kit which wasn't like every other kit on the market, it seems.  They wanted to incorporate elements which they thought made "better sense," in some cases.  They blended elements of the rarer versions of the ship (also seen on screen) such as the Animated Series version, or the 3' miniature which Gene Roddenberry used to keep on his desk (and which was used along with the 11' one on the two pilot films which launched the series).  For example, the "error" with the front of the secondary hull is fairly "accurate" to the version seen in the Animated Series, though totally dissimilar to the ship seen in the original live-action series.So, I think that the "errors" were very likely purposeful design choices.  And as such, I can appreciate this model, and enjoy building it up... into a "sister ship" to the Enterprise (the USS Potempkin, for example).I still plan to fill in the gridlines... they just bug me.  And I'll replace the paper-thin "intercoolers" with more pipe-like parts (perhaps some after-market parts intended for the old AMT kit, which is very close to this in scale).  But the rest of the "flaws" in this kit can make perfect sense as another ship, built at another yard, using slightly different (but functionally interchangeable) equipment and construction.Yep...  this is, to me, the "Revell USS Potempkin."  As such, it's a great model.  But it's not the Enterprise... not by a long shot.

This is NOT the old AMT Kit...  it's an all-new tool, and much improved in many ways.  It is made by Revell Germany, which is a separate company from the Revell USA which makes models sold here.  Technically, Revell Germany is not permitted to sell these in the USA, so there are no "official channels" means of getting it here.  However, you can always buy one previously purchased by someone else...  and that's how most of these are sold.  Revell has done three all-new Trek kits (along with the Voyager which, as I understand, is the same tooling used a few years back for the USA version of that ship).  There's a "USS Enterprise" (which, while a fine model from a technical standpoint, has major errors... or at least "odd design choices"... which mean that it is NOT a model of the USS Enterprise, though it could be considered one of her sister ships).  There's the "New movie version USS Enterprise" which is actually a pretty nice kit... though I, personally, dislike the design of the ship in the new films.And then, there's this kit.  It is NOT a replica of any Klingon ship ever seen on screen...  Rather, it is a hybrid...  a mix of elements found on multiple different versions.Ultimately, it is most closely treated as a half-way point between the "CGI revised" version of the Klingon ship seen in the Deep Space 9 episode "Trials and Tribbleations," and the majorly altered version first seen in "Star Trek - The Motion Picture."Similar choices were made on the "Enterprise" kit... but it's a lot easier to forgive on this ship, as it can easily be treated as representing an intermediate design revision, between those two ship eras.The top surfaces of this ship have very fine panel details which were not present on the original-series ship, but were present (in only slightly more evident form) on the "ST-TMP" ship.  Other details are also "half-way merges" between those two types of ship, where elements' shapes are a blend of old and new.  The sensor tower behind the kidney-bean-shaped bridge is the most notable of the detail changes, as it has the row of observation windows which were shown so clearly in the opening sequence of ST-TMP,  but never seen on any other ship.To me, this is a great addition to the fleet, representing a Klingon ship built in between the end of the original series and the first film, showing the gradual evolution of technology.HOWEVER... if you want this to be a perfect replica of the ship seen in the original series...  you're out of luck.  The original AMT kit is far, far more accurate to that... especially after current American license holder "Round Two" has revised the tooling in the most recent releases.The same applies to the TOS Enterprise kit.  It's a great model...  but it's not a model of the Enterprise.  I plan to build mine as the Potempkin, and treat it as is the case with real naval vessels... ships built at different naval yards may be "nominally the same" but may show very visually evident differences in component shapes, specific subsystems installed, and so forth.As for the quality of the kit itself (or any other recent Revell Germany kit)... the kit is beautifully design, easy to build, and has a wide range of opportunities designed in for builder modification (such as lighting in this case).  The provided documentation is very well done (though the paint callouts refer to paint types typically only sold in Europe, not in the USA, so you'll have to do some homework to find USA equivalents).Overall.. this is probably the best of the German Trek kits.  But all are very, well-made and worth the money, in my view.  You just have to accept the "disputable" design choices (most significant on the TOS Enterprise, next here, and least an issue with the new movie ship).One note... if you buy this, or any other Revell Germany kit... realize that the box it's packaged in is quite flimsy.  Ensure that your seller puts this inside a larger, heavier box, with padding around it... it WILL get crushed by the post office if it's shipped with nothing but paper wrapping (as mine was).  Fortunately, the kit parts were not damaged when my own box was crushed.  But you may not be so lucky.  So, before paying, ensure that the seller will package it well.

Overall, this is a terrific book, but I marked it down a single point because Beck spends a large part of the latter portion of the book blaming things on a subject on which he has no real knowledge...  "violent video games," mainly.The first portion of the book is chock-full of real, and confirmable, arguments which directly counter the most popular arguments made by those who are the ideological heirs to the National Socialists of the past (remember, the "National Socialist Workers Party of Germany" is the true name of what we often refer to as the "Nazi party") as they attempt, one more time, to implement policies and practices intended to create an "elite ruling class" which governs every aspect of the lives of the "lesser, subjected people" (that would be all of US, regardless of skin color, gender, or so forth, for the record!).Lots and lots of strong, factually-accurate counter-arguments.  If that was the whole book, I'd give this a full five-star rating.  (Not much in that first section which I wasn't previously aware of, mind you, but it's good to have it all compiled in one place, especially if you want to share it with others who don't already know it!)But the latter portion of the book, which shifts blame so strongly onto "playing video games" (something I've done, myself, since I was a kid) as a primary cause of "violent behavior" is just poorly reasoned.  It falls into the "post-hoc ergo propter hoc fallacy" realm."Post hoc ergo propter hoc" fallacies basically come down to this... "we see this, and we see this, and they're together, so this one must be the result of that one."  This is BAD LOGIC.  It's just as likely that the one treated as the "cause" is actually the effect, and the one treated as the "effect" is really the cause, or perhaps that both are the "effect" of some other cause which hasn't even been identified.My argument would be the exact opposite of the argument made by Beck in the latter portion of this book.  In this case, you can associate a desire to kill people with a desire to kill people online in video games.  The CAUSE is "a brain wired to want to commit acts of violence," and the EFFECT is "playing games where you get to experience doing that."In my own case, I don't play "online deathmatch" games, because I find them boring... I get no pleasure from that.  But I do play "first person" games, including "first person shooter" games.  The games I most enjoy... the ones I'll actually PLAY... have actual PLOTS.  They're like movies, except that you, as the player, are the star of the film.  The games I play involve puzzles, not just "kill zones," and mysteries which you have to figure out.  Your actions in these games have real consequences, in-game...  choose wrong and you suffer for it (and sometimes "choosing wrong" means killing, or allowing to to be killed, someone who you've just met).So...  because Beck hasn't played these games, and has no personal knowledge of them, and thus speaks from a position of ignorance on this specific subject matter, I've marked the review down a star.  He's right about the main thesis of this book...  that "gun control" is all about "PEOPLE CONTROL" (those who keep the arms, in those circumstances, have total control over those who are disarmed).  But he's incorrect in his attribution and association of "video games" with the perceived increase in sociopathic behavior.Realistically, isn't it a more sound argument to say that "sociopaths today are more free to allow their inner desires out, because the potential consequences to themselves... WHICH IS THE ONLY THING WHICH CAN REIGN IN THE BEHAVIOR OF A SOCIOPATH (who have no sense of morality, and no conscience, by definition)...  have been effectively removed."There are not "more sociopaths" today.  They're not being created by movies, or TV, or video games.  The numbers are the same.The problem is that today's sociopaths feel free to act on their own impulses, in a way which yesteryear's sociopaths knew they could never get away with.

Written in pretty juvenile form...  I forced my way through it, but was not especially impressed.  The author doesn't really tell us a very compelling or complete story.  It has potential, but is not yet "publishing ready."  It's told in first-person form from a person with a very immature and self-absorbed perspective.  I mean, the entire world is collapsing, zombies are clawing at the freakin' doors, and yet every character is behaving like a spoiled child.  Not that there are many characters, mind you.The setup has potential... but we don't really get much story besides "I like this girl and I'll go find her at all costs, even though the world is ending and she's probably already gone."  Yes, the drama (so to speak) involves the delivery of a baby during this time, but it's not well-handled, and there's no emotional impact even when one of the main characters (as defined by "someone who says something at some point") dies.This author needs to take a couple of writing courses, study some really good work from other authors, and then come back and revisit this story.  Because there IS potential here, but it's not really fulfilled at any level by the story as told in this novella.

If you appreciate the humor of the show "The Guild," you'll enjoy this cute little Christmas tune.  "The Guild" can be found online..  in a series of "webisodes"... and can also be found in disk form, available, among other places, through Amazon itself.I love this show...  but your mileage may vary.  Essentially, this is "christmas carols" sung in online chat between a group of online gamers... playing what is never quite identified as, but clearly intended to be, "World of Warcraft."

This item is really a curiosity these days... not something with much in the way of "practical use."However, I still own every computer I've ever built, with the exception of those built for friends, and have only "given up" one which was a deeply flawed off-the-shelf "Packard Bell" system, many years ago.  The old systems make up what is almost a "museum" for me, but I do own some software which simply cannot be run on "modern" systems, and so on occasion I'll hook up one of these (through a KVM - "keyboard/video/mouse" switch - setup) and I can use them well enough.Windows on the PB came with a full set of disks for DOS and Windows 3.11 plus the "Workgroups Add-on."  I still have all that, and I moved it to another machine when the Packard Bell failed so utterly.  That machine still runs today, as I said... but I've never had a full set of manuals for Windows for Workgroups 3.11, only the "Packard Bell" manual, and the "Workgroups Add-on" manual (which is a small part of this full manual).I have learned a few things which I don't think I ever knew, and at the very least have totally forgotten.  It's useful if you want to work, for any reason, on a machine still running Windows 3.11.The biggest surprise, to me, was realizing that there was a 32-bit subsystem even in this version of Windows... something I'd never known.  (Very little software at the time used 32-bit code... though Win9x, which came later, made extensive use of, and provided extensive support for, 32-bit code.)My old machine... with the Microsoft TCP stack, so I can use it on the internet, and an early copy of Netscape (which still works with the majority of websites)... and with a real 5.25" floppy drive installed along with the more common modern bits...  still comes in handy for me, mainly for collecting data from very old sources from time to time.

I held off on buying the main kit for a long time... despite originally having been a participant in the so-called "1701 club," when I discovered that (a) the original kits were full of molding flaws and defects, and (b) the "extras" in the so-called "premier" kit weren't really things I wanted or needed, and finally (c) the team behind the kit had behaved very badly towards some of their customers, I chose to hold off.  I finally got the main kit at a significantly lower than "original" price (though not quite at the $75 price I still hold it SHOULD have sold for, in order to have plenty of sales!)The only "accessory" I really needed in this kit was the photoetch panel, but I decided it would be worth it to get the engine "bussard collector" (front of the engines) light board, as it was supposedly worked out to match, reasonably closely, the original series lighting effects, and I thought I'd give it a shot.  I have no real use for the "weathering decals" (which are very, very overstated by my own standards).  I also wanted some of the additional "clear parts" which I was otherwise going to have to make myself by recasting in clear resin some of the supplied polystyrene kit parts.As with the main kit, I got this at a discount, but it still costs more than the model itself, which is... PROBLEMATIC.What the add-on "accessory parts pack" contains...1)  A very nicely done "add-on" photoetched brass sheet which replaces some fine detail which is otherwise provided in "molded" form on the kit.  Really, this photo-etch sheet should have been provided as part of the MAIN KIT...  or rather, the individual parts (pre-trimmed from the frame and supported via lightly-adhesive backing on a sturdy card-stock sheet) should have been in that kit from the beginning, and should not be "separate."(There is an additional, "third party" photoetch detail sheet available... designed by the same guy who did this one... which is, appropriately, an "add-on" part, which contains some bits to help with the interior bridge and landing-bay setpieces, and gives some other nice options... and even has little figures to go behind windows and the like.  I highly recommend this add-on sheet!)2)  The "weathering decals."  Anyone who is planning to buy a tremendously expensive kit like this one is likely going to paint it, and likely will also be familiar with the use of pastel chalks, or light airbrushing, to create "weathering effects."  (I'm a chalks guy myself, as you can easily remove excess if you overdo it and haven't coated the chalk yet!)  These decals give you the infamous "rust ring" on the top of the saucer, but otherwise, result in a more difficult "weathering" process than just airbrushing or applying chalk.  (And the "rust ring" is really pretty easy to accomplish if you really want it on your ship anyway...especially if you're one of those who intends to keep the inaccurate "engraved gridline pattern" on the saucer surfaces, as you can just use the engraved lines as your guide!)3)  The lighting kit.This consists of the following:a)  two small motors with small gearboxes on them.  They're not the BEST gearmotors for this purpose... they make more noise than I'd like, frankly... but they're sufficient, and you can reduce the noise significantly by proper mounting and noise-insulation inside the nacelles (not following the kit instructions, by the way).  I suspect I'll go ahead and use these motors... but I've already worked out a mounting scheme which will allow me to replace them, easily, in the future if I need to!)b) a length of "LED tape."  This stuff can be obtained through many sources, and at a significantly lower cost than you're paying with this kit...  but the tape itself is good quality and it's worth it, as far as I'm concerned.  I'll be using this, though not in the way the kit specifies, and I'll be adding quite a few more short segments, as my entire ship model is going to have "interior sets" anywhere there's a window (with the windows being made from microscope slide slipcover glass, cut to size).c)  A wiring harness, complete with some LEDs in place already (for running lamps, etc) and with "quick clips" for the LED tape.  This is supposed to make for easy and quick construction...  but, as most will tell you, the clips are not very reliable.  You're far better off to remove the clips and solder directly onto the contact pads on the tape ends... unless you just can't solder, that is.  If you're not able to solder (say, if you have arthritis and you have stiff or shaky hands), the clips may come in handy, but you'll want to be VERY careful to ensure that they're "just PERFECT" before closing up your model!d)  A small "wall-wart" power supply.  In my own case, as I'm adding quite a bit to the model, I'm going to replace this with a higher-amperage (same voltage!) supply.  It'll be a 2A or 3A power supply, switching-type, but with a very high-quality "noise reduction" filtering element.e)  Clear molded copies of several parts which, in the kit, are molded in "hull color."  Mainly, this includes the part for the landing bay (not "hangar deck"...  a hangar is where the craft are STORED, and is found one deck down from the landing bay!), the little bridge, and a few other details.  These should have been provided in the main kit, not as an "add-on" requiring the purchase of all this other stuff (which we really don't need).  While some of us know how to recast parts in clear resin, most don't... and those who do might prefer not having to!f)  Color-molded copies of several parts which are provided in the kit as "plain clear" parts.  These are mainly the lamps used within the nacelle domes, but there are others as well.  Nice to have, but these SHOULD have been provided in this form in the main kit.g)  two printed circuit board assemblies (PCBAs), one for the primary "saucer" hull and one for the secondary "cigar" hull, and one PCBA each for the two warp engine nacelles.  The circuits on these are very simple, but they do include "flasher" circuits which come in handy, though they don't properly replicate the side-of-secondary-hull-strobes properly, and cannot be "modified" to reflect the different flashing patterns seen throughout the run of the original TV series.To me, the lighting kit is a "starter kit" which needs a LOT of work to meet my own needs.  The photoetch parts are wonderful but should have been in the main kit from the beginning.  And the decals are simply a waste of money as far as I'm concerned.That said... if you're rolling in cash, want to build a pretty good replica of the original Enterprise in large scale, don't want to, or are unable to, work very hard in making that...  buying the model and this "accessory pack" and a little glue can result in a model which will look "pretty darned good" until you get up pretty close.If you want to do a "perfect" version of the Enterprise, or want more configurability (and electronics reliability) you'll be treating this as a "starting point" but will be altering it significantly... perhaps even "drastically" as I'm going to be doing.

I've had a nice, sturdy ironing board since I was in college, many years ago.  I had a silvery-silicone-coated cover on it initially, and that cover lasted for many years, but recently the elastic finally "crumbled" and it became useless.  So I needed a new one.The market is just full of what I consider to be tacky, ugly, and (since not coated like my old one was) not very useful "covers."  But I wanted one which would be equivalent to my old one.  Most of them, I think, reduced my testosterone levels just by looking at them, too!This one fits the bill perfectly.  I'm very pleased so far.The cover comes "packed inside itself"... that is, rolled/folded up inside the "storage pouch" mentioned in the description.  You will NEED TO BE CAREFUL as you unpack it, because if you're not careful, you could easily shred the inner foam-rubber liner.It's also, like most older-style covers, a bit... Okay, more than "a bit"... TIGHT, at least initially.  The fabric will stretch, over a short period of time, to conform properly to the shape of your board... or at least, it did with my board!Once on, it provides a great, heat-resistant and stain-resistant surface on which to do your ironing.Personally, I HATE ironing... but when I have to do it, I want a top-quality board (and cover) to do it on... and this one is the best I've seen since buying my original, decades ago.  I recommend this without reservation... if you've gotta iron at all, that is!

It was odd "reviewing" this...  as it's a replacement part for a larger system, and thus it's sort of strange, trying to not review the top-level system along with the replacement component.So...  let's do both.  The Logitech Z-5500 speaker system is a TERRIFIC 5.1 speaker system,  providing outstanding "computer-focused" surround sound for games and in-office-media-playback.  However, it has a few design defects and quality issues.My first control pod failed while the unit was still under warranty.  I sent it back and Logitech sent me a replacement.  The second one still functions, but the backlighting no longer works (making the display nearly unreadable in low-light conditions) and the display itself occasionally stops working entirely.The reason for this is simply that the internal electronics overheat...  sufficiently so that the surface-mount components on the board can "migrate" over time, if allowed to become warm.  The little LEDS are usually the first thing to "float off" of their surface-mount pads, while the display follows suit soon afterwards, and finally the two large integrated circuits (at which point the unit ceases to work at all).The problem is that there are only a few vents on the rear of the unit, and that surface is slanted so that there is no real way to get air circulation through the enclosure.The easiest solution (for a NEW UNIT) will be to disassemble it and drill a pattern of small holes on the upper and lower faces of the control box.  Air will then move through the unit through natural convection, and this may well be sufficient to prevent the ongoing failures so many users have experienced.A bit more complicated, you can mount a small fan inside (or, I suppose, outside?) the grill on the back... IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE HOLES I PREVIOUSLY MENTIONED... to force air into the case (and out the holes I talk about which you'd add), or potentially to pull air out through that existing vent pattern.  I've actually ordered a fan which I plan to install in that location... 40mm x 40mm x 10mm... inside the enclosure.  It's a 12V fan but is supposed to be able to start at down to 6V, and the pod received 7.5V power from the main subwoofer, so it should be an effective (and quiet) cooling solution.The defect is that they really screwed up on their "thermal engineering" and the thing simply overheats... ESPECIALLY if under heavy use, but it gets "too warm" any time it's powered on.If I succeed in getting the new unit to work, I'll "refit" the old unit (resoldering the display and the surface-mount LEDs) and do the same cooling to it.It's worth noting that some people have noticed that the "PID" ("Product identifier," I presume) on the back is significant to determining compatibility.  My original one was a low number (I can't recall the exact number), the replacement Logitech sent to me was a higher number, and this unit is somewhere in between, and all work for me.  However, supposedly, the "PID" can result in some subwoofer/ampliers not working with some control pods.  I have no idea why, but you can find lots of information about this online, and I recommend you look into this and make your own informed choice.  Whether or not you have a good experience or a bad one may, if the internet is to be believed, depend on getting a unit in the right "range."Finally, all of these seem to be coming from a common location, whether you look at Amazon, Ebay, or a few other locales I've check out on the net.  I recommend using care dealing with the vendor.  While I eventually got satisfaction, initially they sent me a $5 USB dongle for a mouse instead... and when I tried to contact them via telephone, was blown off by the young asian woman who answered the phone and who refused to even let me speak to anyone else, and who eventually hang up the phone on me when I insisted that, since the "business" I bought from was the same address and phone number as her "business" address and phone number, she should at least be able to hand the phone to the person who "worked at that business" there.I did get things straightened out, but it was a very annoying (and more than a little insulting) way to be treated.  I informed others at the business, and I HOPE that they have altered their procedures to provide better customer-service.  So don't judge them entirely based upon my own experience, but rather just go in "with your eyes wide open" and protect yourself, in case they haven't corrected their internal issues.Since I have not yet received the fan I've ordered to install in this, I'm currently using an external, USB-powered fan, blowing across the back vent, which is serving to keep it more than adequately cool, by the way.  Even a small amount of air flow should do the trick.  But Logitech didn't really think that aspect of the design through.  So... if you have a failed pod, and need to replace it, this is a GREAT solution... but you'll need to address the root cause of the failure, or it'll just happen again in short order.

I really, really wanted to see this at the theaters, but missed it (due to some...  logistical concerns?) so I only got to see the film, for the very first time, this last weekend.  I was hopeful, but cautious...  who would know if it would be any good?I avoided the reviews, until after I'd seen it, and then read the "rotten tomatoes" reviews on the film.  I find myself wondering what film some of these people were watching, and whether or not the reviewers have any idea what they're talking about.  It seems that most of them refer to the 1979 movie as "the source material" and have no idea that the character of Superman has been around a LOT longer than that, and that the character has been played by many, many different actors, not just the late Christopher Reeve.I knew, the moment I first saw the actor in-character, though, that they'd finally gotten the casting RIGHT.  I've liked various actors at various times to various degrees, but I'd never seen any of them who looked like the character in the books, until now.  Henry Cavill is, in my personal opinion, the single best casting choice for this character yet, and I find it hard to believe that there will be a better one to follow.So...  the film starts, and we get Krypton.  Not the Krypton from the 1979 movie, but an amalgam of different Kryptons from the history of the character.  We see the "organic, grown technology aspect," we get the floating drones (taken almost without alteration from the 1980s comic book reboot, by the same title as this film, "The Man of Steel"), but we also get the "pulp sci-fi" elements of the older versions of Krypton as well...  including the once-ever-present "flying beasts" and so forth.Many, many reviewers recoiled with horror from this sequence... not because it's not faithful to the source material, and not because it's not "good storytelling," but simply because it's "not big white crystal spires with Marlon Brando in white" just redressed.  So, let's be clear... THE KRYPTON IN THE MOVIE IS CLOSER TO THE SOURCE MATERIAL VERSION THAN THE VERSION SEEN IN THE 1979 FILM!  Got it, folks?The film, wisely, skips over the "chronological origin story" since we all, pretty much, know that the Kents found Kal-L, named him "Clark," and raised him as their son.  We're not pounded over the head with a repeat of the full "Clark growing up backstory" but we are shown enough to tell the (rare) newcomer pretty much what's going on, without just rehashing old territory.We are shown General Zod...  but, unlike the (forgive the term) "Cartoon villain" Zod we've seen previously, we get a character who actually is not (at least in his own eyes) the "bad guy."  There is no doubt, in this film... Zod sees himself as the hero.. the savior of his race.What a refreshing thing to see in a film...  a "bad guy" who actually has a real motivation, real emotions which we, as the audience, can relate to.  Isn't it almost shocking to see a "villain" who becomes the villain because, in some twisted way, he's trying to "do good?"  I LOVED this.  It was so, so much more satisfying than another "mustachio-twirling guy" (through granted, I still love the cartoonish villains from the 1979 film in their own way)We didn't get a full backstory for Clark... instead, we "discover" key moments in his past through flashbacks.  It works very well, because it's in no way "contrived."  We see scenes we KNOW are important, not because the producers are showing them to us, but because the CHARACTER is showing them to us...  it makes a difference in terms of the impact of each scene.There are stumbles, of course.  I found the "death of Jonathan Kent" to be really, really badly handled.  I get what they were trying to do...  show us that Jonathan Kent was more concerned with hiding Clark's nature than with anything else.  But...  I'm sorry, it was just SILLY.  Why not have Jonathan carry the child, and have Clark run back to get the dog?  (I mean, Clark would be faster...  and a LOT stronger...  and would have a far better chance of success.  And even if he had to use "super power" in some way, with the tornado behind him most people would not really notice, or would attribute it to their imagination!)I also didn't like how obvious it is, now, where Superman hails from.  Surely SOMEONE would stop to ask "why did the Kryptonians attack Smallville, Kansas?"  Especially now that it's known that Superman "grew up in Kansas."  Martha, expect to see some visitors in black helicopters coming your way soon!I liked the "wandering to find my way" bit...  which, by the way, IS canonical, depending on which version of Superman you're talking about (Clark didn't necessarily go straight from Smallville High to the Daily Planet).  I realize some people will find this derivative of the scenes at the beginning of "Batman Begins" but the "derivation" of this far, far predates that...  read some Joseph Campbell, for his discussion of the "hero's journey" which always involves some period of self-exploration and even self-denial.I will admit that I was surprised to see Lois learning about Clark's identity before he worked at the Planet, but I'm OK with that.  And I liked the portrayal of Lois Lane, though I must admit, the actress playing her was... to my mind...  fairly "generic," and easily replaceable.  (I actually think that the best Lois to date is Erica Durance, from the series "Smallville.")The final conflict-stage of the film showed a LOT of violence and devastation...  and the action was non-stop.  This could have been toned down, a bit, I think...  the CGI effects went over the top...  but this was more consistent with what we see in the comic books than you might think.  (I just hope that Superman takes an active hand in the reconstruction, or it'll take many decades... after all, we've still yet to see a completed replacement for the World Trade Center!)The biggest compliant from "serious" Superman fans is the end of the final battle sequence...  where Superman kills.  But I find that to be a truly sad complaint, showing a lack of grasp of reality (an odd statement to make in relation to a "comic book movie" I suppose).  IN REAL LIFE, there are situations when there's simply no option.  You can try to "make peace" but sometimes, if the other guy is unwilling to make peace with YOU, you have no choice but to knock him down, and make sure he can't get back up again.  In this case, Zod was trying to continue to murder people...  personally, no less (the tens of thousands of dead from his "technological attacks" previously would, to his mind, be collateral damage, not "murder" per-se) and there was NO WAY that you could restrain him, imprison him, or otherwise make him stop... other than simply stopping him, permanently.By killing Zod, Superman saved hundreds of millions, if not six billion, human lives.  A heavy price to pay, but one that a TRUE HERO would have to pay (side note - this is an ongoing discussion in "Batman" circles...  is Batman actually responsible for all the deaths caused by The Joker, since had Batman simply killed the Joker early on, none of those people would have died?)The end of the film... apparently after a major reconstruction effort in Metropolis (and maybe it was the ongoing help in reconstruction which results in Superman becoming, nominally, headquartered in Metropolis rather than, say, New York or Los Angeles or Chicago)...  we find ourselves with the "status quo" we all expect to see...  Clark Kent as reporter at the Daily Planet, working with Lois Lane.  Any future films in this "cycle" will feel much more... familiar?...  to the casual fan.There is NO LEX LUTHOR in this film...  but there are signs aplenty of the presence of "LexCorp," as well as several small references to "Wayne Enterprises" and "Ferris Aircraft," among others... showing that this film takes place in a larger DC Comics universe.And it's being talked about now that the sequel to this film will likely involve some other characters...  Batman and Wonder Woman, very likely (who MAY have even been seen in this film, in a much-debated point), along with Green Lantern.  Maybe we'll even see Green Arrow or some of the other characters come along, in "realistic" forms.You see, DC has taken note of the success of "The Avengers" and the "whole Marvel Universe" approach...  and they're unlikely to let this go.What you see in this film is the origin story of Superman...  in a way you've never seen before.It's not a "darker" story...  but it's not CAMP.  It's perhaps the first fully SERIOUS take on the Superman concept (Smallville, the series, was pretty serious at times, but was a bit too "soap opera-ish" to really count, in my opinion... and all the other versions were light-hearted, non-serious approaches).This is a Superman who exists in a world which we can recognize, with rules we can recognize...  and people who act like real people, not like "cartoon characters."I, for one, have been waiting to see this for a very long time.  And this film, a few minor flaws aside, delivers what I was looking for!EDIT:  As a side note, I strongly recommend the following (I have it as an audiobook) to give you a better vision of Krypton.  The Krypton as seen in this film is really very consistent with this book...***************Last Days Krypton Kevin Anderson*****************

I will start off by saying that I am a huge fan of Max Brooks' two "Zombie" books... "The Zombie Survival Guide" and the far better companion-piece, "World War Z."  Brooks created an entire world, an entire "mechanism," and entire natural history...... and this movie has almost nothing whatsoever to do with Brooks' books.  Let's just be up-front about that.  I CANNOT UNDERSTAND why someone would choose to "adapt a book" and then produce a product with only one name (and two quotes from that character) re-used (and in different context), totally change the nature of the threat, totally change the nature of the narrative... WHY?It's beyond me.  It really is.That said...  as a "zombie movie" this film isn't bad.  It's not GREAT, either, but it's not BAD.  The biggest problems I have with this movie are with how utterly ludicrous certain elements of it really are.Brooks created a disease... including the cause of that disease, a virus called "Solanum" which has been present on Earth since the beginnings of the human race, but which (until the advent of modern high-speed transportation) has always resulted in small, localized outbreaks, never in a world-wide collapse.  Key to this is that the reanimated dead are, at most, SIMPLY HUMAN.  They are not, in any way, SUPERHUMAN.  If the human body cannot do something when alive, it cannot do it when dead and reanimated, either.  And in many cases, especially as the body breaks down, these abilities become less... and NEVER become more.While Brooks' zombies never tire, exactly, they also never heal...  which means that muscle strength decreases, often dramatically, over time.They decompose slowly, because the virus (Solanum) is deadly to ALL LIVING THINGS, including bacteria and insects, and thus most living things instinctively flee from an infection, or are killed immediately if they don't flee and come into contact with it (the partial exception being humans, which are "killed and then reanimated" rather than merely killed.)But the zombies in this film are "SUPER-ZOMBIES!!!!"  (Duh-duh-DAAAAAH!!!)  They can do things no human body could do, even at its prime.  They can burst through plate glass which would be physically impossible for a living human to break.  They can climb up walls which no number of living humans could climb up.  A charging group of them can "churn" over a bus, flipping it in the process.  They can run and leap far, far faster than any mortal human can.Heck, I'm surprised that none of them were able to FLY in this film!Further, Brooks' zombies die in a process which is pretty well-established, and which makes a certain degree of sense.  From initial contact to death is usually around 24 hours, with reanimation usually happening at some point before three more hours pass in most cases.  You can imagine Solanum reproducing within the body at that sort of rate... it requires no MAGIC to happen.  But there is no microorganism ever seen, or even IMAGINED, which can reproduce at the rate seen in this film.  From twenty-four-plus hours, we now see "twelve seconds" to a fully transformed zombie.So... if you hope to be able to "willfully suspend your disbelief" while watching this film...  and if you have the slightest grasp of biology at any level...  you'll be unable to do so, PERIOD.Further, they came up with a "Deux Ex Machina" solution which was made necessary by the "SUPERZOMBIE" nature of the reanimated in this film...  which is just ludicrous and, again, totally inconsistent with real biology at any possible level.SO...  there you go.But on the POSITIVE SIDE... you have good characterizations, a reasonable amount of fairly interesting storytelling, and some real chills and thrills along the way.Yes, it's predictable.  Yes, it's trite at times.  And yes, it relies far, far too much on CGI-created visual spectacle and not enough on solid storytelling principles.  And it's one of the most scientifically laughable movies ever made in the "zombie" genre (and that's saying something, isn't it!)But... if you can put those aside, it's still a movie which you'll probably enjoy, just because you really do come to care about who these people are and what happens to them (unlike most zombie flicks ever made).I do not encourage anyone to take this seriously...  but if you want some brainless, light entertainment, it's not a bad choice.On the other hand, if you're the type who enjoys deep, multi-layered storytelling (not about "I woke up and was chased by zombies all day" but rather "what happens to human society when pushed beyond the breaking point?") you should pick up Brooks' book(s).  Or even better, get the unabridged audio book version (the abridged versions are nice, too, but to get the full story, and see how it all relates, you really want the unabridged versions).The audiobooks are really remarkable, in fact, for having a full cast presentation.  Realize, the book is written from the standpoint of a journalist recording interviews with survivors of the zombie war... aka "World War Z."  It's done in that tone... very much like you'd hear if the news did interviews with 9/11 survivors today.  The stories are arranged to tell the story of the whole war, both in chronological terms and also in "conceptual terms" (with sections describing their purpose, like one entitled "Warning Signs" and another entitled "Blame").  Each story is told in "first person" to the interviewer...  but the characters, and the full cast of big-name actors playing them, is widely varied, and no two stories are similar, really.You can enjoy this film, for what it is... but just realize, it's unrelated to the book, and the book is FAR, FAR more worthy of your time.

Let's start off with the following disclaimer... I am a huge original-series Star Trek fan, and have compared each subsequent series or film to that original show.  In some cases, the latter works compared favorably, and in others unfavorably, but all have the original series as the main "yardstick" in my mind.  This film, and its predescessor, fall into that same category... as far as I'm concerned, they exist in the shadow of the ORIGINAL, and must be compared to it.  After all, the original is still watched, today, after almost half a century.  None of what has followed on has shown anything remotely like the same "legs" that the original show did.The reason that the original series was, in my opinion, so wonderful was almost something "alchemical"...  a remarkable mix of many, many element which just came together to form a fantastic whole.  While the original concepts and much of the character development came from Gene Roddenberry, he was far, far from alone in the creation of the original Star Trek.  And much of what came into being grew, not from his imagination, but from the active involvement of others unrelated to him (Gene Coon, to me, gets more credit than Gene Roddenberry does, for example, and each actor had a large role in defining their own characters).The design, done by a man with a real technical design background (in aerospace), named Walter ("Matt") Jefferies.  The prop designs, and many of the more complex makeup designs, as well as the Romulan design...  by a master artisan named Wah Chang.  The music (not just the original fanfare by Alexander Courage, but the many other musical elements, in many cases long since forgotten by modern Trek composers, and to me sorely missed)...  the scripts written, in many cases, by accomplished prose authors...  some really great art direction and some terrific episodic directors.  It all came together to create "magic."The original concept was that the Captain, the First Officer, and the Chief Engineer would be the three main characters.  However, this shifted as DeForrest Kelley as Dr. Leonard McCoy just caught fire with the audience and the production team.  Scotty was pushed back a bit, and McCoy rose to the forefront.Many view the original as so successful because it played to widely recognized psychological models...  with Kirk as the "superego" (the deciding factor element of the brain in psychological theory), Spock as the "ego" (the purely intellectual, "higher" element of the mind) and McCoy as the ID (the more instinctive, emotional elements of the mind).  Whether this was ever really intended...  it WORKED, and that's central to who these characters are and how they best served in the series.Star Trek, at its best, was always about us trying (and not always succeeding completely) to rise above our base natures.  It was HOPEFUL, but it was also real... these were real people, who we could imagine knowing in real life, but they were "us as we hope we might be, at our best."SOme of the great lines in Classic Star Trek involved Kirk's morality.  Kirk refusing to kill the helpless Gorn commander, who had been trying to kill him...  and this is what proved to the keepers of the Arena that humanity had worth.  Kirk admitting that he's "a killer, from a race of killers... but I choose not to kill today" in another episode.Star Trek, classically, had a MESSAGE.  A message that, as flawed as we are, we can be better, and we can overcome, and we can survive, without giving up our humanity, and without giving into our baser nature.That... not the general shape of the ships, or the color of the shirts, or the names of the characters...  is what made "Star Trek" special.  The latter series tried, and USUALLY succeeded, in adherence to that, but the overall quality of those latter series varied, widely.  Nevertheless, none of them ever attempted to "revise" the original concepts and ideals of Star Trek.Until JJ Abrams came along, that is.The first movie, in 2009, was widely enjoyed by audiences...  for being a "thrilling romp with awesome visuals."  It performed better than other recent Trek films, and (in unadjusted-for-inflation dollars) was the highest-grossing movie in Trek history (adjusting for inflation gives different results, of course, but ST'09 remains among the top-earning Trek films made).But that first movie lost the nature of Star Trek which I loved.  They ignored (due, I assume, to utter ignorance of real-world protocols and, more importantly, the REASONS behind those protocols) military logic.  Putting a fresh cadet in charge of the fleet flagship, ignoring the likely tens of thousands of other serving officers with far, far more experience and qualifications?  Not likely.  Uhura getting aboard the Enterprise through "blackmail" due to her sleeping with her superior... that's why the real military has regulations making "fraternization" a criminal offense (subject to prison time) for the senior personnel involved.  They failed to understand what a singularity is...  they failed to understand anything related to interstellar distances, or even intra-stellar ones (seriously, Old Spock could SEE VULCAN DESTROYED from his vantage point, but his planet was not swallowed up by the same singularity???)Still, I could almost forgive all of that... the lack of logic, of thought behind choices, of the horrendously bad set and prop design...  if the CHARACTERIZATIONS HAD BEEN RIGHT.  But...  they were not.  These were characters who had the same names, and somewhat similar appearances, but who (for the most part) felt utterly unrelated to the characters as portrayed previously.Karl Urban's McCoy was the best of the bunch, in my opinion...  and Zachary Quinto, given the script he was fed, did a decent job as Spock.  Chris Pine was, in my view, badly miscast...  a decent actor, but his "Kirk" has nothing whatsoever to do with the Kirk I grew up with.  They created a new character, from whole cloth, and named him "Jim Kirk," and expected us not to be bothered by the fact that he had nothing at all in common with the character we know.  As much of a fan as I am of Simon Pegg, I thought his "Scotty" was terrible...  like a bad Saturday Night Live parody.  I didn't mind John Cho as Sulu... he's a fine actor who I'm loving in "Sleepy Hollow"...  but I found the casting of Chekov and Uhura to be pretty poor, as neither actor had anything in common with the originals except for a partial skin-tone similarity in one case... and I'd been hoping that they'd hire an actual Russian actor and an actual African actress to play the roles.Still, in that first movie, they retained to a degree the central role of McCoy in the mix, at least.  But they ignored the philosophy of Star Trek...  it was just wall-to-wall "attitude, explosions, and pandering."  And, of course, they seemed to be trying (way too hard, frankly) to put together "the original series status quo" in just a couple of hours.In the end, I really hated it, personally.  The first film left me feeling like I'd woken up in the morning, gone into my child's bedroom, and found a stranger in there, pretending to be my child...  except in mocking fashion, torturing my real child's beloved pets and so forth.  Like a mythological "changeling"... go look it up.Still, I tried to keep an open mind with respect to this second film.  Having "put all the pieces onto the board in the right order" in the first film, I had hopes that they'd treat the second film as a "classic Star Trek episode" as much as possible, relying on the structures and philosophies with the original series so successfully implemented.Sadly,I was disappointed at every turn.At least in this film they seem to have settled on a size and scale for the Enterprise... in the first film, the size of the ship fluctuated wildly, from more than twice the length of the TNG ship (itself dwarfing the original-series ship) to just about 2x the size of the original-series ship, to one sequence showing it smaller than the original-series ship.  This time out, it seems that the "JJ-Prise" is something like 1.75 x the size of the original ship... but of course we get another "hugererererer" ship in this movie... which dwarfs the city of San Francisco (though at that size, its fall from orbit through the atmosphere at the speeds shown would have taken a seconds at most, not the minutes it showed on-screen).The characterizations were not improved in this film, with the exception of Chris Pine, who I THINK was trying (with little help from the script) to give us a Kirk who was at least somewhat reminiscent of the original.  Spock was terribly disserved... and the "soap opera" between lovers Spock and Uhura was really, really badly carried off.  McCoy was almost ignored...  because, apparently, JJ wants the "big three" to be Kirk, Spock, and Uhura.  Urban did his best, but he was given so little to do in this film that it was shocking, frankly.  Pegg's "Scotty" wasn't as badly "parody-ish" this time around... but he still doesn't seem to be portraying a character with anything at all to do with the character played by James Doohan... despite their putting in a "Scotty drinking" scene.  (Drinking doesn't make a character... CHARACTERIZATION does!)  Super-girl Uhura was, to me, just horrendously FORCED... JJ Abrams and team wanting to create a "feminist-friendly starlet character" in the film...  except that it really doesn't work.  While Zoe Saldana is a nice-looking girl and I'm sure is a decent actress... the role that this character is supposed to play in this world would not the "action hero" that JJ wants her to be.  He found every excuse in the book to send her along on the "action sequences" but all this really ended up showing is why, again, FRATERNIZATION IS A REALLY BAD THING in a military or paramilitary environment.The biggest secret re: this film, of course, was ...  KHAAAAAAAANNNN.  It was the secret which was never really a secret.  But, of course, they did their level best to make us not think it was Khan by casting an actor unrelated to either the original presentation of Khan or to the fictional-real-world nature of Khan, and having the actor playing the part show literally no common psychological or personality traits with the Khan we all know.  In other words...  why call him "Khan" if you're not going to make him even remotely similar to Khan as we know him?  I'd have bee happier if they'd left him with the "assumed name" he initially has in the film, and come up with some other reason for him to be a GOD.And that's what he was.  Khan, in the original series, was a man.  A man whose genetics had been improved through eugenics (laboratory-level selective breeding, NOT "genetic code rewriting" by the way!).  Stronger, faster, smarter... but still HUMAN...  just representing the pinnacle of what humanity might be...  say, the top 1% of today's strength, intellect, and so forth, all combined into a single person.But Khan in this film is MAGICAL, it seems.  His strength is akin to Clark Kent in uniform.  He's literally invulnerable to injury or damage (and has "magic blood" which, instead of consuming other genetically-dissimilar life, somehow can "cure anything that ails ya!" regardless of whether you a "superman," a normal human, or a little round fuzzy lifeform from halfway across the galaxy with a totally unrelated genetic structure).  Heck, it can even bring the dead back to life!  And it'll only cost you $9.99... plus you get this set of Ginsu Knives!  (Yes, that's sarcasm... but that's exactly how I felt about this story as they showed that cheap "McGuffin" at the end.)Naturally, they have a massive uber-starship which dwarfs anything ever seen...  and yet can be operated by a crew of one.  (Question... if you only need one man to crew the ship... why have it be so big?  What's the point of the size of the ship in the first place?  Other than to be "kewlerererererer and hugererererererer" than even the JJ Enterprise, I mean?)  And this ship, with the help of this one "superman," has somehow led to technological breakthroughs that the entire rest of a hundreds-of-trillions-strong population spread throughout the galaxy could never have thought of.  Again, see, it's cause "JJ's Khan is a GOD."  It's faster, better, stronger, tougher...  and somehow, NOBODY IN THE CIVILIAN LEADERSHIP OF THE DEMOCRATICALLY-RUN UNITED FEDERATION OF PLANETS HAD ANY IDEA THAT THIS WAS BEING BUILT?  How, I wonder, did they fund this?  Girl scout cookie sales???  Who worked on it?  And is the JJ-verse press so totally controlled that nobody ever reported anything on any of this?  In other words...  is the JJ-Trek future really a fascist utopia?  Because, barring that, I fail to see any way that something like this makes any sense whatsoever.So...  we have this huge ship... and why?  Because "it'll look kewl crashing into the San Francisco Bay and wiping out half the bay."  Again, a real issue of lack of understanding of science...  such a crash would not have just "left a groove" and knocked down downtown San Francisco... that much energy would have wiped out EVERYTHING.  The waves alone would have wiped out every city within many miles of the SF Bay.  The impact would fracture the San Andreas Fault, and anything still standing would be down in short order.  It made NO SENSE...  but it sure did make for a kewl CGI effect, didn't it?  (Crashing something the size of the TOS Enterprise would have been much more reasonable...  but you wouldn't get those kewl sequences of a tilted saucer "skating" through the San Francisco skyline, would you?)Okay...  so...  characterizations - BAD.  Plausibility (remember, SCIENCE FICTION is not the same as fantasy...  it projects from what we know, it doesn't contradict what we know!) - BAD.  Design - only the most minor of improvements from the first film (at least we got minimal exposure to the Pabst Brewery this time around, and the phasers seemed to be a LITTLE bit improved... at least they didn't do "product placement flippy shots" to try to sell toy phasers this time!) but still, overall - BAD.This is not to say that the film isn't entertaining...  but the entertainment value is based entirely upon the "spectacle" of it, not based upon anything remotely akin to "making the audience think."  It's not impossible to do both in a film...  a movie like "The Island" from a couple of years back hit the "thinking" and the "outrageous action" targets equally well, for example...but this one, while a rousing success on the "visual spectacle" level, utterly fails on the "makes you think, and makes you care" level.And that second item - making you think, and making you care - is where Classic Star Trek was at its best.  Unfortunately, JJ Abrams and his team seem not to have a grasp of how to do that.Fortunately, it seems that Abrams will have minimal involvement in the next film...  at the very least, he won't be directing, anyway...  so it'll be interesting to watch and see how a new director may approach this property.  A new team, even one including elements of the team from the prior two films, could make that "magic spark" happen and so there's still a chance... slim, but still there... that the third film (and likely the last one with this cast and production team, I strongly suspect) might finally give us a "Star Trek film" which brings us the things that so many of us loved so much about the original show.  Not the costume design, not the set design or ship design, or prop design... though all of those could be much, much better... but the charcterization and writing... the direction and acting.There's hope for the future, but it's a slim hope.  This movie had "hope" too... and those hopes, for me at least, were totally dashed by this film.

This little tree ornament is very accurate to the filming miniature as built by prop-master Wah Chang during the original Star Trek TV series.  (Chang also did the phasers, communicators, tricorders, and several of the most famous alien designs, including the salt vampire and the "Balok puppet.")The only disappointing element of this is that it's a battery-powered device, and does not plug into the tree lights like the older ones did.  So, it only lights for a few seconds after pressing a button on the back, and does not stay lit.So, for design accuracy and execution - 5-stars.  For functionality as an ornament - 3-stars.  It's basically a static, unlit ornament, when you get right down to it.

Some years ago now, "Polar Lights" shut down and was acquired by "Round 2."  Round 2 has re-issued the prior two 1:350 Star Trek kits (the movie Enterprise and the NX-01 "prequel" Enterprise) but this is the first of the large kits developed entirely under the auspices of Round 2.This kit is very nicely made, overall, but there is still significant room for improvement.  In order to understand why this is the case, it's important to talk a little about the Enterprise itself.The "real" Enterprise, of course, never existed.  The only "real" ship is the one which appeared on TV sets in 1966,1967, 1968, and 1969 (three seasons) and then in re-runs for years afterwards.  There were several models used, during the run of the series, to represent the "real" Enterprise, and these models were not all identical.
