That's good, sometimes... unless you need to be aware of what's happening around you.  If someone tries to talk to me when I'm wearing these (even if nothing is playing), I need to reove them.  They're very effective as "ear plugs."And, third...  my ears are shaped in such a way that I need to reverse them.  I use the supposed "left" in my right ear, and "right" in my left ear.  They're just more comfortable that way for me.  Fortunately, this hasn't ever been an issue to me, but if I put them in "the right way," the body presses against a cartilage bit on my ear at all times, which is uncomfortable.Given all that, though...  the sound quality on these is better than any other in-ear set I've ever used, and on part with all but the very best "over ear" phones I've used.They take some getting used to, compared to anything else I've used.  But the sound quality is truly remarkable.

Polar Lights, now owned by "Round 2," created this as their first "very large scale" model.  And it's VERY large.  It's not as huge as the two other 1:350 kits which have been produced so far, but only because this ship was supposed to be smaller than the other two.This is a fine reproduction of the ship as seen on-screen, and is set up to make for pretty easy lighting.  It's supported from below by multiple points, and isn't really suited for a "single mount point" approach.  The detail of the model is really nice.The one complaint I have has to do with some very small "dish antenna" around the model... which are just miniscule and are easily lost during assembly/handling.  I've now got to figure out how to replace some of these, in a more robust (and more accurate) fashion.  I'm leaning towards using metal pins (dull tipped, mind you!) and small sequins, to replace the fragile little plastic bits.Polar Lights later produced a 1:350 "NCC-1701 Refit" ship, as seen in "The Motion Picture," "The Wrath of Khan," and so forth.  It was also supported from multiple points, but is a fine model.  (Later, when Round2 purchased Polar Lights, they did a minor rework on the tooling for this, and now it's supported from a single, heavy steel shaft in the lower hull.  The new kit also has a much larger decal set provided.)And now, Round2 is about to release a 1:350 "The original series" USS Enterprise model... which should be just about 33" in length... and is a "dream" for me, personally.If you feel the same way about the "NX-01 Enterprise," this kit is the best you'll ever get.The reason it's so pricey is because (1) the kit is large to begin with, and (2) the interest level wasn't that high, so only one production run was done.  Essentially, its' a "rare item."  And as such, the price is what you'd expect.  When released, it cost something close to $100, as I recall.  The new "original series" kit will run at a similar cost (though there will be some "deluxe add-ons" which will increase this dramatically if you purchase everything available!)

I have two different Archos devices... the Archos 5 Internet Media Tablet (250GB internal hard drive) and the Archos 5 Internet Tablet (NOT the same thing... bad naming conventions by Archos, mind you... this is the "next year's version"), (500GB internal hard drive).I also have two battery docks, one for each device.  I don't use them TOO often, but when traveling, they're a lifesaver.The hard-disk-based Archos devices have truly MASSIVE storage (which is why I wanted these, over other devices, and why I have no immediate plans to replace them, even though they're now several years old and in some ways starting to seem "obsolete").  But they're power-hogs.  The internal battery does pretty well, (though I recently replaced my internal battery... not a trivial task, as the device is not designed to be opened and the battery is not designed to be replaced!).  But when traveling, you need some extra power.  If you have access to a plug, on an aircraft, by all means use that.  But if you don't... and most passengers won't, I've found...  this can let you watch a lot of video, or listen to a day or more worth of music, without interruption.It's not all that complicated, really.  It's the same internal structure as the "mini-dock," except that it has a single cylindrical lithium-ion cell inside, with a small "battery management system" (BMS) card attached to prevent overcharging.The device physically attaches through the dedicated Archos-custom hardpoint on the underside of the these two generations of units.  There are a lot of data lines and power lines in those connectors, plus a single pair which every "add-on" device has a resistor across, which lets the main device identify what the add-on device is.  In this case, the "battery dock" and the "mini-dock" are literally identified as the same device, as far as the Archos is concerned.  (There is also an HDMI dock, which is of essentially the same form-factor as the mini-dock but has significantly different functionality).The device comes with a "wall-wart" transformer/rectifier power supply.  It has a port to plug in an "octopus" plug which outputs analog signals (video and sound) to your TV set.  And it has a pair of USB ports (one mini-usb, intended to go to a "host" device, like your computer, and another full-size plug, which is intended to allow the Archos, through this, to behave as "host" to another device.As mentioned in some other reviews, not every device will be recognized by the Archos.  But so far, I've had great success...  keyboards, mice, external storage (all but one devices, including some hard disk enclosures, worked just fine..  though the power available is not very great, so avoid any high-power-draw devices!)I travel with the battery dock and the HDMI dock in my little Archos bag.  They both use the same power "wall wart," by the way, as do all other Archos accessories except for the DVR Station, in these generations of products.  I keep the analog output cable, and a very nice super-thin HDMI cable (see here:  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006VFOHSY/ref=oh_details_o01_s00_i00), as well as a little Riitek bluetooth remote keyboard/mouse combo (see here:  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004I4RW8C/ref=ox_sc_act_title_2?ie=UTF8&smid=A2HBX5WXK67A8) and I basically have a very, very portable "home entertainment system" which I can use in any hotel room I find myself in.  I can charge... I can use the Archos to watch movies, listen to audio books, listen to music, listen to "web radio" or watch "web TV"...  browse the internet... play games... etc, etc, all from the hotel room TV, while sitting on the bed or the couch.The biggest mistake Archos made with this generation of product was to not ship the players with, at least, the "mini-dock" by default, along with the transformer "wall wart."  If you have an Archos device compatible with this (the A5IMT, the A7IMT, the A53G (same as the A5IMT but with integrated 3G phone connection), the A5IT, or the currently-still-available A48 (same as the A5IT but without the GPS receiver), you NEED at least one "docking station solution."  And if you plan to use it a lot, having a secondary power source, like this provides, is a major advantage.Recommended highly for anyone who owns any of the above-mentioned devices.

I do occasionally play some games, to be sure... but the feature list of this keyboard is not "game-specific."I wanted the following:1)  Backlighting - Check. Also, the backlighting on this keyboard can be shifted in color...  there are blue and red LEDs inside, and you can actually adjust the color from red to blue, through the entire range of "purples" in between.  And you can set up different color backlighting for each of three "macro modes."  This is NOT "just for gaming," and I never use it for that purpose, but I DO use it, extensively, during video editing and for CAD work, just for example.  The backlighting can be switch on and off by a button at the top edge of the keyboard.2)  This keyboard has a built-in C-Media audio chipset...  which in theory can drive 5.1 surround sound, but is only accessible for 2.0 (ie, "stereo") sound on this keyboard.  It's basically the same chip that many USB headphones have in them, but allows you to connect an analog headset (or speakers and/or separate microphone) to the keyboard.  No need for the computer to have its own sound system...  so this is idea for "work computers" where there is no built-in sound.  While I do not need this feature, as I have a very nice sound card putting out 7.1 surround...  it's a very nice feature for the board to have.3)  The board has audio controls, which can be used to control your Windows volume level (not just the internal sound chip, but whatever your Windows sound solution is...  I have no idea if this works for Mac, Linux, etc, however), play/pause/rewind/etc for playback control and so forth.4)  The board has a mechanical switch which will disable the "Windows Key."  I leave this always switched off... I don't need the "Windows key" shortcuts, and find that it gets in the way.  I used to have to use a registry "tweak" to disable that... but with this keyboard, I don't have to.  NICE.5)  There's a row of twelve fully programmable "special keys" along the left side.  These can be programmed in three different modes, for any given program... and the functions of these can be set up to alter with whatever program has "focus" in Windows at the time.  It's VERY useful.  I can see how this MIGHT be useful for games, but it's useful for so many things besides games, I almost find myself annoyed that Logitech decided to market this as a "game keyboard."6)  The keyboard is not one of those massive, oversized things that most "game keyboards" are.  It's basically the size of any conventional keyboard, with just a little extra extension on the left edge (for the twelve macro keys).  It fits perfectly into any desk space, unlike those "game keyboards" which are typically just HUGE.It lacks the "game features" some other keyboards have.  It has no built in joystick or built in display, or so forth.It's just a terrific programmable keyboard.  More useful, in my opinion, for "productive" work than it is for "gamers."The only minor quibble I have is that I wish that the "legs" would raise it up to a slightly steeper angle... it still feels "flat" to me, even when it's up on the hind legs.

It seems that a series of different products are all being combined into a "cluster" of reviews.  AMAZON, PLEASE STOP DOING THIS!I am posting a review for the Zip-Linq Retractable Cat6 250Mhz Gigabit network cable, RJN5, 5' length.  Some of the reviews here are clearly for other products, unrelated to this, which is "odd" at best.This is a fine cable.  As with all retractable cables, you need to treat it with a fair amount of care.  "Yanking" randomly on it will cause premature failure, and the mechanism is delicate enough to be crushed if handled improperly.  It's not "fragile," exactly...  it's really quite robust for what it is.  But I know some people rate things badly after abusing them and having the device fail under abuse.  So, treat it as what it is... a piece of technology... and it should be just fine.It's a pretty long cable, and it's really a true gigabit-capable cable.  It's not a "Cat 5" or "Cat 5e" cable, as some reviews here seem to mention.  As a result, it's actually a pretty large spool, just under an inch in total thickness, and about 2" in diameter or so (I haven't measured it, mind you, I'm just estimating here).  The point is...  it's similar in diameter to my previous "retractable network cable" (Cat 5) but is over twice as thick.  You can't really tell this from the images here, so be forewarned.It's ideal for use when traveling, especially if you have a GB network you can connect to, though obviously you can use it with lower-speed networks just as easily.  While I'd prefer a full Cat6 cable which was smaller and easier to carry, this is a fine choice until someone releases one.

Okay, this cable is ridiculously expensive compared to many other options out there, first off...  so don't buy it unless you actually need the advantages it provides.  But if you DO need these advantages... by all means, buy this cable.The advantages, you ask?  Well...  portability, mainly, for me.  I can wrap this up in a little pouch along with my Roku and toss it in my luggage, taking up almost no space.Signal quality is excellent.  Of course, I've never seen a "bad" HDMI cable, at least not yet...  but this one, despite the tiny cable diameter, seems to be immune to EMI (electromagnetic interference) at any level I would ever expect to see, and the connections are good and solid.  The gold plating is of decent thickness, meaning it's not already "wiping off" (as often happens)...  which is critical for a cable to be used for "portable" purposes.And finally, the last "advantage" is the ease of routing the cable.  You could get four of these, coming from your TV, bundled together, and you'd have a smaller, more flexible "cable cluster" than even a single conventional HDMI cable would provide.If you don't need the thinner cable, don't bother spending the extra money.  But if you have cable-routing/cable-management issues, or if you want a very small, high-quality cable to take with you...  this is the best cable on the market today, in my opinion.EDIT:  One thing I realized I ought to add to this review (based upon some issues a friend had while trying to use mine)...  this isn't like your typical HDMI cable in one other way.Virtually all HDMI cables are symmetrical...  meaning that it doesn't matter, at all, which end you plug into your "source" and which end you plug into your "endpoint."  This cable is NOT symmetrical in that fashion.  It must... MUST..  be plugged in, in one specific orientation.  One end of the cable is clearly marked as going to the source, with the other going to the endpoint.If you disregard this, you'll fail to get an output signal.  In other words, in order to get this device as small as it is, there's something "electronic" going on in the termination plugs on each end.  Most HDMI cables just have conductors going through, without any electronics whatsoever.  This is not the case with this cable.So...  if you plug it in the wrong way (ie, if you don't bother to read the markings on the ends!), you won't get a signal out of the cable at all.  I'd always just followed the instructions, but a friend (as I mentioned) tried it the other way, and no signal was carried through from the source device to the display.Definitely something worth knowing, and sharing.

These are prettier than I thought they'd be - they look much like the photo, but better looking "in person" - curiosity had me order them, and the look of them will have me wearing them should that special occasion come where I need something a little "fancier." They'd be pretty at Christmas, or a fall party. They remind me of fall - pretty fall leaves in October.Don't order them expecting quality jewlery if you like expensive "quality" jewlery, but instead like fun "costume" jewlery. On my ears, they look sweet. Not something I'd wear often, and I'd even consider giving them to someone who prefers gold and sparkle. These are just fun sweet earrings to wear - again, if you like "Good" jewlery, then they may not be for you. If like me you wear lots of costume jewlery and don't care a whit about cost or how it's made, etc, then give them a try.At first, I thought the shiny part around the gemstone were those fake looking diamonds and I hate that look, but, I was delighted to see that it is actually a nice silver design, and I prefer that to fake diamonds. Under that is more gold in a "filigree" design that's also quite pretty.The gemstones are nice - I don't know a lot about gemstones and quality, I only know what appeals to my eye, and these are clear and the color vivid.Normally, I would not wear something gold, nor would I wear something that looks "fancier" but these are so pretty, I may wear them when the occasion warrants it (or maybe just because I feel like wearing something sparkly and pretty!). I know I'm using the word "pretty" a lot, but that's the main word I think about when I look at these earrings.I can't find the current pricing on these, so I can't do a "cost to pleasure" ratio, but if they are reasonably priced, I'd say Amazon has a good thing going with their "Amazon Collection" of jewelry for those - I am curious what else they have to offer and hope they offer some more unique interesting jewlery -- something that isn't so sparkly but instead more to my tastes--something more simple, and silver instead of gold.

I was a bit skeptical about this product when I agreed to try out these running thong underwear in exchange for an honest review, but I was curious. I ordered the medium even though I wear a size 4 pants -- and the medium is the just-right size (I'm 5'2" and about 114 pounds).Right out of the package they look "sturdy" and well-made. I washed them before wearing and they washed very well (I washed them twice right out of the package to see how they'd wash) and no problems drying them in my dryer either.At first, when I put them on, they felt snug and I worried I'd be pulling at them during my run. I put on my running/yoga pants and set out - and actually just forgot I had them on! That's a good sign for me -- if I forget I'm wearing something, then it's a good fit and a good product for me. I did my run and there was no slipping at all. That "snug" fit served me well for my run. These thongs stayed put! No riding up or moving about -I was very pleased!I tried them out again but this time I just wore them about the house just to see how they felt, and again, I forgot I had them on. These are really nice thongs, y'all. I'd love to try out the boy short version!Price seems right, as well. These should last a long time - very well made.

Well-made, sturdy, and with a long enough cord to put the phone out of the way (or if you have a phone holder in your car). Everything you need in the package: usb cable and the receptor to plug into your cig lighter. I have an iPhone 5 and it fit perfectly and snuggly. Plugged it into the car's cig lighter (wish I knew another name for it since I don't smoke), and it began the charge. It charged my phone without any problem -- my other charger is hit and miss, so I really appreciated this Belkin one. I have another Belkin product and I've been satisfied with the Belkin line. So far, so good - if there are problems, I will of course, as always, come back and update.My only complaint is $25 is a bit steep. That would make me, certainly, hesitate to purchase this. I didn't want to give it 3 stars, though, since it is a nice product. But taking the price down a bit would be nice.A nice little charger for your car.

Length: Below ShouldersHair Type: very baby fine, highlightedupdate! -- this shampoo does much better as the mountain cove fall dry weather moves in. My hair was soft and shiny after using it in the autumn instead of more humid summer. I'd use this in the dry times of the year but not in the summer. 3.5!---------------------------Folks, this is a huge bottle of shampoo! It will last forever. Just a dollop will do, because this shampoo lathers to a full-out foaming lather. It has a creamy feel to it - and that makes the "moisture rich" claim to be true: this shampoo does go on creamy and rinses out to leave the hair strands soft and silky.However. It's too silky and creamy for my baby fine hair, and after drying it, soon I'm left with limp locks, which is too bad, since I do like the way it leaves my hair soft enough to comb through it easily.As I've been saying for other hair, face, and body wash products, I wish companies would give us some more interesting scents. I'm so bored with the slightly sweet powdery(ish) scents--please! Can we have some citrus, some woodsy, some spice!This shampoo could be better in the winter when my hair, and the mountain air, is drier. Or, for someone with thicker, drier hair. I'd probably not purchase this type but only because it's a bit too heavy for my baby fine hair. I'd look for another type, however, in the TRE-Semme line, and give it a go.

Update: there is some fading rather quickly--I don't know if it's something to do with my hair or shampoo or the product, or if that's just how coloring goes in general. But, it's not been but a couple of weeks and I've noticed my hair is already changing. I don't mind the color, and in fact, some of my high-lights are showing through a little so it makes it look nice, but, still worth noting. I won't change my 4 star (yet) to a 3 but I'm going to see how much more fading occurs.--------------------------Good thing I didn't read these reviews before I bought this (at a store in my little mountain town)! I spent about 20 minutes just staring at all the different types of hair coloring products --completely confused! It's been years since I've colored my own hair. I've been having it highlighted for 4-5 years and was ready for a change and to save some money. I had my boyfriend apply it for me - we followed the directions EXACTLY as they said to - no variations at all. It was easy and no drips or mess.Even with all the shaking, at the end there seemed to be more of an ammonia odor than at the beginning, so we applied almost all of the product and worked it in real good to be sure - I have below shoulder-length hair so needed most of it anyway. I don't have many greys, so that's not an issue. I just wanted to even out my hair color and become close to my natural - within a shade or two lighter.After leaving in the 30 minutes exactly (after working it all in from roots to ends just as the directions state - so actually it's on your hair a bit longer at the roots), I rinsed it out -- my hair felt a little "rough" but after I used the conditioner, it was silky feeling.After rinsing and conditioning, I had it cut, and then I blew it dry. I was very happy with the shine and bounce and body! I haven't had shine and bounce and body for years!Now here is the "warning" -- I have medium-dark brown hair naturally - my highlights were a very light brown or very dark blonde - I chose the 600 Light Brown because I was afraid of going too dark after having lighter hair for so long - and because since I have partial highlights, i had my dark hair throughout and "underneath" -- good thing I chose the lighter color because it would have been too dark at the ends! I would consider going one shader darker next time, just to more match my natural color, but this color is nice enough. It's hard to know how the color will be with subsequent colorings since I did color over highlights, but it looks very natural. No one would know I colored it if I didn't tell them.The color isn't exactly as I would like it to be, but that's more the color I chose in relation to my uneven highlights and re-growth there with dark hair and light hair and strippy stuff where my highlights were growing out unevenly and not a reflection of the product -- I am curious to see what my hair will look like next time: I will try this product again in one shade darker for a more "richer" look and I am expecting great results.I have a pic to show the color - this was right after I blew it dry - a simple blow out with a round brush - nothing fancy.

Honestly, there isn't a lot to say about cotton dishtowels!Are they "attractive?" - these aren't the prettiest dishtowels, but I didn't want pretty--I wanted a dishtowel I wouldn't mind if it becomes stained or a little frizzled from wear and tear. I wanted to scrub and wash and dry and generally give them a good ole kitchen workout. So, to that end, they are not beautiful but they are functional!Do they wash well?  - I've washed them and dried them and so far they are holding up fine. I can see where over time they'll look "worn out" but again, that won't bother me. They are a bit thinner than some dishtowels I have, so I do have a little concern they'll start tearing and looking a little worse for wear, but they also seem pretty sturdy, so there's that.Are they absorbent? - First thing I did after washing/drying them was to put one under the faucet to see how absorbent it is. It seemed to resist the water a little at first but I was able to wring it out and then use it to wipe the counters down without left-over water residue. Over time, with repeated washing, I expect the towels to become more water absorbent. So, it seems, after all, there is a bit to say about dishtowels.

I was a trainer for 6 years, and often used bands for alternatives to weight machines or free-weights--both for myself and for my clients. When I was asked to try these free in exchange for a review, I hesitated: often, in my past experience, exercise bands were not of good quality, and I've had them tear and snap in the middle of a work out. However, I was curious, so I agreed.First, the bands arrived in a nice mesh bag - where they can be stored when not in use: this is great, since I like things put away, and as well, to keep the bands clean, neat, organized, and to keep them from being damaged.I was also impressed with the sizes/resistance qualities of the bands; from very light up to very difficult. I have used these over the last two weeks to work out my entire body - including squats. Not only do they "replace" my free-weights and my tubing to give me a different work out, the different sizes/resistance quality makes for an easy, convenient, and fun addition to my resistance training. Also, I was able to do an anaerobic workout by working out my entire body without stopping--going from one muscle group to the other without stopping - very easy to pick up the "weight" I need from the bands and go to town on them!The "weight" resistance is noted on each band, but after a time, one could know by the color which one to grab (not only that, you can tell the resistance quality by the look of the bands: very very light is much thinner whereas very very heavy is much thicker)--or by the easy to read "weight" resistance quality marked on each band.These are also great for stretching while you are workout out, or stretching at the end of your workout.I'd recommend these as a great addition to any workout. The best workouts are the ones we will do. As well, the best training is when we mix up and change up our workouts--resistance bands are a good way to do this. I'm happy, and will purchase these as a gift for a family member who cannot use free-weights or go to the gym to use their equipment. These can be very gentle on the body - good for starting out a resistance training regime or if you have areas of concern (always see your doc before starting an exercise program!).

Comes in a mid-sized plastic bottle - blue "gel-like" consistency body wash. Pump-action dispenser.Neutrogena's claims that this "rainbath" shower/bath gel will leave your skin soft is accurate. I pumped a bit onto a washcloth first, and slathered it over my skin - it felt silky smooth on application. I also smoothed some on without a washcloth just to see how it felt and whatever is in that gel does create a soft and silky feel! I don't have that dry feeling to my skin after showering--the air can be really dry here in the mountains, so having an emollient product is important. After towel-drying off, my skin feels great. That's the best thing about this shower/bath gel.What I don't care for is the scent. There isn't much scent to it-it's quite subtle, which is fine, but as I've said before with other products, why can't companies create better scents for women? It almost smells "plastic." Men have all these wonderful woodsy, citrusy, spicy scented products, while companies think women want flowery or "grandmother from the sixties" scents--I'm a grandmother but I don't want to smell like my grandmother did. I'd love a shower gel, soaps, face washes, etc, in spicy, citrus, woodsy scents. This gel scent rather bores me. But, I am giving it four stars because it does what it claims to do and there's not a 3.5 star option: makes my skin feel soft and silky and clean. But, please, y'all - give us women some stronger more assertive scents for gawd's sake!

I want to like this hand lotion more than I do, but I can't be very excited about it enough to want to purchase it. What's good about it is it's a thick, emollient hand lotion that when applied softens my hands--but so do many other hand lotions for half the price and at a better scent. What makes it not exciting is that for the price at this size (see photo), it doesn't live up to that price standard. I think the marketers/creators of this hand lotion should give it an exotic spicy scent, or something citrus, or woodsy, so that, like another well-known brand sold in hair salons, there is that feeling of decadence or a "spa-like" experience. This lotion's scent is like grandma (and I'm a grandmother, but I don't want to smell like MY grandmother). There is also an almost "chemical" scent to the "grandma flowery" scent. As well, it takes a while for the lotion to soak into my skin, so if I'm at my computer working on a novel, I have to wait a while--it's a little greasy--yet, that wouldn't be so bad since when it does soak in, my hands do feel great.So, in general, give this lotion an "exotic" or citrus'y scent and/or give a little bit more for the money, and I'd be more inclined to purchase it. Honestly, just changing the scent would do a lot to pique my interest in this product.

I couldn't belive how nice this TeiKis set was when I opened the Amazon box. I received this set free in exchange for an honest review and I since I love giving positive reviews, I am always hopeful the product will be nice; because when the product doesn't deliver what it promises, I have to give a less than positive review whether receiving free or purchasing it -- this set goes above and beyond nice. My guy's really excited to use this on his grill, but I have my eye on this set, too!The set is not only beautiful, but there are more than enough tools for grilling, or for "indoor cooking." I used the knife (photos below) to cut into a lemon just to see how sharp it was - sliced right through. Though not meant to cut a side of beef, this knife will be great for multi-purpose all around cutting up of veggies, fruit, and even meat for inside or the grill. There's tongs, and a cleaning brush, and a "spatula," some steak knives, corn holders, a themometer --everything you need.It all comes in a nice carrying case to keep the tools not only from scratching up but to keep them organized - and if you want to keep the tools outside, you can slip this carrying "briefcase" where you keep your grill.It comes with a meat thermometer - something I had a need of and now I can try out this one. I took a pic of the entire set - it's just as the Amazon photo advertised: and this doesn't always happen with products, believe me. I can't think of anything at all missing from this collection. And, as well, I can't think of anything bad to say. Once we get to cookin' and grillin' with these tools, I'm excited to see how they hold up. If there is any problem at all, and I don't anticipate a thing going wrong - I will of course be back to report it in an "update," as I always try to do as I try out products over time.These tools would make a great gift set, and I already have it on my Christmas Ideas List for friends/family members who love to grill. Very nice set; quite nice looking; and a bargain for the price!----------I also received at the same time the BBQ injector, gloves, and meat "hands" or shredders - I tried to leave a review on that particular product page but couldn't - kept taking me here. So, while the BBQ tool set made me more excited and happy, this set (photo below) will be used just as happily. Especially the injector--stainless steel with two injecting "needles" that you just screw in. The "hands" can be used to pull out hot meat--using the thick thick heat-resistant gloves--or I think for shredding meat if you are so inclined. The gloves are super thick. The "hands/shredders" are a hard plastic-type material--I'd imagine they'd stay more "cool to the touch" - but again, the injector is the star in this three-piece set.Looking forward to having years of use of out of these products!

Update: - the more I use these Calily oils, the better I like them. This morning I put in my atomizer grapefruit and orange in my bedroom, and in the bathroom I put peppermint -- both rooms scented with happy energetic scent. I continue to be impressed with this product.------------------I received these oils in exhange for a review (I just paid shipping costs), and I couldn't be happier with them! In fact, I was quite pleasantly surprised at the quality of not only the product (the oils) but the packaging. These would make a great gift. The oils are attractively displayed in a nice-looking sturdy box. The scents are varied - some of my favorites are lavender, spearmint, lemon, bergamot, eucalyptus, and more. A few drops are all you need, for these oils are potent, but without being over-poweringly scented. There are no "artificial" odors and that makes the experience even more pleasant. I put a few drops into an atomizer I have and let the steam waft the scent into the room: LOVE! I want to try some other methods of delivery, as well. Be mindful to wash your hands if any oil spills onto your skin, as it is strong stuff and could cause irritation, but simply washing your hands with soap and water takes care of that if you are sensitive to the oils.I want to purchase a box of these for a friend (or two or three!) - a really attractive wide-varied array of aromatherapy oils. A scent for every mood and every room, and more! Love it!

I bought this as a gift for someone who is really into metal detecting so I can only write here what they've related to me --  and they are very happy with this pro-pointer. It arrived promptly, and there's been no problems with it. The receiver of this Pro-Pointer is completely satisfied. A very nice product that works great!

I'm torn on whether to give this 3 or 4 stars, simply because it just isn't for me. From the picture, I thought it more "substantial" but it is all lace - very very feminine and light and airy and that just isn't my style. From the photo, I thought it had more of a "white background backing" but it's completely see-through. If you have a nice liner - a really nice liner - it may work just fine as a shower curtain, but it looks to me more of a curtain for a very feminine "sweet" room. If I put aside the fact that I'm not a "lace person," I was willing to try it out for my guest bathroom, but upon receiving it, there is no way it'll work as a shower curtain. It's simply too filmy and lacy. That's my fault, but I did hope it would work.If you like a very feminine all lace see-through shower curtain and have a really nice liner to go with it, then this product may work fine for you. But, I won't be hanging this. I'm trying to figure out just what to do with it - but really, I'll just be giving it away as it does not fit my decor at all. I should have known better when I saw the word "lace" - so in that regard it is not the company's fault but my own. However, they do need a better photo to show the filmy quality of this "shower curtain." It's not so much "elegant" as it is "very sweet and feminine."Maybe good for a girl's bathroom? Or someone who loves very sweet and feminine decor?

You can't go wrong with Aveeno products. This is a thick rich emollient moisturizer that I use over my entire body (excluding my face, though, it probobly would be gentle enough to use as an ocassional facial moisturizer). My skin feels soft and amazing after using it - particularly if I apply right after a shower.I know these products are supposed to be "natural" and gentle, but I wouldn't mind a little scent. Lightly scented products make me feel happier, and give me a boost when I apply them. It seems there should be a way to add some scent without compromising the products claims of being "natural" and good for sensitive skins. A citrus scent would be nice - something light and fresh. That would be my only "complaint" and really it is not a complaint at all.This is a great product to use straight from the shower.

Hair type: below shoulder length, baby fine, hi-lightedI wasn't sure what to think about this product when I first poured some onto my palms---it is an "oily-feeling" treatment, and I feared it would make my baby fine hair look greasy. In fact, I knew I'd put too much onto my hands, and wiped some of it away, so a little will go a long way (this product will last me forever!). I then worked the infusion from about ear-length down to the ends into my just-washed hair--I did not put any at the roots. Then I blow-dried with a round brush. At first, I didn't think it did much, but when I walked out of the bathroom, my guy said, "Wow! Your hair looks beautiful! What did you do differently?" He ran his fingers through it, "it's soft and silky - sexy!"I marched back into the bathroom and looked at my hair - yup, smooth, shiny, and silky all right. And after sleeping on it all night - even tossing and turning -- I woke to smooth silky hair! Okay, so, I'm sold!If you have baby fine hair as I do, don't over-do it -- just use maybe a dime-sized at most, and don't apply it to the roots - also, work it in really well into wet/damp hair, and then blow dry with a round brush--though I want to try it without blow drying to see what it will do. I also noticed it made my hi-lights look better - I think it must be the "smoothing" effects that allowed my hi-lights to shine, but whatever the case, this product works for me.Amazing product!

These are the strangest little berries -- and so beautiful in color, I put them in a jar and keep them on my kitchen counter. They have an intense flavor that starts out a little sweet and ends up with this unique weird after taste that I both love and am not so sure about (laugh) -- my brother ate a handful and said "Mmm, these are good - wait!  I don't know - they aren't so good - but then they are. . . .?" That's the Goji berry experience for some. I happen to like the unique taste, and that almost kind of "burn" in the throat (not in a bad way, just a strange way). I'll eat a handful right out of the bag (or jar) but note that they are not moist but rather "hardened" and dry. However, they can be soaked in water and added to recipes or made into a tea. But I prefer them as a snack out of the bag or added to my trail mix.They do become very dry - perhaps I didn't store them properly. Mostly, I didn't cook with them enough and I didn't want the tea from them, so I tend to forget about them. Out of all of Viva Labs products I've tried, this may be my least favorite.I received these free in exchange for an honest review, but I'm already a big fan of Viva Labs products. Everything I've tried in their line of organic foods has been fresh, tasty, and unique.

First off, Viva Labs has some of the best products out there. I received these cacao nibs free in exchange for an honest review, but I'd have gladly purchased any of their products (and have done so). At first, the coconut oil was my favorite of their line, but add to that their coconut sugar (omg! caramel taste is so good!), and now these cacao nibs with their intense chocolate taste.Now, be aware that these are not sweetened - they pack a wallop of flavor but it's a bitter chocolate taste; however, I like this, for I can control the amount of sugar I put into a recipe. I have eaten these right out of the bag, and a little goes a long way if you want a hit of Big Dark "Cocoa" flavor. But in a smoothie - I put some of Viva Labs Cacao powder, their Maca Powder, a spoon of no sugar added peanut butter, a bit of their coconut sugar, and these nibs, swirled it together with some yogurt and OMG! Best smoothie ever! These are also excellent in cookies, muffins, cakes, and if you are adventurous, even savory recipes--I'm having fun trying them out in my cooking.Brownies made with these - ohhhhh - they were the best brownies I've ever baked.Not only tasty - but these nibs offer nutritional value without added sugar. I'm sold!

age: 50sskin type: senstive with slight rosaceaI love and adore this serum! First, I've been hoping for a facial moisturizer or serum that is citrus scented, so when I pumped a bit onto my fingertips and the citrus scent wafted up, I was a happy woman--there just aren't many facial products with scent and none I've found so far with that nice clean citrus scent; yay! I applied a bit (doesn't take much--about a pea size, so this serum will go a long way), and worked it in with my fingertips - it's a thick white serum (more like a moisturizer in feel), but goes on silky smooth--very nice.It's best to wait at least ten minutes or so (if you have sensitive skin like I do) after washing your face to apply Vit C serum, for you may experience a slight "irritation" (not bad, just a "heat" feeling) sensation to a just-washed face - but give your pores time to close and your face to calm from cleansing and you won't feel that heat; though, the heating up doesn't bother me at all and only lasts a minute.I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review (I'm always honest!) but I'll be purchasing this product once it's gone: I'm sold - I absolutely love this serum!

I have tried several brands of probiotics and while there may not seem to be a difference in them, there are: sometimes subtle and other times more apparent. What I love about 100naturals Upbiotics is that I have no stomach upset from them. Easy to swallow, once a day, and my stomach feels much more "in line." The best thing is how I can take my probiotics (I take it at night) and forget about it - but I know it's working, doing its job to keep my stomach calm and healthy.  Probiotics can be expensive, but at one a day, I can manage this.,I received this product free in exchange for an honest review.

I love giving positive reviews, and absolutely hated to give this negative review because, really, for the price the cover was just as it should be, which is why I gave it 3 stars instead of two. The cover is "leather" but don't expect nice leather feel for this price, and I couldn't get it to "stand up" very well at all. But the main reason for dissatisfaction despite the pricing is that the keyboard did not work. I tried everything and, nothing. I returned it and was promptly given a refund, which is nice and gave me confidence in the company (and Amazon).I'm going to do what I should have in the first place and order a nicer one and I will consider Mama Mouth and the Big Mouth Store if they have nicer quality cases to choose from, because you do get what you pay for. However, the keyboard should have worked even at this price, so thus the three stars and the return.

I do hate giving this nice case only 2 stars, but it does not fit my phone! And the weird this is, if I put it on backwards (across the "face" of the phone), it fits perfectly; however, if I try to fit it to the back of the phone, it will not snap on.The only reason I gave it two stars instead of 1 is because it is a really nice looking case - well-made, and I'm sure would have lasted me a long time -- but if it doesn't fit, it's useless to me. I tried it on my phone and my friend's phone (both iPhone 5's) with the same results.The glass cover sheets did great, however. So that was a plus.If it fits your phone, then you have a great product here; however, if like me the case does not snap on, then it is of no use -- unless I want to snap it on the front, and what would be the point of that?I'm disappointed because I really liked the feel of this case. Too bad!

This is a high-quality kitchen towel! Thick, soft but absorbent, attractive, and well-made. It's much thicker and larger than I thought it would be. I can't comment on the microbial aspects of this towel, but if I ever develop eyes with the capability to see microscopic organisms I'll comment on that part; however, I do trust the All Clad name so if they say it has microbial abilities, then I believe it.I'd like to order more in another color, though this tan-ish color is nice and neutral and would fit in any kitchen decor.Really, overall, I am quite impressed.

I received this press free in exchange for a review - which when I do this, I'm always hopeful the product will be great, since I love giving positive reviews and hate it when I have to give a company a "bad" review (whether free or paid for product). I was completely impressed with the presentation of this garlic press - it comes in a nice box so that it'd be perfect to give as a gift. The press itself is beautiful - stainless steel with a nice grip to it, quality made.I've used the roller thing and it works fine to peel the garlic - I've never tried this before, though I've had an old one stuck in a drawer for years. I'm of the "slam the knife on the garlic to peel and partially smash it to bits so I can chop it" camp. However, now I just roll the garlic in the tube and the peel slides easily off - I like this when I made my "garlic mashed potatoes," where I put whole garlic cloves in the water with the potatoes and boil then mash both together. But I love the ease of the press - my cutting board and my hands now won't have that garlicy odor to them - which is nice when I want to chop up something other than garlic on my "big cutting board" that I don't want to taste garlicy. This press is "heavy duty" - very well made, and looks good enough that I keep it in my utensil holder on my countertop.Just put the peeled garlic into the press -- I do one at a time -- and press firmly down. The garlic squeezes out nicely minced. Clean up is easy, though you do have to work at it a bit, but this is with any garlic press, and to me is worth it. I've tossed this one in the dishwasher after I've cleaned out the garlic and it does just fine.I'm not a cook so anything that makes my life easier in the kitchen, I'm sold on. An attractive product that works really well. I'd give this as a gift to the cooks in my life .

Skin type: sensitiveage: 50sComes in a fairly large squeeze tube application. A tan-putty color. The scent is "earthy" - it took me a few applications to be used to the scent, but it's not unpleasant at all, just different from my other Oz products.I have quite a few Oz Naturals products - as I am on their "review team" receiving products in exchange for a review (I only pay shipping, if applicable), but whether a "free" product or a "paid" product, I am always honest. I wouldn't continue to try out Oz Naturals if I didn't love them so much. And the company is "there" for its customers -- customer service is wonderful. As well, Oz Natural serums and facial cleansers are amazing.While I cannot make claims so early on what this particular Oz product will do for my face, I can say that their line of products, for which I've been using them for months now, have made a positive, radiant, change to my skin. I've had people comment, asking what I've done to my skin. It appears softer, "brighter," smoother. There is absolutely no irritation for my sensitive skin, either. I've used only Oz Natural products, exclusively, over the months so I could better see how my skin reacts. I'm a skeptic, so when something works, I give it its due.This moisturizer is in a large bottle - the price is amazing when you compare it to other skin care lines (even some of those in drugstores) - and will last quite a long time. Apply a small pea-size and work into the skin, adding a little more if necessary--a little does go a long way. I apply to my face, neck, and chest, and then smooth any left onto my hands -- so most of the time I use more than a pea size!Made in the USA, with quality ingredients, an amazing company - you should give these products a try. Start out with one of their serums and see what you think, but I'm sold.

Comes in a large plastic bottle with pump application. Thick white lotion with a pleasant soft scent.I am becoming a connoisseur of lotions, having tried so many, and having some end up languishing in the back of my bathroom cabinet, so while I'm often skeptical, I'm always hopeful that a lotion I try will impress me enough to use it "til the last drop." This lotion will end up turned upside down so the very last of it comes to the top so that I can get every last little bit of it.Curel moisture glides on my skin, and I really do feel as if my skin is sucking up this lotion. The scent isn't overpowering, light and clean--not flowery or heavily perfumed, so it's perfect for bedtime (or anytime). Though the lotion is relatively thick, it goes on silky smooth, and there is absolutely no greasy afterfeel at all. Afterwards, my skin feels amazing--soft and smooth and hydrated.The bottle should last a good while--not a lot is needed, just a few pumps will cover  your entire body. Great for after shaving, too--smooths and calms the skin.I was a big fan of another brand, and while I do still love that brand, I'm sold on this Curel now, and will be trying out more of their products.

I'm not big on putting "supplements" into the environment - where I'm going back home to is on a little mountain where everything is wooded and "natural" - there is not a yard and everything grows wild as it would and does in the woods. However, where I've lived for the past near-year is a house in the suburbs with a yard and a pool. So, this product is perfect for that -- except for the pool part, which there has to be care taken that no product runoff is in the pool - easy enough in the front and side yards, and fairly easy in the backyard if one is careful not to over-soak.The bottle is easy to attach to the yard-hose, and there is a "switch" for water only or feed. No mixing required - just attach, turn on water, set to feed (or just water), and depress "trigger." I have small hands and though I'm pretty strong, it was a little difficult to keep the "trigger" depressed for very long, but some gloves, or switching hands, would work fine.I can't comment as yet on grass growth, but from other reviews I've read, this product delivers. My brother, for whom the yard belongs to, is excited about this turf builder, and I'll be leaving the bottle with him when I move back to my mountain.Can't go wrong with Scotts - it's been around a long time!

I want to give this FIVE stars because of the construction of this product -- it's extremely well-made. However, I will write off the bat here that this armband is way too large for me and will be too large for anyone my size or perhaps even anyone who isn't much bigger than I am: I'm 5'2" and less than 115 pounds. I almost could fit this around my entire waist (if I really tried, and actually, I did!) And the length of it spanned too much of my upper arm rendering it useless for me, unfortunately--I couldn't tighten it enough and it spanned from my shoulder to my elbow in a way that it would be in the way of my activities.All that aside, if you have a large enough and long enough arm and need something that will not only hold your phone, but credit cards and license and some money and some keys and your earphones and a small dog (laughing- okay, not a small dog, but this thing is ROOMY), this will be a great product for you. There is a nice cushion to it that will feel great on your arm so you don't feel the items inside, but also will protect the items inside as you go about your workout or whatever.I received this free in exchange for a review and since I'm always honest, I hate giving such a well-made product 3 stars, and, since this product is so well made in a Five Star way, I know there will be those out there who will do fine with it, it is just too big for my body type, and for the type of workouts I do. It's hard to fault the company on some of that, but since they do call it a "sports armband" it has to be reasonable to assume one could use it in that way, and I, and perhaps others, will have problems in that area.Really, folks, this thing is huge. I just don't know. Unless you are a really Big person, and need to carry a lot of items with you when you are exercising or running or whatever, it's hard for me to imagine this thing on anyone's arm. I do heavy treadmill aerobics, and this would never work for me. Then again, man is this thing well made. I'm so on the fence about it. I think I shall give it to a man friend and let him tell me what he thinks!So, if you are looking for an armband to carry many items, feels comfortable (if you are a large enough person), and something very well-constructed, then this is for you. If, like me, you are smaller, it may not work for you.

Skin type: sensitveHair type: very baby fineage: 50sPackaged in an amber glass bottle with a dropper style application. Thick but not too thick "amber colored" oil.At first I didn't think I was going to like this Avocado Oil product. Many times "oil" products leave an oily film on my skin and it drives me crazy. But, the company was so kind and so enthusiastic about their product, and offered me a bottle to try in exchange for an honest review so that i was curious. Since I'm always honest, I was afraid I'd have to come on here and say I didn't care for their product. First off, when I received the product, it was packaged in a plain white box without any "frills"  - okay, not so bad; after all, why spend money on fancy packaging? The bottle itself looks fine, but when I opened it and droppered some onto the palm of my hand, I was not happy with the scent--it's not an unpleasant or "bad" scent, just not one that I particularly like. As well, of course since it is an oil, it feels oily! But, I made a promise to try it and try it I would. I decided to apply this avocado oil over my entire body - hair included. A little goes a long way, y'all! I smoothed the oil over my face, lips, hair, my feet--paying extra attention to my heels, and over the rest of my body.My worries about it being too oily feeling were short-lived--this stuff absorbed into my skin very nicely! I was surprised! And my skin felt amazingly soft. It also helped with the heels of my feet -- I go barefoot a lot and have to work to keep my feet looking smooth and nice. This avocado oil will work amazing for my feet/heels. There was no irritation for my sensitive facial skin, either. I'd use this on my face maybe once or twice a week, but I more would want to use it on my body.Now, as for my hair--I would use this to deep condition my hair once a month or so, but it did make my hair look very oily. I thought it may absorb into my hair as it did my skin, but I woke to very oily hair, and I didn't use much. So, knowing that, I'd only use it as an occasional hair conditioning treatment.The scent didn't last too long, and it wasn't strong enough to put me off too much -- but I did apply a lotion to my arms and shoulders and chest just to mask the scent of the avocado product. That would be my one "negative" and really it's not much of a negative.I'll continue to use the product and see how it does for my skin when I move back to the dry-air climate of the mountains. That should make my skin even happier.

I came back to give this 5 stars because it's really been a great cable "manager" - I travel a lot and this has helped me be just a little more organized.I read the reviews on this cable keeper and hesitated. I wasn't sure I wanted to try it. With any product I agree to try or that I purchase, I of course want to be sure I'm going to enjoy it, use it, really like it--because I love giving positive reviews when warranted. I'm always honest, but when I choose products I know I need and/or will enjoy, giving a positive review feels great.I was about to click out of the product description, when I looked down and saw the cords of my iPhone and iPad and keyboard and bluetooth earphones and and and - dang! So I decided to give this cable keeper manager a try.Now, there is only one cable keeper and for the price, I may hesitate buying if I'd just purchased this one for $12. Since I received it through Vine, I can purchase another one and the price won't seem out of line (two for $12.00). But, paying $12 for each one--I truly am on the fence about that. For, the good thing about this product is that: It was very easy to zip up my phone cords -- I have two in it now and I can plug in two connectors/adapters at once in the same outlet area, which will be awesome when I want to charge my phone and tablet at once without wires snaking everywhere. -I just thread the top part of my cords into the "hole" provided, and then just zipped it up and the cords easily positioned inside; there's room enough for two cords, which is what I did and I like. You can fold up a longer cord to make it neater but that defeats the purpose of the longer cord I have when I need a longer cord so I don't see the point in that unless it's for storage purposes. I like the idea of using these for storing the many cords I have and the cords my guy has when we are together. The blue is a pretty color; I can bend the cable keeper so that it stays put--for example, if I want to curl it up or fold it a few times, it stays that way; it seems to be quality made; it really did neaten up my cords; it looks more "organized" than when I have white cables flopping about every-which-a-way.All in all, I'm happy with this product. Happier than I thought I'd be, because of my initial skepticism. If they lowered the price just a little, I would buy a few more for friends/family. I am considering purchasing another one for myself at the price for which it is now offered. I do understand that a company must make profits--they can't make quality products and lose money, and so for that reason, why not spend a little extra on an item that works well? As a novelist, I know what it's like to have your "product" sold very cheaply but I also understand that this is how Amazon works and in the long run, your "product" gains a very wide audience through Amazon.Some considerations: I would like it made in varying lengths. I think putting it on sale for a while would benefit the manufacturer.  However, overall, I'm happier with the product than I thought I'd be, and I'm using it, so there you go!

Skin type: very sensitive and prone to occasional breakoutsage: 50sComes in a nice-sized plastic bottle with pump application. Do not use very much of this product - you don't need to. A dime sized or so should give you enough cleanser on your dampened face. Using too much cleanser is only wasting it! And that goes for any cleanser or beauty product.I have weird skin. A product may seem to work and then wreak havoc on my face. It's part of the reason I joined the Vine program - my cabinets were full of product I'd spent money on that I'd have to give away or throw away. So when I find something that works, I hang on to it! I first "judge" a product by scent, how much is offered for the money, how it feels when I apply it to my skin, and then how my skin feels afterward--lately, as well, I am more and more looking at how it is made and what goes into the product. As for long term use, only time can tell for some beauty products, but for cleansers, since they do not stay on the face long, I can tell how much I will like them after only a few days or so of use. What I look for in a cleanser is one that does not have any "grit" or other kinds of "scrubbing" or "exfoliating" actions to them since they make tiny microscopic tears in the skin - particularly as you age. I exfoliate with my Clarisonic Mia or a soft cloth a couple of times a week. This routine works well for my aging skin. Neutrogena Cleanser is gentle enough to use the exfoliation that Mia provides without irritating my face.This Nuetrogena isn't organic or made from "all natural" ingredients as some of the products I do now use, but I wanted to try it anyway since I trust the Nuetrogena name, and as I earlier wrote, facial cleansers do not stay on the face long enough for me to worry as much. I pump out about a dime sized amount of the cleanser and slightly rub it between my fingers and then apply to my dampened face. Sometimes I'll use my Clarisonic Mia and others I'll use only my fingertips to cleanse my face in cirucular motions.The cleanser is soft and silky on my skin, and it has a very light but pleasant scent. I don't like heavy perfumy scents, and especially in my cleansers I prefer a lighter fresh scent.After cleansing, my face feels soft and silky. The price at under $8 here on Amazon is reasonable for the amount received. I'd consider purchasing this when the bottle is empty - but this bottle should last me quite some time.

These plastic measuring cups are in the Kitchen-Aid branded colors - ceramic white with black handles. They are handsome looking. They nest together well and aren't terribly deep, which I like for my particular shallow kitchen drawer. They have a flat bottom, so they sit on a counter evenly. I have two things I dislike. The first is the ring that holds the cups together: It is connected/clasped by a different type of transparent flexible plastic, one I expect to get lost or ruined in a dishwasher. Secondly, the measurements are printed on the handle in silver. Having had other printed cups wear off over time, I don't expect this paint to be durable. I would much prefer a raised molded number. But all in all, these are still nice cups for the price.

Upwords is a play on grid-based word games like Scrabble. You build words that are not scored based on the rarity of letters, but on the number of tiles used. Letters played on the lower levels receive two points per tile, each letter played above that receives one - but you get to count every tile below that when making a new word by stacking. So there is a fair amount of strategy and inventiveness.The instructions are a tad vague as to scoring. It wasn't immediately clear that the lowest levels counted for two points, and the upper levels *and* lower levels when made into a new word, counted for one apiece. But once you figure it out, it's relatively easy to keep score.The board is plastic, with some felt feet on the corners. The pieces are white plastic. The trays for holding letters are rather flimsy. All told, though, it works just fine and nothing seems prone to breakage. I think it would have been nice to include a felt bag for the letters, in the style of Scrabble.This is a fun, quick alternative to Scrabble. A game can easily be played in less than 30 minutes.

What do I want from a toaster oven? Capacity, easy cleanup, and control. Well, the Hamilton Beach 31401 offers 2 out of 3 unproblematically, but the third is a bit more complicated (literally and figuratively).First, the positives. When the box claims that it can fit four slices of bread, it means it. I was using some particularly wide Pepperidge Farm bread, and I could still easily get 4 slices in. I used this to keep a batch of fried fish warm, too, and it fit the entire pound of fried cod with room to spare. All in all, I doubt anyone would be displeased. The rack slides out, albeit not automatically like some competing products. So you so need to shield your hand to do so. The toasting action is even across the oven (easy to test with 4 slices), and the stated "oven" temperatures seem accurate, too. Cleanup is not difficult, with an easy slide-out panel.My issue with the thing is the control scheme. As you can see in the picture, there are three knobs. The top is temperature, the middle is mode, and bottom is timer (I guess). The bottom knob has two little icons - a light piece of toast and a dark piece. The space between these icons is... well, there IS no space between them. It's like playing a game of Operation! trying to find just he right "click" for the dial. It is easy to over or undershoot. Then, in addition, the temperature dial at top has to be set correctly to toast. Why would these interact at all? Toasting should have a hard-wired "correct" temp, and should disable the temperature knob altogether. We had several toasting failures because of this. My only presumption can be that the innards of this thing are entirely mechanical, and so it is a "dumb" toaster oven, so to speak. If you turn a knob, it does its thing, regardless of the mode you're in.Because it does what it sets out to do quite ably (once you figure out the controls), I give it 4 stars. But the hair trigger and the wonky dial scheme won't let me go any higher.

I am not reviewing the game. It's the same Chutes and Ladders it's always been. Rather insipid for anyone over the age of 6, I'd say. No strategy, just counting.What I will review is the board, graphics, and pieces. This is a 70's retro design. I haven't played the 70's version (or at least haven't in 30 years or more), so I can't comment on the accuracy. I did like the pictures - they show little morality tales. Hard-working children who do nice things are at the bottom of each ladder, and are rewarded at the top for their labors. Lazy or mean kids are at the top of each chute, and get heir comeuppance at the bottom. My son (who is 4) enjoyed looking at each pairing and discussing how and why they succeeded or failed.That said, the board is rather busy, and it isn't entirely clear to a younger person which square corresponds to which chute or ladder.The game pieces are sturdy, though the plastic brackets are difficult for little fingers to insert the cardboard children into. The spinner works well once you punch it through. Spinning action is easy and can go for more than a few seconds.All in all, it's the same boring game it's always been. This retro edition offers some nice additional fun, but is rather busy compared to a more clean modern design.

It is difficult to evaluate the claims of this product, because it claims to strengthen your core and improve posture. To the extent that any sort of "ball seat" does this, I believe this product would do so as well.As such, I will evaluate it on comfort and ease of use. The cushion is not terribly heavy, but it does seem sturdy, It comes pre-inflated, and seems rather squishy at first blush. But this is actually a good level of inflation, because it lets you sink in a tad while still supporting your rear-end. The color is unobtrusive in an office setting, and the diameter should fit most chairs. The nubbed texture gives you a bit of traction on the cushion, and isn't unpleasant.One thing I don't particularly like is that it requires a pin to inflate. The pin is included, but it is just taped onto the box, so it is easy to overlook, and as a small part is easy to lose. There is no pump included, either. I assume this is because the manufacturer believes that anyone buying this would also have a yoga ball. But is that really the case?All in all, this is a good cushion for those who want to try core strengthening through sitting. My own suspicion is that this has greater benefits in encouraging upright posture than any actual muscle toning.

Here is what this product is not:-legal or A4 sized-capable of OCR to translate your handwritten notes into searchable text-compatible with any pen or pencil-able to recognize different line widths based on pressure (important for drawing)-inexpensiveHere is what it can do:-record and sync note taking and drawings to the cloud-use any paper you provide (so long as it doesn't go beyond the boundaries of the provided pad-maintain battery life for quite a whileThe Android application was easy to install and use. I don't anticipate anyone having difficulties with it. But all in all, I think the utility of this device is somewhat limited based on the first category of caveats above.

So here are my criteria for evaluating a dress shirt:-Are the sleeves baggy? Here, the answer is no. They are a pleasing width that doesn't make me feel like I'm wearing the Hammer Pants of shirts.-Is it a wrinkle nightmare? Again, no. Although it is not wrinkle resistant by any means, it was very easy to steam out the wrinkles, and even just being in a bathroom while I showered did the trick for most of them.-Are the buttons difficult to pass through the holes? Here, the answer is kind of. I would have liked a few more microns of clearance, personally.-Is it itchy? I'm going to say no. It's not smooth like silk, but it has a pleasing feel overall.-Does it have pockets? No! No pockets! I was taken a bit aback by this, as I looked for a place to stow my sunglasses. So I guess you should be aware of this fact before buying. It's not a defect, but a matter of taste.-Can I lift my arms without untucking the whole darned thing? This is an in-between answer. Raising my arms to write on a markerboard (I'm a teacher) threatened some untucking.All in all, this is a competent shirt with a nice pattern. I wish it had a pocket and that the arms had a little more play.

My son, who is 4, certainly enjoyed this set. He and his cousin played with it for an hour or more. That said, I think it could stand some improvement. The music element is not terribly loud, and the raised nature of it means that many a Thomas train car will derail at the end of it. For the money, I don't think this set included enough tracks or other destination pieces (water mill notwithstanding). On the plus side, this is the same gauge as Ikea's wooden train tracks, so it it easy to mix and match pieces.

This is a review of the Epson PowerLite Home Cinema 1040. It is a 1080p LCD projector lit by a UHP lamp. As its name indicates, it is intended to be a home theater projector, not a business presentation projector. Nonetheless, Epson boasts that this can produce 3,000 Lumens, which is enough to compete with some serious room lighting.I am a recent entrant into the projector game, having purchased an LG PF1500 LED-based DLP projector (also 1080p). That unit retails for about $100 more than this one, but they are both entry-level home theater projectors. As such, I think a comparison between them is fruitful.***Image Quality***The PowerLite certainly provides a crisp image. It was extremely easy to dial in the focus using the recessed focus dial, and the focus uniformity was even across the screen. It certainly felt as though all of the information from a Blu-Ray disc was being displayed on the screen (in this case a Vapex 1.1 gain 106" white screen).The real weakness of this projector is its baseline black level. The darkest areas on the screen never dip below a dull gray, even with the Auto Iris engaged. I would compare these blacks to a budget LCD television like an Insignia or a Seiki. The LG PF1500, which is an entry-level DLP, handily beats it (please see the appended images for comparison, taken at the same ISO and shutter speed on the same screen image. The first is the PF1500, the second is the PowerLite 1040).As such, this would not be my first choice for a home theater projector. It simply doesn't get dark enough to let me immerse myself in the image and "forget" I'm looking at a projection on a screen. Movies with black bars (such as "Ben-Hur," which I used in the screen shots) make this especially evident. 16:9 material (such as Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey) less so.With that said, please also see the third image I took of the 1040 with full room lighting. This IS definitely a projector to consider if you want to use it as a daytime TV (keeping in mind that you will need an external tuner or cable box with HDMI output) with minimal light control in your room (say just some blinds), or a projector to use in the office.***Build Quality***There are a host of nice hardware features. A lens cover is built in. Focus and zoom dials are recessed and are nice and firm, never falling out of position. The unit itself is not gargantuan by any means, weighing in at about 8 pounds and measuring about 10"x13"x4". The power cord is a standard 3-prong PC plug, with no external power brick. This simplifies installation considerably. Standard mounting holes are on the bottom. The included remote is functional and reasonably organized, but not backlit. This projector does not feature a TV tuner or 3D, and has no onboard streaming functions, though it does connect to a home network for image sharing. The fan noise in Eco mode is admirably quiet. It is almost inaudible when the projector is mounted, and is even tolerable when sitting right next to it. Regular mode is another story - quite noisy.***Calibration***I performed a DIY calibration with Disney WOW. Contrast adjustment was ineffective using the Disney WOW disc - no value for contrast would show white bars on the right side of the pattern. This tells me that the projector is clipping information out of the image at higher contrast values. Color and Brightness however could easily be adjusted to proper values. Sharpness was also easy to adjust, allowing for a pleasingly crisp image with no edge enhancement halos. Here are my resulting settings:Color Mode CinemaBrightness 48Contrast 50Color Saturation 50Tint 41Sharpness 5Color Temp 3Noise Reduction 0Detail Enhancement 10Auto Iris High speedAutomatic Iris is noisy and slow, even on the "fast setting."Aspect NativeOverscan OffHDMI Range Auto***Conclusion***This would not be my first recommendation for a darkened home theater room. As a daytime TV or an office projector, this would certainly rate highly because of its ability to compete with room lighting. But in this price range, better performers can be had, such as the LG PF1500 or the BenQ HT1075.

On the pro side, and it's a very big pro, I like the flat wall plug. It really aids in installations behind couches and cabinets, which most home theater/entertainment center applications will need. I was able to nestle this power strip behind a cabinet a mere 2 inches from the wall. I also like the sliding covers for unused outlets.On the minus side, this strip doesn't feature any sort of differentiation between standard 2-prong plugs for smaller gear and "wall wart" power adapters, which a lot of the random stuff you might need near your TV (Chromecast or Fire Stick, Internet router) might need. As such, you are almost certain to have one or more unused plugs that are blocked by a wall wart's overhang.All in all, I like something like the Smart Strip better, since it has size differentiation and shuts off individual outlets to reduce "vampire power."  Smart Strip 4940 LCG3 LCG3M Energy Saving Surge Protector with Autoswitching Technology, 10-OutletBut to be fair, this is significantly cheaper, and I do love a flat wall plug. So I say 4 stars, with a star deducted for wall wart handling.

Our baby enjoys this, and has found some pleasure in all three of the "rings." The top piece has a rubber cat he likes to chew, and the other rings offer interesting textures and are easily graspable.My only beef with this toy is the top - since it doesn't slide all the way down onto the middle post, it constantly invites the parent to pick this up and have it all fall apart while tidying up. I've done it a dozen times already. Those of us trained on other stacking toys (with one center post that goes through all the pieces) will find this a hard habit to break, I think.

So, this does what it says: Offers a portable 3,000 mAh power source that can charge devices that charge via USB. As the instructions indicate, it is better suited to phones than tablets, but it will charge them, albeit slowly. 3,000 mAh is more than most typical smartphones outside of the very biggest, so think of it as at least one more full charge, sometimes two, over your device's built in battery.There are one or two nagging flaws with this unit. First of all, though it has an LED indicator, it doesn't tell you much. It lights when the unit is charging another device, and it blinks when you're below 25% remaining on the unit. But from any point between 100% and 25%, your guess is as good as anyone's. It would have been nice if there had been a 4 step indicator, that is, 4 LED lights that show at least in quarters how full the unit is. I have a camera attachment for my smartphone that does this, and you can press a button at any time to see how much is remaining.The other irritation is the placement of the two USB ports. The ports are to charge the unit (from a wall or computer) and to discharge the unit (into your device). But they are so close together that it is difficult to have both be plugged in simultaneously. Now, this is probably a rare use case, but it could come up occasionally if you don't want to stow one of your cables while the other is in use.Anyway, it's a simple and useful charger at a good price. It could just have had a slightly more thoughtful design and a more useful indicator.

Are these knives more interesting-looking than the average knife? Sure. But I think the design ends up harming the convenience of these knives in terms of storage - they are too wide to fit into my wooden knife block in any slot but the one for the cleaver.  The knives are very heavy, which may lead to some fatigue during extended use. As far as cutting food, they work fabulously. The weight does lend itself to easy cuts, since you can let the knife do most of the work. The knives cut ripe tomatoes with absolutely no tearing or mashing of the fruit, so I was quite impressed.These knives come packaged in a faintly ridiculous glass and metal case with a foam insert. The instructions indicate that one can wash these in a dishwasher, but that it would be better to hand wash to preserve sharpness.Overall, I can recommend them as knives, but if you have limited storage space, they might not be for you.

We are comparing this scale to our previous Health-O-Meter electric scale. One thing the Taylor scale has over our previous electric scale is that it requires no waiting to turn on. You just step on, and it begins weighing you. It seems more accurate than our previous Health-O-Meter scale, as well, which seemed to only get to .2 pound increments and seemed to always add weight to the measurement. The Taylor gets to .1 pound increments and consistently reports the same weight upon repeat measurements. It also seems to weigh your clothes very accurately, so strip down!The profile setup system works well, with just a few button presses necessary to indicate which (of four) profiles you are, your height, sex, age, and activity level. Then, if you weigh yourself on a profile (selected before weighing with some arrow keys on the left of the unit), it will tell you your BMI and the recommended number of calories to maintain that weight. While of course these numbers won't be perfectly accurate, they are a nice start to being aware of your choices.The scale is very low profile and is completely flat. It feels very stable, but I will say I liked the curved aspect of our previous scale in terms of keeping a person on it. Being glass, you might find it nearly invisible on your floor, so be careful and avoid any Kramer moments!For the price, this really can't be beat. I have no hesitation in recommending it.

I am comparing this to the TP-Link TLPA-211 powerline kit, released a few years ago. The short version: this Netgear kit performs equally well, with far easier installation, for a competitive price.The long version: when Netgear says "plug and play," they MEAN it. The TP-Link required multiple attempts with a laptop linked up to get it to sync with the second unit, and if you unplugged one of them, it was all over and you had to go through the onerous process again.
