The Netgear was this simple - I plugged in the first unit and hooked up the LAN cable from the router, then went to the next room and plugged in the second unit, hooking up the LAN cable to my devices (I connected a TV, PS3, and AV Receiver). That's it. No button presses. No syncing. Certainly no fiddling with software. Plug and play.Performance wise, I get my full 30 mbps down and 10 mbps up from my internet provider. So I can be certain the powerline units are no bottleneck. I haven't tried streaming video from one PC to another, as this is not something useful in my setup. It also has a hardware "firewall" of sorts, making the network connection impregnable, though I haven't tried it yet.But really, at this price, you can't go wrong. It competes well with TP-Link's current products and is completely foolproof to install.

I am reviewing this unit in comparison to a Waterpik WP 900 combination electric brush and water irrigation kit. I have to say, in comparison to that kit's brush, I like this one better. It has a few things going for it - the Oral B heads offer great variety, and the included head has lots of swishing action across the whole brush head. The brush itself has two very nice features in its 30 second timer (it buzzes and lights green every thirty seconds, helping you time different mouth areas) and its pressure alert (a red LED blinks when you apply undue pressure in your mouth). These two features make you really aware of your brushing behavior, something the Waterpik does not. I wish the brush had dimmer LEDs that didn't blink so aggressively. At night, this brush had me turning it every which way to try to obscure the light at bedtime.As far as the bluetooth functions go, I was unable to test them, as I use Windows Phone. I realize this will not affect 90% of smartphone users, but it does me. The app purports to track brush usage over time to offer improvement advice.In comparing this to the Waterpik WP 900 (available on Amazon), the Oral B is a superior brush but includes no flossing element. The Waterpik also costs significantly less. As such, It's not a slam dunk recommendation. If you prefer lots of data and lots of brush head choices, this might be the one to go with. But if you want a decent brush sans bluetooth, and an excellent water flosser, the WP-900 might be the way to go.

My wife reports that there are several uncomfortable aspects to this underwear. The cut of the underwear hits her in weird places, and not because it's shaping underwear, but because they just come up too high. Theoretically this would be a good thing, but it hits in a weird place and ends up rolling down (my wife is post-pregnancy for what it's worth). The rear of the panty also does nothing to shape, unlike Maidenform's brand of shaping underwear. It is just flat fabric. There is a tag on the side seam that is very uncomfortable. She also finds the aesthetics unappealing. There is a sort of triangle on the front which is shiny, not "nude" as advertised. So all in all, although she doesn't declare them "unwearable," she wouldn't recommend them to friends.

These panties are made of a nice stretchy material that is smooth and comfortable. My wife wore them all day with no discomfort. She reports however that while the panties made the rear-end area look good, they don't really go high enough (despite being "hi-cut") to offer any control in the areas she is concerned with post-pregnancy. So, your mileage may vary, and the needs they do meet might not justify the price for you. But they're comfortable underwear.

[Just FYI, my wife was wearing and evaluating this item, not that there's anything wrong with the other possibility]The Firm Control Camisole would be terrific. The bust and belly areas fit very nicely, offering a good deal of abdominal smoothing post-pregnancy (but keep in mind that this is not a corset or binder). The problem, as you might be able to infer from the picture, is the bottom. Despite not having tons to "control" down there, the long bottom part of the camisole rides up incessantly, creating an unsightly bulge underneath the parts that are actually being controlled. This did not abate regardless of how someone sits or keeps smoothing it down. As such, it's really close to being great but is essentially unwearable.

This product was relatively easy to install on one of my two toilets. The one it didn't work in was too small to accommodate the device without it interfering with the various elements of the toilet mechanism. But in our more spacious toilet, it worked fine, once it was placed on the side of the toilet away from the plunger lever. Unfortunately, this led to the purple clip of the tablet holder showing from the front of the toilet. I wish it has been white or beige, which are far more common toilet colors than purple.Once installed, it's a matter of sliding the two cleaning tablets into the purple holder, which allows the water that fills the bowl to pass over them and dissolve them over time. The tablets are rather crumbly and the packet they come in is difficult to open without a scissors. Flushing happens normally, no detectable difference. So far, after a few days, the bowl seems clean with no obvious buildup, I will update as the month goes on.The instructions are a bit tiny, and don't offer much detail for those who might not be familiar with the inside of their toilet. Luckily, was passingly familiar with how everything worked. There is an installation video on youtube if you need help.All in all, I think the tablet holder device should have been smaller, a different color, and easier to slide the tablets into. But that said, this works as advertised as long as your toilet is big enough.

These underwear are 100% polyester, but they don't feel bad in any way. In fact, they feel really smooth, almost silky. I was comfortable from the moment I put them on to the moment I took them off. The tagless aspect is nice, as there are no tags to feel or to come loose over time. I am right between the Small and Medium waist size recommended for these, and the medium fit me just fine. They didn't hang loose off of my legs, but they were by no means tight. I have no way to judge the supposed moisture/heat super powers of these underwear, since I am not a marathoner and it is also rather cold outside presently. I think the price is rather high for what you get, but I suppose that's subjective. It's enough for me personally to take this to 4 stars instead of 5.

This bar is chocolatey. Really chocolatey. It has a chewy texture with a pretty good amount of peanuts in it. Cut the overwhelming flavor is chocolate, and pretty decent-tasting chocolate at that. Chocolate is the first ingredient, though it should be said it's a chocolate based on "fractionated palm kernel oil" and cocoa powder, as opposed to some fancier chocolates. The vegetables present are dehydrated carrots and sweet potato juice (?). The caloric content is pretty high at 240 kcal per bar. But protein is high too at 10g.All told, it's pretty much like eating a Snickers bar as far as nutrition goes, with the exception of doubled sugar content in the Snickers. It is definitely filling and tastes good.

At first glance, this SoyJoy bar is weird. It's a little cube-shaped sort of twig, unlike a traditional bar shape. As such, you will probably think it can't be terribly satisfying. But actually, it does a pretty good job of filling you up for a while. I have found that one bar can tide me over for maybe two hours, if I am hungry, in advance of a meal.Taste-wise, the bars are sweet. Included among the ingredients are sugar, raisins, blueberries, pineapple, and coconut. The bars rate 140 calories, which is rather high given their weight (1.05 oz.), but the ingredients are all pretty wholesome, so I don't worry too much about it (interestingly, eggs, milk and butter are among the ingredients as well, despite a notable lack of artificial preservatives).I find myself wishing for a nut to be included, like walnuts perhaps. The included fruits do have a bit of interesting texture after you finish eating it (I can feel some coconut and raisin in my teeth after just having finished one), but I want a bit more of a crunchy note.I think this would be a very nice addition to a school lunch, or a workout bag. It provides somewhat lasting satiety, and isn't loaded with all sorts of bad stuff. It should be noted that these bars are rather expensive, as well, at over a dollar per. But I suppose that's pretty par for the course in this market segment.

This unit does what it advertises - sends an audio signal to Bluetooth headphones without a noticeable lag. As far as ease of use and functions go, this has it all in order. The top button includes a blue-red LED light that lets you know whether it is trying to pair. Included is a magnetic "hook" with some 2 sided tape on one side, which gives the user an option for mounting. The unit charges via an included USB cable.My problem is this: since this unit is basically replacing the function of a Bluetooth transmitter, its utility is primarily for devices that lack such a transmitter. But there is only one kind of input into the device for audio - a 3.5mm stereo mini jack. This takes all sorts of devices that would be really nice to stream to Bluetooth headphones out of the running. I have an A/V receiver and a Blu-Ray player that I'd LOVE to send wireless audio from, but can't, because these devices either lack a 3.5mm mini jack entirely, or only have one as an input. Essentially, if your device doesn't have a stereo mini jack output, you're kind of out of luck (the manufacturer did include an RCA wire to mini jack adapter cable, but this is a legacy cable without a whole lot of application, since again, you would need a device with RCA wire output, not input).Without HDMI or Optical Digital input, the utility is this device is sorely limited for me. As such, 3 stars is where I stand - does what it says, but handicapped by default.

On the plus side, this unit is big, which allows you to place 6 bottles and other pump accessories onto one of two interior shelves. The unit is easy to put together. The top shelf is semi-adjustable, but to make it higher than the preset notch, you'd need to rest it atop the bottom items.On the minus side, the cord is short (~3 feet), which makes placement difficult. You have to disassemble the interior of the unit to pour water in, which is kind of a pain. There is nowhere on the unit to store the water fill cup when not in use. The user is supposed to supposed to wash items with soap and water first, so "sanitizing" doesn't replace washing, though this is pretty standard. It does raise the question of just what is being sterilized after washing with soap and water.  The biggest flaw however is that there is nowhere to hook the lid after opening, so a person needs to put the dripping wet, dome-shaped lid down on counter to unload the unit. It is awkward and inconvenient. Oddly, a cycle take 6 minutes if full, but a lighter load takes longer.As far as cleaning goes, the measuring cup to pour water has a mesh strainer that may catch some mineral deposits in tap water, and the instructions suggest using filtered/distilled water. You clean unit by using vinegar, with a suggested frequency of once weekly.The bottom line is that if you need a sanitizer for one of various reasons, this does a decent job, but it has irritating caveats that will require you to make extra space and go through extra steps to get the job done. There must have been a better way to account for all the use cases that someone will encounter with a sanitizer.

Keeping in mind that I have no facilities to test whether something kills HIV on a surface, I can evaluate this spray as a cleaner. I used it in the kitchen. It seemed to do a good job of breaking up grime in nooks and crannies of the kitchen. The spray is a bit indirect for my personal preference, I'd like it to be more "surgical" so to speak. But the scent is just awful. It was borderline nauseating upon spraying, and it sticks around for quite a bit of time afterward. Imagine a bad floral perfume mixed with motor oil. Yuck. If you need disinfectant action, go for a lemon scent.

***Content***I won't spend a lot of time discussing content. These are Hitchcock's US films that are currently held by Universal Studios. Is it a complete catalog of Hitchcock's classics? No. Missing are "The Wrong Man," "Notorious," "Dial M For Murder," and "Strangers on a Train," among others. But this set does contain his very best: Vertigo, Psycho, The Birds, Rear Window, North By Northwest (under license from WB), Rope, Shadow of a Doubt, etc.The question, content-wise, is whether you would be justified purchasing this set when the much cheaper "Essentials" collection contains the first five of the very best films listed above. I think the answer depends on what sort of fan you are. If you want the cream of the crop and aren't particularly interested in diving in to his lesser-known catalog and watching his evolution as a film-maker both before and after that peak period, then save yourself seventy bucks and pick up the "Essentials" set. They're exactly the same discs, albeit with cheaper packaging. But if you really want to learn about movies, and be entertained, and watch a prolific director change with the times, this set still provides a lot of value for the dollar. Fifteen movies at an average of seven or eight dollars apiece is a pretty healthy bargain.Extras are copious on the "greats" and bit less so on the catalog pieces. Almost all of them are ported over from prior DVDs, and so are low-res letterboxed/pillarboxed presentations. Sigh.***Packaging***The set is contained in a relatively sturdy box, and includes a nice softcover book of about 60 pages that shows movie posters, production drawings, and contains some info about each movie. The binder containing the discs is a bit more problematic. Each disc gets its own page in the binder, with graphics similar to the packed in book. But the sleeves are quite flimsy. Where, say, the Star Wars set or the Alien Anthology set were made of thick foam boards that housed each disc, these are very thin paperboard sleeves. Several of my sleeves have already started to let discs slip through the bottom where the glue should be stronger, as opposed to holding the discs securely inside. So although the box, book, and binder are all quite handsome from a graphical standpoint, the binder ends up coming off cheap.***A/V Quality***These video transfers are a real mixed bag. A few of them rank up with the best blu-ray discs from similar periods: Vertigo, North By Northwest, and The Trouble With Harry each offer superb detail, rich color, and a very film like experience. Others like Rear Window and Rope are pretty good, but suffer from strange digital noise owing to the way these prints were processed. Some, though, are absolutely wretched. Family Plot and Frenzy are edge-enhanced messes crawling with strange digital noise but also smoothed to heck with DNR. The Man Who Knew Too Much offers up totally bizarre colors, with several actors looking gray and ashen.Audio is mostly excellent. When soundtracks have been "upgraded" to 5.1 channel, they sound respectful and accurate. When we have stereo or mono tracks, dialogue is clear and no undue noise seems evident.***Conclusion***This is a great set, and will be thoroughly enjoyed by Hitchcock fans and fans of great cinema. But it has some serious flaws. The packaging stinks and fully a third of the movies look terrible by the standards set by other Blu-Ray transfers of movies from the 30s through the 70s. As long as a customer goes in knowing this, I think tey will ultimately be satisfied.

On the plus side, the cars are neat, and they are reminiscent (probably intentionally) of the Pixar car characters, which ought to please the toddler set. Our son enjoyed playing with them and racing them down the ramps. There are a lot of pieces, giving the builder flexibility in creating stands for the ramps, or even bridges, since there are four of the ramp connector pieces included.There are a few flaws with this set, though.First of all, don't let the box fool you, there is no container for these pieces. So you're on your own when you want to put it away. Secondly, I'm not a big fan of including stickers. It's clearly just a cost saving strategy by the company. Have you ever tried to apply tiny little stickers to blocks in the presence of a 3 year-old? Thirdly, the instructions follow a really weird convention in which the prior steps' blocks are grayed out, presumably to make things easier to follow, but in fact making it difficult to see where the current step's blocks go. Also, the instructions are small photographs taken from a strange angle, and would be somewhat difficult to follow even without the odd color scheme. The suggested configuration of blocks isn't terribly stable, using small "one dot" blocks next to each other as supports, which is never very sturdy.So all in all, I give this set 3 stars, meaning an "OK," average, middle of the road toy. A box and better instructions would have made it a 4. Better customized pieces with paint instead of stickers would have made it a 5.

The Kobi Straight Tip Candle LED is an E12 "Candelabra" base bulb with a tall tip. AS far as build quality goes, this seems nice enough, though the top point has a slightly rough edge instead of a smooth taper (only really noticeable on the finger, not by sight). Heat generation is present but negligible compared to CFL and incandescent candelabra bulbs. The bulb is dimmable to about 10% brightness, which is typical for most current generation LEDs.Using a Kill-A-Watt meter, this bulb measured in at 5.9 watts used with a power factor of 82. This means that you are getting 77 lumens per watt, a good solid number considering this current generation of LED bulbs.Where this bulb really shines (so to speak) is in light dispersal. The dispersal is really even and wide, much better than the Lighting Ever LEDs I currently have in my ceiling fan. It's really best of breed from what I've seen of LED candelabra bulbs.Definitely recommended.

I am replacing a Nalgene Tritan OTG BPA free bottle, which had a fragile cap (it broke within a year or so of light use). My typical use case for a water bottle is while teaching, needing water for wetting my whistle so that I can keep speaking. So I want to replicate the function of the Nalgene (easy one handed drinking, no noise, not too large) and still have a dishwasher safe bottle that won't break.I am already more confident in the durability of this bottle. There is no hinge, which was the failure point of the Nalgene's cap. The Contigo has a very sturdy screw top that seems immune to the kind of breakage that dropping or jostling the bottle might create. There is a spring mechanism with the spout seal, but it is entirely contained inside the cap, so I think it will last long term.As far as drinking goes, the Contigo makes no sucking noise (as some straw based bottles like Camelbak do). When the button is depressed, water flows through by gravity, requiring no extra effort by the drinker.This may not be the ideal exercise bottle because of the need for a button press, and because of the relatively small spout width. But for what I need: secure, durable water conveyance in a conversational setting, it really fits the bill.UPDATEI have had one spill in a bag. Perhaps I got overconfident as to the water-containing abilities of the bottle. But at least one of the measures (cap, switch to prevent button from depressing) failed, which resulted in water leaking on some other things in my bag. I should add, this was simply a bag on my passenger seat, so it wasn't being jostled. Accordingly, I've docked a star. Still a good bottle, but not ironclad.

All questions about cloth vs. disposable aside, these are some pretty nice diapers.1. They absorb and hold a LOT of moisture. They do a good job of wicking it away from the skin, too, which helps prevent rashes.2. The "velcro" attachments are really excellent. The double-locking sort of velcro strips do a great job of adhering, but allow for easy re-adjustment, too. We've used diapers that didn't stick nearly as well.3. The leg-line does a good job of containing any accidents. We've had no leaks in a downward direction.So look. These diapers will do a good job of keeping your kids and your house/clothes dry. Whether or not that is a good thing for long term pottying is a separate question. These work as well as advertised and are great for certain situations.

Our son (going on 3) really enjoyed this book. He found the writing and the illustrations to be interesting, and he retained the information quite well. He has been talking about water and the roles it plays in the world very happily since reading this book. There are descriptions of about half a dozen easy to perform experiments with water that require no special equipment or mess. There is also a nice portion about fresh water and its scarcity in the world, and tips on water conservation. I give it a hearty recommendation for kids with an interest in science.

1. These pans do a good job of distributing heat to give a nice, even cook. I fried and scrambled eggs, made grilled cheese sandwiches, and made hamburgers/veggie patties in them.2. These pans are really heavy. This is a plus and minus. On the plus side, I used these pans in tandem as sort of a panini/grilled cheese press. They're that heavy. On the minus of course is the increased difficulty in maneuvering the pans.3. The non-stick coating works great but is EXTREMELY fragile. I took a grilled cheese sandwich off of the pan with a metal spatula once, and gingerly at that, and still saw scratches in the coating. This was pretty disappointing compared to the T-Fal pan we also have.So, all in all, I can't really recommend these pans for everyday kitchen use. They cook well but the coating is too temperamental to be relied upon long term. Go with one of T-Fal's pans.

I've been living with these bulbs for a few weeks. I initially bought them for a bathroom mirror fixture, but liked the light (and the price) enough to purchase more of them for floor and table lamps. Here are my observations:1. These bulbs draw 7.2 watts of electricity, not 8. I measured several of them with my Kill-A-Watt meter, and they all came in under the advertised 8 watts.2. There is indeed a short delay when turning them on. I'd say a quarter second. Since I am used to the CFLs these replace, this is no big deal for me.3. These are of course in the decorative size, so they are wider than a standard bulb. Keep this in mind when you plan to replace bulbs - I like the wide globe for "Decorative" lights, i.e. lights that one might see at any given time (in a lamp, ceiling fan, or sconce). These might not fit in some ceiling fixtures - it depends on how close the shade is to the socket.4. The base of these bulbs gets hot, but not terribly so compared to other CFL or LED bulbs.5. The dimming function works, but is not great. They don't get terribly dim on the low end, cutting out at perhaps 20% of the dimmer range. Almost every other LED bulb I have goes lower than this one.6. The color temperature is cooler than an old incandescent. but it is by no means blue. It is a really pure white, very close to sunlight.All in all, for under five bones a pop, this is a great buy. Hopefully they last as long as the rated life. If they do, I'll definitely enjoy these lights for a long time. I give them 4 stars for the turn-on delay and for the lackluster dimming performance. But overall I'm very enthused.

Content: Certain episodes are triumphs of presentation (particularly the leaded gas and global warming episodes). Others are a bit scattershot and frustrate by jumping around between subjects too quickly. Overall, a very entertaining show that provides a wide survey of current science, the scientific method, and science history. This doesn't go as deep as some documentary shows (such as Brian Greene's Nova specials or Neil Shubin's PBS shows on evolution), but it is a good show for whetting the scientific appetite.The Blu-Ray: Video and audio quality are generally excellent, with loads of fine detail. Black levels do fluctuate a bit, but colors are always vibrant. Outdoor HD shots are typically better than space footage, which shows the most variability in quality.The extras are rather lackluster. Only one episode receives a commentary. The lone making of documentary is pretty good, if a bit self-congratulatory. The interactive cosmic calendar is a waste of time and effort - too cumbersome to enjoy using, not enough content within it. I really would have liked to see deleted scenes, or perhaps additional spotlight documentaries on certain topics.In sum, this is a good buy to get a layperson interested in science. It will entertain but probably not completely satisfy someone who has already delved into the topic matter in other formats.

This is an MDF picture frame with a faux wood finish. If you go in knowing that and adjust your expectations accordingly, you should be quite pleased.This frame perfectly fit a piece of 12x16 art we purchased. The glass is smooth and even. The rear enclosure used a metal pin style of fastening around the object (see the manufacturer pictures) and the hanger is a hinge piece that maintains a good stickiness (meaning it doesn't fall flat the second you try to hang it). The frame was packaged extremely well and arrived with no damage. From a normal viewing distance, you'd be hard pressed to tell it's not wood, and the "antique" finish is quite convincing.For the price, I don't think you can do better. Would definitely order again.

The topic of stock and bond manipulation might sound dry, but really it isn't. It's the topic of a new nonfiction piece, "Flash Boys," by "Moneyball" writer Michael Lewis. So the question here is whether this treatment of the topic is a bland, paint-by-numbers thriller in the vein of Dan Brown, or is something more interesting. The answer is sort of in between. Character names have a penchant for sounding like Hollywood scripts ("Garret Reilly" is the protagonist), and the style veers a bit florid at times ("Then Blackness Overtook Avery Bernstein.").Overall, this was competent and mostly engaging. By the end, however, things sort of jumped the shark and seemed to lack verisimilitude. Perhaps future novels will be more consistent from start to finish.

Robert Stone has written what might be called an "arty" tale of an unexpected death, but he does so admirably free of overly florid descriptions or unbearably twee trickery. Instead, he creates an interesting set of characters surrounding his central victim, Maud. The character description is reminiscent of Richard Russo, though perhaps not quite as adept. The backdrop is a New York college, with the various types of people you might find there, young and old. Maud herself is a student, who gets involved romantically with a professor. Overall this was a very quick read and was entertaining and interesting, throughout. I did not really like the title, it indicated more of a murder mystery (e.g. all the other "Girl with the Insert XYZ" type cash-ins), when really this was more of a story about all the surrounding and contributing aspects of her death and the effects it has on the other characters.

Jennifer Senior's book is immensely readable, which makes sense given her journalistic background. She provides a lot of anecdotal data and individual stories to uncover patterns and trends in American parenting. She leavens this journalistic style with a fair amount of real hard data, though perhaps not enough for someone who is looking for a college classroom-level look at the topic. Nonetheless, highly recommended for thoughtful parents who are interested in national trends in the topic.

I jumped on this at the cheap refurb price, with the hope that it would equal my current amplified Terk antenna. Not only did it equal the Terk, but it bested it.The Terk had to be constantly adjusted to pick up signals from various locations (I am on the South Side of Chicago, within the city limits, a few blocks from the lake, about 7-10 miles from most broadcast antennas downtown). The Mohu seems to be much better at "omnidirectional" reception, since I have not had to move it from its optimal position. The signal strength across all channels seems equal or up to 10% better than the Terk. Problematic VHF channels come in at 50% and above, and almost everything comes in at 70-plus. CBS, which is really difficult to pull in in Chicago (don't get me started) comes in stably at 30%.Basically, it equals or betters the performance of the Terk without a wall-wart power source and without sticking out on our mantel. It's a slam dunk upgrade. Your mileage may vary, of course. All I can vouch for is its performance in a large urban area. It has freed me from constantly adjusting my very conspicuous amplified antenna. I just set it and forget it.

I have never been able to do very many push ups or really any tricep dips because it always hurt my wrists like crazy. These things make a huge difference! I used them when I did my favorite workout dvd yesterday (Ripped) and normally I have to do tricep curls instead of the dips in the video but this time I actually did them! In fact the workout usually makes my wrists pretty sore between all the push ups, mountain climbers, etc, but this morning I have no wrist pain. Amazing.

I ordered these to use when I clean my dog's food and water bowls. I wash them a couple times a week because he's a bulldog and he's gross, slobber wise, and I hate to use my kitchen sponge I use to clean our human dishes on his crusty grossness. The scrubby side of the cloth gets the stainless steel shining like new with minimum effort and the soft side easily cleans off the soap. I only wish they were slightly smaller because they kind of flop around in my kitchen sink.

My kindergartener normally wears a size 11 1/2 but I heard these run a little big so I ordered her the 11. They are perfect. I love the purple owl design because she no longer wants anything to be pink or to look like it's made for a toddler.My kids wore their new rain boots all day every day during our rainy, muddy, 4 day camping trip. They are so comfortable!

My third grader wears a size 2 sneaker. I heard the Western Chief rain boots run a size big so I ordered these for him in a size 1 and they fit perfectly, not too tight and not too big. I love the black widow design. It's very subtle so is perfect for a kid too old for toddler looking stuff.My kids wore their new rain boots all day every day during our rainy, muddy, 4 day camping trip. They are so comfortable!

These work just as well in our round step-can as the Force Flex bags we normally buy. My husband has a habit of squashing the garbage into the can to fit just a little bit more in rather than take out the trash right away, and that can cause tears in the bag if there is anything with a sharp corner. These have performed great, no tears, and they stretch nicely.

I have the "Bless Our Home" ornament, the little birdhouse with a Cardinal peeking out. The whole thing is painted very well. I think the words on the front are a sticker or stencil but they look very nice. Under the eaves of the house is painted the same pale green as the Christmas trees down in the corners, and I do wish the green was just a little darker to go with the vibrant red of the Cardinal. All in all it's very pretty and would make a nice gift for almost anyone.

I have been buying my kids Aqua Sphere goggles for years, I don't know why I never got a pair for myself. These fit my (small, woman) face well and the seal is so great I feel like I could suck my eyeballs right out if I'm not careful. I hate when my eyelashes brush against my goggles and my lashes have plenty of room inside these. I absolutely have to have sun protection for my eyes so the smoke lenses are perfect.

I used to wear Burberry Tender Touch (the one in the pink bottle) but they stopped making it years ago. Recently I tried Burberry Body and I love it but feel like it's really a summer only fragrance. My other favorite is Kenneth Cole Black for women. Burberry London for women is that perfect perfume, I can wear it every day. It's not chemical smelling, it's not overpowering, I never feel like I need to wear a certain outfit to pull it off. I love it so much I've moved the bottle from my bathroom to my nightstand so that when I put it on in the morning the scent hangs around in my bedroom all day. Buy it for yourself or for a gift without worrying about the season or your age, it's just wonderful for everybody!

Another review mentioned that this Diario coffee tastes like coffee from a good diner, and I think they hit the nail right on the head. That's exactly what I think when I drink it. I normally like a dark roast coffee, especially French Roast, and this is lighter than what I normally use. However, I find that when I'm in the mood for a lighter cup I like it.

These are pretty, thin, light, and small. I love rose gold. They are classy enough to wear to work, but because they are so cute you could totally wear them with jeans and a t-shirt too. Also an excellent choice for a middle or high school girl.

Chestnut street was disappointing. I wish Maeve Binchy's estate would stop publishing unfinished works, or at least I wish I could stop myself from reading them. This is the second book published after her passing and it's even more disappointing than the last. It's both unfinished and depressing. (I suspect it's so depressing because it's unfinished.) Please stop ruining poor Maeve Binchy for me.

I picked these for my elementary age kids to wrap up for me for my birthday. I wanted something I could wear all the time, since of course they love when I wear/use their gifts. What I really love about these is that the "MOM" is easy to read if you know what it says, but can pass as just a pretty scrollwork detail. I can wear these to work and on the weekend because they're small enough to be tasteful and big enough to feel pretty!I have extremely sensitive ears and I have no itching or redness with them. They are a quality product and make me happy.

This is a large and beautiful play set. It really is so pretty without being little girl looking. It's wonderful for my kindergartener but will also last and look current for years to come. I could even see this in a teenager's room, as long as she was really into fairies.It's heavier than I expected and is made of some kind of plastic (vinyl?) which feels both thicker and less brittle than my daughter's Disney castle. The base of the main piece measures 12 x 14 inches and if you arrange the two side pieces as shown on the box the whole set is close to two feet across. Putting the whole thing together took less than a half an hour. No tools are required. The structural elements snap firmly (and somewhat loudly) together, while the pieces you might want to move or change around join together well but can be moved without fear of breaking plastic connecters. The little decorative roses and squiggles were easy for my kindergartener to put wherever she liked without my help.The light up flower on the top is easy to work, very pretty, and comes with batteries already installed with one of those little plastic tabs you remove so the battery doesn't get used up during shipping. Speaking of shipping, each piece is properly bubble wrapped and snugly placed inside the box so I wouldn't think you would get any damage in the mail.

This is a very good Sonicare, and an excellent choice if you are purchasing to be shared by spouses with different dental goals and concerns. The base has little pegs to hold two brush heads so you can alternate for yourself or have one for each partner. What I find strange is the addition of the pressure sensor to a Sonicare that is designed for more aggressive cleaning and whitening than those of us with sensitive teeth and eroded gums can handle. The included brush heads are not good for my eroded gums either, I much prefer the "Diamond Clean" brush heads. You should know though that all the brush heads are compatible with the different (recent model) Sonicare bases. I put the diamond heads on this brush to give it a thorough testing.The pressure sensor is a neat feature and I can trigger it by pushing harder than normal, but not enough to hurt (which would make it a useless feature). If you are continuing to erode your gums even with another Sonicare the price of this toothbrush is a small one compared with gum reconstruction surgery. This is a nice toothbrush and perfect for my husband, but I won't replace my own Sonicare Healthy White with it when the time comes.

I am not doing this bible study with a group, and I don't have the accompanying DVD, but I am really enjoying it. I like that I can do what I feel like each day and skip what I don't have time for. If you don't open your bible and do the accompanying readings you don't have to put the book down for later, you can keep going. I love the way the author writes, not too casual but not so sweet and heavenly it gives me a headache. At one point one of her examples was so right on it literally gave me goosebumps. I'm subtracting a star because some of the side bar writing is in tan. The tan is too light and extremely annoying but wouldn't affect me recommending the book to someone.
Got this in medium for my son who wears a 7 or 8, depending on the brand. It's a little big on him but still looks good. The tag was scratchy so I cut it out. He loves wearing it.

We like BoomCo guns, this is our third. Unfortunately, it's everyone's least favorite. The battery requirement is annoying and I don't think it adds enough to the fun to be worth it. I'd rather have my son have to manually prime it between each shot. No idea why the barrel is so giant when it just fires regular BoomCo darts. It looks very cool, just doesn't deliver on the awesomeness.If you do get this (or any other) BoomCo gun go ahead and order extra darts. You will need them. For example, BOOMco. Ultimate Dart Pack. The first BoomCo gun we ever got is still my son's favorite and as I write this is also a great deal. BOOMco. Twisted Spinner Blaster

This is a high quality set which we easily put together in less than ten minutes. The interlocking pieces are well designed so they are easy to put together and don't fall apart when you need to move the toy around. I love the little light up torches, hopefully those batteries last us a very long time since we are good at remembering not to leave them on. The rubberized blocks are manageable to put into place, but don't fall apart randomly. My 3rd grader isn't thrilled that they stick into their spots too securely for the Terraria dude to knock them out with this sword, but it's better than having them fall out and get immediately eaten by the dog.As a single purpose Terraria playset I would probably give this three stars, just because there's not that much you can actually DO with it. However,when my son was younger I really wanted to find him a generic structure he could use to play with all his various figures. This would have been great for that too! While it's obviously Terraria, you could reasonably use it to play with your dinosaurs, lego minifigures, etc.

This is a very nice gel, works just like the Biolage gel I normally use. It doesn't give you the little bit of crunch you get with Biolage. To me this makes it less than perfect because I like to be able to choose to keep the crunch or scrunch it out, depending on how much hold I need on my curls, but otherwise the Suave version works great.

I bought this to read to my kids at bedtime. The premise of the book seems very cool at first (the idea of physically going into a book, and existing there and being able to interact with your environment and even characters) but the explanations of how this happens are extremely weak. Yes, I know, it's fantasy. But good fantasy should give you something to wonder about, this just doesn't. I also found it extremely annoying that the Kiel Gnomenfoot books were presented as being hokey and Harry Potter ripoffs, and then proceeded to become the focus of the whole book. I agree with the author, his book is hokey. It's like it was poorly written on purpose to show how poorly written some kids' books are. I found the whole thing frustrating to read out loud, and was actually relieved when my kids decided 3/4 of the way through they didn't want me to finish it.

This is a great solar charging kit that comes with everything you need. For our family this is going to be an occasional use tool, brought on the occasional camping trip and providing me peace of mind in case of prolonged power outage.Things I really like:Everything looks top notch and well made and finished. Even the box isn't a tear open and throw away package, it's a sturdy container with molded places for each piece.The attachments don't just clip in (which I think would produce wear and tear after a while) but you clip them in and then screw a threaded piece around the attachment point to secure it.The solar panel itself has three attachments so you can directly charge items.You can chain the portable battery between your device and the solar panel so you can charge both at the same time.The kit includes a short, fabric covered cable which connects my Samsung phone to the portable battery. Now I don't have to take apart my wall charger to bring the cable with me. On one frustrating occasion my husband brought his portable battery charger to Disneyland and we forgot to bring a cable so we had the battery but no way to use it.

I gave this kit to my second grade son and he really likes it. A lot of these kits look like a fun idea but they are filled with junky stuff that either isn't fun or doesn't work. Melissa and Doug really scored with this one! He loves the pens to write secret messages, the red "magnifying glass" makes the matching games a little more fun, and the decoders are great.I like that the three accessories each go with one specific book. This way you can bring just one book and accessory with you to a restaurant or on a boring drive. It also makes it suitable to divide up and give to 3 different kids.

This is a very nice body wash suitable for both adults and children. I am sensitive to fragrances and my kids have sensitive skin. This wash is very lightly (and pleasantly) scented with a fresh smell without that chemical perfume stink, and it doesn't dry out my kids' skin. It's nice to have something we can all use because that's one less bottle hanging around in my shower.

I use spray in my hair for two main reasons: When it's dry to smooth it down and add some semblance of style, or when it's wet to help hold my natural curls together. Spraying this on my dry hair has been a disaster every time I've tried it. It makes my hair feel sticky and really unappealing, and it looks worse. However, putting it on my wet hair is GREAT! I have natural curls that tend to fall apart into fluffy layers if I look at them cross-eyed but I don't always have time (or the desire) to do the whole gel-scrunch-diffuse dry-hairspray routine. I spray this all over my wet hair right out of the shower (no combing) and then scrunch my curls into place and let my hair air dry. Not only does my hair look great the first day, it still has a nice texture and no sticky feeling the next day as well. The spray is lightly scented with a clean summer smell, sort of like Light Blue by D&G or CK One Summer.

My husband and I have been using these with our new Keurig 2.0 K250 for about a week and they have worked flawlessly. I love that they can go in the top rack of my dishwasher, and since there are three I am never without a clean one. To use just fill it up to the top of the dolphins (maybe 1/4 inch below the lid) with coffee grounds and place it in your Keurig with the hinge exactly at the top. When you close the lid the piercing needle will go into the groove at the bottom of the cup without damaging it. When I close the lid the Keurig acts exactly like it does with the licensed K-cups I bought at Costco.I choose a 10 oz cup and use the "strong" setting and the cup of coffe tastes just like when I run the same coffee grounds through my drip maker. The result is a good cup of coffee with no grounds in it, and the reusable cup is clean outside and not dripping when I remove it.

Our first experience with Keurig was the K45 I bought my husband several years ago, and I hated it. The coffee was weak and the machine broke and had to be replaced. Twice. This little Keurig is such a HUGE IMPROVEMENT. I have cleaned and put away our regular drip maker, hopefully for good.What I like about Keurig in general is the lack of dishes to wash. I am a stay at home mom during the day but I work at night, usually until midnight. I'm not really in the mood to wash my coffee carafe and filter basket at 12:20am, and even less so when I crawl out of bed with the kids at 7:00.What I like about this particular Keurig is the "strong" setting. It makes a great cup of coffee, tastes just like drip, with the reusable K cup filled with the coffee of my choice. It's almost too strong, like the coffee at Starbucks, when I use the strong setting with the Peet's Alma De La Tierra organic dark roast K cups I bought at Costco.I think the whole proprietary K cups thing is pretty lame and I don't have the time or interest to sit around hacking stuff. I also prefer to use my own coffee to save money, keep plastic out of the landfill, and improve the variety of coffee available for me to use. I took a chance and ordered these reusable K cups PureJava Reusable K-Cups for Keurig 2.0 Brewers - Also Compatible With Previous Models! Set Of Three Cups With Coffee Recipe eBook Included! and they work great.

I am so disappointed in this book, and for a long time I was so excited about it. I love mysteries and was thrilled at a smart mystery series for kids. The two main characters show the same kind of smarts, mild disobedience and lawbreaking in their efforts to solve crime that you find in a lot of detective novels for adults. In fact, the plot has less holes and is better thought out than some mysteries I have had the displeasure to read.Unfortunately, right when the plot starts picking up speed and rolling towards the end the author resorts to the kind of cheap attention getting tricks that keep me sticking to older books for my kids as much as possible. In this case the gag of choice (get it?) is vomit. Why do so many books aimed at upper elementary aged boys have to be centered on farts, boogers and the like? My son loves farts as much as anyone, maybe more, but we don't need this. This is a really good series, but I can't help feeling like my kid's intelligence is being discounted by this plot device.

Home to Chicory Lane is the first Deborah Raney novel I have read. I definitely liked the book, but it took until the second half for me to get into it. The first half seems very distant, and because I was getting the hear the characters' doubts and fears without having gotten to know them yet I really didn't like any of them very much. Also some of the details seemed wrong to me. The young couple in the book have moved from an apartment on the upper west side of Manhattan to a studio in Bedford Stuyvesant and keep talking about how much more expensive it is. I'm not an expert on New York but a quick internet search confirmed what I thought, that a two bedroom in the upper west side will run you between $4000 and $8000 a month, and a studio in Bed-Stuy is under $2000. I know this seems like nit-picking, but this move and the resulting financial hardship is a huge part of the plot.The second half of the book is much better. The plot picks up speed from angst and whining to decisions and action, and you finally start to see inside the hearts of the characters. Everyone's relationship with God also goes from being randomly inserted to a real part of who they are. By the end of the book I was enjoying their company and feeling good about the decisions they had made. There's not too much substance here, but still an enjoyable read.

This is a fun and easy way to make a gift for Mother's or Father's day, or just to have a plate for each child so they will (finally) stop arguing about who gets which plate when I serve dinner. The kit comes with everything you need, including plenty of paper discs in case your child has trouble getting the hang of coloring on the thin paper or makes a mistake. The plate itself is just like the ones my kids have made at preschool. Cute and they go through the dishwasher with no problem.

Battle Bugs is an excellent adventure story! It combines fantasy, action, and science in just the right ratio to create a book that any action or insect loving second to fourth grader will love. I like that the protagonist, Max Darwin, doesn't speak in any fake sounding kid slang. I like that he uses his knowledge of insects to help defend Bug Island against the lizard invasion. I like that Max just happens to be black, since my son's bookshelf is sadly lacking the diversity of his real life. I like that this is the start of a series, I love series.Usually when I hear someone say a book would be good for "reluctant readers" I kind of think that means it will be dumbed down in some way. This book would be equally appealing to a kid who absolutely loves to read and a kid who dreads reading for school.

Plaster City was the first of Johnny Shaw's books I read, and definitely my favorite. As soon as I finished Plaster City I convinced my best friend to buy it and read it himself. When I asked him how he liked it he said "We know people like this, just like this!" I think that's what the charm of this story is to me, Shaw came up with this great adventure (excuse me, fiasco) and populated it with entirely believable, hysterically flawed, real characters. Nobody has super powers of endurance, deduction, or anything else. These guys would be your favorite friends to hang out with, you would just have to limit the visits to once a month or so to keep your job and your liver intact.

These are nice, big cups to have at a party. Each cup has Jake's face on one side and Finn on the other. I wrote each guests name on them with a sharpie as I handed them out so people were able to keep track of their cup and drink. After the party I kept the ones with my kids' names and we use them and run them through the dishwasher quite often. They still look new.

My kids and I have enjoyed playing other visual discrimination games (like Spot It) and I thought this would be a natural progression for my second grader. I personally found the game to be a weird combination of too easy (spotting the sets) and too complicated (I absolutely hate the "wild" dice). My son and I played it and had a decent time, I just felt like it took more time and energy keeping the score than actually playing the game.

I was really disappointed in the Panasonic DMC-ZS45K Lumix.  I had really high hopes for it as the functionality that is listed in the description really makes it sound like a great point and shoot camera.  I have experience with lots of different digital cameras, from the more sophisticated D-SLR cameras to the simplest disposables.  So I was really let down with this one.First off, for the casual user who just wants a simple point and shoot camera, I would not recommend this.  Panasonic did a horrible job of making the basic camera functions as complex as possible, requiring several steps to making adjustments that other cameras innately have available with one click or turn of a dial.  However, even if this wasn't an issue, which after a few days of use it became a little easier to remember where certain features were located, the biggest problem that I have with this camera overall is the horrible delay between pressing the shutter release button and time it takes the camera to snap the photograph.  This drove me crazy on my old freebie smart phone, so when this decently priced camera did it I was really shocked.  Basically what happens is you go to take a picture of say your children, so you line them up, tell them to smile, and push the button, you can almost count to two before the camera takes the picture.  At this point everyone has moved and the picture comes out all wrong or blurry.  It's really a shame.  I even switched the setting over to "action" so that it would increase the shutter speed time, and the results were exactly the same.  So if you tried to use the "action" mode to catch a thrilling shot at a sporting event or something, the picture would be about two seconds later than the one you tried to take!  At that timing, what's the point?I tried playing with the "WINK" setting for taking selfies, and that also needs some more engineering from Panasonic.  It works, but barely.  After setting the camera to take a picture using a "wink" (in the same menu as the countdown mode) you have to really be patient with it, and stand there looking like a crazy person winking slowly at your camera in an over emphasized manner in order for the camera to start a 3 second countdown to take the picture.  Even then, I could only get it to take a picture once every ten or so attempts.  Or you could just set the camera to countdown mode, press the shutter button, and the 3 second countdown happens exactly the same way.For more experienced photographers, Panasonic didn't help you out either.  The manual settings for adjusting aperture and shutter speed require four different steps, toggling between menu functions in order to make your adjustments.  It really shouldn't be that difficult to do these kind of changes, and really wastes a lot of good opportunities by forcing you to do them.There are a lot of cheaper cameras that take great pictures with so much less hassle.

Simple to install and holds the 23" flat screen LED television securely.  The fact the two vertical bars that connect the TV to the mount are free sliding, it will fit on pretty much any TV or monitor that I can think of.  You can choose which hole combination fits best, secure them to your TV, then simply hang the TV onto the mount's base that you already secured to the wall.However, I have a Panasonic and the bolts that come with the mount for securing it to the TV did not work at all, so I had to use some different ones that I happen to have lying around the house.So be sure that if you have a Panasonic TV, to make sure that you have mounting bolts that fit before purchasing this mount.

Very poor construction.  Thankfully Amazon was able to refund me the cost so that I could purchase a different one.  It created a horribly "digitized" image and the sound was crackly and buzzy.Thankfully I had an extra HDMI cable that I was able to use for my presentation that was perfectly clear for both the image and the sound.  I was hoping that an HDMI was and HDMI regardless of the price, but I was wrong.  The one I bought was about 5 dollars more than this one, and it is working great.

I love the versatility in this prime lens.  It functions so smoothly with my Nikon D3200 DSLR.  I love the functionality of seamless control going from the automatic focus to the manual focus by simply half pressing the shutter button and then rotating the focus ring.  I can easily get the camera to get a solid focus and then manually bump it in either direction, thus giving me so much more control over the final composition of my shots.Because it is a prime lens, you must be willing to move your body around a bit more in order to crop in and out of your desired shot, but for me the control that it gives and the quality of the final photo is worth any hassle I had to go through to frame the shot.This should be a lens in every DSLR user's bag.

My local reservoir has enacted a no lead tackle rule, so these sinkers were a great cheap replacement to the older sinkers I had rolling around in my tackle box.Nice strong loop connections and smooth shape will make using these a much better solution to the old lead ones I've been using anyway.

I was really impressed with the heavy build construction, not fragile and bendable like some of the other stringers.  Although it is very light weight and easily wraps up in the bottom of my tackle box.  Even all the monster fish that I catch on a regular basis will fit perfectly on the generously sized snap loops. (haha!) I would think it will last a long time.

This is such a fantastic game!  My 7 year old son has really started to conceptualize strategy, so we figured that this would be a fun way to build on his growing enthusiasm.  After learning the basics of checkers, he was ready to try out this version.  Basically this is a turn based game where the roll of the dice determines what pieces of which colors a player gets to move.  Each player has a designated color, but you get to move not only your pieces but the other players pieces as well.  The fun "dog" twist is that the checker pieces are small dog bowls, and when a King is made, you just add a small bone into the bowl to represent the pieces promotion.So a big part of the game is to strategize about moving your opponents pieces as well as your own to optimize your chances to win.  It's a great spin on traditional checkers and really gets you thinking about how different moves can effect the game.  Even I am building a lot deeper understanding of checker strategy by playing it.I would highly recommend this game for anyone old enough to understand the basic game of checkers because even the most skilled player can be challenged by having their opponent manipulate their pieces, thus constantly changing the game.  Lots of fun for everyone!

This book is just a typical book on caring for aging parents. The author mentions examples of people who are conflicted about caring for a parent who was abusive in some way but then totally drops that aspect. NO discussion of their decision making process, their feelings, nothing. This book was totally useless.On the other hand the book Doing the Right Thing, Taking Care of Your Elderly Parents, Even if They Didn't Take Care of You, by Satow, is great. It's what this book should have been.

This sunscreen dries super fast once you apply it, which is very important in convincing my kids to hold still for 2 minutes while I apply it. My husband liked that about it as well. No slimy feeling, no visible residue, and works great!

Here's the thing about this book.It's totally unreadable.Totally unreadable means each sentence is it's own paragraph and the writing makes me want to gouge my own eyes out.Descriptions that take forever.Like I mean a whole page that should have been one sentence.I have never known any kid who spoke this way or was such a completely annoying nut job. Both the third graders and the kindergarteners were wildly inaccurate. Just reading it to myself was exhausting. I think I need a Tylenol.

Great body wash.  The biggest problem that I have with the more popular body washes is the lingering oily feeling on my skin.  Some love it, but I can't stand it, so I was very pleased that this washes off cleanly without the feeling that I just put lotion on my skin.  The wash forms a great lather and for those that remember the 80's, it definitely works to make you feel, "clean as a whistle"!The scent is pleasing, with a clear hint of mint.  It comes close to being an almost "candy" like scent, but not sickly sweet.  My wife is sensitive to most fragrances, and she seems to enjoy this.  So that's a big plus for me!

I was fascinated by the concept of this food so I just had to try it. It passes every criterion set by dog food advisor, no weird mystery "meat" or grain fillers. The label does indeed say "complete and balanced". My bulldog will eat anything including gravel so I knew it would be no trouble to get it into him. We do travel with him and I thought it might be nice to bring this little box rather than a big, smelly tub of kibbles.Mixing it up is easy, although like other reviewers I found that less water than suggested was better if your dog doesn't like soup. I was shocked at how not messy his face was after he ate it. When I occasionally give him baby food with his kibbles I think half of it ends up spread between his eyes and neck. There are no bad effects on the lawn, if you know what I mean. No gas, no trouble at all. If you are looking to add variety for the sake of making sure your dog gets balanced nutrition this is an excellent choice.

This is a pretty good parenting book on how to recognize and nurture your child's spiritual connection with a power (whichever one you feel connected to) larger than themselves. The author discusses the difference between her definition of spirituality and adherence to an organized religion. She is open to having a spiritual life outside a church, but is never disrespectful to those of us whose spiritual life is centered in our church community, which I thought was nice.My educational background is in science, I have a couple of degrees in hard sciences. I am also a spiritual person whose faith is totally grounded in my church. I have never had a problem reconciling these two things, they are both who I am. I found the "science" aspect of this book a bit forced. It seems to be aimed at parents who are uncomfortable with religion, especially sharing religion with their kids. This book would be great for people in that situation as it is filled with tons of helpful suggestions on nurturing your child's innate spirituality at all stages of their development.

We bought several brands and types of looms together and this one is my absolute favorite. It is strong and easy for both myself and my 7 year old and myself to hold onto. One of the pegs came out shortly after we bought it but I just pushed it back in and we haven't had any trouble with it since then, despite being used by a second grade boy. Since it's soft and perfectly silent to use we also bring this to church to keep him busy.

I use spray oil on my daughter's hair every day. We use Suave Professionals Light Oil Spray, Natural Infusion Macadamia Oil & White Orchid 3 oz. It works great but smells a little strong for my personal taste so I wanted to give this one a try as well. What a disaster. I (attempted to) lightly mist both our hair before I took her to preschool and by the time we got there our brushed hair had separated into greasy strings. I was so embarrassed at the way she looked I had to explain it to her teacher so she wouldn't think my kid had wet hair all day. Part of the problem is that this stuff is just greasy, and part of the problem is that it doesn't mist, it sprays, so you can't get an even application. It's awful.

My son suffered horribly from eczema when he was a baby, and we still are very careful with his skin. He still gets eczema patches on his knees, and has very dry elbows, chapped lips and skin around his mouth. Since he hates Aquaphor on his face so much I generally wait until he's fast asleep, crawl across his bed, and smear his face with so much Aquaphor he probably sticks to the pillow when he rolls over. This lotion works great and is much more tolerable to him. I have been using it on my extremely dry winter face as well and after a few minutes you pretty much don't feel it. I wish I would have had this for his sad, red eczema face when he was a baby.

This little set has two awesome parts:1. Hit the launcher and send your truck to either crash (fun), get stuck in the dragon's mouth (more fun), or pass through the mouth to hit the tail causing the dragon's head to fly off (obviously the most fun).2. If you get a truck stuck in the dragon's mouth you can move the launcher to the other attachment point and launch another truck at the tail until you pop the dragon's head off and set your buddy free.We are definitely a Hot Wheels family. Along with multiple playsets for the cars and (ugh) hundreds of cars my 7 year old also loves their monster trucks. We have a couple of the mini monster truck sets and a couple sets for the full sized trucks. I think this one is my favorite so far. You have to go into these sets with the understanding that they don't work flawlessly, you are going to have to push the trucks around with your hand sometimes to take full advantage of every feature. Totally recommend for boys and girls ages 4 to 7.

I don't know much about morning sickness, as I was stricken with full blown hyperemesis with both pregnancies. What I do know about is the desperate struggle to get adequate nutrients to your baby when you can't keep much of anything down, so I thought this powdered pre-natal was a good idea and worth trying. Unfortunately it is yucky. I'm not even currently pregnant and I couldn't force it down. I think the problem is that they insisted on including iron, a substance which makes even pills leave a gross aftertaste. Sure iron is great to have when you're pregnant, but it's not critical like some other nutrients like folic acid. Speaking of folic acid, which you absolutely have to have to help prevent spinal defects, if you find you can't keep any pre-natal vitamins down you can take folic acid by itself. This is the one I took during both my pregnancies and I highly recommend it. Country Life Folic Acid 800 mcg, 100 Tablets

This book is less of an in depth discussion of topics and more like a collection of magazine articles. This is less surprising when you learn that the author has appeared on the Today show 25 times, and is trying to develop this book into a TV series. Dr. Holland offers you some pseudo-science such that the reason parents of young children who have been married for several years no longer have so much sex is based on a combination of changes in hormones and the "fact" that humans are not meant to be monogamous. The book is long on explanations but short on suggestions, unless you think that cheating or having an open marriage are "solutions" worthy of your consideration.There are chapters on getting more sleep, eating better, getting exercise; not exactly ground breaking aids to your mental and physical health. The author is also extremely passionate about marijuana, which she insists we call cannabis, because the name marijuana was made up by the Federal government to scare us because we all hate and fear the people of Mexico(?!?). She goes so far as to advise that if you don't like getting high you should run some Mary Jane through your juicer. This book might have seemed interesting when I was 20, but as an adult it doesn't have much to recommend it.

This is a well written book that earns a place on the bookshelf of anyone getting started as a caregiver. The key here, is the "getting started" part. It is an excellent resource for people with aging, but still functional parents. It gives comprehensive guides and checklists (with space for notes) on financial, medical, and legal conversations to have. However, this is more of a narrative than the kind of reference book you look stuff up in. It is also quite specific to the type of caregiving journey the author had with her father: long distance care, followed by care in her own home, followed by care at a facility. The chapter on deciding whether you should have your aging parent in your own home was inadequate unless you had an ideal childhood, are financially well off, and are willing to do anything for your parent. Those of us with abusive parents end up as their caretakers too, and are less likely to be willing to provide care at home.All this being said I think this is a valuable book if you are at the start of your caregiving journey and I would recommend it to anyone in that situation. You would be best served by combining it with a more detailed resource that will actually answer your specific questions, such as Long-Term Care: How to Plan & Pay for It.

I have always resigned myself to the fact that my face will look worse with sunscreen. I head out to the community pool every day of the summer looking shiny and kind of purple. It's worth it, but doesn't do wonders for my self esteem. I also have sensitive skin, prone to rosacea and irritation pimples. For me this Cotz tinted sunscreen is a miracle. Most sunscreen in too dry and irritating to use without lotion underneath, but not this one! It covers my face and neck evenly without leaving my skin dry and wrinkly looking. The small amount of shine from the reflective materials in the sunscreen combined with the light tint make my face look better. I love it and will use it every single day this summer.

We have had so many of the Go Dog brand toys for our English Bulldog and this one was a favorite, but didn't last more than a week. He had the Go Dog donkey since he was a little puppy and we just recently had to throw it away, but this one came apart very fast for a dog who loves toys but doesn't ruin too many of them. If you really want a pink pig for your dog I totally recommend the Go Dog flying pig instead goDog Checkers Flying Pig with Chew Guard Technology Tough Plush Dog Toy, Pink, Small. Ours doesn't have any eyes but has been a favorite toy for months.

Since Graco is marketing the Argos as a 3-in-1, I have to review this seat in three parts: as a forward facing harness seat for toddlers and preschoolers, as a high-back booster, and then as a backless booster.Five point harness seat: FIVE STARSHigh back booster: THREE STARSBackless booster: ONE STARAs a five point harness seat for toddlers and preschoolers the Argos Elite, like the Nautilus before it, is a five star seat. I love absolutely everything about it. It is comfortable, sturdy, easy to install, easy to adjust the harness tightness, has lots of pockets for goodies, easy to wash. This seat has it ALL. With the Nautilus you had to un-latch the seat and re-thread the top of the straps as your child grows, but with the Argos you can adjust the headrest up and down without removing the top of the harness.As a high-back booster there are two flaws. The first is that the seat is so huge that your child will absolutely not be able to buckle themselves. You will be able to clearly see the female end of the seatbelt, but it is difficult even for an adult to get the male end of the buckle around and behind the armrest to click it shut. The second problem is that while it's obviously great to be able to raise the headrest you can't adjust the width of the seat at the shoulders. My 4 year old's shoulders don't fit comfortably between the sides and letting my 7 year old try the seat was a joke. He is probably the skinniest 7 year old on earth, less than 45 lbs, and there is no way he could ride in that seat with the back on. If you need a high back booster for an older kids I use this one: Diono Monterey High Back Booster with Adjustable Headrest, SurfAs a backless booster honestly this seat is a joke. While it is theoretically possible to use the Argos this way I can't imagine anyone ever would. First off it looks ridiculous without the back, big old plastic hinges sticking out the back. Second it is way too high. If your kid is so short that they could tolerate being boosted up this much they need a different seat. And they still won't be able to buckle it themselves.Graco is doing themselves (and their customers!) a disservice advertising this as a three in one seat. The honest answer is this is a seat that will safely and comfortably harness your kid up through preschool. It's a great seat for that and worth every penny! If you need that kind of seat you will love this one. Just don't fool yourself that it will be the only seat you ever need.

Everything I write on this calendar, even in light pencil, transfers through to the next month. The paper is thin and seems prone to tear at the top where it hangs. I am also not thrilled that the quotes on the calendar are from Thomas Kinkade rather than the bible.

I have been regularly using a Crock Pot brand slow cooker for the last 10 years. I wanted to try this Hamilton Beach one because it promises no more overcooked mush, and it actually delivers on that promise. Our old Crock Pot is a nice one, programmable on high or low for up to twelve hours. The two things that have annoyed me about it over the years are that the crock has to be hand washed, and the low setting cooked our dinners in closer to the time recommendations in recipes for high power. After a long day cooking you really did get overcooked mush.The first thing I made in the Hamilton Beach was a potato cheese soup. I threw everything in, used the intelli-time feature, and headed out the door to work. When I returned home I expected my soup to be boiling vigorously like it always did in my old Crock Pot. Instead it was held at a very low simmer, enough to keep the soup piping hot and cook the potatoes, but not so much to dissolve the potatoes into mush. What a difference! I love it.

This is a wonderful Panini press that does a great job providing a sandwich that is nice and hot all the way through the middle, achieving a crunchy outside, all while not burning or charring the bread.I picked up this Proctor Silex because I thought that it would have a smaller grilling area than my Griddler by Cuisinart.  The Griddler is intended to do different kinds of grilling So I assumed that an actual Panini Press would take up a little less counter/shelf space so I gave it a try.  At the very least I was able to really do a thorough side by side comparison between the two.As it turns out the Proctor Silex Panini Press is a little thinner but the overall grilling surface area is about the same size as the Griddler.  The Griddler reached full heat level about two minutes before this Panini Press, so they were both pretty much ready to cook at the same time.  I made four pesto turkey paninis (all exactly the same), two on each press, so as to test the cooking times.  The Griddler finished cooking the sandwiches about three minutes before the Proctor Silex, so it does appear that the heating elements in the Cuisinart does push a little more power to the grill plates than this press does.  A bit of a positive for this Panini press is that it has a locking mechanism on the arm so that you can press the sandwich down and lock it in place keeping it pressed down for cooking.  The Griddler does not have this feature.Both made exactly the same quality sandwiches, as my family couldn't tell the difference between the two sets.  So at least so far both performed pretty much as well as the other, with the Cuisinart Griddler having a little more power for faster start up and cooking time.It was in the cleanup that the Griddler really takes a break away lead from this Panini Press.  Once all the cooking is done and the presses have cooled off, this Proctor Silex Panini Press cleanup requires that you wipe it down with a soft cloth, using mild dish soap for especially soiled areas.  You cannot submerge the press for cleaning, but clean it just like a regular waffle iron.  So it is a bit tedious getting into all the cracks of the press to get it really clean.  The Cuisinart Griddler though as completely removable grill plates that can be dropped right into a sink of soapy water.  Easy to clean, then dry off.Overall, I like the Griddler a little better (5 Stars instead of 4) just because of the ease of cleanup, which holds a lot of weight to me, but I think that most people  would be completely happy with choosing this one over the other.

These dividers are great quality. They hold 8 1/2 by 11 papers nicely until you can get them hole punched. They are easy to write on with pencil and erase nicely in case you need to re-organize your binder. I love Avery's plastic dividers because they will not wear out and get torn like the paper ones I used to use in school did.

After reading many reviews I think there is a strong concern this perfume is not the original one from Calvin Klein.  My bottle seems to be the real deal.  The packaging looked like other Calvin Klein perfume that I have had in the past.  The perfume was not discolored, and the scent seemed to be correct.  This is a small sized bottle that is perfect to carry in your purse.  I have always liked the Calvin Klein scents, they are long lasting, and aren't too floral or sweet for my personal taste.I would feel comfortable purchasing a bottle, as it appeared to be legitimate.

As I wake up out of my chocolate coma I will let you know about how this huge bag of Hershey's kisses were.  They were sublime.  How I love carefully unwrapping each kiss.  The crinkle of the foil, the pulling of the the Hershey Kiss tag and setting it to the side as I pop the kiss into my mouth.  Yes.This large bag is great for gift bags for Weddings, Bridal and Baby Showers, or perhaps you are making bags for a child's birthday party.  Everyone loves chocolate, so this one of those perfect candies to give away.  Mine went to the office, it has gotten me many favors by having a enormous bag of candies at my desk.  I reckon I can continue to get favors done for about two months until these run out.This is a great size to purchase when you need many candies.

I love this notebook, I seriously do.  It takes a beating, the paper if of high quality, and it holds up so well.  This notebook has been in and out of my purse for almost a year now.  It gets spilled on, the notebook can get damp, but it keeps on trucking.  I love the lined paper.  This is just a favorite of mine.

This game is so much fun.  Don't play with people that are easily offended.  I have done this, and well I have offended people.  So don't.  Be sure to play with your parents so you can hide in shame as they give the winning answer again and again. Learn things about friends and parents you wished you had not known.

As often as I drop my phone I need this case.  My phone has been dropped on tile, concrete, wood, carpet, you name it.  I chances are with a large phone like this you may drop your phone too.  The phone works like a charm ;)

Very happy with the card selection I received.  I believe there was 1 card from Russia in there.  Other than that, all cards were in english.  I received only a minimum of dupes, I believe it was I  had 2 cards duplicated.

I had a couple of leather handbags that needed some love.  This added a wonderful sheen and suppleness back to the bags.  This was easy to apply and it soaked in fairly quickly so I could use the bag again.  It made my leather wallet look new again.  I highly recommend this leather milk.  I can hardly wait to use it on more leather items.The scent was neutral and this did not leave a film or anything on the bags.  So I would love to try this on some old leather shoes and perhaps even my couch.  I am very happy with this purchase.

imagine the fun and the excitement of building a fun and entertaining life through random chance.  We all grew up playing "Life", but this game is so much quickly, and isn't a lot of fun.  So we tried this game tonight, and it wasn't a bit hit.  You get to build the best life you can with these cards.  After about 5 rounds of this game, we had gone through the whole deck.  You can swap out cards with others, or build the best life you can from the deck.
