This game is a quick playing game that takes maybe 10 minutes per round.I feel with the number of people you need to play the game with, and the limited number of lifestyle cards, this game has very limited play.  Yes, you will get some chuckles when you find yourself a rock star living in a cardboard box in Nowhereville.  I don't think this would be a game you would be pulling out more than once or twice.  This had a nice concept, and may be a great way to spend time with a group of kids, but definitely not a fun game for adults.

Yes, this is a three pack.  These cords work well, and they will last a good amount of time.  I like to pick these up and put one in my car, by computer bag, and one in the house, this way I am never without these cords.  These are better quality than what you typically find in the drug store.  Very happy with my purchase.

I want to like this more.  My entire house is tile.  I hate to grab the whole mop bucket out, and sometimes pulling out the steamer doesn't make me feel like the floor is clean, because there isn't scrubbing action with the steamer.  I like the scrubbing action of this floor.  So this would be great if it was designed for smaller jobs.Each time you use this you need to pull out the filter and wash it and let it dry.  This is a lot of work for when you want a quick and easy cleaning job.  I have cats, there is nothing like finding a hairball that has dried to the floor.  They tend to only offer one at a time, so for me, this is a lot of work pulling this out, loading up a tank, and then washing the filter.What this is good for is if you want to do large rooms of tile.  So the water spray isn't perfect, you have to squeeze the handle, and you may have to go over it a couple of times.  The wheels could use a redesign.  You can work with them, they aren't agile, they are functional.  I thought this did an ok job on getting to the grout.While I don't love it, and if something else comes in the market that is similar, I would like to give it a try.

The noble Italian Visconti ruled over Milan for generations.  The current Visconti is dying without an heir to pass on the family heritage.  The Sforza family are ready to take the rule in this city has they have been for many years.The old duke, has an heir, but he is not legitimate.  Niccolo a son by a noble lady.  He gives his son to Archdeacon Onorio to be raise so he would be safe.  Onorio is a secret Druid.  Druids have inhabited Milan for many years. They worship Bellslama, who in Christian times turns into Virgin Mary.Niccolo grows up wanting to be an artist; he does.  His closest friend is Lorenzo, who is a killer for the Sforza family.  Niccolo falls in love with Angelica, who is a former mistress of a prominent family.  Niccolo doesn't realize his relationship with Angelica is also doomed because he is a noble, and she is a commoner.Having visited Milan many years ago, I loved this book.  I have been to the Sforzno castle, and I have been through parts of the old city.  The book moves quickly, and is a good quick read.

I love using a body wash, they are scented, and they lather up very well.  This one is no exception.  This says it is perfumed, it is, but it fades quickly.  I find that if you put perfume on after you aren't going to be bothered by competing scents later.  The color of this is red.  So be warmed ahead of time.  I think it is a fun color.This lathers up well and has a nice scent.  I think these are far better priced than say Bath and Body Works.  A good price, great lather, and a refreshing clean feeling what more could you ask for ?

I love vinyl drops for food photography, you can type them off, and vinyl gives you the ability to have diverse back grounds in a small space.  I think this one isn't my favorite because it picks up a lot of glare.  For me the lighter ones look better.  This one looks flat and picks up way too much shine.  I find this one difficult to work with.

Beatrice Knowles is a Maid of Honor for one of Queen Elizabethâs I Court.  She is known for a lady who can break menâs hearts.  Because of her skill she believes she is a valuable member for the Queen, but is she.  The Maids stopped a plot to overthrow the Queen, and Beatrice is to be married to Lord Cavanaugh.  Her plans are up in the air because of the brewing Scottish rebellion.Her new assignment is to infiltrate the visiting Scottish delegation using her womanly wiles.  Her task should be straight forward, but Alasdair MacLeod is a formidable foe. She will get in a spider web of twisting lies.  Danger, love, are all to be found here.

Do you have a young one fascinated by pirates?  These are a great set of figures that you can swap out their dress.  Your characters will soon be going on adventures.  These are made of wood, and they are large, so they are good for those who have small fingers.  Lots of pieces so the possibilities are endless.  These are beautiful and well made.  There is only one minor drawback.  The pouch these come with is a bit flimsy, so you will want to grab a box to put all of your pieces in soon enough.Great design, lots of possibilities, and a lot of fun.  You can swap out the shoes, the pans, the shirts, and hats.  There are even fun items such as parrots.  I think these are great for girls and boys both.  Enjoy your new pirate adventures.

This is good for making waves and making that 2nd hair hair last a day longer.  This isn't one of those brushes that blows air, this one basically gets hot.  I dislike there is no temperature setting on it.  If you are careless you may stress out your hair with all of the heat it can put off.  I don't understand what the glove is for, or rather, I don't know how to incorporate it into use.I got some volume with this, not a lot, I get mostly waves from my hair, but it is nice and smooth.  This doesn't make well defined curls for me.  I will say that I like it because it isn't as hot as a flat iron, and I think it is more gentle on the hair.  I have used this for a couple of weeks now, and I find it a good tool to run through my hair to freshen up my hair.

Seriously, life changing when it comes to food photography.  Why didn't I discover these sooner?  I have no idea.  They roll up, they look wonderful. You can clean them.They are of a nice size, and reflect light very well.  Honestly, I wished I would have purchased my first one a long, long, time ago.  Am I gushing?  Yes.

This seems to be a theme in many books I have read lately.  Being mindful brings you back to your most productive self.  This book by David Gelles is an easy to read and well written book on meditation and how it can make your work seem more productive.  So often I think when we get too busy we lose grasp with ourselves and our ability to concentrate or live in this moment is lost.I think this book is a great primer on how to work meditation and mindfulness into your life.  The book for me wasn't too far out there, but gave enough scientific detail to help persuade you that through meditation you can be a more productive and less stressed person.  We all strive for a work life balance.  One of the things I loved most about this book was that it was well laid out and well organized.  I felt this helped to demonstrate what a peaceful and well organized mind can produce.

These dolls can be a lot of fun, there are four different dolls with a lot of clothing choices.  I love that these are made out of wood.  So they feel as they are made with high quality materials.  You can spend hours making different combinations of the dolls. I have a couple of concerns.  I am not sure that this is appropriate for children that are 3 years old.  I think the pieces are very small.  Additionally, I don't care for the plastic case, it will be easy to lose the pieces.  I think you will need to store these pieces in a box, or other container.I think these are fun, high quality, and will give you hours of play time.

I have been a multi cat owner for a long time now.  For me litter is an important consideration and something I care about.  I thought the Advance High Performance did a good job as a type of litter.  I love the lighter weight cat litters, because I typically buy several at once, and it is less to carry in my home.  This did a good job on order control, and I am a definite fan of this cat litter.I have three cats and this container will last me a little more than a week.  For me spending a few extra pennies on litter means having a multi-cat home can be more pleasant.

I am a fan of New Chapter Vitamins.I have always liked the New Chapter supplements.  I have had some soreness in my knees lately, and I have found these to ease some of the pain I have been having.Zyflamend is aimed at achy joints.  I found it interesting that the instructions on the inside of the box said you should take 1 pill each day for the first week and then on the 2nd week you should up the dose to two pills a day.  I always take these types of products with a light meal.  I found these did not repeat when I had them with a small meal.The Bone Strength tables have a plant sourced calcium along with magnesium and D3.  This combination seems to be a popular one, and one that is very effective.I think if you are concerned for the welfare for your body these are two good supplements to take.

I like many of the L'Oreal Revitalift products.  They seem to be well thought out products that do good things for your skin.  This serum is wonderfully light, and hydrates your skin very well.  I think that some small lines are made smaller visibly with this product.  I like to use this after my toner and before my primer.I haven't used this long enough to see dramatic results.  I am sure I will continue to see good results, I know  it will take time.  I think the package is overkill.  It seems like a lot of plastic that encases a small amount of product.  I like that it isn't in a jar, but I think this would have been just as good if it came out of a tube.

Looking for a hearty can opener that will do the job?  This one may be for you.  I really like the OXO brand, they seem to think out their construction very well.  As a child we always had those inexpensive can openers that were thin.  This one is one where you can easily grip your hand around the the handles.  I find this heavy duty grip makes the larger cans easier to open.I sometimes buy the old large number 10 cans, and flimsy can openers just don't do the job.  I have had an OXO can opener for a long time now.  I have had my other one for more than five years with no issues.  I like this red one because I have a lot of red colors in my kitchen.  If you are looking for a good can opener I couldn't think of one I would recommend more.

I am seeing this brand more often in the stores.  So far I have been very impressed with the Japonesque brand.  They offer a higher end products that are on bar with well known names here such as Make Up Forever, Urban Decay, and MAC.  So this is something much nicer than you would normally get in a drug store.The packaging is a big plus, a very nicely decorated case that is study.  So you can feel like the product won't break or crack in the package should you put it in your purse to carry around.  I think this is a big plus.  I have the purple shade number 06.  I thought the colors were very nice, and very wearable for most for either the office or  evening.The texture is a soft and buttery and they blend very well.  I wasn't in love with the pigmentation.  I always wear eye shadow with a primer and these lasted from 6 am in the morning until 10 pm when I washed them off at night.  This compact really does a nice job at giving you a great day look.  If you want something more intense I think you may need to enhance it with additional colors.  While the quality and lasting power of this shadows is amazing, the pigmentation leaves something to be desired.

This is an amazing lotion!! I personally feel like I need to go to a meeting when it comes to how many different types of lotion I own.  I am always looking for the perfect one that will sooth my dry skin, and keep it protected.  I do a lot of dishes, work with my hands continually, so I wash them very often.  My skin is often dry.  I really want a lotion that will add a protective layer.This is a creamy lotion, it feels soft and silky.  You will feel like you are putting on a protective layer on your hand.  This lotion feels so amazing,  it reminds me of my L'Occitane Shea Butter lotion.  This is much more reasonably priced than higher end lines, but has a very similar feel.  It is heavier, and will give your hands a protective layer that will last for a long time.

More fun, and more hilarity will ensure from this this set of cards.  This set came with some blank cards so you can put in your own questions and your own answers.  I love, love, love, this game, and thought the questions and answers in here added much to this game.  I will definitely be purchasing more expansion packs in the future!

If you are looking for a good solid coffee maker this may be the one for you.  Black and Decker has been making consumer products for many years.  We know and trust their brand name.  While they haven't been making coffee pots for that long, I think this is a great first effort.  I have this machine as well as a Cuisinart.  I will say the one thing this model has over the other for me, is the programming.  I don't like to read directions, and I generally hope that a product is designed well enough for me to use without a lot of reading.  I could figure out how to set the clock and get this model up and running.I loved the filter, in concept.  You won't have to buy disposable filters, but rather you can use the one that comes with the machine, but I have a hard time cleaning it.  Since the blade of the mill is so close to the filter, it is difficult to make sure you are getting it clean without the potential of scratching or cutting yourself.  I don't enjoy having to refill the filter every time I want to make coffee, as I feel the need to clean out the filter.I wished the coffee pot would have been a stainless steel pot instead of the more traditional glass coffee pot.  I don't like my coffee to cook continually, and a thermal pot would have been nice.Nice coffee pot in many areas.  I think there were some design improvements that hopefully will come out in the next model.  You may want to look at other options in this price point.  The coffee tastes great, and it is very easy to program, for me these are major pluses.

I have been recently exploring this line of make up.  I have to say I am impressed.  This is a really nice shade of eye shadow.  It is perfect for a lid color, or a highlighter.  It is a nice fleshy color with a slight shimmer.  This goes on creamy and and doesn't flake off.  If you are wondering what these are comparable to I think they are like Urban Decay.  These are a high end and high quality eye shadow.The packing is pretty, a nice multi-colored case.  It has a nice clasp and isn't going to come open.Overall I really like this eye shadow, its great for everyday wear.

With the first of the year, I always like to get organized.  Getting my files together and actually labeling the files really helps to make things right for me. I liked that I could go online and design my labels. This way I got them exactly like I wanted.  My label maker at home only does 1 font, and 1 size of letters.  With these I could get a little more creative.In a matter of minutes I got my 2014 Tax file, and my 2015 expenses lined up and ready to go.  Since I was able to make these look a little different it is going to be even easier to find what I need.These are high quality labels that you will love.
Works almost as well as a gin and tonic before bed.I actually like the scent and it is pleasant.  It is a relaxing scent.  I enjoy putting a few drops in my diffuser before bed.

I have never used a  Salad Spinner before.  While I can't say that I enjoy eating dirt, I never realized how much dirt these pull away from your lettuce. I like this model, but it is pretty large.  I really thought this did an effective job of getting my lettuce and herbs clean.  I never realized how much dirt was on cilantro.  This is very easy to use, and I liked it quite a bit.  I would definitely recommend this model to others.Pros:Made of good quality plasticEffortless, you aren't pulling and tugging to get the spinning bowl to work wellVery large, you can easily put a bag of salad in hereEasy to useDirt comes off your foodStoppers on the bottom to keep the bowl from spinning across your counter top.BPA FreeCons:Drain plug on the bottom didn't seem  to be effective

These are great tasting almonds.  They aren't too salty and they have a hint of smoke.  I love the bag is resealable.  I liked these so much they went to a subscribe and save more mode.  The sealable pouch means they stay nice and fresh.

PROS:Compact design6 Separate Ink CartridgesSimple InterfaceGood photo qualityCONS:Limited paper storagePricySome of the plastic is flimsyThere is no real simple inexpensive printer solution for both photos, and black and white copies.Out of the boxThe un-boxing is fairly easy.  I thought this printer wasn't intuitive in putting this together.  There is a lot of tape, and you have to be very careful about pulling the tape off.  There are no additional cables but if you are going for wi fi you should be fine.  The power cord is the only item this comes with.You will need to remove items from the printer to get the six printer cartridges into the printer.DesignThe printer is what I would call light weight, but if you are buying this for your home, this should be sufficient.  I like the fact of that there are multiple printer cartridges because you can replace only what you need.  The LCD panel is nice, and designed as well.SetupI thought this was a bit tough.  Lots of tape, and lots of things that need to be moved.  I couldn't use the CD because I have a Mac Book Pro and it doesn't have a CD player.  So I had to download my driver.  It attached easily to my wireless network.PrintingThis printer dose do double sided printing.  I don't think it works well because the ink bleeds.  I use regular office paper.  I imagine that thicker paper may work better.  Photo reproduction is good.  I will still use services like Costco, or Walgreens when I want to print out multiple copies.SummaryI think this is a good printer, it is pricy, I think HP has less expensive options.  If you really like this brand or want to try double sided printing this may be a good option for you.

This book is a wonderful Make-Ahead cookbook.  What I have often found frustrating about these books, is typically they are crock-pot recipes only.  This book gives a lot of recipes for recipes that you can freeze.  This gives you a lot of flexibility in preparing food that you really can prepare ahead of time.One of the aspects that I really liked about this cookbook is that the recipes tend to be from scratch.  So often crock-pot recipes, and other recipes that you make ahead use a lot of items that are processed.  This cookbook has a lot of recipes that are from scratch.  This makes it in my opinion for more superior because the recipes are from real food ingredients.  So if you need to monitor fat, salt, and preservatives that you can customize the recipes.The recipes are tasty.  The recipes are well written, and I think you can get a lot of use out of this book .

I found this bread machine to work extremely well.  I think the design is quite nice, the menu buttons are easy to read.  The resulting bread is has a great texture, and it has three options when it comes to how dark you would like your crust.  I thought this was a nice feature.  This bread maker comes with a great recipe book that has a bunch of bread recipes for you to make.You can program the bread machine to start a loaf a bread at a certain time if you desire.  Also included are specific measuring cups that may make the bread making go easier.I do have other models that are more expensive, but I thought this model performed just as well.  I think that this bread machine will serve you well.  The loaves are wonderfully dense, and hearty.  I love the end product.

Seems like original product.  This charger works as well as the one that I got with my camera.  Only this one I am certain costs a lot less than what it would from Nikon.  Very happy with this purchase.

I have a Nest Thermostat and after much tinkering it worked well.  In fact I feel like I have saved money this year because of the thermostat's auto away feature.  I thought this thermostat was easy to set up, and it seems to work well right now.  i haven't had any false alarms.  I personally will not wire this unit into my house.  My house is already wired very extensively for fire, but what I didn't have was a carbon monoxide detector.  This feature I will use.I have read a lot of bad reviews on this product.  I tend to think that either you get people that with gush over products, or hate them on reviews.  So you may need to take that with a grain of salt.  My opinion on the Nest products is that in theory they are wonderful.  In practice, my results are a little mixed.

Statistics while simple in many of its concepts for me, I simply needed more questions with the answers to help me grasp it more.  This book 1,001 Practice Problems helps tremendously.  If you are hoping this book to be filled with concepts of statistics, it isn't.  It would make a great companion guide for the Statistics for Dummies, or even a Statistics textbook.What I really like about this book is that the problems are clear, and there are written answers with explanations written in the book.  The book does a good job of numbering every question, and numbering the answers.  The book is written in distinct chapters, but you do not have to go through the book sequentially if you only need to brush up in one or two areas of the book.

I have Corgi Mix who loves these treats.  She is up in years, and has been a senior for a long time, so I am always looking for something what can help ease her joints.  I saw that  the Natural Balance contains the same active ingredients as Dasuquin - chondroitin and glucosamine - I thought this would be a great treat to try.As soon as the bag was opened, I had a dog anxiously awaiting to try this treat.  In all fairness, I also had two kittens that wanted to see what was going on as well.These treats have an appealing aroma, taste and texture that dogs and kittens like. Everyone seemed to gobble up these treats quickly.I highly recommend Natural Balance Jumpin' Stix to people who have aged pets that want to make sure they are feeding them pet foods that are made in the USA.

I really like this scale.  It seems to be very easy to use, and it has a lot of nice built in features.  I really like this scale has a glass top and what appears to be no moving pieces.  This makes it very easy to clean.  So often when objects have lots of little parts dirt will get in there, and they ever really get clean again.  I like that this scale is glass because cleaning is a breeze.  Just wipe it off.It will tare for you, so if you set down a plate, you can tare the scale, which resets it to zero, and then you can measure it from zero.  So it makes it very nice.  The scale comes with batteries so you aren't searching for them when you want to get started with this scale.

# 2 in the "What Happens in Scotland" series, but can be read as a stand alone. A fun, sweet romance with a Scottish Blacksmith and a English Duke's sister as the main characters. Witty banter, passion, an unexpected marriage, searching for a misplaced fiance and finding true love, makes for an adventurous romp though the Scottish countryside.Well written tale with a true Romantic climax. The characters are engaging, witty, endearing, passionate and romantic. But the heroine must make some life changing decisions, can she give up her Scottish Blacksmith to do as her brother wishes and marry an Englishman instead? Or will true love win out and they find their HEA. A wonderful, fast paced story from beginning to end. An enjoyable and satisfying read! Fans of romance, Historical Scotland and England, will enjoy this story of love, passion and  acceptance. I absolutely adored this story! Great Scottish Romance!*Received for an honest review from the publisher via Net Gallery*Rating: 4.5Heat rating: MildReviewed by: AprilR, courtesy of My Book Addiction and More

#5 in the heart pounding "A Whisper of Scandal", but can be read as a stand alone.Fast paced, adventure filled with engaging and mesmerizing characters. The storyline is passionate, compelling, and intriguing. It has secrets, passion, a bit of mystery, add in some suspense, romance and what a story!Once again, Ms. Johnstone has written a story that is spellbinding, intriguing and simply mesmerizing! Fans of Historical Romance will be astounded, and thrilled as they turn from page to page. I personally, never tire of Ms. Johnstone's electrifying tales of Victorian Romance. She brings the story to life through the pages of a book!  A must read! Highly recommended for fans of Historical Romance, Suspense and mystery. Another awe-inspiring tale!*Received for an honest review from the author/publisher*Rating: 5Heat rating: MildReviewed by: AprilR, courtesy of My Book Addiction and More

#3 in the "Alex Halsey Mystery", while can be read as a stand alone, I would recommend reading in order. See, "Deadly Engagement" and "Deadly Affair".*Most of this story happens abroad, with another country's politics, and Civil War, in play.* Just let me say from the very start... this is a complicated, complex, compelling and powerful tale!!Fast paced, adventure filled tale, with danger, diplomatic intrigue, dark secrets, family,friendships, intrigue abroad, mystery, suspense with a touch of romance and a chance for second chances. A diplomatic mission with mild violence, a rescue mission and learning some deep dark secrets amongst Royalty, brings "Deadly Peril" to the forefront for any fan of Georgian Historical Romance. Not your run of the mill 18th century Historical Romance! Ms. Brant has written a powerful tale! The mystery and intrigue are intricately entwined with a complicated and absorbing plot. I absolutely loved "Deadly Peril", I was transfixed and transported to another era, where the characters are engaging, their stories raw,their love of family, friends and country are doubtless and constant at all cost including death, simply Powerful!!A dark and intriguing tale of secrets, danger, with the added vantage of political intrigue. Not a lot of romance but a few twists and turns are found, I was completely and surprised and in awe of this complex tale.  What a great privilege and joy to read. Finally, simply intriguing, with very complex characters, challenges and circumstances!!Oh, I do hope we see more stories from this tale. I would love to read more on some of these characters. An amazing story!! A must read. A definite keeper!! Highly recommended!*Received for an honest review from the author*Rating: 5Heat rating: Mild to Hot due to mild violenceReviewed by: AprilR, courtesy of My Book Addiction and More

A wonderful, sweet Regency Romance. A Novella filled with charm, passion, romance and love. Fast paced, quick read. Another awesome addition to the "World of de Wolfe Pack" collection. Heartwarming, with some amazing and enjoyable characters. A must read! While, a quick Novella, the author manages to convey her story to the reader. Fans of Historical Romance, "The World of de Wolfe Pack" collection, and Regency Romance will enjoy "Love's Legacy".  I absolutely adore Ms. Mariel's storytelling, her writing style and her unique way to telling a great, quick read.A sweet, heartwarming story. Strongly recommended!! A great afternoon read!*Personal buy *Rating: 5Heat rating: Sweet to MildReviewed by: April R, courtesy of My Book Addiction and More

WOW! A fast paced, action packed tale of strength, passion, loyalty and bravery. What a Historical comeback for Ms. Vane., who hasn't written a Historical Romance in a while. I absolutely loved everything about this tale from the characters to the storyline to the passionate embraces and yes, even the concept of enemies to lovers and beyond. Powerfully written, quick read. I read it in one setting. Highly recommended!! A must read! Once again, Ms. Vane will capture the reader and hold them in awe.  Fans of the "World of de Wolfe Pack", Historical Romance, romance in general will be entrenched, and lured into the world of "Breton Wolfe" and it's inhabitants. I can't wait for the next installment. Way to go, Ms. Vane!! Passionate, compelling and powerfully written!*Personal buy and/ or gifted copy*Rating: 5Heat rating: Mild to hotReviewed by: AprilR

An awesome  collection  of  12 Christmas  Brides, just in time for the holidays!  12 awesome  stories by 12 talented  storytellers. I absolutely  adored each and every story. It would be hard to pick a favorite story. Each author brought their own unique  writing  style to the collection.The characters  in each story were endearing,  engaging  and  believable.  I enjoy Christmas  stories and gotta say, these are an absolute  delight to  read. A must read for the upcoming Christmas  holidays.  A sweet, heartwarming  collection  of  Historical Romances.  An enjoyable  and satisfying read!* Personal Buy *Rating: 5Heat rating: SweetReviewed by: AprilR

A fun, heartwarming collection  of  stories! Very entertaining,  and Romantic  with witty dialog, bird lovers, and wonderful  secondary  characters  as well as the main characters.  A must read and a bomb for Historical  Romance  readers' souls. Each story can be read independently, in order, as stand alones, or all together, in one setting.  I would suggest  all in one setting. A simply delicious  collection, made for any and all romance fans. Well done!* Personal Buy *Rating: 5Heat rating: SweetReviewed by: AprilR

WOW!! Another awesome read  for Ms. Caldwell! Fast paced and exciting. A heartwarming  tale with a dark side. The characters are engaging, endearing, challenging and passionate. IME FOR A DUKE by Ruth J. Hartman is a sweet, quick, quirky, fun Regency Historical time romance. A Novella that is well worth the time to read.Well written with engaging,and charming characters. A welcome change from the routine Time Travel Romance. Set during the Regency Historical Romance era. This story has a 2012 American Heroine and a 1812 Duke Hero. Romantic drama at it's best! #2 in the "Wicked Trilogy", but can be read as a stand alone. I would also recommend reading Book 1, "His Wicked Reputation".  Once again, Ms. Hunter has written a seductive, intriguing tale with passion, romance,a bit of danger, some mystery, a bit of suspense and lots of love.  Well written tale with engaging, passionate, and lovable characters. I enjoyed the interaction between the H/H, how the family sticks together no matter the circumstances or the conquestances.Fast paced tale with plenty of action, adventure, romance and passion. Wickedly seductive! Once again, Ms. Hunter will mesmerize her fans with "Tall, Dark and Wicked". Highly recommended. A re-issue from the 1990's, but still an epic tale.An epic, and gripping love story that spans years. Filled with grief, tears, struggles, turmoil,pain, love and romance. #4 in this wonderful  series, but can be read a stand alone.  This "sin" is  gluttony.A quick read, one in which I thoroughly enjoyed. Hettie and Jasper, the H/H in this story, has alot to recommend  them, but can they find their HEA?Filled with steamy  sensual  scenes,  remorse, healing, redemption, romance and love with a bit of mystery  and lots of passion.9nce again, Ms. Holt has written  an intense, emotional  roller coaster, interesting  and satisfying read. #1 in the exciting "Warriors of York" series, a newly  revised and expanded version of Danger's Promise, previously released only in print.WOW! I adore Ms. Melton's Romantic Suspense, but gotta say, this Medeival adventure is FANTASTIC!!Fast paced, thrill ride of emotions with engaging, energetic and charismatic characters. The storyline is unique, well written, intriguing and very, very interesting. Filled with betrayal, secrets, suspense, redemption, forgiveness, healing, mystery, romance, passion and deception. I absolutely adored the heroine and the hero in this story. While the hero is nicknamed, "Slayer",Christian de la Croix(Simon), is so much more. The, heroine, "Clare", Clarisse du Boise, is made to be a  part of a  deception in order to save her family, that could possibly result in either her death and her family's peril or find Clare and Simon the love of a lifetime.A complex, compelling and powerful story! Ms. Melton has once again written a tale, where the reader with find themselves  entrenched and held spellbound to the pages of this story and it's characters. You can feel their pain, their frustrations and their love. The emotional turmoil just flows off the pages.A page turning tale from the first page to the last page! This rather choppy mystery set in the Falkland Islands with a nebulous ending is a risky departure for the author from previous novels involving the intriguing character Lacey Flint of the London police department. It is interesting to learn something of the lay of the land of this series of very isolated islands sitting off the very southeastern part of Argentina. The islands are hilly, craggy, windblown, mostly treeless with bogs and peat and hard to traverse in other than four wheel drive vehicles. And then there is the omnipresent sea. It all seems quite ominous.The story begins in Nov, 1994 with an eclipse of the sun pending and lifelong resident Catrin Quinn plotting revenge against her former best friend Rachael, who accidentally caused her two young sons to die three years prior. To complicate matters three other young boys have gone missing in those three years. Harbored suspicions are not held back when Catrin and her British ex-soldier friend Callum, who suffers from PTSD blackouts, happen to find the third boy alive. But if possible, things get worse when Rachaelâs youngest son vanishes.Basically, Catrin, Rachael, and Callum are put in a position where they have to confront their demons from the past and the present and hopefully the mysteries and reasons surrounding the boysâ deaths and disappearances will fall out of that resolution. The book seems a bit overdrawn as far as the psychological distresses and the mysteries recede as a result. Maybe a return to Flint is needed.

This rather sappy story is concerned with Becky Lynn, who escapes from small-town Mississippi and a very abusive past as a teenager to success in the world of fashion photography and modeling in southern California. Becky Lynn is likeable, unpretentious, yet determined, all of which she needs to be to survive in fast-paced, anonymous CA.Luckily, her interest in VOGUE as a youngster pays off when the fledgling photographer son of her CA beauty shop employer recognizes her eye for the perfect picture. Her new job as a photographerâs assistant throws her into the dog-eat-dog world of fashion and into the midst of several personal rivalries. Of course, sexual intrigue is also part of that world and Becky Lynn, oddly attractive, has her pursuers. And, in fact, her unusual looks are finally recognized and she becomes a leading model. Quite a turnaround for âwhite trashâ from Mississippi.The book is a quick, easy read and the fortunes of Becky Lynn hold oneâs attention.

Since this book is a widespread look into the anti-aging scientific world, one might expect a chapter by chapter approach that leads to a prescription for prolonging oneâs life. If that is the expectation, disappointment will follow. The author is a journalist, who examines seemingly a miscellaneous number of ideas held by scientists concerning particulars of body chemistry that detract or add to longevity. And then there is the debate as to whether people really will continue to get much older in the future, or are there biological limits in play?A few centenarians are introduced, but their age seems to be mostly luck, not due to a magic formula. Several persons the author meets take massive amounts of hormones and other chemical supplements, but again there is little proof that they work and could be harmful. Once through the book, one is mostly left with the fact that a sensible, moderate life in terms of consumption and exercise is the best bet against dying prematurely or possibly extending oneâs life.The book is a bit tedious, as the author drags out each of his chapters introducing a particular scientist and his or her insight into aging. Nonetheless, it is interesting to see where the research is on aging despite a good bit of ambiguity.

The incandescently beautiful Dominika Egorova, a mole for the CIA in Russiaâs security service, the SVR, returns in this fast-paced spy novel where she must use all of her wits and spy craft acumen to stay ahead of those who are determined to uncover the certainty of a mole in their midst.  She had returned to Russia a year or so ago in a spy swap only to be severely interrogated, which she managed to survive. Now, fully restored, she is providing information to both her Russian bosses and her CIA handlers regarding a high-tech seismic floor for the Iranians to stabilize the production of weapons grade materials. She has to be extremely careful in her reconnection with her main CIA handler and lover Nate Nash and likewise not raise the ire of her jealous Russian boss, Col. Zyuganov, a holdover from the KGB days.The story is ramped up when a disgruntled top CIA official in Washington under code name TRITON begins supplying information to the Russians. Of course, Dominika, gaining more and more standing in the SVR, learns of TRITON. It really is just a matter of time before TRITON learns of Dominika and exposes her, unless she can get to him first. The story has a certain edginess to it as Dominika must use guile and violence to keep out of the Russian torture chambers. Interestingly enough, Dominika becomes a favorite of Vladimir Putin, which gives her needed cover. Given his characterization by the author, it is doubtful that Putin would be a huge fan of the book.As in RED SPARROW, the author includes a lot of the nuts-and-bolts of spying, which is not surprising given his CIA background. If anything, this sequel is a tighter more compelling read than the first.

The author readily admits that his turning 70 and losing cycling capability are the motivators for this book. It is his claim, backed up by a good deal of evidence, that large declines in performance can be avoided with training and habits that counter physical changes in older athletes. Of the two essential elements of training, that is volume and intensity, it is intensity that must be emphasized to counter the effects of aging. And that is contrary to the advice often given that older athletes must take a long, slow approach to training.Of all the declines in athletes, it is the reduction of VO2-Max, the ability of an athlete to process oxygen that most severely limits performance. After describing that change and others common to aging athletes, for example gaining fat and losing muscle, the author introduces a rudimentary training plan to address those issues. Key to his plan is the inclusion of aerobic-capacity and lactate-threshold intervals of varying intensity and duration. In addition there are more conventional elements like longer aerobic threshold efforts and weightlifting. His plan is tailored for those in any endurance sport. Periodization of training is also discussed with the elements of training adjusted based on where one is in a racing cycle.The main point of the book, that is the emphasis on training intensity, is noteworthy. In so far as the author sticks to supporting and explaining that idea, the book is good. However, there is some redundancy and the inclusion of bits of miscellaneous testimony from older athletes does not add much. The author also veers into general health topics of the aged such as sleep, fat, insulin, and diet. The book is a corrective to the notion that people somehow have to substantially decline in old age.

The night lawyer is thirty-something Eleanor Porter, who at night screens the content of a London tabloid to keep them out of legal trouble. Ellie is supposed to be a sympathetic character who has pulled herself together after being hospitalized in a psychiatric ward after a traumatic breakup with her married lover Will. And she has other issues, namely, that of her father suddenly dying when she was eight for which she takes the blame.Yet, she has the determination to become a lawyer and steadily advance through a manâs world of karate. She shows no fear in traversing the transportation systems and streets of London when she leaves work late at night. But now she becomes more and more certain that she is being stalked by an older man, who seems vaguely familiar. And Will reenters the scene.This story simply does not resonate as it consists of endless trips back and back to work with Ellie obsessing about her issues past and present. One hardly knows how to take her. Is she a strong survivor or is she a weak sister? Her willingness to be victimized again overwhelms what few mysteries are in the story.

The ex-pat community of 1920s Paris is known for being a home to many literary giants of the 20th century, but this book is a grim, realistic look at how the other half lived. The British Marya, a sometimes chorus girl, has been living in Paris with her con-man, Polish husband for a while. But when his racket is discovered, he is sentenced to jail leaving Mayra to basically fend for herself with scarcely a franc to her name.Fortuitously, or not, she meets an English couple who invite her stay in a small room in their apartment. Her life consists of endless outings to cafes, seedy bars, restaurants, and great deal of drinking. More significantly, she is virtually forced to become entangled in their rather antagonistic psychological games. The wife encourages Marya to take up with her husband and then makes life uncomfortable when she does. Eventually her husbandâs release from prison has to be filtered into this distressing situation.The book is basically a brief and bleak look at the miserableness of dead-end lives and the vulnerability, especially of women, of those with no resources to get their heads above water. The end for such people usually is not good. The atmospherics of the book are unrelenting in capturing the entire situation.

This novel, considered to be a classic and set in the early 20th century, is a tragic story of two well-to-do couples, one American and the other English, who spend a good deal of time together in Europe just before WWI. The entire story is told from the perspective of John Dowell, the American husband, as he roams back and forth over the thirteen years that they were together. According to Dowell, they were all âgoodâ people, always able to affect impeccable public behavior, keep a stiff upper lip, etc. But the marriages were not what they seemed. The book is basically a long, distressing examination of their unraveling, the attempts to paper over the cracks, and the tragic consequences.The story can be tedious and trying as Dowell freely skips around in time and locale, although in actually he is telling the story after the fact. The characters are not particularly appealing, but they do garner sympathy as the inevitability that matters will not end well for them permeates the narrative. Given the date of the novel it is an amazingly open exploration of the slipperiness of human affairs.

Kat McCall, ten years before a very rebellious teenager, was an easy target for the police to try to pin the brutal murder of her older sister Sara, Katâs legal guardian, on. Luckily, she escaped conviction in a trial and moved to Portland and became a successful operator of bakeries. Now, ten years later, she is back in Louisiana seeking justice for Sara. To say that she is unwelcome is an understatement: the threats, both verbal and physical, begin immediately and the old police chief cannot contain his antagonism. She is obviously making one or more persons very nervous.Fortunately for Kat, Police Sgt Luke Tanner, the son of the chief, responds to her first call of vandalism at her sisterâs old home because they definitely connect. Over the next few weeks they uncover evidence, especially the whereabouts of various people that had been ignored years before. It turns out that there is no shortage of plausible suspects and they are faced with the unexpected task of eliminating most of them.The story is fast-paced and the interest level is high if for no more than wanting to find out who in a small town would brutally murder a very likeable high school teacher. Itâs always easy to nitpick the believability factor in mysteries. In this case, there are plenty of stupid and inept actions taken but all are within limits of credibility. The characters are not particularly well-developed. For example, we really have no clear idea as to Katâs appearance. However, another well-constructed mystery by this author.

There is no doubt that the book's subtitle is a substantial overstatement, but the authors' enthusiasm must be seen in the context that few even know that Washington used a spy network in New York, let alone the very real risks that those spies took. In New York, which was under British control virtually the entire War, those with Patriot and Loyalist sympathies lived side-by-side with their true feelings often well-concealed; doubtlessly, suspicions of others ran high. Spying was truly risky business; spies were subject to being hanged.New York was the center of British operations during the War and was an obsession for Washington; he hated being forced out in 1776 and always looked for ways to make inroads back into the city. He needed timely and reliable information concerning British military activities â he needed reliable spies. In 1778 Washington tasked Major Benjamin Tallmadge to come up with a facilitator and recruiter for a spy network. This is the best part of the book: the identification and recruitment of six individuals who had the disposition to be spies and their general manner of gathering and delivering information. There is a noticeable lack of specifics about what was observed, but it seems that hardly any of the information was earthshaking; actually it was fairly ordinary, a lot of it just bits and pieces overheard in coffeehouses. It is debatable as to how much essential help was actually provided. The authors include the Benedict Arnold saga in the book, but the ties to the spy ring are virtually non-existent.A lot of the book is filled with conversations that the authors simply create to make the story flow, which could be rather disconcerting to those who want their history to be strictly fact-based. They do utilize records and letters recorded and written by some of the spies and even Washington. Also quite interesting are the steps that were taken to conceal the identities of the spies, even from Washington, the use of codes and invisible ink, and the circuitous routes of transporting the materials. Only one of the spies was uncovered during the War, the one female of the group, who to this day remains unidentified. Some of the spies only became known in the 20th century.This book does fill a gap that is pretty much missing from most histories of the Revolutionary War. It took a lot of sacrifices to defeat the superior forces of the British and this book chronicles just another example of that.

Detective Lacey Flint of the London police is just now recovering from a harrowing case where a Jack-the-Ripper wannabe also targeted her. As tough as she is, Lacey also harbors many demons. When a series of alleged suicides occur at Cambridge over several years, Lacey is selected to become an undercover student. But is she the right pick? Is she not too vulnerable at this point in her life? Can she remain a neutral observer as her instructions dictate or will she follow her instincts and allow herself to be drawn into the case to a point of no return?Lacey has to sort through some pretty grim stuff in her off the record investigation; some very sinister, knowing forces must be at work. As she gets more involved, one wonders whether Detective Mark Joesbury, her on-again-off-again boyfriend, will be able to extricate her from what will inevitably be a precarious situation?The story feels a little choppy and a bit farfetched. But the author has created a plucky, interesting character in Lacey Flint. As always, it is her thinking that is of most interest.

This novel of historical fiction is basically a vehicle for the author to explore the changing mores of mid-twentieth century America and the pressures to conform to traditional values. Louise Brooks, the silent film star of the 1920s, is a key character, but the story actually revolves around Cora Carlisle, a married woman from Wichita, KS, who chaperones Louise on a trip to NYC to attend a dancing school.Louise, the amazingly beautiful daughter of a disinterested, avant-garde mother, even at age fifteen flaunts all conventions regarding dress, appearance, bold behavior, etc. Cora has the thankless task of keeping all of that under control while in NYC. But in a strange turn in this story, it is Cora who in NYC embarks on a life of discovery and handling socially delicate situations. Coming to Kansas on a train as an orphan many years before, Cora has to this point led a fairly quiet, conventional life, although with one dark secret.From this point, such issues as homes for unwed mothers, adoption of orphans, prohibition, homosexuality, marital arrangements, contraception, civil rights, etc will impact her directly or indirectly. Cora, despite her modest and trying beginning, is portrayed as a compassionate woman capable of changing her views. In many cases, she is forced to make changes for her own survival. While Cora is a likeable character, it may be a stretch to imbue her with such a large capacity for progressive thought and action. Also, it is a little disappointing that Louise recedes in importance in this story despite her intriguing personality.

Lots of trauma in the authorâs novels: Detective Lacey Flint, victims, co-workers, and others. Lacey is on leave from a special unit of the London police after a harrowing undercover experience at Cambridge and is not doing well, having to exercise herself to death to escape her demons. Secondly, someone is killing young boys in London and leaving them to be found with their throats cut, drained of all blood, but no other injuries.But the leading character in this mystery is eleven-year-old Barney, a neighbor of Laceyâs and observant beyond his years. His mother has been missing for years, his father too has some kind of disappearing act going on, and he happens to live in the area where the kids are dying. It is his obsession, and possible connection, with the murders that eventually draws a reluctant Lacey into the case.Itâs not just her reluctance that must be overcome: she is on the outs with her boss Detective Dana Tulloch and her relationship with fellow detective Mark Joesbury is muddled.  When matters take a far worse turn, Lacey has to jump in with typical bravado, throwing caution to the wind.Lacey is a good character for the author, although after three novels she seems a little stuck in her hang-ups and relationships. The author keeps things moving, but in this case the plot is a little thin and ultimately falls on the unbelievable side. Capturing the thinking of Lacey continues to be the strength of the series.

This overly long novel is definitely maudlin with an oft-told plot, but the author in the end brings it around with an intense, moving ending. Teenage Katie, bookish, plain, and mostly friendless, one day finds a stunning, new girl Tully from a broken home waiting at her bus stop. No way should they be friends, but that is exactly what they become with Tully leading the way: sneaking out at night to ride widely around town on their bikes and generally pushing the envelope of Katieâs mom.Tully decides that they will be famous reporters and they both get jobs on the edge of the TV news business during college. But Katie cannot match Tullyâs ambition and ability to exploit every opportunity. They remain close, but distant, friends as Tully becomes famous as a TV journalist, while Katie marries and has three children. There are cracks in their relationship, but all is smoothed over whenever they meet. An issue that grows larger every year is Katieâs oldest daughterâs infatuation with Tully. Eventually the cracks become a chasm which seems too large for their teenage pact of forever friendship to overcome.It is hardly unusual that teenage friendships falter for any number of reasons. Tully and Katie are pretty stereotypical characters and much different. It is as much the lure of Katieâs family for Tully that keeps them together as anything. Ultimately they face a make or break moment that will finally define who they are collectively and singularly. The author plays the melodrama card well.

Beginning in the prairies of 1930s in the midst of the Great Depression and the ecologically damaging Dust Bowl, this is a book of devastation, desperation, and survival, but eventually shifting to more hopeful possibilities. The story is told by Lila, a young girl now maybe in her early twenties, who was essentially abandoned by her family at a very young age during hard times, but rescued by a hard-nosed drifter female named Doll, who carried a very sharp knife that she used when required. Their existence is pure hardscrabble, always on the move looking for work and/or food. Eventually Lila has to fend for herself, never forgetting the kindness of the tough Doll.Again on the move, that is the background of Lilaâs arrival in Gilead, Iowa where she takes up residence in an abandoned shack on the edge of a river, but also seeks refuge in a country church where sixty-something John Ames is preaching. It is a case of the lonely meeting the lonely. Ames lost his wife and son forty years prior and is smitten by Lila. Just out of the blue, she suggests that he marry her and despite her almost indifference, it happens.The remainder of the book has Lila pondering her new life where basic needs are met and her life is shared with a kindly old preacher. Having basically adopted Dollâs no nonsense view of life, Amesâs constant praying and religious interpretations of life donât resonate with Lila, but she shows remarkable adaptability and ability to dialog with Ames given her bleak history.The story is vaguely told. Lilaâs background is more suggested than described, and there is a good bit of skipping around among various scenarios from her past. The day-to-day details of her current life with Ames are also minimally drawn. What we see are really two rather unsettled people who are coping with serious issues in their pasts and are unsure how to move ahead. The reader is left wondering just who is this Lila?

This ânuts and boltsâ spy story by a former officer of the CIA shows the complexity of recruiting and maintaining âmolesâ in sensitive areas in a foreign country, the intricacies of everyday spy-craft, and the immense pressure and danger that are always present for spies. This story is concerned primarily with the lengths to which the top spy agencies of the US and Russia will go to find a mole buried within their own governments.The incandescently beautiful Dominika Egorova, the niece of a Russian spy agency director, has been extensively trained to recruit foreign spies using her wits and her physical charms. Her first target: Nathaniel Nash, a CIA operative who has been identified as being the contact person for the US spy MARBLE within the Russian government. But that can work both ways. Can Dominika be recruited by Nate? A real cat-and-mouse game ensues in the Finish city of Helsinki, as Nate and Dominika size each other up, looking for possibilities and vulnerabilities. But this fairly self-contained operation soon explodes involving more people, different locales, violence, and unanticipated outcomes.The amount of detail in the book makes it both interesting, as well as, at times, slightly confusing and tedious. The myriad strange Russian names and the number of agencies, directorates, centers, and the like require a certain amount of backtracking. Probably reflective of the authorâs many postings, he provides glimpses of local cultures, including food, as the story shifts among locales. Most of the characters are believable, though perhaps the author could have done more with Dominika and Nate, while leaving out her supposed ability to read others by associating a color with their persona. The plot does start to strain believability in its sudden developments and harrowing close encounters. One wonders if Dominika will resurface after a return to the bowels of the Russian spy service.

There is no doubt that figuring who one is and wants to become is a very difficult task for teenagers with a lot of room for getting it wrong or slipping, especially without decent guidance from adults and family. Grace, living in small Garland, TN and coming from a dysfunctional family, sees attaching herself to the popular Riley Graham, a classmate, and the well-to-do Graham family as the avenue to a better life; and they become inseparable. It seems like a good plan, but itâs a naïve plan and Graceâs idyllic life begins to unravel.First, Graceâs attendance at NYU creates some cracks in her relationship with Riley and upon a return to Garland she comes up with a scheme involving Riley to rob an historical site of antiques. Hence the authorâs opening scene: Grace is living in Paris under an assumed name as an antique restorer as she escaped from Garland letting Riley and his pals suffer the consequences. But now they have been paroled after three years; she knows they are not happy with her. How worried should she be?The story alternates between Garland, building to her ultimate departure, and Europe where Grace has had to live by her wits, including enduring some unpleasantness and dangers. The story is not without its appeal and edginess, but Grace is not consistently drawn. At times she seems very tough and resourceful, but then comes across as quite naÃ¯ve, vulnerable, and even unknowable. Actually, she is very vaguely described. How her life plays out seems muddled and not quite believable. Ultimately, she is a rather unappealing character.

While the death by assassination of Pres James Garfield in 1881 is the main focus of this book, the author also provides some insight into some of the elements of American society in the early 1880s. Garfield, born into extreme poverty, survived a near death experience while working on a canal as a young man to become a very learned man, president of a college, a Civil War general, and a member of US Congress. Garfield, a robust man with a pleasing personality and gift for oratory, was the compromise candidate out of the Republican convention in 1880, going on to edge a weak Democratic candidate for the Presidency.The 1870s and 80s were times of considerable political corruption, where political offices were often seen as means to reward political loyalists. It is this system that ultimately harmed Garfield. Vagabond Charles Guiteau, a failure in all of his endeavors and a petty thief, repeatedly intruded on the offices of Garfield and Sec of State James Blaine, insisting that he should be given an ambassadorship. Rejected at all turns, he decided that only Garfieldâs death would permit any such appointment.From todayâs perspective, an era of science and security, the authorâs description of the scenario around Garfield is almost impossible to comprehend. Despite Lincolnâs assassination a mere fifteen years prior, Garfield had absolutely no security detail. He literally walked around Washington at will. Secondly, the ineptitude of the American doctors in that time can scarcely be believed. The American medical community rejected as ridiculous the advances that European doctors made concerning sterile environments, finding concern about germs to be pure silliness.Led by the pompous Dr. Willard Bliss, the doctors surrounding Garfield gave no thought to probing his wounds with their unwashed hands. Bliss kept Garfield isolated and pronounced that he was improving despite the drainage of vile liquids and the loss of nearly 100 lbs. An autopsy revealed that Garfield had massive infections throughout his body. Had he never been touched, Garfield probably would have lived, as were thousands of Civil War veterans walking around with musket balls in them.  It can be  noted that even today tens of thousands die each year in the US from the introduction of infections by healthcare facilities.The author, strangely enough, devotes considerable time to the efforts of Alexander Bell, the inventor of the telephone, to devise a crude instrument to detect metal in a patient once he learned of Garfieldâs wounds. All of that was too little, too late for Garfield. It is the remarkable strength of character of both Garfield and his wife Lucretia that stands out in the authorâs story. Interestingly, Vice Pres Chester Arthur gained a measure of respect after Garfieldâs death by rejecting the influence of former New York Senator Roscoe Conkling.The book is not without interest, but it seems like an overdrawn overview with a good deal of repetition. Her story is really rather simple: âGood guy president is shot by a nut and his doctors finished him off.â

Set in the North Georgia mountains in the mid-1960âs, this haunting, but improbable, story brings together two much damaged, needy persons into a loving, volatile, and ultimately flawed relationship. Katherine Reid, an advertising executive and nearly forty, after a diagnosis of a terminal illness, buys a very remote, barebones cabin to live out her remaining days in utter simplicity and isolation. Little does she know that Danny MacLean, a twenty-something traumatized Vietnam vet with a very troubled past, is squatting in an even more inhabitable cabin near hers.Katherine actually begins to thrive in her spartan existence while Dannyâs concealed observation of her becomes an obsession. Their initial meetings are quite tentative, but soon hesitation gives way to a relationship that is both intensely physical and controlling. Of course, this headlong rush into intimacy will eventually have to deal with all of the psychological issues that have been lurking.There is a lot to like about this book. The author definitely captures the difficulties and perils of a remote, restricted life. While it is hard to imagine Katherine as a mountain woman, one can understand that these two damaged people in this setting could be inclined to cling to one another in an almost death-like grip. The real question is what can/will happen long term?

This murder mystery set in London introduces Detective Lacey Flint, as she is part of a team desperately trying to capture a killer of women who operates in the manner of and sends notes evocative of the Jack-the-Ripper, while she has to contend with and keep hidden a troubled past. Disturbingly, the killer seems to be taunting and stalking Lacey.Lacey is a tough nut, a little hard to figure out, and tends to indulge in risky behavior. For example, she frequents places where hook-ups are possible and follows through on that. An intriguing part of the story is her relationship with Scotland Yard undercover officer Mark Joesbury, who is drawn to Lacey but strongly suspects that she is withholding information on the case.The pacing of the story gets a bit slow at times, but the unknowns lurking around the corner keep the pages turning. Eventually identities and connections are revealed, which may be important as the Lacey Flint series moves on.

This well-told story examines the fallout when traditional family bonds and moralities are broken. Subhash and Udayan are two brothers, born in the 1940s of Calcutta, India, whose lives take dramatic turns that leave them and others grasping for understanding. It is Udayanâs political radicalism that triggers an entire sequence of painful events, including Subhashâs permanent departure for the US, which are played out over several decades.Most of the story occurs in Rhode Island, where Subhash earned a PhD and now does research. But the constant undertow of his life is his need to deal with the detritus of his familyâs breakup and his brotherâs self-destructiveness. The question that lingers is can a new balance be achieved?

This rather uninspired murder mystery, set in Eugene, OR, revolves around the moral fanaticism of a parental/church group and the reality of sexual experimentation of their middle school children. A teen club that meets once a week to supposedly discuss religion has far more going on, resulting in several girls going to a clinic for STDs. And then one of them turns up dead in a dumpster just hours after the clinic is bombed.Eugene police detective Wade Jackson is stymied, although he has leads that point to a higher up in city hall. It is Kera, a nurse and counselor at the clinic, who expands Det Jacksonâs view of the cases: the bombing and the murder. And it appears that Kera is also a target.The book is actually somewhat irritating because of the number of characters who engage in the classic stupidity of moral fanatics. Such people are blind to realities and the harm that they cause indirectly and indifferent to the harm that they cause directly. Kera and Det Jackson are moderately appealing but really cannot rescue the book.

This rambling, vague novel follows the life of Philip Bowman, a Navy vet of WWII, as a book editor at a small NYC publishing firm and in his attempts at connectivity with a procession of attractive women. Philip is an ephemeral character: he travels to Europe, goes to chic parties, meets authors, becomes involved with any number of women â yet he remains largely unknowable.His urbane manner and good looks are definitely sellable to women. However, despite the intensity of his relationships, they all seem to fizzle over time. In one strange scenario, Philip turns to the twenty-something daughter of one of his ex lovers with unpredictable results.The book and Philip Bowmanâs world are not without interest. It is a cultured world of intelligent, successful people. The writing is observant and sensual. Eventually, there is the realization that nothing of any significance is going to happen.

The dedicated, wily veteran detective Harry Bosch of the recently revamped LAPD's Open-Unsolved Unit and his newly assigned partner Detective Lucia Soto have a case that is both old and new. Orlando Merced, the leader of a mariachi band, was shot and paralyzed ten years ago in a plaza where bands go to get gigs, the bullet lodging in his spine. Now, Merced has died from blood poisoning from the projectile. Because former mayor Armando Zeyas used Merced as a poster boy in his campaign to fight crime, the LAPD has come under pressure to solve this case.All who know the crusty Bosch from previous books, know that he leaves no stone unturned when digging for evidence and that he works the police process as well as anyone, having connections in all of the right places. In this case, Bosch thinks that everyone may have it wrong. Careful analysis of the crime scene seems to suggest that Merced was not the target in the shooting, and that the path leads to some well-connected, powerful people.Parallel to this case, Lucia has been secretly digging into the Bonnie Brae apartment fire of twenty years ago; it was a case of arson and she, herself, as youngster in that building, barely survived.  Harry agrees to assist Lucy, and discovers, strangely enough, that another crime on the date of the fire appears to be connected to that case. Ordinarily Harry would be soundly rebuked by the higher-ups for letting his attention be diverted, but this is another politically sensitive case which would make the captain look good if it was solved.The book is fairly consistent with previous Harry Bosch books, although his tolerance for newbie Lucy is a little out of character. One learns the streets of LA as Bosch drives among all of the law enforcement agencies, meets his contacts, and interviews witnesses and suspects. Characters from previous books make nominal appearances, including his teen-age daughter Maddie and an old flame from the FBI Rachael Walling. However, the author gives us very little of Bosch's personal life in this book. How to work a case and the education of Detective Soto take center stage. A quibble with the book is the rather muddled ending of the two cases. In addition, at the end a charge by a police official that Harry violated police procedures looks contrived.

In this fourteenth book of the series, Kate Shugak, a pint-sized, native Alaskan investigator and resident of a vast wilderness called the Park, shifts the locus of her work to Anchorage to investigate a thirty-year-old case of possible wrongful conviction. Geography is not the only change in Kate this time around. Never before has she been willing to use her lithe, athletic, and sexy body to virtually paralyze and overwhelm a tough Alaskan trooper.Kate is skeptical when an exquisitely decked out, middle-aged socialite Charlotte insists that her mother Victoria was wrongfully accused and convicted of setting the family home on fire in which one son died and another was permanently injured in jumping from a window. Working with practically no evidence, Kate's quest takes her among the movers and shakers of Alaskan society, but more importantly seems to be worrying someone. People she wants to talk to or has talked to start turning up dead or hurt.The book is fast-paced with an interesting plot that is solvable for the highly observant. Somewhat disconcertingly, secondary characters appear briefly or are mentioned who have been defined in some of the earlier books. The Alaskan landscape, prominent in earlier books, is scarcely mentioned in this book. In addition, while Kate is a force to be reckoned with, in a couple of scenarios she exhibits physical powers in dealing with bad guys that are more like Wonder Woman than a real person. As always, a large half-wolf mutt Mutt is a formidable companion for Kate.

If one needs more evidence that girls from broken homes and squalid environments are likely headed for lives with unhappy consequences, this is your book. In this case, the story is of two high school girls: Baby Girl is the tough, punker chick with a shaved head, glaring lipstick, and dressed in her brotherâs clothes, while Perry is the looker who generally defers to Baby Girl. Perry lives with her prison-guard stepdad and her once-pretty mother, now a boozer. Baby Girl lives with her uncle and brain-damaged older brother.These girls are trouble. Their favorite activity is to go carousing in the wee hours of the night: stealing cars for joy rides, drinking, and committing petty theft. Theyâre no better in school with their sleep-deprived disruptiveness. But there is a palpable sense that their obnoxious behavior and boldness will eventually have serious consequences.Theyâve both been carrying on a text message dialog with a mysterious âJamey,â supposedly a high school student. Though not boy crazy, neither rejects male attention, especially the striking Perry. However, on a rainy night, their pasts, attitudes, and naivetÃ© all come together in a shocking meeting with the shadowy Jamey. Now where do they turn?While the sleazy nature of trailer park living is hardly unknown, the author gets it perfectly. Unfortunately, the story moves surely and inevitably to a conclusion that, while not necessarily predictable, is completely consistent with having lived in an environment where a turn for the worse is far more likely than realizing oneâs potential.

In this fourth installment of the Frank Bascombe series, Frank, the authorâs alter ego, is sixty-eight and is now having to seriously confront the ebbing away of his life to this point. Those familiar with Frank in the authorâs three previous novels know him to be quite likeable but cautious and wary with a sense that the other shoe is ready to drop.In this collection of four pieces, Frank hasnât changed much, but he is if anything even more philosophical and seeing and resigned. He constantly points out convenient fictions that govern much behavior - even his own. Interestingly, appreciating that his life is in decline seems to instill an overriding calmness in Frank in his dealings with others.The stories take place in Nov and Dec of 2012 in New Jersey, where hurricane Sandy has just wreaked massive destruction. In âIâm Here,â Frank is placed in the awkward position of meeting a man to whom he sold a now destroyed seaside mansion years ago. While the loss of property is certainly dramatic, Frank is far more chagrined with the manâs artificial appearance after plastic surgery. In âThe New Normal,â Frank visits his ex-wife in an up-scale nursing home, while understandingly reviewing their attraction and decline.While it is interesting to revisit Frank Bascombe and his unfiltered view of life, the rather disconnected scenarios in this book do not have the appeal of the better plotted previous books.

This often vacuous, melodramatic, and tedious novel is concerned with the behavior of a recovering, forty-year-old divorcee. Stella has figured out how to read and seduce men, which she uses to satisfy her desires as she flies around the country on weekends targeting men in airport hotels and bars. Though Stella is reasonably attractive, the author shares nothing of her background suggesting a predilection for or a belief in her one night stands. Secondly, the avoidance of disease, violence, and other complications seems wishful.And then suddenly â too suddenly â one of the men becomes more than a one-nighter. The melodrama is ratcheted up considerably as the gory, traumatic details of their pasts, including needy ex-spouses and children, intrude on this supposed love affair. Although there are plenty of graphic details of Stellaâs encounters, the characters donât have enough appeal to carry the book. There really is no plot. The best thing about this book is that it ends.

Think a life cannot be ruined in a heartbeat? Matt Hunter, a college student, comes to the rescue of a pal being beaten up at a drunken party, but accidentally kills someone. A jury, showing no mercy, sends him away for several years to a prison for hardened criminals. Never again will he view life the same. Now, ten years later, he is married to the beautiful Olivia and works as a paralegal at his brother's law firm, but Matt retains a perpetual wariness. No wonder - he is buying a house in his old neighborhood, but a town cop lets him know that he is not welcome. His past is not going away.Sure enough, Matt's newfound life does not last. Olivia, supposedly out of town on business, seems to send him a video of her in a hotel room with an unknown man. This is the start of a great unraveling of his life that ripples far and wide. It turns out that Olivia, who Matt met one weekend in Las Vegas while in college, also has a past that she would like to forget, but this time there are some serious, dangerous implications.The story quickly gets rather involved, extending back to Las Vegas and even reaching into a Catholic school in New Jersey. With several people turning up dead, Matt and Olivia have to go into full-on scramble mode to keep their pasts from burying them, while trying to come out the other end alive. The story threatens to derail at a few convoluted points, but actually is fairly interesting and manages to hang on by a slender plausible thread. Matt, being a sympathetic character keeps the reader's interest to the end, but most interesting is the stunning, Amazonian investigator Cingle. The author is known for creating transfixing secondary characters.

In this short mystery set in the barren wilds of Alaska, the tough, thirty-something investigator Kate Shugak is introduced. She has been asked by her ex-boss based in the Anchorage DAâs office to track down a missing park ranger and an investigator sent earlier to find the ranger. Frankly, the plot is really not well developed and is both rather simplistic and jumbled.Kate lives a hermetic existence on the edge of a huge national park in a very tidy setting after suffering a traumatic injury over a year before. The atmospherics of Alaskan living almost dominates the book: the conditions are trying and dangerous. In addition, the book is more sociological than mystery. The conflicts between âgreeniesâ (environmentalists), âoutsidersâ (non- Alaskans), and native Alaskans, in addition to the animosities between those who want to make the national parks tourist friendly and those who want to keep control with profit in mind permeate most of the interactions.At this point Kate lacks definition and is a little rough around the edges. In fact, all of the characters seem a bit too far on the quirky side. It is doubtful that the Alaskan tourism industry would recommend this book. There is promise in the book but needs to be tightened up.

This short mystery set in the rural, coastal town of Binnacle Bay is an entertaining and fast-paced read with a well-devised plot and interesting and/or shadowy characters. Much to Chief of Police Pat Fitzlaffâs dismay, he finds well-respected architect Gus Murdoch shot dead in his secluded cabin and his wife Sasha is missing. There are no clues, but there is a crumpled note in Gusâ hand from Sasha giving her itinerary from the previous day. And a large, friendly dog of mysterious origin is found on the scene.The likeable Fitzlaff immediately encounters resistance in his investigation. The mayor wants a quick resolution â any will do â to save the townâs reputation for tourism, and several others seem to be lying or have a shaky past. Pat, who has a history with Sasha, canât dismiss the possibility that Sashaâs nosey journalism may have gotten her in trouble.Pat, an ex-Marine, has a certain rugged appeal and attracts female attention, although the author seems reluctant to pursue that path. However, it is his calm command of the situation plus an ability to think out of the box that enables Pat to move assuredly to a resolution that he did not expect. The authorâs descriptive powers also bear mentioning. The mist-shrouded landscape, the crashing sea, and the dense forests most definitely contribute to the feeling of danger lurking.

Set in Sydney, this somewhat suspenseful novel involves the fallout of the actions and interconnections of a group of students and young adults that occurred over twenty years ago. Now, nearing middle-age, these various individuals are hard-pressed to keep their lives from disintegrating as the past re-enters their lives.What happens is that Ceciia Fitzpatrick, married to John-Paul, inadvertently finds a letter that he wrote many years ago that is to be opened upon his death.
