His strange, distant behavior of late compels her to read the letter. The letter undermines the very basis of their marriage, but even she does not fully understand the reach of the letter. In another thread, Tess is astounded to learn that her husband Will and her cousin Felicity have fallen in love with each other. And Rachael has never come to terms with the strangulation murder of her daughter Janie in those earlier years. All of these lives will again intersect in trying circumstances.Getting past the melodrama of the book, the story is not without its insights into the regrets and ramifications of the actions of individuals. Furthermore, there is the inherent difficulty of really knowing others and how to respond to them. However, the characters are not particularly appealing. Most seem overly self-absorbed and wounded, but manage to stumble into the future.

The story of the very sudden appearance of a 75,000 person city just west of Knoxville in the mid-1940's is not well known and this book certainly is not without merit in the telling of the story, but its execution leaves one grasping for a good understanding of the background of the entire project and many details of what occurred at Oak Ridge.Once the US realized that an atomic bomb was possible and could immediately terminate WWII, the need to produce the all important isotope of uranium for the bomb became imperative. A very secure place was needed for a huge complex of sophisticated facilities. The first priority was the accelerated construction of several massive factories, but of equal importance was the hiring of tens of thousands people almost overnight and providing adequate infrastructure, including streets, housing, food, etc. The people needed ranged from construction workers, clerks, operators, and janitors to nurses, doctors, and thousands of technical and scientific personnel. To personalize the story, the author selects a few representative women to follow, but, for the most part, they are only minimally captured.Several aspects of the Clinton Engineer Works CEW (Oak Ridge) are repeated over and over in the author's story. First is the incredible security surrounding the entire project. Virtually no one knew why they were there. Most performed a very circumscribed task. Badges permitted entry only to one's work place. Everyone was prohibited from discussing any aspect of their job with anyone: fellow workers, roommates, family, etc. And there were tons of undercover people to enforce those strictures. Many people were escorted out of the facility for talking too much. Perhaps they said the word "uranium"? However, there was a justified fear of spies. Later it was discovered that spies did infiltrate the CEW.In addition, the living conditions were atrocious. The sudden carving of a city out of the earth left a lot to be desired. The Southern afternoon rainstorms made walking almost impossible; those who tried frequently sunk to their knees in gooey muck. The housing for many was crowded pre-fab huts. There was onerous male-female separation, even among the married. Of course, Oak Ridge being in the South, there was racial segregation. Most of the women that the author profiles got used to the conditions; the pay that was much better than could be made in local businesses helped considerably. The conditions and restrictions did create a lot stress. In the modern era probably half of the workforce would be under the care of a psychologist, but there were few such options for the workers of Oak Ridge.The dropping of the two bombs on Japan in early Aug, 1945 came as a shock to the workers of the CEW. They literally had no idea that they were producing the key part of the Gadget (bomb) that was being made in Los Alamos, NM. As the author shows, many did not know whether to be thrilled or horrified. While part of the CEW remained operational and does to this very day, the facility shrunk to one half of its size and most of the workers returned to their previous homes.The Oak Ridge story is both quaint and almost hard to believe. Unfortunately, in this case, its telling is a bit trying. The story is often repetitious, tedious, and scattershot. One suspects that there has been much left unsaid in regard to details and perspective.

In the modern era there seems to be no limits to the deceptions that can be perpetrated on the Internet. Internet dating, virtually by definition, heads the list; everyone presents an imagined self. But things can get far more sinister. How about creating a totally false profile with a borrowed picture and then attracting persons for purposes of criminal intent? That is exactly the scenario that NYPD detective Kat Donavan stumbles into. Her finance from eighteen years ago seems to be staring at her on a dating site. She finally gets the nerve to email him. But he has no idea who she is; how can that be?Kat has a lot going on in her life. At the same time as the dating site snafu, the supposed killer of her father, a former NYPD policeman, is dying in prison eighteen years after being convicted. The problem is that she does not believe that he did it; his death will close that door forever. In addition, she gets a call from a teenage hacker who is upset that Kat is talking to the guy on the Internet who also happens to be dating his mother. Matters soon get rather complicated, even threatening.There are a lot of threads in this fast moving mystery. It is a juggling act, but slowly the author connects a lot of disparate people and events ranging over eighteen years. Kat is an appealing main character. There is enough plausibility in what happens to keep the reader's interest. Also, the story plays on fears of never really fully knowing just who one is dealing with on the other end of an Internet connection.

A subject that gets relatively little attention is what anyone believed a new American would look like after declaring independence from England in 1776. It actually took twenty-five years for that question to be somewhat resolved largely due to the huge influences of Jefferson and Hamilton in the 1790s who were the leaders of the two main political factions of the day, that is, the Federalists and the Democratic-Republicans. It is still debated as to which of those two most represents what America has become.Winning the war against England was foremost in the minds of the colonists in the late 1770sâ and early 80s; frankly there wasnât time for a coherent national policy. Yet there were serious cracks in the new United States that begged for resolution. The national political framework, that is, The Articles of Confederation, had no real power to compel compliance from the independent states in conducting national policies. There was no national economic or financial policy, the American army was hugely undersupplied, and the various states struggled with where to draw the line in permitting democratic governance. Consequently, only a few years after the War, the social and economic elites of the colonies came together in the Philadelphia Convention in 1787 to form the US Constitution, which provided for a strong national government.The author actually spends over one-half of his book in showing that Jefferson and Hamilton came to the 90âs via drastically different paths with virtually no interaction. The well-educated, philosophical, and reserved Jefferson, from Virginiaâs agrarian elite, authored the Declaration of Independence and remained in Virginia during the War. After the War, he served as an envoy to France for five years, missing the Constitutional Convention. The talented, ambitious Hamilton arrived in New York from the Caribbean in 1772 and attended Kingâs College, but is best known for being Washingtonâs top aide-de-camp during most of the War. At the Constitutional Convention, he so desired a strong national government that he suggested a president-for-life executive. He campaigned vigorously for the passage of the Constitution through his authorship of most of the essays in the Federalist Papers.However, it was as Secretaries of State and Treasury beginning in Washingtonâs first term in 1789, that Jefferson and Hamilton began an intense rivalry that subsided only with Jeffersonâs election to the Presidency in 1800. The core of their differences revolved around the size and scope of the national government. And Hamilton won most of their battles. He wanted a national debt funded by wealthy Americans; he paid the War bonds heavily speculated on at face value; he assumed the War debts of the states; he established a national bank; and he advocated the establishment of manufacturing. Particularly galling to Jefferson and fellow Republicans was Hamiltonâs desire to form a powerful state in the image of England. On the other hand, Jefferson envisioned an America of mostly independent farmers with a minimalist national government. Furthermore, he and the Republicans supported the revolutionary movement in France, which abhorred conservative Federalists. There were several more chapters in the contentiousness among the two including the Jay Treaty, the XYZ affair, and the Alien and Sedition Acts. The Federalists were the initiators of government policies in this decade, but the Republicans constantly chipped away at their head start and set a very different course with Jeffersonâs election in 1800.There is no doubt that the modern US is permeated with huge commercial enterprises, has a strong banking system, and is a world power with a vast military apparatus. That points to holding that Hamilton is truly the visionary. However, Americans have always been skeptical of power, either private or public, and are fierce defenders of liberty. They value independence. That all suggests that Jefferson is actually the one in tune with Americansâ core beliefs.The book does a fairly good job of detailing the fundamental differences between Jefferson and Hamilton, but it is a short book and is really only a overview. Over half the book merely describes their parallel journeys to their years of contention. In addition, the author devotes some time to their personal failings some of which are only marginally relevant, although Hamiltonâs volatile and paranoid personality was a source of trouble for him. The book is a nice introduction to the first and most important decade in the formation of the Union.

Set in 1945 wartime Moscow, this historical novel is an attempt to recapture the actual killing of two teenage children of elite Communist Party officials. However, to be precise, the book is far more concerned with the fear that pervades a totalitarian society where every action and word is scrutinized for its adherence to Party dogma and rules. Since everyone is potentially an informant, conformity of behavior is essential.In this story, a small group of literature students of the Stalin Commune School 801 have formed the Fatal Romantics' Club. When two of them are shot during a supposedly harmless game, their elite status and unusual interests attract the attention of the Russian state security apparatus. The lack of check on those with absolute power is shown when friends, brothers, and sisters of those in the Club are subjected to relentless questioning inside a prison as though they were enemies of the state.Doubtlessly, life in the Soviet Union in that era was grim and brutal, but the author has created simple stereotypes throughout the book, who seem more like cartoon characters than real individuals. Much of the behavior is over-the-top in terms of its ignorance, arbitrariness, brutality, etc.By far the best part of the book is in the following of the love affairs of two characters, one a senior at the School, the other a top Communist official, which demonstrates quite poignantly the difficulties of finding personal space in a society where everyone is monitored.While the plight of some of the characters at the hands of the Soviet state certainly invokes sympathy, overall, the book lacks the consistency, connectedness, subtlety, and believability to be compelling.

â¦ is the way to describe the authorâs latest murder mystery set near Dublin, Ireland with all of the spot-on Irish flavor and attitudes that dot all of her previous works. The backdrop to this story is a private, prestigious school for teenage girls, St. Kildaâs School, with all of the emotions and drama present that often pervade settings where girls are trying to find themselves and establish relationships with both girls and guys. A blemish on the Schoolâs image is that a year ago, Chris Harper, a student at an adjacent boysâ school, was found bludgeoned to death on the campus. However, the case was relegated to the cold-case bin in the Dublin police department.But suddenly, a year later, a note is pinned to a special bulletin board at St. Kildaâs claiming to know who killed Chris. Enter young, ambitious cold-case detective Stephen Moran and murder squad detective Antoinette Conway, a tough, no-nonsense, and disliked female. Over a very long day, Moran and Conway encounter any number of female cliques at St. Kildaâs who are determined to bury facts, mislead investigators, and protect their friends. Using group rivalries, sharp observations, and subtle pressure, Moran and Conway slowly eliminate suspects.The day is long and the endless interviews at times become tedious, but it is entirely believable that it would take considerable time to peel away the many subterfuges initiated by these girls about this case. The relationship of Moran and Conway is pretty shaky, especially given the volatility of Conway, but they discover that they complement each other well in their approaches. The story is interesting with continual new developments that keep the detectives scrambling to stay in the case.

Only the most naïve individuals believe that Southern slaves were actually freed by various proclamations and Constitutional amendments in the 1860's. This work by a Southern-born journalist is another chapter in the unconscionable story of Southern elites keeping freedmen in virtually slavery for decades after the Civil War.The emphasis in this rather scattershot book is the criminalization of ordinary behavior that was enforced only against blacks. Not having a job, being out at night, being disrespectful to bosses, speaking loudly around white women, etc would get one hauled before a judge. What followed is nothing short of a conspiracy among law enforcement, the legal system, and business and agricultural elites. The guilty parties invariably could not pay the court-imposed fines or numerous tacked-on fees. The offending persons are then leased to an individual or a business for months, if not years, to pay off the fine. In that custody, they were treated as ordinary criminals and subjected to brutal work regimes and conditions, often being chained to work stations. The death rate among these leased persons was extraordinarily high. Inspectors, being a part of the conspiracy, never reported these atrocious conditions.Of course, this leasing system was only one means to keep blacks under control. The author also discusses the terror perpetrated by such organizations as the Ku Klux Klan and the suppression of voting rights. And then there was the sharecropping system, where small farmers were in perpetual debt to large landholders and local store owners. The so-called New South was not really so new after all. The revival of the South was built on the subjugation of freedmen no less onerous than the system of slavery before the War.The author intermittently focuses on one family grouping, both white and black, who lived in an Alabama county going back nearly two hundred years to show the details of this suppression. The book is written in journalistic mode with lots of names and digressions. The book makes for pretty grim reading. It is a terrible black mark on American history to realize that we as a nation permitted, even to some degree justified, this egregious treatment of freedmen.

Thirty-something and widowed Celia Cassill, the owner of a small Brooklyn apartment building, believes in privacy and separateness. She only marginally knows the long-retired ferry captain on the fourth floor, the middle-aged couple on the third, and George and his current boyfriend on the second floor. When Celia permits Georgeâs friend Hope, a very striking forty-something woman, to sub-let Georgeâs apartment, she cannot fathom that her content, controlled world would soon be unglued.But Hope is not as on top of her game as she seems; she is reeling from a divorce action. It is not long before Celia realizes that Hope is permitting herself to be debased by a former male friend. Beyond her insistence that lives remain private, Celia is especially affected by Hopeâs encounters because she had a similar experience with a stranger met on a NYC subway shortly after her husbandâs death. The psychology of all of this is rather tricky, but Celia finds herself being drawn into Hopeâs orbit with a strong desire to assuage what Hope is missing.Most of the book is what is going on in Celiaâs mind, as she has carefully constructed a life to move on from her husbandâs death. It is interesting to watch her scramble when Hope enters her world and other apartment problems intrude. Perhaps one could wish for more resolution at the end.

This somewhat drawn out novel is concerned with life directions taken by two best high school friends, Mia and Lorrie Ann, and how their choices and circumstances impact and reflect their friendship. Both are from modest situations, but are quite a bit different. Mia is the tougher of the two, while Lorrie Ann is more attractive, good-hearted, and sees the best in others. Considering their ordinariness, it is surprising that the author has Mia, year's later, pursuing post-graduate mythology studies in Istanbul, while the pristine Lorrie Ann experiences any number of tragedies and is in a downward spiral.The focus of the book is on Lorrie Ann, as seen by Mia, and on her trials and tribulations. Slowly the details of Lorrie Ann's life are revealed, causing Mia no little consternation, puzzlement, and feelings of helplessness. Meeting in Istanbul many years later, Mia is again drawn to her but really cannot fully understand who she has become. Basically, Mia finally realizes that the bonds of deep friendship have no guarantees; some people will never be fully revealed.The book feels unbalanced. The beautiful, saintly Lorrie Ann is idealized at first, but then she is cut down at every turn. Meanwhile, Mia escapes her own shortcomings. Eventually, the Lorrie Ann/Mia saga becomes overstated and wearisome.

What could be more exciting than love at first sight? Carol, an exquisite looking, older NYC socialite, and Therese, an attractive counter girl at a NYC department store, are both immediately taken by each other. That is not particularly remarkable, except for the fact that the year is about 1950 and there is virtually no tolerance for such love.The story is told from Thereseâs perspective and details her feelings, doubts, and joy as her relationship with Carol haltingly proceeds. Carol, with the most to lose, has to contend with others, including her husband, attempting to assail the status quo of her life. Most interesting is the several week long car trip that they take through the mid-West that is very critical to their relationship. However, the characters in this short novel could be better drawn.Slightly annoying are the many typos, misspelled and run-together words, and strange paragraphing in this book. The author has to be credited for a very perceptive treatment of a controversial topic some sixty-five years ago.

This book is a collection of about 70 articles culled from the website of the New Georgia Encyclopedia that pertain to the Civil War in Georgia. The articles are grouped as Prelude to War, The War Years, and The Warâs Legacy, but are so short that the book is perhaps best viewed as a âsamplerâ of the Civil War. The book is intended to give a flavor and a feel to the Civil War in Georgia, but is inadequate for a deeper understanding of the Civil War.Most of the significant battles that occurred in Georgia get a chapter; however, disappointingly, very few maps are provided to clarify the maneuvers. Supporting institutions such as hospitals, manufacturing facilities, railroads, newspapers, and prisons primarily located in Georgiaâs main cities are recognized. In addition, the situation for unionists, deserters, dissenters, women, and slaves are described.As this collection makes evident, control of the memories of the Civil War has always been very important to Southerners. Various cities, sites, organizations, activities, books, films, etc have sought to favorably depict the Civil War dating from its conclusion to the present day. In particular, the so-called âlost causeâ theme is often advanced. According to this idea, the Confederacy was a gallant cause waged by honorable men to fend off the depredations of unscrupulous Yankees. Slavery, according to them, was a benign part of Southern life that Yankee invaders destroyed. Some of the articles are critical of this idea, but others are accepting.In many ways the book and the online site are exasperating in their neutrality and passivity to the realities of the South, the Civil War, and slavery. One article in the first section claims that the Civil War was âvery much a political war,â that occurred due to political failure. What is not said, is that âfire-eatingâ Southern social and economic elites drove the political process. America has never figured how to give average citizens a meaningful voice in the political process. An article on Reconstruction scarcely mentions the incredible violence perpetrated on blacks and sympathizers, which continued through several decades of Jim Crow. One author amazingly suggests that blacks and whites hammered out an agreement about freedom after the War.The book is no more than a very minimalist introduction to the Civil War. Some of the places and organizations that remember the Civil War are not found in traditional histories, so may be useful. To learn about the Civil War and its aftermath such books such as David Potterâs The Impending Crisis, James McPhersonâs Battle Cry of Freedom, and Eric Fonerâs Reconstruction must be consulted.

In this somewhat awkward, pieced together story, Joan, a second-tier ballerina, has a fling with up and coming Russian star dancer Arslan Rusakow in Paris - even helping him escape to the West. But, then it's back to high school sweetheart Jacob, who has been patiently waiting on Joan for years, and to a desultory existence in the suburban sprawl of southern California. Her son Harry is the only bright spot in her life, especially when she discovers in her dance studio that Harry is a ballet talent.Both Harry and Chloe, Harry's childhood friend, quickly ascend up the rungs of ballet, being selected for ever more elite training and experiences. Of course, at the highest rung is still Arslan. It is inevitable that Joan will again cross paths with him. Also unavoidable are the revelations of the entirety of her relationship with Arslan, much to the dismay of her family.Overall the story is rather lackluster; the author's injection of bits of melodrama does not rescue the book. None of the characters really spring to life. The author does capture the demands and cruelties of the ballet world; there is a rigid pecking order. The book really does not deliver up to its potential.

In this relatively short work, well-known Civil War historian William Freehling discusses the miscalculations and misperceptions of white Southern secessionists and the deft handling of the Civil War crisis by Lincoln that ensured that the rebellious South had little chance of succeeding in their audacious act. The most glaring error of those leading the charge to succeed was their belief that slave-holding states would take a unified stand against the Union - that all Southerners were on the same page. In addition, their weird and oft-repeated idea that slavery was a form of paternalism was found to be totally false, as blacks deserted their former masters in droves when opportunities were presented.The author breaks the South into three critical regions: Border, Middle, and the Lower South. Only the Lower South had significant regions of large slaveholdings. Deep South plantation owners should have appreciated that fact moreso. Lincoln, actually a fairly conservative Republican, ensured the neutrality of whites in the upper regions of the South by his refusal to touch the institution of slavery in the first two years of the War. This permitted Union armies to operate with little opposition in those states and enabled them to control vital rail lines that connected the Lower South to industrial output in the North and to facilitate quick Union troop movements.The author points out that the South supplied 300,000 white soldiers to the Union cause and an additional 150,000 black troops. Also, as Union forces occupied greater portions of the South, thousands of fugitive slaves joined Union camps to perform backbreaking labor, freeing Union soldiers to fight battles. The South had no equivalent segments of the population to augment their armies after huge loses as did the Union.It is certainly true that the North had a huge advantage in the War from the very start in terms of population and industrial capability. But as the author demonstrates in this book, it is the divisions in the South that expanded that advantage permitting the Union to slowly strangle the South in a devastating defeat.

Sculling is actually quite complex and the author hardly shies away from those complexities. There is so much to be aware of and to perform simultaneously: oar position: height, depth, length of travel, and rotation; the motion and posture of the body involving legs, back, arms, shoulders, and hands; and boat movement: water line, stability, boat check, etc, not to mention boat setup and equipment involving rigging, foot stretchers, oar selection, etc.While the author covers some rudiments of sculls and rowing, that is not his focus. He is far more concerned with the complexities mentioned and the many ways that rowers violate them and methods for correction. For beginners, this book would be pretty obscure: their heads would be spinning after trying to get through it. Experienced rowers looking to make subtle improvements in their rowing would perhaps be the main beneficiaries of this book, however, even then the brevity of the book makes explanations very succinct.The problem with the book is that the author seems to feel that he has written a basic book on sculling. It is not a basic book. It is more likely to be intimidating to an inexperienced sculler, rather than helpful. Somewhat grating is that despite so much emphasis on technicalities, the author suggests that rowers need to "feel" the right way to row. That seems contradictory.

This rather intense novel is concerned with the relentless mental and physical stresses that are part of elite rowing programs and how all of that can ripple out into later years. Rob Carrey, an accomplished senior high school sculler in western New York, has been given a rowing scholarship as a post-graduate student to the elite Fenton prep school, hopefully, for him, as a stepping stone to Harvard. Now, fifteen years later, having become a documentary filmmaker, he has been summoned back to Fenton for his fifteenth year reunion, not to mention the death of one of his crewmates.At Fenton, no longer is Rob the BMOC. In the first place, he had been unaware that his scholarship is for a rower on a four-man sweep boat. The only goal is to beat the rival Warwick team in the spring. And iconic, crusty coach Channing and the blueblood, mainstay of the crew Connor are unhappy that Rob is unwilling or unable to modify his rowing technique to get the necessary speed to win the race.The story is revealed as it shifts back and forth in time from present-day NYC where Rob is breaking up with his longtime girlfriend Carolyn to the past of Felton where Rob is trying to adjust to his crew including the enigmatic and demanding Ruth, the first female coxswain at Felton.For rowing aficionados, the detailed rowing information and the intense training will definitely grab one's attention. However, while one can hardly discount the immense pressures of sports, the drama that surrounds Rob at both Fenton and now in his present life seems somewhat overly done; he seems more resourceful than the author permits. His crewmates and his girlfriend are likewise underdeveloped and not well understood. The book's ending also falls a little flat.

This moderate sized book is meant to be an easily read, overview of the American Revolution beginning briefly with the French-Indian War and concluding with the election of Washington as the first President. The rudiments of the Americansâ grievances with Britain are explored, but there is only minimal discussion of the deeper political, legal issues. The culture and views of the average colonist are not concerns of the author.Most of the book is devoted to the American military campaigns, especially the strategies and actions of General Washington. The author hardly whitewashes the Americansâ efforts. There were disconnects everywhere: troops not being where they were supposed to be; huge shortages of supplies ranging from food, shelter, and armaments; inept military leadership; etc. And, clearly, the ineffectualness of the US Congress and the Articles of Confederation very nearly cost America the war. The war was very protracted with huge loss of life and property. However, in the authorâs telling a few key military leaders, soldiers who overcame tremendous hardships, and timely, sometimes lucky, military actions finally turned the tide against Britain.The author paints Washington as practically a saint in his patience, perseverance, and tolerance for the failures of others. In particular, Washington time and again put up with difficult personalities, including Benedict Arnold, who rewarded Washington by spying for Britain. A glaring shortcoming in the book is the absence of maps to follow the various maneuvers of Washington and others. While this book is not without merit in its own right, there is so much more to know about the American Revolutionary period than what the author covers.

The author, having taught thousands of recreational rowers at Harvard, is well versed in what beginning rowers don't know, and thereby need to know, about rowing. This small, easily read book is a good introduction to many facets of rowing and also would be valuable to those who are not absolute beginners. The author is concerned only with sculling, that is, one man, two oars.The book begins by covering the basics of equipment, boat handling, and rowing technique. At each step rowing and equipment terminology is addressed. Later, refinements to basic rowing that permit one to become a true practitioner of the sport are added, including the possibilities of racing. An obscure part of dealing with boats is the setup of the rigging, that is, the apparatus that hold the oars. The author attempts to give some insight, but one suspects that the help of an experienced boat rigger is necessary. Mention of equipment that the rower should bring like what type of clothing for various conditions is not mentioned. Nor are costs associated with rowing detailed. Some mention of injuries would have been good, like what to do about blisters.Unlike some rowing books, this one is not geared towards coaches with obscure chapters on the physics of rowing, details of physiology, and the like. This book is concerned with the practicalities of rowing and its possibilities as an enjoyable activity for almost anyone with such an inclination.

This meandering, short piece follows the first few years of the author's efforts to learn the practice of rowing at age forty-something. As a classics professor, he was already interested in the military uses of rowing in ancient Greece. He also has the good fortune of living in a city on Cayuga Lake in upstate New York, where rowing is part of the local college community, which includes such infrastructure as boathouses and rowing tanks.The author responds to a "Learn to Row" flyer, despite his distinct non-athleticism and older age. As he admits, he is not a natural. It takes him a considerable amount of time to become comfortable with the nuances of rowing in addition to developing the posture and fitness required. The author is also plagued by injuries incurred while rowing, actually necessitating a two-year break from his learning process. While mentioning the risks of rowing, the author does a poor job of explaining the measures that should be taken to prevent drowning when flipping a scull in cold water on a solitary row. People do die every year while rowing.The author is obviously pleased that he found rowing at mid-life, if partly for the reason that it dovetails well with his professional interests. The book leans far too much towards the inspirational side with a lack of attention to practicalities. For example, what clothing is worn throughout the year in different weather conditions? What are the costs for clothing, equipment, club fees, etc? Is rowing really accessible to most people? We do not all live in Ivy League towns on a large lake.The author's personal journey to becoming a rower is mildly interesting though the story is quite hit-and-miss with any number of tangents, including into ancient Greece. The author's personal observations on rowing do not really compensate for the book's several shortcomings. It is hard to say how much help this book would be to a potential rower.

This manual, consisting of 70 articles by rowing experts and last updated in 1992, produced in association with the US Rowing Association, remains relevant today despite most of the entries being written in the 1970s. The editor is well known in the rowing community as a former rowing coach at an elite Ivy League school. The five sections of the manual are devoted to technique, rigging, training, coxing, and organization.By far the most interesting and developed sections are those on technique and training. The rowing stroke is broken down into minute detail, including its physics. The training articles are correlated with the aerobic and anaerobic energy systems of the body and the energy demands of rowing. Several articles are devoted to rower safety; in particular, what to do if a boat flips over with the threat of hypothermia.The book is pretty much geared to coaches, but would be of interest to anyone with a serious interest in rowing. As usual, in a book with this many articles, there is quite of bit of overlap among the articles with the lack of a consistent thread.

There is not much to say about these other than they are the perfect counters for Magic, etc.  I know most people have moved on to dice, but I still love using my glass counters.  These are well crafted, ship quickly.  Can't go wrong.

Bose Bluetooth Series 2 vs. Sennheiser Presence UC ML vs. Plantronics Voyager Edge vs. Plantronics Voyager Legend UCI began this review after Bose decided to cease production on their Series 2 Bluetooth.  Previous to this review I had been super pleased with the Bose, only complaints were the short battery life (started around 4 hours, and degraded to about 2 hours after a year) and the construction of the item began to falter after about 2 years.Highlights:Plantronics Legend- Comes with a ton of accessories.  Comes with a charging case that doubles as a recharger (too big for your pocket though).  Tells the battery life with each use.  Versatile fit.  Boom microphone should also help voice clarity.  Charging stands for desk.  Auto answers calls, voice recognition. Solidly Built.  Only over the ear Bluetooth I tested.  Was very clear, good volume.Plantronics Edge- Well priced for the quality.  Also has a charging case that doubles as a backup if you run out of juice.  This case uses micro USB.  Lightweight.  The least noticeable on your ear of the four.Bose- Very small.  Very high sound quality. The on/off button is a little flimsy and I have replaces one unit after about 1-2 years.Sennheiser- The boom mike slides in and out to turn on and off. For people that like to turn their devices on and off, this is super easy to use and intuitive.  Nice heavy-duty metal feel.  Great packaging.Cost:1. Plantronics Edge- $50-$602. Plantronics Legend- $1353. Sennheiser UC- $1504. Bose- Sold out- $200+ in aftermarketCase:1.) Both Plantronics cases also hold a charge, which is nice in a bind (be aware that the Edge case will not accommodate the Edge unit if it has the earpiece bar assembled.2.) Sennheiser- Nice, sturdy, high quality, but purposeless case.3.) Bose- I didnât notice or recall a case.Ease of use:1. Bose- Flip switch, put in ear.2. Legend- Flip switch, place over ear, slight adjustment3. Sennheiser- Put over ear, adjust the plastic holder- pull out mike.4. Edge- Place in ear, might have to fidget with the plastic earpiece, as it doesnât go on easy.[This feature is important to me, as I often use my earpiece when driving and I donât like to wear it when not in use, so the ability to pick it up, turn it on, and use it right away is important to me]Comfort:1. Edge- I find this one to be nice and lightweight, fits securely, and once itâs on, you donât notice it.  However **** this one did not stay in my ear without using the plastic around the ear attachment. Without that optional attachment, the Edge would not stay in my ear.2. Bose- Fairly lightweight, and if it fits your ear is nice, if it doesnât fit your ear, you will hate this device.3. Legend is very comfortable, but is also considerably bigger and heavier than the other devices.  If you wear it all the time, would get annoying.  This is however the most versatile fit of all of them.4.) The Sennheiser is a very snug and tight fit, but that can hurt it too, as it sometimes will pinch your face, and getting an optimal fit is not easy.  The rubber coatings are still pretty rough.Battery Life:- This is a tough category, as the Plantronic devices both come with carrying cases that also function as recharging stations, so in essence you can get twice as much life out of a Plantronics.  If you ignore this:1.) Sennheiser- Lasts up to 10 hours, and this seemed accurate.2.) Plantronics- both seemed to get around 6 hours.3.) Bose- this one gets about 4 hours, and then a year later less than two.*  Special note, all three devices other than the Bose announce the battery life.  The Plantronics devices both do it every time the unit is used.  The Sennheiser requires a small button push.  Bose has no feature.Sound Quality: This is a tough category as always. I use mine in the car (road noise) and have a larger head (harder for mike to pick up sounds around my cheeks). Your experience may differ depending on your signal, location, face shape, and usage.1. Bose: By far the most clear. Loud volume. People could hear me. I could hear them.  Most people have never known I was on a Bluetooth.2 (tie). Sennheiser- This one was very loud, no sound distortion2.(tie). Plantronics Legend-  This one also sounds very good, has a nice high volume, and sounds natural.  I didnât get to test this one in as many varying conditions, so gave the nod to the Sennheiser.4. Edge- I didnât like the sound on this one. People could hear my clearly, but they sounded distant and like they were on a speakerphone or in an echo chamber.  Volume was also lower than the other devices.Disappointments:Bose- The on/off button will wear out over time (1-2 years with heavy use).  The battery will also lose effectiveness during this time.  Bose battery life at peak is half of the others (3-4 hours). Can be a tough fit for some ears.Edge- HORRIBLE design if you require using the small plastic ear bar.  If you have this on the device, it will not fit in the charging station.  You will have to take it off every time you want to charge it in the holster.Legend- You cannot charge the unit directly without using a proprietary charging connection (though the case takes micro-usb). It is magnetics, so super easy to use, but if you travel, you need to bring the adapter or the special cord or the case. For business travelers, having to worry about yet another charging method might be an annoyance.Sennheiser-  Pairing can be a little tricky at first.  Putting the unit on and off your ear will take some practice.  Doesnât feel as secure on the ear as the others.Final Conclusions:This one is super hard, as I was hoping that 4 years later the Bose device would have been surpassed. I still think the Bose unit is the best Bluetooth, but the fact that it only holds a charge for 3-4 hours really makes it inferior to the other devices out there right now.  Even though the sound quality is still top notch.I still donât know what unit I am going to keepâ¦..Bose- Bought one of the last new ones before they discontinued it, but I hate the short battery life.Sennheiser- Build quality is great, battery life and sound are great, but the fit is a little uncomfortable.Edge-  Very comfortable, sounds good, but the fact that I canât use the charging station with it makes it annoying.Legend-  Great sound, great charging capabilities, but having the always have a special charger or the charging case on me seems annoying.I hate to say it, but this is my first review ever that will be inconclusiveâ¦.any recommendations???

The Sennheiser is a very snug and tight fit, but that can hurt it too, as it sometimes will pinch your face, and getting an optimal fit is not easy.  The rubber coatings are still pretty rough.Battery Life:- This is a tough category, as the Plantronic devices both come with carrying cases that also function as recharging stations, so in essence you can get twice as much life out of a Plantronics.  If you ignore this:1.) Sennheiser- Lasts up to 10 hours, and this seemed accurate.2.) Plantronics- both seemed to get around 6 hours.3.) Bose- this one gets about 4 hours, and then a year later less than two.*  Special note, all three devices other than the Bose announce the battery life.  The Plantronics devices both do it every time the unit is used.  The Sennheiser requires a small button push.  Bose has no feature.Sound Quality: This is a tough category as always. I use mine in the car (road noise) and have a larger head (harder for mike to pick up sounds around my cheeks). Your experience may differ depending on your signal, location, face shape, and usage.1. Bose: By far the most clear. Loud volume. People could hear me. I could hear them.  Most people have never known I was on a Bluetooth.2 (tie). Sennheiser- This one was very loud, no sound distortion2.(tie). Plantronics Legend-  This one also sounds very good, has a nice high volume, and sounds natural.  I didnât get to test this one in as many varying conditions, so gave the nod to the Sennheiser.4. Edge- I didnât like the sound on this one. People could hear my clearly, but they sounded distant and like they were on a speakerphone or in an echo chamber.  Volume was also lower than the other devices.Disappointments:Bose- The on/off button will wear out over time (1-2 years with heavy use).  The battery will also lose effectiveness during this time.  Bose battery life at peak is half of the others (3-4 hours). Can be a tough fit for some ears.Edge- HORRIBLE design if you require using the small plastic ear bar.  If you have this on the device, it will not fit in the charging station.  You will have to take it off every time you want to charge it in the holster.Legend- You cannot charge the unit directly without using a proprietary charging connection (though the case takes micro-usb). It is magnetics, so super easy to use, but if you travel, you need to bring the adapter or the special cord or the case. For business travelers, having to worry about yet another charging method might be an annoyance.Sennheiser-  Pairing can be a little tricky at first.  Putting the unit on and off your ear will take some practice.  Doesnât feel as secure on the ear as the others.Final Conclusions:This one is super hard, as I was hoping that 4 years later the Bose device would have been surpassed. I still think the Bose unit is the best Bluetooth, but the fact that it only holds a charge for 3-4 hours really makes it inferior to the other devices out there right now.  Even though the sound quality is still top notch.I still donât know what unit I am going to keepâ¦..Bose- Bought one of the last new ones before they discontinued it, but I hate the short battery life.Sennheiser- Build quality is great, battery life and sound are great, but the fit is a little uncomfortable.Edge-  Very comfortable, sounds good, but the fact that I canât use the charging station with it makes it annoying.Legend-  Great sound, great charging capabilities, but having the always have a special charger or the charging case on me seems annoying.I hate to say it, but this is my first review ever that will be inconclusiveâ¦.any recommendations???

Sennheiser- Nice, sturdy, high quality, but purposeless case.3.) Bose- I didnât notice or recall a case.Ease of use:1. Bose- Flip switch, put in ear.2. Legend- Flip switch, place over ear, slight adjustment3. Sennheiser- Put over ear, adjust the plastic holder- pull out mike.4. Edge- Place in ear, might have to fidget with the plastic earpiece, as it doesnât go on easy.[This feature is important to me, as I often use my earpiece when driving and I donât like to wear it when not in use, so the ability to pick it up, turn it on, and use it right away is important to me]Comfort:1. Edge- I find this one to be nice and lightweight, fits securely, and once itâs on, you donât notice it.  However **** this one did not stay in my ear without using the plastic around the ear attachment. Without that optional attachment, the Edge would not stay in my ear.2. Bose- Fairly lightweight, and if it fits your ear is nice, if it doesnât fit your ear, you will hate this device.3. Legend is very comfortable, but is also considerably bigger and heavier than the other devices.  If you wear it all the time, would get annoying.  This is however the most versatile fit of all of them.4.) The Sennheiser is a very snug and tight fit, but that can hurt it too, as it sometimes will pinch your face, and getting an optimal fit is not easy.  The rubber coatings are still pretty rough.Battery Life:- This is a tough category, as the Plantronic devices both come with carrying cases that also function as recharging stations, so in essence you can get twice as much life out of a Plantronics.  If you ignore this:1.) Sennheiser- Lasts up to 10 hours, and this seemed accurate.2.) Plantronics- both seemed to get around 6 hours.3.) Bose- this one gets about 4 hours, and then a year later less than two.*  Special note, all three devices other than the Bose announce the battery life.  The Plantronics devices both do it every time the unit is used.  The Sennheiser requires a small button push.  Bose has no feature.Sound Quality: This is a tough category as always. I use mine in the car (road noise) and have a larger head (harder for mike to pick up sounds around my cheeks). Your experience may differ depending on your signal, location, face shape, and usage.1. Bose: By far the most clear. Loud volume. People could hear me. I could hear them.  Most people have never known I was on a Bluetooth.2 (tie). Sennheiser- This one was very loud, no sound distortion2.(tie). Plantronics Legend-  This one also sounds very good, has a nice high volume, and sounds natural.  I didnât get to test this one in as many varying conditions, so gave the nod to the Sennheiser.4. Edge- I didnât like the sound on this one. People could hear my clearly, but they sounded distant and like they were on a speakerphone or in an echo chamber.  Volume was also lower than the other devices.Disappointments:Bose- The on/off button will wear out over time (1-2 years with heavy use).  The battery will also lose effectiveness during this time.  Bose battery life at peak is half of the others (3-4 hours). Can be a tough fit for some ears.Edge- HORRIBLE design if you require using the small plastic ear bar.  If you have this on the device, it will not fit in the charging station.  You will have to take it off every time you want to charge it in the holster.Legend- You cannot charge the unit directly without using a proprietary charging connection (though the case takes micro-usb). It is magnetics, so super easy to use, but if you travel, you need to bring the adapter or the special cord or the case. For business travelers, having to worry about yet another charging method might be an annoyance.Sennheiser-  Pairing can be a little tricky at first.  Putting the unit on and off your ear will take some practice.  Doesnât feel as secure on the ear as the others.Final Conclusions:This one is super hard, as I was hoping that 4 years later the Bose device would have been surpassed. I still think the Bose unit is the best Bluetooth, but the fact that it only holds a charge for 3-4 hours really makes it inferior to the other devices out there right now.  Even though the sound quality is still top notch.I still donât know what unit I am going to keepâ¦..Bose- Bought one of the last new ones before they discontinued it, but I hate the short battery life.Sennheiser- Build quality is great, battery life and sound are great, but the fit is a little uncomfortable.Edge-  Very comfortable, sounds good, but the fact that I canât use the charging station with it makes it annoying.Legend-  Great sound, great charging capabilities, but having the always have a special charger or the charging case on me seems annoying.I hate to say it, but this is my first review ever that will be inconclusiveâ¦.any recommendations???

Previous to this review I had been super pleased with the Bose, only complaints were the short battery life (started around 4 hours, and degraded to about 2 hours after a year) and the construction of the item began to falter after about 2 years.Highlights:Plantronics Legend- Comes with a ton of accessories.  Comes with a charging case that doubles as a recharger (too big for your pocket though).  Tells the battery life with each use.  Versatile fit.  Boom microphone should also help voice clarity.  Charging stands for desk.  Auto answers calls, voice recognition. Solidly Built.  Only over the ear Bluetooth I tested.  Was very clear, good volume.Plantronics Edge- Well priced for the quality.  Also has a charging case that doubles as a backup if you run out of juice.  This case uses micro USB.  Lightweight.  The least noticeable on your ear of the four.Bose- Very small.  Very high sound quality. The on/off button is a little flimsy and I have replaces one unit after about 1-2 years.Sennheiser- The boom mike slides in and out to turn on and off. For people that like to turn their devices on and off, this is super easy to use and intuitive.  Nice heavy-duty metal feel.  Great packaging.Cost:1. Plantronics Edge- $50-$602. Plantronics Legend- $1353. Sennheiser UC- $1504. Bose- Sold out- $200+ in aftermarketCase:1.) Both Plantronics cases also hold a charge, which is nice in a bind (be aware that the Edge case will not accommodate the Edge unit if it has the earpiece bar assembled.2.) Sennheiser- Nice, sturdy, high quality, but purposeless case.3.) Bose- I didnât notice or recall a case.Ease of use:1. Bose- Flip switch, put in ear.2. Legend- Flip switch, place over ear, slight adjustment3. Sennheiser- Put over ear, adjust the plastic holder- pull out mike.4. Edge- Place in ear, might have to fidget with the plastic earpiece, as it doesnât go on easy.[This feature is important to me, as I often use my earpiece when driving and I donât like to wear it when not in use, so the ability to pick it up, turn it on, and use it right away is important to me]Comfort:1. Edge- I find this one to be nice and lightweight, fits securely, and once itâs on, you donât notice it.  However **** this one did not stay in my ear without using the plastic around the ear attachment. Without that optional attachment, the Edge would not stay in my ear.2. Bose- Fairly lightweight, and if it fits your ear is nice, if it doesnât fit your ear, you will hate this device.3. Legend is very comfortable, but is also considerably bigger and heavier than the other devices.  If you wear it all the time, would get annoying.  This is however the most versatile fit of all of them.4.) The Sennheiser is a very snug and tight fit, but that can hurt it too, as it sometimes will pinch your face, and getting an optimal fit is not easy.  The rubber coatings are still pretty rough.Battery Life:- This is a tough category, as the Plantronic devices both come with carrying cases that also function as recharging stations, so in essence you can get twice as much life out of a Plantronics.  If you ignore this:1.) Sennheiser- Lasts up to 10 hours, and this seemed accurate.2.) Plantronics- both seemed to get around 6 hours.3.) Bose- this one gets about 4 hours, and then a year later less than two.*  Special note, all three devices other than the Bose announce the battery life.  The Plantronics devices both do it every time the unit is used.  The Sennheiser requires a small button push.  Bose has no feature.Sound Quality: This is a tough category as always. I use mine in the car (road noise) and have a larger head (harder for mike to pick up sounds around my cheeks). Your experience may differ depending on your signal, location, face shape, and usage.1. Bose: By far the most clear. Loud volume. People could hear me. I could hear them.  Most people have never known I was on a Bluetooth.2 (tie). Sennheiser- This one was very loud, no sound distortion2.(tie). Plantronics Legend-  This one also sounds very good, has a nice high volume, and sounds natural.  I didnât get to test this one in as many varying conditions, so gave the nod to the Sennheiser.4. Edge- I didnât like the sound on this one. People could hear my clearly, but they sounded distant and like they were on a speakerphone or in an echo chamber.  Volume was also lower than the other devices.Disappointments:Bose- The on/off button will wear out over time (1-2 years with heavy use).  The battery will also lose effectiveness during this time.  Bose battery life at peak is half of the others (3-4 hours). Can be a tough fit for some ears.Edge- HORRIBLE design if you require using the small plastic ear bar.  If you have this on the device, it will not fit in the charging station.  You will have to take it off every time you want to charge it in the holster.Legend- You cannot charge the unit directly without using a proprietary charging connection (though the case takes micro-usb). It is magnetics, so super easy to use, but if you travel, you need to bring the adapter or the special cord or the case. For business travelers, having to worry about yet another charging method might be an annoyance.Sennheiser-  Pairing can be a little tricky at first.  Putting the unit on and off your ear will take some practice.  Doesnât feel as secure on the ear as the others.Final Conclusions:This one is super hard, as I was hoping that 4 years later the Bose device would have been surpassed. I still think the Bose unit is the best Bluetooth, but the fact that it only holds a charge for 3-4 hours really makes it inferior to the other devices out there right now.  Even though the sound quality is still top notch.I still donât know what unit I am going to keepâ¦..Bose- Bought one of the last new ones before they discontinued it, but I hate the short battery life.Sennheiser- Build quality is great, battery life and sound are great, but the fit is a little uncomfortable.Edge-  Very comfortable, sounds good, but the fact that I canât use the chargings station with it makes it annoying.Legend-  Great sound, great charging capabilities, but having the always have a special charger or the charging case on me seems annoying.I hate to say it, but this is my first review ever that will be inconclusiveâ¦.any recommendations???

Volume was also lower than the other devices.Disappointments:Bose- The on/off button will wear out over time (1-2 years with heavy use).  The battery will also lose effectiveness during this time.  Bose battery life at peak is half of the others (3-4 hours). Can be a tough fit for some ears.Edge- HORRIBLE design if you require using the small plastic ear bar.  If you have this on the device, it will not fit in the charging station.  You will have to take it off every time you want to charge it in the holster.Legend- You cannot charge the unit directly without using a proprietary charging connection (though the case takes micro-usb). It is magnetics, so super easy to use, but if you travel, you need to bring the adapter or the special cord or the case. For business travelers, having to worry about yet another charging method might be an annoyance.Sennheiser-  Pairing can be a little tricky at first.  Putting the unit on and off your ear will take some practice.  Doesnât feel as secure on the ear as the others.Final Conclusions:This one is super hard, as I was hoping that 4 years later the Bose device would have been surpassed. I still think the Bose unit is the best Bluetooth, but the fact that it only holds a charge for 3-4 hours really makes it inferior to the other devices out there right now.  Even though the sound quality is still top notch.I still donât know what unit I am going to keepâ¦..Bose- Bought one of the last new ones before they discontinued it, but I hate the short battery life.Sennheiser- Build quality is great, battery life and sound are great, but the fit is a little uncomfortable.Edge-  Very comfortable, sounds good, but the fact that I canât use the charging station with it makes it annoying.Legend-  Great sound, great charging capabilities, but having the always have a special charger or the charging case on me seems annoying.I hate to say it, but this is my first review ever that will be inconclusiveâ¦.any recommendations???
Still among the best deckboxes out there. It will comfortable hold two decks and extras.  Nice clasp, nice feel.  Not my everyday box, but I use it for fun decks.

This is the story of a young, libertine lady and her short life as a stripper.  She is a very free-spirited lass, and while her boyfriend continues to disappoint, she constantly is finding ways to earn them food or money.  She finally settles on stripping, and her tales are enjoyable.I thoroughly enjoyed this book. It is the continuation of the Melody comic book series from the mid-80s.  Granted this series, the artwork is pretty elementary, and while adult in nature, you won't find it very titillating.  You will however enjoy the further adventure of Melody and Nick. Melody wrote and drew this, and it is pretty evident.  However, I did find her unique drawing perspectives refreshing and fun.It's a great read, very enjoyable, and it will have you tracking down the older issues from Kitchen Sink.

My wife is an oncology nurse and she swears by this brand of forceps.  Every year or so, when she's lost a pair or someone's borrowed them, so gets me to log into amazon and tells me that she wants this set, and only this set.  Well priced, good quality.  As good as it gets.

Well, this is still probably the most iconic card in magic, and some would argue an auto include in every deck, but that's simply not true anymore.  Almost every vintage deck uses a Black Lotus, but not all the tier 1 decks do. Some need a more stable manabase (Stax), and don't benefit as much from the mana burst.That said, I never get sick of seeing one out in the wild!

So I am totally torn on this item. For my wife and I it was a lifesaver, but I think there are some serious design issues that reduce it's functionality, not to mention I feel like spending $200-$300 for something that will likely only work for a few months is ridiculous. Is there anyone that really I putting a 2yr old in this? My newborn is almost outgrowing it.Pros:Worked great. THE ONLY thing that chilled my baby out. Well designed. Well manufactured.Cons:The plush upgrade is unnecessary.MY ISSUES:This was effective at chilling my baby out for about 1-2 hours at a time. The problem is that it is not deep enough for the baby to sleep, nor secure enough to hold them in without monitoring.The biggest issue, however, is the small bucket size and lack of a deep well, means that I can't see this thing being useful for more than a few weeks after birth. And it certainly is not big enough for a 2yr old.This item will buy you a few hours of peace and quiet, but your baby cant really sleep in it, and it won't be useable long

This is about as good as it gets in Magic right now. I previously used the single Flip Box (gold color) and while I love the razzle dazzle of it, and the effect, it has become pretty common now. Even worse, if you are no super careful with the single flip box, you can catch a card in the back of it when you fold it over and bend the card in half. Almost happened to a $500 card of mine.The only issue I have is that it might not create a tight fit for your decks, as if you only have one deck, things will move around.This box is bigger, has more space for dice, tokens, counters, whatever. Much easier to use, a little more cumbersome, but all the space is nice. Also, much harded to bend the cards with this one. I like it!
