These socks are soft, they appear to be 100% cotton (I spent a long time with the label and a Chinese-English dictionary), they fit perfectly, and they're very pretty. I bought one pair to check that they were okay, then bought a bunch more. I'm very happy with them.Be warned that they take a while to arrive because they're coming from China.

Twice now I've purchased cheap versions ($25-30) of this type of bag from other manufacturers - one Chinese, one Italian. Both looked very nice new, both disintegrated in just under a year. The back straps ripped off one, the lining separated from the leather in another, and both were made from very thin leather that looked very shabby 10 months later.Buying a well-made $90 bag that lasts for many years is a lot cheaper than buying a $25 bag that has to be replaced every 10 or 11 months. So when the second bag fell apart, I bought a Le Donne bag.I chose this particular Le Donne bag because it has lots of separate compartments - including (notably) one in the back (next to my body) where I can put things like my metro card (I live in NYC) that I need to find quickly, but is valuable and don't want to be easily accessible to someone walking behind me and opening a zipper. No one has ever done that to me in NYC, but I've heard of it happening to other people. If I was traveling, I'd put my passport in that pocket next to my body. I like the pockets on the sides and bottom to give quick access to things - lip gloss, tissues, etc. There's also a zipped pocket on the inside of the main bag.It's just the right size for me. It's a moderate size handbag - big enough to hold what I need to carry (including my Kindle), but not gigantic. It looks very well made. The back straps are thick at the top and padded. You adjust the length of the straps with a notched buckle, not one of those sliding buckles that tends to slip. The stitching for the straps is heavily reinforced on top - it's not coming out. The leather is thick and soft - good quality. The hardware is good quality, too - doesn't look chintzy. The grommets look strong.I've had it for a month and so far so good, but really I need to report back in a year. I paid more for a quality bag that will last. Let's see if it does!

This looks to be a very well-made umbrella. It hasn't rained since it arrived, so I can't verify that the material is waterproof (I've read reviews of umbrellas where that's an issue), but hopefully it is. It's 40" across the bottom when open - measuring the diameter of the open circle, rather than the length across the curved top. That's slightly bigger than the average diameter of 37-38". The 16 ribs should make it much stronger in high winds than umbrellas with the usual 8 ribs - though, as I said, I haven't had an opportunity to test it in rain yet.The reason I'm giving it 4 stars rather than 5 is that the foam handle has a big scrape in it, which is annoying and disappointing. But it's not worth the time and expense to exchange it for one that has no flaws.

Perfect design. Overpriced (I paid $36 & needed two), but there is nothing else anywhere near as good. They display my earrings while protecting them from dust, and everything is still very accessible. Very well-designed. I wish I'd had them years ago to protect my fragile beaded earrings. If you have long dangly earrings, they don't hold very many. That's why I needed to buy two.

There are no reviews of the Kindle version, so I thought I'd post one. This book was thoughtfully formatted to flow well and use the features of an ereader. No content is omitted. Some books are inferior on the Kindle, but not this one.And it's a great book, as so many others have said.
It's very sticky, very thin, and very clear - did the job I bought it to do.

Any time I've had to replace my watch battery, I've spent 20 minutes or more trying to get the back back on, and when you're banging that hard you risk breaking the crystal. So I bought this little thing when my watch battery died, and the back was on again in 5 seconds. Effortless. Surprisingly effortless. There are no instructions, but a picture on the box shows you how it goes together. You just find the pair of plastic thingies that's sized right for your watch and screw them on. Press. Done.

Teeny weeny and works wonderfully. I connected it to my Surface Pro for a miniature computing setup. I bought it to play blu-ray disks when my player died. The Surface Pro and this little disk drive sit next to the TV. The bundled software was a teaser for what I really needed - had to pay $50 to upgrade it, but it would have been more at full price. The setup works great. I can output the Surface Pro screen to the TV, and control the computer from across the room with a bluetooth keyboard and a bluetooth mouse.

These are fantastic. They only last a few years, and I'm so afraid I won't be able to find them again that I buy several at a time - have done for a long time now. There are cheap knock-offs - don't get those. They fall off the faucet. This brand is the real thing.
Instantly opened the back of my watch (once I found where the tiny little tab was). It took a while to arrive from Japan, but it's very well made - worth the wait.

These are easy to put on and generally comfortable except for the little toe, which is extremely overstretched and the reason I'm returning them. There is nothing at all wrong with my little toe, and in fact I can actively move it out very far on its own. I think the design of YogaToes Gems is defective. There is no difference at all in the thickness or spacing of the separators for the smaller toes - there is the larger big toe separator, then all the rest are the same. But not all the rest of one's toes are the same. You can see in the picture for the product that the small toe is overstretched, and I'm sure that the model's foot is bigger than mine (mine is size 8 women's US).So I'm returning these, and though they cost a lot more, I'm going to buy Correct Toes. Correct Toes are customizable, and can be worn walking barefoot and inside shoes.
Weave is extremely loose - big gaps between threads. I would never buy this again.

This is rated as Grade A Medium Amber, but it looks and tastes like Grade A Dark Amber. I would not buy it again. It was okay in tea, but I would not put it on pancakes. The next time I ordered, I bought a different brand, Coombs Family Farms, also rated as Grade A Medium Amber, and this looks and tastes like this grade is supposed to.I used to live in Vermont and one year (and one year only) I tapped my maple trees - graded the syrup and everything (one year only because it's very hard work). I really don't think this syrup is Medium Amber. I don't have the grading bottles - I didn't formally grade it. I'm just eyeballing the color and mostly judging by taste. It was too dark in color, the taste was too strong with a bitter edge. I didn't like it.
Best back scratcher ever. Probably it's good for pasta, too, but that's not why I bought it. I'm not kidding. It's a GREAT back scratcher.

10 Dec 2014: This is an update of my original review, which is below. I have revised my rating from 3-stars to 5-stars. Here's why.At the time I wrote my original review, I had just had a Lapidus bunionectomy on my right foot and was still no-weight-bearing (NWB). My left foot was 5 months post-op Lapidus bunionectomy. During the NWB period on my right foot, when my left foot was doing all the work, my left big toe did what I said I was afraid it would do in my original review - it started to drift towards my small toes again. When I noticed my toe seemed to be angling in again, I asked my doctor to x-ray my left foot when I came in for a check of my right foot, and you could see it in x-ray - an approximately 3mm shift out of alignment. I'd been taping my foot and not wearing the splint.After 5 months of post-op hell on this left foot, there was no way I was going get another bunion, so rather than return the splint, which I was all ready to do (I'd already packed it up), I decided to use it. Since it fits inside no shoes and gets filthy fast if I walk around barefoot, I wear it with a surgical shoe. For the next 3 weeks, I wore the splint almost constantly unless I was wearing shoes. I wear it around my apartment, and I wear it when I'm sleeping. When I go out (i.e. when I wear shoes), I use my custom orthotics so my hypermobile foot has proper support. I also have been using a home ultrasound machine, and after the ultrasound treatment when my foot is warmed up, I stretch that big toe back in the other direction. It started to look a lot better. Yesterday, I had another check of my right foot and asked my doctor to again x-ray my left foot. And... THE BIG TOE ON MY LEFT FOOT IS STRAIGHT AGAIN, back in joint.So this thing does work. I moved my own bones and have the x-rays to prove it. I'm now using the splint as a sort of "retainer" (like the retainers the orthodontist gives you after braces). And I bought one for my right foot. :)5-STARS!!!!! *****---------------------------------------------------------------Many reviewers said this product caused them pain. I'm pretty sure I know why. If you use it according to the directions, you will pull your big toe out of joint alignment, and that's going to hurt. More on this below, but first some context.I am trying this product after major bunion surgery to maintain the correction while my foot strengthens and heals. For those familiar with bunionectomy procedures, I had the big bad gruesome one on both feet: Lapidus. The right foot surgery was very recent, left foot about 5 months ago. I have hypermobile feet and my bunions were severe. The Lapidus procedure straightens then fuses the joint at the base of the first metatarsal, but the rest of my foot remains hypermobile. Also, because I had such severe bunions for so many years, I have atrophy in the adductor muscle in my big toe.Try this experiment. Put your finger on the outside of your big toe, and try to push your toe against your finger, so your big toe is spreading out from your foot towards the center of your body. Can you do it? If so, congratulations! You have a healthy adductor hallucis muscle. Sadly, I cannot do this - or rather, I can barely do this. I like to think there is trace movement, though I'm not really sure there is.Because of my foot's hypermobility and the loss of adductor strength, my stupid freaking big toe wanders in (my physical therapist insists this is "out" because it's away from the center of my body, but I say it's "in" because it's towards my small toes). Anyway, you get the picture. After 5 months of painful and difficult recovery from Lapidus surgery (5.5 weeks no weight bearing!), it's really annoying!! It's important that I keep my toe in correct alignment while I build up strength in my foot - not only to avoid future surgeries, but because my foot starts to hurt when the joint is not aligned.I originally solved this problem with a simple and effective method I devised of taping the toe with Kinesio tape. But then I had to have a second surgery on the same foot because of scar tissue adhesions, and the incision couldn't properly heal when I was taping it all the time. So I looked for an alternative to taping and found this splint.I've learned more about feet than I ever expected to know because of these surgeries, and I know where the proper alignment of my big toe joint is. So one of the first things I noticed about this splint is that if you follow the instructions, you will pull the big toe joint out of alignment - over-correct in the other direction - and that's going to hurt. There is a 1/8" gel cushion that starts at mid foot and ends at the big toe joint. The aligned position of my toe is where it would be if the gel cushion extended all the way up the splint. So unless I want to pull my toe out of joint, I have to leave about a 1/8" space between the outer edge of my big toe and the splint. Maybe this is something unique about the structure of my foot, but it seems like a design flaw.Also, FYI, this thing fits inside NO shoes. I tried it in crocs and my biggest bedroom slippers. Even the crocs didn't work because all that stuff at midfoot needs a lot of room. Walking around barefoot, it would get dirty fast, so I'd put a sock over it. It's good for keeping my toe aligned while doing my foot exercises, although it prevents the second joint from bending.When the incision from my second surgery is fully healed, I'll go back to using Kinesio tape. Taping the joint keeps it in alignment, doesn't restrict any joints, and fits inside any shoe. (Don't do like I did and put Kinesio tape over an incision that is not 100% healed.)I'm using this device to maintain correction post-op. For someone trying to correct an existing bunion, I have two thoughts...1) If you have severe bunions, forget it. With really severe bunions, the correction has to be done at the BASE of the first metatarsal (physically, that's at about your instep). If you could see an x-ray of my foot before surgery, you'd see how impossible it would be for a device like this to have any impact on my foot since this device is putting pressure at the head of the first metatarsal. If you have severe bunions, go find a competent podiatric surgeon (and don't wait as long as I did to do it).2) If you have mild bunions, apply the pressure very slowly - just a little at a time. You are trying to move bones. Think how this deformity happened in the first place. It happened very slowly over time, most likely from wearing naughty shoes. (If you were born with bad feet, like me, you'd have severe bunions.) So don't yank your toe out of joint with this splint. Pull it just a little bit from where it is. Slowly, slowly. Did you have braces as a kid? Remember how that worked? This is the same.
Thick and soft, just what I wanted. Slightly large, but I haven't washed it yet. I bought both colors. I wish Amazon gave the seller a way to combine shipping.

I thought this book was about technique, but it's really a set of biographies about people I couldn't care less about. Plus, astoundingly, there's not a single picture of a miniature! Really awful book - can't understand the 5-star reviews. Returning it.

This is rewrite of my original review. I originally rated the spin dryer 1-star because I couldn't get it to spin, and the company's customer service is absolutely dreadful.In googling the company, I happened upon their Better Business Bureau (BBB) page. BBB gives the company a rating of "F" (Fail) due to multiple complaints, mostly about poor customer service. I, too, have experienced their terrible customer service, but - ironically - I also found the solution to my spin dryer problem in a company response to a complaint on the BBB page.There is a metal bar screwed into the bottom of the spin dryer. It's not documented anywhere (not in the manual, or on the product page on their Web site), but it's a motor lock, and you have to unscrew and remove it or the spin dryer won't work. I'm just glad I didn't try it too many times with the motor lock on - that likely would have damaged it.This is a company with good products, and just about the worst customer service and product documentation I've ever experienced (especially from a company with good products). They are very hard to get hold of. They do not always answer their phone during their stated business hours, and they do not answer email. When you are able to reach them by phone, the person answering speaks such poor English it's almost impossible to communicate. It's a 3-person company: the owner (who the woman answering phones never lets you speak to - "he's too busy"), the warehouse manager (who sent me incorrect tracking numbers for both items I ordered), and the woman answering the phone, who has a very heavy Asian accent, and does not speak or understand fluent English.Their bad customer service wouldn't be such a liability if their documentation weren't so dangerously insufficient. I can't fathom how they could print a manual for this spin dryer without the instruction to remove the motor lock on the bottom. I saw the metal bar on the bottom, but I had no idea what it was, or that I should remove it. Their Wonder Wash machine (very cleverly designed) also has insufficient documentation. The assembly instructions are incomplete. I was able to figure it out, but some people can't (see the reviews for that product).All that said, the spin dryer does work very well, and I'm glad I have it. But it was a stressful few hours until I figured out why it wouldn't spin (with no help from the company). Some people on the BBB site say the company honors their warranties, some say they don't. I'm glad I didn't have to test that.

I came across this by accident while looking for something else, and bought it because I was grating a lot of lemon rinds and the reviews were unusually positive. It's all true! This is the best zester ever - what a smart design!
The wood is poor quality and very uneven - worse than your usual popsicle sticks. I should have returned it, but didn't act fast enough and now it's too late. I guess I'll toss it.
It is stable, lightweight, folding, has the best kind of handle for safety, and it's PURPLE! What's not to like?

It doesn't look at all like the picture - it's basically white - plus the seller (Tile Circle) is horrible. I wanted to return it because the color was not as described, but they did not answer my email. I had to send a complaint to Amazon. Amazon sent me a return authorization, I returned it, and - 11 days after USPS says it was delivered - I still have not received a refund. I just filed a claim with Amazon. Run fast away from this seller.

I tried to use this twice - read the instructions carefully and did everything correctly - and both times it was filled with water after my shower. The thing hugged my leg so tight I thought it was going to cut off circulation (and yet still did not keep the water out), and the disk thing is annoying and gets in the way.I found a different type of shower protector that works much better: DryPro.
I can't do without these - I've been using them for many years - and they can be hard to find. They only last a few months, after which the rubber starts to crack. Happy to buy several at a time.

I'm giving this 4 stars rather than 5 because, after 2 weeks of use, the padding is fraying and compressed at the knee, and there's no way to replace it. Replaceable padding should be part of the design. I had bunion surgery and have only another week or so where I can't put any weight on the foot, but then there is the other foot. A product that costs $150 shouldn't disintegrate after a few weeks.Also, I wish there were some sort of hook or something on it that made it easier to lean against things when I take it off. It's always falling over (with a crash). At home, I find I can use the upper thigh band to hook it onto a table - knee bed extending beneath the table. But that only works if I'm in the spot near there. In other parts of my apartment or in the park, it's hard to lean it next to me without it crashing to the ground.That said, I am very grateful to have this knee crutch! I would be seriously screwed without it. I live on the 5th floor of a walk-up, and I don't know how I'd even have gotten home after my surgery, if not for this knee crutch. It's a very clever device. It gives me freedom and independence for the 3-6 weeks I can't put weight on my foot following foot surgery. Using the knee crutch, I'm able to vacuum, cook, do dishes, and even go grocery shopping (though that was exhausting - not sure I'll try it again).It takes some practice, but after using it for a while, it feels very natural, stable, and safe. Old-fashioned crutches feel downright dangerous compared to this knee crutch. Though it takes 10-20 seconds to put on and take off, I use the knee crutch almost exclusively because it feels so much safer.But as good as it is, it's not the same as walking on two feet. Here are some important caveats:1. Within my apartment, I don't bother with a cane. But that's because the floors in my apartment are perfectly flat. This knee crutch is seriously hazardous on non-flat surfaces - cracked sidewalks, potholes, lumpy repaved roads, and especially inclines. The most dangerous of all is an upward incline. If you're not extremely careful, you will fall over backward, even with a cane, which I always carry when I go outside with it. Another reason to carry a cane when you go out is that, while steps are navigable, you need to hold onto something. Some steps - like stoops - don't have bannisters. The higher the step, the more difficult.2. Make very sure that you have adjusted it properly, and your hips are at the exact same height when your "feet" (the good foot and the crutch foot) are together. If it's not adjusted properly, it can cause serious back pain. At first I had it too high, because I adjusted it wearing shoes, and ended up mostly wearing slippers. That caused excruciating pain in my lower back on the injured-foot side - the muscle used to raise the leg in the crutch. When I lowered the height, I lost track of what hole the peg had been in, and lowered it too much. That caused a different kind of back pain. I finally got it right, and I have no back pain anymore. I read in the company's description that you'll have pain in some leg muscles at first. I never had any sore muscles in my legs - but then again, I have strong legs.3. It's tiring to use, especially at first when you're using muscles in ways they're not used to. The first week I used it, I would get very overheated after walking around a bit, and couldn't figure out why. Eventually I realized it was exertion from using the knee crutch. You get a workout! After 2 weeks, it's easier, but it still puts unnatural stress on the body. It becomes uncomfortable if I'm on my feet too long. After an hour or two, the knee in the crutch starts to ache from the pressure of my weight, and my good leg gets really tired from doing so much extra work.So it's not perfect, but it's very, very good. I'm very grateful to whoever thought of this thing.One other tip... As I said, I live on the 5th floor of a walk-up, and that's a lot of stairs. I have found that it's easiest to go down the stairs backwards. Sideways, you have to be very careful not to bump your injured foot, and in a narrow staircase, sometimes there's no avoiding it. Backwards still takes two hands (one on bannister, one on cane), patience, and concentration, but it's much easier.

This is a very cheaply made device. I bought a pair of them, and when I first took them out of the box, I was concerned at the flimsiness of the switch you use to select between transmit and receive. But I remained optimistic (for a while). I paired the two devices and enjoyed that I could move the transmitter around and the receiver would pick it up without having to re-pair.But the next day, when I went to turn them on, the device set as the receiver started flashing red. I'd only used it for an hour or two so I couldn't see how the battery could be drained already, but I tried plugging it into power again. Though I left it there for hours, the charging light never came on. I went to the Avantree Web site to request support, and saw it's a Chinese company. No wonder. It's very cheaply made, and most likely the battery is faulty.This is a very poorly built device, and whether it works for you will be hit or miss. I'm returning the pair of them and looking for similar products from companies that can build reliable electronics. I would not buy from this company again.

This is an on-ear (versus over-ear) headset, so there is major sound leakage. If you are looking for a headset with good sound isolation, forget this one. Also, I find it quite uncomfortable because I don't like things pressing against my ears - even soft things - which is why I (try to) only buy over-ear headsets. I thought that's what this was because of the misleading first review that says (erroneously) that it has excellent sound isolation. It has no sound isolation. You hear everything around you, and everyone can hear what you're listening to. I'm returning it for this reason.That said, the sound quality and microphone quality are quite good. So too bad that the ear cups are uncomfortable and don't isolate sound.I was able to pair it with my Windows 7 computer, but NOT with my Surface Pro running Windows 8.1. I didn't research this to find out why because I'm returning the headset, but I think it's a problem with Windows 8.1, not the headset.
This coconut flour is weirdly dark in color (burnt, maybe?), and the taste and smell is too strong. Not usable. Yuck.

This is a disgusting product. It's the first palm sugar I've bought, so I don't know if it's the brand or palm sugar in general, but STAY AWAY. It is not sweet - if you put some on your tongue, you want to rinse out your mouth. It tastes awful.

I was very disappointed in this speaker. I read a lot of positive reviews before buying, and it didn't come close to the promise.First of all, the sound quality is poor - not mediocre, poor. It can get loud, but there is distortion and some fuzziness. It is not the crystal clear sound you hope for by a mile. It's tolerable for speech, but with music it would give me a headache.Second, there are serious stalls and drop-outs. I did a reset of the unit per tech support and the drop-outs became shorter, but they didn't stop. For every 10-15 minutes of listening, there would be a drop out as short as 10 seconds or as long as a minute. When I tried to use it with Skype, the microphone would always cut out about 10 minutes into the call and never come back.Last but not least, there is a conflict between the driver for this speaker and the standard Bluetooth mouse driver on Windows. When the speaker was connected to my computer, my BT mouse would lose connection and I couldn't get it back. I wasted DAYS trying to find the problem before I realized it was directly related to whether the speaker was connected. When it was not, the mouse worked perfectly. When it was, the mouse would disconnect and I could not reconnect it. At first I made the mistake of removing the pairing with the mouse, but then the mouse could not be paired at all. I had to do the thing of removing the battery the holding the power button for a while to clear saved settings before I could get it to pair again (and it took me a LONG time to figure that out). Eventually I discovered I could get the mouse to reconnect if I turned off the BT radio then turned it back on. But who wants to be doing that 100 times a day. And it's all the fault of this speaker's driver. The mouse driver is the default BT mouse driver - used with a Microsoft mouse on a Windows notebook. I wasted so much time tracking this down.I have come to hate the UE Boom and I am returning it.

This is the best of the xylitol-sweetened cinnamon gums I tried. It has a good texture - not too stiff - and the cinnamon taste is very nice. The taste disappears fairly quickly, but not as fast as other gums I've tried. When I re-ordered, I ordered this one again.

This was one of two xylitol-sweetened cinnamon gums I tried, and it is by far the worse of the two. The other one, from B-Fresh, has much better texture and taste. This gum is too stiff - exhausting to chew. Also, the cinnamon flavor isn't great, and disappears almost instantly, leaving you with an overly stiff tasteless wad that you want to spit out. I prefer this gum instead: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000RL81AI/

These look okay, but because they are woven, they don't give the benefit of vinyl's "waterproof-ness". If you spill something, it goes right through the holes in the weave - the table is not protected. A cotton weave might actually protect a table more because it would absorb what was spilled. On the other hand, woven vinyl is easier to clean than woven cotton.Although these mats don't provide much protection, they do serve my other purpose: they keep my dishes from sliding off the lap table I sometimes use to eat. The mats aren't sticky or tacky, but they have enough texture to stay put and keep what's on them from moving around.

My very small NYC apartment only has room for an under-the-counter refrigerator. These usually have "coolers" rather than true freezers - a compartment that is colder than the main refrigerator, but not cold enough to freeze ice cubes, meat, frozen vegetables, ice cream, etc. After extensive research, I finally found the one-and-only under-the-counter unit with a true freezer, and this is it!I asked my landlord to buy me one in July 2006, and he did, though it costs approximately double what under-the-counter units usually cost (what a guy!). That was nearly 8 years ago, and it still works perfectly (and silently - quietest refrigerator I've ever owned). It was manufactured in Slovenia, for those who care. I don't know if they are still made there, but I'd guess they are.When my landlord asked me which direction I wanted the door to open (what side to put the hinge on), I made a mistake. I should have asked for it on the other side. I didn't realize this was fixable until this week, so for 8 years I've been leaning over the door to get into the refrigerator and freezer. I've done some damage by doing this. I broke off pieces of the vegetable bin by overloading it and then pulling it out in an awkward way (not supporting the weight). I also (totally my fault) broke off the freezer door by putting excessive weight on it as I leaned over the open door.The vegetable bin damage was no big deal, but a working freezer door is essential. So after I snapped that off, I went to the Summit Web site (summitappliance.com) to order replacement parts. My email was answered immediately and the new freezer door and bin were shipped the same day. The manufacturer is located in the Bronx and appears to be a small company, making it easy to reach people and get whatever help you need.While I was on the Summit Web site (tagline, "Manufacturing specialty appliances since 1969"), I noticed that the CT66J lets you reverse the direction the door opens. Not all refrigerators let you do this at all, let alone so easily, and it's a very convenient feature. The manual has instructions, but I didn't have it for some reason (I guess my landlord kept it), so I downloaded the manual from the Web site. I started to do the reversal tonight, but after I removed the door (very easy to do), I found I needed a socket wrench to complete the job. So I put the door back on and ordered a cheap set of socket bits for $6. I'll finish the job as soon as it arrives. No more breaking things by leaning over the door!If you are looking for an under-counter-refrigerator, this is the very best you can buy. It costs more than the ones with a "cooler" rather than a freezer, but for me it was very much worth it. I am grateful to Summit for making the world's one-and-only under-the-counter unit with a true freezer! Finally I can store frozen foods, make ice cubes, etc. Plus it's well-made, very quiet, and customer service is excellent.

This is a really thick spatula - not very spatula-like at all. It doesn't really bend. If the edge were straight, it could be used to scrape pans in a non-destructive way. But the edge is not straight, it's curved, so it can't be used in that way. The curve suggests someone might use it to scrape out a bowl, but it's too thick and inflexible to be the best tool for that. A real spatula does a much better job. I bought this because it was purple and got good reviews, but I never use it. The other spatula I bought is a putrid green color, but works much better. (And the best spatula I have - very smooth, a lovely magenta color, the right size and flexibility - is sold only at Bed, Bath, and Beyond.)

The manufacturer of this cooktop, Ovente, actually modified the design of the cooktop after reading my original review. I didn't know this for a long time because my review was anonymous and they had no way to get in touch with me. Then a year after my purchase, someone posted a comment to my review saying I was mistaken in my description of the cooktop. This turned up the fact that the current version of the cooktop was now very different, and the problems I'd described had been fixed (see comments below). This prompted me to contact the company about an exchange, which is how I found out that they'd changed the design because of my review. The company rep I spoke to said they'd wanted to send me a replacement after the design change, but didn't know how to reach me. Now that they finally knew who I was, they were happy to exchange my original version of the cooktop for the new-and-improved model, even though I'd bought it a year ago. I had to pay to ship back the old one, but I have a full warranty on the new one.They asked me to revise my review once I'd had a chance to try out the new model (which, confusingly, has the same model number), so here goes...I am hereby changing my original 3-star rating to 5-stars.This Ovente infrared cooktop is excellent - all you could wish for in a portable infrared cooktop. There aren't many infrared cooktops made anymore because induction cooktops are trendy. I have a portable induction cooktop, too, and I like it, but not all of my cookware is ferrous, so I'm very glad to have a portable infrared cooktop as well. The Ovente infrared cooktop is well-designed, well-made, and you can't beat their customer service!!ORIGINAL REVIEW----------------------Original rating: 3-starsOriginal review title: Uni-directional temperature control makes this very awkward-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I bought this cooktop and a high-end single-burner induction cooktop at the same time. I use these two cooktops as my only stove, and I bought this so I would not be limited to ferrous cookware.There is only one thing I don't like about this cooktop, but it's a very annoying thing: the temperature control goes in only one direction (up). If I have the cooktop set to 4 and I want to turn it down to 3, I have to do one of two things:(1) Repeatedly press the temperature control until it reaches the top value (12) then starts again at 1 (that's a lot of button presses when I'm trying to cook), or(2) Turn off the cooktop then turn it on again so the temperature setting is positioned at 1, then click from there to where I want it to be.Besides all the clicks, what's especially annoying about this is, I have to make a mental note of the start number before I make any change, or I can't remember what it needs to be to "turn it down". I don't want to have to put so much mental energy (and button clicks) into controlling the temperature of a cooktop. It should take half a second to turn it down slightly, not focused attention and 6 button clicks. Turning down the temperature should be quick and intuitive so I can focus on my cooking.However, there are not a lot of options anymore for infrared cooktops. Most of the ones sold on Amazon are no longer made, and I didn't want to buy something that is no longer made. This is a very functional cooktop - it just has this one design flaw. But it's an annoying enough flaw that I find myself not wanting to use it unless I really have to (I need two burners, or I need a pan that is not ferrous and won't work on the induction cooktop).

I like this cutting board except for the groove around the edges, which drives me crazy. It serves no useful purpose (this is a cutting board, not a carving board), and things are always getting stuck in it. If I chop some onions, I can't then sweep them off the board into a pan because they get stuck in the groove. It also makes clean-up harder. It's a magnet for dust and debris, so I can't just wipe the board down with a sponge. I have to run it under the sink after almost every use. Exposing it to so much water on a regular basis means I also have to oil it all the time, creating an ongoing expense.A carving board for meat or poultry needs a groove because you are cutting something wet. A carving board also needs spikes to hold this hot wet thing you're cutting. This is not a carving board - it has no spikes. It's a cutting board, for prep work - cutting vegetables, and the like. It should not have that groove - it's a serious design flaw.It's a shame because the board is otherwise well made. Were it not for the groove, it would be the perfect cutting board. Lose the groove!

I don't know why so many people complained that this bag smells. It has a new-leather smell at first, but it's not the noxious smell some people here describe.The bag is generally well constructed with quality materials and nice leather (made in Italy) - much better than a similar Chinese-made bag I bought (http://www.amazon.com/Genuine-Leather-Backpack-Handbag-Pocket/dp/B001TEK22C/) where the straps ripped off after just 9 months of use. The Chinese-made bag was inexpensive, but when you have to replace it after 9 months, it's not so cheap. Penny-wise, pound foolish, as they say.The main problem with this bag is that the snap for the flap is positioned too high so the flap sticks up weirdly. It looks like a manufacturing flaw. Even if the bag was absolutely stuffed, the snap would not need to be this high. I wish I could move it down, but it's not possible.The other thing is, the design of the bag is not that wonderfully elegant. The aesthetics are just so-so, and the pockets provided are not as useful as the Chinese bag. I actually like the design of the Chinese-made bag better, both aesthetically and functionally. I bought good-quality leather straps to replace the ones that ripped off for not too much on eBay, but it's a pain to work with leather and I'd need tools, so for now I'm using this bag.I like "hand bags" I can carry on my back because it balances the weight. Carrying it on one shoulder makes my back hurt.

This is an attractive bag and (for me) just the right size - not too big, not too small. There are convenient compartments to make items accessible.I saw the warnings that it was not well made, but bought it anyway on April 5, 2013. One of the straps broke on January 17, 2014, and when I looked closely, I saw the other one was about to rip off, too. That's just 9 months after I bought it. I use it every day, but I don't abuse it. I've never had a handbag break in just 9 months.The leather is very thin - a thin veneer over fabric. You can get away with this on the bag itself (as long as you don't abuse it), but straps need to be strong. The straps get daily abuse just by being used. After just 9 months, the leather covering on the straps is chipped away all along their length, and the weak material ripped at the ends where it's attached to the bag. You can't skimp on straps.I like the bag enough that I'm looking to see if I can replace the straps with real leather straps. I'm finding that even one replacement strap would cost as much or more than the bag, and I'd need two. Bummer. No doubt, this is why the manufacturer used such cheap straps in the first place. Maybe I can find a cheaper way to fix it - still looking.The other thing about the bag is that the straps use that dumb zipper strategy so that, theoretically, you can use it as either a shoulder bag or a backpack. But this just gives you the worse of both worlds. It doesn't work as a shoulder strap when zipped because the placement is wrong so the bag hangs weirdly, and having the straps together at the top instead of spaced makes it sit wrong as a backpack. I never liked that zipper thing on backpack handbags, and most manufacturers do it. If the top of the straps were spaced properly, you actually could carry it as a shoulder bag, just like you can hold a full-size backpack on one shoulder. It's a shame that someone thought up this stupid zipper strategy and then every manufacturer copied it. If I can find some reasonably price replacement straps, I'll put them where they should have been to begin with, and then maybe I'll have my ideal bag.--------------------Edit: I found some low-price high-quality leather straps on eBay. I'll transfer the hardware on the original straps over to the new straps. Should work.

If you bought this tea before the company was sold, you don't want the one on this page. This one is no longer all-natural. It has artificial flavorings. But the company does now have an all-natural version - the "2014 formutation", probably due to popular demand. You can buy it here: Good Earth Sweet and Spicy All-Natural Caffeine-Free Herbal Tea (2014 version)I still have some of the original tea, from before the company was sold, and I also have the new tea purchased from the link above (not the product on this page). This morning I did a taste test. I took two identical mugs, filled them with identical amounts of boiling water, and steeped both teas for an identical length of time. The *NEW* tea is stronger, and honestly, I prefer it! The new tea bag weighs 1/4 gram less so it may have very slightly less tea in it, but the taste is stronger - lots of cinnamon.I uploaded a picture of the two cups side-by-side that shows that the new tea is darker (stronger). The new tea is on the left, the original on the right. I can't post the link in a review, but I posted it in a comment to another review, titled "Buyer Beware! Not 100% Natural Anymore. Artificial Flavor instead of Natural Flavor". Look at the bottom of page 5 in the comments to that review.[...]

Where do I begin.... First the product description is both incorrect and incomplete. Second, this does not work correctly with Android devices, particularly 10" tablets. It might appear to work okay with smaller 7" tablets that need less power.The labeling on the AC adapter says:Input: 100-240V~0.45A 50/60HzOutput: 5.1V (polarity) 2.1AThe polarity symbol is a solid line on top with three broken lines below it.Notice the input spec of 0.45A. This Web page gives it as 0.15A.The Web site says that the A port outputs 2.1A and the B port outputs 1A. The AC adapter itself labels the ports as A and B, but does not specify their output amperage (red flag - badly made product alert).The labeling on the DC (car) adapter says:Input: DC 12V/24VOutput: DC 5.0V/2AA: For iPadB: For GT-P1000The Web site says that the A port outputs 2.1A and the B port outputs 1A. There's something wrong with that already since the adapter itself says it outputs 2A. As with the AC adapter, the ports are labeled A and B, but their output amperage isn't specified.Notice how the DC adapter specifically says the A-port is for the iPad? By that they mean any Apple device. The B-port is labeled "For GT-P1000". That's the device number of the Samsung Galaxy Tab, so this means the B-port is for an Android device. They must have printed this when the Galaxy Tab first came out. Back then, it was probably a "Kit for the Galaxy Tab".Notice that nothing is said, on this Web page or on the device itself, about the A-port or B-port of the AC adapter being for iOS or Android. This is more sloppiness, and a serious omission. Here's why.The reason that USB charger slots are labeled for iPad versus Android is that iOS and Android detect whether to shift out of USB Mode to AC or DC mode - I'll call it "Charger Mode" - in different ways. In USB mode, the power draw is limited to 0.5A, the idea being that if you plug an accessory into a notebook computer, it shouldn't draw so much power that it screws up the operation of the computer itself. But if the USB device is plugged into an adapter that draws directly from a power source (an electrical outlet, a cigarette lighter), there's no need to limit the draw to 0.5A. The adapter can set the cap. To determine which mode to use, Android looks to see whether two particular pins are short-circuited. If they are, it goes into Charger Mode. Apple devices do it differently. I'm not sure exactly how, but the two pins are not short-circuited. That's the key point.In this kit, NONE - I repeat, NONE - of the USB ports, on either the DC or AC adapters, have the short-circuited pins that signal to Android devices that they can draw more than 0.5A. This was easy to see because the battery on my Nexus 10 kept draining while "charging". But also, I installed an app that can monitor the draw and charge and it was pulling at maximum only about 0.4A. A Nexus 7 requires 1A of power. A Nexus 10 requires 2A.Even if these adapters were operating as designed, the Android devices would be relegated to the 1A USB ports, so for this product description to make it sound like it's designed for Android and an Android device could draw 2.1A is just a lie.If you're not doing anything too battery-intensive on a 7" device, perhaps you could get away with a charger that is dribbling in only 0.4-0.5A. But on my Nexus 10, even reading white on black text - the lowest battery demand possible except sleep - was drawing more power than this charger was providing, so my battery percentage kept falling while plugged in. The best I can say is it fell a little slower. It did manage to charge the Nexus 10 when it was asleep and not being used at all, but this is not what was promised in the product description.This is one sleezy company. I've asked for a refund and a mailing label, because I don't want to pay for the return shipping. I wonder if they'll even answer.

*** [...] ***This is an update to my initial review. There *is* a problem with the BLACK SB6141 modems, but it's not what I originally thought.The BLACK modems are older than the WHITE modems, and ship with an older firmware version that had a serious bug (v1.0.6.3). If you are a TWC customer, BEWARE. As of February 2013, it was TWC policy to NEVER update the firmware of customer-owned modems. I don't know the policy today or the policy in other areas, but if your ISP will not update the firmware of any customer-owned modems (or won't update the SB6141, specifically), do not buy this modem!** Confirm with your ISP that they will update the firmware before buying this modem. ***My initial review repeated what a Motorola tech support person told me - that my modem was defective (constantly "flapping" - dropping the connection) because it was fraudulently sold to me as new when it had to be used - had to be used because it was black, and not the version intended for consumers. The black modems are non-retail - sold by Motorola only to ISPs. The white modems are the ones meant to be sold directly to consumers. He knew there were a lot of problems with the black modems because he was fielding so many phone calls, but he guessed wrong about the reason for the problems. Apparently, the BLACK modems ARE being sold new to consumers by unauthorized sellers (and thus are not under warranty!). However, they have older defective firmware on them, and the only party that can legally update the firmware per DOCSIS 3 is the ISP. Some ISPs - notably, TWC - refuse to do this as a matter of policy. Others, like Mediacom, don't support this specific modem.ALSO NOTE: The BLACK modems are NOT UNDER WARRANTY from Motorola because they were not intended for the retail stream. Only modems purchased from authorized sellers are under warranty, and authorized sellers only sell the WHITE modem.--------------------------The comments to this review contain endless arguments, mostly about whether the BLACK modems are new or used. The most recent comments challenge whether there really was a firmware bug. For the sake of the innocents who come by and read this review, here is the documentation.And by the way, the reason I know all this is because I was bit by this bug - BAD. I bought my own cable modem (a black SB6141) as soon as I could, and then the nightmare began. Everything you are about to read is stuff I learned on my own because TWC was of no earthly use at all. I work out of my home and critically need internet. TWC wasted months of my time and cost me thousands of dollars without ever finding the answer. I found the answer myself. No one at TWC even knew about the firmware bug.--------------------------NOTE: Amazon is probably going to remove all the links from this review (though they are very useful and don't link to products). If you want to see them, look at page 23 in the comments.--------------------------The link below is to a scan of the Motorola firmware update documentation, listing the defects fixed in firmware version 1.0.6.8. Firmware v1.0.6.8 is what the WHITE modem ships with. The BLACK modem ships with an older version of the firmware, v1.0.6.3.[...]Motorola added one "new feature" (optimized performance a bit better) and fixed several things, but here is the critical bug (and I quote):-----------------------8.1.2 Defects Fixed- A random connectivity issue caused by T3/T4 timeouts when operating in Upstream Channel Bonded (USCB) mode has been resolved. Previously, the SBCM would stop ranging on an upstream after a RNG-RSP ABORT is received from the CMTS for one of the upstream bonded channels, causing the unit to reset. Now the unit will not reset, but continue operating in Upstream Partial Service Mode, utilizing upstream channels that fall within the allowable DOCSIS upstream transmit power ranges. (SB-2790, SB-2643, SB-2638)-----------------------In English: Because of a firmware bug, the modem was over-sensitive to any kind of line problem, and lost the connection completely when a problem was encountered. The firmware update corrects this. Now, if one channel is out of range, the modem ignores that channel and uses the channels that remain in-range - i.e., the modem maintains a partial (slower) connection instead of dropping the connection completely.You can see from my modem log (which I saved) that the horrible "flapping" problem I experienced (constantly dropped connections - sometimes every few minutes) was caused by this bug. Look at the excerpt below. See how the T3 and T4 timeouts are causing "critical errors" (lost connection)?-----------------------Feb 22 2013 15:44:31 5-Warning T202.0 Lost MDD Timeout;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 22 2013 15:44:09 3-Critical T05.0 SYNC Timing Synchronization failure - Loss of Sync;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 22 2013 15:37:30 5-Warning Z00.0 MIMO Event MIMO: Stored MIMO=-1 post cfg file MIMO=-1;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Jan 01 1970 00:00:14 6-Notice Cable Modem Reboot due to T4 timeout ;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:00:00:00:00:00;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 22 2013 15:34:21 3-Critical R04.0 Received Response to Broadcast Maintenance Request, But no Unicast Maintenance opportunities received - T4 time out;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 22 2013 15:32:57 5-Warning T202.0 Lost MDD Timeout;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 22 2013 15:32:34 3-Critical T05.0 SYNC Timing Synchronization failure - T4 time out;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 22 2013 14:58:23 5-Warning T202.0 Lost MDD Timeout;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 22 2013 14:57:59 3-Critical T05.0 SYNC Timing Synchronization failure - Loss of Sync;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 22 2013 12:57:16 6-Notice D106.0 DHCP Renew - lease parameters time server-24.29.158.48;tftp file-?BBgdiSyUzLlFew0KMW7Z@CjFu2VTmP4thsTV83CGcYVp2JONZj0g3 modified;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 18 2013 10:37:25 3-Critical R07.0 Unicast Ranging Received Abort Response - initializing MAC;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 12 2013 16:32:29 6-Notice D106.0 DHCP Renew - lease parameters time server-24.29.158.48;tftp file-?BBgdiSyUzLlFew0KMW7Z@CjFu2U1F_xuMzGcv41OSB7zwsiEVTiiI modified;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;Feb 12 2013 09:21:10 3-Critical R02.0 No Ranging Response received - T3 time-out;CM-MAC=94:cc:b9:45:7b:0d;CMTS-MAC=00:21:55:cb:62:b0;CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0;----------------------Motorola released another firmware version shortly after the big fix - v1.0.6.10. At the time I gave up on the modem (since TWC would not update the firmware on customer-owned modems), this was the current release. I think it still is. Here's a link to a scan of the release notes for that version (see page 23 in the comments if Amazon deletes it):[...]If you read the "Defects Fixed" section, you'll see more corrections to timing issues - but the big problem was fixed in v1.0.6.8, which is what ships with the WHITE modem (the retail version).I'm now using a TWC-owned modem because of their adamant refusal to update the firmware on customer-owned modems. I still have plenty of errors in my modem log, but this modem (with its non-buggy firmware) recovers gracefully from the crappy lines and equipment around here.*************** BOTTOM LINE!!! ***************CONFIRM WITH YOUR ISP THAT THEY WILL UPDATE THE FIRMWARE OF CUSTOMER-OWNED MODEMS - AND THE SB6141 SPECIFICALLY - BEFORE BUYING THIS MODEM. IF THEY WILL NOT, DO NOT BUY THIS MODEM!! AS IS, IT IS FAULTY.THE WHITE MODEM HAS A LATER VERSION OF THE FIRMWARE - THE ONE THAT FIXES THE DEADLY "DROPPED CONNECTIONS" BUG. IF YOU WANT TO BE SAFE (NO MAJOR FIRMWARE BUGS AND A MODEM UNDER WARRANTY), BUY THAT ONE.

I love this little case, and since it was cheap, I won't return it. But unfortunately, it's not quite wide enough for my Motorola Droid Razr Maxx HD. According to the Amazon description, it should be big enough for my phone:Motorola Droid Razr Maxx HD dimensions: 5.19(H) x 2.67(W) x 0.36(D) inchesCase (from Amazon description):Bag Size: ~14.5 x 8.5 x 1.3cm/ 5.7" x 3.3" x 0.5" (L*W*T); Weight: 25gFit Phone Max Size: 12.5 x 7 x 1cm/ 4.9" x 2.7" x 0.4" (L*W*T); Strap Girth: 100cm/ 39.4"But (speaking practically) it isn't big enough. I can get it in there with effort, but it's much too snug. It's a shame because it's such a nice case - pretty, adequate padding, a zipper closure, an optional neck strap, and a handy outside pocket. Plus it's tall enough for the Razr Maxx HD, which most cases are not. Maybe my next phone will be a little thinner and it will fit.

I didn't mind that the interface was poorly designed. I didn't mind that it wasn't that great an equalizer. All I wanted it for was to balance the Bosc computer speakers (which otherwise can't be adjusted) that I'm using to replace the tinny sound on my flat screen TV. It was adequate for that, so I was satisfied. But I do mind that it died after 2.5 years. I know that as equalizers go, it was "cheap", but for what I paid, I think it should have lasted more than 2.5 years.First the sound got increasingly buzzy for several days, and then there was no sound at all. I thought my Bosc speakers had died, an upsetting prospect because they cost several hundred dollars. Then I realized it was the equalizer that had died. Annoying. It's not worth the money to replace it. The Bosc speakers sound good enough as they are.

Note that iPads have a 9.75" screen and very little edge. The iPad 1, 2, and 3 all are 9.5" long, 7.3-7.4" wide, and .3-.5" thick (the iPad 1 is .5" thick).The product details say this:"Product Dimensions: 1 x 11 x 9 inches ; 5.3 ounces" but many of the reviews here note that the iPad "fits perfectly". How can that be? A case this size would be too big for the iPad, wouldn't it? I'll tell you how that can be, having ordered this case and returned it. The listed dimensions (and weight) of this case are incorrect.This is the real size of the case: 3/4" x 10" x 7-3/8" ; 4.5 oz (with the tag, which I didn't remove). I measured at the shortest points, since that's what the zipper has to close over!As you can see, an iPad would fit perfectly in a case of this size, but a device with a 10" screen (like mine) would be too long for the case. A couple reviewers with 10" devices said they stretched the case over their devices, but that's a bad idea. Over time, either the stitching will rip the fabric or the zipper will break. The case is too short for a device with a 10" screen. If it were 11" long as listed, it would fit most thin devices with 10" screens. But it is not.This case has another significant problem in addition to the product description. The zipper doesn't have fabric lining as a well-made zippered case should. I have a zippered case for my iPad and fabric beneath the zipper protects the device when the case is zipped (Brenthaven 5103101 Ecco-Prene Sleeve for Kindle / Tablet / Apple iPad - Black). Also that non-square shape with the bulging corners is for a slip-case with no closure, like the one I bought for my Kindle. The sides hug the device so it doesn't fall out. In a zippered case, the bulging corners just add pointless bulk.If you're looking for a neoprene case to fit Acer or Asus 10" netbooks or tablets, here is one that truly fits: Case Logic PLS-9 Ultraportable Netbook Sleeve for 7-Inch to 10-Inch Netbooks (Black)I've had to return two cases so far because of misrepresentations in the product descriptions, so I hope this helps someone.

I have a longstanding habit of buying headsets and then not using them. Either they fall out of my ears or the way they feel annoys me or I can't tolerate the lesser sound and microphone quality. Not so with this headset. No compromises! It is so light and comfortable I don't even know it's on my ear. I can wear it all day without irritation. The sound quality is terrific, and so is the microphone. I left voice messages for myself on another line with this headset and then directly into my cell phone (voice messages that are delivered as MP3 files to my email so I could listen side-by-side). The sound quality is identical. I haven't tested the noise cancellation features yet.Plus it has a nice feature set. I paired it with both my phone and with my computer - originally with the idea of using Skype on the computer, but I also use Dragon dictation software. It's slightly inconvenient to switch between the two modes, so I had the idea that I could instead use Skype on my phone and then I wouldn't have to switch modes. That works - I can use the headset for both the cell phone and the Skype app on my DroidX phone. I also can stream audio through the headset and listen to MP3 files - I don't think every bluetooth headset can do that.I haven't tested the battery life yet, but that is supposed to be excellent, too.High quality components, good feature set, and moderately priced - what's not to like? I'm very happy with my purchase.---------------------------Edit: I had trouble getting the headset to work with Skype on my DroidX phone at first, then it did. Now I'm trying to get it to again and it won't. The earpiece works, but the microphone doesn't. I can't figure out why. So maybe that bit won't work. Wish it would. I did get it to work once, so I ought to again, but I don't know how I got it to work that one time.Ugh - the more I try to do it (I keep trying the Skype Test Call), I find that the headset is somehow frequently launching the audio app during the call. Why?? I saw mention in another review of the audio app on the DroidX being launched when trying to access Voice Commands. There is something wrong. Too bad.

This is a low quality part from China - same as something I ordered from another vendor that also didn't work. I should have known. I heard sound from the right ear piece but not the left (that might be the wiring of my phone, a Droid X). But the microphone does not work at all, and that's a problem with this adapter. Do not buy.I contacted the seller for a refund and have not heard back yet.

This company is sneaky. They use a very cheap low quality part in the place you are least likely to notice it: the microphone. The design is nice and the speaker quality is good; I can hear clearly. But people can't hear me well.I did several tests calling my voice mail with and without the Pop Handset. With the Pop Handset, the sound quality of my voice is very poor - there's a lot of noise and it's hard to make out nuance and expresson (critical for me because I do counseling over the phone). Sometimes it's even hard to understand what I'm saying. When I'm speaking without the Pop Handset, directly into my cell phone, the difference is dramatic. My voice is crystal clear. The microphone on this thing is terrible.I am returning the Pop Handset for a refund. Shame on the company for shaving costs at their customers' expense in a way they hoped no one would notice.

I'm here to buy a second one of these, and I'm noticing that all the 1-star reviews are complaints about the mouse disconnecting. I wrote a blog post with the solution to this problem shortly after I bought the first one. Here's how to fix this:[...]Personally, I think this is the best bluetooth mouse out there. Too bad Microsoft isn't fully supporting it with software anymore. I'll take off one star for that and the small size, but the small size works for me - I have small hands.I saw someone else say it doesn't work with Windows 7 64-bits. Not true - I've been using it with that OS for years.

The subject says it all - I only hear out of the right ear piece. There are three bands so theoretically I should be getting stereo sound plus microphone, but that's not what's happening. I'm getting mono-sound (right ear) plus microphone. That's not what I was purchasing. I have a Droid X.I think this is the real Headset Buddy and not a Chinese knock-off. I was attempting to purchase from Ace Photo Digital, but Amazon for some reason redirected my purchase to Focus Camera LLC. Still, the packaging looks authentic and the product looks like the picture. It does say "Made in China", but everything is made in China.

The boots are very well made, worth the money. They do come smaller in size (they're narrow), so I'd order a bigger size than you normally would to be safe. They're a beautiful color and do well in the outdoors. It's great that they even come water proof! I'd recommend these boots.

This printer is compact, easy to use and efficient. It fits perfectlyon my desk without taking up immense space like my old HP did. Theprinting quality is excellent.It is a breeze to set up on your phone. I use Brother iprint and scanapp, and it is easy to use. I can send faxes, scans, etc all by takinga photo to process the image, and then hitting "print". So convenient!The color photos are very professional quality. I do worry that thisink is a bit more costly in the long run then my old HP Deskjet, butthe quality of this product is much better then the HP in my mind andworth the few dollars more. Not to mention, there's a 2 yr warrantyand free phone support for the life of your printer, which is prettygreat customer service. I'm happy to say that this printer seems aswell-made as the Brother sewing machines, and I fully recommend thisproduct.

The Whim Bar Mops are 100% cotton. They absorb well for cleaning, arejust the right size, and come in handy with spills in the kitchen. I'drecommend these towels for easy cleanup. You could just use them as atowel for drying your hands in the kitchen.  Either way they workedgreat for me.

I've been a casual user of Office for years. Mostly for business purposes, with the occasional personal use. Primarily using Excel by editing or creating basic spreadsheets. Nothing advanced here, but it's definitely handy. As a Mac user, Apple obviously has Pages and Numbers, which work pretty well, but some of the features I use (such as Data sorting and text to column features) are not available in Numbers as far as I know.Since Microsoft made Office 2016 available as a preview, I've actually been using it for sometime. I'd previously been using Office 2011, but got a new Mac, and the installation got all messed up. Couldn't find the disc, but decided to try out the 2016 preview. It's worked nicely. Microsoft has definitely improved the visuals, and having everything be able to sync up via the cloud and iOS is a huge improvement over 2011.As I mentioned, I really don't use it a lot, but I use it enough to have to justify owning a copy. The Home/Student version is decently priced, but I do wish it allowed for at least one more Mac installation. I have a Macbook Air as well, which I'd love to have it installed on, but, sadly, MS doesn't allow more than 1 Mac. Thus, Pages/Numbers have to do for me there. Utilizing Office 365, obviously, solves this, but costs a little more than I want to put in considering my little use.Feature wise, I'm sure there are new things others have been dying to have. Again, for me, it does what I need it to do. I'm fairly basic, and simple Word processing for editing of docs, and basic spreadsheets are all I use it for. I've not tried the new PowerPoint (prefer Keynote anyway), nor One Note. Just do not have uses for them. Office 2016 does what I need it to, doesn't crash often, and allows for me to be productive on a Mac. Can't beat being able to do that, in my mind.

We picked up the $50 Kindle for my son and he desperately wanted a case. His favorite color is red, but they didn't have that available in this style. We opted for the Navy. For $15, it's not bad at all for a case. It has all the features/functionality of the more expensive cases, and still feels pretty nice. It's not leather, nor it is advertised to be, but is definitely made of PU (polyurethane). Often polyurethane items come not smelling great, but this did not.The outer cover is navy, while the inner is grey. It's a nice two-toned look. The kindle fits/slides in just great, and all the buttons are easily accessible. It only covers the sides of the screen, which is a nice plus too. Most cases cover the entire thing that I've seen in this style. My son is happy with it, and I'm sure it will provide plenty of protection for his Kindle. He loves that he can prop it up to watch videos as well.

I got this book for my 9 1/2 year old son. He's read it, and offered his comments below for review."Teen boat is about a guy who can change into a boat. He has a friend named Joey who can turn into an iceberg. Teen Boat's principal was a sailor before he was a principal. When the boat races are held, Joey is not on Teen Boat's team. Teen Boat ends up leaving his crew in the water, and wins the race himself. When Teen Boat's principal tells him to throw his trophy in the water, it gives him a path to Boatlantis. When Joey is at Boatlantis, she is friends with Teen Boat again. Pirates come and attack Boatlantis, they find if they use their powers together, they can make an ice boat. They freeze the pirates and defeat them as a result."As a parent, I'm always thrilled to find new books and series that my son enjoys. This is another one of those. While it is more of a comic book, it's still reading, and I, personally, never have any issues with my kids reading. He loves it, and that means it's a solid book to me.

We have been long time users of LeapPad devices. We started with the explorer, and have had pretty much every version since, including the latest Platinum. We've been happy with them in general, which is why we've continued to get them for our kids. There have been headaches with them over the years, such as apps disappearing, cracked screens, wifi not working, battery life, cartridges getting lost, and more.The latest platinum has been great, and has solved nearly all of our concerns (minus the time limits not allowing zero time), but upon learning about the Epic, I was very intrigued. This did seem like the ultimate device for my kids. My son around this same time decided he wanted to buy the new $50 Kindle Fire, so this has been a good comparison for us as we've now had both devices.Setup is pretty easy and as expected. Connect to wifi, add your Leapfrog parent account, choose the free app, and it downloads everything you've purchased in the past. It's great! I feel like it downloads content a lot faster than the previous LeapPad devices as well, which is an added plus.What I like best about the Epic is it can nearly become the one and only device. While my son does have the $50 Fire, he still has a separate LeapPad Platinum that he uses. That's works, but the Epic pretty much makes it so you only need one device. The fact that it runs Android tells is all. I love the fact that my kids can play their existing Leapfrog games (best part is it downloads them quickly and without cartridges) as well as being able to side load the Amazon app store. You still have full control over which apps you can download from Amazon, and allow your kids to use. This has allowed us to add Amazon instant video for kids as well as the Kindle app. Suddenly all the content from Amazon I get free via Prime is available on the Epic. My daughter, who uses the device, literally has everything I'd want her to have on one device. Again, comparing this to my son with the $50 fire and the platinum.As others have mentioned things like this, there are some great hidden easter eggs on the Epic as well. Things like touching the cat on the main street allow pops up the weather. Touching other things has other games and features, which make it all the more interesting for the kids. Main street (which is the home screen, btw), also allows for kids to add stickers and customize the look of the street. Stickers are basically things like robots that can be added and move around the street. Kinda cool.Leapfrog has done a great job on this device. I really do not have any complaints. It's a solid device. Performs well. Has expandable micro SD storage, allows my kids to use both Android apps from the Amazon app store as well as all of the Leapfrog games they already have. It's customizable. Able to grow with your kids. It is a fantastic tablet. For $140, it might be a bit pricey compared to say, the $50 Fire, but there is something to say about the experience. It's completely setup for kids in mind beyond anything else I've encountered. A solid, fantastic update to the Leapfrog line.

This trimmer is so versatile it could even be used for haircuts!! There are several lengths of guards to accommodate any length of beard, and it worked great going up the sideburns and along the sides. Very good product, comes with all the accessories and works great.

We have had an old baby monitor for sometime that need replacing. It often would disconnect. Having something that was wifi intrigued me, and I thought it would work great since it uses an app.Setup was pretty quick and by the book. Download the app,  connect to the camera, add wifi and user/password, and youâre set!The app itself needs some better design, but it gets the job done. It texts you if you setup motion or sound defection, lets you play 5 different songs, mute, talk to your baby, and more.Video quality is far better then our previous camera, and so I canât complain. We were even able to set it up on different iphones (mine and my wife's) just fine. A nice benefit.The only thing is if you have the detection setup it can get to be a pain. You have to remember to turn it off or the camera otherwise you might get a lot of other alerts if you have others in the room when baby isnât sleeping.Overall, we are impressed!
These earbuds produce excellent musical clarity and detail, with out undo loss of bass frequencies. Comfortable to wear and the mic pickup works fine. Does what they say it will do.

My 6 year old and 3 year old daughters have been into Dora for sometime. We have a LeapTV, and they enjoy watching the episodes.Dora is definitely a good size doll. The description says 11.5" which is about right. She has one free hand, while the other grips the dog leash. You then connect the dog, which has almost a bobble head, to the dog leash. It has a mini headphone jack connection. Make sure it's plugged in all the way, or the dog won't function properly. The instructions say to not plug the leash into any other device.Dora sings, she can have the dog do tricks, has removable shoes, as well as a removable skirt. She has lots of hair, and my girls love doing her hair (braiding it, in particular). On her chest is a light blue, dog image, which you can push to get her to talk. Since she talks, there is a power button, which is on her right-side hip.One major downside is you're supposed to stand her up to have her dog to tricks. Ours doesn't really stand up on her own. My girls end up holding her up, and then push the button, raise her hand, etc to be able to get her to speak and the dog do tricks.Overall, we're happy with it. My kids love it, and that's what matters. They play with it all the time, and, even better, they continue to have interest in learning Spanish (our native language, of course, is english). Nice benefits to Dora, and something, quality, that you can always count on.

We picked up this book for my 9 year old son. He's an avid reader, and we've been trying out a lot of different series. He's particularly enjoyed Jedi Academy, Diary of a Wimpy Kid, Origami Yoda, Diary of a 6th Grade Ninja, and Lemonade Wars. While I didn't read this book personally, I've asked my son his opinion of the book, as well as have obtained his comments. I'm all for letting my kids read whenever they can, especially to try new series and authors. It's good to have a variety. My son's comments are:"Isla is the fox who is telling the story. She lives with her 'Greatma,' brother, and her Mom. They are hunted by the furless, who are the humans. There are other foxes that live in different places and dens. One day, Isla returns to her den, and finds some foxes that she doesn't recognize. Her family is no where to be found. She has to leave her den, and go live on her own. She's also left to try to find her family. At the end of the book, she meets a fox, who is also looking for his family. He talks to Isla, but, sadly, Isla doesn't find her family. The book leaves you hanging."My son really seemed to like it, and he really wants book two once it comes out. It wasn't his most favorite book ever (that currently is Upside Down Magic), but he definitely enjoyed it. He read the book in about a week, and constantly told us how many chapters he had left, and well as his thoughts on the book. Again, I'm all for good, quality books that my kids enjoy, and this seems to be another solid option.

We received this for our 7 year old son. The first time, his 9 yearold sister had to assist him to put it together. The next time, he didit almost completely by himself. He absolutely loves building it andhas put it together countless times since, and is not tired ofrepeatedly taking it apart. The best part is, after it's built, he canshoot his siblings with the darts!I have not put it together so can't say how difficult it is, but hefeels the instructions may be wrong in regards to how it shoots thedarts. He says first you're supposed to pull the top lever, then youput the dart in, then pull the bottom trigger to shoot. But it doesn'twork that way, even after multiple attempts to do so. You only need topull the top lever as far as you can and as straight as possible, andthen it works very well.Not sure if that is my son's error or instruction error, butregardless this is an excellent product. It is very unique to buildand be able to use a toy--creates double the fun as the child had towork to make it happen. I think that's a big part of my kidssatisfaction. Great product, K'Nex!

My 9 year old son is an avid reader, and we're often getting him new books. He's loved the Origami Yoda series, Jedi Academy, The Lemonade Wars, Diary of a Wimpy Kid, Diary of a 6th Grade Ninja, and more. He also loves cats and magic, so we thought this would be the perfect book for him. After he read this book though, he said, "This is the best book I've ever read!"Some of his other comments are, "Nory is a girl whose father runs a school for magic. It's called Sage Academy. Once she takes the test at, she changes into a cat. She then is able to change into other stuff mixed with a cat. For instance, a dragon kitten. She gets put in the Upside Down Magic School where kids have weird magic. Elliot is Nory's friend. He is a flare, but he can shoot ice. Once they find a way to be normal, they use that to try to test to be in Sage Academy. Their friend Andres has to be on a leash, because he would float away. One of the flares burns accidentally burns Andres's leash. Then Nory turns into a bird, with a Nory head, and saves Andres. They still have to be in the Upside Down Magic School."While I didn't read the book directly, we're always thrilled to find good books that my kids enjoy reading. This one is definitely a keeper. Our son has been talking about it constantly since we got it. 5 stars!

We picked up this book for my 9 year old. The description sounded very interesting, and he was really excited when he read the description himself. He was eagerly anticipating its arrival. Once it arrived, he quickly delved in. I personally haven't read it, but am always looking for new books for my kids to read. After a few days, he was more than halfway through the book, and kept talking about how good it was. The next day, surprisingly, he asked if we could "return the book." We said no, and asked why. He said he didn't like it anymore. We were concerned, wondering if there was something bad or uncomfortable in the book. After questioning him further, he simply said it was "boring" during the part where he was. He decided to keep reading, and two days later he decided the book was "awesome again." Here are some of his comments about the book:"When Caw was 5, he was thrown out the window by his parents, and was caught by crows. Since then he was raised by the crows. He has the power to command crows. During the dark summer, a wave of crime and violence started up in the city cased by the Spinning Man. There is a family with a daughter named Lidia. They try to stop the Spinning Man, and Lidia ends up being caught by him. Caw reunites with his parents, and defeated the Spinning Man with the crow's beak/sword."For me, my kids can spend as much time reading as they want. When they find books they like, especially those that cater to their age, I couldn't be more thrilled. They're reading, and that's much more important to me than having them sit in front of the TV all day.

We picked up this book not realizing it was book two of a series for my 9 year old son. We realized it, of course, once it arrived. My son says, "The book was full of action. When they got to London, and were in the plane, it was the rain was red. It was fun. I really want to read the rest of the series."While I didn't personally read the book, I'm always glad to see a new series that my kids like to enjoy. We're planning on picking up the first book for him, and, based upon his reaction to this book, I'm sure he'll like it as well. There is a game series with this book as well that my son is now really interested in, but we haven't let him yet. :-)

We got this book for my 6 year old daughter. It seemed like a good one that she would enjoy, and after reading the description of the book, she felt the same way. When it arrived in the mail, she literally sat down and finished it in about 15 minutes. It's not a long read, almost a comic book like book like style with word bubbles. Lots of good pictures that help move the story along, which the first half of the book were in color while the rest were are all in greyscale. Not sure why?
