I also think that as a prequel/sequel it didn't show any spectacular originality that would have lifted it to 5 stars in my opinion. So it's a solid, 4-star, entertaining family film in my book - not a classic.

This is a fresh and wonderful book for introducing children to Buddhism, or for deepening their understanding. It features seven stories from the daily life of a modern, Western Buddhist family. In each chapter, the parents weave a Buddhist lesson into the family's discussion, helping the children to see its' relevance to their own lives.For example, in the first story, the children, Alex and Brianna, both elementary-aged, are playing outside and do not want to come into the house to do their homework. "I wish we could play all day long and all night too!" they cry. 'Mama' lures them in by promising that once they have done their homework, she will tell them a story "about a father who forced his son to play all the time."The son in this case is Buddha, and Mama tells the children the first part of the Buddha's life story, in which his father the King tries to shield him from all pain and knowledge of sickness, old age, or death. The king prohibits any sign of suffering within the palace grounds, and fills the young prince's life with play and pleasure. Eventually, of course, the prince learns the truth and is moved to seek the true end of suffering for himself and all beings.Other stories are more practice oriented, such as the title story 'In the Garden of Our Minds.' Alex and Brianna have both had a rough day, and are grumpy and out of sorts. Mama invites them to sit down with her and do a simple 'Breathe In, Breathe Out' practice to quiet their minds. She then talks to them about the 'seeds of the mind', and how to make choices that cultivate the seeds of calmness, compassion, and peace, rather than the seeds of anger, ignorance, or fear.The stories and lessons are definitely Mahayana Buddhist in content and style, but because they are dealing with introductory teachings, I feel this book is appropriate for anyone of any Buddhist lineage, or for anyone who is interested in introducing children to Buddhism. For example, in the final story, 'A Visit with Rinpoche', the family attends a dharma talk with a Tibetan Rinpoche, and he explains bodhisattvahood. While the bodhisattva path is a Mahayana one, and not as prominent in Theravada Buddhism, the focus here is on mindfulness and compassion as a way of developing bodhisattva attributes. These themes are such that any Buddhist could adapt them for their children, and any spiritual seeker of any faith could use them as the foundation for a meaningful discussion with their children.As for age range, this book is geared towards elementary-aged children, I would say 6-10 or so, although children older or younger may enjoy it too. In the Buddhist tradition of facing truth directly, some of the stories do discuss death, and in one case violence - the story of the finger-hacking villain Angulimala, who is transformed by the Buddha's compassion. I felt these themes were handled appropriately for my own children, ages 7 and 8 (who loved the book overall), but parents should decide for themselves whether their children are ready for these themes.The Appendices to the book include a glossary, as well as suggestions for discussing the stories and introducing children to practice. Part of the profits from all sales will go to the Tibetan Nuns Project and 84000 - Translating the Words of the Buddha.Overall a great offering, and highly recommended!

Unlike many other YA dystopian trilogies, the final novel in this one didn't disappoint. It certainly went in a different direction from what I expected, but as I accepted this, I realized the beauty of its trajectory. This is not simply a novel about a romance triangle, nor is it just an updated version of Farenheit 451. It combines themes of social rebellion (and the complexity of this) with themes of cultural repression, and then throws in a nice romance triangle too. In this book we move to 3 narrators - Ky, Cassia and Xander, and this adds a lot of depth. It's to the author's credit that this doesn't become too confusing. Overall, well worth the reading time.

I like where this story is going - so often dystopian trilogies fail to follow through on the promise of the worlds they introduce in the first book. In this case, I feel as if the world the author created has gotten more interesting. I also like the narration alternating between Ky and Cassia. I don't want to give too much away in terms of plot, but in this book they both escape Society and for part of it are searching for each other in the wilds. Once they find each other, they have to make difficult decisions about what to do next. The literature and art themes are continued and magnified in this book, and really trigger some interesting insights about the nature and purpose of language, art, and culture. That aspect of this trilogy is really what lifts it above the fray in my view. I usually don't enjoy the overly dramatic romantic plots, but I don't mind it in the case of this one, because poetry is the primary means through which the romance plays out.My only complaint is that I felt the pacing in this book got a bit slow, so I docked a star for that. Looking forward to the final installment.

My family and I enjoyed this more than I thought we would. I had heard it was a bit dark, and so was concerned my 8 and 6 year olds would find it too scary, but it was fine for them. It is basically a `prequel' to the Wizard of Oz, although you (or your kids) don't need to have seen that to follow this.  James Franco plays a traveling magician who is swept up into a tornado (or dream, depending on your interpretation) and lands in Oz, where through a circuitous series of events, he ends up as the Wizard. Dorothy and gang don't figure in this story, though both the wicked witch (Mila Kunis) and the good witch (Michelle Wiliams) do. The special effects are great, and the story, although not terribly inventive, carries along well enough. Overall, it's a good family film - perhaps a bit too dark for the preschool set, but elementary age and up should enjoy it. Let go of your attachments to the original Wizard of Oz, and just enjoy this for the performances and special effects, as an entertaining family film.

I thought this was an excellent movie with great performances, and particularly liked that it was something different. Bradley Cooper earns the praise he received for this role, playing a man with mental health issues returning home after being institutionalized, and trying to win his wife back and start a new life. Jennifer Lawrence is even better as a young widow with stability issues herself, who manipulates him into participating in a dance competition with her.  Every scene between them is spot on in tone, dialogue and depth. The supporting cast is excellent and entertaining as well. It manages to mix poignancy and humor with dark truth, and creates an entertaining and even heartwarming story.

First what I like: I like the idea of this book a lot - a bioterror plot with the clues centered on Dante's Inferno and related history. It provides a good setting for the kind of symbology and history that Dan Brown does best. I also liked the focus on the world's growing population, as I think it is something that should get more attention and perhaps this book will spur some conversation.The problem for me (and it's a big one) is that I just got bored too often while reading. Dan Brown of course has always had the tendency to go off on historical tangents, and to lead into them with ridiculous plot setups. I can forgive all of that if it's actually interesting. In this case, I just got bored with a lot of it. And the action plot and characters didn't compensate enough to re-engage me. By the end I was reading just to finish, not because I had to know what happened.So I'm actually being pretty generous with 3-stars, because I do like the idea and theme. I just wish it had all been better executed!

As a standalone chick-lit novel, I actually think this might be quite good. Unfortunately, as a sequel to The Devil Wears Prada, it's not. There is very little of Miranda Priestly (the devil made famous by Meryl Streep's movie portrayal), and the 10-year time lapse in Andrea's life doesn't quite work. Andrea and Emily (Miranda's other assistant in the book) are now best friends, and at the start of the novel Andrea's about to marry Max, a character she didn't yet know in the first book. Her boyfriend (Alex) and friend (Lily) from the first book do return eventually, but are not main characters.The story itself centers around Andrea's first year of marriage to Max, her doubts about it, and what happens. I can't say much more without spoilers, but I will say that where it all ends up left me a bit shocked and bereft. I had been rooting for a different outcome - not really a good thing in a chick-lit novel, as these are supposed to be about entertainment and happy endings. This wasn't quite a happy ending to me - that's all I will say.However, this book did keep me reading. I wanted to know what happened, I was attached to the characters, so in that sense it earned 3 stars. Let go of reading this as a true sequel, and just enjoy it as chicklit, and you may enjoy it more than I did.

This is a lovely children's book with a non-denominational and gentle spiritual undertone, especially for girls. It's an introductory chapter book with some black and white pictures, and I would say it is best for ages 5-10 or so  - the younger end of this age spectrum would need to have it read to them, but by age 8 or so, most of today's children will be able to read it themselves (both my 7 and 8 year old daughters read it themselves.) It centers on Betsy, a young girl who wants to play football with the boys in her neighborhood. They don't want her to play, but in her dreams she visits 'the golden room' and receives inspiration and advice for how to deal with them. She also receives clues that at first she can't discern, but that in a situation with the boys that arises the next day prove to be a tips on how to help heal one of the boys when he's injured. This event turns things around for Betsy, and helps her realize she may have other gifts that she can share. This book is meant to be the first in a series of books featuring Betsy and her energy healing/spiritual lessons, so I look forward to more!

This movie was a big hit with my family (husband and 3 kids - 8-year old girl, 6-year old boy, 6-year old girl.) Part of the appeal is that it is one of the few animated films that seems equally targeted to girls and boys - there are both a main girl and boy character, and just a tad of romance, but not so much for this to be a 'married happily ever after' princess type story. The nature animation is stunning, as is the view of the fairy world, and the human world seen from the fairy perspective. I loved the story (tho have not read the book so can't compare) and felt it was all carried off very well. Recommend!

I have read most of the YA dystopian trilogies that have come out in the last few years, and this one captured me more than I thought. I had originally held off on buying it, as the romantic looking cover and marketing description made me think it would be mostly teen romance fare (not my favorite.) But the world created here is interesting, and truly a magnification of certain trends in our current society - as the best dystopias are. The completely 'wired' homes, the tablets each society member carries (Prozac Nation anyone?), the faith in data and social engineering - it is possible to see how this kind of society might evolve from the fear created after a major catastrophe (we hear little about what precedes the creation of this one, other than references to 'the warming.') As for the 3 main characters - all teens, 2 boys and girl and yes, there is a kind of love triangle created - they are interesting enough. My main complaint with this first novel is that I didn't get enough of a sense of why they each did what they did, particularly Cassia, which is a real problem since she is the main 'voice' of this book. But the premise and story are compelling enough for me to want to read the rest, so that is mostly a win.

Pema Chodron is a master at presenting teachings in a simple and accessible way, so that anyone can read her books and connect with them. The only potential downside is that it's possible to be deceived by the simplicity and overlook the depth of wisdom actually offered. In the case of this book on meditation, it begins with very basic, easy to follow instructions on getting started with a meditation practice focused on the breath. If you are looking for a straightforward little book to help you begin meditating, this is a great one (and Pema offers many meditation CDs that you can use for guidance as well.)As this book progresses though, it offers many more meditation approaches, and insights that will be useful even to those who have meditated for a long time. Sections 2, 3 and 4 are devoted to 'Working with Thoughts', 'Working with Emotions', and 'Working with Sense Perceptions', and in each she invites us to actually use these as 'objects of meditation' - to invite them into our meditation and work with them as the foundation for our practice, rather than judging them as 'bad' and trying to push them out. This 'friendliness' as she puts it, really changes everything, and offers us the potential for deep understanding and healing. She offers many personal stories, and anecdotes from students, to support how powerful this can be.In the final section of the book, 'Opening Your Heart to Include Everything', Pema connects meditation to the awakening or enlightenment process. This is perhaps the most 'Buddhist' section in the book, although really I feel anyone of any faith interested in spiritual meditation will find much value here (as with most of Pema's books, this one is not targeted to those who define themselves as 'Buddhist'.) Pema offers insight into how to work with our biggest challenges in life as objects of meditation, and even to view them as opportunities for enlightenment. She discusses the role of belief in practice, and how to examine the 'firmness' we find in our minds whenever we are gripping a belief as reality. She discusses working with 'groundlessness', and the way of the boddhisattva, or as she defines it, 'becoming a completely loving person.'So overall, this is a great little book for anyone interested in learning to meditate, or needing to break through barriers in their own meditation practice. If you have already read a lot of Pema's book there may not be anything new here, but as always it is well done and has a lovely transmission behind it. If you are new to her work, and certainly if you are new to Buddhism, this book is a wonderful place to start.

Neither my husband or I have read the Jack Reacher books, so we watched this purely as a standalone action/mystery movie, and we enjoyed it. Cruise is riveting and believable as the aloof, intelligent Reacher with a mysterious past and semi-maniacal dedication to truth. The movie plot held our attention - it begins with a sniper picking off 5 people, seemingly at random, and leaving enough clues that he is quickly caught. However, as Reacher investigates, things become cloudier, and we aren't sure who is behind the shooting or why. The twists are revealed at the perfect pace - fast enough to keep you intrigued, but slow enough that you keep wondering if it's going to twist another direction. My only complaint - which is a common one for me - is the violence levels. I'm ok with a gritty story, and violence that is a necessary part of the plot, but some of if here just bugged me, such as the scene of a man trying to chew off his own fingers, or the one where a young woman is killed for knowing too much. Both could have been briefer and less graphic, and played the role they needed to in the overall plot. I assume they were part of the book(s) and they were trying to be true to this, but in my opinion it's time for Hollywood to ask some tough questions about the violence they portray and how they portray it, and to cut the details when it's an option. It's all gotten way to glamorized.

Works great for my allergy dog!  She's been on this for quite a few years now and her digestive system is SO much better!  The only negative is that it tends to disintegrate in the bottle so there is alway a bit of powder at the end when the tablets are all gone.

I just finished this book and it's a first time in a long time that I wanted to get back to reading a book as soon as I could! I truly enjoyed this book! The book was suspenseful, the characters believable and even the sci fi angle wasn't overdone so I wasn't reading about alien life forms or other far-fetched ideas. There is just enough sci fi - actually at times I found some of it to be quite believable but I won't spoil the book for you.This book definitely kept me reading and I can't wait to read more books by Joe Hart!  This was the best thriller I've read in quite some time! If you like suspense this one is quite good.

I really like the tomato basil flavor but I also like onion so I decided to give this version of lentil snaps a try.  The flavor is a bit milder than the tomato basil and seems to be less infused throughout the bag.  If you've eaten any of the peas or snaps before you might notice that some have a much stronger flavor than others in the same bag.  Overall these are ok but not my favorite and I doubt if I would order them again.  Sorry to say they don't taste like onion rings or funyums but they are definitely healthier!

This stuff is not bad at all but loving it?  Not sure I can go that far!  Regardless I needed to add some greens for detoxifying and I'd tried Chlorella in the past but had a hard time getting the amounts I needed as 30-40 pills was a bit much to remember.  I read the reviews and decided that I would try this powder.  I have also tried other "green" powders in the past but just couldn't get past the awful taste and even worse, the aftertaste!  But.. I decided to give it a go.This stuff is definitely the BEST I've ever tasted or rather not tasted!  It's quite mild and I even drink mine in plain water!  Believe me that's saying a LOT as most of the time I wanted to gag and hold my nose with the other brands I tried.  So, if you want to try greens this one would definitely get my vote as the most innocuous one and easiest to mix - I imagine in a smoothie it would be hard to tell it was even in there as far as taste goes.

I had to order a man's size because I needed an 11.5 and I wear a narrow shoe - but that wasn't the problem with these as I could actually get them to fit well with the laces.However!!!!  The tongue of this shoe, where it's sewn, has a hard lump where the stitching is that reaches all the way across the tongue right at the top of my foot!  The constant rubbing feels terrible and I'm about to give them to charity.  Perhaps with a thick enough sock it might be manageable but not for me.Very disappointed as I've worn other Puma shoes that are just fine!

Hopefully we'll never have to use it.  I've put these in two cars and neither one has fallen off - yet?  I put them on the left side where they rest on the hard plastic that houses the seat belt.  So far so good...  It's nice to know it's there and what others have said about the light is true - very teeny and can't see much with it BUT again... hope I never have to!

Having a narrow foot this slipper was definitely not narrow - at least for me.  The heel was much too wide and the length was a tad short.  I ended up having to return it so just beware it's not true to size.  Otherwise it looked quite nice.

I love this coconut butter BUT... I have previously bought it in the mini packages which are a LOT easier to deal with than this jar.  The jar has to be warmed or the coconut butter is solid and difficult to dish up..  Other than that it's awesome, great flavor!

Having lived through Hurricane Rita I can say that the book is quite well written and well documented.  For me it has personal significance and everyone should be aware that Katrina wasn't the only hurricane that year!  We had 4 tornadoes that blew the roof off our home and filled it with water/mold - it was a horrid experience that I don't wish on anyone else!!!

This slipper is quite nice, easy to pull on and yes it does keep my feet warmer than most of them.  Not having to worry about shoe size/narrow width is a blessing as well.  These would make great gifts for all your cold foot friend!  I've only washed them a couple of times so can't speak to the longevity of the heat??

OK so I read about this in Allure and thought I would try it.  When I got the package I was surprised to find it's a tube.  I have some L'Oreal Revitalift Miracle Blur with Sunscreen and I swear this is exactly the same stuff.  Interestingly, they both have equal percentages of active ingredients.  However, the Miracle Blur is 30SPF and the La Roche is 50SPF???  Hmm makes me wonder a bit.  Also I find that this product balls up on my skin on my neck and around my cheeks that is definitely not attractive.  Overall I might use it up but I won't ever buy it again!
Perfect!  Love these bottles, no leaking, can see clearly through them, larger ones have markings for measuring and stuff doesn't get on the threads!  So impressed they are just the best!

I actually bought these for a friend who loves mango.  She has told me that these are delicious!  So delicious that she's hiding them away from her husband and doling them out carefully over time.  She likes that they are a bit softer than most gummy bears because she has TMJ.
OMG, this is AMAZING!  I buy the big bottles but these are just right for traveling so I'm ready to GO!!!

I like this soap and yes it has a bit of a scent but not overpowering by any means.  The thing that I'm not sure about is that it doesn't lather a whole lot AND I've had a couple of times that the pump didn't expel any soap.  Hopefully it's just going through a new period and it will be better soon
This Eyeliner stayed on really well, has just the right amount of glitter and will dress up those gorgeous eyes of yours.  I'm pretty impressed overall, and it doesn't bother my eyes!

Really like this color!  I actually thought it was going to be more olive green than it is.  It's more of a celery green but it's still lovely, glittery and a perfect fall color!  I'm happy!  Of course Gelish is just the BEST nail polish too!

This is my second purchase!  This stuff is AMAZING - love that it's brown sweet rice and not white!  It's SO yummy with some coconut, fruit and coconut milk - I'm hooked!  It's delicious and I'm sure I'll be back often to buy more!
Awesome bottles!  These are great, and one can fit several on a shelf or in a suitcase for packing.  I'm very pleased with them.  I didn't need clear ones but those are equally great!

Great case, keeps my iPod happy and it's easy to see, easy to grab.  Fits perfectly with a screen protector (I hate when you buy a case that peels up the edges of the protector)... this one doesn't!  Hooray, I am VERY happy!
Yuck!  This stuff flakes like crazy and fell into my eyes!  When I looked in the mirror I had tiny blue spots all over my eyelids, cheeks, etc.  It's headed for the TRASH!
Best Soap out there!  Basically unscented, perfect cleaning, not drying in the least and LARGE bars!  I wouldn't switch soaps for anything and it doesn't make me itch!

These are AWESOME!  I have to drink clay/water every day in 4 oz of water and it has to be shaken quite a bit to dissolve the clay.  I LOVE this bottle - it's lid is tight, it doesn't even get water on the threads - just perfect!  I've bought several now for the house and for traveling - love that you can see through the bottle and know what's in there!

This is a favorite in our house!  Love the pockets - can transfer small notes or 3X5 cards from month to month and store them in the pockets.  We keep track of our water filters, floor cleaning etc. so we always know when we did something.  This calendar is particularly lovely this year with the sayings, the beautiful flowers/humming birds etc.

This stuff is AMAZING!  I've tried Nature's Way and a couple of other coconut oils but this one is just the best - to my taste that is (I know we're all different).  I use it on everything... in food, on my body, in my hair etc.  I wouldn't be without it!  I go through it pretty quickly so I always have one in reserve.  Oh and if you like coconut like I do PLEASE try the chocolate bliss coconut butter and the plain one too... on YUMMY!

My dog had to have eye surgery and I purchased this in advance because I didn't want her using a hard cone collar.  I helped her adjust to it with lots of treats and short times with the collar on.  The day of surgery I took the cone with me and the vet decided that she didn't need to wear it because she wasn't bothering her eye at all.  Oh well, I'm still glad I have it and it's a great alternative!

This stuff is working really well for my small papillon.  Overall I've seen a change in the amount of tartar on her teeth and I think my vet will be impressed as well.  She doesn't even seem to notice it's mixed in her food and although I still brush her teeth this is MUCH easier!  I'll be back to buy more!

This is my second bottle and it works great.  The fact that it doesn't have to be refrigerated is a huge PLUS!  If you travel or if you're like me and have to take one of these at lunchtime they are easy to tote with you.  I'm very pleased and the 30 billion organisms was exactly what I needed!

I finally gave up on trying to get a pair of these.  If the shoe fit, the toes were too short.  Also, with a narrow foot the shoe didn't fit the way it needed to.  I'm just adjusting to going barefoot instead.

I have been using this now for awhile and appreciate it's adaptability.  The only thing I've noticed is that for some reason it causes my skin to itch if I use it in the bath.  So, for hands, hair, cleaning etc. it's wonderful.

This is a gorgeous wig that comes in some very cool hair colors.  I have very short hair so this was fun.  It was packed very well and came out of the bag and box ready to wear. I have mixed feelings about the mascara, but part of that may be because I already have long, thick, black lashes. What I've found is that that it definitely makes my lashes look longer, but it also makes them look thinner by grabbing and clumping them together. Due to bad allergies, I have to make my own chocolates, which I do by melting chocolate chips and putting them in silicone molds. This set was on my radar late last year when people started reviewing it on YouTube.It's really a lot of fun, and encourages people of any age to be creative and try new things. I've used Rice Krispies, the insides of dried figs, and jam, for example.There are a few things I would recommend during use. First, the dispenser is nice and can keep the work area cleaner, but you may want to melt a lot more chocolate at once. I melt it in a bowl instead. By setting out aluminum foil, you can keep your work area clean and even easily clean chocolate off the aluminum foil (never put it in the microwave!) to eat or re-melt. Cleanup overall of chocolate is tough and messy. I run hot water and wipe it off whatever it's on (from spoons to bowls) with a paper towel before it starts hardening much.The only thing negative I can say about the set is that the yellow molds aren't as neat and chocolate bar-looking (I don't think) as the red ones. They're also a bit too tall. Additionally, I wish the plastic inserts for filled chocolates were silicone, like the main pieces in the set, as they may not stand up well to repeated use.Overall, though, this is a really fun set that encourages creativity, and sharing. I only wish the chocolates took as long to eat as they did to make! :)

My cat loves this canned food, and took to it immediately. While I can't vouch for the taste, it smells like chicken, and doesn't have a gross cat food smell like so many cat foods do.The texture is mostly very finely grained, with a decent amount of moisture/broth. She eats it mostly by lapping it up rather than biting and chewing it.It's also really nice seeing that the first four ingredients ("chicken, chicken broth, chicken liver, pork broth") are meat-based, and that it's grain-free. Even though I feed my cat some foods with other ingredients in them, they're obligate carnivores so that supposedly "healthy stuff" is mostly just hype directed at us when it comes to cats. There's no hype here.

Sometimes unscented cat litter nevertheless has a little bit of a smell, and this definitely had a bit of an odor, but it wasn't bad (not a sickly perfume odor as some can have), and once the box was covered, I couldn't smell it at all.My cat very readily used it, even though it wasn't her normal unscented scoopable. It clumped well and coated nicely. The container size was enough for one normal-sized box filling, so it lasted a week for one cat.The biggest difference I noticed was the weight. While it's not as light as non-clay litter can be, it was still less heavy than the normal litter I use, which was a definitely plus!

My cat loves these treats--she has had this brand before, but not these flavors (Salmon & Cranberries and Tuna & Cranberries). My previous cat didn't particularly like anything fish-flavored, so I hadn't really tried much with the current one. But she really took to these and enjoys them. (She's the type of cat where I have to keep bags of treats out of reach, or risk a chewed-open package!)I use them as rewards for teaching her tricks, and they're a great motivator for her since she's a food-motivated cat.One thing I would caution is that if you have a younger cat, the pieces are quite large. I'd personally only feed these treats to full-grown cats.

Princess Pinecone, who usually gets besieged with sweaters, wants a horse for her birthday--like all warrior princesses should have. But she ends up with a pony even smaller than herself, instead. The pony, to make things even worse, is a few bricks shy of a load, and has a serious flatulence issue.But Princess Pinecone is nevertheless determined to get her new pony prepared for an upcoming battle competition. As one would guess, as with any good underdog story, they're destined to win, but how I thought they would win is not what ends up happening. You'll have to read it to find out!This is a cute book, and the uniquely-styled artwork is fun to look at, detailed, and really adds to the story. Some parents may want to take note that the book terminology for the pony's "issue" is "fart," so it's a bit irreverent. That being said, this is a cute and fun, positive little story.

_Becoming Maria_ presents the story of the girl who would grow up to become the beloved character Maria on Sesame Street. As a child who grew up watching Sesame Street, as many people did, I felt I knew her. I even erroneously believed she was married to her Sesame Street husband, Luis, in real life, which made her character seem even more real.Included in the book are memories of Christmas, camp, the neighborhoods she was raised in, her father's drunken rages, and her mother's decisions to always go back to him. Other memories include her brother's severe asthma, and a trip to Puerto Rico--one of the few pleasant memories recalled. One of the nicest things I noticed was how much teachers believed in her and helped set her on a path toward acting. I wish this had been touched on a bit more concretely, as it is helps show what an influence teachers can have on children, especially those in dysfunctional family situations. It also would have been nice to know what they were seeing in her that led them to believe she would be a good actress.The book is written in first-person, from the age perspective of Manzano progressively through time. This makes the beginning a bit difficult to follow, as the author struggles with discerning who the girl Aurea is who lives with her family, or realizes that she has as many fingers as toes. On some occasions, the text almost comes across as a child's stream-of-consciousness. On occasion, I was stumped as to the age of the narrator at the time events took place, though I did greatly appreciate it being written in chronological order (from childhood to around age 20), as this can help a bit with orientation in time. Some of the stories are quite interesting, but the book is written in a way that even those that are interesting are told in the same manner as those that aren't. There's no real rise and fall of action, but rather a steady relation of stories. I personally would have liked to have seen the more interesting stories fleshed out a bit more. The book also would have benefited from moments of joy. Instead, it's mostly a progression of melancholic memories; at minimum, the tone has that quality to it.Incidentally, Sesame Street is not mentioned but in the very end of the book, when the author sees it on TV, and then goes on an audition.I could go into a lot of detail on content that some parents may find controversial or objectionable, or that some sensitive young readers may, but will just quickly list a few (there are more): drug use, alcoholism, strong language, child abuse, and spousal abuse. Because of the topics, I personally felt it was more a coming-of-age memoir suitable for adults. Not only due to its content, but also due to the writing style, I would personally recommend it more for adults or teens than its targeted age bracket. That being said, it could be of great encouragement to any kids in similar family situations, as it may give them hope that they are still important, and capable of great things.

This is a nice towel that is also advertised as a pet blanket, and my cat uses it as a blanket. It's a good blanket for her size (she's about 10 1/2 pounds). I like how the taupe color has a paw print so that it's not pet-specific. It's also a nice, neutral color.The microfiber is a bit difficult to explain, but it has a grip to it--so it's not really super-soft, but is more of a texture that grabs and holds on to things. For example, if I lightly brush my hand over it, I can feel it grabbing at my skin. So, used as a blanket, it has a nice habit of grabbing on to debris and keeping it there. That being said, if used as a towel, it definitely has a front and back to it, with the back lacking the texture of the front.Overall, it's a great little pet product that has more than one use, and it's a nice-sized blanket for cats!

The fourteen-count marker set comes with the following colors/scents:Apple--GreenBanana--YellowBlueberry--Dark blueBlue raspberry--Light blueCherry--RedCinnamon--BrownFruit punch--Medium blueGrape--PurpleLicorice--BlackMint--Medium greenOrange--OrangeRaspberry--Dark pinky purpleSweet plum--Light purpleWatermelon--Light pinkThe colors are vibrant and the markers write smoothly, with a scent that stays on the paper for a bit, too.I have plenty of Crayola scented markers as well, but the Mr. Sketch ones always seem more true to name to me. While I like all the scents in the Movie Night set (which I also reviewed for Vine) about equally, cherry is probably my favorite in this set. If you're not "into" repeats, blue raspberry in this set is somewhat similar to blue slushy in Movie Night, but there aren't any other major repeats in color/scent combinations.These are really good markers, and the scents make them extra fun to use! Well, all except for that licorice one . . .

I got my printer in January 2013, and have been using these since the sampler cartridge ran dry, and have been so happy with the combination that I helped a friend get the printer last year. When trying to find a new printer/ink combination, I didn't want anything fancy, and wanted the least expensive way of printing. It seems so many printer companies sell you an inexpensive printer, then "get" you with the ink. The best solution I could find was a Canon ImageClass LBP6000, along with getting these generic toner cartridges.Each cartridge lasts so long, I tend to miscalculate when I'll need a new one! To make it stretch even more, I often go into the printer settings to make the toner lighter, because it's still very crisp. Even when the toner looks like it's running down, I typically get a significant number of pages printed afterward, by removing the cartridge and shaking it to redistribute the toner. (I shake it over the sink, as the toner sometimes shakes out a bit.)I've never used official Canon toner in my printer, other than the small sample one it came with, and have had no problems. I've always used these.I received the product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion. That being said, please rest assured I have been using this product for quite some time, including other cartridges I got on my own prior to the complimentary one.

The possibilities are pretty limitless with what you can attach this camera to. If you don't like the thought of the sticky mount, it's light enough to attach via masking tape (although this can cover the controls, it's still usable)--although, I've only done this on things that are low enough to the ground that the camera won't get damaged if it falls. You can also purchase separate, more secure, attachments, such as one for a car and helmet/head.There are some things worth noting when deciding if this camera is right for you. Following are some things I was a bit disappointed in. There's no video on the recorder, at all. There's no viewfinder, no playback, nothing. While this is understandable for most applications, especially since it's an action camera and this no doubt reduced its size and weight, it still would be nice to have this on it so that a separate viewing device isn't always necessary. When filming by holding the camera, I feel like I have to be looking at three things at once--what I'm filming, the viewfinder, and the camera! The remote viewer is what you can use for a viewfinder, as well as a very simple to download app (which is nice for a larger view).Unfortunately, there's also no audio playback. To hear the audio captured, you'll have to transfer the file to an outside device, such as a computer, or plug it in via USB and watch it off the card that way.The camera view can sometimes lend a fish eye view to the recording--i.e., some distortion can take place.The controls are not intuitive. While I tried to get the hang of it right out of the box, I ended up having to read the included manuals and online helps before starting. For example, the few buttons on the devices have multiple functions, most of which aren't labeled.While I've listed mostly negatives, that's just because the other things you can learn about the camera are already listed in the product description. These are things to consider that may not be so obvious.As for the quality of the film and audio output, both are really good. The camera does what it claims, and since it's so light and small it's really not difficult to attach it to various things--I've even put it on a pet collar, and harness!

This is a fun Thomas the Train toy for young fans, and a nice spin on the old popper vacuum toys of yesteryear--with the option of floor hands-on "car" play, as well! The wheels, when moved, force a circle to pop up, sending a ball (sometimes) flying within the clear body of Thomas. Despite being clear, Thomas still looks like himself with his trademark grey face. As for details, the handle even creatively looks like a train track!There are two things I think would have made Thomas even better. First, there just aren't really enough balls inside Thomas for a lot of popping action. It would be more fun if the whole base were filled with balls; as they are now, they fill less than half. Still, the faster he goes, the more Thomas will pop. Second, the handle attaches with screws (included) and a screwdriver (not included). I was hoping that it would just snap in and out so that it would be easier to switch the way the toy works.It's really nice to see a toy like this that is creative, yet doesn't need batteries! And it's a fun spin on a good, old-fashioned toy.

This is an amazing laptop that I use pretty much on a daily basis, often for hours at a time. It's compact and light, and it has features you wouldn't expect to see in such a small computer. And it boots up so quickly! I clocked it at 10 seconds, even after getting all the programs I needed installed.One of the first things I noticed when using it was that it has two full-size USB ports, one on each side, which is extremely convenient for attaching whatever you might need--especially since it has no optical drive.The touchscreen works well and is very responsive. It's nice to have the option of a touch/track pad, touchscreen, or even adding on a mouse so you can navigate however you feel most comfortable.The keyboard is full-sized, but you do sacrifice a bit with the compactness of the computer, which may be a concern for those who do a lot of word processing or general typing. The chiclet keys, for example, are a different feel; the F keys are not separated into groupings of four as on a typical keyboard; and the like. Because of that, it's not as intuitive for people like me who don't look down when typing.Windows 8.1 is definitely not a strong selling point! But it appears Microsoft will hopefully be offering a limited time free upgrade to Windows 10. In the meantime, I installed Classic Shell to give it more of the feel of classic Windows.Edit: I originally gave the computer four stars, because its battery-charge status button and battery-charge status lights (all on the left side) weren't working. This made the computer's current battery charge level guesswork. The front status light worked, but that's basically an "all or nothing" light with only an indication of the battery being fully charged (off), charging (constant blue), or needing a charge (flashing orange). Thankfully, the computer also displays its current charge on the desktop, but it's inconvenient not being able to see the status without turning the computer on. That being said, the indicator light eventually started working several days after I got the computer. I turned the computer on, then held the button down for several seconds while the computer remained on. A little load symbol appeared on the desktop, after which point the LEDs lit up. There's currently no user manual, so I just wanted to mention how I got this feature to work in case others experience the same issue. It still doesn't work reliably, but is enough to (if I could) bump up the rating to 4 1/2 stars.The only slight complaint I have is that the battery doesn't last as long as I had hoped, since I tend to be on a computer for hours at a time. However, it's easy enough to plug it in. This laptop is really convenient for daily use, quick, and packs a lot of punch in a small package.

Amazon has these products grouped together, so I should preface the review by saying I have the larger, striped, rectangular basket. I would think the smaller ones would hold their shape better.I really like the appearance of this basket, and the color scheme. It pretty much fits in with any decor. This basket is large enough to hold magazines, which is what I'm using it for.Unfortunately, it's very floppy, and at this size it should probably be of thicker and stiffer "yarn." To give an idea of how soft/non-stiff the basket is, it ships flat. I think this issue will be different depending on the basket size you get, with larger ones being more prone to not be able to support their own weight. It's definitely not a bin you can pick up and move with ease, but more one that has to sit where you place it.As someone who crochets and knits, I'd also like to point out that these bins are made via crochet, not knit, stitches. There are telltale looks to each. While most people may not mind, you definitely don't get the look of knitted stitches with these bins.While the bin is attractive, it does have its limitations in being a bin that more has to stay put, due to its not being strong enough to carry things. That being said, it does look nice and is useful for stationary magazine storage.

I really liked this product for the short time that it worked. It helped add functionality to my Windows tablet so that I could hook up an external hard drive, flash/thumb drive, mouse, and keyboard. That being said, I dropped it and my tablet one time (from about waist height onto a plushly carpeted floor), and while my tablet fared fine, the metal part of this hub (the micro USB) end broke off, rendering the whole thing useless. Even though I was able to reattach the pins, it wouldn't register them again and wouldn't work.It also is unable to power things consistently, although this will depend on the device you're using and how much power it's able to send out to other things. For example, while you're typing on an external keyboard, you may suddenly find that the letters you're typing aren't showing up, and then later the keyboard will kick in again.It's nice to try something like this, and I did appreciate having it while it worked, so I'm giving it two stars. But it's not the best quality made item. It lasted a little over four months for me.

This set is a bit of a cross between a puzzle and paper dolls, in that the clothing has obvious matches for educational value, but the pieces can still be mixed and matched for creative fun.Here's what comes in the set: 1 blue and gold macaw (parrot), 8 hats, 1 Jolly Roger (pirate flag), 1 monkey, 6 pants, 2 (smiling!) pirates, 8 shoes, 1 shovel, 2 swords, 1 telescope, 8 tops, 1 treasure chest, 2 treasure maps (rolled and unrolled). The main pieces have magnets near the front, while the accessory pieces have magnets on the back.Since the set is advertised as being "wooden," it's important to point out that it's not wood. It's either fiberboard or MDF, leaning more toward a thick cardboard consistency and color. While this isn't important to everyone, there are a lot of people who would want to know this upfront. The wood grain you can see in photos is actually printed on a piece of paper. This is why I've removed one star.The set is best for horizontal play since the pieces can jostle off a bit, but they can withstand a little bit of upright/vertical play. Unfortunately, the backdrop has writing all over it, so it isn't really that useful for play purposes. That being said, this is still a really cute set, and it's nice to see paper dolls re-imagined in such a way that they can be targeted to little boys, too.

In a beginning that seems somewhat akin to A Little Princess, Amelia is at school when she learns that her father is missing and presumed dead. Sent to live with her paternal uncle and his wife, she's disappointed to find that her aunt is of the belief that women should be perfect little homebodies. Her aunt finds pleasure in shopping and other stereotypical women's pursuits, all while dealing with a nervous affliction, perhaps stemming from a horrible loss.Amelia is forced to flee this home situation when her friend, her aunt and uncle's maid Effie, injures Amelia's uncle when coming to Amelia's defense. From there, Effie takes her to the poorer side of London, where Amelia sees firsthand how people from Effie's class live. But her biggest concern is a trunk she was supposed to inherit. It has been stolen by her uncle, who hopes to sell all its contents off. Can she get it back in time?I really enjoyed the book, and found it to be filled with rich visual details, perhaps due to the author's background as a screenwriter and director. The only reason I'm giving it four stars is because the editing was lacking at times, including the text being in past tense, but sometimes slipping into present, paragraph breaks missing, and the like. This is something that I'm sure they could improve in future printings, and it's still worth the read!

This birdseed smelled so good when I opened it and dumped it out into a couple of bird feeders that I almost wished I could eat it! It largely attracted chickadees, as one might expect, but also titmice, juncos, finches, cardinals, and a squirrel.I normally just feed birds black oil sunflower seeds, since those tend to be a universal favorite, but it was nice to offer a little bit of variety with this mix. I also didn't see them picking, sifting, and dumping any of it, as birds can sometimes tend to do with a mix that contains things they don't like.

Grace wants to start a business with her local friends over the summer, but her mom surprises her by saying they're going to Paris, because Grace's aunt--who lives in Paris with her husband and stepdaughter--is having a difficult pregnancy.When they arrive, Grace starts to learn about the patisserie her aunt and uncle run. Aside from this, there are various subplots, such as Grace getting to know a stray dog she names Bonbon, and trying to get to know her cousin Sylvie, who can't speak much English. While she's in Paris, Grace is sad to find out that her friends ended up starting a business without her. As the book progresses, readers are also taught some history about Paris.The book is written well, but I kept feeling like something was missing from the story. While I normally enjoy American Girl books, and have been a reader of them since childhood, this one didn't hold my attention too well, and I found it took me quite a long time to read it. It seemed that, though there were many plots, none were delved into deeply enough for me to learn to care for the characters. I wish the author had focused more on one of the subplots, which would have helped with getting to know and feel for the characters. It seems instead that details of various things such as Parisian foods and locales were described, giving more a picture of the location than a three-dimensional view of the characters. It also seemed there wasn't enough conflict with Grace. For example, when her mom tells her in the beginning of the book that she can't have a dog, she just moves on to another topic; Grace gets upset with her friends, but talks herself out of it, and the like. Grace comes across as a sweetheart, but it would have been more interesting if there had been more conflict in the book, as a bit of added tension would have helped drive the story.

The illustrations in this set are absolutely adorable and look fit for a storybook. The clothing in the set includes: a dress, boots, hats, long and short pants, raincoat, shirts, shoes, shorts, and skirts. The other back-magnetized accessory pieces are a hay bale and shovel. There are so many accessories, the front pocket isn't really big enough to hold them all. The barn backing piece is more of a promotional piece and includes writing, so it's not really a part of the set.The accessory pieces have magnet sheets on the back, whereas the main pieces (Fran, Frank, and their pig and cow) have magnet sheets under the front layer. The magnets aren't super strong, so the toys are better for playing with horizontally, though they can be held upright and withstand a little bit of moving about.One thing that's nice is that the pieces are a bit of a puzzle, so this is not just a "paper doll" set. As I got this for a little boy to play with, this is a nice added aspect. The outfits can only be put on Fran and Frank in certain combinations. If boots are used, then they must be paired with shorter pants, and some pieces create very specific outfits for kids to figure out.I'm a "wood snob" in that I think things shouldn't be called "wood" or "wooden" unless they consist of wood or, at the very least, plywood--in other words, that they should have a real wood grain. So it's worth pointing out that the toy is made of fiberboard or pressboard and paper. Because of this, it's not very sturdy on the edges, and some of the pieces came with cracks and splits in the edges. The cow came with one horn's top layers detached and bent.Though the tote is nice, I wouldn't trust it to hold the pieces securely unless held upright, as some fell out during shipping. The pockets close with snaps, so there are plenty of gaps for pieces to fall through.That being said, the toy is still very fun, and the puzzle aspect of it adds educational value on top of the cuteness factor with the illustrations.

I had wanted nail dotting tools for a long time and kept looking around on Amazon for them. This is a nice set in that you really do get five different dotting tool sizes (not just one dotting tool!), plus one end on each one has the same size dotting nub.You can do all sorts of different designs on your nails with dotters, not necessarily limited to dots. For example, swirls, squiggly lines, pictures, etc. These are really easy to use, and the metal cleans up easily.Although I would give them five stars ideally, the white one in my set had a loose nub (it came right out). When I glued it back in, the acrylic housing got cracks in it, though it's so far holding together. Despite that, I would still really recommend this set to anyone who wants to try doing fancy designs on their nails.

I'm so glad I got this stand! Prior to having it, I'd try to prop my 7" tablet up on various things like books or pillows when trying to watch videos on YouTube. Not exactly an easy feat! I also tried to use a case not meant for it as a way to prop it up, but that usually ended in the tablet falling.While waiting for another tablet, I considered getting a case/stand specifically made for it, but it seemed a much better idea to get one that could be swapped between the two. This one is really nice in that it folds relatively flat, and it's really small, so it hardly takes up any room when not in use.The tablets I use it with are 7" and 8" (in screen size). They do wobble a bit when using the touch screen, so I'm not sure I'd go much larger in dimensions than 8". But if you have a smartphone or smaller tablet, this is a really nice, basic stand that can fit in with any decor and is adjustable so that you're not limited to viewing from one angle.

Because Pinypon are often listed as you-get-what-you-get items, I'll specify first off that I'm reviewing the blonde fairy with a grey pearlescent unicorn. My description applies to one fairy you might possibly get.The blonde doll comes with super-glittered blonde hair. The shown face has pink and green eyeshadow with pink eyes. The left cheek has a butterfly on it. On the other face, she has green and purple eyeshadow with eyes that are green. The wings are laminated paper-like fabric that's green and reflects purple in spots. The top is yellow and green, with a yellow butterfly on it and pink at the neck. One special touch is a painted-on necklace. The skirt is mesh fabric on ribbon, with little glitter details in the mesh. This is removable for more customization options. The shoes are green and really unique in how the ties/laces wrap up the leg (including meeting at an X in the back).The two special accessories are a butterfly--which is different from the standard butterfly accessory in sculpt and made from a pearlescent plastic--and a wand, which is also pearlescent.The unicorn has pearlescent grey coloring, which is really whimsical and a nice touch. It has a yellow butterfly near its left rear. Pinypon isn't very consistent with pets' neck widths, but it can swap heads with other animals that I believe are from newer sets.If your kids would prefer for their Pinypon dolls not to be whimsical, it's worth noting that the wings just slip between the neck and head and are removable (as one piece), so this Pinypon doesn't "need" to be a fairy.I had to give this set four stars because of some paint issues. Also, the glittering done on the hair is really messy, and on so thickly in some spots that it literally just chips right off. I soaked it in hot water to get some of the extra off, but it would have been nice if they had perhaps done a translucent hair with the glitter embedded in the plastic instead, or maybe if they had done pearlescent hair it would have still had a magical touch to it. If you don't mind your kids getting glitter all over the place, it's a cute set!

This Pinypon doll comes with light purple hair that sweeps to her right, and five little accessories. One of the unique pieces in this set, as it's often more commonly seen with boy Pinypon dolls, is pants. The pants have a rhinestone on the right pocket. She has glittery purple shoes. The top is a strapless white top with a pink glittery heart on the left.Her showing face has a star on the right cheek, purple eyebrows, and a winking eye. Her eyeshadow has glitter on it. The surprise face is open eyes (pink) with eyelashes and a half smile. This is a really unique face for Pinypon.She's really cute, although I have to admit that the top style is my least favorite with Pinypon. However, it's easy to customize them if need be, and she has other very unique pieces that are worth adding to your kids' Pinypon collection.The painting on mine was relatively good, so I'm giving it five stars. But with Pinypon, it's always four or five for me, depending on the paint job, which is pretty inconsistent at times.

This set (referring to the one with a girl with light purple hair and cat) comes with five accessories. There are some significant repeats with this set as compared to one of the Pinypon Collectors Sets (that comes with four dolls and two pets, from Series 1).It also comes with the cat (although with some painting differences, such as under the chin, a different colored collar, different colored bow, and a heart painted on the left cheek).The main repeat between sets is the face, which is the face with glasses on one side and a small open-mouthed grin on the other, both sides with purple eyes.The clothing on this Pinypon is very cute, with a t-shirt that has a little rhinestone on it. Beneath the skirt there is a special touch of shorts, so the doll doesn't need to wear the skirt piece and has more wardrobe options.This is a cute little set or add on, but it's worth noting that it might have some major repeat parts as compared to another set.

I got this set (the one with a blonde haired girl and brunette boy--which is showing as orange in the photo) largely for the boy in it, to give to a little boy. It's hard to find boy Pinypon characters, and when you do they're generally blonde. The face required some custom tweaking since the boy is very much a love face, which I can't imagine a boy liking. On one side of his face he's winking and has a heart in his open eye. On the other side of his face, he has a large heart in each eye, and a lipstick kiss mark on his left cheek.The female has a kiss face with heart mark on her left cheek on one side, and on the other side, three hearts in each eye. This side is really unique, as she has an open-mouthed smile with upper teeth showing. Her cloth dress is removable, and there is a red strapless top beneath.I'm not sure what I think of a romance theme for Pinypon, as I like to think of them as young children. But adults should be aware they can make some changes to the faces, if wanted, with nail polish remover, craft paint, and sealer. It doesn't yield perfect results (be careful as the nail polish remover may mar the plastic), but is an option if changes are desired.A real selling point to this set might be the special accessory pieces. Those are a box of chocolates, flowers (a single one and bouquet), hair bow, handbag in an unique style, two perfume bottles, and a wrapped gift.I knocked a star off because I had to remove some stray paint marks on one side of the girl's face. I wish Pinypon would have better quality control as it's often necessary to clean up the toys with water or nail polish remover.

1:20 Mins This is a cute, basic train with three cars (engine, car that can tote things, and caboose). It's really sweet that they included an old-fashioned caboose. I remember as a kid, the worker in the back would often smile and wave to people waiting in cars, and this is such a missed part of trains nowadays.The two bears have the same sculpt/mold, and while this is being picky, it would have been a nice touch to have them each different, and it would have also been an added touch if they could stand outside the caboose between it and the railings.The wheels move very smoothly, especially on a hard surface. You have to be a bit careful in handling the caboose as the top/roof comes off very easily, so it can't really be picked up that way.This is our third Green Toys toy, and I just have to comment on how cool the texture of the plastic is. It really reminds you of the recycled milk cartons the toys are made from.The attached video shows the train closer up.

2:19 Mins Shopkins are sooo cute!The sets are all different, so there's no way to review exactly what you'll get, but each set has 10 that are viewable through the packaging (including, in this series, one special edition frozen Shopkins), two mystery Shopkins in little yellow bags, four flexible plastic shopping bags, and one hard plastic shopping basket. The set also comes with a checklist, where you can see the names of the characters and how easy it is to find them (common, rare, ultra rare, or special edition). The bags and basket are big enough to hold all the Shopkins in the set. If you've never seen them before, each one is about 1" high.A neat extra touch to them is that a lot of them (10 out of 12 in the set I purchased) have a hole in the base so that they can be used as pencil toppers.The attached video shows the ones that I got in the set. Though this will vary, I hope it will just give you a representational view of what comes in a set.

This tablet is almost like having a mini computer. To show you how much so, I composed and posted this review using it! It's like having a miniature computer in the things that it's capable of doing.I did a lot of research while waiting for it to arrive, as I wanted the ability to use a full-sized keyboard, mouse, camera, flash drive, and printer with standard USB connections. The tablet itself just has one micro USB port. It can take Bluetooth products, but a way around this, and a way to spend less money, is to get a micro USB hub that has a micro USB and splits into female standard USB ports. Of course it will depend on the adapter and things you're plugging in, but I can run about one thing via the converter USB. Two seems to overtax the amount of power the tablet gives out, even if I have the extra part plugged into a power source. It also drops the mouse a lot, though that could be my mouse. Anyway, I wanted to mention this since it adds a lot of functionality to be able to plug in a mouse, keyboard, printer, camera, thumb drive, and other things that use a standard USB. There doesn't seem to be an adapter that will allow you to charge or power the tablet while using a hub, unfortunately. Installing a printer (or anything else not plug and play) can be a bit confusing, as you may need to check to see if your printer's manufacturer has free drivers to download on their website, as you can't install them via a CD-Rom.The tablet only comes with a trial of Microsoft Office, so I decided not to take the trial. The fact that it doesn't include a "permanent" word processing package is why I docked a star. That being said, Notepad is included, so you can at least do some minor word processing--like writing Amazon reviews!--if you decide not to accept the free trial offer. Aside from that, with the new Windows 8 you can install apps--there are plenty of free ones--surf the Internet, and use various Windows compatible downloads (like Firefox). It's nice in Desktop mode since you can use the full-fledged versions of downloaded software like Chrome or Firefox, instead of the lesser ones you have to use with an Android tablet.Aside from that, there's not much to say as it's pretty much like a miniature PC. Generally, a common statement is that computers are for content creation and tablets are for content consumption. However, I would say this is a bit in between in that you can tweak it a bit to make it more versatile. I do wish it came with a standard USB connection, but this workaround is okay for running a keyboard, and you can also use Bluetooth, as well. I would most recommend this tablet for people who don't like the limited capabilities of an Android tablet. I have both, and have to say it's frustrating at times in that I get sent to tablet versions of websites and can't do certain things like watching videos (depending on the file type used) on Android. This is like a miniature PC in the software it's compatible with, and it allows for some productivity, not just entertainment.

This is the first time I've read a Beforever book where I hadn't read the historical characters' books beforehand. Before I get into reviewing it, that kind of brings up a good point. Based off my reading experiences with the three I've read so far, I would think it best if girls read the historical series first. Otherwise, there are various spoilers in the books, telling about things that happen to the girls. As an example, right off the bat Caroline tells the main character that the British were firing at people and she helped with the situation. I'm assuming that was part of one of the stories in her six (now two) books.Anyway, on to the story! The setup is that the unnamed main character's mom has joined the navy and will soon be leaving the family for eight months. This is something the main character is understandably really sad about. Her mom gives her a family heirloom compass, and this magically transports her back to Caroline's time, during the War of 1812. This is the first Beforever book I've noticed that has a really quick ending if the reader decides not to travel to the past, after seeing how she can return. But where's the fun in that? Not choosing that quick ending, the reader can do such things as help Caroline's grandmother bake, ride on a navy ship as it chases a British ship, help a wounded sailor, or even just have a nice heart-to-heart with Caroline. Caroline offers life lessons to the main character, as her father has been captured by the British and is away, just as the main character's mother will be gone with the navy.The book was fun to read, and offered a good variety of adventures, from a ship adventure to visiting a hospital, to just home chores like sewing (not very well!) and helping Caroline's grandmother with baking.I'll be reviewing Kaya's book in this series next. While I was skeptical of this series as someone who grew up with the pre-Mattel American Girl, and these seem to change the series into more of a Magic Attic, more fanciful world where time travel exists, I do think they might help reluctant readers feel a part of history and more interested in the historical characters, and they're definitely fun to read.

Tara Kent is trying to put her life back in order. She's just broken up with her boyfriend. He wouldn't commit to a permanent relationship. She's hurt and angry that the man she thought she loved took advantage of her. Suddenly her life changes, she bumps into her old friend and classmate, Jesse West. He's now a successful Bull Rider. The chemistry between them is still there, but she broke his heart when she left without a word. It's been ten years. Do they get a second chance for a HEA? Tara appears cool and calm but Jesse captures her heart with his kindness and his sexy demeanor. Is she willing to take a chance on love? Jesse is a strong, powerful man. He has never gotten over Tara. He wants her in his life. I fell in love with him. What a hero! He is a man with a caring heart and a generous nature. I was pulled into their love story. This is a great start to the Hearts Of The West series. The West Brothers are addictive. I wanted to see them find their love. Jennifer Lewis writes with charm and humor. I always look forward to her books.

I've read all the stories in this box set and I've enjoyed them all. Daisy McDare is a talented interior decorator but she's even better at solving mysteries. Who would believe she's always involved in murder? Daisy is an interesting character. She is tenacious in her pursuit of the murderer and in feeding her sweet tooth. I loved her. She is a charming and humorous. Her sassy dialogue made me laugh and the secondary characters were perfect foils for Daisy. I loved the touch of romance that Gavin added. These stories are fast paced and well plotted. The identity of the culprit is always a surprise. K.M. Morgan keeps me guessing until the very end. This cozy mystery collection hit the spot. I'm looking forward to more of Daisy's adventures.

Chloe Cook is at it again. She's up to her neck in murder. When her friend, Hope, is the chief suspect in the killing of her demanding boss. Chloe knows that the Police have it wrong. It's up to her to track down the killer. She has the instincts and the determination. She'll find the truth and clear her friend. Kayla Michelle has written a charming cozy that is a suspenseful mystery combined with a sweet romance. Cape Cod and the people who call it home add color and humor to this story. Chloe is such a feisty woman. She's willing to put herself on the line for her friends. Her boyfriend, Dylan, makes for a nice distraction. What a charmer! I enjoyed this cozy series. The characters are charming and the story grabbed me from the first page. Chloe Cook Cozy Mysteries are a treat.

With his clan nearing extinction, Tor Matheson has traveled through time to find his chosen one. He is drawn to only one woman and will forever be alone if he can't claim his destined mate. He's a fierce and determined warrior, but with his fae-blooded Layla he is the gentlest of men. I'm smitten by these bear-shifters. Layla is very special. She has the power of thought which is a wonderful gift. She's also loving and feisty and doesn't take orders well. Let the battle of wills begin. I loved seeing Tor and Layla interact. When they are together, I could sense the love and desire. Tor must fight for what he desires. I loved the verbal sparring between these two and when Tor called Layla his 'challenging mate', I fell in love. These Highlanders are addictive. I love visiting and catching up with familiar characters. Joanne Wadsworth is a very talented author. I love her writing. She does a brilliant job. Her story is filled with non-stop romance and danger. The history and beauty of Scotland add the perfect background. I'm anxiously waiting for the third book in the Clan Matheson Series.

Joe Tesla should be on the top of the world. He's a successful businessman and a millionaire. Suddenly his life changes. With no warning he develops agoraphobia (extreme fear of public places). Now he lives in the underground tunnels beneath Grand Central Station. While exploring his new realm, he meets a mysterious man and sees to much. He is now a hunted man. Will he live to tell his tale? Rebecca Cantrell's new series is a rewarding story filled with suspense, political intrigue and mystery, The booksis set in the fascinating world beneath New York City. Joe Tesla is a multilayered character who adapts to his limitations and learns survival skills. Joe and Edison, his service animal, are an unbeatable team. All the characters grab your attention and draw you into the story. The plots are solid and the mixture of past and present add depth to the mystery. These books are addictive and I'm hooked! I can't wait for more of Joe's adventures.

Lisa Wellman is starting a new life. She's part owner with Simon Canterville in a bookstore. This is her dream come true.  Now she can devote time to her writing. Unfortunately everything changes when they discovers a body on the roof. Simon is now the prime suspect. To make matters worse her ex-husband, Daniel Fairhaven, is heading the investigation.  What else could go wrong? How about the ghost of Charles Dickens asking Lisa to help him finish writing his last book. It's official Lisa's life is out of control. The characters are so interesting. Lisa is a very determined lady. She'll find the real killer and clear Simon. I love her courage. She will not give up.  No man or ghost will stop her. Daniel is charming and dashing. I liked that he was there to protect Lisa. The hint of romance was a nice addition to this cozy mystery.  I loved the ghost of Charles Dickens. He made me smile with his pompous pronouncements. The story is filled with unexpected twists that added to the suspense. I didn't know until the very end who the murderer was. As always Joyce and Jim Lavene are masters at keeping the reader in the dark as to the culprit. They are a must buy for me. A Dickens of a Murder is a great start to this new series. I'm hooked already.

Delaney is constantly running from her past. Her mother was always at her father's beck and call. She followed him and dragged her daughter with her until she abandoned her to Aunt Reylene. These memories still haunt Delaney. She will never be that type of mother which is why she ran from Cal and his dream of marriage and a family. Now she's back home to see his father, Whit. He needs her help to continue his work. Can she face staying in Prophecy and being the next Prophecy bootmaker? Delaney and Cal are both larger than life. They're still in love, but fear and distrust keep them apart. However, sparks fly when they are in the same room. Their romance is as red hot as is their desire for each other. I liked these two and wanted them to find happiness and a future. I loved the touch of magic that the bootmaking added to the story. These custom boots provide their owners with good fortune and a bright future. What a wonderful gift!  This small town is filled with interesting and quirky characters. They add drama and humor to this romantic story. I was enthralled. A Love to Last is a page turner. I'm looking forward to more stories in the Prophecy of Love series. Kelsey Browning has down a wonderful job as always.

Lia Cassidy is a woman scarred both inside and out. Since the vicious assault that nearly killed her, she has fought to regain control of her life. She has worked hard and is now a volunteer at a remote school in the Costa Rican jungle. Suddenly her life is torn apart again when a drug lord attacks and burns down the school and kills two teachers. Even though he has made her his next target, she won't run away. The Delos Charity has sent Cav Jordan, an ex-Seal, to protect her. They feel an attraction and are drawn together. Do they have a future? This story is impossible to put down. The action is non-stop and so relevant in this age of terrorism. The characters are unforgettable. Lia has such strength and courage. I loved that she wouldn't let society and circumstances make her a victim. She is honorable and courageous. Cav is a man scarred emotionally by his military experiences. He's a deadly weapon but Lia gets under his rigid control and touches his heart. I loved their growing closeness. The fact that they could let down their barriers and reach out to each other was amazing. No one writes military romances better than Lindsay McKenna. The realism and understanding that she brings to her books is amazing. I'm looking forward to reading the Delos series.

Christmas at the Timberton Hotel is special. The beauty and peace people find there is magic. Strangers come to escape their pain and find solace and strength. I loved this story. It gave me a sense of hope. The characters are amazing. Mist is a special person. She has an instinct that helps her sense people's needs and the knowledge to sooth their pain. If you're looking for a story that highlights the meaning of the holiday season, Mistletoe At Moonglow is the perfect story. When I finished, I felt happy. Deborah Garner did a wonderful job!  Plus the cookie recipes are a nice touch.

Whistle Stop, New Mexico is perfect place for Ella Morgan to start over. She's alone and broken in spirit. Here no one will know her and she can be free of their gossip. If only life were that easy! Ella can't escape her memories of the fire that took her mother and younger brother. Her situation becomes more complicated when she rescues a young boy from injury and meets his grumpy uncle. Johnny is a handful and Tony Granger is overwhelmed. He doesn't need this beautiful stranger to distract him, but fate has other plans. He and Ella are thrown together constantly. Both of them are hurting. Guilt is their constant companion and they don't want to risk their hearts. I loved this story. It's an emotional journey filled with both heartbreak and joy. These characters captured my interest and I wanted them to find the happiness that they deserve. Whistle Stop may be just a dot on the map but I loved the generosity and kindness of the people who lived there. Jennifer Faye gave us characters that are beautifully written. They have a goodness that pulled me right into their story. The dialogue is touching and the storyline is filled with romance and emotional turmoil. There are some surprising twists that I didn't see coming. I love this series. These books are keepers.

It's wonderful to come to Whiskey Creek for a wedding and a wonderful new love story. Kyle Houseman can't let go of the past and his lost love, Even though she's married to his stepbrother, he still cares for her. Can he find happiness with another woman? Lourdes Bennett, a well known country and western singer, wants solitude. She rents the old farm house from Kyle. They click immediately but she's here so that she can write new songs to restart her faltering career and deal with the knowledge that her fiancÃ©e cheated. Kyle and Lourdes come to depend on each other for advice and companionship. They both feel the spark of attraction but have too many distractions to take it seriously. Kyle is such a good man. He's generous and kind. I cared for him. He has issues with his ex-wife who is greedy and manipulative. She won't let go. Lourdes is a at crossroads. She is afraid and unsure. His protectiveness towards her is touching. I wanted these two together but there were so many obstacles. I wasn't sure how they would get their HEA. Lourdes loves Whiskey Creek and the people here, but can she give up a career? Kyle is a keeper.  Brenda Novak has written a series that has me hooked. I love the characters, the setting and the drama. I never miss getting one of her books.

Tyler Mackenzie has always cared for his childhood friend, Jess, but nothing happened in the romance department. Now he plans to change that, he invites her to his dude ranch. He plans to show her how good they would be together. Can they be lovers forever? Tyler and Jess are a perfect couple. They both care about the other and want to be both friends and lovers. The pathway to true love is filled with white hot passion. The ranch and the isolation provide a perfect backdrop for seduction. I enjoyed watching these two find their HEA. Just be aware that Wild Ride is very sexually explicit. Cathryn Fox burns up the pages with this scorching romance.

I love the Witches Anonymous series and Dirty Deeds is the perfect addition. The story is fast paced, sexy and filled with humor. I read installment 7 in one sitting.
