I do not like tires that come out looking like they came in a plastic model kit and prefer the look of clean rubber tires, this did just that for me and I'm happy with it just for my tires.If you don't overspray, it doesn't take all that much product to do the job, I like to rub it in and around with a small cloth soaked with the same protectant.Works just fine on all the rubber seals around trunk, hood and doors also, should keep it supple and make it last longer in the Sun.Didn't irritate my skin at all and smells rather good, seemed to wash off my hands better than some of these type protectants.Never actually saw this brand before this, but will not hesitate to try their other products, since this one worked well.Not a huge deal, but don't care for the spray head much, although it produces a good spray, it is a bit wider/larger than most others and wasn't as easy to hold for me, but threads are standard on the bottle top so easy enough to swap out for another one from empty bottle around the garage.Still have to see how long it will last after application however,  will sure come back and tell you if it does not sty on very long.

No kidding, I thought my Wife's Jeep was as clean and shiny as it could be to start with... I couldn't believe it but these products took it past my previous results in making the vehicle look like new.  No hype, could not be happier with each and every product in this 3M care kit.This might be the toughest test for such products since the Jeep was looking good to start with, which should make it harder to impress with results compared to seeing it go from ugly, dirty and dull to finished etc.True, there are several steps and several bottles to use, but really could not be easier as each one does what it was made to do and you don't have to do the whole vehicle at the same time, just full areas to edges or corners.Although all items worked so well, I have to single out the Leather/Vinyl restorer as it did better on the exterior black plastic parts (mirrors, bumper pads, door handles, roof rack parts, rocker molding) than anything I've tried to date.  It's not promoted for that use, but I'm impressed andhave to say, I've been using one of the best known, most popular products for this many years now... will not mention the brand name but it's top of the line and advertised on all the weekend cars shows on TV.I do think it would be nice if you were able to get this kit with no microfiber cloths as many people will already have a good supply and it would cut the cost of "kit" quite a bit.  (not sure how they come up with the full MSRP "list" price on this after checking price on each item)This kit should really have a soft detail brush included to get around emblems/trim and into tight spots.Perhaps in place of one or two of the cloths if not in addition.If unsure, all products are available separately if you don't want all at once, you can build to the full "kit" as you are happy with how each works.I'm sold, I will now buy these 3M products instead of what I've been using for years... what more can I say.

FANTASTIC SSD...SanDisk memory products have always done well for me, but this is the ultimate in performance so far, and with no moving parts to go wrong should last longer than the PC system it's being used with.Can't add much more than what has been said already by other owners, this IS a great SSD and can live up to it's advertised specs in a healthy system.I've also tried it as an external drive using this case optimized for SSD;[Optimized For SSD, Support UASP SATA III] Rocketek USB 3.0 & eSATA Hard Drive Disk 2.5 Inch HDD Enclosure for 9.5mm & 12.5mm 2.5" SATA HDD and SSD, Support Windows 2000/ Me/ 98/ XP /Vista/ 7/ 8, Mac OS 9.1/10.8.4 aboveThat works very well also with USB3 being the only slow down, but that's faster than anything to date as well, I see no reason to be unhappy even when used as a removable external drive.One note however, for some reason it would not initialize, partition or format under Vista and had to be done on another Windows 8.1 system first.I was curious to find an answer at first, but since it now works fine with Vista I'll just accept the fact and be happy.I'll bet others do not have the same problem.Now let's see some very large capacity SSDs get produced so we can move all our files off of the old electromechanical drives before they fail.A great product from a great company backed by a 10 year warranty.

Seems a bit more warm color than 3000K, but same TCP units available in other temperature ranges if you need different.  Also available in 20 degree light spread for more "spot" look, and also in versions with more or less lumen outputNote that Amazon has mixed the review section for two different units sold, this one is 12V AC/DC with GU5.3 base and the other is 120V  AC with GU10 baseThese have a hefty build to them and weigh in at 2oz.I'd say you need to be careful if replacing light weight halogen bulbs that might only be held in by the two straight prongs of GU5.3 base, these might pull out in time from the extra weigh if the outer housing is not supported in frame.  I don't know that would happen, but seems very possible when not used with matching fixutre.All lighting is heading the LED direction and will not only give the same or better light output but will save a good amount on your electric bill and the world's resources.Always nice when you can buy something that will pay for itself over time and then continue to save you money.

Great deal for three ten foot Toslink cables and they work just fine.  Quality seems as good as any I've used reguardless of price.If you will run your Toslink cable in places where it could get hit when moving your AV components around, you might want to buy some with thicker outside covering to protect the fiber optics more.....  BuyCheapCables has those also.These even have protective rubber caps over the fiber optic ends  (don't forget to remove the caps before use)

Four star for "I like it" as it does do what it should and does improve the TV watching experience....although I'm not thrilled with the current selling price compared to similar units.  Perhaps the Denon will outlast all the others to make up for the higher initial cost.175 watts output divided between all speakers and it does boost volume and quality over what the stock TV speakers are capable of by a long shot.Playing music from my smartphone via Bluetooth to the sound bar produces some pretty nice sounds... Streaming Pandora also sounds good from the Smart TV / InternetAt first I found the maximum volume to be low, but I changed my hook up and used only the Toslink cable rather than what the quick start booklet called for (Toslink plus HDMI for non ARC connector)  Volume is now increased to a level where you don't need full blast.All hook up cables are included, unless you need longer than supplied to mount on wall or away from TV etc.Even an IR remote sensor extension in case your TVs get blocked by the sound bar in front of it.Included are;HDMI cable, optical digital audio cable, 3.5-millimeter-to-3.5-millimeter stereo analog audio cable, 3.5-millimeter-to-RCA adapterEasy to hook up with any sound connections you might have on your TV and to get started only requires you to select your preference for type of sound mode you want to use  and set the volume level.. Modes all toggle with same remote button so you need to watch the button lights on the bar to decode which it is set on.The Samsung smart TV we have it on does not have ARC (Audio Return Channel) on any of the HDMI ports so have it hooked up with Toslink digital optical cable which is the second best hook up in the quick start manual after HDMI.As default setting, the sound bar will turn on when you turn on the TV with the TV remote.  (can sense if the TV is on/off though cable connections)Turning the sound bar off while the TV is on will only see it turn itself back on again.  I do not want the sound bar on for all TV watching and only when I want it on so had to toggle the DHT-S514 to manual setting in order to get that control.Using the supplied IR remote control, it is difficult to know which "mode" you have it on as there is only the small LED button lights on the top front of sound bar to let you know your selection.From a normal viewing distance you can not tell what is what (perhaps you might memorize positions and icons at some point)When plugged in, the BlueTooth sub woofer (110-120V AC-no power pack) pairs itself quickly when sound bar is on,LED on the back of woofer case will stop flashing red and glowa green when ready.  Has it's own manual volume knob on the back also.Always ready for use, but wish it had an on/off switch so not using AC on standby all the time, I will give it it's own power strip with switchWorks well, sounds good...  always good if you need to turn it down a bit in my opinion.For more power and true surround sound you might want to have a look at another Denon home theater setup if you have the room for it.Denon DHT-1513BA Total 650 Watt 5.1 Channel Home Theater System with Boston Acoustics Premium Speaker SystemSpecs for DHT-S514 Soundbar;Rated output:Sound bar10 W + 10 W (4 Î©/ohms, 200 Hz, 0.7 % T.H.D)Subwoofer49 W (4 Î©/ohms, 60 Hz, 0.7% T.H.D)Frequency Range:40 Hz to 20 kHzHigh Frequency Drivers:35/64" (14 mm) tweeter x 2Mid Frequency Drivers:2 1/64 x 5" (51 x 127 mm) HHRT drivers x 2Low Frequency Drivers:5 15/64" (133 mm) woofers x 2Dimensions: (H x W x D)Sound bar3 9/64 x 39 17/32 x 3 5/64" (79.8 x 1004 x 78.3 mm)Subwoofer12 21/64 x 6 3/4 x 13 5/8" (313 x 171.5 x 346 mm)Wireless Technologies:Bluetooth 2.1 + EDR, A2DP, APT-X2.4/5.2/5.8 GHz triband frequency hopping (subwoofer)Rating Voltage:AC 120 V, 60 HzPower consumption:Sound barDC 24 V, 2.5 A0.5 W or less (Standby)Subwoofer60 WWeight:Sound bar5 lbs 1 oz (2.3 kg)Subwoofer13 lbs (5.9 kg)

No reason for this to be only in the Automotive section as it has many other uses for sure...It was a nice treat to find ~ NO assembly required ~ and is ready to use right out of the box!  These days that can be rareEasy to carry while folded and weighs in at only 9 lbs on the digital scale.5" wheels inclusive of the solid synthetic rubber tires (white) roll freely even with a load onboard, easy to steer and enough leverage with the handle to tilt the load off the ground.  Again, well designed.Metal and heavy duty plastic construction seems to be a good combo for strength and keeping it as light as possible for something that can move 150 lbsHandle has simple, easy to use push button facing up on the top cross piece to unlock it so it can be extended to the full 40" length from the 30" storage size... Whole cart is only 2" thick when foldedCargo platform and wheels fold up without need for push button or levers by just pushing the handle forward with a bit of pressure... opens and locks by just  pushing the cargo platform down with your foot... very smooth operation.If you need to move heavier cargo, check out the other Heininger hand trucks on Amazon;Max 275 lbsHeininger 5081 GarageMate HeavyRoller Personal Hand TruckMax 400 lbsHeininger 5082 GarageMate HeavyRoller Personal Hand Truck

Have no idea what went wrong but got a notice from Amazon that it could not be delivered because the Email address used....Trouble is, it was the same Email address I've used with my Amazon account for many years now.Amazon customer service was not able to find the problem so just had to cancel the order and purchase Amazon gift card at local brick and mortar store.I'm sure this works just fine for most people, but wanted to share my experience
Third one, but not because first two stopped working but because we have multiple devices that need the 10 watt output of this AC charger.Plus this part number comes with a four foot Micro USB cord

For an OtterBox, this is really lightweight.  I guess I'm just used to the Defender and the Commuter; both are really tough, double-layered, and thick.  So if you're looking for a slimmer case, but still an OtterBox, this might be for you.The Symmetry is a one-piece phone case made mostly of hard plastic with some rubberized accents for shock absorption.  It's pretty simple, but it works well and fits snug.But for me, I expect a bit more from an OtterBox. (Especially at this price)

For an OtterBox, this is really lightweight.  I guess I'm just used to the Defender and the Commuter; both are really tough, double-layered, and thick.  So if you're looking for a slimmer case, but still an OtterBox, this might be for you.The Symmetry is a one-piece phone case made mostly of hard plastic with some rubberized accents for shock absorption.  It's pretty simple, but it works well and fits snug.But for me, I expect a bit more from an OtterBox. (Especially at this price)

Just like the heavy-duty OtterBox Defender, the Commuter is made with two levels of protection: bump negating synthetic rubber, and rigid polycarbonate armor.  Unlike the Defender, however, the Commuter puts the rigid armor on the OUTSIDE, so it's your outer layer of protection.Personally, I like the Communter's design a bit better.  With the slick polycarbonate on the outside, it slide in and out of pockets easily without picking up lint or being resistant.  While this does mean that the poly will get scratched if dropped (WHEN dropped in my case) it makes more sense to me to have the soft rubber up against the phone.Also, I like the fact that the screen protector is separate.  This means that it adheres directly to the screen and won't move around or cause image distortion.Of course, there are drawbacks.  Mainly, the in form of port access.  Kudos for keeping the charging and headset ports covered and protected, but with the hard poly on the outside, it's a bit tough peeling back the rubber and keeping it out of the way when trying to plug anything in.  And the Silence switch is no easier to deal with.Regardless, this is serious armor and will keep your phone safe from most drops.

I'll cut right to the chase:Massive pain to set this up, but once it's going it's pretty good.The long version:This Q-See camera system with DVR comes with everything you need to get it up and running except a video monitor or computer to use as a monitor. (I've connected mine to a laptop.)The cameras all need to be physically connected to the DVR box.  They all receive their power and send their video feeds this way.  While the connecting cords are about 60 feet long, remember that you won't be running chords "as the crow flies."  If you want to tuck chords away or run them in corners of walls, that 60 feet runs out quickly.  (One 15x15x9 foot room could eat up as much as 40 feet of cable depending upon how the cable is run and DVR placement.)  As another reviewer noted: plug in and check all of your camera cables BEFORE you run them to ensure that they work correctly.  One of mine didn't.Also, the system uses separate power bricks for the DVR and the cameras, so wherever you set it up, you'll need more than one power socket open.Trying to use a Mac computer to control the system is difficult.  I had to go through multiple restarts to get the application to run, and even then it took forever to sync up the cameras.  Trying to use a PC is even worse.  The software is buggy and crashes often.  As much as I whined about the setup of the NEST Cam, this Q-See experience has converted me.Anyway, full marks for image quality of the cameras once the system is up and running.  Minus a half for a bad cable, and minus 1.5 for the horrible software.

Honestly, here's my review:Lightweight, comfortable, good bass reproduction with good fidelity.But, since Amazon wants me to be verbose:These are seriously lightweight.  Almost forgot-I-had-them-on lightweight.  This is a major factor in their comfort.  But the biggest factor: for on-the-ear headphones, they don't push or pinch.  They don't jam down against my ears, and that's a good thing.The sound is very nice.  Good bass reproduction (not amazing, but good) and the mids and highs are true.  For mobile device gaming, I'm a fan.They're compact, foldable, come in my favorite shade of orange and have a built-in mic if I have to take a call while playing a game on my iPhone.All around; I'm a fan.

It's tough for me to review a product that works as intended.  I feel like I'm just an advertiser for the thing.But, this 32GB USB 3.0 flash drive by Samsung just works.  And it works quickly.  Fast data transfers when connected to a USB 3.0 port.  Since it's flash-based, it's silent.  It's small; protrudes out less than 1/4" from the side my laptop.It works on Mac (Mavericks/El Capitan) and Windows 7 with no issues.I'm using it for old-skool sneakerware transfers between machines and it's doing a great job!

These sports headphones by Panasonic are ok.  Not particularly fantastic.While the "ear hangers" aren't uncomfortable, they're not exactly comfortable either.  Thankfullly, they don't pinch my ears, so that's a good thing.  But after 20 minutes of hard activity, they start to get a bit annoying.Cord management is good. Plus there.But the biggest minus for me is sound fidelity.  Lows are nearly nonexistent and everything sounds a bit tinny.There are better sports headsets out there for the money.

So many printers, scanners, embroidery machines, and sewing machines these days require less creativity and more computer skills.  The Brother CM350 ScanNCut is no exception.My first tip is to fully read the instructions.  The ScanNCut 2 doesn't come with an activation card -needed for wireless communions with other devices: computer, tablet, mobile phone- and doesn't come with a USB cable -required for use with computer if you don't have the activation card.  That pretty much ticked me off right out of the gate.  So while it says "wireless ready" and "cloud-based" blah blah, that's all useless unless you have your own way to connect it to a computer.Getting the machine set up and through its first cutting job isn't particularly easy.  But, after doing it once, it's not too tough going forward.The cutting results are pretty good. I can see this being useful for decorations, quilting patterns, sewing patterns, or even helping the kids with project work.Now the negatives are easily overcome, so really, it's more about how easily annoyed you are.  If easily annoyed by not-included parts, marketing rhetoric, or techno-speak, you should likely stay away.  If you can all that in stride and need machine that will cut out paper doilies for you, give it a whirl.

I am a klutz.  I drop my phone at least once a day.  So, when I bought my new iPhone 6S Plus, I insisted on getting the toughest protection possible for it: The OtterBox Defender.I've been using OtterBox products to protect my iPhones since I had the iPhone 4.  They've protected my electronics from myself time and again.The Otterbox Defender for iPhone 6 Plus/6S Plus is tough. First, it wraps your iPhone in a tough polycarb shell that has built-in screen protection.  Then, that hard shell gets wrapped in another layer of firm, rubber-like silicon; it acts like a rubber bumper: shock absorption.  All the ports (save the camera) are covered by thick flaps of the silicon bumper.I've already dropped by more phone more than a dozen times, and it still looks & acts like it's new.However...The flaps covering the ports are a pain.  Especially the one covering the Lightning connector.  I wrestle with it every night when trying to charge my phone. Sure, it's great for protection, but lousy for letting me access the port!I hate the built in screen protector. It messes with Touch ID just enough to annoy me from time to time and the plastic attracts oils and dust like a magnet.  Worse, it's a pain to clean.And of course: This case makes a huge phone even LARGER.  I can shim it into my back pocket, but just barely.  And while, yes, there's a belt clip, that's huge too!  Its like walking around with a stack of CDs glued to my hip.Personally, I tore the built in screen protector off and got one of the Tempered Glass screen protectors.  It's easier to see through, easier to work with, and a simple wipe with a t-shirt cleans it off.  Plus, since the Defender has high beveled edges, the screen is well protected.Anyway, in spite of the drawbacks, this is still the best protection for your iPhone 6S Plus.

Setup on my iPhone was a breeze.  Movement tracking seems to be spot on.  It's lightweight and wears easily. I do like the fact that it holds a charge for about a week.Pretty awesome is:  The alarm.  I have my phone set to "Do Not Disturb" and regularly forget to switch that off when setting the alarm on my phone... or I just sleep the noise of it.  But, a thing going BZZZ on my wrist: guaranteed to wake me up!However, I'm not sure how this thing tracks sleep.  I wake up one or two times every night, but the UP2 doesn't catch it consistently.And I don't know about other folks, but the band actually irritates my wrist.For me, the UP2 is hit & miss.

Here's what I did when I got the Rock Candy wireless keyboard:1. Unboxed2. Installed batteries3. Connected it to my computer4. Tested functionality (it works with Windows & Mac OS)5. Took it outside and poured Pepsi all over it.6. Let it rest7. Took out the batteries (and closed up the battery compartment nice and tight)8. Threw it in the top shelf of my dishwasher & ran it through a wash!9. Reinstalled batteries10. Re-tested itAnd ya know what? It works just fine.  I voided the warranty by sticking it in the dishwasher, but I wanted to really test out how washable it is.  (It very clearly says NOT to put it in the dishwasher on the keyboard)Now... little things you should know:1. The function keys are odd and don't seem to map correctly, and the volume controls don't work on a Mac2. This is NOT Bluetooth.  There's a little USB dongle that has to plug into your machine, so don't lose that! (it's tucked into the thick end-cap in the packaging)3. The key throws aren't what I was expecting.  It's not a satisfying click like a regular full-sized keyboard, nor a quick tap like a chicklet keyboard; it's somewhere inbetween.  Not really a fan of that.4.  Make sure you have a micro/electronics screwdriver set or opening the battery compartment will be a pain.Still, I plan on letting my local 6-year old use this as her everyday keyboard. If it'll survive a few more trips though the dishwasher, it'll earn its keep!

I'm a lucky enough guy to own a motorcycle with a sidecar.  This means I can haul around gear and another person very easily and comfortably while still having a full on motorcycle experience. Of course, there's no radio built into my motorcycle, but no biggie as I don't listen while riding... HOWEVER, there have been multiple occasions where music would be great at my destination.  The Planet Audio PSA4CB works great for that purpose.I managed to install the unit into the trunk of my sidecar (yeah, a motorcycle with a trunk!) and I built a small box to house the speakers.  Now, when I get where I'm going; I open the trunk, place the speaker box where ever I want, and stream music from my iPhone to the Planet Audio unit.  I'm very happy with this unit as it does exactly what I want.

Did you know that cats can be gluten intolerant?  Yep.  One of my kitties retches violently if she eats any sort of wheat product.  Which is a pain as a lot of cat foods use wheat as a filler.  But there's none of that in Solid Gold.  Better still, this is a "weight control" cat food which means my other cat can have it (he's put on a pound this year).But most importantly: they eat this food like it's a bowl of treats.As for the ingredients, you might see the word "meal" and become concerned.  However, Chicken Meal (for example) is the dry rendered product from a combination of clean chicken flesh and skin with or without accompanying bone, derived from whole carcasses of chicken, exclusive of feathers, heads, feet and entrails; according to the Association of American Feed Control Officials.  So it's just chicken meat and skin, possibly with bone; no guts or beaks.  (In the wild, cats do eat bird bones, so don't freak out about that... besides, it's seriously pulverized before going through a device called an extruder.)Here's the ingredient list: Pollock, Peas, Tapioca, Chickpeas, Turkey Meal, Pea Fiber, Pollock Meal, Chicken Meal, Potatoes, Dried Eggs, Chicken Fat, Natural Flavors, Canola Oil, Potassium Chloride, Choline Chloride, DL-Methionine, Salmon Oil, Taurine, Calcium Sulfate, Carrots, Pumpkin, Parsley, Apples, Cranberries, Blueberries, Lettuce, Celery, Beets, Watercress, Spinach, Dried Chicory Root, Broccoli, Spearmint, Almond Oil, Sesame Oil, Yucca Extract, Dried Kelp, Thyme, Lentils, L-Carnitine, Vitamins, Minerals, Probiotics.No cellulose, no wheat, no "by-products"; but lots of things that cats find tasty in the right proportions: salmon oil, cranberries, and watercress are good examples.Anyway, good ingredients list and my cats can't get enough!

"Carry Case" best sums up this offering from Case Logic.Yes, it fits 13" MacBook Airs & Pros.  Yes, the outside of the case is durable and shrugs off water.  It does come with a shoulder strap. The zipper is easy to operate, evern around those troublesome corners.But I'm underwhelmed by the interior.  There's generous padding on one side only.  The side that Case Logic imagines is the bottom, has very little padding at all.  Also, the liner that covers the inside of the zipper (to keep it from scratching your laptop) is rigid with zero give.As a carry case, this will definitely save your laptop from scratches... Just don't expect it to protect your laptop from a fall of over 3 feet.

First up: only stainless steel touches the contents of the Stanley Classic Growler.  That's good for multiple reasons, but most importantly: it won't impact taste!Next up: will it keep your brew cold and fizzy?  Short answer: yep.  Long answer: I washed mine out, rinsed it well, and filled it with ice water.  I let that sit for an hour to pre-chill the Growler.  I then filled the Growler with 64 ounces of ice cold beer. (That's a bit over five 12-ounce beers.)  Closed the lid, sealed it up, and let it sit on the kitchen counter for 24 hours.  When I opened it, the beer was still cold and still fizzy.Of course, this is just letting it sit untouched for a day.  If you were to open it up after 8 hours, drain off 24 ounces, seal it up... then repeat... the brew that's left will wind a tad on the flat side because: the beer will continue to bubble inside the growler, and with all that space to fill up... you get the idea.  If the growler had a way of injecting CO2 to pressurize its contents, that would be fantastic and keep everything fizzy.  But that's just the nature of the beast.Anyway, this puppy works as advertised.

Ethernet ports have become a rarity on new laptops.  But. whether it's for speed or security or whathaveyou, there are some times when a wired connection is a necessity.Most USB-based Ethernet adapters are hobbled by their insistence on sticking with USB 2.0.  USB 2.0 speeds just aren't enough to get you to real Gigabit speeds.  Thankfully, the TP-Link TL-UE300 uses USB 3.0 protocols which allow it to get (really close to) Gigabit speeds.I tested this dongle on an ASUS laptop (Windows 7), a Dell laptop (Windows 8) and two MacBook Pros (one Yosemite, and one El Capitan).  All four machines recognized the dongle allowed me to use it with minimal fuss. (Well, as minimal as Win8 allows for...)As for the dongle itself, the USB connector tucks neatly into the main plastic body.  This means that the connector should stay clean(ish) and the whole thing is easily tucked away in your laptop bag if you should ever need it.All that said: the main body (that houses the Ethernet port and electronics) is pretty thin plastic.  If I had a fat enough piece of heat-shrink tube, I'd wrap the thing for a bit of added protection.  It just seems a tad flimsy.Still, as a cheap Gigabit Ethernet adapter, it works well.

Take an Apple Airport Extreme, make it less flexible, paint it a pretty color, and you have the OnHub Wireless Router made by TP-LINK and marketed by Google.Both the OnHub and Airport Extreme require you to use an app on a device to program them.  Still, I'd give Apple the edge here as the Airport phone app is pretty intuitive; plus you can use the more "deep" desktop app with Airport. With OnHub: you have to use the phone app.Both devices use the most recent (as of January 2014) IEEE 802.11 set and SHOULD allow device throughput of up to 500 megabits per second.  Neither device actually hits that mark, and in my tests the OnHub was erratic.  Not only did its throughput speeds never get close to 500 Mbit/s, single-device speeds wavered greatly.The 802.11ac protocol set allows for multi-channel binding; meaning that the device should maintain a stable, fast connection even through walls as long you're within range.  But the OnHub router doesn't seem to use multi-channel binding; instead switching from 5GHz to 2.4GHz quickly, and then down to a single 20MHz channel. (Instead of other current routers that bind two 20MHz channels together for a 40MHz band.)OnHub claims (on their website: https://on.google.com/hub/) that you can get faster speeds, but I didn't see it.The whole "speaks your language" thing is pretty neat.  But I can see how it might annoy some folks.Honestly, the tech of the OnHub doesn't justify the price tag.  There are many other non-pretty wireless routers out there that will give you better performance at a lower price-point.  However, if you're interested in a pretty easy setup via your mobile phone, this is a decent option.

Right so.  This is a camera for monitoring your home or office.The Nest Cam connects to the Internet via WiFi, so if you want to use it, you need to have Wireless Internet to hook it into.  And yes, Internet access is REQUIRED. No, you can't just hook it into your local area network and monitor it that way.  It uses the Internet connection to sync up to Nest's (aka Google's) servers.  Those servers then server your video to you over the Nest App.Yes, you not only MUST have Internet for this to work, you must also use their app on your iPhone or Android phone.All that aside, the camera itself will give you an image from 360 pixels tall to 1080 tall. The camera also features: - Mic & speaker - so you can listen in and talk to folks through the camera - Night vision - so you can watch what's happening even at night - Digital zoom - just pinch to zoom on your phoneWhile the camera is powered via USB, don't think that you can hook it into your computer and use it that way... cuz that doesn't work either.The camera gets warm, but not overly hot.Now, the app:  The app gets 3 stars.  It takes FOREVER to initialize, FOREVER to find the Nest Cam, and is more finicky than a spoiled cat.  It drops signal for no apparent reason.  Oh, and worse:  If I get a notification that the camera picked up sound or movement and I don't check immediately: it won't load.  I then have to go to the live feed and search back to see the event.Worse of all: if you want to keep more than 12 hours of footage, you need to subscribe their service for $100 a year.  That's not too bad of a subscription fee, but be sure to add it to the cost of the device when considering it.I love the camera, but I'm not a fan of the app.  Maybe someone will find a way to make it work locally.

What is it?  The Linksys LGS108P is an 8-port Gigabit Switch.Why would I want it?  The LGS108P is pretty much a business class Power over Ethernet Switch used in situations where 4 devices need PoE and up to 8 devices need Gigabit speeds.  Devices that usually need PoE are things like monitoring cameras, Internet phones, and access points.It's silent, and plug & play.  The metal case also helps with the whole "peace of mind" thing.Anyway, if you need Power over Ethernet for multiple devices, this should works just fine!

So, I let the wifey try these out, cuz, no way would my foot fit.She says that the opening is a bit small and unforgiving; it was tough getting her foot in.Once in, sizing seems true.The footbed is quite comfy, good cushioning and comfy.Minimal arch support, so if you have high arches, this might not be comfortable enough for you.  For her (high arches) they were good for a few hours.Relaxed fitting in the body of the shoe, and plenty of give in the toe box.She'll be using them for quick runs or cross-training sessions.

Personally, I hate lighter fluid.  The smell, the residual taste... never been a fan.  So, I've been using newspaper and olive oil to start my briquettes in a chimney starter for years now.And now we have these Aura All Natural Fire Starters.  Per the instructions, I used 3 to start my charcoal. It took a few matches to get the starters going, but once they were burning, they did the job.These do seem a bit pricey when compared to leftover newspaper and a few drops of olive oil.  However, I'll happily pack these away as fire starters when camping. These are much smaller and easier to pack than a mess of newspaper.I like these and I have a few different uses for them, so I'm happy.

I use Neutrogena's "Rainbath" as my everyday shower gel.  So I'm used to a light scent that rinses almost completely away."Warm and Spicy N. 63" is *not* a light scent that rinses away. This is a big, bold scent.  I think this is what would happen if you mixed original formula Old Spice with Pinaud Clubman: manly scent, bold, as subtle as a brick on a 2 x 4.  That said, it's not *nearly* as olfactorily  assaulting as say, AXE.  So while it may not rinse completely off, at least it's not stinky.As far as cleaning goes, I found it great on my skin, but a bit harsh on my hair.I'll wear it on weekend, but my day-to-day shower gel remains as is.

So, right out of the box: these things look beefy.  Nice grip pattern, heavy material, and decent flexibility.However...  I wear medium sized gloves (as a motorcycle rider, I'm well versed in what size gloves I wear) and have slightly pudgy hands/thick fingers.  I found these cumbersome to get on and peel off again.  My wife (who also wears medium gloves, but has dainty hands) has no problem putting these on or taking them off again.  All this to say: slight warning on the fit.Next up: They work well.  For temps at 400 or less, these saved my hands from heat.  Better still, because they are silicone, they block moisture.  No steam, no boiling water, no beefy roast juice is going to soak through and burn me.  That said, I prefer to use these outdoors, as opposed to in the kitchen.Their 425 degree max heat rating means that I need to be careful around my charcoal grill (which can hit temps in excess of 600 degrees) but they are just too perfect for grilling to not use.  Their grippy exterior means that tools and tongs are easily manipulated.  They deftly block heat from the grill as work over it.  And I drop a glove, I can hose it off and keep going.I like em.  Besides the fit issue, my only problem is fighting with the wife over where they live; by the grill or by the stove.

So, first up: don't freak out because of the word "palm" in this sweetener.  This isn't the dreaded deforestation for palm oil that's destroying Borneo, Malaysia, etc.  They tap the coconut tree similar to how they tap maple trees.Anyway, as sweeteners go, this stuff is pretty heavy tasting.  The bottle claims to have a flavor like "rich caramel."  In my opinion, the flavor is more like molasses.  It tastes NOTHING like coconut.  It's a complex and rich flavor that I just LOVE in coffee.Ok, the bottle also claims this is a "low glycemic" sweetener.  That's pretty dang true.  As best as I could dig up poking around the Internet, Coconut palm syrup has a glycemic load about 1/4 that of white table sugar.  (If you find more liable information, let me know!)And lastly: gluten free.  Well, since they don't use any thickeners nor additives, there are no grains nor starches to add gluten in.You'll likely notice that I've glossed over the "organic" labeling.  Without knowing the country of origin (there's no information about where this stuff is actually from, just who the distributor is) there's no real way of gauging how truthful the "organic" label is.Besides putting it in my coffee, I've also used it as: a replacement for honey in Honey & Balsamic Glaze, a replacement for brown sugar in various glazes and sauces for fish and pork, and as a replacement for molasses in my own barbeque sauce.  It adds wonderful complexity to everything I've put it in.I suppose that for most folks the important bits are: tastes like light molasses and actually is low glycemic & gluten free.  Well, those are the important bits for me anyway.

The short version:It's bright, comes with its own batteries & charger, is easy to operate with gloves on, and works well.The long version:The Phantom Aquatics Impulse 1500 is sturdy, heavy, and comes with all the accessories most would want to use.I let the batteries charge up for 3 hours, but I wasn't paying attention, so they could have taken less time.No instructions were included, so I just guessed at how to take it apart... grip the light/control end with one hand, grip the handle with the other and twist.  It worked, but sure did take a while to unscrew.There are three separate O rings in the assembly to ensure water proofing. They are lubricated, and while extra O rings are supplied, no additional silicon lubricant is included.  So if you do need to swap one out, I hope you have some of your own.This is a seriously heavy beast.  Underwater it won't be a chore.  But on dry land, it might get cumbersome.  Still, with how unimaginably bright this flashlight is, I'm seriously tempted to use as a camping flashlight.Speaking of bright, the flashlight has three brightness settings.  You switch through the brightness levels by pressing the large, easy-to-use switch.The flashlight comes in a padded plastic case with the light, batteries, charger, lanyard and strap.  I had to fiddle around quite a bit to get everything back in the case after I'd taken it all out... but it all went back in.Anyway, it works, it's bright, and it's easy to use.

[Reviewing the 6 inch Gray Metallic Lightning cable]Ah, digital life.In mine, I spend a large amount of time on my iPhone for work.  Since I'm actually *working* on said device, I need it charged all the time!  With Location Services running for several apps, and Bluetooth on for just about everything, I burn through battery life rapidly. So, I always have an external battery and a Lightning cable on me.Like most folks, I prefer to use Apple-branded when possible.  However... a 6-inch cable is the perfect pocket-sized charging accessory.I've been using it on and off all day today with my beloved Jackery Bar External Battery and have had zero hassles.  Everything is running smoothly.The gray color is nice, understated compared to my other bright orange accessories.  The woven sleeve on the cable is aesthetically pleasing, but I'm not sure if it offers any real benefits other than that.  Connections work smoothly and aren't too tight as so many third-party accessories can be.It works and is perfect for my purposes.

I'm not saying that I know a lot about computers and computer networking.I'm not saying that I've been building & re-building & modding computers (PC & Mac) for the past two decades.I'm not saying that I've set up and installed 7 home networks and two business networks (wired & wireless).I'm not saying that I provided technical and desktop support for a large multinational company.I'm not saying I've designed and delivered training to hundreds of people on the history and function of the modern computer, computer networking, and the Internet...What I'm saying, if I'm saying anything at all, is that this thing would not work for me.I installed & reinstalled the WeMo app on my iPhone (6 running the latest version of IOS, if it matters to you) 4 times.I powercycled my iPhone 6 times.I powercycled the WeMo link hub 4 times.I reset (hard reset) the WeMo link hub 3 times.I powercycled the light bulbs over two dozen times.When the WeMo app wasn't repeatedly crashing, or the WeMo link wasn't dropping signal or spontaneously shutting itself down, the BEST result I ever got out of the system was the app connecting to the WeMo link hub and syncing with my home network.The lightbulbs were NEVER recognized by the app/link.I could never get the system up and running. I scoured the Internet to make sure I'd tried everything (and I had.)  After two hours, I gave up and called Belkin Support.  Since their best advice was to "powercycle everything" -which I'd already done repeatedly- I threw in the towel.I love the idea, but the technology doesn't live up to the promises.

As a Vine member, there have been a few times where I've thought, "Hey! What a great chance to try something I would never buy!"  And this was one of those times.As the owner of a ping-pong table, I've always found it difficult purchasing a new paddle for more than $25.  I suppose for me it's the same as paying more than $4.99 for a mobile device game... I just can't bring myself to do it.I'm not saying that more expensive paddles aren't better than cheaper ones; maybe they are.  Also, maybe they're not.The last paddle I purchased cost me $11.00 and it's a [Name Redacted] available here on Amazon. Comparing that paddle with the Joola Spinforce 300: I can't tell the difference.  Handle, paddle, surfaces, edge finish... right down to the oval inset for the nameplate.The weight is the same, and most importantly, the contact surfaces are the same.Now: I am *not* a Table Tennis Pro.  I still call it Ping Pong.  I play occasionally... mostly when friends come over and a few shots of whiskey have been done. So maybe I don't know what I'm talking about.  Take my notes with these grains of salt.On the same hand: I've been a table owner for over a decade.  So, buyer: be aware of the alternatives.

I've been using the "regular" Rainbath shower gel by Neutrogena for years and have zero complaints about it.  It lathers well, it cleans well, and my skin looks and feels nice afterwards.  So, I expected all of that from this new Ocean Mist variation, but I was concerned about the scent.  I'm usually pretty touchy about scents...But no worries.  The scent is just as light as the original, only sweeter.  It doesn't remind me of ocean mists, but it does remind me of spending time on a tropical island... perhaps with plumeria and starfruit scents on the breeze.  Not exactly a manly scent, but it doesn't stick to you; it rinses clean.I like it.  My wife likes it a lot!

Reviewing the Capo LiteSo, the Planet Waves ND Guitar Capo Lite is made of black plastic.  The parts that make contact with the guitar are a nice firm rubber.  The slim, unobtrusive design means that it's easy to work up close to the capo.  The major downside is that it won't clamp onto headstocks, so no quick switching.So, Pros are: -Slim construction, easy to work around while it's on -Works well on classical guitars with radiused fretboards -Easy to adjust tension with the thumbscrew -Small footprint means it's easy to storeAnd the Cons: -Not effective on non-radiused fretboards -Won't work on thinner-necked instruments -Won't clamp onto headstocks (no quick switching)All in all, it works well.  And as long as you're using it on a Classical Acoustic with a radiused fretboard you're set.

So, I get it. I do. This bag/holder/folder is supposed to help me pack in such a way that my clothes don't get wrinkled.  However, I found that instead of wrinkles, my clothes wound up with odd creases.  Perhaps there's some mystical perfect way of wrapping my clothes around the folding board, but I haven't found it... and the instructions seem to be geared towards folks of a more diminutive stature than myself.While it works really well at clothes compression, it's just not quite right for me.

The Drop Tech V2 case for iPhone 6 Plus is serious protection for your Precious.  It's the first case I've ever seen that can compare with the armoring offered by Otterbox, and that's a huge compliment.Personally, I *am* a klutz.  I drop my iPhone at least once every other day.  Heck, in a restaurant, I once flung it two tables over... by accident!  My iPhone 3 was face down on asphalt not 1 hour after I'd purchased it; but yeah, I had it in a case 45 minutes before that happened.Anywho, the Drop Tech V2 is a Gumdrop case made of two protective layers: an inner hard plastic shell (with built in screen protection) and a softer outer shell. It even comes with a 3rd layer: a beefy belt clip.The packaging claims "Mil Spec" protection, but I'm not sure about that.  Why?  The camera and lens on the back are fully exposed.  Likewise the camera and sensor on the front and the main sound port (so you can hear your phone ring) are also completely left open to the elements.  So, don't go thinking you can take your phone out into a sandstorm, and definitely don't drop it in a toilet as the Drop Tech V2 will *not* help in those instances.That said, for a goof like me, this case is still golden.  I'm guessing they named it the "Drop Tech" on purpose, knowing that folks like me drop their phones.  And for that purpose, this case is excellent.I'm not completely sold on the included belt clip.  The case itself makes my phone even more gigantic that it already is, the belt clip just magnifies that effect.  Of course, if the case makes it impossible for you to put your phone in your pocket, then perhaps the belt clip is just what you need.  Still... you'll be strapping a 5x7 hunk of metal/glass/plastic/PTE to your hip.  It's definitely not fashion-forward.The belt clip is still quite useful as it also works as a stand; useful for watching videos or when using external input to the iPhone.Yes, the case is big and bulky.  But guess what?  So is the iPhone 6 Plus.  At least this way you can protect it properly.

Let me just start by asking this question:How can Curt charge so little for such a high quality product?I'll let you read up on the specs of the Curt Cargo Carrier, but there were a few things that I felt the need to REALLY test:1. 500 pound load capacity2. Folding shank3. Fit & finishFirst thing I did was hook this puppy onto my SUV.  Now, with a factory install 2" x 2" receiver, I have no worries about my rig being able to hold the weight of the Cargo Carrier & its contents.  If you aren't so lucky, check to make sure that your after-market tow receiver will handle the weight and that your vehicle can handle it.  Tossing over 500 pounds of dead weight past your rear bumper *will* affect ride and handling; so be safe out there!Anyway, the Curt Cargo Carrier slotted in with no issues.  Locking down was easy and firm; it'll wiggle a bit, but not rattle or shake.  A quick inspection showed me that all surfaces are well coated, all bolts are accessible should I need to tighten anything down. Good fit & finish.The folding mechanism works like a snap... however, when folded up it's impossible to even open my rear door; when it's folded down it's impossible to get at the rear cargo without:Standing on it.I'm a big guy; 200 pounds. I figured standing on the cargo carrier would be a great way to test its strength and flex.  So I did. And: The Curt 18109 didn't care.  Sure, it gave a bit on one side, but it remained steadfast.  I did the "Truffle Shuffle" while standing on it and it didn't care.  (My wife, on the other hand, laughed her butt off.)Bikes, tents, sleeping bags, loaded coolers... I don't think I'll have to worry at all on my next camping trip!

What I like best about solid state drives is the fact that they're silent and quick. I'm using the Vertex 460A in an external enclosure.  If you do the same, make sure that your enclosure makes full use UASP to ensure that you get support of maximum speeds. I did and boy, is it worth it.The Vertex 460A is fast, quiet and a bit small.  The "bit small" part can be tricky, especially with external enclosures that don't use screws to hold the drive in place.  In my case, the enclosure came with a few small pads to help keep the drive inside from rattling around... it doesn't help much.  It's very small form factor that actually plays against the drive in external enclosures. For internal applications, as long as the drive locks in or screws down, you're all set.But the speeds: wow.

Remember when mousepads were just thick neoprene with a thin plastic or cloth covering glued on top?This is not that mousepad.Since optical mice (mouses?) have moved away from visible red laser to not-visible lasers, the woes of working on a glossy or reflective surface have slipped away.  Tracking on these new ubermice is smooth regardless of the surface upon which they are used.  Or is it?In my own experiences with several brand-name ubermice, the surface that the mouse works on makes a large difference.Being 100% honest, I haven't played twitch-reflex games (Battlefield, League, CoD) in a few years; however, I do use my mouse for video and audio editing purposes.  Being able to quickly track in using the whole mouse before dialing in with a wheel/dot/dial saves me time and stress.  The Turtle Beach Drift mousepad helps me a lot.Anyone familiar with "swipe/stop/creep" will find this mousepad useful.  The pad's surface is smooth but tactile.  The underside is herringbone silicon or rubber and does not let the pad move.  The anti-fray whipstich edge may look like a bit of overkill, but with heavy use, I can see it being a major plus.Since it comes rolled up, I expected it to stay bumpy for a day or two.  It, however, relaxed into totally flat in the span of an hour.Yes, it's large.  For gamers, the extra space is quite useful for large sweeping moves.  For me, it means I have a built-in drinks coaster.  ;-)I'm a fan.  The Turtle Beach Drift isn't just for gamers.

So, the mat itself: very heavy, dense polyvinyl.  Seriously heavy duty.Using the mat:  I put my workout machine on it.  The machine is about 200 pounds.  And while it does have rubber feet, I never wanted it on my new hardwood floors. So, until two weeks ago, the machine lived in the garage.But now, the hardwood is protected!  After two weeks of regular use, I've checked under the mat and there's no sign that the machine has even been there.  Better still, there's no sign that the mat has been there.  I sort of expected that the mat itself might rub the floor and leave marks or residue, but no.I'm very impressed.  The mat works very well.

I had a look through a bunch of other reviews up here on this lever style corkscrew, and:It's true that this opener does not come with instructions. But seriously, that should really only be a concern for someone who has never used a corkscrew in their life.Then again, that may be unfair... I did, after all, study physics in high school and college.  Anyway;Personally, I use a Laguiole corkscrew.  No complicated this, no lever that... just simple.  However, it does take coordination and hand strength to use it.My wife uses the original "Rabbit" lever corkscrew because it's easier for her.  However, she's never liked the fact that it forces one hand (the one that holds the bottle gripper) into an odd position.  For that reason, she (and I) like this Artaste Vertical corkscrew.  Instead of having to vise-grip hold two horizontal handles to clamp onto the bottle, the Artaste has you, basically, holding the bottle.  The "clamp" here has you holding a vertical position, which is much more natural.Need instructions?  Here:1. Remove the foil from the bottle. (but NOT with the included foil cutter)2. Raise the Artaste's lever, bringing the corkscrew all the way up3. Position the Artaste on the bottle so the corkscrew is directly on top of the cork.4. Grip the clamp with one hand so that the Artaste is "locked" onto the bottle.5. Lower the lever, driving the corkscrew into the cork.6. Raise the level, pulling the cork.7. Done.If you'd like to easily remove the cork from the corkscrew:1. Release the clamp so that it is fully open2. Lower the lever fully so the cork is inside the clamp (like you'd position the unit for storage)3. Grip the clamp so that it "locks" onto the cork.4. Raise the lever.5. Done.I've knocked one star because the included foil cutter is useless.It's a tad smaller that the original "Rabbit" and it's moderately aesthetically pleasing. Still, it's not something I'd proudly display on buffet or desk.But it works well and doesn't force you to make silly hand gestures.

So yeah... this stuff is a weird consistency, like cold cream.  But don't take it out of the tub.It smells strongly of Tea Tree oil... which is to be expected since it's made of tea tree oil.And: it works.My kitchen sink leaked a while back. And while it's all repaired, there is, infrequently, a slight mildewy smell that pops up.  I can't really say of this stuff kills mildew, but it certainly kills the smell associated with it.  It's a great air freshener.

I've already written up a glowing review of the D'Addario American Stage Instrument cable... I did so a few years back.  It went something like this:"Buy this cable. Stop looking at other brands. Stop wondering if you'll get the best bang for your buck. You won't find a better quality cable than the American Stage cable.You'll likely spend years and hundreds of dollars finding and tuning the perfect instrument for you. You'll then spend hundreds, maybe thousands of dollars on the perfect amp. ...And then you'll complain about spending $25 on an instrument cable.I know. I've done that.  But if you spend all that money on the perfect axe, and all that money on the perfect amp, shouldn't you invest in some quality cables to connect the two?The connectors on the American Stage cable really do sit better. And the cable itself is tough and study."None of that has changed.  (What did change is the name.  Planet Waves was the name on the packaging at the time, but D'Addario has since unified its marketing.)  The cable is still awesome.  Mine took a hit from a Manhasset music stand and is still rockin' just fine.  The connectors are still fantastic and seat well.The new trick here is the momentary kill switch.  Like most electric musicians who use pedals, I have a kill switch pedal at the end of my signal line in case something self-oscillates (*coughSeaMachinecough*).  It's very handy.  But that's not what this kill switch is for.The kill switch in the American Stage cable is for when you change instruments.  Yes, if you have an in-line kill switch pedal, you can use that.  But if you don't, this is quite handy.The trick is: the switch is momentary.  That means:Momentary Switch; noun. A type of switch usually in the form of a push button that is only engaged while it is being depressed, as opposed to a typical âon/offâ switch, which latches in its set position.So, when you push the button, the signal is "killed." Once you release the button, the signal is live again.If you're going to use this feature, if makes sense to plug the kill switch end into your guitar.It's handy and works well.

In "When God Becomes Small" Phil Needham has presented an intriguing look at modern society and how God does and doesn't fit in.There are signs and ads all around us telling us to buy more, to do more, to be more.  But how does that stack up against God's wishes for us?Needham does a wonderful job of reminding us that a large number of (dare I say "most"?) Christians have forgotten or overlooked Jesus' teachings... you know, the guy for whom the religion is named. Needham also reminds us that Jesus was countercultural; that He shook up the church and government, and was, essentially: a hippie.Take an afternoon and read this book.  See if it doesn't help you reconnect with what really matters in life.

I got it to work.First, let me say that while this Belkin Keyboard Case says that it's for iPad Air & iPad Air 2, it's not really.  It's for the iPad Air 2, as the iPad Air is thicker and takes serious work to get mounted in the case.  Even then, I felt like I was going to either break the case or my iPad.Anyway, lots of folks have written reviews about the troubles this Keyboard case has given them.  For me, it just wouldn't stay connected via Bluetooth to my iPad.  So:Step 1. Update IOS.  I know, I know... Belkin says that IOS 7.2 and later is supported, but apparently you need IOS 8.1 or later.Step 2. Reset/clear the keyboard: press and hold the iOS Home key, Function key, Delete, and the Right Arrow key for five secondsOnce I followed those two steps, I've had no technical issues with it.Other stuffs:I like the keys on the keyboard.  While it's all very compact, they feel like quality laptop keys with good throw response.  The magnets that hold thing shut and hold the iPad up for keyboard use are strong, but not overly so.  And whatever material is coating the outside is pretty grippy; meaning, the whole thing doesn't slide around when typing.Once I got over the connection issues, I've been pretty happy with it.

Sorry, Amazon... but you missed the mark here.Ok, so:TECHNICALLY speaking, the AmazonBasics Bluetooth Mono Headset works.  Pairing to my iPhone was a snap.  Charging is simple.  The sound quality on both ends of the line is good.  But then...AESTHETICALLY speaking, it's unattractive.  I get it, "Basics." I understand the simple approach.  But this thing is thick black plastic and it looks like it.  No adornments and the shape is not pleasing to the eye.PRACTICALLY speaking, it's uncomfortable.  The hard plastic loop that hooks behind the ear is much too small for me and pinches terribly.  AND, the single, included earpiece is too large so the thing won't sit correctly.I suppose this headset might fit some folks, but it does not work for me.  I'll be putting this one in a drawer.

I'm surprised.Usually, any "drying lotion" causes my skin to turn red and peel.  But Acnefree Drying Lotion is very gentle. Per the instructions, dip a cotton swab into the jar, down to the pink sediment near the bottom, then apply. I'd recommend doing this about an hour or so before bedtime.  It'll give the lotion time to work into your skin so you don't leave it all over your pillow.For me, it worked on a troublesome blocked pore overnight without causing my skin to rebel angrily.  Knocked one star off because it doesn't disappear into your skin; meaning you can't apply it in the morning and let it work all day unless you like having pink dots on you.

Step One: Read the included instructions.Step Two: See Step One.You know how most electronic devices with batteries pre-installed will have a little plastic tab that you can pull to quickly remove the plastic with no fuss?  Well, Taylor wanted me to burn some calories before I even used this scale. They had me to go to the garage and get a small phillips-head screwdriver to take the battery cover off, so I could then remove the plastic thingy.Very thoughtful of them.  I'm sure I burned 15 calories in that little adventure.Anyway, I can't imagine anyone figuring out this scale without the instructions.  So please read them, again and again.  Thankfully, they are written in plain English... well, as plain as anyone can get with a piece of electronic technology.You can have this scale hold the information for up to 4 people.  Each can then pull up their data, weigh themselves, and see how they are doing.After entering your personal data and weighing yourself, the scale will give you a number that you can then look up in the included BMI table and then feel very, very badly about yourself.The scale itself doesn't judge you. It gives you the tools to do that to yourself.  Again, very thoughtful.The Body Mass Index table included in the instructions does not distinguish between men and women... but the scale itself does want to know your gender.  I'm guessing that the scale takes everything into consideration when making its calculations so that you don't have to look at two different tables.Oh, this is just a scale with a calculator in it... it does *not* use bio-resistance measuring to determine your BMI number.The scale is accurate.  Well, it's as accurate as the other two scales in my house.Anyway: Pro Tips!Pro Tip One: Read the instructions.Pro Tip Two: Set the scale on a LEVEL hard surface (no rugs nor carpet)Pro Tip Three: Don't feel too bad.  Most of us are in the same boat you are.

It's tough reviewing towels as so much is subjective. Softness, absorbency, texture, color... all are subject to the preferences and whims of the user.  (And before you quibble over Absorbency: talk to someone 6'5" and 250 pounds, then talk to someone 5'2" and 100 pounds)Anyway, I received the towel set in "green" and found the green to be a yellow-green, or even a tan-green.  They were soft out of the box, and remained so after washing.  Not what I'd call "plush" nor "luxurious" but still soft.  They're a looped pile texture... so plan on them snagging on something at some point... but don't all towels do that?Honestly, they're very towel-like.  I'm sure that the Hitchhikers' Guide to the Galaxy would approve of the largest towels in the pack (the bath towels) as something you might take traveling.  Not that there's anything wrong with the hand towels nor the washcloths, but you definitely couldn't use either of those as a blanket... unless you were very small indeed.The Mills "Naked" 6-piece bath set ticks all the boxes as far as towels go, but aren't amazingly fantastically wondrous.

If I had to sum up my review in one word, it would be: Unimpressive.The photos make this small flask (holds 6-ish ounces) look stylish and cool.  Good marketing there, because when you get up close with the Metrokane/Rabbit Hip flask, it sure falls short. 1. The rubber or silicon or whathaveyou strip on the flask is not fitted well.  It bulges in some spots, not in others.  Mine won't even stand up on its own for filling. 2. The stainless steel has sharp edges.  Mine looks like someone took a hammer to the top edge to flatten it out; leaving protruding sharp edges. Just what I always wanted: a flask that will cut me every time I want a sip. 3. The screwtop cap is gray plastic (i.e.; ugly) and releases from the "tether" with minimal force.As anyone who owns stainless steel appliances will tell you: touch it once and you've left a mark.  Very true here as well.And, as another reviewer noted, mine arrived smelling of 3-in-1 Oil.Oh, and can I just say, using this as a marketing line: "Sneak it in your purse for some swigs on the go" sounds like Metrokane is enabling alcoholics.  Well, it sounds like that to me... and I used to write Marketing.Anyway:  It's a pain to clean.  Smells off.  Doesn't hold much.  Wants to cut me.  And didn't even come with its own filling funnel.And now it's off to the recycling bin.

Too many times I've been up here writing reviews about things that just didn't deliver on their promises.This is not one of those times.Construction:The rubberized coating makes everything about this cable easy to grip.  The cord itself is a bit thicker than most other USB 2.0 Micro cables I have, which is also a good thing.  AND, it arrives coiled (circle) not bent (figure 8) which is better for the longevity of the cord. (Good on you, APLWL)Connectors:They work.  Not overly snug, so they seat well and stay there till you unplug them; and they don't argue with you when you try to unplug them.Colors:Bright and vibrant.  If you think you might want to color-code your USB connections for quick reference, these will help.  No more scouring through a drawer looking for "the right" black USB cable.Charging & Data Transfer:I've used this cable with a Jockery battery pack to both charge the Jockery (5Volts 1.2Amps) and using the Jockery to charge a phone (5Volts at 2.1Amps) and itworked with no issue.  When moving data, it works at standard USB 2.0 rates... slower than USB 3, FireWire 2, and Apple's Thunderbolt/Lightning, but still within USB 2.0 guidelines.It works and is easy to use.  What more could you want from a cable?

These bags do a great job of keeping things inside them and keeping them fresh.First thing I did when they arrived was fill them water and zip them shut.  NO LEAKS.  Even after I applied a bit of pressure, they still didn't leak.  The bags are thick, and the zip closure is easy to use and air tight!Next thing I did was wash them.  They do have a peculiar plasticky smell about them when they arrive, so a hand-washing is in order. (They are not dishwasher safe.)  Washing was easy.  Drying is sort of easy.  I dried them out as much as possible with a towel, then set them over upturned glasses to air dry.Anyway, they work, they are extremely sturdy and WAY better for the environment than using disposable baggies.

Short Version:  It does it's job.Long Version:I bake a chicken a week.  The leftovers go into chicken salad or pot pies, so for me it just makes sense.  Getting the whole bird out of the roasting pan without making a mess has always been a touch problematic.  I use the "big fork" from a carving set to get the bird out and usually wind up burning my hand on the edge of the roasting pan, spilling juices, or both.The OXO Poultry Lifter *does* keep me from burning my hand on the roasting pan.  Since the handle is positioned OVER the bird, there's no need to get my hand down near the pan.Still, lifting a bird using this gizmo is awkward at first and takes some getting used to.  And larger birds (turkey & geese) will still require a bit of stabilization, so be prepared to use your other hand.All in, I like it.  The Poultry Lifter does make a tedious task a bit easier.

So, for most of my adult life, if I bought an electric heater, it has been a DeLonghi Heater.  This is because, in my experience, they are built to last and are reliable.That said, this is the first DeLonghi heater that I've owned in which the housing is 100% plastic.  Initially, this caused me concern because typically, Heat + Plastic = Toxic Fumes.  But not here.  The HVY1030 barely let off any "first time start up" smells at all.  And that was nice.Also nice is the fact that it's a metal coil heater.  It heats up quickly and gets the job done.  I've used it in a small bathroom (about 70 square feet) and a small bedroom (about 130 square feet) and it has performed well.The "thermostat" is one of those dials where you get your room up the desired temperature and then back the dial down until the heater stops; the heater then knows what temp you want your room and will work to keep it there.The heater has Low, High, and Fan settings.  Fan, obviously, just turns the fan on...but strangely, you must still use the Thermostat dial to kick the Fan on.  Low is nice and works well in small spaces.  High is dang hot and heats up small rooms quickly.I've seen reviews of people saying that this heater just doesn't get hot enough.  Either those people are made of asbestos or obsidian, or they aren't cranking this sucker up.  There is always the possibility that they are using it in too small of a space or have the heater up against a wall.  If you do either, it will shut itself off pretty quickly as the coils won't have fresh air to heat.At any rate, I've found it perfect to heat up small rooms and it doesn't let off nasty smells.  It's a keeper!

It's very hard to find good, 4" powder puffs, but these are great and you get five individually-wrapped puffs at this low price.  What a deal!  They shipped from Hong Kong in less than two weeks. Recommended.

These Hershey's candies are delicious and one pound is a lot of candy.  They look like M&Ms, but I like these better; they are creamier, more chocolaty, and softer.  This would be nice to put on your party buffet or desk at work.I am deducting one star because the tin does not have a holiday graphic; it says, "HERSHEY'S," which, I think, makes it  more of an advertisement and less desirable as a gift. And at this price, the tin should be pretty, something you'd like to keep. Plus, several candies were broken in transit.  They still taste good, though, so this is perfect for movie night.

This figurine doesn't look nearly as pretty and graceful as the picture shown on this page (which is a drawing, not a photo of the actual piece).  The face and crown, especially, aren't painted well.  The dress is pretty and sparkly, but the cape looks dull.  It feels so light it could be made of styrofoam coated with plastic.  Worth about $5.98.

Damak is absolutely delicious!  The chocolate is not too sweet; it's more like European chocolate.  It's very smooth and the pistachios taste good, too.  The only down side to this candy is that there are 440 calories per bar and it would be very easy to breeze through the entire box of six bars in no time.

This 9" plate isn't as beautiful as most Lenox pieces are; it's too busy.  The holly design on the rim is delicate and lovely, but  spoiled by the addition of poorly-painted and sloppy gift boxes.  The center picture is an impressionistic Christmas tree that is messy, lopsided, and looks like a child's drawing.  If they had just kept the nice holly motif that would have been fine. Of course, the center will always be covered by food, so it's not a big deal, just not up to Lenox usual standard.  And with no gift box, it's not worth the price.

This is a great shower-in-the-tub mat.  The suction is good, it has no new-plastic odor, and I like that it is transparent. The size is just right and there are little holes all over to let water through.  I feel safe using it and it is comfortable on my feet.  Recommended.

What a disappointing book.  This is nothing more than a chronological listing of events in Jane Wyman's life - her marriages, children, movies, television, etc.  There's nothing here that you couldn't get from reading Wikipedia or IMDB.  She appears to have been a very private person who hated discussing her off-screen life and kept everything to herself.The book offers no explanations for, or insight into, her decisions or actions. No one, not even Jane Wyman, was interviewed for this book; instead, the authors sprinkled in short, previously-published quotes that make her sound like a  completely humorless and cold control-freak.  She was a talented actress, but, apparently, not a nice one.

This is a lovely 6" square porcelain dish with a cardinal and holly graphic and gold rim.  As with all Lenox products, it comes in a pretty box, suitable for gift giving.  It is small, but there are many times when one wants to give just a few special Christmas cookies or candies or petits fours, and this is the perfect dish for that.  It is a sophisticated, decorative piece and the price is fair.  Recommended.

I have been using these Hefty slider bags for a long time and like them very much.  I hate, hate, hate to use ziplock, squeeze-together bags.  Sliders are so quick and easy and I've never had a problem with leakage.  The quart size is good for everything from sandwiches to candy and refrigerator storage.  To get 184 bags at this price is good deal.  Recommended.

The story of the prisoner exchange involving Francis Gary Powers is one of unending tension broken just occasionally by little humorous comments.  Tom Hanks plays the lawyer defending the Russian spy that was eventually traded for U-2 pilot Powers.  The negotiations are complicated and could have been tedious in the hands of a lesser cast and director. Hanks is completely believable as an intelligent but ordinary man thrust into global affairs; he's a pleasure to watch.  We get to know and, to some degree, sympathize with the Russian spy and Powers is certainly a likable character, shot down on his first spy mission.  Very entertaining and educational film.  Recommended.

These scissors are sturdy and sharp with lightweight handles and a comfortable grip.  The blades are 4 inches long, suitable for all everyday cutting needs.  I am especially pleased with the price; it's very reasonable for a top quality, name-brand pair of scissors.  Recommended

This is an excellent shampoo; it lathers nicely, doesn't have a noticeable scent, and leaves my hair easy to comb out with no tangles.  It does take a little more rinsing  to get to the squeaky-clean stage than my usual clear shampoo, but it's still fine.  The best part is the price:  Name brand shampoos are getting so expensive and this Pantene is still reasonably priced.

This cream feels really good on my hands.  It softens them instantly. I think the price is very reasonable.The down side is that the perfume scent is way too strong; fortunately, it goes away after a few minutes.  Another negative:  The lid does not have a pop-top.  Overall, however, this is a good, moisturizing cream.

This is a beautiful pendant, much prettier than the enlarged photo which makes it look a bit gaudy.  In reality it is very feminine and tasteful.  The stones all look real and the pale blue  goes well with the stunning, fiery opal.  It comes nicely boxed.  I, personally, prefer a longer chain than this 18" one, but that is an easy fix.  It is lovely necklace and I think the price is very fair.  Recommended.

Turner's later life is portrayed in a series of often unrelated vignettes, showing his deep love for his father, his loyal housekeeper, his famous artist colleagues, and his lady love, but mostly it showcases his blustery, growling, nasty personality.Timothy Spall does an excellent job of conveying Turner's irascibility; he is forever grunting and groaning and getting away with it because of his wonderful talent.  The movie is filmed in such glorious colors that each scene looks like an oil painting by a  master; visually this film is a delight.  The 19th century sets and costumes are also perfect. On the down side, each scene begins intriguingly but goes nowhere; there is no continuity or build-up to a dramatic end. But it is the man himself, Turner, that I found so utterly loathsome that I can't recommend the movie.  It does show many of his art works but everything is secondary to the repulsive blowhard himself.

This very cute bowl set has "party" written all over it!  Looking at it, you can imagine 4th of July picnics with a big bowl of potato salad, holiday salads, and even watching TV with a big bowl of popcorn.  The four bowls have very tall sides and are good for salads, cereal, soup, and pasta.  The big bowl holds a lot of food; I like that the sides are low.  The two serving utensils are cute and handy.This set is casual, fun, and cheerful, and would make a nice gift. The price is very reasonable, too.  Recommended.

Chris and Emily grew up as neighbors, playmates, best buddies, and later, high school sweethearts.  They were two halves of a whole, people said.  And then ,one night, they had a gun and their lives exploded.The basic plot is a very good one and the author, for the most part, writes engagingly.  A lot of it was can't-put-it-down-good, but unfortunately, a lot of it was just filler.  At 500 pages, the book is about 200 pages too long.  There are endless (and ultimately pointless) pages of courtroom testimony that I found dull.  Worse than that, the (non-) ending:  It was such a disappointment!  We waited all this time to find out WHY and then, sorry, reader, you lose!The descriptions of Chris and Emily's developing romance and the backstories of their parents were all very interesting and I found the jail scenes especially riveting.  However, being so let down at the end, I can't recommend the book.

The four penguins (pre-Madagascar) travel the world trying to escape an evil octopus named Derrick, no, Doris, no, Dave!  Well, that's as much of the story as I could understand.This one is strictly for the kiddies.  It's all fast and furious with very little funny, aside from some cute celebrity puns.  I loved the Madagascar movies, but they were about friendship and loyalty and real emotions; this time out the plot makes no sense at all and quickly becomes annoying.  This is a shame; a wasted opportunity.

Stanley (Firth) is a famous magician who goes to the south of France to check out a young woman (Stone) who claims to be a medium.  As Stanley knows all the tricks of the trade, he's skeptical, but her charm wins him over.How could anything with Colin Firth as the romantic lead be this awful?  He was so wrong for the part of a sarcastic trickster who hates everyone and he wasn't funny at all. With his innate genteel sophistication and noble appearance, he sounded ridiculous saying the Woody Allen dialogue.  Emma Stone looked like a little girl with a big lisp and was totally annoying.  She looked young enough to be Firth's granddaughter, not his love interest.The location photography and 1928 sets were lovely, but I never bought the characters or the situation.  And it was neither romantic nor a comedy.

A wealthy American woman (de Havilland) takes her sweet but brain-damaged daughter (Mimieux) to Italy, where a local man (Hamilton) attaches himself to them and immediately falls for the girl.I enjoyed Olivia de Havilland's fine performance as the elegant, over-protective mother. Yvette Mimieux was perfectly cast as the fragile and beautiful woman who will never grow up.  On the other hand, I couldn't buy George Hamilton as an Italian stud-muffin; he looked ridiculous and the love-at-first-sight plot was unbelievable.While the scenery of Florence was lovely, the print quality was very poor and almost unwatchable.  A time capsule from Hollywood in 1962, when tourists wore hats and gloves and Italian men were always on the make, this is just an okay film.

When I first opened the box and felt this pillow, I was stunned by how soft and silky it was.  It felt like hugging whipped cream. It seems a shame to put a pillow case over it, but it's easier to wash and replace a pillow case than wrestle with the snug-fitting zippered case.It's a heavy pillow, but medium firmness and very comfortable.  This pillow is also ideal support while sitting up in bed.There was a slight chemical smell at first; after two days on the patio in the hot sun, the odor is gone. I think it's a quality product and the price is reasonable.

I've always wanted a travel neck pillow and this one is great.  The velour cover is so soft and cuddly and is removable for washing.  The size fits my neck and when leaning back on the car head rest, it's like snuggling up with a teddy bear - soft and comforting.I like the midnight blue color and I think the price is very reasonable.

The Good:My cat loved this whirling feather toy.  She jumped right on it and treated it like a real bird; she was in killer-mode!  She burned a lot of calories chasing the feathers and pouncing on them.  I liked that there's an on-off button and it's quiet.The Bad:After only an hour of playing with it, she had pulled off all but one measly, wispy 1" feather fragment. I don't think the remaining bit of fluff will last long.  They should include replacement feathers! It's also very cheaply made - worth about  $.99, considering you have to put in two  batteries.

What a let-down.  This book was dull, dull, dull, in sharp contrast to the very exciting first book in the series.  This book had endless boring monologues from people I didn't care about.  The only one I did care about was Talon, the villain, a man of very few words.This story was about a search for "the Writing on the Wall," mentioned in the Book of Daniel.  Everything about the trip to Babylon was dull, phony, and pointless.  There are too many characters that don't matter, too many wild goose chases, too much filler.
