If this is your cup of tea, then I recommend Finchâs âAn Old Betrayalâ to you.

With the words "Quartet" and "Boards" (plural) in the title, and a picture of four boards on the label and in the product images I thought I would be receiving  four whiteboards, but there is only one in the pack.  At the time I didn't realize that "Quartet" was the brand name.  Sure, I should have double checked the details before buying, but at the very least they should put "Board" singular in the title.The word "Tin" in the title is also misleading - I was expecting solid metal whiteboards but this feels like there's a VERY thin metal film over plastic that's wrapped around a piece of plain cardboard.  It's very light - if it weren't magnetic you'd never know there was any metal at all.  Overall it feels very cheap.  Even so, getting four at the price I paid might have been worth it, but for only one I definitely did not get my money's worth. For the price of four of these boards to make a reasonably sized whiteboard on the wall you could buy something much bigger and nicer.As far as performance, the marker writes fine and the board works like any other cheap whiteboard. It erases OK but does a leave some ghosting.  The magnets hold fairly well. One magnet can hold up 5 sheets of letter copy paper. I haven't tried hanging it on the wall yet, but it does come with double-sided sticky pads for the purpose.It's a perfectly usable whiteboard and the magnets are a bonus. I just think it's expensive for a single board.

Do you have children with insatiable appetites for information?  Then you should add this encyclopedia to your bookshelf. The Knowledge Encyclopedia, by DK and Smithsonian, is full of amazing information presented in a more amazing visual way. Itâs incredible that so much information on a single topic can be found on only two pages, but that is the format used for this encyclopedia. Yet, it works beautifully, and it doesnât intimidate or overwhelm young minds. The text is given in small text blocks or paragraphs, key information is in color blocks, and most important for a childrenâs encyclopedia the pages are full of graphics that are stunning as well as informative. Both of my daughters, ages 7 and 9, say they really like the Knowledge Encyclopedia and they have spent many hours pouring over the pages and learning something new.

When I see a collaborative publication by the likes of DK and Smithsonian, I am immediately interested in its contents. The âHistory Year By Yearâ is an historical encyclopedia for kids that doesnât disappoint. The pages of contents are laid out in a timeline that is organized by historical period, which makes searching for events logical and easy. Each event is presented on only two pages so that children are not overwhelmed. However, that doesnât mean these pages are lacking in pertinent information. Indeed, they are full of great historical information presented in small text blocks and paragraphs, along with graphic aids and fantastic illustrations and photos which follow the timeline of the particular event. Interspersed throughout the pages are quotes by archeologists, historians, photographers, museum curators, and other experts to lend an authentic and personal perspective to the information. Most importantly, is that my two daughters loved it and spent hours pouring over the pages.

Pardon my pun in the title, but I'm not overly impressed by this blow dryer. The first thing I noticed when I took it out of the box was it's weight. It's quite heavy, and much heavier than my last two blow dryers. I don't know if I'll get tired of holding something heavier, but I am hoping that it's an indication of quality.I do like the three heat settings, two air speeds and the cool shot of air, which can be used while drying. It is quieter than my last dryer, which was a Conair with the same wattage. The dryer is a little awkward to hold, however, and I had trouble changing heat and speed while holding it midair and drying my hair. It did dry my hair faster but not by much. I used both attachments to see how they work and diffuser worked like it should - giving curl without the frizz. I had trouble getting the concentrator attachment on the end, and then it blew off the dryer both times that I used it. I don't know if mine just doesn't fit well, but that was a little annoying.It may seem like I'm being knitpicky in this review, but I'm just trying to cover all the bases for a blow dryer. After saying all that, it does what it's supposed to do - dry my hair. If it lasts longer than my last two blow dryers, then I'll be really happy.

I really didn't think that these shears would make a cut that is better or different than my current, large craft scissors. I was wrong. The Fiskars Amplify Mixed Media Shears really do make a smother, cleaner cut through thicker materials. I cut through several layers of cardstock, cardboard, matboard, thick felt, and an outdoor vinyl fabric using both the Fiskars and the large craft scissors that I already own. The Fiskars Amplify consistently cut through the materials with a much smoother edge than my other shears. These shears don't actually make cutting thick materials easier, it just cuts more smoothly. I only gave the shears 4 stars because the grip seems a little small even for my hands, which aren't large by any means. Other than that, I'd recommend these shears to any crafter.

I decided on this particular Dirt Devil Bagless Upright vacuum to use on the second floor of our house. The upstairs doesn't get as dirty as downstairs so I thought a smaller upright vacuum would suffice. I liked that it was bagless, and has a hose and attachments. But after using it, I learned that it really won't work as a full time vacuum on any space larger than a studio apartment. It is very hard to push and it has insufficient suction to really clean. On my model, it can be difficult to lower the head of the vacuum and it seems like there isn't enough space between the roller and the floor creating a drag when vacuuming. The attachments are handy, but again there's not enough suction power to thoroughly clean even small or tight spaces. It is a small upright vacuum, but it's heavy and loud for its size. I'll end up using it for spot vacuuming light messes, but not for any actual vacuuming.

I have combination skin that get dry in the winter and this provides the right amount of moisture for me. It is a gel texture that feels cool on the skin. I also like to use it after being in the sun too much. I don't know if it actually heals the skin, but it feels like it to me.

I have a very hard time wearing conventional fragrances. Most perfumes/fragrances give me a headache, and I find that most essential and aromatherapy oils smell a little too much like a health food store. I was excited to find Tata Harper's Aromatic Treatments and chose this one (Irritability) because of the many great reviews. When I first tried it, I was pleasantly surprised. It did not smell like a chemical, department store perfume, but it didn't smell like the health food store either. It's a lovely and yet complex floral/herbal scent. I was trilled that it did not give me a headache either. As another reviewer said, only a little bit is needed and it does last all day. Now, for the negative aspect: the scent started out so pleasant and then faded to something reminiscent of OFF. Yes, I do mean the insect repellant. Now, that could just be my body chemistry but I thought I'd warn potential customers that it may not work for you. I think it would be worth a try to get a sample from Tata Harper before spending the money on a full sized bottle. And the change in the product's aroma is the reason that I only give it 3 stars.

If you are new to creating fonts or digital lettering, then I think you'll find this book useful. The book is not for the the creative person who wants to learn how or be inspired to draw fonts or unique letting techniques. Instead, it introduces you to the more technical points of font creation, such as x-height, cap height, weight, eye and other parts of a glyph or typeface. The book is mostly a collection of font artists' work with a grid page that follows on which one can practice drawing. The author does encourage studying and practicing drawing letters, which is obviously good advice since "practice makes perfect" with any endeavor. I think the most important information in this book is understanding letter forms, typefaces and full fonts, if you are just beginning to create your own fonts or if you like lettering and wish to take them digital. Understanding digital fonts is the next important aspect of this book. The author explains the differences in digital typefaces, quickly explains how to create a digital font, and introduces the reader to digital type creation tools. No part of the book is explained in detail, but is for the beginner or novice. With that in mind, Tony Seddon wrote a font book that gets right to the point for a budding font artist to get started.

While these socks are not exactly thick, they are more substantial than the cheap socks you find at the super stores. They're comfortable and fit well. I've only had them a couple of months so I can't say how they hold up, but I'm optimistic enough that I plan to buy more.

Unfortunately I found this book to be poorly written, overly wordy and unfocused. I say unfortunate because it has a few real pearls of wisdom, like the 6 P's of Innovation (which I believe Andy Bruce developed many years ago), but the book does an extremely poor job of expanding on these pearls beyond just listing them.The book has far too many useless, wordy passages that drone on and on - I get the feeling they were paid by the word.  There are lengthy definitions (with pros and cons) for common things like video conferencing, electronic databases, blogs, even email! (that's right, a definition with detailed pros and cons of EMAIL)  One so-called quick tip is "Schedule a monthly half an hour to search the Internet for potential sources of ideas and information..."  Do the authors really think there's a person alive that wouldn't think to search the Internet - and only 30 minutes a month?The formatting and diagrams are terrible. Unreadable screen shots of a SofTools web page randomly appear in the middle of text with no explanation and no reference to them. One diagram that's supposed to help explain an ideas filter is actually a funnel with things going into the top AND OUT of the top - I would call this overflow, not filtering. I don't believe I found a single diagram that improved the understanding of a topic and some added confusion.It's bad enough that the book offers so little useful (and so much useless) information, but there are even places where I think the information can be misleading.  For example the authors write "The process [of portfolio management] should be simple and easy to follow, but it should also reflect best practice - this can be a difficult balance as one often works against the other."  If a practice is not easy to follow then it's not the best.  But even if the "best" practice is complicated, the implication that you should do something less than the best if it's too hard makes me wonder if the author's are truly interested in my success.Overall this book is a jumbled mess that's boring and hard to read. The little bits of good information are hard to extract and provide only the highest level of understanding.  If I had paid the $25 price listed on the back cover (or even half that price) I would have been first in line for a refund.

I found the Epson WF-2540 to be easy to print to both wired and wirelessly. Print quality is very good in black-and-white but only acceptable for color photos.  Compared to an older Canon MP560 using the same high quality photo paper the colors from the Epson printer are less vibrant and less saturated.  Scanning quality is good - about what you'd expect from an all-in-one.  I do like the auto-feeder that lets you stack up to 30 documents and scan or copy them all at once without having to lift the lid and swap sheets, but it's fairly slow.  It's convenient if you can set it up and then go do something else for a while. Since I don't have a land-line I was not able to test the faxing capabilities.Setting up the WF-2540 on the wireless network was easy and configuring my iMac to print to and scan from it was a snap.  It was also simple to print to it from my iPhone and iPad using the epson iPrint app.  After I updated firmware on the printer I was even able to print from these iOS devices directly without the need for the Epson app.  Wireless printing from all devices has been glitch free, except you do have to remember to turn (or leave) the printer on.I did go through the original inks very fast.  I don't know if the included inks have less than the normal replacements or if I will always go through it that fast.  There are XL versions of the replacement cartridges that claim to have more ink. I did notice there seems to be fewer 3rd-party options for replacement ink cartridges and they are much more expensive than the 3rd-party replacements for my Canon.Another negative is that the printer only has one way to feed paper - from the back.  So you have to change paper every time you change the type of print you're making.  I prefer printers with a paper tray that I can load with standard paper and then when I need to print an envelop or a photo I can load that into a bypass slot in the back without having to remove paper.So for now my Canon MP560 will remain my go-to printer/scanner and I'll use the Epson as a back-up.  If I go through the next batch of Epson inks as fast as the first I'll probably stop using it for prints and only use the scanner when I need the sheet feeder.  But if you find this WF-2540 at a good price and you don't need top-quality photo prints it will probably be a solid performer for you.

The TL-WR702N from TP-LINK is a fine choice for the knowledgeable user looking for a travel WAP, but NOT for the novice.I have used a number of WAPs and Bridges and this one works as well as any.  It's not the fastest product in its category, but the price is right for what you get.  My only real issue is with the documentation which I think would be nearly impossible for the novice to follow.Having set up products like this before I didn't really need the documentation except for the default IP address, but even that was hard to find.  The paper documentation in the box gives only definitions of the various modes in English - all the detailed setup instructions are in other languages (fortunately the IP address needs no translation). It does list a URL for more details but that leads to nothing but a 404 error.  I was able to find the details on the company's web site after some searching but not only were the instructions hard to follow, they were incredibly outdated (they still refer to Internet Explorer 6.0).I should also point out that the product is amazingly small and light.  That's a good thing if you're traveling with it, but with no rubber feet it's so light that the weight of its own power cable can pull it off the table. It took some tinkering to get it to stay where I wanted it.Overall I'd say the TL-WR702N is a reasonable choice as long as you know what you're doing it.  Otherwise I'd stick with a more mainstream brand.

These are very cute shoes from Tom's that my 6 year daughter just loves. They are the classic style with a glittery upper. They seem to run just a little big but that only give my daughter to wear them. I only gave them 4 stars because these are not the sturdiest of shoes and the soles are very slippery.

I had reservations because it was so much less expansive than other iPad covers, but it has excellent build quality, fits perfectly, is easy to use and has some nice features not found in other covers.  I've been using it for about 2 months now and have no complaints.  The cover clicks closed just right and has the magnets to lock/unlock the ipad. It props up the ipad at 4 different landscape angles.I don't use the back hand strap as much as I thought I would but mostly because I've learned how to hold/prop the ipad so that I don't need it. When I first started using it the bottom corner tabs that you have to pop the ipad out of to prop it up fit a little snug but they've loosened up just a bit over time and it's now a simple operation.The elastic strap to hold the cover open and the pen loop are nice extras.  Overall this was well worth the price and if it ever wears out I'll probably try to buy the exact one again - maybe next time in leather.

My daughters, ages 8 and 6, and I had fun for a few hours after receiving the StampingGear set. It's extremely easy to use, and the video that is included on the product page clearly demonstrates its ease of use. We began by just practicing on plain paper. Even my 6 year old got the hang of using the cog and wheel system very fast. The set comes with plenty of cling stamps and both oval and circular cogs and wheels. You do need fairly large paper when using the outside of the wheels, and square paper works great with the circle. Of course, you don't have to stamp right in the middle of a sheet of paper or a card. Stamped designs that bleed off the edge look great. After practicing, we then started to make actual stamped items such as cards, fancy envelopes and gift tags. I also think stamping on plain wrapping paper in holiday colors would be very pretty. We don't make a great deal of paper crafts in our house so our one problem with the StampingGear set was what to make after we made several cards with matching envelopes. The set plus many colors of ink pads make incredible designs so in the end we decided on wall art. We framed our favorite designs and now have a beautiful display. The Inkadinkado website also has many great ideas to inspire you so I'm sure a stamper is only limited by her/his imagination. If you like to stamp, I'm sure you'll like this set.

I wanted to correctly repair torn pages from some of our favorite childrens books, and knew there was product for just that purpose. The Transparent Mending Tissue is that product. It is a tissue like tape that is very thin, but very transparent. So much so that it is difficult to see, and not apparent at all, on some pages. It also feels like a strong tape so that it should be difficult, or impossible, to pull free from the page. I think this is a must-have in any house with books, especially to repair your keepsake books or albums.

I've been using the wool dryer balls for more than a month now, and admit my surprise when I discovered that they actually work as described. I was looking for a natural way to eliminate static cling and fluff my laundry, and this was the product that I decided to try. I used the dryer balls in a load of towels for the first time, and they did indeed come out soft and fluffy. Next, I used them with a load of jeans, and this load too ended up soft and fluffy. By that second load, I was quite impressed. Then I washed and dried a load of color laundry and forgot to place the dryer balls in with it, and because of two acrylic nightgowns, there was static cling. I put in all three of the wool dryer balls and ran the load on the fluff cycle for 20 minutes. Wow, the static cling was gone and the clothes seemed a bit softer too, all without the use of chemicals or fragrance. I searched around for more scientific information about how they work - is it the natural fibers or the lanolin found in wool - but to no avail. Whatever the reason, I'm hooked and now use them all the time.

I absolutely love Melissa & Doug products for small children, and this box of art supplies is no exception. First, it is a box full of art necessities for little ones. In one package are two boxes with hinge lids of triangular shape crayons, a box of triangular shaped chalk, box of triangular shape color pencils with great colors (including gold and silver,) and a box of non-roll markers. All the coloring products stay on the table and stay in one piece for much longer! The boxes also come with a pad of color constructions paper, a drawing pad, and a more artist grade, acid free drawing pad. You can buy cheaper drawing pads but I think the M&D paper is closer to young artist quality paper from art supply shops. My daughters LOVE the color pencils. They are bigger and are easier to hold, and the colors are beautiful with a really nice range of colors. The jumbo crayons are good too, but they are a hard, waxy consistency and do leave the balls of wax on the paper. The 18 piece set has been fun to use because the box has a carrying handle - making it easy to carry to the park with a pad of paper. Overall, I recommend this drawing set for young children. In one box, it has everything you could need to make a little drawing studio for your child.

The B&D Platinum hand held vacuum does a good job vacuuming small messes. It seems to have plenty of suction, and works great for areas likes cleaning stair treads or the car. It took approximately 4 hours to charge the battery, and the charge will last me an entire week of small cleaning jobs.The vacuum has a couple of flaws, which I consider minor for how I use it. It is quite noisy for such a small machine. I use it for short periods of time and only a few times a week so the noise isn't a persistent issue. The vacuum also does not have a bracket to mount the battery charger on the wall next to an outlet. A wall mount bracket for the charger and another for the vacuum would be a very nice feature for convenient storage in the garage or utility room.All things considered, I do like the B&D Platinum Slide Pack vacuum. It definitely does the job for small vacuuming when the full-size vacuum is just too much.

This is my second and last Vincent Zandri book that I've read. I really wanted to like this book, but it was just too predictable and clichÃ©, like his other book, The Innocent. The writing is average--not great, and the story moves at a rather fast pace. It lacks what a good crime novel should - a good crime. I figured out the the who, what and where just too quickly. Of course, that may be because I felt like I've read this story before. For a novel to be good, crime or otherwise, it needs to be interesting, original, and well written. Vincent Zandri partially met only one of these three requirements. What a shame.

love a good crime novel and was excited to read a new author, especially after reading such great reviews of Vincent Zandri's other works. Unfortunately I was quite disappointed with "The Innocent." Yes, it's an easy read, but it's just a little clichÃ© for my taste. Zandri used the usual elements for his story: a scarred hero, a misunderstood female who is a bit of an intellectual but easily abused, the loyal female sidekick, and the usual group of criminal types who all have a good reason for turning to crime. Throw in a light Indiana Jones moment, an attempt at a shocking ending, and the result was a predictable and rather boring story. I feel like I'm being generous giving it two stars, but it's easy to read and just interesting enough to finish.

I give this book 3 stars mostly for the interesting facts about Fenway Park, but it wasn't really what I was expecting. The book is actually pretty hard for me to categorize. The clunky "A is for..." rhymes and the lack of photographs or quality illustrations make it not really suitable as a coffee table book.  The fact that the illustrations aren't targeted at kids coupled with the fine-print historical facts in the margins means it doesn't make a great children's book.  And while there are a number of interesting facts on every page, it's not really comprehensive enough to satisfy a die-hard Red Sox fan.  But if you're looking for a different and a little bit quirky book about Fenway Park you might enjoy it.

As with most books for children, the themes of good triumphing over evil, loyalty and friendship are common. However, it never hurts to read about and learn them often. In Barry Wolverton's novel "Neversink," the story is told with mostly Northern birds, and with Scandinavian folklore in the mix. The story has adventure, unlikely friendship, and a lesson in the ways of greed and politics. I especially enjoyed the protagonist's, a Puffin, love for his wife and unborn Puffling, his respect for the elder on the island, and his open-minded friendship with a walrus and hummingbird. They are an unlikely crew that knows what's right and will risk their pride, tradition and lives to save their fellow citizens and home. The true test is how well my seven year old daughter liked the book, and it was a hit with her. It moved at a fast enough pace to keep her interested, and it helped open a dialog about a American history, and how to pick and keep good friends. I do recommend this book, but will warn you that it contains mild elements of threat, deceit and death. It is mild enough, however, that my daughter wasn't scared but did learn about unhappy but real elements of life.

I have mixed feelings about this story. On the one hand, John Grisham wrote a smooth, easy to read story. But I felt like more could have been told about Joe Castle and Paul Tracy. I'd even consider this more a novella than a novel. I'm an amateur baseball fan at best, but I do have more knowledge about the culture of baseball after reading this book. I just feel there was more to learn about the characters. The ending was wrapped up too quick and pretty, but Calico Joe is a quick and easy read, and one I think baseball fans will especially enjoy.

The Goalrilla Torch portable floodlight is a very nice multipurpose LED floodlight that is mainly designed for outdoor sporting events where you need to light up a playing field at night. The entire floodlight assembly comes in pieces inside a large carrying case with wheels. You get a two-way pump for inflating the protective padding around the central support tube, tripod support legs, high-visibility "wing" flags that connect to the legs and center pole (so players can easily spot the light stand and avoid hitting it) as well as a set of ground anchors.The single biggest complaint I have about the product (and the reason it only gets 4 stars instead of 5) is that the rechargeable battery pack is NOT included. This floodlight retails for $350 on the manufacturer's website and that's a lot to pay for an LED floodlight without a power source ... even if it does have great padding and high-visibility flags to help with sporting events.As I previously mentioned, this floodlight works fine as a multipurpose light and doesn't have to be limited to sports use. I've used this as a "studio light" for taking product photos and shooting YouTube videos ... and it works great. I also plan to use this at a neighborhood party around Halloween so all the kids have a well-lit area to play.Just be aware that you need to buy a separate battery if you want to use this.

This Casio Solar-Powered Digital Watch has been around in one form or another since the 1980s and is still one of the best low-cost digital watches on the market ... assuming you aren't a cave dweller who never leaves your basement.As the name suggests, this is a 100% solar-powered digital watch; you never have to buy one of those stupid little watch batteries again. Electrical power comes from a small bank of solar panel cells that feed electrical current to a capacitor inside the watch. The capacitor essentially acts as a battery and as long as you allow the solar panel cells to absorb some light every day the capacitor will stay charged and keep your watch running perfectly.The biggest "problem" with this watch is the unfortunately long initial charge cycle for the capacitor (an unavoidable flaw in having a battery-free design). The capacitor is completely dead when you first remove the watch from the box, and since the digital components require a "relatively" large amount of voltage the capacitor can't keep up with the demand until it is FULLY charged. This means you have to leave the watch out in the sun (with minimal cloud cover or shade) for a full day and then still charge it under a BRIGHT lamp indoors after the sun goes down for a full night before the capacitor has the charge needed to get started.There is a little "sun" icon that appears below the time if the capacitor is running low. Even after the sun icon disappears during the first day of charging you STILL have to leave the watch out to charge (again a full day of sunlight and a full night of bright lamp light at least) for that first charge.After the capacitor has received a full initial charge you won't have to worry about charging it again as long as you spend at least 45-90 minutes outside every day and the solar panel isn't covered by your shirt sleeve. An hour to an hour and a half of sunlight is all this watch needs to keep running all day and night ... as long as you have given the capacitor a full initial charge.The only other thing I think this watch is missing is a light to allow you to see the time at night. Granted, even a single low-voltage LED would drain the capacitor VERY quickly and defeat the purpose of having a battery-free watch, but it would have been nice to have a light. I suppose I'm willing to put up with the lack of a light if it means I never have to buy another watch battery and never have to remove the cover from the back of this watch.If a solar-powered and battery-free digital watch sounds like a good idea to you then you'll absolutely love this watch. Just understand how the capacitor works and give it that LENGTHY initial charge it needs.

The Dyson V6 Mattress is an updated handheld vacuum from Dyson's newest V6 line. Although it's marketed as a "mattress" vacuum you would be silly to only use this for cleaning mattresses. The only thing that is clearly different about this V6 handheld and the other V6 handheld vacuums (other than the color) is that the V6 Mattress includes a dedicated "motorized mattress tool" and it may have better HEPA filtration (although I can't tell for sure about the filter).The motorized mattress tool works on carpet and upholstery as well, so again there is little point to only using this vacuum on mattresses. The Dyson V6 Mattress also includes several other vacuum attachments (crevice tool, upholstery brush, etc.), but it doesn't come with the extra-long attachment arm and the wide floor cleaner heads like the "V6 Absolute" or "V6 Motorhead" vacuums. That said, I don't see the point of using a handheld vacuum for cleaning wide areas of flooring, so the V6 Mattress has all the attachments you really need for the things you'll want to do with a handheld vacuum.Dyson claims the V6 Mattress is quieter to use than the "V6 Trigger" handheld; I don't know what the V6 Trigger sounds like, but I can tell you that the V6 Mattress is LOUD. It's not deafening or remotely painful to my ears, but if you turn this on in a room where someone is sleeping they will wake up. Similarly, if someone is watching TV they will have to turn up the volume to hear the TV over the noise from this vacuum ... and the V6 Mattress is certainly more than loud enough to scare the living hell out of our family dog. I guess "quiet" is a relative term.Despite being louder than the cheap, under-powered handheld vacuums I've used before, the V6 Mattress is a GREAT vacuum with an AMAZING amount of suction for a handheld. While my wife and I were cleaning our house we kept thinking of that scene from the movie Wayne's World where Mike Meyers is talking about a vacuum and says, "It certainly does suck!" The dust cup is easy to empty into the trash and you can clearly see when the cup is getting full and needs to be emptied. The battery life (roughly 20 minutes per charge) is "decent" for a handheld vacuum since most of the time you won't use a handheld vacuum on big chores, but if you are a professional cleaner who plans to use this to clean multiple homes every day then you'll need spare batteries.Bottom line, this is a great handheld vacuum (the best one I've ever used) and is a great solution for people who want an awesome handheld vacuum. It isn't perfect (and certainly isn't as quiet as I expected) but this might be about as good as any handheld vacuum gets.

The Case Logic SLRC-208 Slim Action Camera Case is a nice, compact camera case that is perfect for protecting a GoPro Hero-type camera, small lenses, or a small-to-medium compact camera.The product name "SLRC-208" is a little confusing because at first glance that name makes the case sound like it was designed to hold "SLR" style cameras. There is no way that any SLR or Digital SLR camera will fit inside this case without risking damage ... unless you have a small SLR and remove the lens from the camera and put the camera inside the case flat with a body cap over the lens mount.That said, this case will hold smaller lenses for a DSLR or SLR camera and will easily accommodate compact cameras up to something as large as the Sony RX1 or RX1R.There is no shoulder or belt strap with this case because it's designed to protect a camera and/or lenses inside another case or bag. This is a good solution for protecting your camera gear inside luggage or a large backpack.

There is only so much that I can say about this S'mores Kit from Hershey's; it is what it is ... tasty S'mores.My whole family loves to make S'mores when we go camping, when we hang out next to the fire pit in our backyard, or sometimes just to have fun during a movie night at home. Usually we pick up the S'mores ingredients (Hershey's chocolate bars, Graham crackers and large marshmallows) separately at the grocery store. This seemed like a convenient way to get our S'mores "fix" so I decided to give this prepackaged kit a try.The chocolate bars, Graham crackers and large marshmallows are basically the exact same thing that we usually purchase separately at the store, so this is a nice "one stop shop" solution to making S'mores at home. This would be a good purchase before a camping trip or as a gift for someone who regularly camps.The only thing "missing" from this kit is sticks to use for roasting the marshmallows over an open campfire. Granted, most people just find sticks at a campsite, but I wanted to mention the lack of roasting sticks just so people know what is or isn't included.The only complaint that I have about this product is that since I ordered this during the heat of the summer months and the box wasn't refrigerated during shipping, all of the Hershey's chocolate bars inside my kit arrived partially melted. That isn't the end of the world for S'mores since you're going to melt the chocolate anyway, but it would have been nice if the chocolate bars hadn't arrived melted ... it's hard to break the Hershey's chocolate bars into smaller pieces for S'mores if the bars have melted and re-hardened into chocolate "bricks."Don't order this kit during the summer and you should be fine. Alternatively, Amazon could package this kit in a box with dry ice to prevent melting during the summer.

The UP3 from Jawbone is a simple-looking yet feature-packed activity tracker bracelet that works with your iPhone or Android smartphone.Like most wrist-worn health trackers, the UP3 is packed full of sensors to track your every movement from heart rate and steps taken to a detailed breakdown of how active or restful your body was while you slept. While this $180 activity tracker has plenty to offer, Jawbone's Up2 has most of the same features and design elements from the Up3 for just $99.The wrist strap itself is different from Jawbone's previous UP thanks to an adjustable strap with all of the Up3's electronics located in the top of the band directly under the new touch-control surface. You can double-tap the touch surface on the top of the wrist band to switch between sleep and activity modes, while three LEDs let you know which mode you're in (or you can check the "UP" app on your smartphone).This brings us to the one notable missing feature on the UP3 which is also an advantage: There is no LCD on this activity tracker. You can't simply glance down at your wrist to check your heart rate or see a chart of the total steps you've taken because the UP3 has no screen. Instead, it sends a wireless signal to your smartphone and updates Jawbone's "UP" mobile app. The downside is that you need to have a paired smartphone to use the UP3, but the upside is that the UP3 gets FANTASTIC battery life (roughly a week between charges) because there's no LCD screen sucking the wristband's battery dry.Speaking of "dry" ... Jawbone specifically says the UP3 is "water resistant" but not "waterproof" ... meaning you can leave the UP3 on your wrist when you're washing your hands, taking a shower or doing the dishes but you don't want to wear it while swimming.I'm glad the UP3 is so comfortable to wear, is packed with activity monitoring features via the UP app, and has great battery life. However, the lack of even a small, low-resolution LCD screen means this activity tracker isn't as useful when you're working out. You can't just glance down to see if you're maintaining your target heart rate during your workout or if you need to push yourself a little harder. Pulling out my smartphone breaks my concentration when I'm exercising and that's not ideal.Bottom line, the UP3 and the UP mobile app work together to deliver a great tool for people who want to track their activity and hear rate over a prolonged period of time (like a fitness blogger or someone who is actively trying to loose weight with the help of a physician and needs to provide progress reports to a doctor or personal trainer). However, heart rate monitoring isn't nearly as useful during workouts if you can't check it at a glance.

While these Philips SHQ2300LF/27 "ActionFit Sports Earbuds" are clearly marketed as a nice mid-range set of earbuds (not cheap $5 earbuds but not crazy expensive either), the simple fact is that these earbuds deliver terrible sound quality.I wasn't expecting these Philips earbuds to rival the premium earbuds from Sennheiser, Shure, or Audio Technica priced at more than $100, but given the retail price of these Philips earbuds I expected better quality than what I get from the free earbuds that I get on a long flight. Unfortunately, I put the audio quality from the Philips SHQ2300LF/27 earbuds on par with those free earbuds from airlines.I wouldn't call the audio "unlistenable" as other reviewers described, but the highs and midrange tones are shrill and distorted. You can hear and understand music or the audio from a movie, but it isn't very enjoyable. Bass is essentially absent when using these earbuds, so don't even think about using these if you're really into hip-hop, rap, funk, techno, dubstep, or anything with a prominent bassline. Honestly, that last bit makes this product less than ideal as "sport" or "exercise" earbuds. Likewise, if you're watching an action movie or horror film and using these earbuds the soundtrack and sound effects will sound tinny, hollow and lacking "impact" that typically comes from bass.These earbuds also suffer from erratic static problems depending on the audio source. I didn't have a problem with static disrupting the audio when I used these earbuds with my iPhone, but these Philips earbuds suffered from terrible static when I used them with my laptop, my Android tablet, and when I plugged them into a video camera to monitor the sound while recording. I double-checked the audio by plugging them into my iPhone and the static was gone again. In short, I wouldn't rely on these earbuds to deliver quality sound.If these earbuds were priced at $5.99 then you would know what to expect, but the MSRP for these Philips earbuds is $29.99 and that makes this a VERY bad deal. If you can find these on sale or as a free extra with the purchase of another item then they are fine. If you're paying full price then you should consider other earbuds like the Sony MDRXB50AP or the Audio-Technica ATH-ANC23.

I was looking for a gift to give my daughter as she "graduated" from lower elementary to upper elementary this year and the Sterling Silver and Diamond Infinity Pendant proved to be a wonderful choice.I normally think that infinity pendants are a bit corny or cheesy, but this one is nicely done and it gave me the opportunity to talk to my daughter about the importance of always continuing to learn; that even when we graduate from school life is full of opportunities to learn. I told her that each and every one of us should make an effort to learn something new each day, and that each new day is a blessing because we have a chance to learn something that will make us better tomorrow than we are today.The pendant itself is about the height of a U.S. nickel and the chain is the perfect size for a young girl or a woman with a slender neck. The chain does look a bit fragile and if you're planning to purchase this for an adult woman with a wider neck then you really need to purchase a longer (and thicker) chain for this pendant.Overall, my daughter was pleased to receive this pendant as her "graduation" gift and I'm happy she likes it so much.

The Nerf N-Strike SharpFire blaster is an impressive looking Nerf single-shot blaster with a simple loading method: as you pull back the "slide" to load the dart you also charge the firing mechanism so that you can fire.This loading/charging mechanism makes the SharpFire one of the easiest and fastest single-shot Nerf blasters to use during a Nerf war between friends or coworkers. Unfortunately, this blaster is plagued by a few problems.First and foremost, this is the worst performing "N-Strike" blaster that I (and my kids) have personally used. Most N-Strike blasters fire with an impressive amount of force at close range and retain good accuracy up to between 30-70 feet (the maximum range usually depending on the condition of the darts). This SharpFire blaster fires darts much more "softly" than other blasters; the speed that the dart leaves the blaster is visibly slower, the maximum range of each dart is noticeably shorter, and darts hit the target with almost no force behind them.Second, the modular design is pointless as implemented. The barrel extension serves no purpose, it doesn't improve the accuracy of the darts, doesn't provide a good space for a second hand to grip the blaster, and the front "sight" is worthless for aiming since the darts are so underpowered. Likewise, the removable stock serves no purpose other than to provide a convenient place to store your darts when the blaster is not being used. The stock is too short to provide a good shoulder brace when firing (it's not only too short for adults but my five-year-old son is too big to use this stock effectively). The stock is also supposed to function as a "holster" for Nerf battles, but you have to reach down and press a button to release the blaster from the stock when you're using it as a holster, so that prevents you from quickly drawing your blaster during play.The weakness of this blaster could arguably be a selling point for parents who are worried that their children will be hurt by foam Nerf darts that are shot with too much force behind them, but in reality it just ruins the fun of shooting Nerf darts at friends. I would only give this blaster to someone in a large group Nerf battle if I was planning to use that person as a human shield or sacrificial bait for opposing players to shoot.

My review title says it all. I don't know what kind of miracle metal the people at Doughmakers Gourmet Cookware are using to create the Doughmakers Grand Cookie Sheet, and I don't know the name of the genius who came up with the idea for the "Original Pebble Pattern" but this cookie sheet is AMAZING.I'm not an expert chef or baker, but I know the difference between a cookie, bread roll or muffin that is evenly baked to PERFECTION and something that is baked properly on the top and burnt on the bottom. For years my wife and I made cookies and other baked goods that weren't evenly baked and I just thought it was our oven or terrible technique on our part since we aren't artisan chefs. As it turns out, all we needed was better bakeware!The first three batches of cookies that my wife and I made for our family using the Grand Cookie Sheet turned out PERFECT as if we had purchased the cookies from a high-priced bakery. We then decided to try cooking croissants and bread rolls on the cookie sheet and they likewise came out of the oven baked to perfection.Apparently, the "Original Pebble Pattern" that Doughmakers uses on its bakeware is the secret. You aren't supposed to use non-stick cooking spray on this bakeware because it will tarnish the metal surface and is difficult to clean out of the embossed pebble pattern. That said, you can grease the bakeware with a stick of butter or use flour if you want. The embossed pattern on the metal allows air flow under the item being baked and that's apparently the secret to both the even baking and why baked items don't stick to the surface.Even if you have to pay the full manufacturer's suggested retail price of $20 to get this cookie sheet it's worth the money. After making a wide variety of cookies and croissants on the Doughmakers Grand Cookie Sheet, my wife and I decided to go out and purchase and entire set of Doughmakers cooking pans! We now own the 9" x 13" Cake Pan, Square Cake Pan, Sheet Cake Pan, Loaf Pan and the Muffin Pan.I highly recommend this cookie sheet.

The Meguiar's G4200 New Car scent protectant wipes are a good alternative to the typical Armor All protectant wipes. The scent is not as strong as Armor All and these wipes give the plastic, vinyl and rubber parts inside your car a clean, polished look without the overly "wet" look of Armor All.I like the scent of these wipes but I'm not too sure if it's really the same as a "new car smell" as advertised. It's a clean smell with a faint note of chemicals (not unlike the smell of interior fabric adhesives curing in a new car) but whether or not this is what you expect from a "new car smell" depends on you.Overall, I like these wipes and I'll continue using them on my vehicle's interior. I don't know how well the shine holds up over time, but it seems to hold a shine and provide some protection for at least 3-4 weeks.

My wife is generally not a fan of perfumes and prefers to rely on bathing with good soap and using a quality antiperspirant/deodorant. That said, we decided to give the Calvin Klein euphoria Eau de Parfum a try and we're glad we did.Like many perfumes, euphoria is quite strong and I don't recommend spraying the bottle directly onto your skin or clothing ... otherwise the scent is WAY too strong. This is one of those perfumes where you pretty much have to spray a mist in front of yourself and then walk through the mist so that the intensity of the perfume is reduced. That being said, this perfume smells quite good; like a mixture flowers and fruit.My wife and I are pretty sensitive to strong perfumes and colognes and we get headaches if the scent is too strong, but the euphoria doesn't give either of us headaches as long as my wife doesn't spray the bottle directly onto herself. If you're looking for a nice, clean-smelling perfume with a scent that is reminiscent of flowers and fruit then I'd highly recommend Calvin Klein euphoria.

I was looking for some safety glasses that I could use outdoors in bright sunlight or indoors with bright work lights so I decided to give the Jackson Safety V50 glasses a try.On one hand, these are perfect for keeping your eyes shielded from debris while doing yard work or other dirty tasks in a well-lit environment. The polycarbonate lenses are pretty tough and they don't alter my vision the way some cheap safety glasses do. As the item description says, the lenses have an "anti-fog" coating and the cushioned pads around the back of the lenses (as well as the "brow bar") have small openings or "slits" to provide ventilation and further reduce the chance the the lenses will fog up.On the other hand, I have mixed feelings about these safety glasses specifically because of those cushioned (and ventilated) pads around the back of the lenses. Keep in mind that the black foam cushions not only make the glasses more comfortable but they provide an extra barrier to keep debris from getting to your eyes while you work. However, because of the way these glasses are shaped, those cushions also dramatically impair your peripheral vision.If you are using these glasses while driving a riding lawn mower then you REALLY need to turn your head from side to side more frequently to make sure there isn't something just outside your field of view. I likewise can't recommend driving any automobile while wearing these glasses because of the way your peripheral vision is blocked. Granted, most people don't drive while wearing safety glasses, but I wouldn't recommend these for people driving lawn mowers just because a kid or pet could come running up beside you and you won't see anything unless your head is turned in that direction.Other than that issue, I found these safety glasses to be extremely comfortable and useful whenever I need safety glasses with tinted lenses.

We had a minor problem with moss in our back yard where the trees provide ample shade and an ideal environment for moss. My wife and I were particularly annoyed by the moss because it often spread to the stepping stones in our back yard and made the stones slippery and potentially hazardous to walk on.Since we also had some thin and patchy grass in that area I decided to try Scotts Turf Builder Lawn Food with Moss Control. Within a week the moss problem has vanished in our back yard, so I can confirm that the "Moss Control" portion of this Lawn Food works exactly as described. My wife and I are happy that we don't have to worry about family members (or guests) slipping on the moss that was growing on our stepping/paving stones behind the house.I'm a little reluctant to give this product a full five stars because I'm not completely sure how well the "Turf Builder" portion of this lawn food works. I have noticed a general thickening of the grass in our back yard, but that is also normal for our lawn in late April and early May. I used Scotts grass seed in the bare spots and that seed has taken well, but it's hard to judge what the "Turf Builder" has or hasn't done in terms of helping the grass grow and thicken.In short, if you have a moss problem in your yard then I would highly recommend this product. It definitely kills the moss and it "probably" helps the overall health and thickness of your grass. However, I've used other lawn food/fertilizer that made a more obvious improvement to the health of my lawn in previous years when I just wanted to help the grass.

I've used several different brands and types of grass seed over the years since I have kids and dogs that play in our front and back yards ... meaning my lawn develops patches of dead or worn grass every year. I've personally had very good results with Scotts brand products of grass seed and fertilizer, so I decided to try a bag of Scotts Turf Builder Grass Seed: Sun and Shade Mix.One of the first things you'll notice when you open the resealable bag is that this grass seed look bright blue. That bright blue coating is the Scotts Watersmart Plus Coating, which absorbs extra water for the seed, feeds the seed with some fertilizer, and protects the seed with some fungicide to help keep away fungus that commonly attacks newly planted grass.This might be a total coincidence, but when I've seeded with other types of grass seed in previous years (stuff that isn't coated or looks like regular light brown grass seed) I've had problems with birds eating the grass seed. This year the birds didn't attack the Scotts Turf Builder seeds. I'm wondering if it has something to do with the blue coating ... maybe it makes the seeds harder for birds to see or they think it's something poisonous. Even if it's just a coincidence and there is nothing protecting the seeds from birds, I'm glad the birds didn't devour the grass seed and the seed was able to take root in all of the bare and thin spots in my yard.The species of grass seed in the Sun and Shade mix isn't identical to the majority of grass in my front and back yards, but it blends in nicely and, as I previously mentioned, I've used a wide variety of grass seeds over the years and my lawn is probably a hodgepodge of different grasses.Bottom line, this grass seed is easy to spread, takes root reasonably fast (particularly if your lawn is getting rain or you use sprinklers) and I didn't have any problems with this seed. My only complaint is that the bag is pretty small and that means you'll need multiple bags if you have a lot of bare/thin spots in your yard or you have a large yard. One bag wasn't "quite" enough to cover all the spots in my front and back yard (about 1.25 acres).

My 6 year old son is a huge fan of Captain America and all Marvel super heroes, so the new Avengers Age of Ultron Captain America Star Launch Shield seemed like a perfect fit for him. He already owns the Captain America Winter Soldier Stealthfire Shield that fires Nerf N-Strike darts, but my wife isn't a huge fan of that shield since it "shoots" things. I figured this shield would be a better idea because it fires launch discs (essentially little helicopter pinwheels) off the star in the middle of the shield.Unfortunately, I noticed a problem that deeply worries me while my son and daughter were playing with this shield ... and it's related to the ripcord that is used to launch the star discs/helicopters.At first, my son thought the ripcord was a bit annoying because the mechanism that pulls the ripcord back doesn't pull the line very tight, so the ripcord handle "dangles" freely just a bit while he is running with the shield. That was indeed a little annoying, but the bigger problem came about an hour later.My son eventually discovered that after he pulls the ripcord out to launch the star disc he can use it like a garrote wire to "play choke" his sister. That concerns me.The ripcord line is just long enough to wrap around a neck of a child, and although my son wouldn't intentionally hurt his sister, I'm amazed that the toy designers at Hasbro didn't recognize this problem and use an internal spring-based launch trigger instead of a ripcord. Granted, I never would have thought about this danger if I hadn't seen my son discover his first garrote while playing in the front yard ... but I don't design toys for a living.This is a legitimate choking hazard.The Captain America Winter Soldier Stealthfire Shield might freak out my wife because it shoots foam darts that could potentially hit someone in the eye ... but it seems less dangerous to me than this shield which has a small rope coming out that is a potential choking hazard for children.

I've shot with a wide variety of digital cameras since switching from film to digital almost 14 years ago. I shoot professionally and for my own personal satisfaction. The Sony RX1 is one of those few cameras that satisfies BOTH my professional and personal desires while I'm shooting.For starters, the RX1 is compact without being too small and the controls and menu interface are easy to use without being too simple for serious control. You might think it's easy to make a camera that does those things, but trust me, it isn't. Sony struck an almost perfect balance in terms of form and function.The biggest advantage to shooting with this little camera rather than another small "mirrorless" camera is image quality. There are many, many ways to define "image quality" but in this case I define it as images with the greatest possible detail (high ratio of actual image data rather than "noise") combined with an extraordinary dynamic range (detail recorded in both highlight and shadow) and a smooth transition between in-focus and out-of-focus areas (butter smooth bokeh that isn't harsh and distracting).I've shot with a number of full-frame cameras including the Sony A99, A7, A7r, Nikon D700, D600 and Canon 5D mkII. Those cameras are all great, but none of those other cameras (at least not with the lenses I used) deliver the same combination of rich details and insane amount of exposure latitude that comes from the RX1 and its 35mm Zeiss Sonnar T lens with f/2 aperture.I know most people interested in small full-frame cameras are turning to the Sony A7 series and interchangeable lenses, but if you are content with a 35mm lens then the RX1 will not disappoint. The price of the RX1 is higher than it should be now that there are more affordable full-frame cameras on the market, but it still delivers fantastic value when you consider the full frame sensor and the amazing 35mm lens. I've shot side-by-side with RX1 and the Sony A7 and Sony 35mm f/2.8 Zeiss Sonnar T FE ZA lens ... and I personally prefer the images from the RX1.I also own and shoot with several DSLRs and mirrorless interchangeable lens cameras for work, but I enjoy shooting with the RX1 because it has everything I care about in a small package. I bought into cameras like the Olympus OM-D and PEN cameras and Sony NEX cameras because I wanted something small, but as soon as I added multiple lenses they where basically small DSLRs with less image quality. The RX1 is small but doesn't compromise on image quality. The Sony A7 series deliver similar quality, but as soon as you start adding lenses you might as well be using a DSLR kit. I'll stick with a full-frame camera that fits in my jacket pocket.Bottom line, if you are a serious (professional) photographer and can afford this camera (and you don't mind being "stuck" at 35mm) then there is no better camera than the RX1 in terms of delivering great results in a relatively small package.

I'm not a huge fan of MTECH knives because the quality isn't particularly good, but they have some interesting designs and as long as they are dirt cheap then they offer a good value.As my review title suggests, I was looking for a cheap assisted-opening knife to use for opening and breaking down a large amount of cardboard boxes and for dirty jobs where I might not want to damage a more expensive pocket knife. The MTECH MX-A804GP is the cheapest pocket knife I've purchased in a long time but it has good ergonomics and a nice spring assisted opening mechanism.This knife is a "flipper" design, meaning that when the knife is folded in the closed position you press on the exposed "nub" sticking out the back of the knife handle and the knife blade will swing forward rapidly (because of a spring that "assists" in swinging the blade out) and locks into place using the liner lock in the handle.The "flipper" becomes a finger guard when the knife blade is exposed, and that adds a sense of safety when using this knife for various cutting tasks. The liner lock is pathetically thin and won't handle abuse, but if you're just opening boxes and doing basic cutting tasks then the liner should hold up fine. My blade was well centered, but even if it wasn't I doubt I would have cared because this is essentially a "disposable" knife for light/medium work where you need to repeatedly cut cardboard, carpet, etc.

Let's be honest ... the old Minolta 50mm f/1.7 AF is the cheapest fast prime you can find for the Alpha lens mount for Minolta and Sony cameras. The reason so many people buy this lens is because it's cheap. You either don't have the budget to spend on a faster 50mm f/1.4 lens or you want a cheap lens that is essentially "disposable" for work in a dangerous situation ... or both.I wanted a cheap but fast lens that would work on either my Sony A99 or A77II for use around muddy sports events (motocross and rallycross) or sports where I'm close enough to possibly get hit by athletes (court side high school basketball or roller derby). I braced myself for terrible CA and purple fringing when shooting wide open at f/1.7 and I expected this lens to be painfully soft since it's so stinking cheap.Much to my surprise, the old Minolta 50mm f/1.7 AF is extremely sharp wide open at f/1.7 (not as sharp as my Sony Zeiss 85mm f/1.4 wide open, but that's comparing a $1,600 lens to a $40 lens ... of course the more expensive lens is sharper). There is a fair amount of CA and purple fringing around high contrast edges, but those optical flaws are easy to fix in Photoshop or Lightroom. I've also found that I like to increase the contrast in Photoshop when I'm using this lens for sports (although the weaker contrast looks fine when shooting portraits because most people don't want contrasty, razor-sharp skin pores and wrinkles).This "throw away" Minolta 50mm f/1.7 AF has become my favorite lens to use on the A99 when shooting portraits indoors where I'm working closer to the subject. I sometimes use this with the A77II as well because the crop factor on the A77II makes this 50mm lens more like a 75mm lens (although it still has the 50mm optical characteristic of "rounding" faces ... it just crops the image closer).I also picked up an old Tokina 80-200mm f/2.8 AT-X AF lens that is my "disposable" cheap telephoto lens if I need more telephoto reach when shooting sports close to athletes/danger/mud. That lens is optically similar in terms of CA and purple fringing and is a good choice if you need a "throw away" lens with more reach than this cheap 50mm lens.Bottom line, the Minolta 50mm f/1.7 AF isn't the greatest lens available for the A-mount, but it does deliver the best value for the money. I can't think of another fast autofocus lens for the A-mount that performs this well that you can buy used for between $25 and $60 depending on condition.Highly recommended!

I am a caffeine addict and so is my wife, but the older we get the pickier we've become about the coffee we drink. That said, we only spend as little as possible on coffee because we have two kids, a dog and many bills to pay every month. As much as we love good coffee, we love having enough money to live comfortably more. The Natura Coffee Monteverde Costa Rican Coffee is a "little luxury" that isn't too expensive for our monthly budget and it's affordable enough that we don't feel guilty indulging is good coffee.Before switching to this coffee, we previously purchased Eight O'Clock Colombian Peaks Ground Coffee or Gevalia Kaffe Columbian Ground Coffee (both are usually priced between $0.55-$0.65 per ounce). Those coffees are both good and we loved them more than Folgers or Taster's Choice (which are more bitter and have a mild "artificial" taste), but Eight O'Clock and Gevalia didn't have the same flavor as a good cup for coffee from a quality coffee shop.I decided to try something different and ordered the Natura Coffee Monteverde Costa Rican Ground Coffee (which is slightly more expensive at about $0.80-$0.91 per ounce depending on the current price). The first thing I noticed about the Monteverde coffee is that the aroma of the ground coffee is stronger and smells more like freshly ground coffee. The brewed coffee is likewise more fragrant and the taste is "rich" with a hint of "chocolate" behind the main flavor of the coffee. It's not like hot cocoa mixed with coffee ... it's very subtle, but it's there.I'd love it if this coffee was a little less expensive, but as long as it doesn't get any pricier then my wife and I will continue buying this coffee for a long, long time. We HIGHLY recommend this coffee if you're looking for a high quality coffee for your home coffee maker that isn't too expensive.

Let me start out by saying that I've owned, carried and used many, MANY knives over the decades. That said, although I know more about knives than the average person, I don't claim to be an expert. What I can tell you about is my personal experience with the Schrade SCH501 that I purchased to replace my (more expensive) Kershaw Thermite as my everyday carry (EDC) pocket knife.I enjoyed the Kershaw Thermite because the blade was between 3 and 4 inches and the G10 handle was between 4.5 and 5 inches (my favorite blade/handle size for an EDC pocket folder). Unfortunately, that particular Kershaw knife uses the Kershaw "SpeedSafe" assisted opening mechanism to help you flip the blade out when you need to use the knife. The problem with SpeedSafe knives is that the torsion bar component of the SpeedSafe mechanism is prone to breakage and when the torsion bar broke on my Thermite the knife was practically useless as a pocket knife.I started looking around for another knife with a similar size and shape to the Thermite and discovered this SCH501. There are several things that I like about this Schrade knife over my old Kershaw Thermite knife:-- The SCH501 uses 9Cr18MoV blade steel which is slightly better than the cheaper 8Cr13MoV steel used on my old Kershaw knife. The steels are very similar, but the 9Cr18MoV is a slightly harder steel with slightly better edge retention. What that meant in the real world is I didn't have to resharpen this SCH501 knife as often as I had to resharpen my Thermite after heavy use.-- The manual flipper and dual thumb stud folding mechanism is more durable than the delicate SpeedSafe mechanism and its flawed torsion bar design.-- The dual G10 handle slabs on this Schrade linerlock fill my hand better than the single G10 slab on the Thermite's framelock design ... meaning it is more secure in my hand when I'm applying pressure to cut thick material.There are only a couple of things I don't love about the Schrade SCH501: First, the jimping (textured pattern on the front and back edges of the G10 scales) is too rough and needs to be sanded down more. If you grip the knife firmly without gloves and you use it for a while you'll start to feel "hot spots" on your fingers and palm where the sharp edges of the jimping digs into your skin. The jimping also frequently catches on the edge of my jeans pocket and is starting to rip up my jeans a bit in those spots.Also, the pocket clip is not reversible for "tip up" carry, which is my preferred way to carry a pocket knife. It would have been nice if Schrade added extra holes on the clip-side of the knife so users could move the pocket clip for tip up carry. One last issue is that the "slot" that serves as a lanyard hole is too narrow for a standard 550 Paracord lanyard ... but that is really only an issue for me if I'm carrying a pocket knife in the tip up position, and since this is tip down carry I don't personally care about the lanyard hole.Bottom line, although the Schrade SCH501 isn't perfect, I like this knife better than my old Kershaw Thermite and I would recommend this knife to anyone looking for a reasonably large EDC folding knife with a budget price tag. This is a nice, durable pocket knife that holds an edge well and doesn't require constant resharpening.

The LeapTV Dance and Learn video game is one of the first games available for LeapFrog's new LeapTV system. LeapFrog has been making educational video games (and game systems) for children for many years and the Dance and Learn game hits all the right check marks on the list of what makes a good LeapFrog reading game:-- Basic alphabet ... check.-- Phonics and basic construction of words ... check.-- Vocabulary ... check.-- Getting kids off their butts and motivated to learn ... check.That last item on the check list is largely made possible thanks to the fact that the new LeapTV console and controller work amazingly well. It's almost like LeapFrog combined the ability to track player movement from the Xbox Kinect with the physical, gyroscopic controller for the Nintendo Wii.It took my kids a couple of tries before they got the hang of it, but the control interface is so simple that it was easy for them to get going once they understood how the console's camera, controller and the game worked together. I only had to help my son with the game the first two times that he played, after that he could keep up with his older sister.My 8-year-old daughter understands that this is a game designed to help kids learn and not "just" a dance game, but she and my 5-year-old son love coming home from school so they can start dancing and jumping around with this game. This has been great fun for the winter season when it's too cold to go outside after school.As other reviewers have said, one of the main things about the LeapTV system and this game is that it requires use the of console's camera. You need to have the console setup in a room with plenty of light (multiple windows are good) and it's very difficult (or nearly impossible) to play this game if the camera can't see the player due to poor lighting.The bottom line is that the LeapTV Dance and Learn video game is a great addition to the LeapTV console and is a fun way to get young kids to be physically active and work on basic reading skills.

I've used many budget and premium solid state drives (SSDs) over the years and I've almost always been happy with the drives from OCZ. This drive falls into the category of a "budget SSD" but it is one of the nicer quality affordable SSDs on the market as of late 2014 and early 2015.The maximum sequential read speed of 480MB/s and maximum sequential write speed of 430MB/s aren't as impressive as my more expensive Samsung 840 EVO SSD, but this OCZ drive is faster than my slightly cheaper Kingston V300 SSD. If you are upgrading from a traditional hard disk drive with a spinning platter then there is NO QUESTION ... this drive is faster and will make your whole PC experience faster from Windows boot up to opening applications.I haven't had this drive in my PC for very long, but I haven't had any technical problems as of yet. I noticed that two people posted reviews here reporting drive failures. Those things happen (just like getting a bad DIMM of RAM when you buy a memory upgrade for your PC), but my experience with OCZ's other drives has been good to date and I haven't noticed any issues with this SSD so far.I would recommend this SSD to anyone looking for a good SSD at a fair price. The only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is that it's not the cheapest and not the fastest ... but it is faster than the cheapest SSDs and cheaper than the fastest SSDs.

My family and I just returned home from a vacation to Disney World when I found this book and decided to give it to my 8-year-old daughter as a gift. My daughter still loves the Disney princesses and she insists on growing her hair long "like a princess" but no one in our family knows how to do princess hairstyles.This book of 40 Disney princess hairstyles was just what we needed and made the perfect gift, not only for my daughter but for my wife as well. My wife now gets to spend some extra "girl time" with our daughter as they style her hair in a variety of ways. The illustrations are nice and my wife says the instructions are easy to follow ... which says a lot about the quality of the book since my wife HATES reading instructions.If you have a little princess at home who has shoulder-length or longer hair then I highly recommend this book. I specified the length of hair because most of the styles in this book cannot be done with short hair.

The BenQ HC1200 is one of the best 1080p home theater projectors currently on the market (early 2015). The color accuracy is beyond reproach and, although I haven't owned it long enough to confirm, the advertised resistance to color fading over time are some of the major reasons to buy this projector over other full HD (1080p) projectors.I speak from experience when I say that color fading is a BIG problem with home theater projectors because they are typically used for longer periods of time and more frequently than typical business projectors. Even after replacing bulbs in old home theater projectors, I've noticed bad color reproduction, so if BenQ's claim is true that the HC1200 doesn't suffer from typical color fading then that makes it worth a higher than average price.Contrast from the BenQ HC1200 is noticeably better than other home theater projectors I've used: blacks are "blacker" and the brights are brighter while still retaining detail in the highlights and shadows of the movie or TV you're watching.As with all home theater projectors I've used, the HC1200 benefits from being projected on a quality screen surface rather than simply a wall that has been painted white. My experience with this projector is that it works very well with my projection screen, but your results may vary if you're projecting directly onto a wall.Overall, if you're looking for a high-quality 1080p home theater projector from your basement theater setup then the BenQ HC1200 is a fantastic choice.Highly recommended.

I've been hesitant to move to a newer iPhone because I've been perfectly happy with my "old" iPhone 4S smartphone. That said, I recently started having battery life problems with my iPhone where the battery would quickly drop from full charge to almost no charge in just a couple of hours with minimal 3G or WiFi use.I realized the battery inside the iPhone was starting to die and when I looked into getting a new phone from work it was obvious that it would be more trouble than it was worth or I might even end up with a worse phone than my current iPhone 4S. After doing some quick research online I figured out that replacing the battery was equally troublesome, and that the best course of action was to get an external battery pack case for my iPhone.The uNu Power DX PLUS has one of the highest battery capacity ratings of any case for the iPhone 4S, and my wife has had an excellent experience with her uNu case for her newer iPhone 5, so I decided to take a chance and buy this case.This uNu case has worked flawlessly and now my iPhone frequently lasts 2-4 days without needing to be plugged in for a charge. In fact, now my only problem is that sometimes I go for days without remembering that I need to plug in my iPhone to charge it at some point. This is MUCH better than having my phone die after only a couple of hours.

Adobe Photoshop and Lightroom are the 1-2 punch for photographic editing. There are other options out there, but whether we like it or not, most of us keep coming back to Adobe sooner or later for one reason or another.When Adobe switched to the "Creative Cloud" online subscription system (where users have to pay monthly or yearly for a subscription to use Photoshop and Lightroom) I joined many consumers in switching to other applications rather than migrating to Photoshop CC. My concerns were justified when Adobe's Creative Cloud system was hacked within the first 12 months and all the credit card numbers for all subscribers were compromised. That security breach alone guarantees that I will NEVER subscribe to Creative Cloud by providing my credit card information to Adobe.That being said, Creative Cloud does offer several unique features you won't find in the boxed version of Photoshop CS6 or competitive products. When I saw that Adobe was offering 12-month prepaid memberships to Creative Cloud (so you don't have to provide your credit card information to Adobe) I decided I'd give Creative Cloud a try.The latest incarnations of Photoshop CC and Lightroom are the most versatile versions of these programs to date and they work together very nicely. I know many photographers who do all there editing in Lightroom and never even use Photoshop anymore, but I'm old school and prefer working in Photoshop and almost never use Lightroom.I won't go through the 100s of features in these applications (there are many sites and videos online if you're curious about how to use these programs) but I will say this is the best way to use Creative Cloud with the least risk to your personal credit information.I'm still not happy that Adobe has switched to the subscription method instead of just letting people buy the software once and be done, but if you need to use Photoshop and Lightroom then a prepaid 12-month subscription card is the way to go.

I have used a number of wired gaming headsets over the years from Turtle Beach as well as other companies like Logitech, but I've avoided wireless gaming headsets prior to this because I've read many complaints online about older wireless gaming headsets. Namely, the audio tends to "drop out" for a few seconds at random times when the older wireless headsets lose their connection. Still, I wanted to give the Turtle Beach Ear Force Stealth 500X a try.I hoped to avoid trouble with the Stealth 500X, so I connected the included transmitter and the headset to my Windows 8.1 desktop and installed the latest firmware from the Turtle Beach website. After the firmware update I tried connecting the 500X transmitter to my Xbox to get started testing.One good thing about the 500X is that the wireless headset and the transmitter are already paired, so you won't have to go through the a frustrating process of pressing extra buttons and typing in a Bluetooth pairing code just to get the transmitter and the headset to start working.Audio quality is pretty good both in terms of the earphone speakers and the quality of the audio picked up by the microphone. Games sounded as clear to me using the 500X as they did when I was using a wired headset, and other gamers heard my voice loud and clear. My only major complaint in terms of audio is that -- as a few other reviewers have mentioned -- the maximum volume setting on the Stealth 500X isn't as high as the Logitech headset that I typically use. I usually have the Stealth 500X set at or near maximum volume just so I can hear the more subtle sound effects in a game ... and I have pretty sensitive hearing.One other item of note is that the "surround sound" modes on the Stealth 500X feel a little more like a marketing gimmick than a useful audio setting. I felt like the standard stereo mode gave the best audio quality.Speaking of "surround sound" ... the earphone cups don't do a very good job of isolating sound from spilling outside the headphones. In other words, if I'm sitting on the couch using the Stealth 500X and my wife is sitting next to me she will still be able to hear much of what is going on. It's not that the headphones are too loud, it's as if they are projecting sound both toward the person wearing the heaset and out around the user. That sort of defeats the purpose of wearing headphones.The headset itself was pretty comfortable on my head and ears, although I found the microphone moves out of position a little too easy.I never had the wireless single drop off during use, but if I started using it after it had been idle for a day or two sometimes the microphone wouldn't work unless I reset the transmitter and the headset. It's not a huge problem as long as you remember to do it before you start playing.The bottom line is that this wireless headset is "pretty good" but I don't know that I would be willing to pay the full retail price of around $230 for this headset given all the "minor annoyances" it has. Turtle Beach might be able to fix a few issues via firmware, but I wouldn't buy this at full MSRP unless you absolutely cannot stand using a better headset because of the wired connection.

The Canon Pixma MG5620 is an all-in-one printer with scanner, copier and printer capabilities (no fax).
