The main headline here is that this printer uses Wi-Fi to your home network, so any device (PC, Mac, tablet or smartphone) can print documents or photos to your printer.Since it's from the team at Canon and part of the "Pixma" line, photo quality is a priority. This will make borderless photo prints up to 8.5 x 11 inches on a variety of photo papers. There is a typo in the description of the "Print" specifications on the Amazon product page that claims this printer can handle larger paper sizes like 11 inches x 17 inches and 13 inches x 19 inches, but that is an error on the Amazon page.Wireless printing is relatively easy to setup, but I will caution Mac OS and iOS users that the folks at Apple have a hard time getting any of their devices to play nice with printers. I usually have to restart my wife's MacBook Air or my iPhone if I want to print something or the print job will not be sent to the printer. I have ZERO problems using PCs or Android devices with this printer ... so it's a problem with Apple, not Canon.The photo quality coming out of this printer is fantastic. Unless you are very picky about your prints you'll have a hard time seeing a difference in photo quality when comparing the prints from this printer to prints from a photo lab.My only complaint about this printer is that the ink tanks are too small considering that this is being aimed at people who want to print photos. Photos (particularly borderless photos) consume a massive amount of ink and if you print a large number of photos that use the same color then you'll quickly run out of ink in one or more of the ink tanks/cartridges.For example, when I printed some photos from a beach vacation with lots of blue skies and blue water the cyan ink cartridge ran out. When I printed a bunch of night shots with black skies the regular black and pigment black inks ran low. The size of the ink tanks wouldn't be a big deal if this was a work printer and you just print a bunch of pages of black text, but if you're primary purpose for this printer is to make photographs then you better buy a bunch of spare ink cartridges.If Canon made this same printer with tanks that are twice as large then I would have given it 5 stars. Canon does offer "XL" ink cartridges that are larger, but they don't hold much more ink than the standard cartridges. We really need tanks that are twice as large as the "XL" cartridges for photo printing.

A few years ago I started shaving during my morning shower (while I'm still in the shower) rather than shaving before or after my shower. The biggest problem I ran into was dealing with shaving cream.Most shaving creams don't respond well in a shot shower and either wash off before you've finished the shave or just short of fall off your face because of the humidity in the shower. I started using body wash instead of shaving cream to shave in the shower, but the problem with that is that most body washes dry your skin and I was left with very, VERY dry skin after every shave.I decided to try out Nivea for Men Maximum Hydration 3-in-1 Body Wash because the "hydration" part of the name made me think it might be just what I needed.As a matter of fact, it was. This body wash works just like any other body wash / liquid soap but it has significantly more ingredients for hydrating your skin ... making it ideal for someone like me who wants to use body wash to shave in the shower.Since I switched to this body wash I've noticed that my face is much smoother and my skin is softer after each shave ... a big difference from the dry, flaky skin I had after shaving with regular body wash.

The Sterling Silver Twist Medallion is a very attractive pendant made of polished sterling silver and looks a bit like a crescent moon from a distance.The real beauty of this pendant is only visible when you get closer and can see the twists and imperfections of the polished metal as it bends up and around the hole for the chain. It's a simple design but very lovely.My only complaint about this necklace is that it's a very nice pendant and a very cheap chain. The pendant is quite stunning in person but the chain is short and thin and looks and feels cheap ... which detracts from the pendant.Overall, I highly recommend this pendant as a gift for women who like silver and don't like gaudy, over-the-top jewelry ... but purchase a nicer (and longer) chain to go with it.

The Turtle Beach Ear Force stereo gaming headset for the Marvel Super Heroes video game is a pretty great gaming headset.This headset works for gaming consoles or for desktop PC's thanks to the included adapter. Each of the headphone cups has a removable panel that can be customized with a different logo panel. I liked the default panel (the one with the various Marvel super hero logos) but I also suppose you could put any picture there as long as the image is cut to fit.Audio performance is pretty good; there is a wide range of sound from highs to lows and the padded cushions are comfortable and keep your ears isolated for quality audio.The adjustable microphone is decent, and people playing games with me had no complaints about my voice from the mic. That said, the adjustable microphone arm (the flexible wire that holds the mic in position next to your mouth) isn't as firm as I would like it to be. I had to readjust the position of the microphone more often than I do with my Logitech G230 headset.Overall, this is a great gaming headset and is ideal for gamers with modern consoles or PCs if you're into Marvel comics. The microphone arm issue isn't the end of the world, but might be annoying if you are used to headsets with really firm microphone placement.

Mega Bloks is the Canadian toy company that makes the best Lego-compatible building block sets. Mega Bloks also manages to get some of the best merchandising deals with game developers (Halo, World of Warcraft, and Call of Duty are also available Mega Bloks sets).The Mega Bloks Assassin's Creed Gunboat Takeover is a nice set that comes with everything you need to build the pirate ship "Takeover" and includes four action figures with accessories. I actually call the figures in Mega Bloks sets "action figures" because they look more anatomically correct (at least in terms of having knees and elbows) and they have more points of articulation so you can pose them in different spots on the ship and they look natural instead of just looking like squarish Lego figures stuck on a toy.My only complaint about this set is that the Gunboat Takeover itself is not to scale with the included action figures. It's a nice set, but the boat needs to be bigger based on the size of the figures. When you load all four figures on the boat it looks more like the "dingy" Takeover rather than a fierce pirate ship.This set is definitely designed for teenage or more adult Assassin's Creed fans in that several stages of the build are somewhat complex and the finished ship is somewhat fragile because of the slender mast and sail rigging.That said, if you are looking for a cool pirate ship and don't want to spend the INSANE $300 or more that Lego charges for its pirate ship sets then the Mega Bloks Assassin's Creed Gunboat Takeover is a great choice.

I've been using Corel PaintShop Pro side-by-side with Adobe Photoshop for almost a decade and the number of reasons to use PaintShop Pro just keep adding up with every new version.For starters, the overwhelming majority of photographers will discover that PaintShop Pro X7 can do more than Adobe Photoshop Elements and "almost" everything that Photoshop CS6/Photoshop CC can do.People who aren't familiar with Photoshop will be pleased to know that the user interface in Corel PaintShop Pro X7 is MUCH easier to understand without the need for a training course. The interface is simply very intuitive.There are two headaches that you will run into if you are someone who used Photoshop and has decided to move to PaintShop Pro because you don't want to "rent" your software from Adobe's Creative Cloud. First, as previously mentioned, the interface is very different from Photoshop so if you're used to Photoshop it will take time to train your brain. Yes, PaintShop Pro is very intuitive, but if your brain got used to Adobe's weird way of doing things it will take time to "unlearn what you have learned."Second, PaintShop Pro X7 has a very basic (almost useless) RAW editor build in. If you're used to ACR in Photoshop or Lightroom then the RAW editor in PaintShop Pro X7 is pretty terrible. This is all the more frustrating because Corel has an AMAZING software program for RAW editing called "AfterShot Pro" which is better than ACR or Lightroom in my opinion.If anyone from Corel is reading this, you need to delete the current RAW editor built into PaintShop Pro and figure out a way to insert AfterShot Pro into PaintShop Pro the same way that ACR is built into Photoshop. This is the ONLY thing that keeps Corel's software from absolutely CRUSHING Photoshop ... at least for those users who aren't blindly loyal to Photoshop.As for the rest of PaintShop Pro, it's pretty great. Some image edits are MUCH faster in Corel PaintShop Pro and others are faster in Photoshop. I've personally found all the edits that I do on a regular are faster in PaintShop Pro except when editing RAW. Again, figure out a way to squeeze AfterShot Pro into PaintShop Pro and Adobe better watch its back.

I am one of those people who usually dismiss fuel system additives as useless "snake oil" products that are just a waste of money. That said, I decided to give the 3M Complete Fuel System Cleaner a try because I read another review here on Amazon. The other reviewer mentioned his car had a rough idle and that a bottle of this cleaner stopped the problem (or at least stopped the rough idle).My 2008 Scion xB has been suffering from a rough idle for a couple of months now and after several trips to the dealer and an independent mechanic they said nothing was wrong. Still, every time I stopped at a stop sign or a traffic light my engine would sputter and the idle felt like the engine was almost flooded or something.I decided I had nothing to lose by trying a bottle of the 3M Complete Fuel System Cleaner. I didn't really expect it to work, but the rough idle completely stopped within a couple of hours of driving around town after I added the bottle to my fuel tank!I still don't know what the problem was, but this stuff solved it. If my car ever develops a rough idle like that again and my mechanic says nothing is wrong I'm going to buy another bottle of this stuff.(Surprisingly) Highly recommended.

This is a great soft shutter button to add to the Sony RX1. As much as I love using the RX1 the shutter button is too low and contributes to camera shake when I press the shutter button. Adding this screw-in shutter button to the camera completely changes the feel of the shutter button and helps me keep the camera steady when I'm shooting at slow shutter speeds.The finish of this Gariz soft release matches the RX1 perfectly and looks like something that was made specifically for this camera. Unlike cheaper soft releases that sometimes loosen over time and fall off the shutter button, the Gariz soft release button has a small rubber washer around the screw threads so the button stays firmly in place and won't wiggle loose over time.Highly recommended.

The Nerf Rebelle Rapid Red Blaster looked like a dream come true for my daughter who wanted a "cool" blaster for shooting me and her brother in the Nerf wars in our house. However, this little blaster has a couple of design flaws that spoil some of the fun.For starters, there are several unique design elements that make the Rebelle Rapid Red more appealing to young girls. Yes, it has light purple and red and pink colors, but there is more to it than that. The grip of the blaster is slightly smaller than the typical grips on Nerf blasters and this makes it MUCH easier for young girls to hold the blaster and shoot for prolonged periods of time without their hands getting tired or sore.On the flip side, this makes the Rebelle Rapid Red a little uncomfortable for adults to hold because the grip is too small for adult hands.Next on the list of unique features are the darts. Although the Rebelle Rapid Red can fire standard Nerf N-Strike Elite darts, this blaster includes six pink and black N-Strike darts and six "message darts." Your daughter can write short messages on the darts and then the words written on the darts are invisible until you put the darts into either the red semi-transparent ammo magazine or put the message dart into the included red decoder to see what message is written on the dart.The biggest design flaw with this blaster is that the "jam door" located on the top of the blaster sometimes pops open on its own. The jam door is there in case one or more darts get jammed inside the blaster -- you can open the blaster and clear the darts out -- but the jam door has a safety switch that prevents the blaster from firing when the door is open. So ... the jam door sometimes pops open on its own and when that happens the blaster won't fire.My daughter got really annoyed with the jam door problem because sometime she would jump out from behind a hiding place to shoot me or her brother during a Nerf war and suddenly her blaster wouldn't fire. That's a really lame design flaw. This problem can be avoided if you're careful and keep one hand near the jam door to keep it closed or use tape to keep it closed, but it's a problem I've never had on any other Nerf blaster.I probably would have given this blaster 4 or 5 stars if it wasn't for the jam door issue. It's actually a pretty good blaster if it wasn't for the jam door popping open.

The Cactus V6 wireless radio transceivers are relatively new to the market but are without a doubt the most versatile radio triggers on the market AND are still cheaper than many radio triggers that are less effective (including PocketWizards).What? How can I dare suggest that the Cactus V6 transceivers are better than PocketWizards? Because I've used almost every variety of PocketWizard made in the last 15 years ... and I've personally found these are easier to use and more reliable*. I put an asterisk by that last comment because the only shooting environment where I haven't tested the Cactus V6 is a professional sports event where there are dozens of other photojournalists using radio triggers at the same time.The main advantage of the Cactus V6 is that it works with a variety of TTL flash protocols so you can control the power output of wireless speedlights even if they come from different manufacturers or use different TTL standards. That's right, you can mix and match flashes from Nikon, Canon, Pentax, Metz, and others ... and the Cactus V6 controls them all as if they are part of the same flash system.The setup is a little complex at first because the V6 has to be told what flash has been connected (or you have to set it up so the V6 can "learn" what flash is connected on its own). However, once you've done the setup a couple of times you'll be able to setup the V6's MUCH faster.I particularly love the V6 system because I use a variety of cameras and flashes from different brands and the V6s communicate with every camera and every flash while giving me the same level of control that is only available with the PocketWizard MiniTT1, FlexTT5 and AC3 zone controller. Keep in mind that the PocketWizard products I mentioned above only give you TTL/ratio control with one type of TTL protocol (Nikon or Canon) and you cannot mix and match like with the Cactus V6.I use multiple V6 transceivers with Pentax, Sony, Olympus and Canon cameras and a mix of Canon, Pentax, and Metz flashes. These triggers give me amazing control over my off-camera lighting all through the V6 that is connected to my camera. I don't have to walk over to flashes or have my assistant change the flash settings ... I can setup everything in  advance and then control my lighting from behind the camera.As I mentioned, I personally found the V6 to be more reliable than the PocketWizards over extremely long distances. My PocketWizards sometimes failed to fire reliably beyond a distance of about 30-35 feet. The Cactus V6 has ALWAYS worked at distances of up to about 60 feet as long as I setup the V6s correctly. I've never used the V6 system beyond about 60 feet so it may work fine beyond that range but I've never tried it.Bottom line, this is a BEST radio trigger system currently on the market in terms of both flexibility and value for your money.Highly recommended.

I've shot with a wide variety of digital cameras since switching from film to digital almost 14 years ago. I shoot professionally and for my own personal satisfaction. The Sony RX1 is one of those few cameras that satisfies BOTH my professional and personal desires while I'm shooting.For starters, the RX1 is compact without being too small and the controls and menu interface are easy to use without being too simple for serious control. You might think it's easy to make a camera that does those things, but trust me, it isn't. Sony struck an almost perfect balance in terms of form and function.The biggest advantage to shooting with this little camera rather than another small "mirrorless" camera is image quality. There are many, many ways to define "image quality" but in this case I define it as images with the greatest possible detail (high ratio of actual image data rather than "noise") combined with an extraordinary dynamic range (detail recorded in both highlight and shadow) and a smooth transition between in-focus and out-of-focus areas (butter smooth bokeh that isn't harsh and distracting).I've shot with a number of full-frame cameras including the Sony A99, A7, A7r, Nikon D700, D600 and Canon 5D mkII. Those cameras are all great, but none of those other cameras (at least not with the lenses I used) deliver the same combination of rich details and insane amount of exposure latitude that comes from the RX1 and its 35mm Zeiss Sonnar T lens with f/2 aperture.I know most people interested in small full-frame cameras are turning to the Sony A7 series and interchangeable lenses, but if you are content with a 35mm lens then the RX1 will not disappoint. The price of the RX1 is higher than it should be now that there are more affordable full-frame cameras on the market, but it still delivers fantastic value when you consider the full frame sensor and the amazing 35mm lens. I've shot side-by-side with RX1 and the Sony A7 and Sony 35mm f/2.8 Zeiss Sonnar T FE ZA lens ... and I personally prefer the images from the RX1.I also own and shoot with several DSLRs and mirrorless interchangeable lens cameras for work, but I enjoy shooting with the RX1 because it has everything I care about in a small package. I bought into cameras like the Olympus OM-D and PEN cameras and Sony NEX cameras because I wanted something small, but as soon as I added multiple lenses they where basically small DSLRs with less image quality. The RX1 is small but doesn't compromise on image quality. The Sony A7 series deliver similar quality, but as soon as you start adding lenses you might as well be using a DSLR kit. I'll stick with a full-frame camera that fits in my jacket pocket.Bottom line, if you are a serious (professional) photographer and can afford this camera (and you don't mind being "stuck" at 35mm) then there is no better camera than the RX1 in terms of delivering great results in a relatively small package.

The Nerf N-Strike Elite Demolisher 2-in-1 is probably one of the best blasters currently available from Nerf. That said, it has a few flaws preventing it from being the "perfect" blaster to bring to a Nerf war.First, let's talk about the good. For starters, the Demolisher is a "flywheel" blaster (a battery-powered, fully automatic blaster) that uses standard N-Strike Elite darts but launches those darts over a greater distance than previous generation N-Strike Elite blasters. Most of my older Nerf blasters lose accuracy after about 30 feet and then the darts travel another 5 to 40 feet with much reduced accuracy. The Demolisher is still pretty accurate out to about 50-60 feet.On top of that (or rather "below" if you're looking at the blaster) there is a built-in "rocket launcher" that fires giant foam rockets over about the same distance. The rocket launcher is a pump-action design so you launch it by pulling the gray charging handle forward and pulling it back quickly. The blaster comes with two rockets: one stays in the launcher and the spare rocket is stored in an empty space in the shoulder stock.This is where we get into the design flaws. For starters, the stock isn't adjustable so it won't fit everyone. Second, the storage space for the spare rocket is located in a position where your face or body rubs up against it. The foam rocket has small foam "stabilizer fins" that help make the rocket more accurate after you launch it, but I'm worried the fins on the rockets will be damaged over time by being stored here.Next, the ammo magazine is actually a standard N-Strike Elite magazine but it has a "bend" at the bottom to make it curve like a "banana clip". Unfortunately, the capacity of the clip is very low (10 darts) because only the straight part of the clip holds darts ... the bent part is just empty plastic. If you aren't already aware, 10 darts is practically nothing for a fully automatic flywheel blaster. You will run out of ammo in a few seconds and have to either stop and change the magazine or reload. It would have made more sense for Nerf to include a drum magazine that can hold 35 darts. Heck, even the 18-dart drum would have been better.I also would have liked it if the rocket launcher had been removable. It's a self-contained pump-action blaster that is fused to the plastic of the main blaster. It would have been nice to make it a removable part so you can carry a smaller blaster if you don't want or need the rocket launcher.Bottom line, this is a cool blaster, but you have to worry about the rocket stored in the stock and you are constantly running out of ammo if you use the included banana clip.

The BOOMco. Twisted Spinner Blaster is a large two-handed dart blaster that fires the new BOOMco. darts.What makes the BOOMco. blasters unique is the plastic darts which are tipped with a proprietary rubber-like substance that sticks to the provided targets (which are likewise coated in a proprietary substance) but the darts won't stick to anything else.These darts make it easy to know exactly if and where you hit the target because the dart sticks EXACTLY where it hits (as long as it hits the provided target or the "shields" attached to the blasters).That said, the plastic darts (which are really just fat plastic drinking straws that have been cut to length and tipped with the weird rubber sticky substance) are a little more painful when they hit at close range than the rubber-tipped foam N-Strike Elite darts from Nerf, and the BOOMco. blasters don't feel as good in the hands (or when shooting) as the Nerf N-Strike Elite blasters.The new BOOMco. Twisted Spinner Blaster looks pretty cool ... until you start using it. The big problem with this blaster is that the cocking mechanism (pulling the front handle back) raises the barrel out of firing position, so it's impossible to keep the blaster pointed straight at your target when you're rapidly firing the blaster (or "slam firing" the blaster by holding down the trigger and pulling back the charging handle every time you want to fire).The uniqueness of the BOOMco. blasters wears off quickly (once you realize the darts are just lame "drinking straw darts" on anything other than the provided targets/shields) and you miss the target because the charging handle moves the barrel. You end up asking yourself, "Why not just use a Nerf blaster?"The Twisted Spinner Blaster is better than nothing if you don't have any blasters at all, but if you can't already tell ... I'd suggest buying a blaster from Nerf's N-Strike Elite line instead.

Let me start out by saying the BOOMco. line of toy blasters is meant to compete head-to-head with the Nerf N-Strike Elite line of dart blasters. What makes the BOOMco. blasters unique is the plastic darts which are tipped with a proprietary rubber-like substance that sticks to the provided targets (which are likewise coated in a proprietary substance) but the darts won't stick to anything else.These darts make it easy to know exactly if and where you hit the target because the dart sticks EXACTLY where it hits (as long as it hits the provided target or the "shields" attached to the blasters).That said, the plastic darts (which are really just fat plastic drinking straws that have been cut to length and tipped with the weird rubber sticky substance) are a little more painful when they hit at close range than the rubber-tipped foam N-Strike Elite darts from Nerf, and the BOOMco. blasters don't feel as good in the hands (or when shooting) as the Nerf N-Strike Elite blasters.The new BOOMco. Dual Defender Blasters are a pretty decent set of dart blasters for kids (or big kids in an office) but the uniqueness of these blasters wears off quickly (once you realize they're just lame "drinking straw darts" on anything other than the provided targets/shields) and you're left asking, "Why not just use a Nerf blaster?"These blasters are better than nothing if you don't have any blasters at all, but if you can't already tell ... I'd suggest buying a blaster from Nerf's N-Strike Elite line instead.

I decided to try out this Samsung 23-inch LED LCD because my aging ASUS 23-inch display has horrible viewing angles (the colors look weird if I move my head to the left or right and the screen washed out too bright if the screen is tilted down and is too dim if it's tilted up  ... you have to view it from straight on).Viewing angles aren't a problem with this monitor because it uses IPS (in-plane switching) technology. You can do a Google search if you want all the technical details, but the bottom line is that a good IPS display looks the same whether you're looking at it from straight on or viewing it from the side. The colors and brightness/contrast don't change if you move your head around.You might be fine with a cheaper standard LCD if you're just browsing websites and typing in a Word document, but if you're watching Netflix movies on your PC or editing family photos then a nice IPS display like this makes a MASSIVE difference because you see how things are supposed to look ... not a messed up view with weird colors because the screen isn't perfectly positioned in front of your eyes.The only negative comment I have about this monitor is that I wish the stand had height adjustment so the monitor isn't so low on my desk. I'll have to get a monitor stand to prop this screen up so my neck isn't in a weird position looking down at my desk.Overall, highly recommended.

I've been a long time user of Eneloop batteries since Sanyo originally came out with them many years ago. Now that Panasonic has taken over the Eneloop line of batteries I was eager to see if these new batteries perform just as well as my old ones.For those of you who don't know, the Eneloop batteries come pre-charged and are among the best mass-produced Ni-MH rechargeable batteries you'll find anywhere. I use them in most of my electronics and I also use them in my camera flashes (the kind that mount in a DSLR hot shoe) because these batteries hold their charge for a long time and quickly recycle the capacitor in a camera flash so you can take the next shot quickly without needing to wait a long time for the flash to recharge.Eneloop batteries also have a longer lifespan than the other rechargeable batteries I've used over the years ... so you don't have to replace them as frequently. As many people know, rechargeable batteries lose capacity over time as they get recharged over and over again. I don't understand the chemical trickery that Sanyo (and now Panasonic) used with the Eneloop line, but these batteries retain their high capacity for longer than any other brand of rechargeable batteries I've owned.I used these new Panasonic Eneloop AA's in a variety of electronics (like the camera flashes I mentioned previously) and rechraged them several times with the old Sanyo Eneloop charger that I have. The batteries performed exactly as expected and  I didn't have any problems. I can't say for certain how long these batteries will last, but if they perform as well as my Sanyo Eneloop batteries then they'll last for many years to come.Highly recommended.

The Epson WorkForce WF-7620 is a BIG printer for your home office or office. It's not a giant office printer from the 1990s but it's bigger than a typical office inkjet printer because this bad boy can print on 13x19 wide format paper.This makes the WF-7620 ideal for small businesses that need to print posters or large presentation materials for clients. The photo quality is good, but if you're looking for a dedicated wide format photo printer then I'd suggest something like the Epson Stylus Photo R3000 or the Canon PIXMA PRO-1 professional photo printers.The WF-7620 is a great all-in-one printer, but those dedicated photo printers I mentioned above use inks specifically formulated for printing photos and their ink tanks are a bit larger. The problem I immediately noticed when printing photos with the WF-7620 is that the ink tanks run out FAST. The ink tanks/cartridges for the WF-7620 are barely larger than the ink cartridges for a standard 8.5x11 home office printer. That's fine if you only make 8.5x11 prints, but the only reason you would buy a printer as big as the WF-7620 is if you plan to print BIG (which consumes more ink) so why did Epson use such small ink cartridges?I like the fact that the WF-7620 has two paper trays for storing different paper types in the printer (like standard office paper in Tray 1 and photo paper in Tray 2). However, the printer drivers that I downloaded from the Epson website for both Windows and MacOS are terrible.The printer driver would pop up with an error message whenever I tried to print something from my Windows 8 PC or my Apple MacBook Air because the printer would get confused about which tray to use and what paper type was in each tray. I would have to walk over to the printer every time and press menu buttons on the printer to manually override the error message and get my project to print.Epson really needs to completely rework the printer drivers and make better ones available IMMEDIATELY.The print quality itself is fantastic and the large flatbed scanner and fax capabilities work perfectly. I didn't have any problems getting this printer connected to my Wi-Fi network, and my only complaints are about the small ink cartridges which will run out too quickly and the terrible printer drivers that make it impossible to use this printer without walking over to the printer and pressing buttons.If Epson fixes the driver issues then I'll give this printer 4 out of 5 stars.

I previously purchased an earlier generation 128GB OCZ Vertex 4 SSD so I was eager to upgrade with the newest 240GB Vertex 460 series when I had the chance.While the 128GB capacity of most budget SSDs is enough for a Windows boot drive and most applications, you'll quickly run out of space if you're storing all your images,family videos, or game installation files on your C-drive. Granted, a 240GB SSD isn't as much storage capacity as a modern 1TB or 2TB hard drive, but 240GB is enough for most users who don't have massive libraries of high-resolution images or a Steam library with several dozen games that you play regularly.This SSD works fine for desktop owners or "most" laptop users, but some of the "Ultrabook" style thin-and-light laptops made in recent years require a smaller "mSATA" SSD because a standard 2.5-inch SATA drive like this one won't fit inside. Be sure to check the specs for your laptop (or contact the manufacturer) to see if your laptop uses a standard SATA drive or a smaller mSATA (or another form factor SSD).Boot times into Windows 8 are marginally faster with this drive than with the older Vertex 4, but it's really only noticeable if you break out a stopwatch. The main advantage of using this drive as far as I'm concerned is that it has a higher capacity than my old 128GB drive.I never had any issues with the older Vertex 4 and I don't anticipate any problems with the new Vertex 460, but OCZ has an okay reputation for customer service should I have a problem.Overall, highly recommended.

I've owned and used many knives over the decades before I discovered the Tops Knives company here in the good old USA. Tops makes outstanding knives with some of the best quality and attention to detail that I've ever seen. I purchased the Tops Knives Interceptor (331 model) because I previously purchased the smaller Tops Knives Tom Brown Scout and it quickly became my favorite EDC (every day carry) knife.I suggest reading my review of the Tom Brown Scout knife if you're interested in a slightly smaller knife than the Interceptor with close to the same design and build quality. Now let's focus on the Interceptor.The Interceptor is available with several different blade styles (blade geometries) but I picked the 331 spear point model because it's the closest to the Tom Brown Scout ... just longer with a thicker blade material (for the times I might need a larger blade) and it has thicker handle slabs.Speaking of the handle, I love this handle style on Tops Knives. Tops has several different knives with handles like this and I own every one of them because I think this is the most comfortable handle design in the world for smaller blades (less than 6 inches of actual blade). The linen-wrapped Micarta handles feel amazing in my hands and I can squeeze this grip as tight as possible and there are no "hot spots" where the grip pattern hurts my hand. It's almost like the grip seamlessly melts into my hand.The blade is perfect for bushcraft or general use with an area of jimping on the thumb ramp to help you hold the knife securely if the knife gets wet or bloody when processing game. There are also holes near the back of the blade to help you secure the knife to a stick/branch if you need to make a survival spear.There are only two reasons that I gave this knife 4 stars instead of 5.First, my Interceptor didn't come as sharp from the factory as my other two Tops Knives. The edge on my Interceptor could barely cut paper straight out of the box but my other Tops Knives were almost "shaving sharp" and cut through paper like it wasn't there straight out of the box.Second, the Kydex sheath that came with my Interceptor wasn't fitted properly so the knife falls straight out of the sheath if you hold it upside down and lightly shake the sheath. My other Tops Knives with Kydex sheaths stay secure in their sheaths and won't come out unless you pull the knife out.Neither of those issues are deal-breakers since I can sharpen the knife and I can heat up the Kydex with a heat gun and mold it to give the Interceptor a more secure fit.Bottom line, I would highly recommend this knife to anyone who wants a medium-sized camping knife or a large EDC fixed blade for military or police use.

I'm not a hardcore outdoorsman but I do like being in the outdoors and I don't mind camping on my own or with another adult. However, as a parent, I discovered that camping is a COMPLETELY different experience with two little kids. Kids need more space (at least if Mom and Dad want to get any sleep) and kids have a natural tendency to complain about any lack of comfort.That's where this Wenzel Klondike tent really comes into a league of its own.This is technically an 8-person tent but I'd say it fits six people "comfortably" and fits a "family of four" with plenty of room to move around and have some of your stuff inside the tent. The main tent room is large enough for a queen-sized inflatable mattress (something my wife insists upon nowadays) and the front room is big enough for our son and daughter to have their sleeping bags, clothes and lanterns inside the tent.Setup was remarkably easy. I've never setup a multi-room tent like this before and it took minimal effort and I probably could have done it without reading the instructions (although I always do ... to avoid unpleasant surprises at the camp site). My wife and I had the entire tent setup in less than 10 minutes the first time (we can probably put the tent up in less than 5 minutes now that we know the process). Tearing down the tent and packing it back up takes a bit more time and effort (as usual) because you have to fold/roll everything back into the bags, but the process is just as easy in reverse.All the screened-in openings have privacy flaps (including the door flap between the main room and the front room). We only had two problems during the camping trip:1) Since the tent is so big sometimes people forgot it was a tent and left the front flaps open so more bugs got inside than usual. (Both the kids and Mom were guilty of that one).2) Every child at the camp site wanted to come play inside our tent. This isn't such a terrible thing when you have kids who want to socialize and play with new friends ... but trying to manage a constant stream of kids wanting to play inside your family's tent gets old after about a day.Honestly, I have nothing bad to say about this tent. If you're in the market for a large tent for a family camping trip then you'll be hard-pressed to find a better tent at a better price than this.Highly recommended!

I was looking for a new first aid kit to replace an old one that has seen heavy use and decided to give this PhysiciansCare kit a try. I wanted to have a freshly stocked first aid kit in the house for my kids' babysitter since my son and daughter play rough and regularly end up with scrapes and bumps that need mending.Although this is from the "PhysiciansCare" brand I wouldn't say this is a true "physician's" first aid kit since it's not setup to handle massive bleeding or more serious life-threatening wounds. That said, this kit comes with a pair of scissors, tweezers, a couple of larger trauma bandages, a role of medical tape, a bunch of generic small bandages (band-aids), as well as several packages of antibiotic ointment, antiseptic wipes and burn cream. You also get two pairs of rubber gloves, one cold pack and one container of eyewash.In short, this is enough for typical first aid needs around the house but probably isn't enough for serious accidents out in the field and is not a "trauma kit" for camping/emergency survival. As long as you know that at the time of purchase then I think this is a nice first aid kit to help treat your family for the typical little accidents at home.

The MarBlue Sleeq Stylus is a basic stylus pen for controlling a touchscreen device without gettign your fingerprints all over it.Although it can be used with a tablet or phone, I'd personally suggest just using this for a tablet or a touchscreen desktop monitor because the body of the stylus is pretty thick and the tip is likewise a little too fat for the small icons on some smartphones. For example, I kept hitting the wrong buttons when typing on my iPhone using this stylus ... but I didn't have any problems using this stylus with my larger Android tablets or my touchscreen Windows 8 laptop.My only real complaint about this stylus is that the clip on the body is a little too form-fitting and hard to use. It's hard to clip the stylus to my shirt pocket because the clip is recessed into the body of the stylus.Overall, it's a good stylus for people who want a pen to use on their tablet or touchscreen PCs.

I needed a nice folder with a medium-sized blade back in 1996 and purchased this Schrade Old Timer at a Walmart store. There is nothing particularly special about this locking folder -- it has nice, large rubber grip inserts (the green part) that provide good grip for very large hands and the knife has a lanyard hole if you want to attach some paracord.The blade is nice and beefy and holds an edge pretty well. The combo of a serrated and straight edge help make this knife useful in a number of situations from opening boxes and cutting wires to skinning game or cleaning fish. The locking mechanism is a little bit "dated" compared to newer folders, but it works and hasn't failed in almost 20 years. I've taken this knife on a few car trips over the years as an emergency tool but it usually just sits in a tool box at home and gets used as a utility knife.I decided to write this review because I was just sharpening this knife and it dawned on me that this knife has lasted longer than any other folder I've used. I was curious if this knife was still being sold and when I found it here on Amazon I wanted to let people know it's a good knife.I suspect it will keep on working as a great utility knife for another 20 years or more as long as I don't do something stupid with it. GREAT knife.

The AmazonBasics Mini DisplayPort to HDMI adapter is a simple cable adapter for connecting a laptop or other mobile device with a mini DisplayPort to an HDMI monitor or HDTV.I used this to connect my Dell XPS laptop to my HDTV at home and it works flawlessly. The cable looks pretty good and should hold up fine. I to wish this adapter was black or dark gray because the white plastic shows dust and dirt very easily and just looks dirty.Overall, there really isn't much to say here ... it works and that's the most important part.

My 4-year-old son absolutely LOVES this playset. It's his "rocket ship" and it's simply a great toy. It's really two toys in one: a launch pad/base and a space shuttle with an astronaut figure.The shuttle has sound effects that aren't "too" annoying and the space shuttle and base can shoot plastic missiles (which are apparently supposed to be "lasers" ... I just noticed that in the product description).I don't have a ton to say about this other than the plastics used in this toy feel very solid and it has help up to the constant abuse from my son. I think it's also a good sign that my son has trouble going to sleep at night if he doesn't have this blue "rocket ship" in his bed or on the dresser next to his bed.Fisher-Price does good work as usual.

The ADX Handheld Mini CREE LED flashlight/lantern is a basic key chain LED flashlight with a "lantern" feature to spread the light over a wider area.My biggest complaint about this flashlight is that it uses a CR 2032 coin-style battery rather than a standard AA or AAA battery. Yes, a standard battery usually means the flashlight has to be longer, but frankly I'd rather have a slightly longer flashlight that uses a standard battery than get stuck during a power outage without a replacement battery.If you overlook the coin-style battery then my next complaint is the "lantern" feature which feels more like a gimmick than a really useful feature. Sure, when you move the front of the flashlight into the lantern position it spreads the light out but the light output is so weak that you aren't really getting the amount of light you expect from a small lantern.My last issue with this flashlight is the keyring attachment. The clip itself is pretty solid and works exactly like you want it to, but the circular ring that connects the clip to the flashlight is just a thin wire ring and it's easy to pull apart. I actually pulled the flashlight off the ring by accident because the wire pulled apart.Bottom line, this flashlight works but it's not ideal because of the non-standard battery, weak lantern feature, and weak wire ring connecting the flashlight to the key chain clip.

I started using Pinnacle Studio 17 Ultimate a few weeks ago mainly to help me record live capture of what is on my computer screen so I can make videos to train people how to use various applications on a PC. Pinnacle Studio has been wonderful for that purpose but it is able to do so much more.For starters, it simplifies the process of importing video from my cameras and my iPhone as soon as I connect them to my computer. From there, it's pretty easy to do quick edits and export the finished video to YouTube or burn a DVD. Of course, if you want to do more complex, "serious" editing then Pinnacle Studio has a bunch of 2D and 3D effects and filters you can apply to make your videos look extremely professional.The user interface is very straightforward -- if you've ever used a "timeline" style video editing application it should only take you a few minutes to figure out how to edit a basic video using this software.I didn't test the 4K capabilities of this software because I don't have a native 4K camera or a 4K monitor, but it's good to know that this software has the capability to edit video footage that has been shot at "greater than 1080p resolution."In short, I would recommend this software because it has a lot of great features and it's easy to use. I haven't found an easier application for recording live capture on my PC so this is great.

I was eager to try out the Panavise PortaGrip Phone Holder with Windshield Mount for my car (a 2008 Scion XB) because I use my iPhone in my car all the time. My iPhone is my music player, my GPS, and I use it for hands-free calls. The problem is that I haven't found an in-car mount for my iPhone that I really like.I've tried several, but none of them have the flexibility or the mounting hardware that I need. I did recently purchase the iOttie HLCRIO102 One Touch Windshield Dashboard Universal Car Mount Holder for my wife's van and that iPhone holder has been wonderful in my wife's van. I was about to purchase one of those for my Scion when I saw the Panavise and decided to give it a try.The Panavise PortaGrip is very similar to the iOttie HLCRIO102 but the Panavise PortaGrip has two major flaws:1) The release isn't quite "one touch" like the iOttie holder, so I often had to fumble with the release buttons on the sides to get my phone out of the holder.2) The suction cup mount is essentially useless. I couldn't get this suction cup to stay mounted to any window or windscreen in my car or my wife's van. I don't know why it's called a "windshield mount" if it doesn't stay mounted to the windshield.Overall, I can't really recommend the Panavise PortaGrip because it doesn't really work as a "windshield mount" in either of my vehicles. If you want something like this then I'd recommend the iOttie HLCRIO102 One Touch Windshield Dashboard Universal Car Mount Holder instead.

I used Dr. King's Natural Medicine Skin Tag Remover as directed by the instructions on the bottle for more than a month and the only thing that happened is I started smelling like Tea Tree oil.For those who aren't familiar with it, tea tree oil (also called melaleuca oil) is an essential oil that many people claim has a variety of medicinal uses for everything from working as an antimicrobial additive for soap to treating head lice or ... possibly getting rid of skin tags.Frankly, after doing some basic Google searches there is no clear scientific evidence that tea tree oil can get rid of skin tags ... and even if it does you may not want to go around smelling like tea tree oil.Maybe this stuff works for someone, but it did absolutely nothing to my skin tags after more than a month of use. I just ended up smelling like melaleuca oil.

The Goal Zero Switch 8 is a basic and convenient USB rechargeable battery that fits in your purse, coat pocket, or bag and gives you an emergency power boost for your smartphone, tablet, e-reader, or other mobile devices that can be charged over USB.It's a little disingenuous to call it a "solar recharger" because this battery pack is only solar powered if you combine it with the Nomad 3.5 solar panel ... which is sold separately.That said, there are three things that I love about this charger:1) It's powered via USB input so you can plug it into any USB port on a PC or a USB-to-power outlet adapter to charge this battery pack/stick.2) The USB output is a good 5 Volt, 1 amp for a variety of devices, so you just need to bring your iPhone USB cable to connect the battery to your iPhone or iPad.3) You can "daisy chain" multiple batteries together for more power.Here is the bad part ... the battery capacity is very weak. A single stick is just 2200mAh (compared to many iPhone battery packs or battery cases that have a rating of "at least" 2350mAh. This means you need to get at least TWO of these Goal Zero batteries and daisy chain them together to get a really nice power boost.As a side note, I recently attended a business presentation where someone gave out similar USB battery sticks to everyone for free ... and that guy bought his battery sticks from some other website for $10 each ... so I don't think this particular battery offers a great value per dollar other than the fact you can daisy chain multiple batteries together.

The Actiontec Dual-Band Wireless Network Extender is a well-built Wi-Fi externder for your home network and works with both Ethernet and COAX routers.This box actually includes both the WCB3000N Wi-Fi extender (the main reason you want to buy this device) and a ECB2500C Ethernet over COAX Adapter. I don't have any need for Ethernet over COAX so I only used the WCB3000N Wi-Fi Extender in my home.If you're a techie like me then it should only take you 10-20 minutes to add this device to your home network. My home has a mixture of MacOS, iOS, Android, Windows 7 and Windows 8 devices and they all recognize this device without any problems. Wi-Fi speed varies dramatically depending on network usage from my main PC that's wired directly to the router, but devices that used to be at the extreme edge of my home Wi-Fi network can now access the Wi-Fi signal with better speed (most of the time ... again, it depends on if my main PC is really hogging the network).As others have mentioned, the quick start instructions aren't the best, and you might not get much help from the Actiontec website so I recommend that non-techies just take some time and read the full manual.

The Corsair RM Series 550 Watt power supply unit is hands down the best PSU I've used ... ever. I've had higher wattage PSUs with removable cables but this 90Plus Gold-Certified PSU is a premium product with all the bells and whistles you need ... as long as you don't have a giant rig with multiple high-end graphics cards.For starters, the RM550 is built with high-end capacitors and transformers and a super quiet fan so you don't get the coil whine fan noise that is typical to MANY power supplies. If you are sensitive to high-pitched noises from electronics then this is the PSU to get.Second, like most high-end PSUs, the RM550 has removable/modular cables so you only need to use the cables needed for your rig and you don't have a bunch of extra cables filling up your PC.The last big thing is that this power supply is very energy efficient ... my rig actually consumes less power (according to a kill-a-watt plug-in meter) than the same rig with a cheaper 500W PSU.This brings me to the last issue: wattage. If you are a system builder or you're doing a DIY upgrade, be sure to know the power requirements for your components. I'm running a modern Core i5 desktop with three SSDs, a DVD drive, card reader, and a single upper-mid-range Nvidia graphics card for gaming. 550 Watts is plenty of power for my rig, but if I had a higher wattage Core i7 and two or more graphics cards then I'd probably need a higher wattage PSU.Bottom line, the RM550 is a GREAT desktop power supply and I highly recommend it.

Cyberlink PhotoDirector 5 Ultra is a rather limited photo editing and retouching application compared to something like Photoshop CS or Photoshop Elements, but it does a VERY good job at simplifying several rather complex editing tasks ... making it possible for amateurs to do very difficult retouching.For starters, many people would like to quickly remove blemishes or make themselves look thinner in photos, and PhotoDirector 5 makes it so easy to do those things I'm actually surprised they're so difficult to do well in Photoshop.The content-aware object removal tools make it easy to remove distracting objects from the backgrounds in photos, but like Photoshop and Photoshop Elements you have to be careful since the software can get confused by complex backgrounds.In short, if you just want to quickly edit your family photos and don't want to learn more complex photo editing techniques then PhotoDirector 5 Ultra is probably the right software for you.

CyberlinkPowerDirector 12 Ultimate is a complex video editing suite that uses a very simplified user interface to let just about anyone edit movies at home.I like this software because it's easy to use, robust in features, and comes with a ton of templates if you just want to make a "quick and dirty" video from your clips.One of the big bonus features here for me is the ability to edit 4K video. Sure, most people aren't shooting in 4K video yet, but 4K video cameras are becoming more affordable and that means novice videographers need a editing solution to produce finished videos from 4K cameras.Overall, highly recommended.

As stated in the title, the Twister Dance Rave game is essentially a little electronic dance game that uses supplied music or an iPod or iPhone to play your kids' music. The "game" includes dots for kids to place on the floor so they can plot out dance moves.Overall, it's a nice idea and my daughter had fun with this at a sleepover party with her cousin, but I don't really see how this relates to the Twister game that I grew up playing as a kid.

The Tylt Energy Power Case is a simple hard case for the iPhone 5 and 5s that also includes a rechargeable battery to extend the life of your iPhone while you're on the go.The 2350mAh battery capacity is enough to nearly double the battery life of the iPhone and the rubber-coated hard plastic case gives your iPhone some added protection in case you drop it. Of course, the added battery means it takes roughly twice as long to charge the phone if the case battery and the phone battery are both depleted, but that should be expected since you're adding another battery.My only two complaints about this case are that the pass-through is a little small for the volume buttons and mute switch on the side so it's harder to access those buttons if you have big fingers ... and the case increases both the size and weight of the iPhone.Granted, the size and weight increase aren't massive ... but if you already think the iPhone 5 is a big phone then you might want to pass on this case.As far as I'm concerned, the added protection and additional battery life make this case more than worth it. Highly recommended.

I upgraded from an older AMD Radeon 6850 graphics card (which was the loudest thing inside my PC) to this Gigabyte GeForce GTX 660 OC edition. The new card is significantly better than my old card -- I can see lighting and shadow details that I didn't even realize where in my games -- and it runs MUCH quieter.The "Windforce" heatsink and dual fan design keeps the GPU cool but the card remains relatively quiet even when the fans turn on high. This lack of noise combined with exceptional gaming performance is why I love this graphics card. Sure, I can still hear the fans working when I'm pushing a game at 1080p resolution with all the detail settings maxed out, but the fans aren't so loud that i can't hear my wife or kids calling my name from outside my office (that was a problem with my old Radeon card).Add to this the fact that the GTX 660 supports my 3D monitor (for the handful of games I might want to play in 3D) and the GTX 660 supports streaming games to the Nvidia Shield and this is simply a fantastic card.Keep in mind this is a dual-slot card because of the large cooling block so make sure you have two open slots on your motherboard/case. Space isn't too much of an issue -- I was able to fit this card inside a typical mini-tower without any problems -- just make sure you have at least a 500w power supply and you should be golden.

The Kaotiks Psycho-Plex track and car is a pretty neat RC car playset with a few minor issues that spoil the fun.This is a pretty entry-level rechargeable RC car with only forward and reverse controls (the car turns on the track only because the walls prevent the car from moving in a straight line). As a result, the car isn't much fun without the track since you can't turn it and move it around the environment.That said, when you're using the Kaotics car inside the Psycho-Plex track it's pretty cool because the walls keep the car moving around the track and the ramps let you do some cool jumps/tricks ... until the battery runs out.This brings me to my biggest complaint about the car: The capacity of the rechargeable battery is too low. My son and daughter run down a fully charged battery in less than 10 minutes ... meaning they have to stop playing after 7-8 minutes and recharge the car for at least a half hour!The lack of steering makes the car a little annoying since you can't turn it outside the track but the weak battery spoils the fun since the car usually stops working right when my kids really get into playing with it. As it is now, I'd say my kids spend more time waiting for the car to recharge than they spend playing with it.I also think the walls on the track need to be twice as tall so that the car doesn't fly off (and out of) the track so frequently during jumps off the ramp.Bottom line, this is an affordable RC car track with a fast little car that does cool tricks on the track ramps, but the play experience is hurt by the lack of steering control and the weak battery.

My 4-year-old son loves every play vehicle we've purchased from Green Toys and my wife and I love the fact Green Toys are affordable, well built and made of recycled materials right here in the USA.This rocket is durable with two compartments (with doors that open and close) and comes with two astronaut figures.I won't call these "action figures" because they don't have any articulation (no movable joints). That's really my only minor complaint about the Green Toys Rocket: I wish the astronauts had movable arms and legs. Sure, that would make the figures a little less durable and these toys are designed for kids as young as 2, but the astronauts are pretty boring compared to the cool rocket.In any case, my son loves this toy and I highly recommend it (and other Green Toys products) to any parent looking for a quality toy for young kids.

The Genius Wireless Energy Mouse is a nice wireless mouse that is useful for laptop users who want to take an external mouse on the road and it offers a little something extra with the ability to provide some power to your smartphone.First, let's start with the mouse. This is a basic wireless mouse with an optical sensor and a relatively high DPI (1200 DPI) setting which is good for high-resolution screens. If your PC has a low-resolution display then the cursor/pointer will move VERY when you move the mouse. Unfortunately, the DPI can't be changed for low-res screens but most modern desktop screens and laptops have 1080p screens nowadays.The bottom of the mouse it "okay" for mobile use but I would have liked to see bigger/wider glide feet on the bottom so the mouse could more easily slide over desktop or mouse pad surfaces. The micro-sized USB receiver is nice because it pops into a USB port on your laptop and doesn't stick out like a sore thumb ... so you can leave it plugged into your laptop when traveling.Now lets move onto the "Powerbank" function of this mouse. The Powerbank is rated at 2700mAh which means it's not particularly powerful. In simple terms, when my iPhone 4s was down to minimal battery power (red) I was only able to get the Energy Mouse's Powerbank to charge my iPhone up to around 50% (+/- 15%). The same goes for my ASUS MeMo Pad 10 FHD Android tablet.Bottom line, the Powerbank inside this mouse is just meant for "topping off" your smartphone or tablet or is meant to provide "emergency power" to your smartphone. It's not capable of completely recharging a device from almost zero battery power to full. As long as you understand and accept that limitation the Genius Wireless Energy Mouse is a pretty nice travel mouse.

The Crest Oral-B Professional Whitening Kit is a complete package designed to help you with dental hygiene as well as make your teeth look "pretty" and as white as possible.The biggest and most important part of this package is the included Oral-B Professional Precision 4000 Electric Toothbrush ... which I can honestly say is the best toothbrush I've ever used ... better than my Sonicare toothbrush that I used to think was the best toothbrush in the world.The Precision 4000 brush makes my teeth and gums feel MUCH cleaner than they did with my Sonicare toothbrush and this Oral-B toothbrush also has a pressure sensor that flashes a red light if I'm pushing too hard when brushing (too much toothbrush pressure can damage your tooth enamel and your gums).The toothbrush includes an extra brush head and a travel case so I can bring this awesome toothbrush with me when I travel.You also get some great toothpaste, mouthwash, and professional-strength whitening strips to help clean your teeth and gums and make your teeth look extra white.Bottom line, this is a great all-in-one solution for keeping your teeth clean and white.Highly recommended.

Overall this is a good case for the ASUS MeMO Pad 10 FHD. The tablet fits inside relatively securely and the case itself provides some added protection.That said, I couldn't give this folio case a 5-star rating because the part of the case that holds the tablet in place is a fraction of a millimeter too large (allowing the tablet to slide around a bit inside the case) and that gets annoying sometimes when I go to press the power button on the tablet and the tablet "slides" inside the case instead of the button getting pressed.If the "pocket" for the tablet was just a little smaller then the tablet wouldn't slide at all and I wouldn't get frustrated sometimes when I go to press the power button.

we love the mountains - we love Colorado.  I've lived there in the Army in the 80's....we plan to retire there in about 5 years.These plates are first class, metal, and don't fade or chip and proudly display our passion.  We live in a state that doesn't require front license plates...so we have them on the front of my jeep and my wife's Yukon denali

I'm a guy - and I'm a big guy at over 6'4" and around 250...I tried a wider one of these from another company here on Amazon....I thought it would be better being wider.  I also liked the "idea" of a vertical phone pocket....until I tried it on and it promptly folded in half to about the width of this belt.In short - I ordered the original here - and I love it.  It works awesome for my gym key and cell phone.  It works fine on runs too...but I use a concealed carry belt called Pistol Wear for that...so I don't wear both at once then.This belt is just beyond great for what I use it for, I'm happy I have it.

can't add much to the massive volume of data/reviews on Lifestraw - EXCEPT that I got tired of "playing around" with lesser brands and not so simple products.  I love my Katadyn Base camp for the big chores...but for the backpack and just all around everyday...this is my go to.Tried, proven, tested the world over.  I got over myself and just ordered this.  Glad I did.

I have to say first of all that I'm a guy.  I assume it will work differently for ladies with hips.  I will find an appropriate larger lady to gift mine to when the time is right...but I ordered an XXL and while it fits me just fine, it would fall off my wife and daughter.The part I liked - the "vertical" cell phone pocket.  I really thought that was a better plan as I looked at these....but I was wrong....for a guy anyway.  As a big guy, I have a little "V" but not a lot...and I have no "hips" that stick out...so the width of this....that looked so promising....well, it just folded right up on itself no matter how high or low I tried it on.  In the end, it was just about 3" wide....just like the original flip belt....which I ordered next, use with no problems, and think is really a great way to go hands free with my cell phone, gym locker key, and whatever else I want with me.I tore the packaging very badly, can't find the info card...etc... so I don't think it's cool to take advantage of returning this to Amazon...I will keep it until I can gift it away.  I am sure it will work wonderfully for a lady with hips that flare out enough to hold it's shape,haha!

I suppose it's me...I just think they are too small.  I see guys at the gym pool with their belly lapping over their tiny speedos...but I sure hope I have more decorum than that! lol.I pullled these out and immediatly knew they were just way too short.  The model in the ad must be 5'2" or something.  I'm 6'4" and these come down somewhere to what I would call the top of my thigh.Amazon Prime was awesome, as always, and my refund was super fast.

Out of the box (or their protective case!) these goggles are really amazing.  They are simple to adjust, don't bind or pinch, and haven't moved in any stroke I've tried.  I used to swim a lot - even competitively in my younger days - and I can't remember if I ever had a better pair of goggles.  I certainly enjoy them every time I swim, which is 3-4 mornings a week.I'll also say this seller is one of the better ones on Amazon.  The nice emails and the genuine concern they seem to show for my satisfaction in this purchase is really nice.

As I approach 50 I could care less what my dress shoes look like...I just want them comfy!  And I'm sorry...but it's not like size 14 extra wide shoes are everywhere.  My wife is less than thrilled that I have yet another pair of "old man shoes" to wear to work...but I don't really care, haha!I work in an industry where it's still "white shirt and tie" 4 days a week...and "casual friday" is a blue dress shirt!  It's just the way it is, I accept that.  If I could, I'd wear tennis shoes to work and scrubs but I chose finance over medicine and that's that.These shoes are a little tough on my feet at first - but that's probably from all my running and other training I do - my feet are generally sore a few days a week when the monthly mileage creeps up over 70-80 miles, so I can't blame these shoes.I can say they are supple when broke in for a few days and the leather is equal to any good leather when polishing them.  I don't find my feet hot in these shoes at all, and I don't find any points that cause friction or pain.  I am thankful to have found these and I may just buy another pair right away to put up for when these wear out in a few years!

My own logs are recent compared to some here...mine only go back to 2003...but I treasure these logs!Sure, I have runkeeper and other apps...but things go wrong with electronics...and it's hard to look back through anything else like you can a book format.I use different colored inks for recording facts vs extra noteworthy items (new PR's, special states or neat places I run,There is plenty of room to add what you want - I add the time of the run, duration, and min/mile, and what shoes I wore that day. (So I can track the mileage of different shoes)These logs are like old friends...just last month I reviewed how I did in a 15k in 2003 in sub freezing temp with high winds. I have a potentially similar race coming up this winter...and it was nice to make note if some things I did and what worked and what didn't - even that many years ago - that info is nice to have and review.

got this for the motorcycle - fits easy in the bag on the Ultra Classic and really helps for peace of mind on the long rides.I plan to rotate the gas from the bottle to the jeep each month.just like some reviews say - if you tighten the cap FULLY - it will not spill.

I like it.  It's not a 100% true free rotate thing.  It does rotate but on an "oblong" path.  So...for my bars on my ultra classic...I can't quite rotate this enough for me to see the screen at the angle I wanted....but it's OK - it puts the phone up front, exposed where I can see it at least, even if I can't tilt it to read for maps.

countless 5k's....not sure why I never bought one of these...but when I got thru a 15k, I figured why not? So I got the 5, 10, and 15k set for the side window of the jeep.5k's are just so fun - and I'd run one, jog one, or walk one every weekend if someone wanted me to join them.

we love this rack.  It's easy to put on and off....it folds....and it holds the 3 bikes super securely.we got tired of needing the socket set to attach the bolt and nut that slides into the hitch receiver....but I just bought a regular slide in bolt and cotter pin for $4 at Walmart and it's fine...we don't even hear it move or rattle...if it does at all.

LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this collection.1st, I like the Chicken Soup series in general....I've read a few over the decades...but this one is SO GREAT.  I can see me re-reading these stories again a time or two in the years to come.If you run, jog, or power-walk....and I do all three off and on...you'll appreciate this book.

SUPER nice blanket....even if the colors are a bit more for a lady...I like it.Wish it would have been the blue or black pattern....but I got the one with a lot of raspberry tones in it.it IS soft...it is plenty big...and it rides on the back seat of my jeep ready for anything I need it for.

Have it on the side window of the jeep....couldn't have said it better myself, lol.  What was I thinking?!but...you know...when you accomplish something like a 15k.....you just appreciate it.White I have run countless 5k's...a good number of 10k's...I'm not sure I'll ever go beyond 15k...I might..But I do like the decal and it's funny.

I guess you either like him or you don't....and I sure LOVE his positive messages and the way he teaches.My wife and I owe so much to our amazing God....and we thank Him for leading us to Joel over the past 5-ish years.Our lives are better, our kids are better, our marriage is better....when we focus on the good things God has in store for us.This book is "more of the same" yes...if you receive it...you'll love it.If you don't....you won't.
can't walk in them....but I do like them.wearing them for 15 minutes provides a much needed stretch to my toes.  I enjoy the feeling a lot for hours afterwards.

daughter bought this for nursing school - she loves the big second hand....makes it easy for her to do vitals with....and she's watched me wear the same casio watch a lot of her life, so she knows she can trust it.I have had 2 Casio DW 56000e's  in 30 years since basic training.They just are bulletproof watches you never have to take off or worry about damaging.
daughter picked it out - it was a great value - she loves it.  Very fluffy and very much to her liking.

I'm on month 2 now of using it.  I've decided to start cycling my multi-vitamins and prostrate supplements every few months after I read an article about your system getting used to a certain formula and it having decreasing effectiveness.anyway - GNC is under some scruitiny, sure...but that's why it's a perfect time to use their stuff.  You know they aren't going anywhere....you know they try even harder now to get all good stuff in their stuff....and the value is better than ever.I'll probably go about 4 months total on this and switch off to my old brand, but I like it.

well, the wife loved it.  lol.she's usually a medium in a unisex t-shirt and a large in a ladies cut.she's 5'4 and about 118-120...but likes her shirts to fit looser in the body and bust...and this one is right on for the way she likes it.
I developed kidney stones recently and have to limit the protein intake...you know....I'm actually gonna miss this one - it was one of the best shakes I have had in 20 years of lifting.

worked on my bald head in early spring, haha!I have since spent enough time in the sun to darken up the glaring white bald head I get from the winter...and I don't use it anymore...but it was great.goes on easy, washes off the hands easy, and in a few days you can tell a gentle tanned effect.  I think I used it for around 2 weeks.

bought this 10 pack to help replenish our various go bags, camping bags, and vehicle bags.  They get used from time to time...and we don't try to reuse them past one shelter or one blanket type event.  These have come WAY down in price over the years...and yes...they are very thin and there are better ideas like the "sportsmans blankets" but these pack so small...they belong in any small kit or bag just because.  I have one in my small kit that goes with me EVERYWHERE.  It's in my briefcase during the day, in my carry bag around work hours or in my cargo pocket, and it's thrown into other bags for trips.

makes a nice gift that isn't too expensive for kids getting into the outdoors.  Not a terrible idea to have the mag bar in your go bag either....the ferro rod on the side is really sub-par compared to the dedicated versions you can (and should) have in your bag...but it's an added bonus that comes with the mag bar.  I've been able to use the mag bar on several occasions to make a fire easier with wet materials.  Not a total solution...but a nice helper.

if you have a son, think you'll have a son...or just want to understand some of the really cool things God has put in boys, guys, and men...then this book will be a great resource for you.  I enjoyed it on a lot of levels years ago.  Came here to purchase as a gift today.

works well for a Glock mag "hide in plain site" solution.  I did take a small piece of black cloth and insert it into the bottom to cover the hole so the top round in the mag wouldn't show.  I like it a lot.

this is really high quality stuff here.  The medallion is heavy, backed with really quality 3m tape that sticks to the paint very well on the back of my Jeep Wrangler Unlimited.  I've had the stickers for years on different vehicles but wanted to try something nicer...and wow...this is like a whole other category over a decal.
My wife loved it!!!!

I do like this band a lot.  I find I wish it was a little longer...but then I hung my bar over my 8' full reach height (I'm 6'4" with long arms) and I am not very flexible to get my foot high enough to put into the bottom end.  I get it done...but it requires a 3 step ladder and I'm sure it's still quite funny watching me try to pull up my leg high enough to get it looped under my foot, lol!  If anyone is concerned about weight, I am 260 right now and the band doesn't have any problems with my weight.But... all that funny "contortionist stuff" said...when I get DO get my foot in there...and I step off the ladder - it's awesome to be able to do a respectable "set" of pull ups before I can't do another....and then a few minutes later to do it again.  I've done chin-ups before (usually just a few) but never got more than a single wide grip pull up.  With the band I can do 15 to 20 before failure I go fast, and a solid 10 if I go slow and really feel the contraction of the lats. Of course the second time I do it I can only manage 5 or so....I ended up buying the next size heaver band too.  I want to be able to do even more - like my weights, something like 3 good sets of 12-15 reps to really work the muscles in my back.  I'm pretty happy with this set up.

love this stuff.  I use it on the Harley, mowing the yard, fishing, whatever....It goes on nice and cool and NOT sticky.  I think it must do it's SPF job...I seem to last longer before I feel anything.  I do try to cover up a lot with sun shirts and hats...but when I don't I feel this does a good job.Last year I ordered a 2 pack with Prime shipping for what I paid for one this year....but I do think it's that good.

have to say - this a SCREAMING DEAL here!It's in the description...but note that it comes with the anchors to go into a brick or concrete wall - NOT any type of wood mounting.I stopped at the hardware store and got some heavy duty lag bolts and washers (way under $5) and it went up in minutes.I currently weigh 260ish and can not feel ANY movement in this set up.  I have it mounted into the header above the door going into my garage from the laundry room.  With the slight step-down there and by mounting the bar above the door....I can fully extend my arms to grab the bars and just be on my tip toes....and I'm 6'4" so I can't cheat.  I like it.

this was our second order of these.  We have 3 iphones in the family with lifeproof cases and these work well to replace the "dongle" that is required when using earbuds and those cases.Eventually...they spin out...but it's ok as you can get 3 under $10 and Prime shipping.  They seem to last around 6 months and it's totally dependant upon how tightly you regularly connect these to the case.  If we aren't in water...we tend (now) to just lightly tighten them to the case.  Works fine and lengthens the time they last
perfect fit for my machine.  Nice to have backups for a value price and Prime shipping

I had to return them immediately as they are too narrow for a wide foot.Hopes were high given the great reviews that they would fit my 4e foot...but no dice.The arch support seemed good and my gosh...they DO feel like walking on clouds!My little toe was squeezed way too much - I felt it immediately and in 5 minutes I had soreness there.

we love this.  Coming off years of the old circle scale with the dial....this is awesome.  It's great to track all sorts of things.A bit touchy...but as a recent kidney stone issue presented itself....one of the things the dr. wanted me to do was to keep track of how much I was going.  Well, you may remember the old saying "A pint is a pound all the world 'round" ....well, close enough...A quart/liter is about a pound of water (and pee) and it's easy to keep track of how much I pass with this scale.Of course...the 5'4" 100 ish pound wife uses it to obsess over a half a pound...lol...but it's still a great scale.  We love it.

I've gotta say...I've been cutting my own hair for a decade now...and I've never had it easier than using this set up.I take it out and lay out the guides and start...and just a few minutes I am done.  The ear guides (left and right) and the eyebrow guide...all the hair guides...simple and quick and I can't see how anyone couldn't do a great job.

47....haven't seen a dr. for more than a cold since I left the Army at 22 years old.  Imagine my surprise when Kidney Stones hit me last month!Well, as this book (and my Dr.) pointed out...I was "working hard" at making Kidney stones!  How? oh...just being "healthy!"  I got a Nutribullet....I stuffed Kale and Spinich in it....threw in all kinds of nuts....then added blueberries and razberries to cover the taste of the kale...then I added a scoop or two of protein powder....and I drank this "healthy" shake 2 times a day for months!  Oh sure...I dropped the pounds and thinned up considerably....but I NEVER realized that my "shake" consisted of 5 of the top 10 WORST things to eat for making kidney stones!  I mean...who talks about that?  (Kale, Spinich and Beet root are all tied for the number one offender spot in the book!)  Then throw in rapid weight loss, not enough water, eating too much additional protein, and loving tomato sauce....and I "hit" about NINE of the top 10 worst things you can do....every day/every week!
