The book is SO full of knowledge!Never had anything so painful...NEVER want them again!  I read this entire book in 2 days WHILE on 3 pain meds they gave me to help pass them!  I have since gone back several time to several passages with highlighter and stick note "tabs" I made.  I have learned SO much.  The book is technical...but not too much....and it's SO complete.The restaurant guides and food lists are worth every penny - the entire book is.  I hear of people getting them over and over - my Dr. says it's mostly because they don't change their diets....but I can't imagine why not.  I'm VERY motivated and have not had ANY problems changing my diet!

awesome seat for spinning bike!  This seat is fantastic - I'm 6'4" and 260....my wife is 5'4 and 110-115....we both use this seat on the spinning bike we bought and LOVE it.  No hot spots or rubbing...and no sore butt!

OK....I'm closer to 50 than 40...and this is WAY overkill for what I needed...but daughter in college really pushed for the wife and I to get this one - it's the same model in her college gym - where they have a room full of them for spinning classes.  She wants to use it in the summers when she comes home.My wife is 5'4" and about 110-115....and I am 6'4" and now down to around 260....down from 300 last year...and headed to around 225 I think.Here's what we did to make this "work" for us:1st - the seat.  We found a nice full size, dual spring "comfort seat" for $20 here on Amazon....(Sunlite Cloud 9) I noticed Walmart and Academy had the same/similar as well.  The seat on this bike as it comes is so awful it's hard to put into words...I've biked most of my life and even a bmx trick bike seat seems like I remember it being better than this.  Luckily, it's a fast and cheap fix.2nd - the handlebars.  Unless you enjoy looking at the ground in front of the bike....something has to be done.  Even with the seat at lowest position and bars at highest position - for my shorter wife - she couldn't look up at the TV on the wall for more than a minute without hurting her neck.  For me...it's impossible to see more than the front wheel without unnaturally craning my neck at an extreme angle...let alone even seeing the TV on the wall to watch it at all.  We found a U shaped bar - it actually came off a Pilates we no longer use...and it has become our "raised bars" - we hook it thru the bars and it raises them about 15" or so....it also moves the grip spot back towards the seat - helpful if you are not trying to achieve the "tour de france look"  lol.The good?  The bike is WHISPER quiet.  It's probably going to last decades as there is really nothing to go wrong....and it's built like a tank.  I average an half hour to an hour on it in the evenings and then I go do some other workout things.  My wife walks on her treadmill (in the same room) for an hour or so...then jumps on this bike for another half hour-ish.  It's become a nice staple in both our routines.  The daughter?  she does crazy stuff like spending 12 hours straight spinning for charities and stuff like that....so if she wants to throw on the original seat this summer...she can...but the handle mod just comes off and on simply....so she can spin all she wants....she has already tried to show us how to put spinning videos on the TV...but we just watch our TV shows and pedal away.We set the resistance to something more than  easy....and then we either turn up the resistance during the commercials or try to increase our speed to as fast as we can go during the commercials...to make it a great workout.  I know I am drenched by the time I get off it....and she's already sweating before she gets on it....but I know we end up doing a lot more laundry each week since we got this bike, lol.

Forst I tried tried the silly little ones that looks like an extendable car antenna. They are awful in that they twist and flop my iPhone around terribly!  Sure they are small and under $10 with shipping...but a total waste of $ to me.Next I tried an old mono pod - remember when people carried cameras and video cameras? Lol.  We had it lying around and it worked...sorta...with some cobbled together accessories.  It also was around 2.5 to 3 feet long in the shortest position.So - my son (who is a go pro dude on all his outdoor adventures) finally said...get one like this - so we ordered this one...and couldn't be happier.It's very compact - seems really sturdy - and even my wife's iPhone 6 plus WITH a case fits fine in the expandable jaws.  It's in the saddlebag of the Harley - ready for a trip tommorrow as I type this!Pay for good stuff like this - it's worth it!

I liked it - easy and quick read.  The author seems to be just like anyone which is what resonates so well I am sure.On a cold, icy Saturday in February when our group ride was cancelled, it was perfect to read!

not sure what's going on...my wife lives on this stuff...the local healthfood stores are out or running out....they seem to think it's not gonna be made anymore???  My wife has had every script known for allergies and this stuff really helps her.anyway - we got her a bottle - may order a couple more (expiration dates taken into account) and we'll see from there....

EDIT after a month:  lowered to 3 stars, I do like it.  If I didn't have the original Smart Carry experiences to compare it to...I might not do this.  The angle of the top of the pouch is too straight.  With the Smart Carry the top of the pouch angles down to the outside allowing for an easier draw.  Again...nothing terrible here...just not as good to me...I'm gonna go back to the Smart Carry for this particular set up as well.I've used the real Smart Carry's for close to 10 years - I think I have 6 or 7 for different set ups, wanted one in a hurry and this was Prime and I got to add next day shipping so I had it in a day - very nice, that.It's good.  The double elastic on the sides is interesting, that is one area that does get stretched out some in Charlie's original design...but usually long after I have duct-taped together the pouch after years of use.The pouch itself seems to be sewn in a similar fashion to the original as well.The biggest difference is funny - the Velcro is exactly backwards! lol.  I am constantly trying to put the wrong end across my back first!  Well, it has been around a decade 'going the other way' so I expect that's just my own habit.I've got a tub of holsters like so many.  I like IWB and OWB when my dress allows...but I have NEVER found a more comfortable way to carry - with the weight centered over both hips - as a Smart Carry, or of course, this one here.  It's really great for me in dress slacks (I wear fully pleated) and my shirt and tie during the work week.  It's fantastic with sweat pants and basketball shorts - which is 90% of what I wear when I'm not at work and not on the Harley or in a range training environment.Good deal, I'm happy with it, and love that Amazon got it to me so quick to meet the need I had.

still a lot of recipes in here that use a surprisingly large amount of ingredients...but it's easy enough to make some deletions and use it as a guide to make some simple 'blasts' - which is what my wife and I do.
since I am US Army Veteran....and have that decal on my rear window...I love this decal on the other side.they compliment each other well.....and I love the message!

I give these away for gifts - everyone loves them from clients to family.Last time the power went out we used these all over the house as candles - standing on the tail section - they made wonderful lights in several rooms.Also just the right 'power' to carry at night when walking.  My wife and I have a pit of paracord on two of these...and we put them on our wrists/hands and carry them "on" 100% of the time when we walk after dark.  Light enough for cars to see the moving lights...and yet we aren't night blinded ourselves.

maybe it's me...but when I put a Glock 19 mag in this...it's pretty bulky. Even seems bulkier than in a vertical holster somehow...also, there is a lot of exposed "loop" part of the Velcro...and I'd think over time that will collect of fuzz, strings, etc...I could be wrong though...but...it's in the holster box now...and if I need this option, it's there...and that's the best part - it gives you options.

life changing?  well...not yet...but that's probably our fault.basically we are both really turned off by any of the 'blasts' that end up green - ugh!  but...we have a lot of mixes we found in books and online...and are experimenting for ourselves too...and we are making a lot of blue, purple, red and orange mixes...lol.  We found the key is to add just a little of the green stuff - but hey, we are eating it now, so that's cool!  It's also cool how it makes nuts, ginger root, and even the skins of fruits and veggies just disappear in the mixes - totally makes them disappear!as always...exercise and portion control in your meals is the key to weight loss...but this machine makes some tasty mixes.

it's not like it's a hard job to cut up an apple anyway...but this little gizmo is pretty cool.we got a Nutribullet recently (Amazon Prime, of course! lol) and it's really easy and quick to jab this thing in...pull out the core...and throw the apple in the blender.

Interesting combination of a well-done romantic costume drama with fascinating details of 17th century creation of gardens at King Louis XIV's Versailles Palace. Both historical romance fans and avid gardeners will be happy with this film.

This movie had excellent costumes, settings, and representations of Elizabethan England. I found no errors in the dances, the court terminology or other details. The acting was great.But wonderful actors and exquisitely detailed scenes could not compensate for a wholly unbelievable plot. I was prepared for the plot to be a bit contrarian -- it suggests that the Earl of Oxford, not Shakespeare, wrote Shakespeare's plays.However, many of the characters are shown behaving in ways that contradict the historical records of that era -- and we have pretty good records of Elizabethan England. I don't mind some stretching of history, but I object to outright rewrites that have no historical foundation at all.

Wonderful movie about the triangular relationship among 18th century German poet Schiller, his wife and his sister-in-law. Explores compassionately, but unsparingly, what happens when idealistic young people violate the social norms of their era.The movie also examines the optimistic expectations Schiller and his friends had from their Enlightenment outlook, and how those ideas went badly wrong during the French Revolution.Plus, aficionados of 18th century costume, manners and furniture will love this movie's attention to detail.

I have mixed feelings about the Common English Bible (CEB).It is definitely a new translation of the Bible -- there is little or no attempt to keep the King James Version phrasing  and structure that lingers in the NRSV (New Revised Standard Version) and the NIV (New International Version).I'm an Episcopalian -- one of the denominations that sponsored the CEB -- so I should have been delighted with this Bible, but I've found equally good and bad aspects of it.As someone who has read the KJV (King James Version), the RSV (Revised Standard Version), the NEB (New English Bible), the NRSV and the NIV, I found the CEB refreshing and gripping. I enjoy reading it.It appears to be intended as a theologically liberal rival to the popular conservative NIV in the niche for Bibles that are written in plain English for people who find more traditional language versions too difficult to read.I wish it were possible to give the CEB several ratings, rather than one rating. Regarding its goal of being easier to read, I'd give it a "5." It is written in a 7th grade vocabulary, according to some sources. It is not noticeably liberal, so conservative readers might also find it interesting.It is even easier to read than the NIV. It has a direct, forceful language that makes it ideal for teens, adults who are baffled by traditional Biblical language, new converts and people who want to read a Bible without having to stop and look up complex terms every fifteen minutes.But the CEB does have its problems, which is why I rated it as a "3."It's problems are especially apparent in the Psalms. The Psalms were used as liturgical poetry, and the CEB makes them sound -- well -- whiny and overly slangy, like posts on a totally self-absorbed teen's blog.I'm skeptical that the priests in the Second Temple chanted psalms that said: "So kings, wise up!" (CEB translation of Psalm 2:10)Another "howler" -- as I call these slang insertions -- Psalm 22:18: "They divvy up my garments" -- "divvy up"???? -- please, that's just bad grammar. Also, I think 99 percent of most English language speakers would have understood: "divide up" just as well.Some of my other favorite "howlers:"Judges 11:3: "Worthless men gathered around Jepthah and became his posse." His "posse"? Are you kidding me? I think "gang" would have been far better -- that's the word that the NIV uses.The trouble with choices like "divvy' and "posse" is not only their questionable grammar, but the fact that as slang terms, they'll go out of fashion in ten to twenty years.Then there is the well-publicized "howler" of changing references to Christ as the "Son of Man," to the "the Human One." While that usage would fit translations of the Prophet Ezekiel, who is addressed in older translations as "son of Man," by Christ's era, the title "Son of Man" had come to be understood as a Messianic title with very specific connotations. It think it is inaccurate to translate it as "the Human One."Another "super howler" -- 1 John 3:9: "Those born from God don't practice sin because God's DNA remains in them.""God's DNA"? Folks, DNA -- the DNA molecule -- the genetic blueprint in each of our cells that programs the kind of person we are from conception -- wasn't discovered in its true complexity until 1953. No way the first Epistle of John used that term or any term like it. The usual translation is "God's seed" -- or if you want to get really, really down to earth, perhaps "God's sperm"? But not "God's DNA."The CEB also drops many traditional theological terms, such as "repentance" -- they are changed to phrases that may mean the same thing, but read awkwardly. For example "repentance" is translated as: "changing their hearts and lives." These changes will, as several media reviews noted, cut new Bible readers off from thousands of years of accepted theological terms such as "repentance" and "sanctification."On the other hand, the CEB does seem to translate the Pauline epistles more accurately than other Bibles I have read, following recent scholarship on what Paul was actually saying in the original Greek.. That is impressive.My final "takeaway" --  I will continue to rely on the NRSV as my primary Bible.and consult the CEB and  the NIV versions as my secondary choices.

This is a book raises serious questions about current Christian views of what constitutes orthodox theology, by examining how early Christians actually saw Jesus and what Jesus and St. Paul were calling for.The authors make a good case -- relying on modern scholarship -- that early Christians believed that Jesus died as a martyr for their new faith -- not as a sacrificial atonement -- and that Christians would receive salvation not only through faith in Jesus as the Son of God and the resurrected Christ, but also through the doing of good works imitating their founding martyr's life..They argue that  the Catholic and Protestant beliefs current today among many Christians -- the fall of man, salvation only through faith, Christ's sacrificial atonement on the cross -- and related doctrines -- are based on medieval Catholic and Reformation Protestant theologians having access only to poor translations of the Bible and being so separated in time and space from the original Christians that the theologians frequently misinterpreted key Gospel and Pauline texts.The authors are respectful of both conservative and liberal views of the Bible and theology, and base themselves solidly on modern scholarship that has learned far more about correct translations of Greek and Hebrew terms, and also far more about the Jewish and Greek cultures of Christ's era than was accessible to medieval Catholic and Reformation Protestant theologians.It's hard to summarize such a rich book in a few words. I would suggest that you read it yourself and see what you think. I'm still mulling over their arguments in my mind. I'm not entirely convinced that generations of Christian theologians are completely wrong, but the book is making me re-examine my beliefs.

Excellent movie! I had expected that since it was filmed in the 1950s, it might be a very simplistic Bible epic. But it is apparently based on both the Biblical mention of Barabbas and a novel by a mid-20th century Swedish novelist, so it has great depth.Barabbas is depicted as a complex person, who endures great suffering on his way to determining his true path. The early Christians are not portrayed very favorably -- surprisingly, they somehow blame him for surviving when Jesus was executed, even though Barabbas had nothing to do with Pontius Pilate's decision to spare Barabbas..A movie that raises a lot of complex questions, it will intrigue both Christians and non-Christians.
Fascinating.

I enjoyed "Dearest Rogue" by Elizabeth Hoyt. I've been tired for some time of historical romances where both the hero and heroine are not only physically gorgeous, but have absolutely no disabilities or chronic health problems. It has been a real relief to see historical romances starting to portray their protagonists in a more realistic manner.I was very intrigued by the idea of a blind heroine and a hero who has to use a cane, and wondered how the author would handle it. I had never read any of Elizabeth Hoyt's books before.Lady Phoebe Batten is a vivacious, pretty 21-year old who has struggled with growing loss of sight since age 12, knowing it must culminate in blindness. Captain James Trevillion, age 33,  has lost his position in the British cavalry because one of his legs -- broken on two separate occasions -- is so weakened that he must rely on a cane to walk.Trevillion now works as Phoebe's bodyguard, hired by her protective brother. Initially, Phoebe strongly resents his watchfulness and her curtailed freedoms. The conflict between Phoebe and James slowly evolves into a friendship and then a romance, as each learns more about the other's vulnerabilities and both of them struggle for independence and the respect of others in an 18th century society that regarded people with disabilities as inferior.The author carefully supplies details about how Phoebe and James "work around" their disabilities against a slowly darkening background of attempts to kidnap Phoebe, sponsored by an unknown villain.I reread the book when I finished it the first time, because I had missed some details in my haste to follow the adventures of this appealing couple. This book goes on my shelf of "keepers."

I'm very fond of the novel "Quo Vadis," a story of the early Christians in ancient Rome, so I decided to watch a movie based on the novel.In some ways the movie is actually an improvement on the novel -- the aristocratic hero, Marcus Vinicius, was so young in the original novel, that I was always surprised by his power, ruthlessness and self-confidence. In the movie, Marcus is depicted as a Roman general and an older man by actor Robert Taylor, so his authoritarian ways are more understandable.Deborah Kerr is lovely as the Christian heroine, Lygia. She and the actor Robert Taylor have some screen chemistry, but the romance develops too quickly -- they go from antagonism to passionate love very rapidly. In the novel, the romance develops more slowly, and is more convincing.The movie's spectacle aspects are terrific -- a lot of money was spent to hire hundreds of extras and costume them and the lead actors properly. The movie works hard to show many different aspects of Roman life, just as the novel did.Anyone who enjoyed the novel will definitely enjoy the movie.

In 1935, a young Italian-Brazilian teenager code-named "Elza Fernandes" (real name: Elvira Cupello Calonio) is the mistress of a handsome, charming, older man code-named "Miranda," the leader of Brazil's underground Communist party. Miranda (real name: Antonio Maciel Bonfim) promises to marry Elza, but the couple are caught up in a failed Communist revolt that leads to Miranda's imprisonment and Elza's murder.The novel is not a "who done it?" but a "why done it?" -- why did the revolt fail? Was Miranda a hero or a secret traitor? Why was Elza, an innocent and uneducated adolescent, targeted for assassination?The novel alternates between italicized sections of historical research done by the book's author and fictional reconstructions of key events told by an aging Brazilian ex-Communist to a bewildered, much younger Brazilian freelance writer decades later. This format is rather awkward. I learned a great deal about Brazilian history and politics, as well as being drawn in by the tragic romantic triangle at the heart of the fictional part of the book.I recommend this book for people interested in Brazilian history and politics, Communism, and totalitarian societies.

"Moon Over Tangier" is part of a series by Janice Law in which gay artist Francis Bacon -- historically famous for his disturbing paintings and wild sex life -- functions as the investigator of various crimes.While these novels are fiction -- the real Francis Bacon had a difficult enough life without serving as a crime investigator -- the author works within what is known of Bacon's life to write plausible stories about a bemused Bacon's role in solving fairly nasty crimes.In "Moon Over Tangier," Bacon has come to Morocco in the early 1950's to revive a failing love affair with a pianist who was a Royal Air Force hero during WWII and has now become an alcoholic. The couple's assistance to a badly-beaten Arab they find lying in the streets of Tangier entangles Bacon with spy networks, a corrupt art dealer specializing in fake Picassos, and parties hosting the upper-crust of Tangier's colonial society.Bacon soon finds himself painting fake Picassos, encountering dead bodies, and slowly grasping the full extent of the social abyss he has fallen into.A delightful story with a witty and resourceful hero, that is sure to appeal to gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender readers, detective fiction enthusiasts, art historians, admirers of Francis Bacon's paintings, and anyone who likes a well-written crime mystery.

I found "The Horse Healer" wholly absorbing, from the moment I opened the first page, all the way to end, 539 pages later. It portrays the turmoil of 13th century Spain (around the year 1200) from the perspective of a young man studying to become a veterinarian, who is dragged into the numerous wars between the Christian kingdoms of northern Spain and the Islamic empire that occupies southern Spain.Diego de Malagon is the teenage son of a widowed innkeeper, who is abruptly orphaned during a surprise raid by the Imesebelen, the fanatical African bodyguard troops of the Arab caliph. The Imesebelen also murder Diego's sister, kidnap his two other sisters, and kill two knights who attempted to defend his family. The only family Diego has left is his Arabian mare, Sabba.Diego becomes a refugee, and then the apprentice of a Muslim veterinarian in Toldeo. He learns that many Muslims and Jews have been forced to flee the Islamic empire after its takeover by a fanatical Islamic sect called the Almohads, who view everyone who doesn't follow their brand of Islam as heretics.The rest of the novel follows Diego as he travels through Spain acquiring medical, literary and military skills. He is inexorably drawn into a network of knights, kings and churchmen trying to defeat the Almohads before the extremists conquer all of Spain and destroy every other culture within the country.Diego is the type of hero a reader can cheer for -- fair-minded, passionately interested in learning new things and struggling not to be sucked into the rampant misconduct he sees all around him.The novel also has many appealing secondary characters, such as Diego's love interests, friends, co-workers and enemies. It's a very "you are there" type novel that tries to be fair to all of the groups struggling to survive in medieval Spain. The novel does not romanticize the Middle Ages -- monasteries, knightly orders, churchmen -- even the feared and hated Imesebelen -- are shown as human beings with flaws and virtues.Since the novel is set during a period of extended warfare in the Middle Ages, be prepared for a lot of violence, some rapes (though not graphically described), and repeated scenes of fear and suspicion.This novel will interest medievalists, people interested in Spanish history, especially the "Reconquista" period, students of the Crusades, veterinarians, military history fans, and anyone interested in a story filled with adventure.

This is a documentary about the Scottish Covenanters, a group of 17th century Scottish Presbyterians, who led a war against King Charles I, an Anglican, were persecuted by his sons, Charles II and James II, died in large numbers for their faith, and were finally vindicated when James II was overthrown, and a new king and queen made Presbyterianism the national religion of Scotland again.The documentary presents the Covenanters as brave and noble martyrs for freedom of speech and religion.That's very one-sided. The Covenanters were also religious fanatics, and one of their goals was to wipe out other forms of religion in Scotland. While their initial revolt was sparked by Charles I's ill-advised attempt to introduce an Episcopalian prayer book within the staunchly Scottish Presbyterian national church, it rapidly spread into a complete overthrow of his authority, and a determination to stop Episcopalian and Roman Catholic Scots from practicing their faiths.I was shocked when the documentary went directly from the Covenanters' revolt to their persecution by King Charles II. The documentary literally skipped over a 12-year period in which the Covenanters ruled Scotland with an iron and bigoted fist.  One modern historian has compared them to the Taliban of Afghanistan.I felt that the documentary should have given some air time to the Covenanters' faults, as well as their undoubted virtues.The documentary also has positive aspects. It presented the good side of the Covenanters in detail, and contains many interesting facts about their struggle to practice their faith free of government constraints. Viewers should just understand that it is interesting, but it will not present the Covenanters in their entire human complexity.

Queen Christina of Sweden baffled her own 17th century society and continues to puzzle modern people. She was in some respects a 21st century woman who was somehow born in the wrong era.She became queen of Sweden as a child, but resigned from her job in her late 20s and left Sweden for Rome to pursue artistic, spiritual, and cultural interests in an urban Roman Catholic environment she found more supportive than Sweden's rigid  and mostly rural Lutheran society. Abdicating a throne to pursue "personal interests" was almost unheard of.The mysteries surrounding her began with her birth, when the midwives declared her to be a boy, only to discover that she was a girl. As a child, Christina looked female, but had mostly interests that were considered "male" in her era -- riding, hunting, weapons, military history, and Greek and Roman soldier heroes. She preferred wearing men's clothes. She was bisexual and openly fell in love with both women and men, causing immense scandal.Her favorite companions were men who were "bad boys" -- dissolute adventurers who were soldiers and priests "gone wrong." Her other preferred companions were pretty and virtuous women. Once in Rome, she developed additional interests, converting to Catholicism and becoming a passionate art patron, while continuing to live a private life outside of the social and moral boundaries of her era.In this entertaining and well-researched biography, Veronica Buckley explores Christina's adventurous life, both her victories and her defeats. Christina's wretched childhood and adult opposition to the status quo severely strained her emotional resources, leading to some dreadful tragedies and much self-centered behavior. Buckley presents Christina's dramatic journey in a fair and balanced manner. I was fascinated, and read every page.I recommend this novel for royalty fans, feminists, members of the GLBT (gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender) community, Swedish history enthusiasts, students interested in 17th century intellectual history, Christians interested in the 17th century conflicts between the Protestant Reformation and the Roman Catholic Counter-Reformation, and people interested in Baroque era art, music, sculpture, literature and science.

"Forty Days of Celebration" was apparently originally intended as an Advent season (the 40 days before Christmas) scripture journal. It has been adapted to be used at any time in the Christian seasonal calendar -- it still contains references to Christmas, but they are integrated with other Bible themes.The daily format of the journal consists of three or four passages from the Old and New Testaments, plus the author's "Meditation" of about a paragraph on the themes of the Bible passages. The author, a United Methodist Church minister, has chosen these themes: hope, peace, love and joy in Jesus Christ.Ideally, the reader of this journal is supposed to write his or her reflections on the Bible passages and the author's "Meditation" just below the "Meditation." Unfortunately, there's only room for about three or four sentences in normal handwriting under the "Meditation" each day.  Any new edition of the book should increase the amount of space for reader reflections.The "Meditations" mostly -- not always -- show a liberal theology. Here's a sample from page 68: "God, the faithful Creator, wants justice for the people of the earth, especially those without food, freedom, power or health. . . . How can we responsibly use power to respond  to those on the margins of society?" This "Meditation" puzzled me, as it seems to assume that all readers of the journal are well-off middle-class folks.Other "Meditations" suggest a more traditional theology -- here's an example from p. 95: "Joseph and Mary trust that nothing is impossible for God, even in the face of profound unanswered questions. . . . How do you respond to the angel's affirmation that 'nothing is impossible for God?' "The journal chooses heartening scripture passages.  However, the Bible version used for the journal may not please everyone -- it is the Common English Bible. This is a new translation adopted (among other translations) by the United Methodists, the Episcopal Church and several other mainline denominations -- the Episcopal Church mostly uses the New Revised Standard Version in worship, but the Common English Bible is apparently gaining popularity among the Methodists.I did not like the Common English Bible translations of many passages at all, even though the Biblical passages the author chose were good. Everyone who complained that the NIV (New International Version of the Bible) was too folksy, too contemporary, and had accuracy problems -- heck, the Common English Bible translation makes the NIV look as formal the King James Bible. The CEB Bible passages made me reluctant to use the journal, but your views may differ from mine.

I was very interested in the title of Leonard Sweet's new book, "Me and We: God's New Social Gospel." I knew only a little about the Social Gospel movement of the early 20th century and was curious to see what kind of new social gospel Sweet might suggest.Unfortunately, the book reads like a rough draft. For example, the author tries to define at pages 15 through 19 what his version of a new social gospel would be and fails. The explanation contains several complex metaphors that simply don't work together. I couldn't figure out what he was talking about, and I'm a fairly intelligent reader with a strong background in theology and several other fields.Transitions between paragraphs in the book are often non-existent. Thought A in one paragraph is suddenly dropped in a following paragraph for an unrelated Thought B in the following paragraph.The book frequently lapses into academic jargon. Here is one sample: "However, any attempt, on whatever end of the theological spectrum, to move Christianity toward a mere propositional matrix rather than a relational mesh is a regressive, not a progressive, act." (p. 10) Huh? Please explain?This book also has factual errors. For example, the author claims that "individualism and depression (melancholia) developed simultaneously in Western culture from 1600 upwards." (p. 21) That's just not true -- there are Roman Empire era medical treatises mentioning depression and discussing treatments for it.On p. 19 the author suggests that St. Paul described the Christians of Laodicea as lukewarm in their faith. Actually it was John of Patmos in the book of Revelations. (According to the last chapter of the Epistle to the Colossians, Paul wrote a letter to the Laodiceans at one time, but it appears to have been lost.)I finally gave up around page 30.

"Five Years in Heaven: The Unlikely Friendship That Answered Life's Greatest Questions" is a memoir of a friendship between an 87-year-old nun and a 31-year-old writer and publicist whose career crash had driven him back to his small, rural hometown.I'm an Anglo-Catholic Episcopalian, so I was looking forward to see what kind of spiritual advice Sister Augustine would give John Schlimm. While their friendship seems to have been wonderful for both of them -- she encouraged him to successfully restart his career and he publicized her ceramics, making her regionally famous -- the spiritual and psychological advice she gave him didn't seem that unusual, didn't answer life's greatest questions -- though it did answer many of Schlimm's questions -- and frankly was a little on the dull side.For example, pages and pages are devoted to Sister Augustine's cats -- I like cats, but briefer descriptions would have worked better.Sister Augustine and Schlimm shared common interests as artists and teachers, but reading their conversations is like sitting in a room where you can hear a happily-married couple discussing their daily concerns in the next room -- whose turn is it to mow the lawn? The couple is clearly very happy and deeply intertwined in their shared interests, but their conversations may not have much relevance for the listener's life.

The 20something narrator of "His Own Man" initially seems to have an idyllic life ahead of him. The son of a Brazilian diplomat, he has followed in his father's footsteps, securing a job in Brazil's prestigious Ministry of Foreign Affairs, housed in the luxurious Itamaraty Palace in Rio de Janeiro. He can look forward to a financially and socially rewarding career.But In December 1968, Brazil is ruled by a relatively new right-wing military dictatorship, that uses increasingly brutal tactics to keep a restive population under control. The narrator confides his misgivings about the regime to his idol, a slightly older 20something coworker named Max, who embodies everything the narrator admires -- good looks, humor, tact, vast literary knowledge, aristocratic ancestry, moderate political views and an ability to manage their bosses.But is Max a Brazilian patriot who is simply biding his time at Itamaraty until democracy is restored in Brazil? Or is Max an agent of the dictatorship, cloaking his real allegiance behind smooth manners, social charm and rationalizations? Or is Max's real allegiance only to himself?As the narrator takes one path -- accepting diplomatic assignments that take him out of Brazil and away from contact with the dictatorship -- Max plunges into intrigue. The narrator slowly pieces together the truth about his adored friend over a period of several decades, from documents, interviews with Max's ex-wife and other diplomats, and gradually reaches a chilling conclusion.The novel is a story of friendship, betrayal and the tough choices faced by decent people living under a tyranny. It is written in an elegant, but lucid style, and chapters alternate between the narrator's life as a young man and his life as an older diplomat, as he gradually learns the full extent of his friend's actual activities and intentions.Readers interested in Portuguese language literature, Brazilian history, the story of how the CIA and U.S. politicians supported the military dictatorships of Brazil, Chile, Uruguay and Argentina in the late 20th century, fans of spy novels, and people who like psychological thrillers will enjoy this book.The nearest comparison to this book that I have ever read was Klaus Mann's "Mephisto," a fictionalized biography of how Klaus Mann's brother-in-law, an actor, preserved his career by joining the Nazis.

"Clara" describes the life of a young woman and her family -- Austrians, actually, not Germans -- during the 1930s and 1940s, showing how even "good Germans/Austrians" were gradually pulled into Nazi-dominated societies.When the novel opens in October 1932, Clara is a graduate student in Vienna, studying for her doctorate. She plans to become a college professor who teaches literature or philosophy, and is studying with heavyweights like Sigmund Freud and Martin Heidegger. She is in love with an Austrian cavalry officer, who is also a skilled horse trainer. One of her friends is a Jew, and she thinks she might vote for the Social Democrats.But when the Great Depression of the 1930s capsizes Austria's economy, causing bank collapses, unemployment and massive homelessness, thousands of Austrians join the Communists or the Nazis, kill each other in street battles, and engage in violent attempts to overthrow the ineffective Austrian republic.Clara and her lover are not Nazis, but they find themselves slowly, inexorably drawn into Nazi connections through a foolish young family member. This family member dies for the Nazi cause, resulting in a legal catastrophe for the rest of her lover's family and establishing a permanent and unwelcome benevolent interest in Clara and her lover on the part of the Nazi authorities who eventually take over Austria.The novel alternates between Clara's life as a student and as a German army wife and her life as an elderly writer and translator in the early 21st century. The Nazi takeover of Austria and World War II are seen through the eyes of Clara and her civilian female friends as they struggle to survive a crazy totalitarian dictatorship and frequent bombings by the Allies.I enjoyed the novel and found it engrossing reading. My only criticism was the transitions in the narrative from young Clara's experiences to older Clara's current life were not always clearly indicated. The author may wish to put notations such as "Vienna, 1932" or "St. Tollden, 2004" at the heads of chapters or transitions within chapters. I could follow the transitions, but had to keep alert for them.This novel will interest WWII history buffs, military history enthusiasts, Austrian history students, and people who like a romantic heroine with courage and determination.

The title of "Coffee, Tea and Holy Water: One Woman's Journey to Experience Christianity Around the Globe" misleadingly suggests that the author looked at the full spectrum of Christian churches in several cultures.In actuality, the book is a short, light weight account of a young American Protestant evangelical's visits to a few different Protestant evangelical churches and missionary medical clinics in five countries -- Brazil, Wales, Tanzania, China and Honduras. It might better have been titled "Impressions of A Few Protestant Evangelical Churches and Medical Clinics in Five Different Cultures."The author, raised in a large, strongly fundamentalist Protestant church in the Deep South, just ignores churches that are different from her own. For example, she visits Brazil, which she explains is the largest Roman Catholic country in the world, but her sole visit to a Catholic site is the large statute of Jesus Christ on a mountain overlooking Rio.Instead of then discussing a bit about the Roman Catholic church's successes and failures in Brazil, and perhaps how these contrast with those of the Protestant evangelical churches she visited, she devotes time to learning about the spiritist culture of Brazil, a mixture of Christianity, vodoo, Satanism and other faiths and contrasting that faith with the merits of evangelical Protestant Christianity.The author has a number of perceptive things to say about the interactions of national cultures and Protestant evangelical Christianity in each country that she visits. But I did get very tired of visiting one cinder block church after another, crammed with praise bands. I'm an Episcopalian, and I found her avoidance of all forms of Christianity except her own puzzling and disturbing.At first I thought that she ignored other forms of Christianity besides her own because of time and money limits during her travels, but she had time to visit a national wildlife park in Tanzania and get a massage in China, so she obviously did have time to visit churches with theologies and liturgies different from her own.

I read "How Jews Became Germans" with great interest, because I am a member of an interfaith family.Professor Hertz originally wrote an account of Jewish women intellectuals in 18th and 19th century Berlin who ran influential salons that hosted Christians and Jews discussing new ideas. She then wrote this book as a follow-up, and used data collected by the Nazis in the 1930s from centuries-old church archives on intermarried Jews and their descendants.The result reads almost like a novel. It is a fascinating portrait of many Jews who converted to Christianity for a wide variety of reasons, especially the Berlin salon hostesses and the Jewish male and female intellectuals who were their salon guests, friends and relatives.Some Jews converted to Christianity because they could not advance in their professions unless they changed religions. Other Jews were sincerely tired of the narrow and legalistic form of Orthodox Judaism which was the only form of Judaism available in Germany at that time, and found Christianity more appealing theologically and emotionally.Still other Jewish converts to Christianity changed religions so they could legally marry Christian lovers. Yet a fourth group of converts were committed German nationalists who felt that as long as they remained Jews, they could never become truly part of their beloved Germany.The author deals with her subjects, many of them eminent intellectuals of the early 19th century, with patience and kindness, showing that two factors finally slowed the large number of Jewish conversions into Christianity by the mid-19th century.First, Reform Judaism developed, which offered Jews discontented with Orthodox Judaism a form of Jewish practice that they found more appealing. Second, many of the laws and social customs making conversion to Christianity mandatory for participation in various professions, intermarriage, and in other settings gradually relaxed, allowing Jews to keep their ethnic and religious identities as Jews while participating more fully in Christian German society as German Jews.For anyone interested in why Jews opt to remain Jews or leave Judaism for Christianity, this is a well-written study that is still relevant to today's Jewish and Christian communities worldwide.

This novel will appeal to many audiences -- military history buffs, fans of the Kipling and Conan Doyle novels, people interested in a well-researched and truthful picture of colonial India, and just about anyone interested in a mystery and thriller set in the chaotic India of 1837.Ensign William Avery is stuck in cholera-plagued, miserably hot Calcutta in 1837. His India is not the India of later Victorian era -- "the Raj" -- ruled directly and relatively efficiently by British government bureaucrats -- but the pre-Victorian India, run by the British East India Company, a trading corporation that has morphed into a corrupt, greedy and ruthless semi-government of large parts of India.Avery, a 20something soldier from a gentry family, is ordered by "the Company" to accompany a man he loathes -- Jeremiah Blake, an older, mysterious former captain from the slums of London -- on a secret mission to find a missing famous poet and writer, Xavier Mountstuart -- a Byronic figure with so many enemies that he may already be dead. One rumor says he's been kidnapped by "Thuggee" ritual killers, who strangle their victims.Blake and Avery journey hundreds of miles searching for Mountstuart, slowly getting to know each other. Blake has a combination of Sherlock Holmes' detective skills and a grasp of Indian languages and customs straight out of Kipling's "Kim" -- but as he and Avery gradually immerse themselves in Indian and European groups, Avery learns that the real "strangler vine" of India may not be the Thuggees or other Indian rebels, but the ruthless, arrogant British "Company" and its growing tyranny over the Indians.The novel is filled with both adventures and interesting panoramas of India in that era -- unlike Kipling's and other 19th century novels, the earliest British colonial military, traders and civilians are shown in this novel both in their strengths and weaknesses, and "equal time" is given to the culture, feelings and history of the Indians themselves.While there are plenty of adventures in the novel, there are many thoughtful passages and characters' reflections about the two clashing cultures that make this novel much more interesting than the average "adventure novel in British India."

"As Good As Dead," is a "dramedy" (comedy plus drama) about how a youthful act of betrayal by one student of a close friend at the famed Iowa Writers' Workshop in the late 1980s has unexpected and terrible consequences extending years into the future, affecting both students' careers, marriages, finances, reputations and children.Charlotte Price appears beautiful and brilliant, but behind the facade she feels deeply shy and insecure, growing up with hostile working class parents who believe her interest in writing and books is foolish. Charlotte hides her insecurity as best she can, including silencing it with alcohol and drugs.Her roommate, Esme Cole, has everything Charlotte does not -- self-confidence, comfort with her own good looks, indulgent upper-class parents, the ability to drink and drug without becoming addicted, and the capacity to make friends with anyone.Esme and Charlotte form a close, but highly volatile friendship, in which Charlotte gradually fears her life is being taken over by a "frenemy," a friend who is a rival. Esme belittles Charlotte in many ways, and Charlotte finally engages in a secret act of betrayal that will put both of their lives off-track for many years.The novel travels back and forth between Charlotte's and Esme's past in Iowa, and their present -- twenty years later -- in Tuscon, where both women live with their husbands, but in dramatically different circumstances. I read the novel twice -- once because I was desperate to find out how the complex story ended -- and a second time to relish the meticulously-depicted hothouse world of academia that that the author ably portrays.This is a well-constructed, gripping novel about the deviousness of the human heart.

I enjoyed Justin Taylor's "Flings," a collection of short stories, and yet I had some reservations when I finished.His language is vivid, and readers are plunged into the situations -- a young man fleeing a commitment-minded girlfriend, for example -- very quickly.Taylor also has much wit, describing an estranged Baby Boomer Jewish father as developing "a bombastic pride in his heritage -- this despite a near-perfect indifference to its teachings or practice." His Millenial daughter, seeking reconciliation with him, reflects, "This was common among Jewish men in their late middle age, Danielle thought; she had many friends whose fathers had done the same."But the people inhabiting the short stories are sometimes unpleasant and self-destructive -- not to mention dishonest and lacking in self-perception -- it was hard to care about what happened to them. Only a few of them grow and learn from their experiences.

I've already read this book twice, I enjoyed it so much!When I began this book, I knew only a little about Josephine. I had always assumed that she was a trivial personality, the cast-off first wife of a great man.Kate Williams' biography of the Empress Josephine showed me that I was greatly mistaken. In an account as gripping as a novel, and filled with direct quotes from Josephine's letters to Napoleon and other people, Williams traces the evolution of a badly-educated, naive girl from the French colonial aristocracy of Martinique to the astute wife of the most powerful man in Europe.Ms. Williams shows how Josephine overcame laziness, promiscuity, two difficult marriages, sexual exploitation by powerful men, an addiction to making money by shady means, and many other character flaws to remake herself as the faithful, kindly and charitable consort of an egotistic ruler.I was astonished to learn that Josephine was a self-taught and learned botanist with an in-depth understanding of many plant and animal species. She was also an astute art collector. Many other evidences of her innate intelligence were concealed behind her facade of a dutiful, shopaholic wife.I was also surprised to learn that Napoleon's and Josephine's sexual relationship continued to the end of their marriage, despite their infidelities. They were evidently deeply in love, and Napoleon's divorce of Josephine was one of his most costly mistakes.

"Vatican Waltz" will interest Roman Catholic readers, other Christians with an interest in the lives of the saints and Roman Catholic mysticism, and both friends and opponents of the Roman Catholic Church.The novel initially appears to be asking: what are saints like as young children and young adults? Cynthia Piantedosi is raised by her widowed Italian Catholic father and maternal grandmother in a rough working class town near Boston.In early childhood shy, studious, pious Cynthia begins experiencing slight blackouts in which she is granted visions and messages from God. She discusses these occurrences primarily with two politically liberal priests, devoting hours to prayer, but otherwise living an ordinary life.So far, her life story sounds very much like that of many of Roman Catholic saints when they were children and young adults.Gradually, her story darkens -- a vocal, powerful, secretive right-wing opposition group within the Church seems involved in the death of one of the two priests she trusts.Cynthia goes to nursing school, and her visions shift. She believes that she is being commanded to become a Roman Catholic priest. But there is a problem -- the Roman Catholic Church doesn't ordain women.Nevertheless, Cynthia, previously an obedient daughter of the Church, begins visiting one senior priest after another, urging that the ordination of women be allowed. She finally travels to Italy, to argue her case with the higher Catholic authorities.At this point I became a little skeptical. The story is set around 2005 -- wouldn't Cynthia first have gotten in touch with other women who have tried to be ordained as Catholic priests? -- it would be easy, thanks to the internet -- before pestering senior priests, bishops and cardinals?The novel's descriptions of Italy -- the churches, the food, the people, the scenery -- are wonderful and felt very authentic. Its descriptions of Cynthia's encounters with the Catholic hierarchy took me into the realm of conspiracy theorists.Despite her humble and polite manner, and her youth -- the Church hierarchy treats Cynthia as if she were dangerous to the Church -- and there are growing hints that the right-wing Catholic extremist group which may have killed one of her priests is targeting her for elimination.This kind of plot might work in a novel set in General Pinochet's dictatorship of Chile (1970's) or in a novel set in the 16th century Spain of the Holy Inquisition -- but if a fanatical group within the Catholic church in 2005 was killing American and Italian Catholics who convincingly advocated for change in the Church, the streets of both countries would have been strewn with dead Catholic clergy and lay people.Nevertheless, the author builds up a compellingly menacing atmosphere around the pious and kindly young woman. I thought, OK, this novel is actually asking: how would a secret society of fanatical Roman Catholics react to a future saint who advocated for change within the Church?But the author abruptly changes the direction of the novel a third time. Cynthia discovers her real Christian spiritual mission -- a mission that is far more unlikely than becoming a female Roman Catholic priest.The ending is subtly foreshadowed in various parts of the novel, but I still found it unbelievable. The novel is very interesting and well-written, but it's as if the author couldn't decide whether he was writing about the development of a saint, the formation of conspiracies within the Church to stop changes, or an even more improbable spiritual mission to revive the Church.I found the novel enjoyable, but sometimes exasperating.

I enjoyed "An American Duchess" -- it is a well-researched novel set in the post-World War I era in England. The plot is fairly standard. Starchy, highly educated, financially ruined English nobleman, deeply wounded physically and emotionally by crushing war experiences and losses, falls in love with young, assertive, poorly educated American woman whose wealth conceals her own difficult past and war losses.Can this relationship work?Nigel is a war hero, but since his return from WWI, he wants peace and quiet on his estate, and a complete return to his lost traditional English past -- nothing will change in his life or on his family estate.Zoe, daughter of a self-made American millionaire, has reacted to her own tragedies by embracing everything modern in the Roaring Twenties -- she manages her own fortune, pilots airplanes and drives fast motor cars, in an era when few women did. She also attends innumerable wild parties.While the complex plot threads about the relationship between the hero and heroine were engrossing, and their numerous culture clashes were realistically portrayed, I wasn't convinced that they could have overcome the huge gaps in their differing life experiences to forge a lasting marriage. But as a glimpse into the Roaring Twenties and the impact of WWI on previously staid Edwardian high society in England and America, the novel provided me with many laugh out loud moments.

"The Word Exchange" plunges the reader into an alternative history in which a popular smart phone's electronic virus not only ruins computers and other smart phones, but starts infecting, injuring and killing people.The novel is long and slow-paced, but filled with rich and intricate details about the chilling impact of the virus on a world that is heavily dependent on electronic communications.Anana Johnson and her friend and co-worker, Bart, are 20somethings working for a New York-based non-profit producing a major dictionary. When Anana's father, president of the non-profit, abruptly disappears, and Anana and Bart develop severe flu symptoms and sometimes speak gibberish, they begin a race to locate Anana's father before the "word flu" claims their lives. They believe that Anana's father may hold clues to the sinister origin and possible treatments of the "word flu."But how can they conduct this search when they must avoid using the internet and smart phones, and even aging cell phones are starting to show signs of infection? Older and safer sources of knowledge and communication -- libraries, fax machines, printed newspapers and magazines, land line telephones, letters sent by postal mail service, paper posters and brochures, and pneumatic tubes -- have nearly all vanished thanks to the growth of the internet, leaving Anana and Bart with few places to turn to for help.I enjoyed the novel tremendously. I had only two complaints.I did think that the author, in an effort to realistically depict her two dictionary geek protagonists, used way too many obscure words and concepts in some sections of the novel. For example, I didn't need a full page lecture on the philosopher Hegel, complete with German terms for his ideas, to see that the two protagonists are intelligent.I also found the depictions of infected people speaking gibberish to be too detailed, as whole paragraphs from conversations, journals and emails were pockmarked with nonsense words where one or two such paragraphs would have sufficed.But the novel's plot interested me, and its depiction of the immense societal damage caused by such a virus, as seen through Anana's and Bart's eyes, was cleverly drawn.

I enjoy ghost stories. I also enjoy ghost stories with romantic and historical elements. A love affair between an architecture professor who buys an old house and the ghost of a beautiful young woman who has haunted the house since 1840 seemed right up my alley.Unfortunately, I couldn't suspend disbelief at a number of plot elements. First, the woman ghost has been haunting this house since 1840. She is understandably desperate to understand why she has not passed over into the afterlife. But not once -- as far as I could tell -- does she pray, mention God or check out a Bible.This is a financially well-off woman from 1840, an era in which religion saturated America. Consulting the beliefs typical of her era would have been her first step after finding herself stranded as a ghost following her death. She is, after all, able to read modern newspapers, magazines, and watch television. There would undoubtedly have been a Bible in the house at the time of her death.Second, her modern lover doesn't really check out any spiritual resources on his own. Instead, claiming to be writing a novel, he pays one of his graduate students to do some internet research on psychics for him. No professor who wanted to keep his new interest in ghosts absolutely secret would entrust such research to a graduate student, students being notoriously gossipy.Finally, the ghost expert that the professor finds in the modern era to help him and his beloved seems to have very peculiar credentials. There are many modern psychics and ghost experts with far better credentials and training. The expert's advice sounded utterly implausible, even for a ghost story, where I am normally willing to allow major implausibilities.These doubts killed off the story for me.

Ever since World War II ended in 1945, memoirs, biographies and other books documenting the lives of artists and writers who lived in Paris during the Roaring Twenties, the Depression and World War II have poured out of publishing companies.Biographies and memoirs about Hemingway, Gertrude Stein, Picasso, Henry Miller, and dozens of other famous expatriate and French artists and writers have appeared. Simultaneously, numerous accounts of the French resistance groups who attacked the Germans during the German occupation of France have been issued, along with histories of the Holocaust, and disturbing revelations of how French collaborators with the Nazis handed over many of France's Jews and other French citizens to the Germans.Novelist Francine Prose has written a comic novel which basically makes fun of all of these genres. The novel is composed of alternating selections from fictitious letters, memoirs and biographical materials written by a photographer, a writer, the owner of a gay and lesbian night club, a French Resistance leader, an arrogant French aristocrat, and a famous French female athlete (apparently lesbian and transgender) who goes from being a patriot to a traitor who works for the Gestapo.These characters are all given fictitious names, but they are clearly based on historical figures. For example, sex-obsessed American writer Lionel Maine is clearly based on American writer Henry Miller, while Lou Villars, the French athlete turned traitor, shares much of her life history with real life pioneering French athlete Violette Morris, who ultimately turned traitor.I laughed out loud repeatedly as the author caught perfectly the "voice" in which many memoirs, autobiographies and biographies of this era are written -- the boasting and name dropping of the male artists and writers about their sexual conquests and creative work, the contentious French Resistance memoir where the Resistance leader appears mostly concerned with herself, the aristocrat who serves in the Resistance, but indignantly rejects accusations that she scooped up art work from desperate artists at bargain prices after the German invasion -- she wants the reader to understand that she did the artists a favor!More poignant is the fictional biography of Lou Villars, who starts out as a good person, but is slowly embittered by constant mistreatment because she is lesbian/transgender to the point that she starts viewing other French people as her enemies and the Germans as her friends. Even this tragedy has elements of humor -- Francine Prose gives Villars a neurotic, academic feminist, politically correct biographer, clearly deeply troubled, who keeps interrupting Villars' sad story to complain about her own much less interesting life and emotional problems.My only complaint about the novel is that the real life Violette Morris was about 20 years older than Lou Villars and had an established record as an Olympics participant and as a heroic messenger and nurse for the French armed forces during World War I. Her treason was rooted in being booted out of her athletic world by a French society uncomfortable with her lifestyle, an act she experienced -- correctly -- as an extreme betrayal.She was a brilliant athlete and intelligent, not that I'm excusing her terrible crimes. Whereas the "Lou Villars" of the novel is depicted as not very bright, not nearly as high-achieving in sports as Morris, and -- while understandably bitter at how she was treated as a lesbian/transgender person -- not high profile enough and not intelligent enough, in my opinion, to have been sought out as a potential key spy and Gestapo torturer by the Germans.But other than that complaint, I thoroughly enjoyed the rogues gallery Prose presents.

"The Visitors" is a beautifully-written book with fascinating characters, but it is damaged by its attempt to combine two novels in one book. I enjoyed reading it, but it did take time.The first novel describes the deadly intrigues, love affairs, politics, lies and secrets that swirled around the discovery of Pharaoh Tutankhamun's treasure-filled gravesite in Egypt in 1922. The story is narrated as seen through the eyes of Lucy Fox-Payne, an 11-year-old who has been sent to Egypt with a chaperone to recover from typhoid fever. While the insights of Lucy and two of her girl friends seem way too sophisticated for elementary school age children -- they talk like educated teenagers who are about 18 years old -- their children's eye view of the unscrupulous adults around them makes for an absorbing and well-researched novel.Unfortunately, the author moves back and forth between the Egyptian novel and a second novel -- the story of how Lucy survives a very dysfunctional childhood and adolescence to become a successful writer. Upon Lucy's return from her first trip to Egypt, her widowed father, a selfish and bullying Cambridge don, marries an equally selfish and bullying young woman on the fringes of the Bloomsbury Circle of writers and artists. Lucy's experiences trying to survive a home that her father shares with her stepmother's lesbian lover -- a selfish Bloomsbury Circle artist -- and Lucy's unhappy first marriage to a selfish Bloomsbury Circle poet -- are very interesting, but appear to be a second novel that co-exists uneasily with the first one.The two novels are tied together by chapters depicting Lucy in her early nineties, looking back on the first 30 years of her life. While I enjoyed "The Visitors," readers will need patience to absorb the book's 509 pages and the shifts in viewpoint between Egypt in the 1920s, England in the 1930's and 1940's, and modern London around the year 2000. I was willing to put in the time required to read the book because I'm a passionate Anglophile, and the book offers lovely descriptions of England and its changing social classes in various eras.Both novels feel somewhat incomplete, as if they were conjoined (Siamese) twins, sharing the same book cover, but each needing more room. The author might have done better to write two separate novels.

"One Night in Winter," set in 1945 during World War II and the Stalinist dictatorship of Russia, describes what happens when a romantic triangle among some high school students, ending in a murder-suicide, has catastrophic consequences for the teens who befriended the dead students and their parents.For the dead teens are not ordinary youth -- they are the children of vicious dictator Joseph Stalin's courtiers -- his top bureaucrats and generals -- in a closed totalitarian society where any crime, love affair or other unusual behavior among the Communist Party elite's children can be used to ruin them and their parents, leading to job loss and imprisonment.I was captured by the plight of the surviving students and their parents from the moment the book opened, and raced through it to see what would become of them as they were imprisoned and questioned by Stalin's secret police.This is the rare adult novel that might appeal to a young adult demographic as well.Author Simon Sebag Montefiore is a respected biographer of mid-20th century Russian dictator, Joseph Stalin. Since completing his two volume biography of Stalin, Montefiore has written two novels about the private lives of Stalin's elite -- "Sashenka" and "One Night in Winter." They are stand-alone novels -- you do not need to read both to enjoy "One Night in Winter" -- but "One Night in Winter" does contain a major character from "Sashenka," whose fate is finally revealed.

"The Secret Life of Violet Grant" is actually composed of two novels. One novel describes the early life of Violet Grant, a woman physicist working in Oxford and Berlin in 1914, and her disappearance with her alleged lover after the murder of her husband, an older, famous scientist.The second novel is a social comedy set in 1960s New York City, the era of the "Mad Men" television series. The heroine is the great-niece of Violet Grant, a young college graduate from the same upper-crust family her great-aunt belonged to. The great-niece, Vivian, receives a mysterious suitcase from Europe with tantalizing clues about what happened to her great-aunt, and resolves to write a magazine article about what happened.The novel set in 1914 is very good. The author clearly shows the tenuous position of women in the sciences, in an era where such an occupation was thought unladylike. Violet struggles to carry out her research and win the esteem of colleagues who include the young Albert Einstein. She also struggles with a growing attraction to a handsome young British officer, who is very different from her much older, philandering, selfish husband.The novel set in 1960s Manhattan is a failure. While the author's historical research is as meticulous as in the 1914 novel, the characters seem to have escaped from a failed sitcom. They speak in snappy one liners, even in very serious situations, and are shallow as puddles.The ending of the novel, where the author attempts to merge characters from both novels, is quite unrealistic. I was skeptical that people "on the lam" from a murder accusation could have hidden in plain sight for decades.I would give the 1914 novel a "4" and the 1960s novel a "2." That works out to a "3." I wish the author had simply written a longer 1914 novel.

"The Woman Who Would Be King" is a compelling biography of an ancient Egyptian princess, who through sheer talent, personality, and political shrewdness, became king -- not queen -- of Egypt and had a highly successful reign.Princess Hatshepsut faced disaster as a teenager. As the high priestess of Egypt's most powerful god, and the chief wife of her younger half-brother, Pharaoh Thutmose II, her future seemed assured, but Thutmose II was sickly and died young. Hatshepsut became regent for Thutmose II's infant son by another wife, but it seemed doubtful that a teenage girl and a baby king could keep their dynasty on the throne.Would Hatshepsut and her infant stepson be replaced by an adult male relative? Or would Egypt descend into chaos, as competing family members intrigued and fought for the throne?How Hatshepsut seized power, eventually proclaiming herself king and co-ruler with her stepson, maintained her shaky dynasty on the throne, and served as a competent and efficient ruler, is a story that author Kara Cooney narrates almost like a novel. Piecing together temple inscriptions, papyrus texts, and tomb pictures, Cooney manages to convincingly recreate Hatshepsut's life in an era where women might serve as regents, but almost never became rulers themselves.I found the book engrossing. In the course of following Hatshepsut's life, I learned about Egyptian temple rituals, Hatshepsut's use of her position as high priestess to enhance her support among the powerful clergy, and many other aspects of ancient Egypt.

The conventional view of the 1950s is that the entire decade was a major setback for women's rights in the U.S. and Britain, as millions of women were swept out of their jobs in offices and factories at the end of World War II and dispatched to lives as housewives.British writer Rachel Cooke decided to highlight the other side -- women who managed to maintain and expand their careers in the face of intense societal pressure against employed women.In "Her Brilliant Career," a gossipy and thoroughly enjoyable set of essays, Cooke explores the careers and love lives of ten British women who were well-known in their careers in the 1950s -- a film director, a food writer, an architect, an archaeologist and others -- but who have since been eclipsed in public awareness by the coverage of the more flamboyant and numerous career women of the feminist 1960s and 1970s.The career women she selected are a fascinating group -- they range from Margery Fish, a brilliant elderly gardening writer, whose career did not exist until after the death of her loved, but domineering husband, to the stable lesbian triangle of journalist Nancy Spain, publisher Joan Laurie and race car driver Sheila van Damm.The author writes with humor, sympathy, tolerance and kindness of her ten career women, who subverted 1950s norms to lead lives better suited to 2014.

I read every page of this novel and was sorry when it ended. It is a richly detailed portrait of a civil war in Spain between 1701 and 1714 and how fighting in that civil war alters the life and perceptions of a previously carefree and amoral rogue."Victus" begins as a typical 18th century novel of a rogue's humorous misadventures. It is narrated by Marti Zuviria, who -- when the novel opens -- is a teenage military engineering student in France. His primary interest in life -- other than drawing maps of fortifications -- is his teacher's pretty, red-headed daughter.Marti is a foreign student -- he is a citizen of Catalonia, a rebellious province of Spain -- but in an era in which military engineers habitually sell themselves to the highest royal bidders, his Catalan background has little meaning. Both Marti and his tutors assume that he will enter the French military service.Marti's career plans suffer a serious setback when his mentor dies. He then travels with a French army to Spain to support a French prince's claim to the vacant Spanish throne. On arrival, he discovers that his province, Catalonia, and its capital city, Barcelona, are supporting a rival Austrian prince's claim to the Spanish throne, because they fear the French prince will end Catalonia's ancient constitution and liberties.Marti is thrown into a maelstrom of conflicting loyalties, clashing love affairs, and encounters with two battling armies where no one can be trusted because so many people have changed sides repeatedly. But when he returns to Barcelona and becomes part of its military defense team, he is forced to make moral choices that will scar him -- physically and emotionally -- for the rest of his life.Eventually, he must decide whether he can save his beloved Barcelona -- and his loved ones trapped within the city -- by betraying the city during a terrible siege.I turned each page right to the end of the book, wondering what choices Marti would make.The author's research on the era is extensive -- the reader meets characters from every walk of life and follows their struggles to survive in the middle of a civil war. The novel reminded me of many American Civil War novels.This novel will interest military history fans, 18th century history buffs and anyone who likes an intense tale of moral conflicts and exciting adventure.

England lost an entire generation of young men during World War I, leaving desolate families all over the United Kingdom. Thousands more veterans returned with permanent mental and physical injuries. Anna Hope's "Wake" describes three women from families whose men died or were injured during the war, and how they finally come to terms with their losses and try to start new lives.Novelist Hope has done very thorough research on World War I and the beginning of the Jazz Age afterwards. The stories of the women feel authentic -- Ada continuously sees the ghost of her only son in the streets of her village; Evelyn has become an embittered spinster after losing her fiance; and Hettie helps support a brother reduced to nearly permanent silence by "shell shock."The book is well-written and flows easily. There are no jarring anachronisms. Even the advertising is taken directly from newspapers and magazines of the era.My only problem with the book is that it is very dark. If you are having a depressing week, wait to read it until things in your life improve. While each woman slowly works out positive adaptations to the dreadful losses she has experienced, the mercifully brief accounts of the Western front during WWI are stomach-turning.

Will Baker, a 25-year-old American WASP from a "Mayflower" families background, smarting from the defeat of John Kerry's 2004 presidential campaign, in which he was a senior worker, and disturbed by the recent death of his estranged drug addict father, abruptly drops his New York City girl friend, apartment and political life to spend a year getting a master's degree in English at Oxford University.The novel is beautifully written. The descriptions of Oxford, London and England are truly lyrical, and the reader feels transported to the country, admiring everything from boat races between Cambridge and Oxford to the light as the sun sets on the university's lawns.But beautiful writing in this type of "young adult grows up" novel is like a frame for a painting -- it's bad if the frame is more beautiful than the painting, and that seems to be the case with this novel. The beautiful writing frames a story that is not very interesting.The expectation for this type of college novel is that the heroes or the anti-heroes will make significant discoveries about themselves and exhibit some type of growth.Will simply doesn't do that. He finds replacement girl friends, has an unhappy love affair, behaves badly to his girl friends, half-heartedly considers pursuing a Ph.D. in English -- he has a trust fund -- and the end of the novel finds him little different than when it began.His friends at Oxford, evenly divided between the children of very wealthy families and middle class scholarship students, are actually much more interesting than Will, and do make some changes in their lives, but there is nothing especially interesting about most of their lives or personal changes.The novel also has structural problems that an editor could fix -- Will behaves badly to women, but the family problems in which his behavior is rooted are not explained until the book is two-thirds over. There's also an entire chapter about Will visiting an old friend in Paris that does nothing to advance the plot and could easily have been cut.There are many references to political events within the Kerry campaign and the war in Afghanistan which may render the novel incomprehensible to younger readers within another generation. These references needed to be removed or gracefully explained within the novel itself.I read the novel once, but would not reread it.

The depravity of the Renaissance era is no secret -- within the last few decades at least two gaudy television series about one of the most evil Popes, Alexander Borgia and his equally icky illegitimate children, have been produced. Many novels and much poetry about Renaissance Italy, filled to the brim with murder and adultery, have been published in the last three centuries.But historian Alexander Lee believes that modern admirers of the art and literature of the Renaissance tend to romanticize the era, seeing only the beautiful altarpieces and statues like Michelangelo's David in isolation from the horrific society which produced them. He argues that moderns tend to believe that people who paid for and produced art and poetry that beautiful couldn't have been bigots,  murderers and rapists, and must instead be close to moderns in their thinking. Lee's book tries to break up the sanitized picture of the Renaissance as a wonderful time of intellectual discovery and show its seamy underside.In "The Ugly Renaissance," Lee describes how many of the altarpieces, with pictures of the art patrons painted into them, were given to churches to alleviate the guilt that the wealthy merchants, violent soldiers and corrupt church officials felt about their sin-stained lives. Huge libraries were built by merchants fearing that they would spend eternity in purgatory or hell for ruthless acts of usury.Lee writes in an engaging style as he takes the reader on tours of breathtaking crimes and atrocities, followed by commissions to Raphael or Fra Lippi that were intended as atonement for the crimes. Even readers who are not convinced that the public has a sanitized view of Renaissance Italy can learn much from this fascinating book.

"Sight Reading" is the story of thirty years in the lives of four people -- three musicians and an art entrepreneur -- who meet as young people in 1987, form complex romantic and professional entanglements -- and eventually emerge into middle age in the year 2007 with unresolved problems that must be addressed.The writing is excellent. The author's grasp of the insular world of classical music education, training and job searches is authentic.
